meaningMnemonic: If someone tries to dig up private dirt on you, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the past. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.
additionalM:
Hints
Keep your private dirt in the past. It's better for everyone.
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading きょ, we'll use "Little Kyoto." This will differentiate きょ from きょう, which is regular-sized Kyoto. Get it? You decide to bury all this private dirt from your past in Little Kyoto (きょ). That stuff is from when you were just a little 子 (こ) and you don't like to think about it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine physically, literally burying your past 子 self. If you hide it in Little Kyoto, no one will ever be able to dig it up.

meaningMnemonic: The plate kanji and the plate are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.
additionalM:
Hints
If you know your radicals, you know your kanji too.
readingMnemonic: The person washing all the dishes was named Sarah (さら). She was named that because of her large head, which was shaped like Sarah Jessica Parker’s head (very big).
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine someone with a huge head, washing dishes. When I say huge, I mean huge. She turns towards you with her big head and says “Hi, I’m Sarah” and you see her name tag, which also says Sarah. She is Sarah, the dish washer. The plates she holds up next to her head pale in comparison, even though they're the biggest pieces.

meaningMnemonic: Slide some dirt on your legs so you can feel like you're from a previous time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the feeling of dirt on your legs. Now think back to the previous day. The previous year. The previous century.
readingMnemonic: As you sit there, pretending you're in a previous time you see a centaur (せん)! That's right! Centaurs are from wayyyy in the past.
additionalR:
Hints
Centaurs were definitely real in the past. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. They're just afraid of the truth.

meaningMnemonic: The radical for red and the kanji for red are the same thing!
additionalM:
Hints
What a lucky ducky - as long as you know your radicals, you'll know this kanji's meaning as well!
readingMnemonic: Think of Fozzie Bear. He says "Wakka wakka wakka" a lot. Now, think of an evil, red (and I mean totally red) Fozzie Bear. He drops the "w" and just says "Aka Aka Aka," because he's totally evil.
additionalR:
Hints
You'll have to think of him as really, really red, though. Like, a glowing, searing kind of red. Red enough for you to associate red with this evil Fozzie Bear. If you do, then you'll be good to go (as long as you know his catch phrase as well).

meaningMnemonic: The leader is next to the tree. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, resting.
additionalM:
Hints
The best thing to do with a tree is rest under it. Picture the leader resting under the tree with his eyes half closed.
readingMnemonic: As he rests, he suddenly gets hungry and pulls a cucumber (きゅう) off the tree and bites into it. A good rest isn't complete without some crunchy tree cucumbers.
additionalR:
Hints
Don't email me saying cucumbers don't grow on trees. Cucumber trees exist. Look them up and then rest easy knowing I'd never lie to you.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a cross in your mouth, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say you say humbly.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself with a cross in your mouth, saying all kinds of humble things. "Oh no, I'm not that good." "Oh no, my mustache doesn't look that great."
readingMnemonic: When you think of saying humble things, think of the humblest man in the world. His name is Moe (もう).
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this character in your head. If it helps, you can take a Moe you already know of (Simpsons, perhaps?) and pretend he's extremely humble - ridiculously so. Just remember to make it crazy so you can remember it better.

meaningMnemonic: The radical see and the kanji see are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you do, you'll know a lot of kanji as well, almost magically!
readingMnemonic: You see something. It's walking towards you, but you need to see better. When the person comes close, you realize "That person is me (み)!"
additionalR:
Hints
The struggling to see bit is pretty important - make sure that you slowly see a little better and better as the person comes closer, but it's difficult the whole time (struggles are good for memory). Then, it starts to become more and more clear, and you start saying "that can't be me. No way it's me..." When the person comes up to you (the person, being you) you learn about parallel universes and other fabulous things. Still, the whole time you can't stop thinking about how "this person looks just like me... no, this person is me!"

meaningMnemonic: The shellfish radical and the shellfish kanji are the same! It can be just the shell part too.
additionalM:
Hints
Shellfish are shellfish, you know?
readingMnemonic: To get some shellfish, all you have to do is hop in your kayak (かい) and get some. Shellfish live in the water.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine rowing your kayak out into the ocean to collect shellfish. Imagine the color and shape of the kayak. Feel the spray of the salt water and the taste of some fresh shellfish, right out of the ocean.

meaningMnemonic: The stone radical and stone kanji are the same thing!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals and therefore know your kanji. It's just that simple.
readingMnemonic: You throw a stone through a window... and, now you can see something very sexy (せき).
additionalR:
Hints
Whoops, maybe you shouldn't throw stones through windows or you'll see people's sexy times.

meaningMnemonic: The leader for the ceremony can't come so you need a substitute to replace them ASAP!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the leader of the ceremony out back, unsure of what period or age they're in, while the substitute leader walks in and stares at them in shock.
readingMnemonic: The substitute leader is wearing the wrong color clothes, so you have to dye (だい) them, like they did in the olden ages.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're out back with the original leader and the substitute leader, trying to dye the color of this stupid shirt to match that one.

meaningMnemonic: Always remember to give umbrellas to the spirits to show your thanks. The next time you're walking by a shrine and you see a statue dedicated to a spirit, leave your umbrella open to protect it. This is the best way you can show your thanks for life, food, shelter, and all that good, good stuff.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a spirit shrine with an umbrella protecting it from the heavy rain. "Thanks for everything," you say softly.
readingMnemonic: After you say thanks to a spirit, sometimes you'll get a gift back. You look down. There is a ray (れい) gun by your feet. Huh. Maybe you should show your thanks to the ray gun spirit more often.
additionalR:
Hints
Thanks for the new ray gun, spirit!

meaningMnemonic: The thread radical and thread are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.
readingMnemonic: You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat (いと) the thread.
additionalR:
Hints
Think about how it tastes. Think about how it feels in your throat. Let it get caught on your teeth and around your tongue. It's a weird feeling having thread in your mouth, and you want to use that weird feeling to remember you're going to eat it.

meaningMnemonic: When you see both a rice paddy and a street in the same place, you have the makings of a whole town!
additionalM:
Hints
Think about it, a single farm wouldn't need a whole street. Just paths would do. There is a street next to this rice paddy, so there must be other people, which makes this a town.
readingMnemonic: You go to visit this nice little town. But then, there she is... Every time you walk down the street, the street-woman Mrs. Chou (ちょう) arrives to ruin your day.
additionalR:
Hints
Remember imagining Mrs. Chou in great detail in level 2? Time for some of that work to come to fruition. Imagine Mrs. Chou walking down the street of the town towards you, ready to make your day bad. She breaks things as she walks towards you, then knocks you down for walking around in her town. She says, "Wherever there's a street, you'll find Mrs. Chou." Then spits on your back as she walks away.

meaningMnemonic: Under his roof, the king stares into a drop of water containing his greatest treasure. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the treasure reflected in the drop of water. It's marvelous!
readingMnemonic: All of this treasure is kept in the king's home (ほう). He can't let other people see how much treasure he has, or they'll get mad, or worse(!) ask him to share some with his people. Yuck. The treasure stays at home.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture his home from the outside. It looks like a normal, small castle. But then you walk in and it's a treasure trove of... well, treasure!

meaningMnemonic: Someone’s taking measurements of the trees… Why is someone taking measurements of trees? These people are planning to take the trees and cut them down to make their village.
additionalM:
Hints
There is a whole group of people out there who are measuring these trees. Imagine them asking each other “do you think this will be a good tree for our village center?” and other people nodding in agreement or disagreement as they measure.
readingMnemonic: They take all the wood back to where they're building their village and once they construct the village center they paint a mural (むら) on the side of it. The mural is of the forest where they got the tree from so they remember the building's origins.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the mural on the side of this newly constructed village center. So many trees! Visualize the whole process as the tree becomes a building as you gaze and reflect on the message of the mural.

meaningMnemonic: The world radical and the world kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: generation.
additionalM:
Hints
It's all these generational differences that make the world go 'round!
readingMnemonic: It's your job to protect the world and every generation with your special saber (せい). It was given to you to uphold correctness, and you'll pass it on to the next generation when it's time. Then they'll watch out for the world when you're gone.
additionalR:
Hints
Hold the saber up high and pledge to protect the world for all of the generations to come! Then swish it around and make buzzing sounds with your mouth.

meaningMnemonic: The cow part of this kanji is slightly altered, but I think you can see where it is. The gun looks just fine, though. Think back to a fake memory you have living on the farm. You have your gun, and you gotta use it on a cow (ruh roh). Once a year on New Year's, you have to go out and shoot one of the cows. It's only a yearly shooting, though, so at least there's that respite.
additionalM:
Hints
You'll have to imagine yourself doing this to remember the meaning of the kanji. Focus on the thought that "okay... it's only once a year... I only have to do this once a year..."
readingMnemonic: It is New Years, though, so when you bring the dead cow back home, it’s time to celebrate. Using the cow’s organs and bones, you and your siblings construct a nendoroid (ねん). Nendoroids are Japanese toys - little plastic figurines (Google it if need be). You make a little cow nendoroid holding a gun. How cute.
additionalR:
Hints
How funny that you use dead cow parts to make a miniature cow holding a gun much like the one you murdered earlier. Imagine yourself playing with this nendoroid as you think about how weird it was to make a cow nendoroid out of a dead cow.

meaningMnemonic: Your task in prison is to bend things into different angles and then put them in the corner. No one will tell you why you're doing this, but you get a couple cents an hour to do it, so you aren't going to complain.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself sitting in a corner, bending pieces of metal and scrap to fit the angle of that corner.
readingMnemonic: To get the angle right you find that you have to cock (かく) your head to the side a lot. After cocking your head at weird angles so much you also start to hear cocks crowing in your head. Cock-co-cock-co-caww!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine cocking your head to different angles and hearing cocks crow every time you do. Prison isn't as fun as you thought it would be. Manual labor and loud chickens aren't what you expected.

meaningMnemonic: The axe radical and the axe kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the bread loaf counter, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you've gone back in time a good hundred years, and you're trying to count loaves of bread after each swing of your axe. Axes and bread loaves will become intertwined in your brain.
readingMnemonic: You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an axe to be a bread loaf counter for the King (きん) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being stuck using an axe on bread while the King of England glares down at you, munching and spilling crumbs everywhere.

meaningMnemonic: The blue radical and the blue kanji are exactly the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Don't feel blue, you should know this kanji automagically!
readingMnemonic: You've been feeling really blue. Mostly because your skin, hair, and eyes have all turned blue. The Shougun (しょう) found out and now he's back. He places his hand on your shoulder and then points at your saber (せい). It's blue too! You aren't alone!
additionalR:
Hints
You aren't sure how you or the saber turned blue, but you're pretty sure the Shougun had something to do with it. At least you match now, I guess.

meaningMnemonic: The leader has a book all about the human body. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking down at your body and thinking, huh, I wonder what all that junk is? Oh well, I'm sure the leader has it all figured out in that book of his.
readingMnemonic: The leader's body book also taught him about something very body specific: how to tie a tie (たい). You can't have a tie on your body, no no. Those are for the leader and his smart body.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the leader, reading a book, putting a tie on his body. Look around at you and your family and your neighbors. You don't know what your body meat-bags do and you don't know how to tie a tie. Womp womp.

meaningMnemonic: The color radical and color are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Color me pink! This kanji's super easy if you know your radicals.
readingMnemonic: You already have color on the mind because you know the meaning of this kanji, so think of something colorful about yourself. Imagine your ear (いろ) being a weird color... green, purple, red, whatever. Just make it really bright and standing out.
additionalR:
Hints
You can even have someone ask you about your ear... "Is your ear okay? I think it's the color blue..."

meaningMnemonic: There's rice spread out all over the ground. This will cause the Predator to come because he loves kome (rice). Then once he's gone, the next Predator will come to eat.
additionalM:
Hints
Also imagine everyone else coming to the rice next. When rice spills, people come from all around to line up and grab a handful of it to take home. Who's next? Come forward!
readingMnemonic: When they come, though, everyone is disappointed. It turns out it's rye (らい) grains, and rye grains taste terrible. Yuck.
additionalR:
Hints
If you love rye grains, on the other hand, imagine everyone being really happy that they came to get the rice. They're so lucky it's rye!

meaningMnemonic: Plant a spirit in the dirt before you start your company and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a young man way back in old-timey history times burying the spirit of one of his ancestors in the dirt. Now watch as an old-timey time lapse plays out in front of your eyes and a company is born!
readingMnemonic: Where did you learn about this method of company growing? From a shaman (しゃ), of course. Shamans aren't just spouting nonsense, they know what they're talking about. And spirits are right up their shaman alley.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine going to a shaman and having them tell you that for your company to be successful you need to bury a spirit in the dirt so it can help the company grow. You should probably listen.

meaningMnemonic: There's a triceratops and a wolverine. What are they doing together? You'd think they'd fight, but they took their battle to another venue... they're competing in a game show! One of them answers a question, and the host says, "Success! You're correct!"
additionalM:
Hints
Feel free to think through several questions and answers, but make sure they're all right, because that's what we're focusing on. Also make sure to focus on the triceratops and the wolverine themselves. You want to make sure that when you see these two radicals you automatically know they're playing in a game show, not doing anything else, like fighting or racing or something.
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember the reading とう, we use the Japanese city Tokyo. The last question in the game show match is the following: "What is the capital of Japan." The triceratops and the wolverine scream the correct answer at the same time: とうきょう!
additionalR:
Hints
Wow, that was a pretty easy answer to get right. とうきょう is what pretty much everyone would guess, and they'd be correct.

meaningMnemonic: The treasures are in the mouth where there’s ice. How cryptic! You want to find the treasure, that’s for sure (treasure is great!). It is somewhere where there is ice, so maybe the arctic? What you are looking at is a diagram which will guide you there.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at a diagram or map – and it has pictures of treasure in an area where ice is. This is where you will find the mystical treasure. This diagram will show the way. You're so excited that you found this map!
readingMnemonic: What will you do when you find these treasures that are shown on the diagram? Well, you get there, and you find that the treasure is actually a wooly mammoth! What will you do with this wooly mammoth? You grab it and put it in your zoo (ず).
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine dragging a wooly mammoth back with you to the town or city you live in, then throwing it in a zoo to be kept. People are quite amazed by this mystical creature you’ve found, though, which is pretty cool.

meaningMnemonic: You see some windows... you have a gun. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... every single one of them.
additionalM:
Hints
Make a point to make sure you get every one, and don't miss any of them. Actually search around in your imagination for any more windows, because you want to stress it's important you hit every one.
readingMnemonic: Now that every single window is broken you feel pretty stupid because a bunch of mice (まい) come pouring in through them. You've made a way for them to get into your house. That wasn't smart.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you need to shoot every one of the mice that came through those broken windows. You can't let any survive. You have to get every last one out of here!!

meaningMnemonic: The feather radical and feather are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Have you been studying your radicals? If so, this'll be easy!
readingMnemonic: All these feathers. You're a bird man / woman, and you're getting ready to fly. Just as you're about to take off, someone dumps you with honey はね and you're all goopy, unable to go anywhere.
additionalR:
Hints
Taste the honey, feel it all over your feathers. Go ahead and plummet towards the ground (because you were jumping off a building to fly when someone doused you with honey). At least it's a tasty way to go, no?

meaningMnemonic: You have a tree and another tree. You basically have yourself a forest!
additionalM:
Hints
Follow the logic of this one and you should be okay.
readingMnemonic: So, now you have this forest and you want to cut it down (so much money!). But, you don't have any tools, only your hands. You think... I've done karate for a while, so I can probably chop it down that way. You get in a chopping stance, then do your battle cry and hit: "HAYA ... .SHI******!"
additionalR:
Hints
Obviously that didn't work well - you'll want to focus on your battle cry plus indecent swearing right afterwards to remember this reading.

meaningMnemonic: The go radical and the go kanji are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
If you know your radicals well enough (and you do), you'll know this kanji.
readingMnemonic: "Go!" someone is telling you. "Go! Go! Go!" That person is こういち. He is holding his finger out, and pointing at your WaniKani reviews. "Go! Go!" Then, he over-enunciates the word "go" by saying "GYOU!!" (ぎょう).
additionalR:
Hints
You try to go another direction, and he just yells and points louder: "GO!"

meaningMnemonic: The gold radical and the gold kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Just know your radicals and you'll be golden, so to speak.
readingMnemonic: The most gold in the land belongs to the King (きん) of England. In fact, you've never actually met someone with gold, it all goes straight to the King whenever someone finds some. You just have a few pennies to work with.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the King on a huge pile of gold. Gold coins, gold candelabras, gold ponies. He's laughing and pointing at all of it while making very strong eye contact with you.

meaningMnemonic: You plant your flowers in the light of the sun in the shape of a cross, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with grass. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of how disappointed you are. You wanted a beautiful cross of flowers, and now you just have a big overgrown patch of thick grass. It isn't even pretty green grass, it's a little brown and damaged from the sun.
readingMnemonic: The grass on top is brown and burned from the sun, so you need to take a cool saw (くさ) and hack the tops off. The saw is actually physically cool to the touch, to help heal the grass' sunburned bits. It just happens to look cool too.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine using your cool saw to saw off the heads of all of this grass. You made the cross pretty big, so there is a ton of grass to get through. The sun is beating down on you and the grass too, which isn't making it any easier.

meaningMnemonic: The village you always think of first is your hometown.
additionalM:
Hints
Why would you ever talk about the village where someone else was born? Answer: you wouldn't. Everything is always about you.
readingMnemonic: You go back to your hometown in a saddle (さと). You can't take a car or a train there, it's really in the middle of nowhere. So you have to ride a horse, so break out that old saddle and go visit your parents.
additionalR:
Hints
Close your eyes and imagine being on a saddle, heading back to your hometown right now. Feel your butt and legs chafing. Eh... that's not such a great memory, now that you think about it.

meaningMnemonic: The leader's key is the key that makes all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the leader taking his key to open up a safe that has a button to make other keys for the underlings. No key is as great as this key, though.
readingMnemonic: You make a key for an underling, and he looks at it disapprovingly (even though you're their leader!). He simply says, "this key sucks" (さく) and then walks off. How could this be?
additionalR:
Hints
Feel angry about this. Maybe you should kick your foot in his mouth and make him suck on that.
Also keep in mind that there's another reading that pops up too that's さ. It's similar to さく, though, and I think you'll be able to learn both the readings via the vocabulary.

meaningMnemonic: How many evenings are there? There are many.
additionalM:
Hints
If you accidentally think "a lot" or something similar, that's okay too. It's the basic meaning that counts, and all these things are pretty close, though eventually you want to get to the point where you know that this kanji does in fact mean many.
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading た we use the word "Taco"
additionalR:
Hints
The tacos pelt you and knock you off your feet. Hard shell, soft shell, meat, lettuce, tomatoes, cheese... it's terrible. And there are so many of them, flying from the sky to drown you in tacos. This is absolutely absurd (and you should think that too, so you remember the reading).

meaningMnemonic: The meat radical and meat are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Study those radicals, and perhaps we'll eat some meat tonight.
readingMnemonic: You know there's people-eating going on here, with this kanji. So, when you think of this meat, you'll have to think about whose meat it is. In this case, it's Nick's (にく) meat.
additionalR:
Hints
Do you know someone named Nick you can imagine? There's celebrities too, if you don't have someone. Someone like Nick Cage would do the trick.

meaningMnemonic: The meet radical and the meet kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
readingMnemonic: What better way to meet new people than to start kayaking (かい)! Get into your kayak and just float out into the water. You'll eventually bump into someone else in a kayak and boom, you're meeting someone new!
additionalR:
Hints
"I met my soulmate in a kayak," said Koichi.

meaningMnemonic: You put a lid on your father. But, he won't taste good alone, so you mix in some other ingredients. They mingle inside the pot with him.
additionalM:
Hints
This may seem traumatic, but actually your father is surprisingly into it. Imagine him mixed in with all kinds of other things. It's important to note that this kanji is about things being mixed in, not so much about the action of mixing. That's another kanji.
readingMnemonic: With a mix of your father and other ingredients mingling in your cooking pot, you lift up the lid... your father pops up. Your father is こういち. He stares back at you with a big smile.
additionalR:
Hints
"I love mixing in with potatoes and tomatoes," your father こういち states. "Turn up that temperature. I like to mingle with a bit more tingle."

meaningMnemonic: Someone on a scooter has an axe, and they're getting near to you really fast! Oh no, they're so close now, you need to get out of here!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a scooter coming toward you in the dark. You see the gleam of the axe as it looms nearer and nearer.
readingMnemonic: As they draw near, you recognize who is riding the scooter: the King (きん) of England! Behind him, a bunch of his guards also on scooters and wielding axes appear and move close to you.
additionalR:
Hints
The King is now so near to you his nose and mustache are tickling your face. He's holding the axe high above his head and saying, "I can get as close to you as I want and you can't stop me because I'm the King. I can get sooooo close. Look, I'm not touching you though!"

meaningMnemonic: Who's someone who's just a mouth with legs? That's your know-it-all older brother, who won't shut up about anything.
additionalM:
Hints
To help this mnemonic along, literally imagine your older brother as someone that's just a giant mouth with a pair of legs walking around. It talks and talks and talks, too, irritating you. Feel the irritation specifically at your older brother. He's older than you, so you can't beat him up... yet.
readingMnemonic: You wish you could box your loud-mouth older brother up and send him far away to きょうと. きょうと is super far away from where you currently live, so just ship your older bro off so he can never bother you again.
additionalR:
Hints
Hmm... don't you want to go to きょうと someday? Maybe you should have sent your brother somewhere less cool.

meaningMnemonic: The radical for rain and the kanji for rain are the same thing.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know your radicals!
readingMnemonic: What if the rain actually tried to aim (あめ) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a world where each rain drop had to choose a target to aim for. How strange would rainfall be? Also, あめ and "aim" don't really sound too much alike, but the goal is to use "aim" to get to あめ, so make sure to take note of that in your mind as you learn the reading.

meaningMnemonic: The rice radical and rice are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This also refers to "America," maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
additionalM:
Hints
Aren't radicals nice? They make things so much easier... if you've been studying them.
readingMnemonic: You've got tons of dry grains of rice. You have no idea what you're going to do with it. Then, you come up with a solution. All this dry rice could go towards filling up the bay (べい), so you have more land to farm on!
additionalR:
Hints
In your mind, bulldoze the rice into the bay, watching it fill it up, then pile high. It's not particularly good looking land, but it'll do, and it's already full of seeds, so that's pretty good. The important thing is that you think you have way too much of the stuff, so the only way to get rid of it is to dump it in a large body of water, and that large body of water is a bay.

meaningMnemonic: The radical run and the kanji run are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know your radicals!
readingMnemonic: You run and run and run and suddenly you feel your soul (そう) leave your body. Still running, you turn around and see your soul running a few steps behind you.
additionalR:
Hints
Running really takes it out of you. In this case, it takes your soul out of you. Don't worry, when you stop your soul will collide with you again and everything will be okay. (Probably.)

meaningMnemonic: There's a mustache on the ground. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the same as yours!
additionalM:
Hints
Pick up the mustache, hold it up next to your face in front of a mirror. It's unbelievable, but it's the same in every way, down to the last hair.
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember the reading どう, we use the word "doughnut".
additionalR:
Hints
If it helps, imagine hundreds or thousands of doughnuts all around you with the same exact mustache. First of all, it's terrifying to be surrounded by thousands of mutant doughnuts. Secondly, it's really weird they all have the same mustache as you.

meaningMnemonic: The say radical and the say kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
readingMnemonic: If you aren't sure what to say, just think about Genji (げん) and ask yourself, "What would Genji say?"
additionalR:
Hints
Genji is a real smooth talker. In fact, he can talk his way out of anything. If you can just stay calm and think "What would Genji say?" before saying anything, you'll probably end up saying something cool instead of something lame.

meaningMnemonic: The self radical and self are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Radicals have self. Kanji has self. Kanji and radicals can sometimes be the same thing... so do they really have "self"? Only way to find out is to study both of them hard!
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember じ we use the word "Jesus."
additionalR:
Hints
You can feel free to do some introspection here.

meaningMnemonic: You're walking at night when you discover a lantern covered entirely in hair, making it a very strange shape. In fact, this is a form you'd never expect a lantern to take.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all the different shapes this hairy lantern could take in your mind.
readingMnemonic: You stare at the shape until you finally recognize it: cake (けい)! Well, it's hairy, glowing cake, but it's still shaped like a big slice of cake.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the shape of this hairy, glowing cake.

meaningMnemonic: Slide down a branch and your skin will come off. Unlike what Tarzan will make you believe, you can't just slide around on branches, they're rough and painful and if you do it your skin will come sliding off and it will hurt.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sliding down a slide made of a big, branch. The branch's bark digs into your skin and pulls it right off of your body.
readingMnemonic: Without your skin to protect you, you feel the full heat (ひ) from the friction of your body going down the branch slide.
additionalR:
Hints
Your skin protects you from really feeling lots of heat. It gets burned before you and it has many tiny layers to keep you safe from heat generating things like the sun. You really need your skin!

meaningMnemonic: Giving a roof legs is the kind of construction you do. You make it so a roof can be in the sky. In addition to meaning "sky", this kanji often means "empty". Think about it - there's nothing more empty than the sky!
additionalM:
Hints
Think about it. If you give a roof legs, it goes even higher up. What's higher up? The sky is!
readingMnemonic: The reason you want to put a roof in the sky is because it gets the roof away from all the cooties (くう) that are on the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
Say "coooooties" nice and long, just like a little kid, to emphasize the long vowel in くう.

meaningMnemonic: For some reason, you are standing on the sun. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the sound of you burning up.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a super loud sizzling sound, drowning everything else out. It's ridiculously loud, and hurts your ears more than the sun's heat hurts your skin.
readingMnemonic: This sound isn't just loud, it's familiar. Finally you place it: onions (おん)!
additionalR:
Hints
Your burning body sounds just like sizzling, crispy onions being fried in a pan. Listen close. It's exactly the same! You can almost smell onions too!

meaningMnemonic: You have a wild viking child you have to take care of. He won't do anything but study, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.
additionalM:
Hints
Of course, this isn't what you'd expect of a little viking child. It's the opposite. That's why it's so surprising! He loves to study!
readingMnemonic: This crazy viking child who prefers study over pillaging (and other viking activities)... the other vikings just stop and gawk (がく) at him when they walk by.
additionalR:
Hints
You should tell the other vikings to stop gawking at this child. Just because he likes to study doesn't mean he's a bad viking...

meaningMnemonic: You see a triceratops in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly pi shaped (that is, circular). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much sunlight (or just light is fine, too) as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.
additionalM:
Hints
Absorbing sunlight is natural for reptiles, after all. And a round one can absorb even more light. Imagine it sitting in a round spot of sun, enjoying the warmth. What a rare sight you've come across!
readingMnemonic: As you watch this majestic beast absorbing sunlight, suddenly several dozen feral (こういち)s burst from various hiding spots, spears in hand. Oh no! Those こういちs are hunting this rare piceratops!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine many different (but also kind of the same) こういちs attacking and throwing spears at the piceratops. But, because it was able to charge up in the sunlight, it uses its powers to shoot light in all directions, rendering all the こういちs momentarily blind, allowing it to escape.

meaningMnemonic: In a coffin is someone begging. But, it won't work. You won't listen. So, the man in the coffin just begins to think: What could I have done better in my life? Why am I in this situation? How will I get out? Think, damnit, think!!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine him changing from a begging position to a stereotypical "thinking" position, hand on chin, eyebrows furrowed. Focus on the beggar's thinking. This is a pretty abstract idea to imagine, so it will be important to create a very vivid picture in your mind's eye.
readingMnemonic: What is the beggar thinking of? A thought bubble pops up into existence near his head. In it is a picture of こういち! He's thinking that if こういち was here, he'd save him. Oh, if only こういち could save us all!
additionalR:
Hints
Then, the beggar realizes that he is こういち. You're burying こういち in a coffin alive and all he can think of is himself.

meaningMnemonic: There's a mouth inside a mouth. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of times there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means revolve too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself counting and counting smaller and smaller mouths inside of each other, recording the number of times you can find a mouth inside another mouth. Dig deeper and deeper until it feels ridiculous how small the mouths are getting. Be sure to focus on the counting and the number of times you find one. Now, how many mouths is this times two, because your mouth is like this too.
readingMnemonic: If you're having a hard time wrapping your head around the infinite number of times these mouths revolve, just picture yourself in a little kayak (かい) going around and down through the mouths.
additionalR:
Hints
Your kayak is slashing and dipping through the revolving mouths, going down and down more times than you can count!

meaningMnemonic: There's a hat decorated with fins and (presumably fish) mouths on it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the valley people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of California, Hollywood / LA. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a bunch of Valley Girls walking around with these strange hats. Fins and fish mouths... what a strange new fad.
readingMnemonic: Hanging around with all the Valley Girls in the sunny area of LA is also a robot. It's WALL-E's distant (and lazy, lounging) relative, TAN-E (たに). He sits around getting a tan in LA with the Valley Girls while his cousin picks up trash.
additionalR:
Hints
What a jerk he is. Imagine the deep tan lines on TAN-E as well. He's the epitome of robot laziness.

meaningMnemonic: You have a samurai with a flag on a stick. On his flag is this symbol, the kanji for voice. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine him and other samurai with their flags on sticks waving them around shouting things like "we want a voice in politics!" etc., etc.
readingMnemonic: Once you start asking the samurai more specific questions about how he wants more voice he starts playing coy (こえ) with you. He doesn't really know what he wants, he's just here for the sake of protesting.
additionalR:
Hints
Then you ask him out on a date. He still plays coy with you... one of those samurai, I guess.

meaningMnemonic: The west radical and the west kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know all those radicals, will make your life more pleasant.
readingMnemonic: People are attacking from the West, so you pull out your saber (せい) and beat them back. You keep pushing further and further West until you reach the ocean and there's nowhere left for them to run.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself fighting your way West, your saber shining in the light of the sun as it sets in front of you. You'll protect your home from the West if it takes everything you and your saber have left!

meaningMnemonic: Our leader has a lip ring. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? WHAT??
additionalM:
Hints
Think of our president (or your prime minister, or dictator, or whatever) and imagine this person appearing on television one morning with a big ol' lip ring. Feel surprised by it. Just say "What??" over and over again. You want to have the feeling of "what" in you when you imagine this - that'll help you to remember this kanji's meaning.
readingMnemonic: The leader with his lip ring is now eating some naan (なん) and curry. It's delicious, of course... but then he gets it caught on his lip ring, and tears half his lip off. He screams: "Nannnnn eeeeeeeeeehhh!!" (なに) in anger at the naan and curry.
additionalR:
Hints
Make this one vivid and scary. He's eating the naan (that's your なん), and then he screams at the naan but gets overwhelmed with pain (that's the なに). Smell the naan (you're there) and see the blood gushing out of his/her lip. It's terrifying. How did the naan even catch on his lip ring anyways?

meaningMnemonic: The life radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the winter you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the wheat you store away.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you're starving. It's cold and you've run out of food. You don't know what you're going to do. If you don't find something, you'll lose your life. Then, you break open a barrel, and wheat pours out. It's beautiful. You just found some life in the middle of winter.
readingMnemonic: You found your wheat. Thank God. You'll survive. You have to take the wheat back to your house, though. On your way, you get mugged (むぎ).
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the disappointment. You go from finding life to losing it all... now you have no hope for the winter :( Also, keep in mind that むぎ and mug aren't super-alike, so you'll have to use it to get  close enough to remember the actual reading, むぎ.

meaningMnemonic: There is someone with a bow and a stick, wearing horns, going down a slide. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your younger brother.
additionalM:
Hints
Just pretend you have a younger brother for now, if you don't. Also be sure to imagine this person really vividly. He is a stereotypical little boy, playing dress up with horns and a bow and stick (he can't have an arrow, that's dangerous), and he's going down a slide too.
readingMnemonic: Your younger brother loves playing dress up so much that he's now started dyeing his hair all kinds of colors. Imagine the bright red, blue, green and purple dye in his hair.
additionalR:
Hints
 Imagine the bright red, blue, green and purple dye in your younger brother's hair. He's put so much on that he's dyed half his face too. He's going to be in trouble when he gets home!

meaningMnemonic: The bamboo radical and the bamboo kanji are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Just make sure you know your radicals!
additionalR:
Hints
Of course, focus on the absurdity of a bamboo shrub that can cry and eat a lollipop. Also, think about how mean you are to take the lollipop away from a defenseless bamboo shrub in the first place!
readingMnemonic: There's a little bamboo shrub sitting there, holding onto a lollipop. Because you're bigger than the bamboo shrub, you just take (たけ) it from the bamboo, causing it to cry.

meaningMnemonic: The radical car and the kanji car are exactly the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.
additionalR:
Hints
The more fantastic you make this car, the better. Also, feel the surprise of a shaman getting out of this car. What a cool dude that shaman is.
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use "shaman".

meaningMnemonic: If someone has a big head you have to try to focus on the center of it when you talk to them.
additionalM:
Hints
You don't want to get caught with your eyes wandering all over their big head. Stare right at the center of their face. Ah geez, their eyes are kinda far away from here. You can really only see their nose...
additionalR:
Hints
The 王 will definitely cut off your normal-sized head if he sees you looking all over his big head and not at the center.
readingMnemonic: This is the center of the 王's (おう) head so you have to be extra careful not to look anywhere else.

meaningMnemonic: The beggar is pointing his forehead up at you, his feet trapped in the ground. What diabolical scheme are you planning with this poor beggar you trapped? Turns out, you're planning to copy him to have your own version of him.
additionalM:
Hints
You can imagine the whole story - him walking along, you setting a trap... and then whamo! You catch him. Then, come up with some crazy way / invention you're going to copy him. Are you cloning? Are you just taking his skin? Are you removing his forehead to grab his brain? Up to you - just make sure you make it ridiculous enough to remember.
additionalR:
Hints
The shaman runs around for a bit, doing ridiculous things. Imagine it dancing about and mumbling shamanic chants as the beggar is copied.
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading しゃ, we use the word "shaman".

meaningMnemonic: The leader samurai didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by doing.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the leader samurai doing things. He's doing more than anyone else, no one can keep up with what he's doing.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the leader samurai doing lots of sheep things. He's shearing sheep. He's feeding sheep. He's doing everything you could possibly do, because he's the sheep samurai.
readingMnemonic: He was doing things with sheep (し). He is the leader of the sheep clan, and he was able to do more with sheep than anyone else. That's why he's the leader.

meaningMnemonic: The ear radical and ear kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!
additionalR:
Hints
This is sort of a stereotypical singer sort of image. Make sure you concentrate a lot when you're listening to your mimimimiiii tone. In fact, why don't you do it out loud right now - make a little fool of yourself. It's fun, and it'll help you to remember!
readingMnemonic: Put your hand to your ear and sing... "Mimimimimimiiiii!" (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear.

meaningMnemonic: When the sun is over the cross it's time to go to church... which is so darn early. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be fast, otherwise you'll be too late.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says EARLY and FAST on it, flashing in big red letters and alternating.
additionalR:
Hints
But you get your soul up early and head to the church fast anyway, because you're doing all of this for your soul in the first place!
readingMnemonic: To remember the そう reading we use the word "soul."

meaningMnemonic: You're looking for a treasure, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of energy. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a spirit ball of energy like you've never seen.
additionalM:
Hints
Try to touch the energy spirit, it's pretty amazing. Is it solid? Does it shock you? What does it feel like? Be sure to imagine it out.
additionalR:
Hints
You take the key and open another treasure that's nearby. Open it up and see what's inside. Imagine something spectacular.
readingMnemonic: As you reach inside the energy spirit, you feel something hard inside. It's a large key (き) that gives you access to another treasure.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to dry your horns you need to lay them flat. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's peace.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine carefully taking off your horns and laying them flat on a paper towel. You have to smooth them out so they're as flat as possible.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine carefully laying a flat layer of hay on top of your flat horns. You feel really at peace and... you're tired now. You decided to lay on top of the hay and take a nap while you wait for your horns to dry.
readingMnemonic: Being flat isn't enough, so you cover the whole thing in hay (へい). Hay absorbs water, so you add a flat layer of it.
mainReading: へい, ひょう, びょう

meaningMnemonic: A leader with a spoon is planting flowers so that one day this place may be full of beautiful flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
It's kind of weird that the flowers radical is only a part of the flower kanji, but you'll make do. Just focus on the fact that the leader is planting all these flowers for a bigger picture thing (that's what leaders do). He wants there to be flowers for future generations as well, because he's a nice dude like that.
additionalR:
Hints
Do you know anyone named Hannah? Any famous people, perhaps? Try to come up with someone you know of named Hannah that you can imagine to be in this mnemonic, to help you remember it better.
readingMnemonic: The leader can't stop planting flowers though. He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? He comes up to someone named Hannah (はな) and starts planting flowers in her face, probably killing her in the process.

meaningMnemonic: The radical for foot and the kanji for foot are exactly the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Same kanjis and radicals make Jack a happy boy. You should also learn the other meaning as well, though, if you can.
additionalR:
Hints
Just think about your bare feet. Think about them too much. Feel how cold it is on your feet. Now, put on a sock to make it feel better. Ahhh, so nice!
readingMnemonic: What do you wear on your foot? You wear a sock (そく).

meaningMnemonic: Take your fingers to the street to hit some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine: it's just you, your fingers, and the wild street. It's hitting time!
additionalR:
Hints
Now imagine your dad saying, "Don't do a hit!" over and over at you. "I'm sorry dad! But the streets were calling me!"
readingMnemonic: As you hit one chump after another, suddenly your dad (だ) comes marching out of your house. Uh oh. Dad caught you hitting, which, honestly, isn't a very nice thing to do, so he has every right to stop you.

meaningMnemonic: There is a leaf growing out of the sun! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a hundred! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine flying toward the sun to see a hundred leaves growing together in the shape of one big leaf. You want to go closer!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hearing Goofy guh-hyuck over and over after you save him from being stranded on the sun. How would you feel being stuck in a cramped ship with laughing Goofy and his hundred leaves? Oh, you thought he would leave those behind? Nope, they saved him so you have to take them back too. Happy travels!
readingMnemonic: You fly closer, counting all one hundred leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH HYUCK (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention.

meaningMnemonic: You have water already... and it's pretty cold. All it takes is one cold drop of liquid nitrogen added to it to turn it into one big block of ice, just like that.
additionalM:
Hints
Go ahead and touch it... wow, it's really cold - and only from one drop, too. Feel the burn on your finger from where you touched the ice.
additionalR:
Hints
How did this happen? Was it your fault? Imagine the situation that would get Corey frozen like this.
readingMnemonic: When you think of ice, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named Corey (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice.

meaningMnemonic: The insect radical and insect are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine little words that say "mush" flying out from under your foot as you mush the poor thing. What does a "mush" sound sound like? You'll have to come up with something unique to yourself, and focus on it to remember this reading.
readingMnemonic: It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (むし) sound.

meaningMnemonic: The roof child stands upon the roof, holding up a single letter, a single character, a single symbol for the world to see.
additionalM:
Hints
More people can see this character since the kid is on the roof.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the child holding up the letter yelling at everyone who passes that the "J" stands for "Jesus." And yes, this kid just loves the Big Lebowski.
readingMnemonic: The character that is being shown is "J," which stands for Jesus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this letter and symbol.

meaningMnemonic: Rice paddy power comes from a man. One man, in fact. He's running on a big wheel next to the rice paddy and providing all of the power for the rice to grow and be harvested.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the power this man is generating! Now look at the next rice paddy and you'll see it's on a different power grid with a different man powering it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the man watching as the first light of dawn tints the color of the sky, turning it pink and orange. He stops working, lays down, and falls asleep.
readingMnemonic: A man can power an entire rice paddy until dawn (だん). Once dawn comes they need a little break, so they nap. But once dawn is over, they're back at it again!

meaningMnemonic: The radical master and the kanji master have the same meanings!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this master of water controlling the droplet as it flies around inside these chutes, like he's solving a difficult puzzle with it. Astounding!
readingMnemonic: Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the master is floating a water drop above his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master sends the drop of water into a chute (しゅ) and it goes careening through an intricate series of them.

meaningMnemonic: What is the evening mouth? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so famous that everybody knows his name (“Evening Mouth.”).
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself going to the area you chose, and watching “Evening Mouth” speak. There are thousands of others there, wanting to see the giant floating mouth in the night sky. “Evening Mouth” then says “Everyone, what’s my name!?” and everyone shouts back “Evening Mouth!” in unison. “Evening Mouth” has certainly gotten really famous.
additionalR:
Hints
You know what they say. April showers bring May Flowers. What do May Flowers bring? They bring “Evening Mouth,” baby.
readingMnemonic: So, when does “Evening Mouth” appear? Turns out, “Evening Mouth” only comes out to talk in May (めい). You know this because it’s just starting to be spring, and when you look around (you’re watching “Evening Mouth” again) you see some spring flowers come up.

meaningMnemonic: The radical not and the kanji not are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!
additionalM:
Hints
Actually, it does make it easy - the radicals make kanji wayyy easier, no?
additionalR:
Hints
Be sure to feel irritated at that person. Think in your head as they're telling these dumb "not" jokes how much of a fool they are... and how much of a fool you are for sitting here and listening to them.
readingMnemonic: To remember ふ we'll use the word "fool."

meaningMnemonic: There's a mouth in the ground (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of prison you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of numbers that you don't understand.
additionalM:
Hints
What are these numbers? What do they mean? Think over it for a while, get frustrated, and try to figure it out. You can't, though, so you probably won't ever get inside.
additionalR:
Hints
ごういち keeps saying numbers as you free him from the prison. Just one after another. Numbers numbers numbers. Hopefully old man ごういち isn't crazy.
readingMnemonic: "You want to know the number to the hatch?" yells an old voice from inside. You say "yes," and the voice gives you the numbers and you're in! You go down into the prison, where there is one prisoner: Grandpa Koichi (ごういち).

meaningMnemonic: The leader of alligators... he's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. He's not a politician.. he's not a king... He's one of the Other Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine different groups of leaders - they're all dressed nice and normal. Then, off to the side are the leaders who are leaders of bears, cats, alligators, and narwhals... they're the other ones, no matter how you look at it. They are in their own group, and they are considered "others" because society won't accept them :(
additionalR:
Hints
Just imagine the "others" shaking their heads at these taco worshipers. Seriously, what the heck?
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading た, we use the word "Taco"

meaningMnemonic: If someone tries to dig up private dirt on you, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the past. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.
additionalM:
Hints
Keep your private dirt in the past. It's better for everyone.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine physically, literally burying your past 子 self. If you hide it in Little Kyoto, no one will ever be able to dig it up.
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading きょ, we'll use "Little Kyoto." This will differentiate きょ from きょう, which is regular-sized Kyoto. Get it? You decide to bury all this private dirt from your past in Little Kyoto (きょ). That stuff is from when you were just a little 子 (こ) and you don't like to think about it.

meaningMnemonic: The plate kanji and the plate are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.
additionalM:
Hints
If you know your radicals, you know your kanji too.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine someone with a huge head, washing dishes. When I say huge, I mean huge. She turns towards you with her big head and says “Hi, I’m Sarah” and you see her name tag, which also says Sarah. She is Sarah, the dish washer. The plates she holds up next to her head pale in comparison, even though they're the biggest pieces.
readingMnemonic: The person washing all the dishes was named Sarah (さら). She was named that because of her large head, which was shaped like Sarah Jessica Parker’s head (very big).

meaningMnemonic: Slide some dirt on your legs so you can feel like you're from a previous time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the feeling of dirt on your legs. Now think back to the previous day. The previous year. The previous century.
additionalR:
Hints
Centaurs were definitely real in the past. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. They're just afraid of the truth.
readingMnemonic: As you sit there, pretending you're in a previous time you see a centaur (せん)! That's right! Centaurs are from wayyyy in the past.

meaningMnemonic: The radical for red and the kanji for red are the same thing!
additionalM:
Hints
What a lucky ducky - as long as you know your radicals, you'll know this kanji's meaning as well!
additionalR:
Hints
You'll have to think of him as really, really red, though. Like, a glowing, searing kind of red. Red enough for you to associate red with this evil Fozzie Bear. If you do, then you'll be good to go (as long as you know his catch phrase as well).
readingMnemonic: Think of Fozzie Bear. He says "Wakka wakka wakka" a lot. Now, think of an evil, red (and I mean totally red) Fozzie Bear. He drops the "w" and just says "Aka Aka Aka," because he's totally evil.

meaningMnemonic: The leader is next to the tree. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, resting.
additionalM:
Hints
The best thing to do with a tree is rest under it. Picture the leader resting under the tree with his eyes half closed.
additionalR:
Hints
Don't email me saying cucumbers don't grow on trees. Cucumber trees exist. Look them up and then rest easy knowing I'd never lie to you.
readingMnemonic: As he rests, he suddenly gets hungry and pulls a cucumber (きゅう) off the tree and bites into it. A good rest isn't complete without some crunchy tree cucumbers.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a cross in your mouth, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say you say humbly.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself with a cross in your mouth, saying all kinds of humble things. "Oh no, I'm not that good." "Oh no, my mustache doesn't look that great."
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this character in your head. If it helps, you can take a Moe you already know of (Simpsons, perhaps?) and pretend he's extremely humble - ridiculously so. Just remember to make it crazy so you can remember it better.
readingMnemonic: When you think of saying humble things, think of the humblest man in the world. His name is Moe (もう).

meaningMnemonic: The radical see and the kanji see are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you do, you'll know a lot of kanji as well, almost magically!
additionalR:
Hints
The struggling to see bit is pretty important - make sure that you slowly see a little better and better as the person comes closer, but it's difficult the whole time (struggles are good for memory). Then, it starts to become more and more clear, and you start saying "that can't be me. No way it's me..." When the person comes up to you (the person, being you) you learn about parallel universes and other fabulous things. Still, the whole time you can't stop thinking about how "this person looks just like me... no, this person is me!"
readingMnemonic: You see something. It's walking towards you, but you need to see better. When the person comes close, you realize "That person is me (み)!"

meaningMnemonic: The shellfish radical and the shellfish kanji are the same! It can be just the shell part too.
additionalM:
Hints
Shellfish are shellfish, you know?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine rowing your kayak out into the ocean to collect shellfish. Imagine the color and shape of the kayak. Feel the spray of the salt water and the taste of some fresh shellfish, right out of the ocean.
readingMnemonic: To get some shellfish, all you have to do is hop in your kayak (かい) and get some. Shellfish live in the water.

meaningMnemonic: The stone radical and stone kanji are the same thing!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals and therefore know your kanji. It's just that simple.
additionalR:
Hints
Whoops, maybe you shouldn't throw stones through windows or you'll see people's sexy times.
readingMnemonic: You throw a stone through a window... and, now you can see something very sexy (せき).

meaningMnemonic: The leader for the ceremony can't come so you need a substitute to replace them ASAP!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the leader of the ceremony out back, unsure of what period or age they're in, while the substitute leader walks in and stares at them in shock.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're out back with the original leader and the substitute leader, trying to dye the color of this stupid shirt to match that one.
readingMnemonic: The substitute leader is wearing the wrong color clothes, so you have to dye (だい) them, like they did in the olden ages.

meaningMnemonic: Always remember to give umbrellas to the spirits to show your thanks. The next time you're walking by a shrine and you see a statue dedicated to a spirit, leave your umbrella open to protect it. This is the best way you can show your thanks for life, food, shelter, and all that good, good stuff.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a spirit shrine with an umbrella protecting it from the heavy rain. "Thanks for everything," you say softly.
additionalR:
Hints
Thanks for the new ray gun, spirit!
readingMnemonic: After you say thanks to a spirit, sometimes you'll get a gift back. You look down. There is a ray (れい) gun by your feet. Huh. Maybe you should show your thanks to the ray gun spirit more often.

meaningMnemonic: The thread radical and thread are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.
additionalR:
Hints
Think about how it tastes. Think about how it feels in your throat. Let it get caught on your teeth and around your tongue. It's a weird feeling having thread in your mouth, and you want to use that weird feeling to remember you're going to eat it.
readingMnemonic: You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat (いと) the thread.

meaningMnemonic: When you see both a rice paddy and a street in the same place, you have the makings of a whole town!
additionalM:
Hints
Think about it, a single farm wouldn't need a whole street. Just paths would do. There is a street next to this rice paddy, so there must be other people, which makes this a town.
additionalR:
Hints
Remember imagining Mrs. Chou in great detail in level 2? Time for some of that work to come to fruition. Imagine Mrs. Chou walking down the street of the town towards you, ready to make your day bad. She breaks things as she walks towards you, then knocks you down for walking around in her town. She says, "Wherever there's a street, you'll find Mrs. Chou." Then spits on your back as she walks away.
readingMnemonic: You go to visit this nice little town. But then, there she is... Every time you walk down the street, the street-woman Mrs. Chou (ちょう) arrives to ruin your day.

meaningMnemonic: Under his roof, the king stares into a drop of water containing his greatest treasure. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the treasure reflected in the drop of water. It's marvelous!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture his home from the outside. It looks like a normal, small castle. But then you walk in and it's a treasure trove of... well, treasure!
readingMnemonic: All of this treasure is kept in the king's home (ほう). He can't let other people see how much treasure he has, or they'll get mad, or worse(!) ask him to share some with his people. Yuck. The treasure stays at home.

meaningMnemonic: Someone’s taking measurements of the trees… Why is someone taking measurements of trees? These people are planning to take the trees and cut them down to make their village.
additionalM:
Hints
There is a whole group of people out there who are measuring these trees. Imagine them asking each other “do you think this will be a good tree for our village center?” and other people nodding in agreement or disagreement as they measure.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the mural on the side of this newly constructed village center. So many trees! Visualize the whole process as the tree becomes a building as you gaze and reflect on the message of the mural.
readingMnemonic: They take all the wood back to where they're building their village and once they construct the village center they paint a mural (むら) on the side of it. The mural is of the forest where they got the tree from so they remember the building's origins.

meaningMnemonic: The world radical and the world kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: generation.
additionalM:
Hints
It's all these generational differences that make the world go 'round!
additionalR:
Hints
Hold the saber up high and pledge to protect the world for all of the generations to come! Then swish it around and make buzzing sounds with your mouth.
readingMnemonic: It's your job to protect the world and every generation with your special saber (せい). It was given to you to uphold correctness, and you'll pass it on to the next generation when it's time. Then they'll watch out for the world when you're gone.

meaningMnemonic: The cow part of this kanji is slightly altered, but I think you can see where it is. The gun looks just fine, though. Think back to a fake memory you have living on the farm. You have your gun, and you gotta use it on a cow (ruh roh). Once a year on New Year's, you have to go out and shoot one of the cows. It's only a yearly shooting, though, so at least there's that respite.
additionalM:
Hints
You'll have to imagine yourself doing this to remember the meaning of the kanji. Focus on the thought that "okay... it's only once a year... I only have to do this once a year..."
additionalR:
Hints
How funny that you use dead cow parts to make a miniature cow holding a gun much like the one you murdered earlier. Imagine yourself playing with this nendoroid as you think about how weird it was to make a cow nendoroid out of a dead cow.
readingMnemonic: It is New Years, though, so when you bring the dead cow back home, it’s time to celebrate. Using the cow’s organs and bones, you and your siblings construct a nendoroid (ねん). Nendoroids are Japanese toys - little plastic figurines (Google it if need be). You make a little cow nendoroid holding a gun. How cute.

meaningMnemonic: Your task in prison is to bend things into different angles and then put them in the corner. No one will tell you why you're doing this, but you get a couple cents an hour to do it, so you aren't going to complain.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself sitting in a corner, bending pieces of metal and scrap to fit the angle of that corner.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine cocking your head to different angles and hearing cocks crow every time you do. Prison isn't as fun as you thought it would be. Manual labor and loud chickens aren't what you expected.
readingMnemonic: To get the angle right you find that you have to cock (かく) your head to the side a lot. After cocking your head at weird angles so much you also start to hear cocks crowing in your head. Cock-co-cock-co-caww!

meaningMnemonic: The axe radical and the axe kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the bread loaf counter, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you've gone back in time a good hundred years, and you're trying to count loaves of bread after each swing of your axe. Axes and bread loaves will become intertwined in your brain.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being stuck using an axe on bread while the King of England glares down at you, munching and spilling crumbs everywhere.
readingMnemonic: You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an axe to be a bread loaf counter for the King (きん) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.

meaningMnemonic: The blue radical and the blue kanji are exactly the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Don't feel blue, you should know this kanji automagically!
additionalR:
Hints
You aren't sure how you or the saber turned blue, but you're pretty sure the Shougun had something to do with it. At least you match now, I guess.
readingMnemonic: You've been feeling really blue. Mostly because your skin, hair, and eyes have all turned blue. The Shougun (しょう) found out and now he's back. He places his hand on your shoulder and then points at your saber (せい). It's blue too! You aren't alone!

meaningMnemonic: The leader has a book all about the human body. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking down at your body and thinking, huh, I wonder what all that junk is? Oh well, I'm sure the leader has it all figured out in that book of his.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the leader, reading a book, putting a tie on his body. Look around at you and your family and your neighbors. You don't know what your body meat-bags do and you don't know how to tie a tie. Womp womp.
readingMnemonic: The leader's body book also taught him about something very body specific: how to tie a tie (たい). You can't have a tie on your body, no no. Those are for the leader and his smart body.

meaningMnemonic: The color radical and color are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Color me pink! This kanji's super easy if you know your radicals.
additionalR:
Hints
You can even have someone ask you about your ear... "Is your ear okay? I think it's the color blue..."
readingMnemonic: You already have color on the mind because you know the meaning of this kanji, so think of something colorful about yourself. Imagine your ear (いろ) being a weird color... green, purple, red, whatever. Just make it really bright and standing out.

meaningMnemonic: There's rice spread out all over the ground. This will cause the Predator to come because he loves kome (rice). Then once he's gone, the next Predator will come to eat.
additionalM:
Hints
Also imagine everyone else coming to the rice next. When rice spills, people come from all around to line up and grab a handful of it to take home. Who's next? Come forward!
additionalR:
Hints
If you love rye grains, on the other hand, imagine everyone being really happy that they came to get the rice. They're so lucky it's rye!
readingMnemonic: When they come, though, everyone is disappointed. It turns out it's rye (らい) grains, and rye grains taste terrible. Yuck.

meaningMnemonic: Plant a spirit in the dirt before you start your company and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a young man way back in old-timey history times burying the spirit of one of his ancestors in the dirt. Now watch as an old-timey time lapse plays out in front of your eyes and a company is born!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine going to a shaman and having them tell you that for your company to be successful you need to bury a spirit in the dirt so it can help the company grow. You should probably listen.
readingMnemonic: Where did you learn about this method of company growing? From a shaman (しゃ), of course. Shamans aren't just spouting nonsense, they know what they're talking about. And spirits are right up their shaman alley.

meaningMnemonic: There's a triceratops and a wolverine. What are they doing together? You'd think they'd fight, but they took their battle to another venue... they're competing in a game show! One of them answers a question, and the host says, "Success! You're correct!"
additionalM:
Hints
Feel free to think through several questions and answers, but make sure they're all right, because that's what we're focusing on. Also make sure to focus on the triceratops and the wolverine themselves. You want to make sure that when you see these two radicals you automatically know they're playing in a game show, not doing anything else, like fighting or racing or something.
additionalR:
Hints
Wow, that was a pretty easy answer to get right. とうきょう is what pretty much everyone would guess, and they'd be correct.
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember the reading とう, we use the Japanese city Tokyo. The last question in the game show match is the following: "What is the capital of Japan." The triceratops and the wolverine scream the correct answer at the same time: とうきょう!

meaningMnemonic: The treasures are in the mouth where there’s ice. How cryptic! You want to find the treasure, that’s for sure (treasure is great!). It is somewhere where there is ice, so maybe the arctic? What you are looking at is a diagram which will guide you there.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at a diagram or map – and it has pictures of treasure in an area where ice is. This is where you will find the mystical treasure. This diagram will show the way. You're so excited that you found this map!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine dragging a wooly mammoth back with you to the town or city you live in, then throwing it in a zoo to be kept. People are quite amazed by this mystical creature you’ve found, though, which is pretty cool.
readingMnemonic: What will you do when you find these treasures that are shown on the diagram? Well, you get there, and you find that the treasure is actually a wooly mammoth! What will you do with this wooly mammoth? You grab it and put it in your zoo (ず).

meaningMnemonic: You see some windows... you have a gun. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... every single one of them.
additionalM:
Hints
Make a point to make sure you get every one, and don't miss any of them. Actually search around in your imagination for any more windows, because you want to stress it's important you hit every one.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you need to shoot every one of the mice that came through those broken windows. You can't let any survive. You have to get every last one out of here!!
readingMnemonic: Now that every single window is broken you feel pretty stupid because a bunch of mice (まい) come pouring in through them. You've made a way for them to get into your house. That wasn't smart.

meaningMnemonic: The feather radical and feather are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Have you been studying your radicals? If so, this'll be easy!
additionalR:
