Hints
Taste the honey, feel it all over your feathers. Go ahead and plummet towards the ground (because you were jumping off a building to fly when someone doused you with honey). At least it's a tasty way to go, no?
readingMnemonic: All these feathers. You're a bird man / woman, and you're getting ready to fly. Just as you're about to take off, someone dumps you with honey はね and you're all goopy, unable to go anywhere.

meaningMnemonic: You have a tree and another tree. You basically have yourself a forest!
additionalM:
Hints
Follow the logic of this one and you should be okay.
additionalR:
Hints
Obviously that didn't work well - you'll want to focus on your battle cry plus indecent swearing right afterwards to remember this reading.
readingMnemonic: So, now you have this forest and you want to cut it down (so much money!). But, you don't have any tools, only your hands. You think... I've done karate for a while, so I can probably chop it down that way. You get in a chopping stance, then do your battle cry and hit: "HAYA ... .SHI******!"

meaningMnemonic: The go radical and the go kanji are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
If you know your radicals well enough (and you do), you'll know this kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
You try to go another direction, and he just yells and points louder: "GO!"
readingMnemonic: "Go!" someone is telling you. "Go! Go! Go!" That person is こういち. He is holding his finger out, and pointing at your WaniKani reviews. "Go! Go!" Then, he over-enunciates the word "go" by saying "GYOU!!" (ぎょう).

meaningMnemonic: The gold radical and the gold kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Just know your radicals and you'll be golden, so to speak.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the King on a huge pile of gold. Gold coins, gold candelabras, gold ponies. He's laughing and pointing at all of it while making very strong eye contact with you.
readingMnemonic: The most gold in the land belongs to the King (きん) of England. In fact, you've never actually met someone with gold, it all goes straight to the King whenever someone finds some. You just have a few pennies to work with.

meaningMnemonic: You plant your flowers in the light of the sun in the shape of a cross, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with grass. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of how disappointed you are. You wanted a beautiful cross of flowers, and now you just have a big overgrown patch of thick grass. It isn't even pretty green grass, it's a little brown and damaged from the sun.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine using your cool saw to saw off the heads of all of this grass. You made the cross pretty big, so there is a ton of grass to get through. The sun is beating down on you and the grass too, which isn't making it any easier.
readingMnemonic: The grass on top is brown and burned from the sun, so you need to take a cool saw (くさ) and hack the tops off. The saw is actually physically cool to the touch, to help heal the grass' sunburned bits. It just happens to look cool too.

meaningMnemonic: The village you always think of first is your hometown.
additionalM:
Hints
Why would you ever talk about the village where someone else was born? Answer: you wouldn't. Everything is always about you.
additionalR:
Hints
Close your eyes and imagine being on a saddle, heading back to your hometown right now. Feel your butt and legs chafing. Eh... that's not such a great memory, now that you think about it.
readingMnemonic: You go back to your hometown in a saddle (さと). You can't take a car or a train there, it's really in the middle of nowhere. So you have to ride a horse, so break out that old saddle and go visit your parents.

meaningMnemonic: The leader's key is the key that makes all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the leader taking his key to open up a safe that has a button to make other keys for the underlings. No key is as great as this key, though.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel angry about this. Maybe you should kick your foot in his mouth and make him suck on that.
Also keep in mind that there's another reading that pops up too that's さ. It's similar to さく, though, and I think you'll be able to learn both the readings via the vocabulary.
readingMnemonic: You make a key for an underling, and he looks at it disapprovingly (even though you're their leader!). He simply says, "this key sucks" (さく) and then walks off. How could this be?

meaningMnemonic: How many evenings are there? There are many.
additionalM:
Hints
If you accidentally think "a lot" or something similar, that's okay too. It's the basic meaning that counts, and all these things are pretty close, though eventually you want to get to the point where you know that this kanji does in fact mean many.
additionalR:
Hints
The tacos pelt you and knock you off your feet. Hard shell, soft shell, meat, lettuce, tomatoes, cheese... it's terrible. And there are so many of them, flying from the sky to drown you in tacos. This is absolutely absurd (and you should think that too, so you remember the reading).
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading た we use the word "Taco"

meaningMnemonic: The meat radical and meat are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Study those radicals, and perhaps we'll eat some meat tonight.
additionalR:
Hints
Do you know someone named Nick you can imagine? There's celebrities too, if you don't have someone. Someone like Nick Cage would do the trick.
readingMnemonic: You know there's people-eating going on here, with this kanji. So, when you think of this meat, you'll have to think about whose meat it is. In this case, it's Nick's (にく) meat.

meaningMnemonic: The meet radical and the meet kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
"I met my soulmate in a kayak," said Koichi.
readingMnemonic: What better way to meet new people than to start kayaking (かい)! Get into your kayak and just float out into the water. You'll eventually bump into someone else in a kayak and boom, you're meeting someone new!

meaningMnemonic: You put a lid on your father. But, he won't taste good alone, so you mix in some other ingredients. They mingle inside the pot with him.
additionalM:
Hints
This may seem traumatic, but actually your father is surprisingly into it. Imagine him mixed in with all kinds of other things. It's important to note that this kanji is about things being mixed in, not so much about the action of mixing. That's another kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
"I love mixing in with potatoes and tomatoes," your father こういち states. "Turn up that temperature. I like to mingle with a bit more tingle."
readingMnemonic: With a mix of your father and other ingredients mingling in your cooking pot, you lift up the lid... your father pops up. Your father is こういち. He stares back at you with a big smile.

meaningMnemonic: Someone on a scooter has an axe, and they're getting near to you really fast! Oh no, they're so close now, you need to get out of here!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a scooter coming toward you in the dark. You see the gleam of the axe as it looms nearer and nearer.
additionalR:
Hints
The King is now so near to you his nose and mustache are tickling your face. He's holding the axe high above his head and saying, "I can get as close to you as I want and you can't stop me because I'm the King. I can get sooooo close. Look, I'm not touching you though!"
readingMnemonic: As they draw near, you recognize who is riding the scooter: the King (きん) of England! Behind him, a bunch of his guards also on scooters and wielding axes appear and move close to you.

meaningMnemonic: Who's someone who's just a mouth with legs? That's your know-it-all older brother, who won't shut up about anything.
additionalM:
Hints
To help this mnemonic along, literally imagine your older brother as someone that's just a giant mouth with a pair of legs walking around. It talks and talks and talks, too, irritating you. Feel the irritation specifically at your older brother. He's older than you, so you can't beat him up... yet.
additionalR:
Hints
Hmm... don't you want to go to きょうと someday? Maybe you should have sent your brother somewhere less cool.
readingMnemonic: You wish you could box your loud-mouth older brother up and send him far away to きょうと. きょうと is super far away from where you currently live, so just ship your older bro off so he can never bother you again.

meaningMnemonic: The radical for rain and the kanji for rain are the same thing.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know your radicals!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a world where each rain drop had to choose a target to aim for. How strange would rainfall be? Also, あめ and "aim" don't really sound too much alike, but the goal is to use "aim" to get to あめ, so make sure to take note of that in your mind as you learn the reading.
readingMnemonic: What if the rain actually tried to aim (あめ) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.

meaningMnemonic: The rice radical and rice are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This also refers to "America," maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
additionalM:
Hints
Aren't radicals nice? They make things so much easier... if you've been studying them.
additionalR:
Hints
In your mind, bulldoze the rice into the bay, watching it fill it up, then pile high. It's not particularly good looking land, but it'll do, and it's already full of seeds, so that's pretty good. The important thing is that you think you have way too much of the stuff, so the only way to get rid of it is to dump it in a large body of water, and that large body of water is a bay.
readingMnemonic: You've got tons of dry grains of rice. You have no idea what you're going to do with it. Then, you come up with a solution. All this dry rice could go towards filling up the bay (べい), so you have more land to farm on!

meaningMnemonic: The radical run and the kanji run are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know your radicals!
additionalR:
Hints
Running really takes it out of you. In this case, it takes your soul out of you. Don't worry, when you stop your soul will collide with you again and everything will be okay. (Probably.)
readingMnemonic: You run and run and run and suddenly you feel your soul (そう) leave your body. Still running, you turn around and see your soul running a few steps behind you.

meaningMnemonic: There's a mustache on the ground. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the same as yours!
additionalM:
Hints
Pick up the mustache, hold it up next to your face in front of a mirror. It's unbelievable, but it's the same in every way, down to the last hair.
additionalR:
Hints
If it helps, imagine hundreds or thousands of doughnuts all around you with the same exact mustache. First of all, it's terrifying to be surrounded by thousands of mutant doughnuts. Secondly, it's really weird they all have the same mustache as you.
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember the reading どう, we use the word "doughnut".

meaningMnemonic: The say radical and the say kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Genji is a real smooth talker. In fact, he can talk his way out of anything. If you can just stay calm and think "What would Genji say?" before saying anything, you'll probably end up saying something cool instead of something lame.
readingMnemonic: If you aren't sure what to say, just think about Genji (げん) and ask yourself, "What would Genji say?"

meaningMnemonic: The self radical and self are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
Radicals have self. Kanji has self. Kanji and radicals can sometimes be the same thing... so do they really have "self"? Only way to find out is to study both of them hard!
additionalR:
Hints
You can feel free to do some introspection here.
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember じ we use the word "Jesus."

meaningMnemonic: You're walking at night when you discover a lantern covered entirely in hair, making it a very strange shape. In fact, this is a form you'd never expect a lantern to take.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all the different shapes this hairy lantern could take in your mind.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the shape of this hairy, glowing cake.
readingMnemonic: You stare at the shape until you finally recognize it: cake (けい)! Well, it's hairy, glowing cake, but it's still shaped like a big slice of cake.

meaningMnemonic: Slide down a branch and your skin will come off. Unlike what Tarzan will make you believe, you can't just slide around on branches, they're rough and painful and if you do it your skin will come sliding off and it will hurt.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sliding down a slide made of a big, branch. The branch's bark digs into your skin and pulls it right off of your body.
additionalR:
Hints
Your skin protects you from really feeling lots of heat. It gets burned before you and it has many tiny layers to keep you safe from heat generating things like the sun. You really need your skin!
readingMnemonic: Without your skin to protect you, you feel the full heat (ひ) from the friction of your body going down the branch slide.

meaningMnemonic: Giving a roof legs is the kind of construction you do. You make it so a roof can be in the sky. In addition to meaning "sky", this kanji often means "empty". Think about it - there's nothing more empty than the sky!
additionalM:
Hints
Think about it. If you give a roof legs, it goes even higher up. What's higher up? The sky is!
additionalR:
Hints
Say "coooooties" nice and long, just like a little kid, to emphasize the long vowel in くう.
readingMnemonic: The reason you want to put a roof in the sky is because it gets the roof away from all the cooties (くう) that are on the ground.

meaningMnemonic: For some reason, you are standing on the sun. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the sound of you burning up.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a super loud sizzling sound, drowning everything else out. It's ridiculously loud, and hurts your ears more than the sun's heat hurts your skin.
additionalR:
Hints
Your burning body sounds just like sizzling, crispy onions being fried in a pan. Listen close. It's exactly the same! You can almost smell onions too!
readingMnemonic: This sound isn't just loud, it's familiar. Finally you place it: onions (おん)!

meaningMnemonic: You have a wild viking child you have to take care of. He won't do anything but study, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.
additionalM:
Hints
Of course, this isn't what you'd expect of a little viking child. It's the opposite. That's why it's so surprising! He loves to study!
additionalR:
Hints
You should tell the other vikings to stop gawking at this child. Just because he likes to study doesn't mean he's a bad viking...
readingMnemonic: This crazy viking child who prefers study over pillaging (and other viking activities)... the other vikings just stop and gawk (がく) at him when they walk by.

meaningMnemonic: You see a triceratops in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly pi shaped (that is, circular). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much sunlight (or just light is fine, too) as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.
additionalM:
Hints
Absorbing sunlight is natural for reptiles, after all. And a round one can absorb even more light. Imagine it sitting in a round spot of sun, enjoying the warmth. What a rare sight you've come across!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine many different (but also kind of the same) こういちs attacking and throwing spears at the piceratops. But, because it was able to charge up in the sunlight, it uses its powers to shoot light in all directions, rendering all the こういちs momentarily blind, allowing it to escape.
readingMnemonic: As you watch this majestic beast absorbing sunlight, suddenly several dozen feral (こういち)s burst from various hiding spots, spears in hand. Oh no! Those こういちs are hunting this rare piceratops!

meaningMnemonic: In a coffin is someone begging. But, it won't work. You won't listen. So, the man in the coffin just begins to think: What could I have done better in my life? Why am I in this situation? How will I get out? Think, damnit, think!!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine him changing from a begging position to a stereotypical "thinking" position, hand on chin, eyebrows furrowed. Focus on the beggar's thinking. This is a pretty abstract idea to imagine, so it will be important to create a very vivid picture in your mind's eye.
additionalR:
Hints
Then, the beggar realizes that he is こういち. You're burying こういち in a coffin alive and all he can think of is himself.
readingMnemonic: What is the beggar thinking of? A thought bubble pops up into existence near his head. In it is a picture of こういち! He's thinking that if こういち was here, he'd save him. Oh, if only こういち could save us all!

meaningMnemonic: There's a mouth inside a mouth. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of times there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means revolve too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself counting and counting smaller and smaller mouths inside of each other, recording the number of times you can find a mouth inside another mouth. Dig deeper and deeper until it feels ridiculous how small the mouths are getting. Be sure to focus on the counting and the number of times you find one. Now, how many mouths is this times two, because your mouth is like this too.
additionalR:
Hints
Your kayak is slashing and dipping through the revolving mouths, going down and down more times than you can count!
readingMnemonic: If you're having a hard time wrapping your head around the infinite number of times these mouths revolve, just picture yourself in a little kayak (かい) going around and down through the mouths.

meaningMnemonic: There's a hat decorated with fins and (presumably fish) mouths on it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the valley people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of California, Hollywood / LA. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a bunch of Valley Girls walking around with these strange hats. Fins and fish mouths... what a strange new fad.
additionalR:
Hints
What a jerk he is. Imagine the deep tan lines on TAN-E as well. He's the epitome of robot laziness.
readingMnemonic: Hanging around with all the Valley Girls in the sunny area of LA is also a robot. It's WALL-E's distant (and lazy, lounging) relative, TAN-E (たに). He sits around getting a tan in LA with the Valley Girls while his cousin picks up trash.

meaningMnemonic: You have a samurai with a flag on a stick. On his flag is this symbol, the kanji for voice. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine him and other samurai with their flags on sticks waving them around shouting things like "we want a voice in politics!" etc., etc.
additionalR:
Hints
Then you ask him out on a date. He still plays coy with you... one of those samurai, I guess.
readingMnemonic: Once you start asking the samurai more specific questions about how he wants more voice he starts playing coy (こえ) with you. He doesn't really know what he wants, he's just here for the sake of protesting.

meaningMnemonic: The west radical and the west kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know all those radicals, will make your life more pleasant.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself fighting your way West, your saber shining in the light of the sun as it sets in front of you. You'll protect your home from the West if it takes everything you and your saber have left!
readingMnemonic: People are attacking from the West, so you pull out your saber (せい) and beat them back. You keep pushing further and further West until you reach the ocean and there's nowhere left for them to run.

meaningMnemonic: Our leader has a lip ring. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? WHAT??
additionalM:
Hints
Think of our president (or your prime minister, or dictator, or whatever) and imagine this person appearing on television one morning with a big ol' lip ring. Feel surprised by it. Just say "What??" over and over again. You want to have the feeling of "what" in you when you imagine this - that'll help you to remember this kanji's meaning.
additionalR:
Hints
Make this one vivid and scary. He's eating the naan (that's your なん), and then he screams at the naan but gets overwhelmed with pain (that's the なに). Smell the naan (you're there) and see the blood gushing out of his/her lip. It's terrifying. How did the naan even catch on his lip ring anyways?
readingMnemonic: The leader with his lip ring is now eating some naan (なん) and curry. It's delicious, of course... but then he gets it caught on his lip ring, and tears half his lip off. He screams: "Nannnnn eeeeeeeeeehhh!!" (なに) in anger at the naan and curry.

meaningMnemonic: The life radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the winter you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the wheat you store away.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you're starving. It's cold and you've run out of food. You don't know what you're going to do. If you don't find something, you'll lose your life. Then, you break open a barrel, and wheat pours out. It's beautiful. You just found some life in the middle of winter.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the disappointment. You go from finding life to losing it all... now you have no hope for the winter :( Also, keep in mind that むぎ and mug aren't super-alike, so you'll have to use it to get  close enough to remember the actual reading, むぎ.
readingMnemonic: You found your wheat. Thank God. You'll survive. You have to take the wheat back to your house, though. On your way, you get mugged (むぎ).

meaningMnemonic: There is someone with a bow and a stick, wearing horns, going down a slide. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your younger brother.
additionalM:
Hints
Just pretend you have a younger brother for now, if you don't. Also be sure to imagine this person really vividly. He is a stereotypical little boy, playing dress up with horns and a bow and stick (he can't have an arrow, that's dangerous), and he's going down a slide too.
additionalR:
Hints
 Imagine the bright red, blue, green and purple dye in your younger brother's hair. He's put so much on that he's dyed half his face too. He's going to be in trouble when he gets home!
readingMnemonic: Your younger brother loves playing dress up so much that he's now started dyeing his hair all kinds of colors. Imagine the bright red, blue, green and purple dye in his hair.

meaningMnemonic: First of all, there's a cross making up the middle, which automatically makes this a religion-based radical. That cross is the frame of someone's body and the things coming off of it are wings. This is an angel.

This looks like a tail with some hairs coming off of it. It shouldn't be confused with fingers though, because it's curved, and the things sticking out are more erratic, like hair or fur would be. That's why this radical is the animal radical.

There's a little speck of something on your plate (皿). "What is that?" you ask. Oh no... that speck is BLOOD!!! I hope it's blood from a nosebleed you suddenly have and not someone else's blood. (Your waiter is probably gonna get fired, btw.) At least your platelets should stop the bleeding soon. Haha, get it? PLATE-lets? Japanese blood jokes.

This radical looks like the fire from the burner of a stove or the steam coming up off of a pot of water. That's because this is the boil radical. You need to boil a bunch of water over some flames. This radical looks like all of those parts at once!
This box is open. There could be any number of things inside, but for now all you need to know is the meaning of this radical, which is box.
You already learned the kanji 市, which means city. We're treating it as a radical too, since it pops up in many other kanji. When used as a radical, it still means city.

There's a lid on a lion. And you're stuck under the lid with the lion, which means you will surely meet your death. Or if you don't want to die, think of the poor lion. If you leave a lion under a lid for too long, death will come for it too. Either way, somebody's gonna die today.
You put on your hat and go outside to kick something white. It's a big white goose and you killed it with your kick. That's because you're going to cook and eat it. Yum!

Someone has a toe in their mouth. They are a fortune teller telling your fortune. But for her to do it, she has to take one of your toes and taste it. This better be a good fortune for you to let someone put your foot in their mouth.

This is a tree with a slide cutting off the top. What do you cut off the top of trees and plants? The grains. Imagine taking a sickle and slicing the grains off rice or wheat. The plant you leave behind will look like this radical. It's a sign that you got a grain of some sort from it.

This is like one of those jets that have the little nose-wings going on too. Imagine you're looking at the jet from the top down, this is what it would look like. It's also why this is the jet radical.
This is a knife. See how it has two sharp sides? And there's a little handle at the bottom for the... well the handle. Be careful you don't cut yourself!

There's a person in a prison. Why is this person in prison? Because they lack the stuff humans need to be around other humans. If you're lacking something (kindness, self-control, etc.) you may do something that makes other people put you in prison. Try to fix what you lack so this won't happen to you.
There's a ladle scooping up two drops of liquid. See the handle and the scoop part of the ladle? Imagine ladling some water into your mouth. Mmm.

This L-shaped radical is the lion radical, because "L is for Lion." It also looks like a lion's mouth being opened really, really wide. Imagine a lion opening its mouth to yawn. It looks like this radical!

You have a modified key radical on top of the kick radical. You kick the key as far as you can, then measure the distance. How long did it travel? How long will it take you to find it? How long will you be in trouble for kicking a key into the woods?
This radical is just like the katakana character "ma" (マ). So let's keep things simple and make the radical mama.

There are some horns on the ground that you want for yourself. You pick them up and you attach them to your neck. Imagine these horns sticking out of your neck. No one can slit your throat now that your neck is protected.

This is a sheep and you're looking at it from above. See the two ears and the body of the sheep going back (with all its wool poking out to the side) and then the little tail sticking out the back. What a cute sheep!
Something is sticking out of a mouth. Something with a thousand little tastebuds on it. It's your tongue!

The evening radical is under the ground. Who's doing things underground at night? The Yakuza. Picture Yakuza members sneaking around in the subway, or in the sewers. They're definitely up to no good down there.
Kings with hats. Did you know that all kings wear hats?
additionalM:
Hints
Think of as many kings as you can think of. Guess what, every single one of them (aka all of them) wear hats! Think of strange hats, funny hats, and normal hats. Just make sure you're amazed by the fact they all are wearing them.
additionalR:
Hints
To add to this story and make it more memorable, you can imagine the other kings getting upset, saying things like "All kings must wear hats! You are no king!" The king of Zen Buddhism just ignores them and begins to meditate.
readingMnemonic: But, as you're going through all the kings, it turns out not all of them have hats after all. The last one you come to does not have a hat. He is the king of Zen (ぜん) Buddhism. He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby.

meaningMnemonic: If you loiter around to poop in winter you never know what could be happening behind you. After you're done you could turn back to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to loiter while you poop in the winter. You're just trying to take your time as you squat over the snow, but soon you hear things behind you.
additionalR:
Hints
Godzilla and こういち were going at it behind you the entire time you were just lazily taking a poop in the snow?! Ahh, that's so embarrassing! And also dangerous, they could have crushed you! You should look behind you more.
readingMnemonic: You finally look behind you and see Godzilla (ご) and a giant こういち having a violent battle back there!

meaningMnemonic: The blood radical and blood are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
There'll be some bad blood between us if you're not studying your radicals, especially when they're the same like this kanji!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the relief that you didn't just lick up someone's blood. Taste the ketsup taste, too. It's pretty good. Not quite ketchup, but not quite catsup. Yum!
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup!

meaningMnemonic: Under the ground, which you dug into, you found two great finds. You found both a mountain and a head, two strange things to find underground.
additionalM:
Hints
You'll want to focus on the part where you find both, not so much the things themselves. Think about how you can't believe you did so well finding both things at once. Usually you only find one or the other when you're searching.
additionalR:
Hints
Also think... "What's that row boat doing here?" But, it's your only hope, so you have to focus on it really hard.
readingMnemonic: But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a row (りょう) boat floating off in the distance.

meaningMnemonic: The sun AND the moon are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly bright outside.
additionalM:
Hints
Look up at both of them, hanging out in the sky together. Make them super bright, so bright you have to shield your eyes.
additionalR:
Hints
If your months don't match up with this too well (if you're down in the southern hemisphere, for example) then you'll have to imagine all this up in the Northern Hemisphere. Sorry about that, South Hemisphere folks.
readingMnemonic: When do things start to get bright outside? I'd say when things start getting sunny, and that is the month of May (めい).

meaningMnemonic: There is a lid covering all the mouths that are too small to feed themselves, forming the capital. All of the small mouths come together and create a place where everyone can support each other.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the capital of your country. How many mouths have come together to support each other there? A thousand? A million? More?!
additionalR:
Hints
When you think of the capital, think of きょうと!
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading きょう we use the Japanese city, Kyoto, which is spelled きょうと. It was once the capital of Japan! It was soooo full of mouths that came together that it was the capital for a long, long time.

meaningMnemonic: A leader with a spoon is a powerful thing. Even something like a spoon when given to the right man or woman can make great change in the world.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your leader-hero holding a spoon out, then doing something awesome with it to totally change everything for the better. It's amazing the change this person can do with such a blunt, small, device!
additionalR:
Hints
Of course, doing something like this is utterly amazing. Feel amazed in your imagination, because if you don't, then it'll be hard to remember the reading for this kanji. If you are amazed, you'll know that spoons going to cars = the reading is か, so make sure you take the time to be amazed.
readingMnemonic: Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, changing it into a car (か).

meaningMnemonic: The mouth of the king extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his country, give or take a few drops.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.
additionalR:
Hints
Would you drink that much soda for breakfast? Now this king says he wants to pass a law requiring everyone in the country to drink nothing but Coke! That's crazy!
readingMnemonic: Turns out the king of this country loves drinking Coke (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast.

meaningMnemonic: You scoop some grains into a ladle to do science. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science course.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine carefully ladling grains into different piles so you can do science experiments on them. This course is going to make you an expert. You'll be the best in this department!
additionalR:
Hints
From your science meddling, these grains grow huge, red, and sprout sports cars when they're ripe. This is the true power of science!
readingMnemonic: Using your science skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a car (か). This is the science department's special car now!

meaningMnemonic: The radical death and the kanji death are the same.
additionalM:
Hints
This thing is deceased. It ain't alive anymore.
additionalR:
Hints
You didn't want to know what would cause your death, you say? Well that's a shame. I guess you could try to avoid bowling from now on, but that won't do any good. Mark my words, your death will be bowling-related.
readingMnemonic: Your death will be because of a bowling (ぼう) accident. Oh, you didn't know? You're going to be hit by a giant bowling ball and crushed flat.

meaningMnemonic: If the yakuza hands you a spoon, death is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death.
additionalM:
Hints
This spoon isn't for pudding, it's for death!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the death sheep. He looks like a black shadow, and he has a scar on his face. He's holding a bunch of spoons, from all the other people the yakuza marked for death!
readingMnemonic: Death comes in the form of a sheep (し). The death sheep works for the yakuza, and kills anyone who has their spoon.

meaningMnemonic: There's a close-up of a leaf in a rice paddy inside of a box. Wait, it's not a box, this whole thing is just a drawing.
additionalM:
Hints
Look closely at this box-shaped drawing. See each little stroke, smell the paper and the lead.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the entire drawing. There's a cock sitting on a gargoyle, watching over this rice paddy. It's actually quite beautiful and idyllic.
readingMnemonic: The drawing seems to have something else in the rice paddy, behind the leaf. You realize the drawing is actually of a gargoyle (が) and a cock (かく). You see the cock sitting on top of the gargoyle, crowing into the sky.

meaningMnemonic: A dirt alligator lives in the earth, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing the earth moving as a dirt alligator rises out from the ground. You should run.
additionalR:
Hints
If you ever see someone throwing cheese on the ground, now you know why. They aren't crazy, they're saving us humans from what's lurking under the earth.
readingMnemonic: The only way to keep this dirt alligator from dragging you under the earth and eating you is to feed it cheese (ち). That way it won't lead you to a horrific death under the earth by dragging you under and spinning you around until you eat dirt (literally).

meaningMnemonic: Behind that tree the sun is rising in the east. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the sun behind the tree, don't picture the sun alone, you'll burn your eyes. It's slowing coming up behind it. Now think: where does the sun rise? In the east!
additionalR:
Hints
When you think about East Japan think about とうきょう. And if you're bad at geography, just look at a map for a while. Or, stand outside in the morning, watch the sun rise behind the trees, and point that way. That's east, it's where とうきょう is!
readingMnemonic: You walk east for a few hours until you finally come to a city. It's とうきょう. Oh! とうきょう is in the east. I get it now!

meaningMnemonic: The radical for eat and the kanji for eat are the same! Lucky you.
additionalM:
Hints
If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is meal. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know "eat" you should be able to remember "meal" as well.
additionalR:
Hints
So, do you keep eating and keep getting shocked? Or do you not eat and continue to starve? What is worse? Obviously you're in one of the Saw movies, or something, too, so feel the fear. What will you choose? Life with shocks or death from hunger?
readingMnemonic: Thank goodness, you finally get to eat your meal. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a shock (しょく) from somewhere.

meaningMnemonic: You accidentally stab your cross into the eye of a lion. This is a terrible thing you did and you need to fix it right now. I'll be direct with you, this is something you have to fix on your own.
additionalM:
Hints
How will you fix this mistake though? Maybe if you build a time machine you can go back and stop yourself from throwing your cross around so carelessly. Whatever you do, focus on how important it is to fix the mistake, more than anything.
additionalR:
Hints
You're relieved! You don't know how to fix a choking, eye-stabbed lion, but you can absolutely fix a ROBOTIC one. Robots are fixable.
readingMnemonic: As you try to fix the lion's eye, it starts to choke (ちょく) and make what can only be described as a jikijikijiki sound (じき). Through its choking jikijiki sounds, it coughs up a gear. Wait. Is this a machine lion?

meaningMnemonic: There are some horns on the ground and a moon knife in front of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.
additionalM:
Hints
Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care. Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run. Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.
additionalR:
Hints
Go ahead and do some Zen Buddhist meditation. Maybe it'll help you to remember this kanji's reading better (and calm your mind so you're ready for the next kanji!).
readingMnemonic: You're going crazy with these things in front of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a Zen (ぜん) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked!

meaningMnemonic: A narwhal and a moon is all you have. Imagine one of each under your arms.
additionalM:
Hints
You don't have anything else. This is it. All you have.
additionalR:
Hints
They came and took your things. Now they have all your stuff, and you only have the moon and a narwhal. You don't have much anymore, but at least you have these things still.
readingMnemonic: Everything you have (except the narwhal and the moon) were taken from you by a roving gang of youths (ゆう).

meaningMnemonic: Your private grains are meant to stay private! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at your private grains. Who are those for? Why, they're for I!
additionalR:
Hints
The moral of the story is: don't let a sheep sneak into your private stash of things just for you (I). I'm sure this is a metaphor for something important...
readingMnemonic: You're getting into the zone, thinking about yourself (I) and how much you love having things that are private and just yours, when you realize there is a sheep (し) in this grain bag. And it's eating all of your (I's) private grains. No!

meaningMnemonic: Just before saying something important, you take an arrow to the mouth which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you know with someone else.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being so surprised by this arrow. Then, think of all the things you know that need to be said and told to everyone. Maybe you have information about nuke codes. Maybe you have information that will save the President. Whatever it is, make sure you know important things that need to be said (but also things that people want to prevent you from saying, even if it means shooting you in the mouth with an arrow).
additionalR:
Hints
Try saying the words "cheese" with an arrow in your mouth. What would that sound like? Go ahead and pretend out loud.
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading ち we use the word "cheese."

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami of tongues is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... lively!
additionalM:
Hints
Your entire body wakes up, you feel so lively! The tongues are making you more aware of yourself and your surroundings than you've ever been. You want to dance, you want to sing, you want to live your life.
additionalR:
Hints
You and the cats are running around playing together, because you can't seem to get the lively feelings to stop. You have to get the energy out, but the cats have sharp claws and they're scratching you.
readingMnemonic: This lively feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the cats (かつ) in your neighborhood too!

meaningMnemonic: The long radical and the long kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
As long as you know the radical long, you know the kanji long as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Long isn't an idea that's easy to imagine in any specific sense, but you can try some other things too, as long as it gets associated with Mrs. Chou. For the most part, when you see a kanji with the radical 長 the reading will be ちょう.
readingMnemonic: You see a very long person. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the leader of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou.

meaningMnemonic: Twenty mouths are together. That's a lot of mouths. What do they do? They sing beautiful music together.
additionalM:
Hints
Listen to the twenty mouths. They sound great. Have them sing your favorite music. Also note that this kanji also means "bend." Imagine the music coming out at you bending all around in strange shapes through the air.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how you feel as they cloak you with music. Feel the music all around you, enveloping you. Become the music itself.
readingMnemonic: The twenty mouths make so much music that they literally cloak you (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music.

meaningMnemonic: The radical neck and the kanji neck are exactly the same!
additionalR:
Hints
Look at yourself in a mirror as the cool beans make their way down your neck. You can see them, like little ants marching all the way down to your tummy.
readingMnemonic: The only thing you do with your neck is use it to swallow lots of cool beans (くび). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there.

meaningMnemonic: You lack ice. So you go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!
additionalM:
Hints
Feel a little frustrated you can't find ice. Have the words "next next next" echoing through your head as you go from store to store, irritated.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine him coming down. Imagine your surprise. He hands you the ice, and it's cold. You thank him, and he flies away.
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading じ, we used the word "Jesus" - Finally, when you're at the last store in existence, you decide it's time to pray to Jesus (じ), asking for a miracle. He comes down from the heavens with ice in his hands.

meaningMnemonic: A leader is wearing a lid and is standing outside in winter. Plus it's raining and he's covered in drops of water. On top of all this, it's night.
additionalM:
Hints
If it helps, you can come up with a reason why he's outside in the winter at night. Also, why is he wearing a lid on his head? Probably because he's protecting his people from something that comes at night.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the Yankees stomping towards the leader, baseball bats in hand, blood on their faces. They're here to eat, and nobody will stop them. Feel the fear of their approach. Will you survive another night with them on the prowl?
readingMnemonic: Question is, what is he protecting them from during the night? Turns out, it's the Yankees (や) baseball team. They're out for blood, and only the leader can protect us.

meaningMnemonic: The only woman in this city is your older sister. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.
additionalM:
Hints
You want to go to the city someday, but you're not old enough yet, like your older sister is.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your older sister and her sheep walking through the city. Everyone turns to stare at them, because they're the only ones of their kind.
readingMnemonic: Your older sister may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet sheep (し) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet.

meaningMnemonic: Your fortune boils down to a single point in time. One decimal point in the math of time determines how the rest of your future will go.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine actually going somewhere to get your fortune told and watching a big boiling pot of goo. As it boils, it melts down to a single point at the very bottom. Where this point is determines your future.
additionalR:
Hints
Is the ten spot good? Are you going to live a long life or does this point mean you're only going to live ten more years?! Ahh!
readingMnemonic: As you stare at the decimal point you watch in awe as it moves to the ten (てん) spot in a long series of numbers.

meaningMnemonic: With a roof over her head, a woman can relax. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a safe place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super cheap, so she can even relax about her finances.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the super relaxed woman lounging under her cheap but sturdy roof. Ah, she doesn't have a care in the world!
additionalR:
Hints
Think about it: anchovies cost next to nothing, they come in cans, you don't have to cook them or cut them up. You just munch them down. There's nothing more cheap and relaxing than eating anchovies under your own roof.
readingMnemonic: As she relaxes, she pulls out the cheapest, most relaxing food in the world anchovies (あん).

meaningMnemonic: On the dirt you've made a roof over the ground where you can be in private. This is your room! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the room you live in now. Take away all the stuff and you're left with a roof and the dirt on the ground. It's your own little private place.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine watching the little shih tzu come into your room and lift its leg to all your things. This isn't fair. The shih tzu has its own room to pee in. Why does it have to ruin yours?
readingMnemonic: The only problem with your room is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's shih tzu (しつ). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami is coming, so you point your gun out the window at it. "You better turn back, sea, or I'll shoot!"
additionalM:
Hints
You'll have to think of the "sea" as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the "sea," not the "tsunami." It's like aiming for the head of a zombie and not the arms or legs.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine paddling in your kayak, your gun still in one hand, as you chase the sea back to its home.
readingMnemonic: The sea decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your kayak (かい) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else.

meaningMnemonic: The sheep radical and the sheep kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning.
additionalM:
Hints
You are no sheep—you study your radicals, unlike most Japanese learners. You'll learn sooo much faster!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the taste of this yogurt. You're scared and tired from running, but it tastes great!
readingMnemonic: To remember よう, we use the word "Yogurt." The sheep are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... because you stole their sheep's milk yogurt (よう). Now you're running and crying and trying to eat the yogurt before the sheep catch up and stomp you down with their hooves.

meaningMnemonic: A long time ago, someone put up a canopy over their fortune telling booth and created the first shop. This store was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the very first store in history. A fortune teller decided enough was enough, they should be in some kind of structure where it's safe, official looking, and more permanent.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture ten shops, all made up of someone selling something under a canopy. The first one is the fortune teller, but the nine others are whatever you want them to be!
readingMnemonic: This shop quickly turned into ten (てん) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more.

meaningMnemonic: The cross you're holding above your head to keep your horns dry keeps pulling you south. Probably because it's warmer and less damp down south.
additionalM:
Hints
Look down and see the compass pointing south and feel the cross pulling you in that direction.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being in the south and taking big bites of naan. It tastes good, but now your mouth is dry just like your horns. Too dry...
readingMnemonic: You finally make it down south, and it is dry, but you're really hungry. When you try to find southern food you realize every single store is only selling naan (なん).

meaningMnemonic: The sun that gives life is our very own star (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky and there are billions of them. I hope you don't feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're soaring through between the stars, swinging your saber through the silence of space, and... wait. No that was a dream. You roll over and pat your saber. The two of you are ready just in case the stars need your help.
readingMnemonic: This star (the sun) and all of the others are yours to protect with your trusty saber (せい). If you could protect your land from the West, then you can certainly defend the stars too!

meaningMnemonic: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three drop drop drops in the large river that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's states or provinces.
additionalM:
Hints
Also, another way to think of this is that the river radical is actually just three rivers, separating drops, which are capitals of various states. Rivers are usually great ways to divide up a country, and states are one way to do it!
additionalR:
Hints
The state shoes also have things like the state birds, state flowers, and state fish printed on each of them. They're quite collectable, you should buy a pair for your favorite state!
readingMnemonic: Each state has its own shoe (しゅう) to represent it. The bottom of each shoe is the shape of the state, so when you step it leaves a state-shaped imprint in the ground.

meaningMnemonic: You come across an angel wearing a hat that's covered in flowers. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make tea out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though.
additionalM:
Hints
How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*
additionalR:
Hints
It gets kind of weird when you know their names... Usually you just make them into tea without knowing who they are (easier that way). This one... this one is Chad, and you remember it vividly, because now you feel kind of bad.
readingMnemonic: In your tea you find a little metal button. I guess you missed it while you turned the angel into tea. You look at the button - on the back it says "To Chad, you'll make an awesome angel." Looks like you're drinking Chad the Angel.

meaningMnemonic: In a rice paddy you find a heart and it makes you think. You think a lot of things like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"
additionalM:
Hints
Think, think, think. Think about this rice paddy heart.
additionalR:
Hints
Do you think you could tell if a heart is from a sheep or not? I think you could.
readingMnemonic: You think this heart is from a sheep (し). It's big and covered in wool. It's also baa-ing a little. Why would you think anything else?

meaningMnemonic: You stop at a small slide. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were walking.
additionalM:
Hints
Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say "keep walking, friend."
additionalR:
Hints
Of course, imagine the pain of your face. Did your nose break? After bringing yourself together, look down at what hit you. It's a hoe! How did you manage to step on just the right spot to flip it up on you like that? Examine the hoe. Pay close attention to it. Whose hoe is this? etc.
readingMnemonic: So, you're walking around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a hoe (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you.

meaningMnemonic: A drop hits your mustache. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from yonder," you say, facing that way.
additionalM:
Hints
Yonder is a bit of a weird word, but it fits the meaning of this kanji quite well. You'll have to trust me that it's more useful in Japanese than it is in English. When you imagine through this mnemonic, make sure the drop comes from the side and hits you in the mustache with quite a bit of force. That means it came from a far distance thus making you look over "yonder."
additionalR:
Hints
"Who is that over yonder!" you yell.
"It is I, (こういち)," he yells back. "I shot at you over yonder because you weren't doing your kanji reviews often enough and you're taking up space on our database."
"But I'm paying you!"
"Oh, that's true. Well, I'm going to walk over yonder and leave you alone, then."
readingMnemonic: Who shot this drop at you from yonder? You look over yonder, and see a figure. It is こういち.

meaningMnemonic: Who's that woman pretending to be a jet? That's my younger sister. *Sigh*
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!
additionalR:
Hints
Ew, gross. Your younger sister is such a weirdo! Why does she have mice on her back while pretending to be a jet?
readingMnemonic: Your younger sister is giving some mice (まい) a ride on her back like a jet.

meaningMnemonic: While riding your scooter, you take your sword and cut out an area on the ground. This whole place is your area now!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine riding your scooter around in a really large circle, pressing your sword into the ground as you do. Once you close the circle, you claim to everyone around that this is YOUR area, and they aren't allowed in.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine doing everything you can to get this hen out of your area, but it manages to dodge and outwit you at every turn. You even slash at it with your sword and try to run it over with your scooter, but the hen can't be stopped. This is the hen's area now. You have been defeated.
readingMnemonic: As you look down at your area, you suddenly realize there is a hen (へん) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg.

meaningMnemonic: You have the measurement of a leader. Imagine yourself measuring said leader (his/her height) and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you attach another head to the top of his/her head.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you really feel like the person can’t be a leader because they’re too short when you measure them (I know this isn’t true, but we’re remembering kanji here, anything goes!). As long as you feel disconcerted that the leader isn’t tall enough, you should be able to remember that you need to attach something to the leader to make him/her tall enough. The fact that you’re attaching another head to the top of his/her head is pretty weird too, and should help you to remember the meaning.
additionalR:
Hints
Just focus on how attaching requires two things to remember this reading.
readingMnemonic: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of attaching something to something else. What would you need? You'd need two (つ) things to put together!

meaningMnemonic: The tree has an umbrella, and it's holding it over his head, which is strange, because trees normally like water... turns out, it's not water falling on him, but dollar bills floating down.
additionalM:
Hints
The sick part of this is that those dollar bills were once this tree's friends. The tree is sobbing uncontrollably as pieces of his friends fall on him and all around him - which is why he's using the umbrella to protect himself.
additionalR:
Hints
What else could he do? He couldn’t move, so he sat. It’s weird imagining a tree trying to sit…
readingMnemonic: The tree couldn’t take the body parts of his friends falling down on him, so he sat (さつ) down, and began crying uncontrollably.

meaningMnemonic: The bird radical and the bird kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
As long as you know the radical bird you know the kanji bird.
additionalR:
Hints
After bursting out of this bird, she turns her head sharply in your direction. "I don't just own the streets, I own the birds too. I'm inside every bird, and I, Mrs Chou, can burst out at any time.
readingMnemonic: Think of a run of the mill bird, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaningMnemonic: The radical black and the kanji black are exactly the same.
additionalR:
Hints
You need to drink all this Coke, otherwise you're going to drown. Drink this Coke and keep tasting its cold sweetness as you drink it all to survive.
readingMnemonic: You're in a completely black room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's Coke (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke.

meaningMnemonic: Your boat has fins and a mouth! It's still a boat though.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this boat. It's still a boat, but there is a big mouth on the front and it has fins that it paddles forward with.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this mouth and boat with a bunch of centaurs riding in it. Centaurs have a lot more parts than humans, so it makes sense that their boats have more parts (animal ones) too.
readingMnemonic: This boat belongs to the centaurs (せん). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before.

meaningMnemonic: The slide coming out of the patient's heart is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for certain death.
additionalM:
Hints
As you imagine the mad scientist drawing blood out of the patient's heart with a small slide, also imagine a little meter hooked up to him as well. On one end is "SURVIVE!" on the other end is "CERTAIN DEATH." Right now the finger is pointing close to certain death, though :(
additionalR:
Hints
Maybe imagine yourself running in there too, just trying to hit the patient back to life, because the patient was your friend.
readingMnemonic: As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the doctor puts his hands together and hits (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.

meaningMnemonic: This kanji uses a modified jet radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the end of the earth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the end of the earth being like how they imagined it pre-Columbus era. Just a big drop going off into space, giant waterfalls plummeting down. Your crazy jet has made it to the very end! Congratulations!
additionalR:
Hints
It's surprisingly dirty down here, because all the water takes the garbage this way. That's why you sit on these mats you brought.
readingMnemonic: When you get to the end of the world, you land your jet and put out a few mats (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights.

meaningMnemonic: Your clan is where you get your name. But not your given name, your family name. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your surname! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
additionalM:
Hints
Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your ancestors, herding sheep. Thanks to them your name means "sheep people." Thanks great great great great great grand pappy.
readingMnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your family name came from. Your family used to herd sheep (し). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.

meaningMnemonic: That slide is your husband's only fault. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking out the window of your house and watching your husband slide down his slide over and over. He's not even good at it, he falls off the side halfway down most of the time. You want to complain, but he's pretty decent otherwise. This is his only fault.
additionalR:
Hints
You run outside and yell, "AHA! It's your fault that shih tzu died! You and that stupid slide!"
readingMnemonic: You try to come up with another fault of his so you can complain when you see a tiny shih tzu (しつ) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing.

meaningMnemonic: The radical fish and the kanji fish are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Nothing fishy about that, right?
additionalR:
Hints
Have him continue to scream "GO GYO GYO GYO!" as you try to get your engine started and attempt to flee your impending doom. The fish helps too, because he's pretty worried as well.
readingMnemonic: You catch a fish. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "GO!" (ぎょ). "GO GYO GYO GYO!" There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you.

meaningMnemonic: The lion drops a drop of saliva onto this person from above. The person is in a much worse place compared with where they were before, since they only just recently fell into this pit.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the person, the lion is leaning over them, the drop of spit dangling from their mouth. "I-I want to go back where I came from," the person gasps, shaking.
additionalR:
Hints
The eagle came from the sky and technically rescued him, but compared to where he was before, it may not be a better situation. I think this person is going to be eaten either way.
readingMnemonic: From above there is a loud caw, and a giant eagle (い) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, compared with where he was before, is this really better?!

meaningMnemonic: Sew thread through your top hat and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a group of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a group of people threaded together by their top hats. Don't you want to be part of a cool group like that? Your own top hat team.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being in a group of soap makers. Picture the soap bubbles floating between all of you.
readingMnemonic: This group decides to make soap (そ) together. You take off your top hats and use them as soap molds, mixing together all of your favorite smells and colors.

meaningMnemonic: Under this roof is a pig. Your pig, because it's your house! You keep your pig inside where it's nice and warm. He's a member of your family, so he deserves to live in your home too.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the little pig, prancing around happily under the roof of your house.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the pig again, but this time sitting in your car, which is also in your house. The three of you are warm and cozy and safe together in your home.
readingMnemonic: Also in your house, is your car (か). Your pig and your car are safe under your roof.

meaningMnemonic: This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. Lack becomes Lack!
additionalM:
Hints
If you know the radical you know this.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine having to use regular, ordinary ketchup, or just old, boring catsup on your burger. Or even worse, an actual tomato. BLEH!
readingMnemonic: To remember けつ, we use the word "ketsup." It's the perfect blend of ketchup and catsup!

meaningMnemonic: You're flying in a Jet. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "Not yet! Not yet! NOT YET!"
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the irritation of this. How irritating is this kid going to be the whole flight over? The jet is going as fast as it can!
additionalR:
Hints
Go ahead and pretend to listen to the kid asking if we're there yet. Then in your mind go "me me me me me me me" quietly.
readingMnemonic: What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is "Me (み) me me me me me me me me me me." Hate kids like that.

meaningMnemonic: The thread that ties you to your clan is paper. Your papers, that is.
additionalM:
Hints
The paper itself was also made by your clan using thread woven really tightly together.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a big guard coming up to you and asking to see your papers so they can see what clan you belong to. Well you're from the Commi clan, so you really hope this guard is okay with that.
readingMnemonic: You need this specific paper to prove that you aren't a Commi (かみ), aka a Communist. Or that you are. It really depends on where you want to go and what decade this is.

meaningMnemonic: There's a scooter with your mama carrying a task she needs to get done. You see her pass through, hurrying by to get that task done.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your mama passing through your house on a scooter, not stopping because she needs to get her task done urgently.
additionalR:
Hints
Why do you have to do the task too? Because there are two tasks, so the two of you have to do them.
readingMnemonic: As you watch your mama pass through the house, she yells, "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS TASK TOO (つう)!" Too?! Oh no, now you have to do it too. Hurry up!

meaningMnemonic: The mouth clan are a group of people. They are the people of a nation.
additionalM:
Hints
The mouth clan are distinct peoples. They do, of course, use their mouths.
additionalR:
Hints
That's why they're the mouth clan. This nation of people are known for mouthing off and saying mean things. Imagine them, as a nation, saying mean things to you. How awful! All being from the same place, they're all into it too. In a way, they're not the mouth clan, they're the mean clan.
readingMnemonic: The mouth clan peoples are a nation of people who use their mouths to say mean (みん) things to other peoples.

meaningMnemonic: The king's village is the reason he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.
additionalM:
Hints
If a king has no one to rule then he has no reason to exist.
additionalR:
Hints
Just like you can't have a king without a village, you can't have reason without re.
readingMnemonic: You can't have reason without re (り).

meaningMnemonic: A giant cross with a mouth stands above you. "I am reason!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.
additionalM:
Hints
Because it's a cross with a mouth, it thinks that it is reason in all the chaos.
additionalR:
Hints
"Those youths just do things for no reason! That's why I, the Cross of Reason is here! I will knock some reason into those youths."
readingMnemonic: The reason that this Cross of Reason exists is to combat the youths (ゆう) of the world, who just bring chaos into everything.

meaningMnemonic: Next to the tree, a lid is put on your father. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new school."
additionalM:
Hints
He goes on to explain that he changed your school to here because there is a tree to block the satellite's view. Also, he wears a tin foil lid on his head so they can't track him. The regular school was no good because "they were watching." So now you have this new school, taught under a tree by your father who's wearing a lid on his head.
additionalR:
Hints
On your first day of school, imagine walking under the tree and seeing all your classmates. They're all こういち–similar to each other, but with some variation. Your father explains these こういちs escaped from a government research facility, and they come to this school to receive a better education.  "These poor こういちs need a school that will teach them more than just kanji and Japanese vocabulary."
readingMnemonic: Your new school has other students too. They are all こういちs, though.

meaningMnemonic: The rain is hated so much by wolverines, so they always want to live in the snow.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine rain falling on a wolverine and how much they hate it, so the wolverine moves up north to somewhere with lots of snow.
additionalR:
Hints
He keeps saying "Yucky yucky yucky" over and over again. Imagine him doing this with an accent that would bring the word closer to ゆき.
readingMnemonic: You ask the wolverine, "Why do you want this snow so bad?" He replies quickly: "Because the rain is yucky" (ゆき).

meaningMnemonic: You have a private bow made of insects that's extremely strong. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for strong bows. You also have to be strong to use it, since it was made just for strong arms.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding this strong bow in your strong arms. Look closer at the little insect bodies that make it up. Thanks for your help, little guys.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine all the strong people who live in きょうと and make strong things. You should go there someday!
readingMnemonic: You had this strong bow made especially for you in きょうと. きょうと is famous for their strong bows, so if you ever want another, you know where to go.

meaningMnemonic: The eye leaf grows only in the winter. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
additionalM:
Hints
Just think of the eye leaf as weird (it is weird, after all). It grows in the winter. Now, think of any normal leaves. They do the exact opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
additionalR:
Hints
Think about summer. Now think about yourself tying knots. Now think about summer again. Now think about tying knots again. Now think about your mother getting upset at you because all you do is tie knots all summer long. Go play video games like a normal kid!
readingMnemonic: Now it's summertime! What do you do during the summer? You just sit around with your favorite string tying knots (なつ) in it over and over again.

meaningMnemonic: There's a lid on your mouth and mustache, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how tall and expensive you are.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself saying how tall and expensive you are to everyone in the room. Then they use a lid to cover your mouth so you can't talk to anyone anymore. But, then your mustache starts talking, saying the same thing. That's why this lid covers both your mustache and your mouth. Now you can't say that you are tall or expensive.
additionalR:
Hints
The こういちs finally get tired of your shenanigans, and lid up your mouth and mustache so you can't say that you're tall or expensive.
readingMnemonic: "I am taller and more expensive than you."

meaningMnemonic: A teacher in winter is happiest because they get to teach! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a teacher excitedly teaching, bundled up in the cold. Snow falling outside. Grumpy children being taught inside.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the teaching teacher teaching you about Japan in きょうと in winter. You've always wanted to go to きょうと!
readingMnemonic: Teachers can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to きょうと. きょうと is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows.

meaningMnemonic: The sun is used in a temple to tell time. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in a temple and realizing you don't know what time it is. Never fear! Look on up at the sun. Ah, yes. Blinding noon.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine him going to all kinds of different times and also make sure you're specifically imagining Jesus doing all these things. Put these two together and you'll remember the reading in no time. (Haha, get it?)
readingMnemonic: Time in a temple makes you think of Jesus (じ). Specifically, Jesus being able to perform time travel magic. He winks at you, goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth.

meaningMnemonic: You have two bows but they're both covered in ice. This has made them very weak.
additionalM:
Hints
Just look at these weak, iced over bows. If you tried to draw back their strings they'd snap into a million pieces.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're stuck with two weak broken bows and no jack. Ice is lame.
readingMnemonic: You give up on your trip and bring the weak bows back to your car, but it's stuck in the ice and snow. You decide to use the bows as a jack (じゃく) to try to get your car unstuck. Unfortunately, they're just too weak and they break in half.

meaningMnemonic: Use a scooter to travel the circumference of the world and it will take you a full week. Seven whole days!
additionalM:
Hints
A week in earth time is also known as a "full scoot" in scooter lingo. ;)
additionalR:
Hints
You can't ride a scooter for a week barefoot, are you nuts?! Get some shoes!
readingMnemonic: If you want to scoot for a week, you'll need shoes. Good shoes too, not sandals or high heels or boots. Solid, high quality shoes, so you don't fall off the scooter and hurt yourself.

meaningMnemonic: There is an insect sliding around under your table, being blown by the wind. You try to grab the insect but it keeps sliding past your hand because the wind is so strong. It’s going to start blowing you around under the table too!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture an insect, on its back, being blown around under a table. Feel the wind pushing you as you try to save the poor thing.
This kanji also means style too. You can think of the wind blowing one style in fashion one moment and then another the next. It blows your clothes off and blows new style clothes onto you, over and over again. Imagine this happening. Are you embarrassed when all the clothes are off? Pleased when you get new style clothes on?
additionalR:
Hints
Try to stuff food in your mouth in the wind. Food tastes even better when you have to fight for it!
readingMnemonic: The only way you can distract yourself from the wind and the insect sliding around under your table is by eating lots of food (ふう). That’s why you were at the table in the first place. It’s your dining room table and it’s dinner time!

meaningMnemonic: What you say to oneself (yourself), you decide to write down. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to record these important thoughts in some way.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine writing in a diary and saying everything to write aloud to yourself in your head. 
"Dear me, today I learned a lot of new kanji on WaniKani. It was the best. I love the crabigator sooooo much. Love, me."
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the key you use to keep what you write down a secret. What does it look like? How does it feel in your hands?
readingMnemonic: You need to protect what you write down and record for yourself with a key (き). These are your special thoughts and feelings, you don't want anyone else to see! Lock them away with a key!

meaningMnemonic: The radical yellow and the kanji yellow are exactly the same!
additionalR:
Hints
