The walls are coming in closer, too. Make sure you feel a bit of peril as you look for this key. The walls have a slight opening at the bottom too, so if you don't find it before the wall goes over it, the key will be lost forever, and you'll be smushed!
readingMnemonic: You're in a room, surrounded completely by yellow. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow key (き) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape.

meaningMnemonic: "Does the bamboo shirt suit me?" you ask... but nobody will answer.
additionalM:
Hints
Shout "PLEASE ANSWER ME!" a few times to get the idea of "answer" in your head. What you really want is an answer, whether it's bad or good, but nobody's willing to say anything because you look so terrible.
additionalR:
Hints
With this shiny quarter in your hand, everyone is giving you their answer. Yay for bribery!
readingMnemonic: You pull out a quarter (こた) and offer it to whoever will give you an answer.

meaningMnemonic: The stool is in the cliff. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty anti society, hiding away like that.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine someone who looks super antisocial (and a little feral). Ask them why they're sitting on this stool inside a cliff... they reply because they hate people. They are anti people!
additionalR:
Hints
Make sure you get to the point where you pull this anti-social guy's beard off, to reveal Han Solo beneath. Be surprised... not just because he's Han Solo, but because he's real, too! Maybe you can yell out "Han! Your people need you!"
readingMnemonic: Turns out, when you go to this guy and pull off his beard, he's Han (はん) Solo, the anti-hero from Star Wars! What is Han doing here, so hidden away? He's obviously hiding from Jabba because he doesn't want to get frozen in carbonite again.

meaningMnemonic: A wolverine is going down a slide into your mouth. Why is he going into your mouth, though? You're opening it really wide, because you're screaming "BUDDY!!! You're so excited to see your wolverine buddy-pal again. You thought he was dead.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you feel super happy. Even yell "Buddy" out loud while imagining this wolverine coming at you, if you're not in a quiet-zone.
additionalR:
Hints
"RaCCOON!" you yell. "THIS IS NONE OF YOUR BUSINESS. Get out of here." Feel some hate for the raccoon. He ruined everything.
readingMnemonic: As you're about to embrace your buddy wolverine, a raccoon tackles the wolverine off the slide, preventing your mouth embrace.

meaningMnemonic: Your nation's flag sits on top of a caped mouth. This is the symbol for the "Bureau of Secret Things." It's a special department of your government made to keep things hidden.
additionalM:
Hints
The cape covering the mouth represents how this bureau never talks about their secrets. The flag represents your country. Think about all the cool secret things the Bureau of Secret Things must have.
additionalR:
Hints
Now, this mnemonic isn’t perfectly close, but the goal is to get you close enough in your brain so that you can remember きょく later. If you can get to CLOAK YOU, then you can get to きょく much easier than just trying to get there from scratch. So imagine working in this bureau and getting to cloak yourself all the time.
readingMnemonic: The bureau's best-kept secret is cloaking devices that cloak you (きょく) with the press of a button.

meaningMnemonic: There are some shellfish in a net that you can buy. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking over a bunch of different kinds of shellfish wrapped in nets. Think about which ones you want to buy.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine buying an entire car's worth of shellfish. Mmm delicious.
readingMnemonic: You decide to buy as many shellfish as you can fit in your car (か). You keep buying until your car is completely full of shellfish before you stop. Cars are totally a realistic unit of measure.

meaningMnemonic: A rain cloud is still a cloud! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the different types of clouds in the sky. There are puffy white ones, heavy dark ones, and wispy thin ones. But they're all clouds.
additionalR:
Hints
You look at each cloud and each one is a different cool mom. They're each doing different cool mom things. You suddenly don't want to look at the clouds anymore.
readingMnemonic: You lie down and try to figure out what the clouds are shaped like. The first cloud is shaped... like a cool mom (くも). She's wearing high pants, and holding a kid on each hip, but she's also listening to the latest music and using slang. Huh. You look to the next cloud and see... wait, another cool mom?

meaningMnemonic: The white ice tree is a magical tree. When you eat its ice flowers it gives you incredible amounts of comfort, ease, and pleasure.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself picking the white ice flowers off the tree. Then, put it in your mouth. Make it taste comforting... It puts you at ease. Then, swallow it. Feel your head go nuts with comfort. This is the greatest drug in the world when it comes to comfort. So much pleasure!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine setting up the rack. Make it look beautiful. Shift around the flowers. Fill up the entire rack. Of course, your focus should be on the rack portion.
readingMnemonic: You want more of this, You gather as much as you can, and create an entire rack (らく) at your store with this tree. You sell out immediately, and have to refill your rack.

meaningMnemonic: In the winter, the woman has to go through all the rice and count each individual grain. Once she's counted all of them, she'll have an amount / number so that she can split them up accordingly.
additionalM:
Hints
She has to count each grain out in order to divvy up the supply to last through the winter. Imagine yourself getting just a few grains today for food. It's not a good time for you guys :(
additionalR:
Hints
Come up with a story about why your farm got sued for everything. Go to the court  case. Listen to the judge come up with your verdict. Be angry. This has ruined everything.
readingMnemonic: Why are you so low on rice? It's because someone sued your farm and took everything you owned. So, you had barely enough rice (or not enough).

meaningMnemonic: You have at your disposal a tsunami and a hook to assassinate this person. Which weapon will you choose. Decide now!
additionalM:
Hints
Have trouble with the decision. Which one? Tsunami will be big and cool, but a hook will be more discreet. How can you decide? Can you think of a neat way to decide this, like Two-Face on Batman?
additionalR:
Hints
Get everything ready to take your target down. How will you plan this? Where will you put it? Go ahead and watch your plan unfurl, too.
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading けつ we always use the word "ketsup." It's a special mix of ketchup and catsup (yum!)

meaningMnemonic: Using just thread meeting the paper (with a little ink on the end) you create a masterpiece of a drawing (or a painting).
additionalM:
Hints
It's unbelievable the kind of drawing you're able to draw with just the tip of a thread. So much detail. So artistic. If it helps, imagine that you drew the Mona Lisa, better than the original, only using this floppy thread tool.
additionalR:
Hints
Tell a few more people how you drew this. Have them all do the same "Eh!!??" reaction.
readingMnemonic: You tell someone that you drew this drawing only using a thread. Their response? "EH?!?!?" (え)

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the masters gets the biggest dwelling. He resides in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the leader master's big, beautiful dwelling. Everyone else is jealous.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine opening the door to the leader master's dwelling and thousands of jewels come pouring out, whisking you off, down the mountain.
readingMnemonic: He needs this big dwelling so he has somewhere to store all of his jewels (じゅう). Masters always have lots of fancy, expensive things, and he has jewels.

meaningMnemonic: You're standing in the middle of a rice paddy in the rain with an umbrella. You're standing here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by electricity (aka lightning) to show that it exists.
additionalM:
Hints
Get hit by the electricity. How does it feel?
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the indent in your face. It doesn't hurt, strangely, but it is pretty huge. Panic about this dent a bit.
readingMnemonic: After the electricity hits you, you feel your face. In it is a huge dent.

meaningMnemonic: This kanji is just the tree radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means "forest."
additionalM:
Hints
Makes sense, because a bunch of individual trees is what makes up a forest!
additionalR:
Hints
Keep repeating this pattern over and over, continually focusing in on how you need "more" trees to make this forest. For some reason the person working with you only goes up by one at a time, though, so you have to say it a lot (it'll help you to remember, anyways!).
readingMnemonic: One tree? No. Two trees? Not enough. I want more (もり) trees, please!

meaningMnemonic: With top hat power, you're able to help anyone.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting on your top hat and getting power from it. Then, you use that power to help someone. It's important to make the association that it's the top hat giving you the power to help that person. You're basically Frosty the Snow Man.
additionalR:
Hints
You can imagine saving her however you like. Perhaps she was under a car, and you used your top hat powers to help her out of that situation by lifting it above your head.
Note: Jo-Anne is the character we're using with じょ reading mnemonics. She is short compared to Jourm (じょう), the giant farmhand, which is how you'll differentiate the two similar readings.
readingMnemonic: The person you help with your top hat power? It's Jo-Anne (じょ).

meaningMnemonic: The horse radical and the horse kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the shock of this. It sounds just like a sheep, it's strange.
readingMnemonic: You are looking at a horse. It's looking at you. You try making horse noises at it, to get a reaction. Instead of reacting with a normal horse noise, it just makes sheep noises: "Baaa," (ば) it says. "Baaaaa."

meaningMnemonic: There's a gate that the sun goes through at a regular interval. There is an interval of time in the sense that the sun goes through it at the same time every day. And there is an interval of space in the sense that it has to go through the space between the gate posts.
additionalM:
Hints
"Interval" is a weird word to remember, but just think of the sun going around the earth and through the gate like clockwork. Every 24 hours it passes through the gate, and each interval is exactly the same.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Genghis Khan ordering his most skilled inventors and builders to create this special sun gate so they can harness the power of intervals, and all people under his rule can benefit from the accurate telling of time.
readingMnemonic: This method of keeping track of intervals of time was invented by the great Khans of Mongolia, specifically the most famous Khan of all: Genghis Khan (かん).

meaningMnemonic: Dirt makes it easy to identify your location. If you know that, you can go from place to place.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at the dirt. It's a distinct color and texture, and you're able to identify your location just from that alone.
additionalR:
Hints
Remember Jourm? He's our local farmhand who only has nine toes (from the 上 mnemonic). Imagine that guy explaining to you how to know your location from dirt. He may be a bit clumsy, but the man really does know his dirt.
readingMnemonic: Knowing your location from dirt is quite a feat! Who taught you that? It was Jourm (じょう), the big local farmhand. Despite being a bit weird, he does really know his dirt and can tell you the place from which any dirt came.

meaningMnemonic: You're in a cage and you've been shot by an arrow. Obviously things are looking pretty bad. You need some medicine if you hope to live.
additionalM:
Hints
More specifically, antibiotics. Your wound is festering pretty badly.
additionalR:
Hints
Or, so you think. He just keeps circling and circling. Feel some hate for the eagle. Why isn't he dropping the medicine? You don't have long to live!
readingMnemonic: When we need to remember the sound い we use the word "Eagle."

meaningMnemonic: There's a cross sticking out the top of the sun and another cross sticking out the bottom. The moon is off to the right. That's because it's the morning, which is when the sun and moon switch over. Those crosses are making sure the sun stays high in the sky for the rest of the day.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a sun attached up in the sky with two crosses, which act as scaffolding, and the moon gradually fading off to the right as the morning wears on.
additionalR:
Hints
You watch the sun scaffolded by crosses, and the moon next to it, as you sip on your early-morning Asahi.
readingMnemonic: Every morning you have Asahi (あさ) beer for breakfast.

meaningMnemonic: You have to sickle the rice paddy today because it's your turn. This kanji also means number in a series, which is a lot like a turn. For example, you're number 3, so your turn will be number 3.
additionalM:
Hints
Go through in your mind the system your farm / village uses for deciding who has to sickle on any given day. It rotates, and it's a turn-based system. So, do you all stand in a line? Is there a calendar? Come up with something interesting, focusing on your turn in the process you come up with. 
 It will be helpful to remember both the "number in a series" and "turn" meanings for the vocab coming up in the future.
additionalR:
Hints
Try to feel disappointed by this. Strange thing to feel disappointed by, but you were a great sickler. You were going to win the great prize, too (come up with something huge!), but now you're banned for the season.
readingMnemonic: This turn-based rice sickle system is a contest as well! But, you are disappointed to find out that you have been banned from the game because of the performance enhancing steroids you've been taking.

meaningMnemonic: You're taking an axe to a door. You're absolutely crazy. "I HATE THIS PLACE!!" you keep yelling as you smash in the door.
additionalM:
Hints
Why do you hate this place, in particular? Come up with a great reason why to help you to remember this very broad kanji meaning.
additionalR:
Hints
Come up with a weird reason as to why the circus is at this place you hate so much. Why did you come here with your axe? Does it have something to do with the circus show?
readingMnemonic: You finally break through the door and jump in. Inside is a great circus show (しょ). There are elephants, tightrope walkers, bears on unicycles, and more! The greatest show on earth, but why is it here at this place?

meaningMnemonic: The poor alligator was taken far inland by a tsunami. Now his only source of water is a tiny pond that barely fits his body, and doesn't even provide much food.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the alligator riding the tsunami in. When he hits the ground, and the water recedes, he's all alone in a pond, but it doesn't provide much for him. Imagine him looking for food in the little, shallow pond. Imagine him trying to stay wet... it's just not a great situation to be in, unfortunately.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture an alligator crying in a pond full of cheese. It's eating a piece really slowly and weeping.
readingMnemonic: The worst part about this pond is that the only thing for the alligator to eat is cheese (ち). Cheese may be yummy for humans, but alligators hate it. They'd rather eat the cow the cheese came from. Sadly, this pond is full of cheese.

meaningMnemonic: You dig nine holes for your research. You should always do research with nine variables so you can compare them and so there's an uneven number.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine carefully digging nine holes so you can do your research. Hmm, I wonder what kind of research these holes are for...
additionalR:
Hints
Put nine full grown cucumbers into their holes so you can research what happens next.
readingMnemonic: You are researching cucumbers (きゅう)!

meaningMnemonic: Aim the scooter's neck at the road! Scooters are only meant for driving on streets and paths, and if you go the wrong way, you'll probably break your own neck!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine riding your scooter down the road. You're carefully aiming the scooter's neck the right way so you don't end up going out of control and dying.
additionalR:
Hints
Alternate ending: You do a sweet jump, go right through the doughnut hole, take a bite, and land safely back onto the road!
readingMnemonic: To remember the reading どう we use the word "doughnut."

meaningMnemonic: You loiter around with a weapon because you're currently doing your service and duty to your country. You're standing guard outside, waiting just in case something will happen.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing around with a weapon in your hands. It feels more like you're doing nothing, loitering around the wall, but this is how you offer your service to your country, so you have to do it.
additionalR:
Hints
Somehow your duty has become pushing this stubborn, hairy yak away from the entrance to your country. You poke it in the butt with your weapon, but it doesn't seem to care.
readingMnemonic: You're about halfway through your service, when a yak (やく) walks by. It stops directly in front of you and grunts. "Excuse me, Mr. Yak, but it's my duty to escort you away from my country."

meaningMnemonic: A stone lantern is an excellent way to sharpen anything, even in the dark. Your knives, your forks, your spoons, and even your sword.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking around at night and you need to sharpen your sword. You walk up to a stone lantern and rub your sword all over it to sharpen it. Touch the blade. Indeed, it's been sharpened!
additionalR:
Hints
You'll want to remember this character, because he will come up many times throughout your WaniKani journey. Ken the samurai used to work for WaniKani, but then he went rogue because he thought WaniKani wasn't being radical enough. So now he wanders the website carrying his squid friend (who you'll meet later) in a bucket.
To help you visualize him, imagine a samurai with armor made from crab shells, a helmet that is just an alligator head, and swords with crab claw hand guards. His great beard and mustache are styled in the shape of whatever kanji is giving you the most trouble at the time.
readingMnemonic: Why did you sharpen your blade? Because you are about to do battle with Ken (けん), the famous samurai warrior.

meaningMnemonic: The self radical is a bit modified, with things sticking out, but that’s because it’s falling down a slide.
additionalM:
Hints
Apparently, you’re having some kind of internal crisis. Come up with a rough one and you’ll remember this kanji better.
additionalR:
Hints
Just make the tumble and shin hit as painful as possible in your imagination and you’ll surely remember this kanji’s on’yomi.
readingMnemonic: You’re falling down this metaphorical slide… And then you hit something… and you hit it really hard. It’s your metaphorical shin (しん). You split it in half and it’s at a right angle. The pain is incredible (shins have a lot of nerves!). It may have been broken, and you may not be able to walk correctly again… metaphorically speaking, that is.

meaningMnemonic: A coffin has been left out in the sun for too long. When dead bodies are out in the sun like this, they really begin to decompose. You are wondering who this person is, though. You can't tell because it's fallen apart too much. You look on the coffin. There's a label, but it only says "someone."
additionalM:
Hints
Smell the stench of the decomposing body. Also, feel really curious as to who this person is. It came from somewhere that gives you a reason to believe it's someone you know. Then, feel the disappointment as you read the label that says "someone" instead of an actual name. "Someone," you repeat. "Someone."
additionalR:
Hints
How strange that a shaman was delivered to you this way! Come up with a story explaining why this shaman's body is here at your door, rotting in the sun. Make it ridiculous and interesting so you remember it.
readingMnemonic: To remember the sound しゃ we use "shaman."

meaningMnemonic: The branch radical and the branch kanji are the same! This kanji also means support. To remember it, think about a tree with lots of branches. The branches support each other and the trunk of the tree. If you were to climb the tree, the branches would be able to support your weight too!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a branch supporting the weight of you, your entire family, and maybe a few friends.
additionalR:
Hints
The big sheep walks up the side of the tree with its weird hooves and starts to put its weight on the branch. "No no no!" you and your whole family scream. The branch can't support the weight of the sheep. It snaps! You all tumble to the ground.
The end.
readingMnemonic: You're happily sitting on this branch, letting it support all this weight, when a sheep (し) starts to climb the tree. A very, very big sheep. Uh oh... no no, sheep. If you get on this branch it won't be able to support all this weight!!!

meaningMnemonic: Say it with your tongue. If you do, you'll be able to talk. You'll be able to speak.
additionalM:
Hints
Your problem is you weren't saying it with your tongue before. Once you start using your tongue, you're able to speak suddenly!
additionalR:
Hints
You decided to teach a walrus how to speak because it seemed like the hardest thing to teach, with its tusks and all that. It turned out to be really easy. Although, you may have picked the Justin Long walrus, by accident. Either way, this walrus can speak! And you definitely (probably) helped.
readingMnemonic: If something uses their tongue, it will be able to talk and speak. To prove this, you teach a walrus (わ) to use its tongue, and lo and behold, it speaks to you!

meaningMnemonic: In your fingers is a weapon, so you throw it. Maybe you're angry and you threw the weapon at a person you don't like. Maybe you're a pacifist and you threw it away so no one else could use it. Either way, when you have a weapon in your fingers you have to throw it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a weapon in between your fingers. It doesn't matter what kind. Now feel the weight as you throw it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine throwing the weapon in your fingers just before you walk into とうきょう. You can see the lights, smell the smells! Throw your weapons and your cares away!
readingMnemonic: You throw your weapon away because you're about to enter とうきょう and there are no weapons allowed there. There is, however, a big pile of thrown away weapons by the border, which is where you're throwing yours right now.

meaningMnemonic: You want to take a measurement of what you're writing to make sure it's long enough to hand in to your professor, when you realize it's the opposite of what you should be doing. You don't measure writing, you check things like word count and page numbers. Now it's going to be you versus the teacher on who determines how long this thing you're writing should be.
additionalM:
Hints
Okay. It's going to be you versus the teacher. Subject? Measuring physical length versus checking word count.
additionalR:
Hints
Next to your nicely measured writing, tape a brand new tie with a sticky note that says, "I hope this isn't the opposite of what you want, because I really need this A."
readingMnemonic: You let your nerves get the better of you and right when it's about to be you versus your professor, you hand him a new tie (たい). Is this also the opposite of what you should be doing? Probably, since it's bribery. But no one can say no to a tie, right?

meaningMnemonic: You’re sitting on a stool and someone cleats you in the forehead as part of an acceptance ritual. It’s for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. You got knocked off the stool, and the cleats really hurt your forehead, but you’re just glad to have been accepted.
additionalM:
Hints
You’re dealing with a lot of mixed emotions right now. You feel the pain from being cleated in the forehead and knocked clean off your stool, but you’re also glad to have finally been accepted into the soccer club. Suppress your pain. Accept this honor.
additionalR:
Hints
Did you ever play soccer as a kid? Do you remember accepting a small juice box into your little kid hands during halftime? Apparently pros drink the same ones.
readingMnemonic: After you've been accepted, they give you a small juice (じゅ) box to help you recover from the trauma of getting kicked. And you receive it with grace.

meaningMnemonic: You put a cross in the mouth of a wolverine. What a strange action. Why would you do such a thing? The fact of the matter is that you're not too sure why you put that cross in the wolverine's mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine that poor wolverine standing in front of you looking confused, with a cross in its mouth.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Jesus gently taking the cross out of the wolverine's mouth. What a swell dude.
readingMnemonic: This action doesn't impress Jesus (じ), who appears and gently removes the cross from the wolverine's mouth.

meaningMnemonic: A beast king with big horns marries a true beauty. The big horned king may look like a beast, but the beauty loves him for what’s inside. That is where true beauty lies.
additionalM:
Hints
I’m sure you know of Beauty and the Beast. Remember that movie? Think of the king and his big horns. And remember the beauty that loved him.
additionalR:
Hints
It’s a Disney movie. Everyone knows about it. How many times have you seen it? Remember the movie Beauty and the Beast.
readingMnemonic: Beauty and the who? Beauty and the Beast (び). The Beast. That’s right. Beauty and the Beast! How could you forget?

meaningMnemonic: What does your mama tell you to do in the street? Look before you cross! You gotta do it beforehand, or it could be too late.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself about to cross the street, and your mama saying in your ear: "always look beforehand"!
additionalR:
Hints
As you cross the road, you pick up the yo-yo and put it in your pocket. You're really glad you looked beforehand, because you now have a yo-yo!
readingMnemonic: As you look beforehand, you see a yo-yo (よ) lying in the street.

meaningMnemonic: Take the moon stamp on the stool in front of you and use it on all of your clothes. Now even if you sell or lose a piece of clothing, you'll be able to find it again by checking for your special moon stamp.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine placing each piece of clothing you own onto the stool and carefully stamping them with a symbol of the moon. This should stop people from stealing all of your clothes!
additionalR:
Hints
Your friend turns red and tries to pull the clothes back, "F**k you!" they yell. "No, f**k you, these are my clothes and I have proof this time!"
readingMnemonic: A few days later you're with a friend when you recognize the clothes they're wearing. You grab it, rip it off, and scream, "F**k (ふく) you!" There is your moon stamp! These are your clothes!!

meaningMnemonic: A yurt's stool is always placed at certain degrees. The degrees change depending on specific occurrences.
additionalM:
Hints
Since a yurt is round, the stool has to be angled at certain degrees. It's part of yurt culture. Imagine someone adjusting the stool with a measurement tool to adjust it to an exact degree.
additionalR:
Hints
The dog changes its degrees at every occurrence of the stool changing. Picture the dog leaning at the exact degree the stool is at.
readingMnemonic: Also angled at exact degrees is the dog (ど).

meaningMnemonic: Once you remove the lantern from the tent, we will be ready for departure. We can’t leave the lantern inside of the tent; that’s a fire hazard. We’d best take it with us before the departure. Don’t you agree?
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the heat from the lantern. It’s not quite as comforting as being inside a tent, but it’s better than nothing. The lantern will light your way on your departure.
additionalR:
Hints
How cold and unprotected would your head be without a hat? Very. Taking hats along with departures is integral to their success. Imagine how unsafe you would feel with no hats. That’s no departure I want to set out on.
readingMnemonic: Oh! Don’t forget your hats (はつ) either. Wouldn’t want to start a departure without hats or a lantern. That’d be a short journey.

meaningMnemonic: A roof is correct only if you determine that it is.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at a roof, and someone asks you, "Is this roof correct?"
"I determine it is."
additionalR:
Hints
"Because of my tater tot roof test, I have once again determined it is correct."
readingMnemonic: You determined it, but you still have to test this determination. You go to the top and roll a tater (てい) tot down the roof. Tater tots will only roll down a perfectly correct roof.

meaningMnemonic: You say things around a fire. In fact there are two fires, and you're discussing something that's really important to you with a group of people, all sitting around two nice campfires.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself next to the two campfires, having a heart-to-heart discussion. What are you saying?
additionalR:
Hints
If you try to discuss something all night and past dawn, you'll burn out. Take the day, think, then tonight you can try to discuss it again.
readingMnemonic: You discuss in this intense, fiery way all the way until dawn (だん), but no longer! Once dawn comes the discussion needs to be concluded.

meaningMnemonic: Sometimes life gives you a kick, and you have to express yourself to deal with it!
additionalM:
Hints
Think of the last time life gave you a kick, and how you expressed that pain to make it go away.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself saying it more like ひょう, though, so your friend has to try to figure out what you're saying.
readingMnemonic: You need to express yourself, so you call up a friend and say “Heyo!” (ひょう).

meaningMnemonic: Under your roof in winter there are more mouths to feed because you let guests stay with you when it's cold. Some of them aren't family, so they have to pay to stay under your roof and get food. Those are customers.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the hungry guests and customers under your roof, eating your food and sleeping on your floor.
additionalR:
Hints
Kyaku looks just like any other customer. Picture a stereotypical "customer" type person in your head.
readingMnemonic: One of your guests is a regular named Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku is always staying over at one place or another, so everyone knows their name.

meaningMnemonic: The heavy radical and the heavy kanji are the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine holding a real jewel in your right hand and a fake jewel in your left. The one in your right hand is suuuuupeerrr heavy!
readingMnemonic: In your hand is a very heavy jewel (じゅう). Real jewels are always heavier than they look.

meaningMnemonic: You need to get your fingers around a temple if you want to hold it. Is the temple too big? Hold smaller temples you can buy in the temple's souvenir shop.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding a tiny temple in your fingers. Hold it up to the light. Hold it on the train. Hold it while you sleep.
additionalR:
Hints
Jesus likes when you hold things like temples. He probably likes when you hold other things too, like ice cream, puppies, and homeless peoples' hands.
readingMnemonic: As you hold the temple you hear a voice. You look down through your fingers and see a tiny Jesus (じ). He's smiling and gives you a thumbs up. Aww, thanks Jesus!

meaningMnemonic: When you're in prison, whoever ends up with the shellfish will lose. It's the game all prisoners play. It's like keep away from the shellfish. And if you end up with the shellfish BZZZZTT that's it, you're the loser.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine that it's your first day in prison. You're walking around the yard, minding your own business, when suddenly a shellfish smacks you right in the head and falls into your open hands. "HAHA YOU LOSE!" someone shouts.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you have to try to make some other fool lose. Otherwise you'll be the loser fool forever.
readingMnemonic: If you lose, you're a fool (ふ). All you had to do was not hold the prison shellfish. It really shouldn't have been that hard to not lose, ya fool.

meaningMnemonic: You need to look a tree in the eye to gain a mutual respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.
additionalM:
Hints
It's the same with humans, you know? If you want to have a mutual relationship you need to be able to look each other in the eyes. If you're too embarrassed, or you look down on them, then that isn't mutual respect!
additionalR:
Hints
This is basically a FernGully moment, you know? You can feel the tree's pain like it's your pain. It's that kind of mutual sharing of souls you need.
readingMnemonic: If your respect for the tree is mutual with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's soul (そう). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding."

meaningMnemonic: A woman who pilots a helicopter will have the insatiable need for something. She doesn't know what it is. But she needs it. And that's why she's flying around looking for it!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the woman in the helicopter needing something. She's looking around. Searching. But she doesn't know what it is!
additionalR:
Hints
What does she need? Yogurt!
readingMnemonic: Finally she knows what she needs! It's yogurt (よう)! Delicious, creamy yogurt!

meaningMnemonic: There's a standing tree that you're taking an axe to. You're going to cut down this tree to let a new tree grow.
additionalM:
Hints
As you imagine yourself cutting down the standing tree, think about what new tree you'll plant in its place.
additionalR:
Hints
Only your shin got hit, so focus all your imaginary pain down there. Try to pull out the splinters. Ouch!
readingMnemonic: You cut down the tree to make room for a new one, but it falls on your shin (しん).

meaningMnemonic: The clown building is over in that part of town. We keep the clown part as separate as we can from the rest of the normal people. In fact, the entire clown education department and their clown clubs have to stay in their part, they can't come in ours.
additionalM:
Hints
Of course, we feel terrible about forcing the clowns into their own part of town. It's not that they're lesser than us, it's just that we don't like them.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of the clowns, trapped in their weird clown part of town, drinking booze and smashing each other over the heads with the bottles. You're glad you don't live in that part.
readingMnemonic: You see, that part of town is full of booze (ぶ). Clowns need a lot of booze to keep their charade going, so we just let them have it. But they aren't allowed in our part anymore, because they all stink of nasty clown booze.

meaningMnemonic: When everyone has grain in their mouth, you will have peace. That is the Japanese style of doing things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine Japanese people with grain in their mouth. The whole country is at peace.
additionalR:
Hints
The walruses also achieve peace by putting grain in every walrus' mouth, following the Japanese style.
readingMnemonic: Peace is the Japanese style. The walruses (わ) living off of Japan see this, and start to emulate.

meaningMnemonic: The eye of a small lion gazes upon the prefecture that will one day become his. He’s a small lion prince, but once he grows up, everything reflected in his eye will be his prefecture to rule over.
additionalM:
Hints
You remember the old classic movie about the white lion and his prefecture. No? Oh, you're thinking of that big studio knock off. That's okay, whatever makes you remember the laws of prefectural rule.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Ken protecting the prefecture, punching hyenas in the face, and yelling, "This may just be a prefecture, not a country, but I'll give it my all for my lion king!"
readingMnemonic: This small lion's prefecture is being protected by Ken (けん) the samurai because the lion is too small to protect all of this land himself. Ken the samurai is used to wandering far and wide, so one, eye-sized prefecture is nothing to him.

meaningMnemonic: The mouth of a tree leader is all about trying to preserve the trees. In fact, he guarantees that he will preserve the trees if it's the last thing he does.
additionalM:
Hints
Basically, a tree leader is someone who stands up for trees. Mostly he talks, but that can be a powerful skill to have.
additionalR:
Hints
What a terrible scene. Focus on the fact that they're using a horrible, modified back hoe. It's more like a weapon than a back hoe, and they show no mercy at all.
readingMnemonic: He chains himself to a tree to preserve them. But, unfortunately, the lumberjacks just take a giant back hoe (ほ) and tear this tree leader and the tree he's attached to in half.

meaningMnemonic: Your scooter is anti scoot. It doesn't want to run. So you have to return it.
additionalM:
Hints
Unfortunately, now you have to return to the store to return this scooter, but you have no scooter to get there with. Ugh.
additionalR:
Hints
The employee leans down toward you in hen form and says, "Ooh, I'm sorry. We don't take returns from hens. You'll have to just return home."
readingMnemonic: You return to the store and wait in line to return the scooter but the person working returns doesn't want you to return it. He stares you dead in the eyes, waves his hand, and turns you into a hen (へん)!

meaningMnemonic: You put a grain in your mouth and let it take a ride. This kanji has the same radicals as 和, but this time the grain is in your mouth, which is why there's little pieces of grain sticking out of the 口 part ;)
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine you're a car or a train and the grain is a person. It's going for a nice ride in your mouth!
additionalR:
Hints
Now the nori is going for a ride too, woohoo!
readingMnemonic: You decide the grain is probably lonely on this ride alone, so you add some nori (の) seaweed, so it has a friend.

meaningMnemonic: Some of your private dirt is on the ground, so you stick a flag into it. Then on this private land you claimed, you build a roof. Under the roof you also build some shops and stores.
additionalM:
Hints
That's the natural next progression of claiming some land. Building a roof upon it and building some shops and stores inside. You'll see why in a moment.
additionalR:
Hints
You have yourself a whole Yankees stadium, and all it took was a roof and some shops / stores! If you build it, they will come.
readingMnemonic: The roof covering the dirt is there so that the Yankees (や) can play baseball year round. The stores and shops are there to sell hot dogs and Yankees memorabilia.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a samurai with (just) his forehead and legs. Everything in between is missing. What happened to everything in between? He was low on money, so he had to sell it all, leaving him with only the top and the bottom.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this terrifying samurai. You have legs… okay, that’s normal. But, then you have just a giant forehead on the top of everything else, walking around. It's pretty scary that someone would sell such important parts of their body.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine saying, "Bye," loudly into the forehead of a samurai trying to sell you the rest of their face. If you say it loud enough it will distract them while you run away.
readingMnemonic: If you see a samurai trying to sell all their body parts here's what you should say, "Bye (ばい)!" and just get the heck out of there. Actually, if anyone tries to sell you a body part you should probably say bye over and over until you can get away from them.

meaningMnemonic: On its scooter, a horned creature from heaven will take things you want to send there.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the horned thing on its scooter, a big messenger bag over its shoulder with the kanji for heaven on it. "You got somethin' you want me to send?" it mutters.
additionalR:
Hints
You put your soul into an envelope, stick a stamp on it, and hand it off to be sent to heaven. Bye bye! I hope this doesn't have any negative effects on your body!
readingMnemonic: You want to send your soul (そう) to heaven. I mean, you don't want it to go to some of those other places you've heard of, so why not send your soul?

meaningMnemonic: Old flowers are suffering because they're old.
additionalM:
Hints
Old things go through a lot of suffering because their bodies are breaking down. Flowers are no different from you and me.
additionalR:
Hints
No one can resist a good cookie. It will ease your suffering, or at least distract you for a little bit.
readingMnemonic: If an old flower (or person) is suffering, give them a cookie (く).

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami is going to last an eternity you better learn how to swim now. We'll be under water for the rest of time and if you can't swim you're not gonna make it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture most of the earth's population already swimming on the tsunami that will last the rest of eternity. Your floaties and life preservers would help you through this mess. You need to swim!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself swimming in the tsunami with everyone else. You can't really talk to them, you're too busy swimming for your life, so you just shout "Oy!" to them and they shout it back.
readingMnemonic: Oy (およ)! Oy, stop daydreaming about swimming and actually do it!

meaningMnemonic: Your leader is very anti-everything, making it all temporary. You get a new shirt, "I'm anti shirts!" he yells, and out it goes.
additionalM:
Hints
He tires of things so quickly, you hardly have time to get used to them before they're gone.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of the temporary cars he's tried filling up an entire junkyard. They're all a little different, but in the end they were all just temporary fads.
readingMnemonic: The leader's most temporary possession is his car (か). Or... cars, because they're all very temporary. He buys one, drives it around, and then suddenly he's anti red car. He needs a blue one!

meaningMnemonic: A horse and a squid taking a test.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the horse and the squid sitting at desks in a big room, scribbling madly on their tests. They're both nervous because this test is really important.
additionalR:
Hints
To make sure the horse and the squid don't cheat on the test, Ken (けん) the samurai is watching them closely, pacing up and down. Every now and then, he waves his katana menacingly.
readingMnemonic: The test is being supervised by Ken (けん) the samurai.

meaningMnemonic: A winged cow is flying in the air. What a strange thing! You’ve heard of flying pigs before, but cows? This is a new and strange thing indeed! Cows with wings! What a silly thing to imagine.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if cows could fly. Wouldn’t you be jealous of them? I mean, if a cow can fly, any old thing should be able to, right?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a thing like flying boots. Do you believe such a thing could be real?
readingMnemonic: You want a thing to help you fly with the cow so you put on your flying boots (ぶつ). Your flying boots are a pretty strange thing in themselves, but they're the only way you can keep up.

meaningMnemonic: An eye and fins litter the ground. What happened? You killed a fish. You must hide the murder tool before someone finds out it was you.
additionalM:
Hints
You feel the panic upon realizing what you've just done. This is murder in the first degree. You used a terrible tool to do it, and now you must hide it.
additionalR:
Hints
That goo is really slimy. It’s disgusting. You feel sick to your stomach. Please don’t throw up, there’s already enough junk on the ground with the eye and fins and all.
readingMnemonic: There’s goo (ぐ) all over your hands. Goopy goo. It’s the guts of the fish you just killed and it’s dripping off of the tool as well. Yuck.

meaningMnemonic: Climb onto the roof in spring to see the truth. The world is waking back up from winter and revealing the reality of what it is all around you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sitting comfortably on your roof as the world around you changes to spring. Snow melts and reveals all of the truths that have been obscured and hidden in winter.
additionalR:
Hints
Gee! Two babies! Reality sure is lovely.
readingMnemonic: At the moment, you're trying to learn the truth about the deer that is coming out of the snowy woods when you see not one, but two baby deer appear with it! Gee! Two (じつ) babies! You keep looking around and realize that all of the animals seem to have two babies that they had hidden in the snow.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to say something at a ceremony for construction workers you're going to have to try really hard. Construction is loud, so if you want to be heard you have to attempt to be louder than the drilling and smashing and digging and handing out of awards.
additionalM:
Hints
Try to imagine trying this hard to be heard. The construction workers are all screaming at each other with ease. It's so hard for you to try and keep up with their volume!
additionalR:
Hints
Huh. You should have thought to try this sheep technique earlier.
readingMnemonic: You try to get their attention the only way you know how, by lifting a sheep (し) above your head. The sheep baas and suddenly everything is silent, all eyes are on you. Well, they're on the sheep.

meaningMnemonic: A good leader can put the ground's history to great use. You are a good leader. You have studied the ground and dirt of the earth your entire life. You know the history of the ground and you know how to use it to lead your people.
additionalM:
Hints
Smell the ground. Waft the earthy smell of history into your leader-like nostrils. What does it smell like? It smells useful. And also like ground.
additionalR:
Hints
When you use the ground for sheep like this, your people rejoice. You're the best leader ever! You always use everything to your advantage!
readingMnemonic: You use the ground to raise sheep (し). When you were down there sniffing around you realized that your people will flourish best if you use this land for grazing and raising sheep.

meaningMnemonic: The moon grants a gladiator its power so he will win! Victory will be his!
additionalM:
Hints
Watch as the moon's power fills the gladiator. He starts to glow, grows larger, and has some craters on his face now. Well.. okay.
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun is only interested in people who win. But you probably could have guessed that already.
readingMnemonic: He wins over and over again, and soon the Shougun (しょう) is even rooting for him. In fact, the Shougun claims him as his personal gladiator of choice.

meaningMnemonic: All the rice paddies are jammed into the world.
additionalM:
Hints
The world is basically just a bunch of rice paddies smooshed together, if you think about it.
additionalR:
Hints
A rice paddy is mostly made up of water, just like our world, and you don't want to have wet feet. Use the power of your kayak to become a world traveler.
readingMnemonic: To get around this world of rice paddies, you need to use a kayak (かい).

meaningMnemonic: You give your scooter to a turkey so that it can advance. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine picking up the turkey and putting it on your scooter. Of course, you give it your helmet as well, safety first.
additionalR:
Hints
Silly turkey, you can't advance that fast, of course you'll hurt your shins. It's better to advance slowly, but I guess I couldn't expect you to know that.
readingMnemonic: You wave as the turkey advances into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its shins (しん) almost immediately. Ah!

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami is an alcoholic beverage containing a lot of alcohol. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it.
additionalM:
Hints
It’s made with spiced rum, coconut rum, and dark rum. Imagine yourself on a sandy beach drinking this cocktail. Feel the sun on your face and the wind in your hair as you sip on this fruity and rummy alcoholic beverage known as a tsunami. You could even picture an actual tsunami in the water coming right for you. I wouldn’t recommend it though—actual tsunami are scary, not drinkable and delicious.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the alcohol flowing down this long chute from somewhere far away. You try to see where it's coming from, but all you can see is this long, long chute stretching along the entire beach, until it disappears into the distance. You should probably be concerned that you're nonstop drinking alcohol from a random chute, but it tastes so good!
readingMnemonic: As you lay on this beach, the alcohol keeps coming down a chute (しゅ), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute.

meaningMnemonic: If you give a woman a machine she'll begin learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to start before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a woman seeing a new machine and beginning work on it right away to see how she can start it up.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a machine starting up as the woman begins to shear the sheep. Picture the sheep staring at you, staring at it.
readingMnemonic: Actually, before she can begin, she has to shear the sheep (し) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe!

meaningMnemonic: If a sheep is having trouble trying to eat a fish with spikes on its fins, then the sheep probably has no business trying to eat it in the first place. Don’t sheep usually eat like, grass and stuff? What is this sheep doing trying to eat a fish with spikes on its fins? What silly business this is.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this crazy sheep. Why is it trying to eat this fish? This sheep is blood crazed. Blood crazed for fish meat, especially the meat from fish with spikes on their fins. This crazed sheep means business.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine you’re at an Asian style restaurant and you just ordered a big plate of gyoza dumplings. Next thing you know, this crazy sheep busts through the front door and starts devouring all your gyoza! Where did this sheep come from and why does he love gyoza so much!?
readingMnemonic: What’s this? The sheep is also trying to eat some gyoza (ぎょう) dumplings! Where will this sheep’s madness end? First spikey finned fish and now gyoza? This is some crazy business.

meaningMnemonic: If you get stabbed in the eye twenty times with bamboo, you’re going to have a hard time beginning to calculate where anything is. Taking a bamboo shoot to the eye is no pleasant experience, especially if done twenty times. You’d be blinded for sure. And a newly blinded person is going to have one heck of a time calculating where everything is without the power of sight.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine getting jabbed with a bamboo shoot. Now imagine getting jabbed in the eye with a bamboo shoot. It’s going to hurt. Try and calculate exactly how painful this would be and imagine it happening to you.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this evil Asian Santa-san, clad in blood red garments and brandishing pointed bamboo shoots in each hand. He’s a cold and calculating madman! You’d better start studying! Santa-san is watching!
readingMnemonic: Do you know how Santa-san (さん) punishes naughty boys and girls in Asia? He doesn’t give them coal, Santa-san tortures them with twenty bamboo jabs to the eye. Yikes. Do you know how Santa-san calculates who is naughty and who is nice? By their school grades, of course.

meaningMnemonic: When you ride your scooter, your forehead sticks out of the car, so you have to carry it. The scooter doesn't fit in the car when you aren't on it though, so you have to carry it out the window. And it takes a lot of luck not to get clipped by a car or accidentally take out a pedestrian with it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to carry your scooter out the window. Your forehead is still sticking out of the car as you do this.
additionalR:
Hints
It's hard enough to carry a scooter while you drive, but now you have to try to keep yourself and it dry with an umbrella too.
readingMnemonic: As you carry the scooter, your luck turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your umbrella (うん). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella outside of the car.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hit ancient China and formed the Chinese country we know now as... China!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the world way far away, from space. You see a giant tsunami carve out a massive chunk of land to the west of Japan on the main continent. Slowly the tsunami waters recede, leaving the outline of China.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the Khan takes China for himself. A tiny little flag with a horse on it is raised in the middle, for all of the Chinese people to see. Hmm, this could be a problem.
readingMnemonic: You peer closer at China and realize the borders are inching inward, even though the tsunami is already gone. You look even closer and see the Mongols, being led by Genghis Khan (かん) moving in to conquer all of the Chinese people living in China!

meaningMnemonic: When a bird opens its mouth, you’re most likely to hear a chirp. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself out in the wilderness on a sunny spring day. The weather is perfect and the scenery is beautiful. The only sound you can hear is the chirp of birds throughout the woods around you. It’s very peaceful.
additionalR:
Hints
Nature is a great place to clear your mind and relax. Picture yourself in nature’s wilderness once again. The sun on your face, the wind in your hair, the grass beneath your feet, and the chirps of birds in the air. It’s quite nice.
readingMnemonic: The best place to experience the chirp chirping of birds is when you’re out in nature (な). You’re not going to hear birds chirping in a crowded city, so you need to get out into nature to fully experience the birds and their chirps.

meaningMnemonic: You chase a turkey up a tree to collect it. At least, you will once you've gathered enough turkeys into this one tree.
additionalM:
Hints
Collect another turkey, send it flying and gobbling up into the tree next to the other one.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the nice, feathered shoes you'll be able to make once you've gathered all of these turkeys together. Ohoho, you can't wait! Go collect another turkey!
readingMnemonic: Once you've collected enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a shoe (しゅう). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean gathering even more turkeys!

meaningMnemonic: You don't want to keep all the alcohol to yourself (oneself), so you distribute it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!
additionalM:
Hints
Don't be that person who keeps the alcohol all to themselves. Distribute it to all of the legally-aged people you know!
additionalR:
Hints
This becomes the haiku you say before every party, every potluck, and every night out at the bar. You even get it tattoo'd to your arm.
readingMnemonic: As you distribute the alcohol you say a haiku (はい):

meaningMnemonic: You can eat all you want, but you'll still lack something to drink. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine eating and eating and lacking a delicious, cold, thirst-quenching drink. Your mouth is dry. You have to drink something, anything!
additionalR:
Hints
Luckily, this nori isn't dried and pressed like they usually are, and you manage to make a bright green nori drink. You gulp it down, and even though it tastes like the ocean, it hits the spot!
readingMnemonic: You get desperate for a drink and put some nori (の) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own.

meaningMnemonic: The thread of winter splits in two when the year comes to an end. One half symbolizes the year you were just in, and the other symbolizes the new year beginning, cutting winter in half and finishing off the year.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the threads that symbolize winter splitting in two to mark the end of the year. Winter isn't finished though, it's only half done.
additionalR:
Hints
It's the end of the year, so it's time for new shoe laces!
readingMnemonic: Right as winter ends you grab the two threads and lace them into your shoes (しゅう). Oh, you thought these were metaphorical? No they're real threads, although, they're technically shoe laces now.

meaningMnemonic: Here you stand, a hair’s breadth away from the edge of a cliff, when out of nowhere a geoduck slaps you right in the face. Geoducks are gross, and you back away from the edge of the cliff you were standing but a hair’s breadth away from just before. Your face is all gooey from the geoduck’s slimy residue.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being slapped in the face with a geoduck. It’s probably one of the worst things that could ever happen to someone. Those things are disgusting. Now you have geoduck goo all over your face. It’s sticky and slimy and gross.
additionalR:
Hints
Cows are big animals. So you probably got hit in the face with that geoduck pretty hard. Feel the geoduck shaped welt starting to form on the side of your face. It’s very painful and stings a lot.
readingMnemonic: But where did that geoduck come from anyway? As you turn around from the cliff edge, wiping the goop from your face and out of your eyes, you see an angry cow (かお). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with this geoduck. I know not the reason, but this cow is most definitely not happy with you.

meaningMnemonic: A violent tsunami causes flowers to be ripped from the branches of trees and they swirl around and kiss your face gently as they fall. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew many flowers all about. It’s a pretty sight amongst all the destruction.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being out in this tsunami induced storm. You can feel the rain and wind on your skin – you’re wet, cold, and scared. But you see some flowers being blown to the ground and you are mesmerized by the dance they do on the wind before they finally fall to the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine running around catching the flowers as they fall. Imagine placing each little petal onto the rack to keep it safe and dry.
readingMnemonic: You want to save these flowers you see falling in around you, so you take out a drying rack (らく) and place them carefully on it. Now whenever you feel scared, you can look at the flowers on this rack and you won't be scared anymore.

meaningMnemonic: You blast your music loud so it causes a landslide, revealing the perfect soil for farming! Musically moved dirt is perfect for agriculture.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine slowly turning up your big boombox until your ears hurt and the ground beneath your feet is vibrating with the beat. Soon you and the boombox are sliding with all of the earth down the hill and onto your farmland. Hooray, now the farming can begin!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Nostradamus flailing his arms and trying to explain his vision to the farmers at the time. He knows that if they listen their farming techniques will improve, but they're looking at him like he's nuts.
readingMnemonic: The first person to come up with this farming method was Nostradamus (のう), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth."

meaningMnemonic: You jump on your scooter with a big bundle to go as fast as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how fast you can go on your scooter holding this bundle. It's way faster than trying to go on foot, that's for sure!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine riding the scooter as fast as you can in just your socks. You can feel the wind pulling them off your feet!
readingMnemonic: You were going so fast, you only put on socks (そく). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks.

meaningMnemonic: If a geoduck eats lots of beans, its head will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, a geoduck’s head will grow incredibly large. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine, if you will, a geoduck. Now imagine that same geoduck with a massive head. It looks ridiculous, and more disgusting than ever. It’s actually really creeping you out, because the head keeps getting larger as the geoduck eats more beans. Ew.
additionalR:
Hints
Remember how gross geoducks are? Of course you do. Now imagine one exploding right in front of you. You’ve got geoduck mess all over yourself. It’s gross, slimy, sticky, and covering you from head to toe. It’s wretched.
readingMnemonic: As the geoduck eats more and more beans, its head gets bigger and bigger until finally the geoduck’s head explodes like an atomic (あたま) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of the geoduck’s massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout.

meaningMnemonic: If you press your ear up to a gate, you’re likely to hear what’s going on on the other side. The other people on the other side won’t know you are listening to their conversation because you are so sneaky and clever. They’ve no idea you’re on the other side of the gate hearing every word they say.
additionalM:
Hints
I’m sure you’ve pressed your ear up against a wall, door, or gate at sometime to hear what’s going on on the other side of it. Remember back to a time you did this and how sneaky you felt listening in on people without them knowing. You sneaky frood, you.
additionalR:
Hints
I’m sure many of you were forced to play the recorder in school at some point and were made to play the song known as hot cross buns. Picture yourself playing this song and remember the melody when you see this kanji.
readingMnemonic: From the other side of the gate, you hear one of the people on the other side start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as “Hot Cross Buns (ぶん).” You haven’t heard this song in a long time. “Hot cross buns… hot cross buns~”

meaningMnemonic: This building has a roof and will teach you about the origin of many things. It's an institution!
additionalM:
Hints
Institutions are places of learning, but they have to be a physical place with a roof and all that. If you're learning out in a field somewhere, that's probably not a proper institution.
additionalR:
Hints
Just remember, it's an IN-stitution, and you'll know this reading easy-peasy.
readingMnemonic: What does institution start with? In (いん)!

meaningMnemonic: You say something about the circumference of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to investigate something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet tone of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them.
additionalM:
Hints
Because the radical circumference is in play, you can think of the crime scene you're investigating as a statue of a giant globe, and you're doing a circumference around it. Then, in the reading, we'll think about what you'll say.
additionalR:
Hints
From what you know about evil Mrs. Chou, you probably could have guessed it was her. The "Circumference Investigation" is now over, though you do still have to catch the perp, Mrs. Chou.
readingMnemonic: "I came here to investigate this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. Chou (ちょう)!"

meaningMnemonic: You look at some gold and notice a fault in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless iron!
additionalM:
Hints
You think you've found a ton of gold bars! Imagine being so happy about this. Then, imagine your heart dropping in your chest when you notice the fault. Then, it dropping down even farther when you figure out it's merely iron.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch a trailer on YouTube for Tetsuo the Iron Man. Go ahead, do it now – I’ll wait. Did you watch it? Remember that nonsense every time you see this kanji.
readingMnemonic: Do you know that movie, Tetsuo (てつ) the Iron Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever.

meaningMnemonic: What you say between five mouths is a language. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture these five mouths saying the same language to each other. They can understand each other! The mouths are smiling and laughing too.
additionalR:
Hints
Godzilla speaks a language some people understand! You wish you knew this earlier, then you might have been able to stop some of his destruction. Try to say, "Hey Godzilla, please stop destroying my city," in his language. It's a lot of growling and yelling. He doesn't seem to understand you. You better practice your pronunciation.
readingMnemonic: Another mouth joins in speaking the language, but it's green and scaled and... it's Godzilla's (ご) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too.

meaningMnemonic: In the world of flowers and trees, the most important thing is the leaf. Leaves are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!
additionalM:
Hints
Leaves, no matter how little, are the most important thing in the world for them.
additionalR:
Hints
は is the sound of a leaf coming into existence. Whenever you see a plant from now on, hear the little ha sound it makes when each leaf pops out of its body.
readingMnemonic: Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The leaf pops out and it shouts, "Ha (は)!"

meaningMnemonic: You find some white feathers and you want to learn more about where they came from and what they're made of.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself in a library poring through huge tomes on birds, feathers, and the history of white birds. You want to learn everything you can!
additionalR:
Hints
Oh geez, oh no. You better learn how to control these shoes before you—CRASH!!! Welp, you just shot through a plane. You need to learn more before you act next time.
readingMnemonic: You learn that you should tie these white feathers to your shoes (しゅう). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building.

meaningMnemonic: A tombstone may be heavy for a human, but to a car, they’re relatively lightweight. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be lightweight and easy to transport.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself trying to move a huge slab tombstone. It’s difficult, no? I bet you wish you had a car or some other vehicle to make the process much less painful. Your arms are getting sore from carrying the tombstone and you’re getting sweaty and hot from all the work. What you would do for a car with air conditioning.
additionalR:
Hints
Remember all that hard work you were doing before and how you got all sweaty and gross? Now imagine yourself inside of a nice car with air conditioning, and the tombstone in the trunk. It feels great doesn’t it? The air conditioning is perfect, and driving a car is much easier than carrying a tombstone around.
readingMnemonic: What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right – a car (かる). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but lightweight pebbles!

meaningMnemonic: If someone falls overboard while you're white water rafting, you can use a long piece of thread as a life line. Sure it might be thin, but a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard! Those white water rapids are vicious.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you're the person who fell overboard. The white water is rushing violently and it is deathly cold. Feel the water and freezing temperature on your skin. But look! Someone has thrown you a line of thread! You're saved!
additionalR:
Hints
Coming out of the rushing water, this centaur is like an angel sent from heaven. He's just saved your life. Imagine the happiness and gratitude you feel towards this centaur as you are pulled to safety by that line of thread.
readingMnemonic: The person who threw you that line of thread is actually a centaur (せん). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off.

meaningMnemonic: Let the sun shine into your ear while sitting on a stool and make sure most of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone has ever.
additionalM:
Hints
Most of the sun is getting into your ear, but not all of it. Darn, maybe you should try angling yourself a different way.
additionalR:
Hints
Install the part into your cyborg. As long as most of the sun gets into its human ear, most of its cyborg bits will have power.
readingMnemonic: Most of this is for your cyborg (さい). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts.

meaningMnemonic: A gate with a lantern is open for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being a traveler, walking around the outside of a huge walled city. You really need to get inside but all of the gates are closed. Finally, you see a single, bright lantern marking the open gate! What a relief.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine kayaking in the dark toward an open gate. Finally, you've made it!
readingMnemonic: This open gate is in the water though, so you'll need a kayak (かい) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case.

meaningMnemonic: If you see a tree that you want to stand under to take a break while hiking, a good parent will stand under the tree with you. This is a kind and caring parent who can see that you are tired and want to relax by standing in the shade of this tree.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine that you’re on a long mountain hike and so far you’ve been hiking all in the sun with no shade. Feel the sun beating down on your back, the sweat getting in your eyes. Finally you see a tree to seek refuge under. It’s like an oasis in a desert. You’re saved!
additionalR:
Hints
Busting your shins on things really hurts. I'm sure you've hit your shins on coffee tables and the like all your life. Remember that pain and think how much worse it would be banging your bare shins on pointy tree roots after you've been hiking all day in the hot sun. Not enjoyable.
readingMnemonic: Once you get closer to the tree, you and your parent see that it has some pretty crazy roots coming out of it. While making your way into the shade, you manage to bang your shin (しん) on one of these roots. Your shins already hurt from walking so much, and this is just icing on the cake.

meaningMnemonic: You have to say what you’re selling because people don’t like to read. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine reading what you have for sale out loud to people walking by because they’re too lazy to read it for themselves.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine reading through your list of yo-yo tricks. Do you know how to pronounce those weird yo-yo names?
readingMnemonic: What are you forced to read aloud to sell? Yo-yo (よ) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them.

meaningMnemonic: On the ground is a water drop you spilled, so I request you wipe it up. I would do it myself, but you're the one who spilled it, so I'm requesting you do it and take responsibility for your mistake.
additionalM:
Hints
It's a simple request, really. Just wipe up that water drop off the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
"But cucumbers are already mostly water, this isn't going to absorb anything!" you cry. Well too bad. That's my request, so you better do it. Figure out how to make the cucumber work.
readingMnemonic: Oh, one more thing. I request that you wipe up the water with this cucumber (きゅう).

meaningMnemonic: If your car runs into a cloud you'll revolve around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine driving your car around and around the cloud, instead of going through it. At least it's soft and cool.
additionalR:
Hints
Unfortunately, not long after you get through that cloud another one comes down and gets in your way. Now you're counting each revolution, one... two... three... all the way up to ten.
readingMnemonic: You have to revolve around the cloud ten (てん) times before it disappears and you're able to go through.

meaningMnemonic: If you’ve been walking all day, nobody is going to want to kiss your foot if you’ve been walking barefoot down a dirt road. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine kissing someone’s foot. Now imagine kissing someone’s foot after they’ve been walking down a dirt road for hours. It’s disgusting. Smell the stench of dirt and sweat wafting up into your nostrils as the foot approaches your lips. It’s wretched.
additionalR:
Hints
Walking down a dirt road barefoot like this is a sure way to dirty up your feet. Feel the dirt, rocks, and twigs under your feet. The road is hard and dry and is not making your journey very comfortable at all.
readingMnemonic: What was this person walking down again? Oh, that’s right – a road (ろ). They were walking down a dirt road.

meaningMnemonic: A sick stick of dynamite is going to be sick forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if you were a sick stick of dynamite. Every time you sneezed you ran the risk of blowing up. It would be a terrifying way to live. Just imagine it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this as your life. You could explode at any moment, you’re sick, and you have B.O. Nobody wants to be around you because you might explode and kill them, and you stink. What a terrible way to live!
readingMnemonic: Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? B.O. (びょう). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being sick is no excuse.

meaningMnemonic: The tree marked with a yellow X on the side of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the scene of a woman with a chainsaw cutting down this tree marked with a yellow X. Hear the sound of the chainsaw buzzing and the grinding of wood as it meets the side of the trunk. It’s very loud. Woodchips go flying everywhere.
additionalR:
Hints
Now picture the same scene as before only imagining Yoko Ono wielding that chainsaw. Maybe she’s dancing. Maybe there’s some Beatles music playing in the background. Either way it’s a strange sight – remember it.
readingMnemonic: Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is Yoko (よこ) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the side of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko.

meaningMnemonic: If you lack a lip ring (or two in this case) it's going to make it way easier for you to sing a song.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a song with lip rings. Then imagine one without. Sing them, pretending you have lip rings. It doesn't work as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself getting hit by this car. All the air flies out of you as you sing your song. You think "I shouldn't have tried to sing a song with all these lip rings..."
readingMnemonic: You're singing a song with all these lip rings in your mouth and you sound terrible. You're on the side of the road singing. People are freaking out. Finally, someone drives into you with their car (か).

meaningMnemonic: Run into oneself in a dream and you'll definitely wake up.
additionalM:
Hints
If you run into yourself, it really messes you up, you know? You won't be able to handle what you're seeing so you have to wake up.
additionalR:
Hints
Your obi is like a special object you only have in dreams. If you have your obi, it's okay, it's a dream and you can wake up now! Make sure you memorize exactly how it feels so dream-you can't trick you or something.
readingMnemonic: If one runs into oneself and you don't wake up, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an obi (お) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from.

meaningMnemonic: Using your construction power you build something great. A true achievement built for the achievement of making kanji learning easier!
additionalM:
Hints
Just constructing this thing was an achievement. Feel proud like it was, well, an achievement.
additionalR:
Hints
Thanks こういち. Now everyone will know of your achievements around kanji learning and inside-out earth theory.
Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading. Remember that, because it comes up quite a bit!
readingMnemonic: This achievement was made possible by こういち, so of course this construction project is a giant statue of the man himself. What an achievement of a statue. What an achievement of an achievement.

meaningMnemonic: When a drunkard holds a sword it becomes something else. The drunkard doesn't become a swordsman, they're still just a drunkard. But the sword in their hands does.
additionalM:
Hints
