Picture the drunkard standing in front of you. He picked up the sword and is holding it above his head. It's becoming... becoming...
additionalR:
Hints
If a sword becomes a saber in the hands of a drunkard... then what are you? Geez this became pretty deep.
You slice down the drunkard with your saber and become a little more depressed than you were before.
readingMnemonic: The sword has become a saber (せい)! It's just like the saber you have! Hey, wait.

meaningMnemonic: The mountain on top of the cliff is dry from the coast below. Just from looking at the raging shore below, you'd think everything would be wet, it's splashing everywhere!
additionalM:
Hints
You're on top of the mountain and the entire coast is stretching out below. The shore goes as far as your eyes can see.
additionalR:
Hints
Sit down next to Gandhi and close your eyes. You can hear the water hitting the shore below. The coastal birds are screaming. You crack open an eye and see Gandhi still sitting perfectly still.
readingMnemonic: Sitting up there, watching the coast with you, is Gandhi (がん). The world famous Gandhi, is just hanging out up here with you, looking down at what you now realize must be a coast in India.

meaningMnemonic: Standing next to your older brother is another standing older brother of yours. They're trying to compete, to see which of them can stand the straightest and tallest.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your two older brothers competing like this. Are you going to root for one of them? That's not very nice, you shouldn't have a favorite older brother.
additionalR:
Hints
Look really closely at your older brothers. They're competing pretty hard for your attention. They really want to go to きょうと... but which one do YOU want to spend time with the most?
readingMnemonic: Your older brothers are trying to compete to see which of them gets to go to きょうと with you. You won a free trip to きょうと, but there's only one other ticket, so now your brothers are competing for you.

meaningMnemonic: If you keep a wolverine in a prison with barbs, you’re likely to get into a conflict with animal rights groups. Wolverines aren’t meant to be kept in cages, let alone barbed prisons. There’s going to be some sort of conflict here, and animal activist groups are not going to be happy with you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you’re the wolverine in this barbed prison. There’s hardly enough room for you to even turn around in here. The barbs keep poking you as well. Have you ever run into a barbed wire fence? It’s not pleasant.
additionalR:
Hints
Pretend you're the wolverine once again. You're already in pain from gouging yourself in this barbed prison. But now you can feel a conflict within yourself. Your soul can't take this. You have to hold on, but it's so hard to keep fighting.
readingMnemonic: When the wolverine cuts itself inside the barbed prison (which is inevitable), the conflict changes. Now there is a conflict between the wolverine and its soul (そう). Does it lose it and become a shell of its former self? Or does it keep fighting and try to hang onto what's left of its soul?

meaningMnemonic: A leader stands upon the ground of the rice paddy. He is searching for treasure. It is said that this treasure here in this rice field will make things much easier for the leader (that's what leaders really want, after all). If he gets this treasure, it will be a great convenience for him, because convenience is everything when you're the leader.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the leader looking around the rice paddy. He keeps saying, "Ugh, it would be convenient if I didn't have to walk around out here looking for the treasure that's going to make things more convenient for me. Ugh." Go ahead and say this phrase out loud, too, pretending to be the leader in the rice paddy. Feel the cold and the wet, making it less convenient for you.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the happiness that the leader would feel at this revelation. It will make everything much more convenient for him, since he's not the one doing all the manual labor. He won't have to eat out of a bento, that's for sure.
readingMnemonic: He finds a place to dig in the ground. It looks like there's some fresh dirt here. Finally, the treasure of convenience that will make this leader's life so much easier. He digs into the ground and pulls out a box. When he opens it, he finds out it's a bento (べん). My god, he thinks. This really will make my life more convenient. My people can take their lunches with them now instead of coming back to base to eat, which will waste way less time!

meaningMnemonic: By the time you finish digging a coffin hole with nothing but a spoon, you’ll be an old elderly person. Digging with nothing but a spoon takes a long time, especially when the hole needs to be big enough for a coffin. You might as well be digging it for yourself at this rate. By the time you finish, you’ll be all wrinkled and elderly and just about ready to keel over.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself digging a coffin hole with nothing but a spoon. Your hands get all cramped, your wrist starts to hurt, and you get painful blisters on your hands. It takes forever to dig a hole big enough for a coffin!
additionalR:
Hints
You hated roe when you were still young, but now that you’re an elderly old fart you really want to eat it. Roe is for old people, you guess, as you slurp it up.
readingMnemonic: Now that you’re elderly (and probably about to die) you suddenly crave some delicious roe (ろう). Salmon roe, sea urchin roe, tofugu roe, doesn’t matter. Your old, tired bones need roe after all that hard work!

meaningMnemonic: Orders coming from your mouth will determine the fate of your men. You are a commanding officer and orders from your mouth are law. Your orders alone determine the ultimate fate of your soldiers.
additionalM:
Hints
Pretend you are a high ranking officer and imagine yourself giving orders to your underlings. Imagine all the power and influence you have. It feels good.
additionalR:
Hints
Students of American history are very familiar with the Mayflower. Recall learning about it in school whenever you see this kanji. Or look it up on Wikipedia if you don’t know about it. The Mayflower is a big deal!
readingMnemonic: You are the commanding officer on the Mayflower (めい). You give orders to colonize America. The orders spewing from your mouth hole determine the fate of the settlers and the fate of America and the fate of the world! You and the Mayflower have changed everything forever.

meaningMnemonic: Try to use your fingers to spoon out some of the sun and you'll come back with just one finger.
additionalM:
Hints
Look down at your finger and the burned stumps where the rest of your fingers used to be. It hurts. And you're sad. But at least you still have one finger left.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture sitting with a sheep. It's right across from you, staring into your eyes. It reaches out its sheep finger hoof and you reach out with your finger. They touch. It's magical.
readingMnemonic: Don't worry, you aren't the only one out there with just one finger, sheep (し) only have one finger too. I mean, they're hooves, which are really just a single animal finger. It's just big and kind of flat.

meaningMnemonic: If you want a spirit sword, you have to be the first one to find it. Do you really think the first person to come across a spirit sword wouldn't want it?! No. So if you're any place but first, you're not getting anything.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine it like commenting on Youtube or Facebook. If you can say FIRST, first, well congrats. You win the internet spirit sword.
additionalR:
Hints
This is the first show of this type, anywhere in the world!
readingMnemonic: If you were lucky enough to be the first one to find the spirit sword, you should open up a small show (しょ) to show it off! And then you can make yourself the first in line every day to see the show.

meaningMnemonic: What is the jet of your mouth? It's flavor. It's what shoots your mouth off, which explains why it hurts so much when you eat something awesome.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how your favorite food tastes. Imagine a jet taking off in your mouth because of it.
additionalR:
Hints
Of course, if you're vegetarian imagine the flavor of the meat being terrible. Up to you. Make the mnemonic work for your lifestyle.
readingMnemonic: And what has more flavor than a big slab of meat (み)? You love meat and its flavor nearly as much as you love the flavor of its juice. So many good things to put in your mouth!

meaningMnemonic: On a scooter there is a bear trying to follow and chase you! You're on your own scooter, luckily, but that doesn't make this any less terrifying.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the bear on its scooter, following really closely behind your scooter. You can almost feel his bear breath on your neck!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the bear chasing you on its scooter, trying to reach out and grab the obi off your waist. Woah, it's getting a little too close!
readingMnemonic: The bear is trying to follow you because it wants your obi (お). The obi is waving in the wind behind your scooter, and the bear is reaching out with its teeth to try and grab it.

meaningMnemonic: You should have a spirit that's humble when before a god. You never really have to act all nice and humble before anyone else, but if you meet a god... well... you should probably lower yourself appropriately. They can smite you and all that.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a spirit appearing before you. It's a god. You should be as humble as possible. Out of respect and also because you don't want to be cursed or something.
additionalR:
Hints
If you don't get down on your shins before god, they could take them away. Even your jeans couldn't protect you then. You don't want to live a shin-less life, do you?
readingMnemonic: When you see a god, you need to get down on your shins (しん). Get down on your ankles? No, not low enough. Knees? No, no, get your shins flat on the ground to show how humble you really are. Luckily, you're wearing jeans (じん), so at least that will stop your poor shins getting chafed!

meaningMnemonic: A drop of water to a root is good. It's good for the roots to grow and live and thrive. And what's good for roots is good for our plants and us humans too.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting a little drop of water over a root you want to grow. Doing this is good for the plant and also good for your soul.
additionalR:
Hints
Rowing even feels good on your arms and back. Probably just as good as all these roots will feel.
readingMnemonic: A good way to get a lot of drops of water for your roots is to buy a row boat (りょう). Then just row out to the middle of the lake and plonk all the roots right into the source!

meaningMnemonic: The sound of your heart gives me an idea. The methodic thump thump thumping of a heart puts me in a trance that gives me great ideas. It’s a very inspirational sound, the sound of a heart is. It gives me an idea.
additionalM:
Hints
Put your hand over your heart, or on your wrist, or somewhere you can feel your pulse. Your heart is pumping blood through your body, hear the sound of your heart beat and try to picture and get an idea for how all the blood flows through your body.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the majestic animal that is the bald eagle. Imagine the sound of an eagle screeching as it zooms through the air, flapping its wings in the wind. It’s pretty impressive.
readingMnemonic: The heart of an eagle (い) is very strong. The person who knew this probably came up with the idea to make the bald eagle a symbol of the United States. Eagles are always flying around and doing things, so their hearts are very strong.

meaningMnemonic: A Viking in a position of power does not need to labor in the fields. Labor is for the weak! A Viking of power takes what he wants, and need not labor for it. A powerful Viking plunders all and takes what he wants!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself as a powerful Viking. You have the power to take anything you want, pillaging and plundering to your heart’s content. Imagine all the things you would acquire with this sort of power.
Note - there are a few other kanji that have a similar meaning to this one. This kanji is used in words related to physical, or manual labor, with an emphasis on how darn tiring it is!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this powerful Viking laying siege on a small fishing village and taking all the roe and stuffing it into his bearded face. So much labor went into harvesting that roe! Vikings are so mean!
readingMnemonic: It takes a lot of labor to harvest roe (ろう) so that’s what the Viking decides to take first! Roe is delicious, but it’s small and delicate. Vikings don’t labor for their own roe! They take it and eat it!

meaningMnemonic: There are pieces of thread on each escalator showing you what level they go to in your school. Each escalator takes you to a different grade, so make sure you follow the right thread or you'll end up in a class that's either way above or way below your level.
additionalM:
Hints
When you level up your Japanese skills, you'll take this escalator to rank up too!
additionalR:
Hints
A teacher comes over and says, "Excuse me, this is advanced level cucumber studies. I don't think you're at this level yet... please take the escalator down and follow the threads to find your level."
readingMnemonic: You want to see what the highest level is, so you go up the wrong escalator. At the top you find a giant cucumber (きゅう).

meaningMnemonic: There is a woman and a child in front of you. You like them very much.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a woman and a child you like very much. Just appreciate them, and think about how much you like those two. The reading mnemonic definitely won't ruin your image of them or anything.
additionalR:
Hints
And you DO like them. You have always been a fan of こういち's kanji learning methods, and you feel so lucky to have married a woman who looks just like こういち and then (this is the real miracle!) gave birth to a child that looks like こういち too. Hashtag blessed.
readingMnemonic: "I like you two," you say to the woman and child. They both turn their heads 180 degrees back towards you. They both have faces that look just like こういち's. "We like you too," they say in unison.

meaningMnemonic: You’ve been playing blackjack in the sun since long ago. This is the longest game of blackjack you’ve ever played and it feels like ages since you started. You’ve been sitting out in the sun playing blackjack since long, long ago.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself playing a never-ending game of blackjack out in the hot sun. You’re sticky, sweaty, and tired. But all you can do is continue to play your game of blackjack. It’s miserable.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your muck ashi, all dirty and muddy from walking on that old road from long ago. Feel the muck between the toes of your ashi, squishing with every step. Hear the sound the mud makes as it slides between your sweaty mucky toes.
readingMnemonic: Once you finally finish the game, you walk the long walk back home, in the sun, barefoot, on a dirt road that hasn’t been maintained since long ago. Your feet are all sweaty from being out in the sun, and walking on this dirt road gives you muck ashi (むかし). Your ashi (feet) are all mucky and muddy from the combination of dirt and sweat. Your muck ashi are really gross, man.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of your clan wants to live close to the ground so he demands you get low. Low, low, with your belly to the ground. That way you're always below him, since he's the leader.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself, face smooshed into the ground, and you can hear the leader shouting above you, "GET LOW!"
additionalR:
Hints
Get low to the ground right now and ask your mom or dad to roll some tater tots towards your face. Eat them up, mm mm.
readingMnemonic: Low people like you can only eat low food like potatoes. But that's boring, so you low people learned to make tater (てい) tots. You roll them to each other and eat them without lifting your heads.

meaningMnemonic: Give trash to the moon and it will nurture and raise that trash like it's its own little moon baby.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the moon raising this ball of trash, giving it love and attention.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the little trash ball 行くs up into the sky and floats around its moon mama. If you raise your child right it will want to 行く wherever you go too.
readingMnemonic: The moon nurtures the trash ball until one day, it speaks! "行く (いく), 行く！" it says. It wants to go live with mom moon!

meaningMnemonic: If you know the radical meaning order you know the kanji meaning order as well!
additionalM:
Hints
Here's an order: study your radicals.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine an authority figure giving you this order as an official order. Ray guns don't really exist, so you think it's a pretty strange order.
Hint: when you see the orders radical, the reading will often be れい. The mnemonic will likely involve orders to get a ray gun of some kind.
readingMnemonic: Your orders are to get a ray (れい) gun.

meaningMnemonic: You see something that would suit you so you use your fingers and pick up the thing you want. You can pick up anything you think suits you. A shiny rock. A new pair of pants. Anything!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine something that would suit your life and your style. Now pick up that thing. Hold it in your fingers. Feel it. It's yours now.
additionalR:
Hints
You picked up the hero sword and now you're the new hero. Time to go kill a dragon. Good luck, try not to die hero person!
readingMnemonic: You're walking around looking for something to pick up when you see a sword in a rock. Yes, this will suit you. You pick up the sword and people jump out around you and tell you that you are the new hero (ひろ)! Uh oh. Maybe you shouldn't have picked this up.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami master has the power to pour water wherever he pleases. Tsunami masters are masters over the most powerful water force in the universe, so it makes sense that they have the ability to pour water at will, wherever they please. Best not tick off the master, unless you want a tsunami poured on your head.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself as this tsunami master. You’re like a water bender from Avatar, only more awesome. Feel the cold wet water pouring out of your fingertips as you create water out of nothing. Imagine what it would be like to have this power.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Chewbacca soaking wet. All his fur is matted down and he looks pretty depressed. He smells like wet dog too. Smell this smell in your nostrils as you imagine how pathetic this drenched Chewbacca feels.
readingMnemonic: If Chewbacca (ちゅう) was trying to attack you, you’d be able to defend yourself easily. Simply pour a tsunami on him and Chewbacca would surrender in a heartbeat. Chewbacca doesn’t like having water poured on him, especially not all the water from a tsunami.

meaningMnemonic: Cut grains with a knife to make them smaller and you'll make a great profit. By cutting them, now you can get three grains worth of money for what was once a single grain.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine buying some rice. Now cut all the grains with a knife into smaller grains. Now sell them for two, three, four times the profit!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of your reeds full of grains in a row. The entire world will benefit from your crafty invention. And you'll turn a great profit too, which certainly doesn't hurt.
readingMnemonic: To make an even better profit, you decide to cut up reeds (り) too. You stuff the grains in the reeds and sell that as "self-cooking" sets.

meaningMnemonic: A leader stands at the highest rank in an organization. The leader is of the highest rank and stands above all others.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this great leader. Imagine him actually standing on the shoulders of his supporters who are a lower rank than he is. He’s standing atop this great pyramid as a fearless leader.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the same ranking pyramid from before, only all the members are boy scouts, and the leader at the top is an eagle. Hear the piercing screech of the eagle with your ears.
readingMnemonic: This great leader is actually the leader of the boy scouts. And as we all know, the highest rank in boy scouts is the rank of eagle (い) scout. This great leader has attained the rank of eagle scout and stands above all other scouts.

meaningMnemonic: A middle of the road leader is likely to have an average relationship with everyone. He doesn’t really take sides in matters, and just stays in the middle. This makes him seem like sort of a wishy washy people pleaser, and as such his relationships with people are rarely anything more than average.
additionalM:
Hints
I’m sure you’ve heard of “flip-floppers” in politics, or people who try and take both sides of an issue, always staying in the middle ground and never really taking a stand. Imagine one of these people to represent this kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your favorite flip-flopper from before. Now imagine that there’s a knocker on his forehead and you get to knock that knocker as hard as you like. Sounds like fun, doesn’t it? Imagine yourself doing this.
readingMnemonic: This kanji is pronounced exactly like the kanji 中 (なか). It's one of those kanji where you can figure out the reading from one of the radicals.

meaningMnemonic: When winter comes your direction, the trees must release their leaves for the coming cold.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture winter heading straight for you and frosting everything over. Now picture the leaves being released by the trees.
additionalR:
Hints
"Release my home from this leaf prison!" you shout at the now bare trees.
readingMnemonic: The trees release all of their leaves onto your home (ほう). Slowly, you watch in horror as your home is consumed by the released leaves. They enter in through the windows, doors, and the chimney.

meaningMnemonic: You only got a few grains on your plate. It only takes you a  second to eat them. It can't take any longer because there were so few.
additionalM:
Hints
Count how many seconds it takes for you to eat the few grains you have. One... oh, they're gone.
additionalR:
Hints
Whenever you eat a few grains, even if only for a second, you get a terrible reaction seconds later that causes some pretty terrible B.O.
readingMnemonic: And also, a second is how long it takes for your awful B.O. (びょう) to appear.

meaningMnemonic: In your mouth you put a sword and a knife. Now that you have them in there, you have to make them separate from each other.
additionalM:
Hints
Anyone can put a sword and knife in their mouth. But not everyone can make them separate while still in your mouth.
additionalR:
Hints
"I bet you can't separate the sword and knife," they say in an annoying voice. Alright, time for you to show them. Nobody bets you anything without you blindly trying to do it!
readingMnemonic: Why are you trying to make a sword and knife separate in your mouth? Because someone bets you (べつ) can't do it.

meaningMnemonic: This cow temple is special. This cow must have been very important to have an entire temple dedicated to it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a temple dedicated to a single cow. All of the people who come and worship here have a special place in their hearts for the cow.
additionalR:
Hints
You walk up to a statue of the special cow in the temple and see a collar around its neck with that says "Tokugawa Moo Moo" on it. How... special!
readingMnemonic: This cow is special because it belonged to Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu, Japan's first shougun and uniter of Japan! He's a super important figure in Japanese history. You should absolutely look him up and read a bit about him (when you're caught up on these lessons, that is).

meaningMnemonic: The card game fish are best at is blackjack because they can easily hold the cards with their fins together. In blackjack you don't have to have a huge hand, full of cards. It's just a few, so fish fins can keep them together and just hit or stay.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a fish trying to hold a full hand of cards together. Impossible! Fish don’t have fingers to keep them spread properly. Now imagine a fish trying to hold two cards together and nodding to hit. It's much easier to keep things together this way!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a bunch of fish gathering together in きょうと to participate in this blackjack tournament. With so many fish all together in one place, it probably smells pretty fishy.
readingMnemonic: Once a year trillions of fish get together in きょうと to play blackjack. They have a huge tournament there once a year.

meaningMnemonic: A woman of power sits on a stool while her servants toil away in the kitchen. They are toiling away preparing a feast for this woman of power while she kicks back on her cozy stool. She’s a queen and deserves to be pampered.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you are in a position of power and can relax on a stool while your minions toil away in the kitchen to prepare you a feast. It’s good to have money! You’ve got it made. Imagine how smug you feel.
Note - there are a few other kanji that have a similar meaning to this one. This kanji is used in words that refer to doing work, with a focus on making a concerted effort.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine eating all this food with your dog. Hear your dog barking as it woofs up the food next to you as you do the same.
readingMnemonic: The servants are making lots of food for you and your dog (ど). You're really hungry, so you encourage your minions to toil away faster so that you might feast a bit sooner.

meaningMnemonic: The leader has a cloud that he uses to transmit all of the messages he needs to send to his people. The cloud floats above him and when he wants to tell people something he just whispers into the cloud and it transmits his message really, really loudly to all of them.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this special cloud floating above your leader. It's probably just a speaker attached to a drone covered in cotton balls.
additionalR:
Hints
You highly doubt this is a magical cloud that can transmit messages. You inch closer to the big dent and try to poke it. Your finger goes right in! Hmm, you're still pretty sure there's a trick to this thing.
readingMnemonic: As the leader transmits his latest series of messages to you and the others, you notice a pretty large dent (でん) in it. That dent is probably a clue to what this cloud is really made of.

meaningMnemonic: Even a simple drunkard can start a war. In fact, it's really common for one simple drunk person to offend an entire country into declaring war.
additionalM:
Hints
Think about all of the people you know. You can picture at least one of them getting drunk and, I dunno, sending out a simple drunk tweet that starts the next world war. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the war of humans vs centaurs. Do you really think the humans will win? Centaurs are really powerful and they have all of the same high tech weapons as us AND horse legs.
readingMnemonic: Welp, you woke up this morning and now you're at war with the centaurs (せん). This is especially unfortunate, because the centaurs are really good at battles because they're all automatically cavalry troops.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits your skin and creates smaller waves. Those hit you too!
additionalM:
Hints
If you’ve ever been to the ocean or a large lake, you know what kind of forces even small waves can hit with. Now imagine the force with which a tsunami wave would strike you. You’d have the wind knocked out of you for sure.
additionalR:
Hints
The waves are basically punching you in the gut, forcing the air out of your lungs, and making you shout HA!
readingMnemonic: When each wave hits your body, you shout, "Ha (は)!" It's not like it's on purpose. When the wave crashes into you, the wind gets knocked right out of your mouth, making a HA sound.

meaningMnemonic: A sheep rides a tsunami in classic Western style. And by Western style I mean the sheep is dressed in a cowboy outfit and has put a saddle atop the tsunami wave to ride it. It’s a tsunami rodeo and this crazy sheep is riding that tsunami wave in classic Western style.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how ridiculous a sheep would look all decked out in Western style cowboy gear. Now imagine it riding a tsunami wave as it screams, “Baa~ baa~ baa~!”
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself eating this Western style apple pie yogurt. It tastes just like apple pie only creamier and fruitier. Taste the sweet yogurt in your mouth as you imagine yourself scarfing some down.
readingMnemonic: After a whole day of riding this tsunami, the sheep is hankerin’ for some Western style food. This sheep loves yogurt (よう). And its favorite flavor is Western style apple pie yogurt. America loves its apple pie and this sheep loves Western style apple pie flavored yogurt.

meaningMnemonic: A leader with a lot of power can move heavy things with hardly any work. By power, I mean a lot of strength because this leader is very strong and moving heavy things is no problem for him. His power allows the leader to move heavy things with little to no work at all.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this powerful leader, bare chested with a crown on his head. His muscles are bulging as he picks up heavy things and casually tosses them aside. How does he maintain so many muscles?
Note - there are a few other kanji that have a similar meaning to this one. This kanji is used in words that refer to doing work, with a focus on movement or physical operation of a device.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself eating one of these power doughnuts. It’s delicious. Doughnuts are fantastic. Taste the fresh doughnut in your mouth as it crumbles and melts on your tongue. It’s the best doughnut you’ve ever had.
readingMnemonic: Where does this leader’s power come from? Doughnuts (どう). He eats nothing but doughnuts. He has a special crew of bakers that work for him in his castle and they work all day to make the leader doughnuts of power. They are imbued with many secret ingredients that give the leader the power to move anything, no matter how heavy it is.

meaningMnemonic: In Asia they assume everyone's heart is automatically bad and evil.
additionalM:
Hints
You don't want a bunch of evil in your heart, do you? No, I didn't think so.
additionalR:
Hints
Acupuncture was originally invented in Asia a long, long time ago, to stop the bad chi from going through your heart.
readingMnemonic: Luckily, people in Asia know how to get the evil badness out of your heart with acupuncture (あく).

meaningMnemonic: Imagining one’s self without a heart can make it hard to draw breath. Without a heart, you’d have no blood pumping and you would start to die. This would make it increasingly harder to draw breath and get oxygen to stay alive.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to live without a heart. You couldn’t. Your blood stops flowing and your body shuts down. You would no longer be able to draw breath.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine smelling this smelly sock. Imagine the smelly stench of the dirty sock wafting up into your nostrils and filling your lungs with its odor. Gross.
readingMnemonic: You know how when people are unconscious and their breath slows or comes to a stop, they use smelling salts to revive them? Well a smelly sock (そく) can work just as well. Socks get really stinky and their stench is powerful enough to revive someone who isn’t drawing breath.

meaningMnemonic: You stand at a podium early in the morning to practice reading the chapter from your latest book.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself, standing tall in the light of the early morning. You hold your head up high, open to your bookmark, and read the name of the chapter aloud: "Chapter 42: The Most Important Number."
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself in a line with other authors, standing in the early morning, waiting to read chapters from your respective books. You really hope the Shougun likes yours. If he does, you'll be famous! If he doesn't, you might be beheaded.
readingMnemonic: You're practicing this specific chapter because you've been asked to read it for the Shougun (しょう). There will be a bunch of other authors reading chapters of their books to him too, and you want to make a good impression.

meaningMnemonic: You're in a tent eating beans because you're trying to climb a mountain! When you climb, you sleep in a tent and eat only beans (the ultimate climbing food).
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine climbing slowly and carefully up a cliff on the side of this mountain. Your tent and your beans are tied to your back, and you're letting out little farts with each step from all the beans you've been consuming.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh, what was the name of the とうきょう mountain you just worked so hard to climb? Mount Takao. (You should go climb it with your real body and see とうきょう with your real eyes sometime!)
readingMnemonic: You climb and climb and climb until you finally reach... とうきょう! At the top of this mountain you've been climbing you can see all of とうきょう. It's beautiful! It's breathtaking! All your climbing makes this view of とうきょう even more worthwhile!

meaningMnemonic: The roof, even though it's almost spring, is still covered in ice so it's cold. Inside the house is cold, outside the house is cold. Everything is cold!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the entire roof covered in ice. It's supposed to be spring right now, but it's too cold for the ice to melt off your roof.
additionalR:
Hints
The samurai isn't doing a good job stopping the cold, and soon he and his sword have frozen into your ice roof. So now it's cold and you have a dead samurai stuck to your house. Great.
readingMnemonic: You can't stand the cold anymore, so you hire a samurai to come try to hack the ice off of your roof with his sword. You stand outside shivering, and watching as the samurai tries to stab the ice off of your roof.

meaningMnemonic: The force of a tsunami is enough to put a gash in a tree about pi (3.14) feet deep. Tsunamis are pretty powerful, so the force of the water alone is enough to cut into a tree several feet deep.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this tsunami wave hitting the tree. It’s like a lumberjack axe of water, cutting deep into the tree with the force of a thousand lumberjacks.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being deep in the woods and banging your shin on a stump you didn’t see. It hurts to bang your shin, so imagine this pain and the awful sensation it brings.
readingMnemonic: Some tsunamis cut so deep that they flat out chop the tree right off its stump. In areas like this, you have to be careful not to bang a shin (しん) on them. These stumps are right about shin height, so you want to be cautious when walking around them as to not injure yourself.

meaningMnemonic: A leader who hires his own personal clown will likely double his entertainment. Clowns are funny and make people laugh, so the leader decided to hire one. Since that time, the leader’s amount of mirth has doubled.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a clown and all the ridiculous funny things they do. Imagine the clown throwing a pie at someone’s face and how funny that is. Chuckle to yourself and remember this kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
This clown has served its purpose. Wave your hand in the air and say bye-bye to this worthless clown.
readingMnemonic: When the clown stops being funny, it’s time to say bye (ばい). At first, the clown doubled the leader’s entertainment, but now the clown is just annoying. It’s time to say bye-bye.

meaningMnemonic: You’ll have to excuse me, having all this power puts a lot of strain and exertion on my body. My power comes from exertion of muscle, so please excuse me if I start to perspire.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself under great exertion. You’re attempting to use your power to move something and it’s really requiring a lot of exertion to move. Picture yourself doing this action and imagine how difficult it is.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this Ben in your head. Ben always uses lots of exertion to do tasks. Imagine him using an unnecessary amount of power and exertion in carrying out normal everyday tasks.
readingMnemonic: Excuse me, I don’t think I’ve introduced myself yet. My name is Ben (べん) and I use powerful muscle exertion to accomplish every task. Ben knows what Ben wants and how to get it. Remember that, kids.

meaningMnemonic: A long time ago a huge tsunami swept a triceratops up into the moon and extinguished its life.
additionalM:
Hints
I’m sure you’ve heard many theories on how dinosaurs went extinct. Well, this is the real story. Imagine this poor triceratops and all his friends being extinguished by this powerful tsunami, sweeping them up into the moon where there's no air to breathe or leaves to eat.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch the Shougun's eyes light up as an actor dressed like a tsunami crashes into an actor dressed as a triceratops and all of the lights on the stage are extinguished. Spooky...
readingMnemonic: This famous event where almost all life was extinguished is reenacted every year for the Shougun (しょう). He's got a bit of an unhealthy obsession with extinguishing life...

meaningMnemonic: You have a tent with a jackhammer in it for the festival! Festivals need booths where people can do activities. In this tent, festival goers can use a jackhammer and make a lot of noise, perfect for a festival!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being at a festival and waiting in line to ride the jackhammer. You don't want to eat candy apples or ride rides, you want to wait for the jackhammer tent.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your cyborg going to this festival. Everyone here has some type of cyborg enhancement, like robotic arms, legs, or braces. Your cyborg is really excited to be around its people and play with jackhammers.
readingMnemonic: This festival is for cyborgs (さい) only. Picture the cyborg you made getting excited that you're taking it to the festival. That's why all of the activities have to do with heavy machinery. The rides are mostly just cyborgs letting other people ride them, but it's still pretty fun.

meaningMnemonic: The village beforehand (what the village was before it was a village) was a field.
additionalM:
Hints
It makes sense for a big open field to have been what was there before the village was made.
additionalR:
Hints
It was sad that they had to destroy the natural habitat of the Yankees (a field) to put up the village.
readingMnemonic: On this field, the Yankees (や) used to play.

meaningMnemonic: Look at a building and compare the white parts. Each of those white parts is a floor. Multi-story buildings have tons of different floors that you can see from the outside.
additionalM:
Hints
All buildings have white marks that you can compare with the rest to see where the floors are.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this building and each of its floors. There should be one floor in particular with a waterfall coming out of it that you can climb with your kayak.
readingMnemonic: You need to use your ability to tell where floors are from the outside of the building to find the story that lets kayaks (かい) in. You're coming from the side of the building surrounded by water, so you need to find the kayak floor to get in.

meaningMnemonic: There's a canopy and a man called the Yoga King standing in the middle of your garden.
additionalM:
Hints
Somehow your little garden is now being used by the Yoga King to teach yoga to a whole group of random people under this canopy... you have no idea how they got back here.
additionalR:
Hints
You're not sure what else to do, so you end up serving tater tots in your garden all day to stretchy strangers.
readingMnemonic: Not only is this Yoga King taking over your garden, but he's ordering you to serve food to his class. "You there, peasant, fetch these people your freshest tater (てい) tots from this puny garden to give them strength."

meaningMnemonic: There's a tsunami coming and you want to be together with it by yourself (oneself) so you go to the harbor.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the harbor. You're the only one there. The wind is whipping violently and all of the boats docked around you are being bounced around. You can see the tsunami rising out of the ocean and coming for you and the harbor.
additionalR:
Hints
Well this sucks. You wanted to enjoy being alone together with the tsunami and the harbor, but now こういち is here ruining your peace. He's floating around in the harbor like everything isn't about to be destroyed, sipping on a fancy drink in his inner tube.
readingMnemonic: As you look around at the harbor in your last moments you suddenly see someone in the water. It's こういち! He's sitting in an inner tube in the harbor waiting for the tsunami too.

meaningMnemonic: When someone goes out in the sun, they get hot. That’s just how it is. Someone standing out in the sun for a long time will inevitably get hot. The sun is hot, and it makes you get hot too.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you are this someone, standing out in the hot sun. Feel the sun’s hot rays beating down on you as you stand outside. The hot sun makes you start to sweat and you get all sweaty and sticky from the heat. Note that this usually refers to the hot weather or the heat of an area you're in and doesn't refer to a hot "thing."
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine that great feeling when you go from hot and sticky outside to nice and air conditioned inside. Feel the heat transition on your skin as you step into an air conditioned room at Suzie’s. It gives you goose bumps.
readingMnemonic: You need to get out of this hot sun and into some air conditioning. Then you remember there’s a great air conditioning unit at Suzie’s (あつ) house. Ah, Suzie – our savior! If you need me, I’ll be at Suzie’s place.

meaningMnemonic: If there's a tsunami it's easy to get hot water. Just stick your hand out the window as the tsunami goes by and poof! That water's HOT.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the boiling hot tsunami water as it comes for you. Psh, this will be easy.
additionalR:
Hints
You decided to live in a yurt because of the easy access it provides to hot water. They're so mobile!
readingMnemonic: As the hot water comes, you just lift up the bottom of the yurt (ゆ) you live in, and it comes flowing in. All of the cups, pots, and barrels you laid on your floor are now full of hot water.

meaningMnemonic: A leader of business? Ha! That's me! That's I!
additionalM:
Hints
This version of I is more boyish. It's a sort of young man/boy way of saying "I," though you'll hear women use it too sometimes (it's a teensy bit tomboyish though).
additionalR:
Hints
I am beaucoup I am. (Is that a pun? Did I do it right?) I dunno. Just say ぼく a lot and try to connect all of your approximate knowledges of languages together. Merci ぼく from ぼく.
readingMnemonic: You use the word I a lot. You say it so much, you just start referring to yourself with the french beaucoup (ぼく) for a lot. Because you love yourself a lot.

meaningMnemonic: A bird sits upon a mountain. If you look at the radicals, the bird is quite large and the mountain quite small. Think of this in the mnemonic as well. The reason the mountain is small is because you can only see the top of it, sticking out of the water. On it is the bird. This small mountain with the bird on it is an island.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the mountain as small as you'd like. Maybe it's only barely sticking out of the sea, and the bird is having trouble standing on it. Whatever you do, make sure you think of it as an island, possibly owned by the bird.
additionalR:
Hints
I don't think She-Man is a real character, but you can make up this imaginary He-Man girlfriend in your mind. She is weird about her island, and weird about eating birds, but He-Man and She-Man are in love, so why are you judging? Imagine the two having dinner on their small island later that evening. He-Man wonders where she got the bird from.
readingMnemonic: But this island doesn't only belong to the bird. In fact, the bird shouldn't be on this island, because it belongs to She-Man (しま), He-Man's girlfriend. She-Man comes out of the water and grabs the bird, eats it, and then goes back into the sea from whence she came.

meaningMnemonic: The people who stand in your village are juveniles. They aren't babies, who crawl, and they aren't adults who sit in front of their computers all day. They're juveniles who stand.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the juveniles standing in your village. You used to stand out there too and it was really boring, but at least kids these days have phones to keep them company.
additionalR:
Hints
Look in disdain at the juveniles standing around with their delicious doughnuts. You're really jealous, I mean, you're really... mad! Those lazy... um... ah man. You really want one of those doughnuts. You miss being young.
readingMnemonic: Right now all of the juveniles are standing in line to get doughnuts (どう). Free doughnuts, actually. Psh. Just like juveniles to get handouts, amirite?

meaningMnemonic: A shellfish with a mouth is a member of the invertebrate family. Yes, shellfish do have mouths, look it up!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a shellfish opening and closing its mouth, talking to you and telling you what a proud member of its family it is. It’s a strange sight, but picture it in your mind anyway.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to go to the shellfish inn. Imagine all the members-only signs telling you that you can't come in. Womp womp.
readingMnemonic: If you were a member of the same shellfish family, you'd be able to go to the special shellfish inn (いん). Every species has a members-only inn.

meaningMnemonic: A standing mustache with legs is able to sell merchandise. Most mustaches can’t stand because they don’t have legs. This mustache, however, does. It also has a keen business sense, which is why it’s selling merchandise.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this mustache entrepreneur, standing at his merchandise stand, selling his wares. He looks quite dignified, legs and all.
additionalR:
Hints
Now all of the merchandise belongs to the Shougun. The mustache has nothing left to sell, but at least he's rich!
readingMnemonic: The mustache is selling his merchandise so well that even the Shougun (しょう) notices. He leans down really close to the standing mustache man's merchandise and stays very still. Then he snaps his fingers and his servants come rushing out to buy it all!

meaningMnemonic: Someone decided to build a bunch of buildings and turn them into a metropolis. You don't know who they are, but now an absolute ton of other someones you don't know also live here in these buildings and work in this busy metropolis.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine just how many different someones live in this metropolis. There are so many people, you'll never meet them all!
additionalR:
Hints
If you think about it, every metropolis is completely jam-packed-full of toes. Just picture it. Toes. Everywhere. In every building. Filling up the streets.
readingMnemonic: You try to picture the faces of all the people who live in this metropolis, but for some reason you can only picture their toes (と). And there are ten times as many toes in this city than someones.

meaningMnemonic: When something is heavy, you need a lot of power to move it. It’s not going to move unless you use a lot of power. That thing is heavy and unless you use all the power you got, it’s not moving.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a massive 1 ton weight. It’s heavy. You can’t even begin to move it without some sort of powerful machine to help you. Imagine yourself trying to move it with just your bare hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so you don’t have enough power to move this doughnut as is. In order to move it, you’re going to have to use your superhuman power of eating. Once you eat enough of it, the remainder will be easy to move. Imagine yourself digging into this massive doughnut and taste its fresh baked goodness on your tongue. It’s mighty tasty.
readingMnemonic: Remember that 1 ton weight? Well, actually it’s a doughnut (どう). A huge, massive, 1 ton doughnut. It’s super heavy and hard to move, but it’s delicious.

meaningMnemonic: Bamboo's younger brother is counted with an ordinal number prefix. An ordinal number is one that represents a position or rank in sequential order (like first, second, third, etc.). We use this ordinal number prefix before counting these things in Japanese sometimes. Like with bamboo, going down in order toward the youngest.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a line of bamboo shoots arranged from oldest to youngest. They look like pipe organ pipes, or a xylophone, and now you need to count them.
additionalR:
Hints
Now they're in descending order already, and you can count them nice and easy thanks to your dye method.
readingMnemonic: To remember you need to use the ordinal number prefix before you count these bamboo, you dye (だい) them.

meaningMnemonic: A crab left on the moon for a period of time will surely die. Crabs aren’t meant for the moon, let alone outer space. Why would you take a crab to the moon? You take it outside the spaceship for any period of time and it will surely die.
additionalM:
Hints
I’m sure you’ve seen movies where people go out in space with no spacesuit. Now imagine this happening to the poor crab. It only takes a small period of time for the dark reaches of space to kill him.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this crab floating around in an aquarium half filled with water in little to no gravity. The water is floating all about and the crab is confused as can be. He just wants the key so he can get out of this crazy moon box and back to the real ocean where he belongs.
readingMnemonic: In order for this crab to live on the moon for any period of time, you’re going to need to put him in a special moon aquarium and lock the lid with a key (き). This crab is crafty, so after you lock it, take the key with you and don’t let it out of your sight for any period of time. This crab knows how to use a key.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to fix a tree you have to plant it. It's pretty obvious that digging up the tree broke it. So fix it by planting it again. That is how plants work.
additionalM:
Hints
Is your tree broken? Fix it up by planting it somewhere else. Somewhere with the right amount of light and no biting bugs.
additionalR:
Hints
Have you ever seen a tree in shock? Imagine it now. It's shaking and dying and sad. Make sure you properly plant all your trees from now on.
readingMnemonic: If you don't plant a tree it goes into shock (しょく). Which, honestly, shouldn't be very shocking to you, since it's a tree.

meaningMnemonic: A tree root is still just a root!
additionalM:
Hints
Roots are roots, ね.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a family of condors nestled at the bottom of a tree in its roots. Then a huge machine comes over and mows them all down as it cuts all the trees off their roots. Darn you humans! Do you have to ruin everything?!
readingMnemonic: Tree roots are the perfect roosting place for condors (こん). Unfortunately, living on roots is also why they're always endangered. Condors can be killed pretty easily living on the ground on roots like this.

meaningMnemonic: If you shoot a tall stalk of beans with an arrow, the bean plant will go from tall to short. When the beans are hit with that arrow, it severs the plant in two, and you are left with a stalk of beans that is much shorter than before.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself shooting this arrow. Imagine yourself nocking the arrow to the bow, and pulling the string back. That bean plant is not short enough, and you’re going to do something about it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself being out in the sun for so long that you get an amazing tan. Your skin feels warm all over from all the sun you were getting throughout the day. Feel the warmth coming off of your tanned skin.
readingMnemonic: All this shooting of arrows to make the bean plants more short is taking a long time. Since you’re out in the sun, you’re starting to get a tan (たん). After the day is finally over, your tan is really, really dark.

meaningMnemonic: The king requests a sphere! He didn't say what kind though, so you're going to have to figure it out and bring him the right kind of sphere.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all the different spheres you know and bring them to the king one by one. He doesn't seem to like any of them... think of more spheres!
additionalR:
Hints
Cucumbers aren't really spheres... they're circles at best if you cut them, but you can't tell the king that. Just let him eat your cucumbers and think they're sphere-shaped. Maybe next time use a melon-baller and make your cucumbers into spheres for him.
readingMnemonic: You can't seem to find the sphere the king requested, so you take a break, sit down, and take out your lunch. "THAT!" the king screams, "THAT IS THE SPHERE I REQUESTED!" You look down and he's pointing to the cut up cucumbers (きゅう) in your salad.

meaningMnemonic: White water shoots out from a spring in the ground. Due to the force the water shoots from the spring, the water looks white with all the air bubbles.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine these geysers and the white water shooting from the springs under the ground. Now imagine yourself standing over one when the water shoots out. You’d get super wet and probably knocked over due to the force of the spring water. Imagine this happening to yourself.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this centaur standing over the white water. It’s just like a shower for him! Hear him laughing with mirth as the whoosh of the spring water washes him down.
readingMnemonic: The only creature powerful enough to withstand the force of these white water springs is the mythical centaur (せん). His horse body allows him to be stable and withstand the white water shooting up from the spring. Centaurs are pretty impressive creatures.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami lifts all the trash out of the river and it streams out onto the shores.
additionalM:
Hints
As the tsunami recedes, watch as all of the trash comes streaming out of the river and crowds the bank.
additionalR:
Hints
Now Ryu is punching and kicking and tatsumaki senpukyaku-ing all of the trash into burnable and non-burnable piles. But the stream doesn't end. Now he's trying to get his other Street Fighter pals to help him beat it back!
readingMnemonic: Next to the trash stream you suddenly see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter and he looks pissed. He's furious that so many people throw their trash in the river and it causes streams like this.

meaningMnemonic: The radical suit and the kanji suit are exactly the same! This kanji can also mean join which makes sense. When something suits you well, like a hat or something, it joins together with you quite well too. Join me, my hat! You suit my head well. It just fits, you know?
additionalM:
Hints
Just remember that this "suit" means "to suit you" - not the thing you wear, okay!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine you two standing next to each other, posing for a photograph. You two suit each other well. ごういち with his gray beard, and you with your [well, you have to fill in this part by yourself].
readingMnemonic: You need someone who will suit you. Someone who can join you on your life journey. So you call ごういち.

meaningMnemonic: A building has easy access to sunshine. It's big and tall, so the sunlight shines right onto its roof.
additionalM:
Hints
You're standing on top of the building as the sunshine comes down. Its warm light fills your entire body as it covers the building with ease.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the sunlight on your face and taste the yogurt on your tongue. What flavor is it? Try to imagine it as vividly as you can so that sunlight always tastes like yogurt from now on.
readingMnemonic: Standing in sunshine for this long has worked up your appetite, so you take a yogurt (よう) cup out of your bag and eat it.

meaningMnemonic: Stop! That box of rice is actually full of teeth! I know it says "rice" on the cover, but I promise you those are all teeth and if you bite into them you'll break a tooth of your own.
additionalM:
Hints
Stop what you're doing and look into the rice box. Nope, it's definitely full of teeth. There's a grain or two of rice, but it's like 98% teeth.
additionalR:
Hints
Ha! Wouldn't you like to know why there are teeth in there? Ha. Ha ha. HA HA HA HA!
readingMnemonic: Why do I have a rice box full of teeth? Ha (は)! Would you like to know. Ha! I definitely have an answer that isn't weird or creepy. Ha... ha ha...

meaningMnemonic: If someone with a gun is headed your direction, nock an arrow in your bow and gather your tribe behind you because it’s about to get real! This cretin with a gun is headed your direction and he doesn’t even know what you and your tribe are gonna do to him. If he gets any closer, you’re likely to shoot that arrow right at him.
additionalM:
Hints
This guy headed your direction with his gun doesn’t look friendly at all. Hear the sound of the bowstring as you nock your arrow and prepare your shot to defend yourself. Then imagine the sound of everyone in your tribe doing the same.
additionalR:
Hints
You remember what a bosozoku is, right? We wrote about them on Tofugu a while ago. They’re bike gang members and the “zoku” in bosozoku means tribe. Remember that article when you see this kanji.
readingMnemonic: When he starts to get closer, you notice that this guy is a bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member. Bosozoku means “running tribe” and this guy is running right at you. With a gun. So gather your own tribe behind you and prepare to defend yourself against this bosozoku member.

meaningMnemonic: If your friendly neighborhood tofu takes a gun and points it in your direction, you might want to take a trip. This tofu obviously has something wrong with it. If it’s taking a gun and pointing it in your direction, now’s probably a good time to get away and take that trip you’d been talking about.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this menacing block of tofu threatening you with a gun. Guns are scary so you want to get away. Use images of your trip to make the thoughts of the big bad tofu and his gun fade away.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being stuck on a trip with a block of tofu that took your robe and is wearing it around, still pointing the gun in your face. This vacation has been ruined.
readingMnemonic: Your plan didn't work and the tofu went on your trip with you. And now it's wearing your hotel robe (りょ)! It looks so comfortable, wrapped up in the robe. That's the best part of going on trips, and he stole it from you.

meaningMnemonic: People who loiter around the temple are probably just trying to wait. They don't mean to look like they're up to no good, but it's hard to wait without looking suspicious when you're waiting outside a temple.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine waiting outside a temple. People are giving you looks. People think you're loitering, not just waiting innocently.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine adjusting your tie as you wait. Oh no, now even more people are staring at you. The tie thing is making you look even more suspicious!
readingMnemonic: As you wait outside the temple, you can't help but adjust your tie (たい). When you wait you get nervous, and when you get nervous you fidget. So now you're messing with your tie a whole bunch.

meaningMnemonic: After a tsunami, any plate left out in the sun will be sure to get warm. The tsunami knocked this plate out of the kitchen, and now it’s just sitting outside in the sun. The sun heats things, so the plate is getting really warm.
additionalM:
Hints
Right after the tsunami, this plate was wet, but the sun is warming and drying the plate. Imagine looking at the plate and seeing the beads of water evaporate off it as it warms up. Feel the warm steam on your face as this happens.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself frying onions on this plate warmed by the sun. Smell the onion smell as the onion fumes get into your eyes and your sinuses. It makes your eyes water as you are very sensitive to onions.
readingMnemonic: The plate starts to get so warm that you could fry an onion (おん) on it. Who doesn’t love fried onions? That plate sure is warm enough, so start cookin’ ‘em!

meaningMnemonic: There are sheep right before your eyes, because they just love what you wear. It's a little known fact that sheep are fashionistas, and they arrive daily to admire your style. These sheep are so stylish they wear their tail to one side - in the latest fashion (check out the sheep radical - the tail is sweeping stylishly to the left!).
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all the chic sheep lining up to check out your style, with their carefully coiffed left-hanging tails!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself chalking up a line on a chalk board for each sheep that comes to admire you.
readingMnemonic: More sheep arrive every day to admire the clothes you're wearing. You use a chalk (ちゃく) board to keep count of how many sheep come by each day.

meaningMnemonic: If you compare white light to the other colors you'll realize... white consists of all the colors in one. It contains all the colors in the spectrum in one color. It is the one color that is everything.
additionalM:
Hints
Just look at the color white. Compare it to other colors. Now look at white again. Split it up into all the colors, creating a beautiful spectrum. Wow, it's all the colors!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine everything covered in white. Everything in the world. Then, you see a dark splotch. It's the miners, they're all covered in coal, ruining all your ambitions. Walk up to them and see all the dirt on the perfectly white uniforms you gave them just a few minutes earlier. Feel enraged at them. How could they ruin all this white you made for all the people of the world!?
readingMnemonic: You decide white light is the ultimate color. You decide you want to put it on all things to make everything white. "What a great idea," you think. You try to put it on everything and you nearly succeed... except, the miners (みな). They keep getting dirty doing all their mining things. NOOO, your plan is ruined!

meaningMnemonic: You thought it would be a good idea to say the body measurements of everyone in your village and now you have to apologize.
additionalM:
Hints
When you do a bad thing you should apologize. And saying everyone's private body measurements is definitely something you should not have done. So it's apology time.
additionalR:
Hints
"What do we say?" the shaman says, poking you in the back. "Ugh, I'm sorry I told everyone how tiny your socks are, I guess." "And?" "Annnddd I'll never do it again."
readingMnemonic: You were told you had to apologize by the village shaman (しゃ). At first you didn't even know why everyone was glaring at you, but the shaman took you aside and explained. And now she's standing behind you with her arms crossed as you apologize to everybody.

meaningMnemonic: Putting your wood in bundles for winter is the correct way to arrange it. You want to make sure you organize all of your wood before winter comes, or the loose logs could get blown away in the first winter storm.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the bundles, neatly arranged and organized, as the first snowflakes begin to fall.
additionalR:
Hints
You can't just throw an entire bundle of logs onto a fire, you have to saber them into smaller chunks. And it's easier to arrange them first, saber them all in half, and then you have two nicely arranged rows!
readingMnemonic: Right after you've finished arranging the bundles, you take out your saber (せい) and do one final slice. All of the bundles are now perfectly organized AND cut.

meaningMnemonic: A tree from heaven with a mustache above his mouth valiantly crosses a bridge. This holy tree from heaven was sent down to earth to cross this very bridge. It is the tree’s angelic mission. Also the tree has a mouth and a mustache.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this majestic tree as it crosses the bridge. Its mustache is very distinguished. Hear its roots and branches swaying, creaking, and cracking in the wind.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine sitting on the bridge with the tree and eating hash browns with it. It's heavenly!
readingMnemonic: The tree finishes crossing the bridge and on the other side is a plate of steaming hash (はし) browns! That's why it has a mouth. To eat yummy bridge hash browns.

meaningMnemonic: You want to get a scooter so you have one of yourself (oneself) and another self working together to choose. The two tiny yous sit on each of your shoulders and argue about which scooter you should choose.
additionalM:
Hints
The white self says you should choose the safest scooter. The red self says safety is for suckers, and you should buy one that's loud and dangerous and covered in flames.
additionalR:
Hints
The white self says, I choose this centaur scooter because of its strong arms. The red self says, I choose this scooter because it looks like a badass horse monster, wooh!
readingMnemonic: Suddenly your selfs both gasp and choose the scooter in front of you that looks like a centaur (せん). The scooter is designed like a human on the top, the bars are its arms, and the bottom with the seat and the wheels are all horse. This centaur is what you choose to ride.

meaningMnemonic: On this tree there is an eye inside a heart that was drawn trying to express some sort of concept. Unfortunately, concepts like this, especially concept art, has never been your strong suit.
additionalM:
Hints
You sit down in front of the tree with its eye heart and stare at it, trying to understand the concept it's trying to express. Concepts are too abstract. This is hard.
additionalR:
Hints
The soul of the tree or symbol or whoever granted the ability to understand complicated concepts to YOUR soul. Groovy.
readingMnemonic: After a few hours of contemplating this concept, suddenly it becomes clear and a soul (そう) pops out of the tree. It leans forward and touches your forehead and your head fills with new concepts and ideas you've never considered before.

meaningMnemonic: Big products need to be put in a big container. A small container just won’t do. These products are big and they need a big container to be contained in.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having all these big products. How will you contain them all!? Imagine yourself stuffing all of these big products into their respective containers.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the size of these big keys you have to use to lock these containers. It’s a really big key. Picture yourself straining to turn the key in the lock.
readingMnemonic: Once you get the big products into a container, you then lock it with a key (き). You wouldn’t want these products to bust out of their containers, so it’s best to lock them up with a key.

meaningMnemonic: If you yourself are a sun, and you stand next to another sun, no area around you will be dark. The two suns are very bright and standing right next to each other, so all the area will be lit up and nothing will be dark.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of how bright the sun is. Now multiply that by two. Suns are especially bright right after you come out of a dark area. Imagine yourself looking at these suns and feeling the pain as your eyes are blinded by the bright light.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself eating anchovies. The anchovies taste particularly fishy and salty. Taste the anchovies on your tongue as you eat them in darkness.
readingMnemonic: Since the sun has blinded you, your vision is now very dark. You can’t see anything, but you are hungry so you reach around for some food and eat it. Yuck! It’s anchovies (あん). You don’t even like anchovies, how did they get in your house?

meaningMnemonic: When you get home from school, your mama says to hang your spoons and arrows on the coat rack. That doesn't sound like something your mama would say, and you begin to doubt that she's your mama at all! She usually takes them and washes them in the sink. You doubt you could hang them on the coat rack even if you tried.
additionalM:
Hints
Your mama is acting weird. You doubt she's really your mama. What are you going to do?
additionalR:
Hints
Watch the doubt wash over her face as she looks up at you from her position in the guillotine. Finally she mutters, "Well, this is disappointing, and I doubt you hung up your spoons and arrows on the coat rack before trying to murder your ol' mum."
readingMnemonic: Your doubt is growing really strong, so you decide to test your mama by putting her head in a guillotine (ぎ)! Oh come on, don't feel bad, you're preeettty sure this isn't your real mama.

meaningMnemonic: You have a rice ladle that's specifically for paying the rice fee. Each scoop of something has an extra fee tacked on, so when you use a material, there's a fee you have to pay in that material as well.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine ladling up a nice big scoop of rice and then seeing the little fee ladle next to it. Ugh. The material fee.
additionalR:
Hints
That's a lot of material you have to give up every time you want to eat some rice. Maybe you should take this row boat oar ladle and row out into the ocean where no one can tax you.
readingMnemonic: One day, the fee ladle is suddenly the size of row (りょう) boat oars! What! You're supposed to pay a row boat sized fee now?!

meaningMnemonic: Your soul is blue. As in, it's sad and not feeling well. Your soul changes colors depending on what it's feeling or what emotion you're expressing.
additionalM:
Hints
Start with a blue soul. What feeling is that? Now a red soul. What emotion is that? Go through as many colors as you can think of, focusing on the fact that each color represents a different emotion or feeling.
additionalR:
Hints
Perhaps Jourm can't read. Or perhaps he doesn't want to see you again because of something you did. Whatever the story, make sure it makes you feel a little blue too.
readingMnemonic: Why is your soul feeling blue? Because Jourm (じょう) the big man farmhand did something mean to you. Imagine a story playing out, and then imagine your soul turning blue with emotion.

meaningMnemonic: Down a slide, a drunkard comes and places a creeper into your heart. Your entire body is filled with a feeling. A feeling you don't like.
additionalM:
Hints
This awful sliding drunkard filled your heart with his creeper vibes (and an actual creeper) and now you're feeling a lot of things. Probably bad things.
additionalR:
Hints
Genghis Khan's horse and sword materialize out of your feelings and you ride toward the drunkard who made you feel these things.
readingMnemonic: This feeling wells up in you and bursts forth. You feel mad, you feel like you want revenge, you feel like Genghis Khan (かん) reborn! And you will have your revenge on this drunkard.

meaningMnemonic: A sheep in the water by a tree has the formal name title of Sir Wilburt Coddington III. When he’s not in his castle, Sir Wilburt Coddington III enjoys playing in water and by trees. He’s a royal sheep.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture how Sir Wilburt Coddington III obtained his formal name title. He must have done some pretty amazing things, even for a sheep. Just imagine the feats he must have accomplished.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine playing in the water in the summer. It’s crazy hot outside in the summer, so going in the water feels nice. Imagine the coolness of the refreshing water around your body.
readingMnemonic: This sheep with the formal name title of Sir Wilburt Coddington III only likes to play outside in the water during the summer (さま). Summer is the best season for this fancy sheep. The other seasons just can’t compare.

meaningMnemonic: Sheep fins are good for fostering children. The sheep have been genetically combined with fish, so the sheep have fins (and they've lost their tails - which is why the tail part of the sheep radical is missing in this kanji!). These sheep fins are very rich in nutrients and as such are very good for foster children that need to grow up big and strong.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine eating a fish fin with sheep wool on it. It tastes fishy like the ocean but the wool tastes like clothes. It’s probably the worst thing ever. Imagine eating something like this and taste its flavor on your tongue.
additionalR:
Hints
Remember how bad those sheep fins tasted? Now imagine eating your favorite yogurt flavor instead. This yogurt is delicious.
readingMnemonic: The best way to foster a better relationship with these foster kids would be to give them some yogurt (よう). Maybe they can dip the sheep fins in the yogurt to help mask the strange taste. Yogurt is also very nutritious, so it’s a good supplement to the foster kids’ diet.

meaningMnemonic: If you see a wolverine in the water playing with a piece of thread, there’s no doubt that it’s green. Wolverines love green thread. Almost as much as they love the water.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this wolverine playing with the green thread. It’s like a little kitten with yarn. That wolverine loves that green thread. Picture how cute it is as it plays with the thread and coos in happiness.
additionalR:
Hints
If you’ve ever had Midori before, imagine that taste. It’s also green, so that’s an easy way to remember this kanji. If you haven’t had it, just picture the taste of melon and imagine that flavor on your tongue.
readingMnemonic: Midori (みどり) is a green colored melon liqueur with a sweet, fruity taste. This wolverine is too young to drink alcohol like Midori, so he just sticks to drinking water.

meaningMnemonic: Your womb spins in a circle and starts to boil with heat. Uh oh, I think you have a fever.
additionalM:
Hints
Even if you don't have a womb, just picture one anyway: it's turning around in a circle faster and faster, as the heat bubbles and boils in you. You can feel this heat spread through your entire body as you burn up with a fever.
additionalR:
Hints
These nets aren't making the fever heat go away, but they have made the spinning stop at least.
readingMnemonic: The heat from your fever is making your insides and your head and your entire body spin and boil, until your doctor throws some nets (ねつ) around you. You were flailing around and they couldn't get you to stop, so they had to catch you in a series of nets.

meaningMnemonic: A cult leader has a great idea to recruit a hundred million new members. Since he’s the guy with all the ideas, he is the leader of the cult. His idea is to give every new member a free puppy. He’ll have a hundred million new recruits in no time.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a hundred million free puppies. That’s a lot. Imagine playing with all of them. You’d be pretty happy. Unless you hate puppies. Then you’d be pretty unhappy, I imagine.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this cult leader gathering a hundred million people into Oklahoma. It’d be awfully crowded. Imagine yourself being stifled by the bodies of a hundred million other people.
readingMnemonic: The cult leader has his headquarters in Oklahoma (おく). Are there a hundred million people in Oklahoma? No, probably not. But hey, this leader is shooting for the stars. First Oklahoma, then the universe!

meaningMnemonic: There's treasure in this tree so you take out your weapon and kill it.
additionalM:
Hints
You didn't just cut the tree down, you stabbed it and sliced it and killed it to death.
additionalR:
Hints
You sats down after killing the tree because now the tree is getting its revenge and killing you back. Was there poison in the tree? And where is the treasure that was up there?!
readingMnemonic: After the kill though, you didn't feel so good, and you had to sats (さつ) down. Woah, I mean sat... sats? Uh oh. Something is happening to you. You sats down but your brain is all funny and you can't get up again.

meaningMnemonic: The roof under which the leader can house one hundred of his people is at the local lodge.
additionalM:
Hints
Back in the old days a lodge had to be huuuuge so when a leader brought a hundred people through town they'd have a place to stay.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being someone staying at the lodge as they came in and everything shook around you. This lodge would probably last through an earthquake too!
readingMnemonic: The lodge shook (しゅく) as the hundred people came tumbling in through the door. It shook, but it didn't fall over. The roof stayed firmly in place, and everyone got to sleep under it okay.

meaningMnemonic: When a spirit decides to live in your scarecrow, you'll be granted good luck. Crows won't hang out in your farm. Everything you grow will become large and delicious. But not everyone is so lucky that a spirit will decide to live in their scarecrow. So maybe the luck was in you all along!
additionalM:
Hints
Nope, the luck is definitely coming from the spirit in your scarecrow. You aren't lucky on your own.
additionalR:
Hints
If you get a luck spirit to say f*** you, you might accidentally convince it to move somewhere else. If it does, you lose your luck. So be careful.
readingMnemonic: You want to check the scarecrow to make sure your recent luck is coming from it, so you kick it. "F*** (ふく) you!" it yells. Oh yeah, there's a spirit in there.

meaningMnemonic: You can see gold if you stand in front of a mirror. Yes, you are made of gold. You’re so great and valuable, standing in front of that mirror. It’s not hard to see, especially in a mirror – you’re golden.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at yourself in the mirror only to see you’re made of gold. It would be pretty shocking. Imagine how surprised you would be.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being the CAG of a ship You are in charge of all the pilots and defending the ship. It’s a lot of responsibility. Can you handle it?
readingMnemonic: Your name is Amy and you are the CAG (Commander, Air Group) of the Battlestar Galactica. People call you CAG Amy (かがみ). You have so many gold medals on you that you’ve earned the nickname “Golden CAG Amy.” You like to look at yourself in the mirror and admire yourself.

meaningMnemonic: Under a misshapen crescent moon, a dog boils as much nature as it can find.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a weird-looking, misshapen crescent moon casting its light onto the scene of a dog boiling up everything you'd find in nature. Trees, sticks, mud, little animals. All of that is being boiled by this dog by the light of a weird-looking moon.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the dog kneeling in front of the pot of concentrated nature and breathing deeply as it practiced Zen. You kind of wish you could join it, considering how peaceful it looks.
readingMnemonic: Destroying nature like this is the dog's way of practicing Zen (ぜん) Buddhism. As it breathes in the fumes from all of the different pieces of nature being boiled down, the dog gets really zen and chill.

meaningMnemonic: What you say at a temple is a poem. It has to be a poem, because if you say anything else it's just plain disrespectful. All of the monks and priests at this temple have to read and recite poems all day, and if they can do it forever, you can while you're visiting.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the people at the temple reciting poems together. You join in too, and it's a really powerful moment!
additionalR:
Hints
You turn to the person next to you and realize you have to say everything in poem form.
Excuse me
I'm not a creep
so hear my plea
is that a sheep?
readingMnemonic: As you recite a long poem at the temple you see a sheep (し) in the crowd. It's opening and closing its mouth like it wants to say the poem too.

meaningMnemonic: Pointing a thread to the east, you practice your navigation skills. You’ve discovered a method to tell direction using just a thread, so you point it to the east in order to find your way. The method takes practice though, so you’re sure to practice every day.
additionalM:
Hints
