East is the land of the rising sun, so imagine yourself practicing this method, pointing the thread to the east as the sun rises up. Feel the heat of the sun’s rays and see the bright light as the sun shines up over the horizon.
additionalR:
Hints
If you’ve ever seen the show Ren & Stimpy, imagine what it would be like to be Ren. If not, watch a clip on YouTube and pretend you are Ren when you practice doing things, like studying kanji.
readingMnemonic: Also, you are Ren (れん), from Ren & Stimpy the TV show. Since you’re not in the TV business anymore, you’ve decided to practice your other skills. How mature of you, Ren.

meaningMnemonic: Shoot a shellfish that's in the mouth of a Viking at the fair and you'll win a prize. The game is to shoot the shellfish in the Viking's mouth and knock it over.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at a big Viking with a shellfish in its mouth. You want to knock it over. You want this prize.
additionalR:
Hints
You want this prize. You want to meet the Shougun. Soon you'll both be eating shellfish together!
readingMnemonic: The prize you're working so hard to win is lunch with the Shougun (しょう). This is a pretty huge prize, considering all you're doing is knocking something over.

meaningMnemonic: If you run into a gate mouth first, you’re going to have a problem. Smashing your mouth into a gate is going to hurt. A lot. The problem you’re now in is one of getting to a hospital and having your mouth sewn back on.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having your mouth bashed into a gate. It’s going to hurt. Imagine how painful this would be and how problematic it is.
additionalR:
Hints
Monsters are scary. Maybe you’ve had a dream where you were being chased by one. Remember how scary that is when you see this kanji.
readingMnemonic: The reason you ran mouth first into this gate was because you were being chased by a monster (もん). A monster in and of itself is a big enough problem as is, let alone smashing your mouth into a gate. You poor, hapless soul.

meaningMnemonic: Eating on this roof is a bear, which is how you know this is a public building. The law says that all bears are allowed to eat on the roofs of public buildings. In Japan at least, I don't know where bears are supposed to eat in wherever you're from.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a public building, like a museum or a library, and look at the roof. There's a bear eating up there! And it's smiling and waving to you!
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you see a public building, think, "Thank you Genghis Khan." Because of him bears are free to go up to the roof and eat whatever they please whenever they please.
readingMnemonic: All public buildings must serve bear needs thanks to the monumental law passed by Genghis Khan (かん). Genghis Khan knew that bears weren't treated well by humans, so he made sure all public buildings were at least partially bear accessible.

meaningMnemonic: The sun in the center of the sky gives off its light, which reflects off of everything around it.
additionalM:
Hints
Look around you, everything you see is reflecting the light of the sun. Unless it's night time, then the tiny sun in the center of your lightbulb is creating the light that reflects there.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the light of the sun reflecting off a single acorn on the forest floor. So much symbolism!
readingMnemonic: This reflected light is important for acorns (えい), in particular. Without light reflecting off everything, the sun's light would never make it down to the ground where they've fallen. They would never grow into trees. And we'd all suffocate.

meaningMnemonic: The original geoduck had a request. He wants there to be more geoducks in the world!
additionalM:
Hints
Remember, this is the OG = original geoduck. There are no other geoducks yet.
additionalR:
Hints
People listened when Gandhi said, "My friends. We must stop trying to eat the geoduck, and instead allow it to breed. Join me in this fast!"
And that's why we have so many geoducks on the earth today. Thanks Gandhi.
readingMnemonic: The only person that would even hear the geoduck's request was Gandhi (がん). Gandhi closed his eyes, sat down, and spread the geoduck's request to the rest of the world.

meaningMnemonic: The samurai radical and the samurai kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the sheep samurai. Maybe draw him on a piece of paper. He's a sheep wearing wool armor, and he has ram horns on the hilt of his katana.
readingMnemonic: The most famous samurai in Japanese history was the illustrious sheep (し) samurai. He wasn't JUST a sheep who learned the ways of the sword, he would use the wool from the sheep enemies he killed to create his armor!

meaningMnemonic: I always say the fruit section at the grocery should be at the front of the store. It’s the perfect place for the fruit section, I say.
additionalM:
Hints
Think about it. Every grocery store has the fruit section right at the front, wouldn’t you say?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself driving a car and salivating over the fruit waiting for you in the fruit section. Imagine your favorite fruit as you put the pedal to the metal in your awesome car.
readingMnemonic: To get to the fruit section, you have to go to the store. To get to the store you have to drive a car (か). Driving a car is the fastest way to get to the fruit section at the store.

meaningMnemonic: You see a tree with a helicopter and a jackhammer tied to it. You look closer, because this is an odd sight, and realize that there is a sign here too. It's telling you to beware of helicopters and jackhammers in this woods. It's a poorly made signpost!
additionalM:
Hints
This is not the best signpost you've ever seen, but it's better than nothing at all, you suppose.
additionalR:
Hints
Press it a few more times and hear the sound in your head. Also spell it out in kana as you hear it as a nice little additional visual.
readingMnemonic: As you look at this weird signpost you notice a button. You press it because it will supposedly tell you more about these dangerous helicopters and jackhammers. Instead, it just yells out in a loud obnoxious voice: HEYO (ひょう)!!

meaningMnemonic: At the root of gold, there is silver. Gold is basically just silver leveled up. That's why gold is first place, and silver is second. If you just scratch gold really good, you'll find that at its root, there's silver hidden just underneath.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine taking a gold coin and rubbing it with some soap and water. As you rub, you slowly see that it's really silver underneath. Huh!
additionalR:
Hints
Guinea pigs are to silver as normal pigs are to truffles.
readingMnemonic: If you want to hunt for some silver for yourself, all you need is a guinea (ぎん) pig. Guinea pigs can smell silver, so get a couple and set them loose in the woods and they'll lead you straight to it.

meaningMnemonic: A horse and a shrimp are sitting next to each other. They are both at the train station, waiting for a train to come and take them home.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the horse and the shrimp sitting next to each other on a small bench. There is nobody else at the train station. It is awkward.
additionalR:
Hints
Instead of saying "a key" he says "eh key." How strange. Imagine the station master saying it like this with his weird accent. You ask him if he has "a key" and he replies with, "What is a key?" Then you say "eh key." He totally understands you now.
readingMnemonic: The train pulls into the station. They walk up to the train doors, but they don't open. "Perhaps a key (えき) would help?" asks the station master, as he goes over to open the door to the train.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the elephants was so great, they made a statue of him. This image of him looks down on all the other elephants at all times.
additionalM:
Hints
For now, just imagine the leader of the elephants being told they're getting a statue. Don't think about what the statue looks like, because that's next.
additionalR:
Hints
But this is exactly what the leader of the elephants asked for. For you see, the leader of the elephants was a big fan of zombies. Imagine the elephant leader being so excited to have a zombie version of the statue.
readingMnemonic: When they unveil the statue of the leader elephant, everyone gasps. It's a statue of the leader, but they are a zombie (ぞう). Gasp!

meaningMnemonic: If you use the sun, you can find the correct geoduck. That's the topic of today's lecture.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a teacher pointing to a chalkboard with a big pointer, and it says "TOPIC."
additionalR:
Hints
You use the dye in the correct sunlight to find the geoducks hiding under the sand. And once we master this topic, we'll move onto actually using dye to find them in the wild.
readingMnemonic: Our topic is actually mostly about using the sun to see different colored dyes (だい) in the water.

meaningMnemonic: For your car you use a hat, some ground and a bookshelf to build a new wheel. I mean, it's generally ring and loop shaped, so it should work, right?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this wheel you made out of a hat, some ground (presumably to keep it all together), and a bookshelf. You install it on your car and hope for the best. This is why you should buy wheels from professional wheel makers.
additionalR:
Hints
A ring-shaped wheel is better than nothing. Hopefully it will get you where you need to go.
readingMnemonic: Your wheel is... generally ring (りん) shaped, so that's good.

meaningMnemonic: You keep some private spoons on the moon and they give you a special ability. It's the ability to predict the future! The moon spoons reflect the knowledge of time and space into your brain. Now that's a cool ability!
additionalM:
Hints
I wish I had this kind of ability... maybe I'll go up to the moon and try to steal your spoons.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh, you thought I was talking about that old Nostradamus, who also had the ability to predict things? Nah, you're way cooler than him.
readingMnemonic: This ability to predict the future makes you famous and now everyone knows your name: Nostradamus (のう)! And now that people know about your name and special ability, everyone will love you!

meaningMnemonic: There are fake flowers at your feet and fake clouds above you because you're acting.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine acting in a play or a movie where there are flowers and clouds all around you. You're singing and smiling and dancing and acting your absolute heart out!
additionalR:
Hints
Maybe you'll love it, maybe you'll hate it. Whatever happens, feel that emotion well up, as the flowers and clouds spin around you, and you act out the scene.
readingMnemonic: You have to do some acting that involves you being gay (げい). You should imagine this scene, whether you're gay and it's not actual acting or not.

meaningMnemonic: There go some angel with drop on their shoulders. Carrying drops like that is a real art. It requires technique.
additionalM:
Hints
Angels are really good at going around carrying drops! Imagine the artistry and technique involved. I bet they do some kind of dance, and there's lots of sparkly magic.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine an angel trained in ninjutsu. Marvel at all their divine ninja techniques!
readingMnemonic: Angels are so good at this because they are trained in ninjutsu (じゅつ), or the "art of being a ninja." Everyone knows that ninjas are great at carrying drops on the go!

meaningMnemonic: Part rain, part other stuff. I imagine this is what people thought the atmosphere was made out of thousands of years ago.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking up into the sky, trying to figure out what the atmosphere up there is made out of. Your only lead: It's raining, a lot. So, the atmosphere must be partly made of rain, and it's just falling down.
additionalR:
Hints
Also, studying the atmosphere is a ton of fun (ふん), if you're into that sort of thing.
readingMnemonic: The reading for this kanji is actually the same as 分s. One trick about complicated kanji is they often take the reading of one of the pieces that they're made from. In this case it's 分, which is cool.

meaningMnemonic: If you have a mustache and you hit your forehead on the moon, you’re probably going to break a bone. Ok, so it doesn’t matter so much if you have a mustache, but if you’re travelling fast enough to make it to the moon, you’re definitely breaking a bone if you run into it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the force and mass of the moon hitting you right in the boney part of your forehead. Whomp! It sure would hurt.
additionalR:
Hints
Again, feel your bones crack as you smash into the moon. At least you're warm though. Feel the cozy coats you're wearing and snuggle up in their warmth.
readingMnemonic: Outer space is cold, and if you're traveling to the moon, you're going to need a lot of coats (こつ). All of these coats will keep you warm, even if you do end up breaking your forehead bone.

meaningMnemonic: The bundle radical and the bundle kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine doing laundry and making sure to bundle your socks together so none of them will be lost.
readingMnemonic: You should always bundle your socks (そく). If you don't, there is a 100% chance you'll lose all of the left ones.

meaningMnemonic: The circumference radical and the circumference kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Try to find the circumference of your shoe and then email us with the measurement. I promise you'll never forget this kanji if you actually do it.
readingMnemonic: Practice how to measure the circumference of an item by using your shoe (しゅう). Your shoe is kind of round, and it's free. I mean it's right there on your foot.

meaningMnemonic: Next to the cross we combine our power power power so that we have cooperation. And with our powers combined, we become stronger than we ever could have been apart, lifting the cross above our heads!
additionalM:
Hints
The power of cooperation is a *ahem* powerful thing.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being a citizen of きょうと. Watch as the powers from your neighboring prefectures march across the border to come cooperate together to stop the bandits that raided your farm. You admire their cooperation. You admire きょうと!
readingMnemonic: Nowhere is the power of cooperation more apparent than in きょうと. When invaders are attacking, when the townspeople want to rebel, when there is a kitty up a tree, the people combine their power from all reaches of Japan and cross into きょうと to put a stop to the madness through cooperation.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the yakuza shows you his knife. He says, "This is an example of a knife."
additionalM:
Hints
The leader of the yakuza is just showing you an example of a knife. Maybe to scare you? Why would an example of what a knife is scare you, though? Coming from the leader of the yakuza, this is a weird tactic.
additionalR:
Hints
Why is the leader of the yakuza showing you examples of weapons, not to mention weapons that aren't real, like ray guns?
readingMnemonic: "This is an example," the leader of the yakuza tells you. Next time, I'll show you an example of a ray (れい) gun.

meaningMnemonic: If your fingers are strong enough you can take an axe and fold it in half. Bad men were cutting down all the forests, so you're going around bending their axes so they can't cut trees down anymore.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding an axe between your fingers and folding it like a pretzel. Or some silly putty. Or a really soft axe.
additionalR:
Hints
How many axes can you bend at once? A set of two? What about a set of four? Or a set of forty-two?
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, as you fold these axes in half you realize they come in sets (せつ), so there are twice the axes you thought there would be. To compensate, you start folding them in sets too.

meaningMnemonic: Crabs in the dirt make a great foundation for a seaside hut. It's right on the seashore, where all the crabs dig their holes in the dirt. But as they get old and die, their bodies form a strong base. Perfect for the foundation of a building like this!
additionalM:
Hints
Do you live on the beach? Maybe the foundation of your house was made from crabs in dirt too. Why don't you go outside and check?
additionalR:
Hints
Keys to houses are always made out of a piece of the foundation it was built upon. How else would they be unique from one another?
readingMnemonic: Remember, a good foundation is the key (き) to a good house. No, literally. You have to use a piece of the foundation to make the key to your house.

meaningMnemonic: Each life has a soul, and that soul determines what gender you are. It's not so much about your body parts, it's more about what's inside that matters.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your own soul and your own life. Listen to what your soul says about your gender and live your life to the fullest!
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you get one of those surveys where you have to choose your gender just think back to that time your life when the Shougun came and officiated your gender with his saber. Ahh, what lovely memories.
readingMnemonic: Once you've decided what your gender is, the Shougun (しょう) comes to your house, lays his saber (せい) on your shoulders, and then it's official! It's in all the newspapers, there's a parade, and everyone is patting you on the back because you did it!

meaningMnemonic: A woman with cleats is walking on someone's back, but she doesn't want to hurt him. She has to be very gentle. Cleats are sharp and pointy, and not designed for back walking, so she's being extra, special gentle right now.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a woman walking gently over someone's back. She's hardly moving.
additionalR:
Hints
Poor, old dad. His back hurts so his daughter has to walk on his back with cleats to make it feel better. But if she isn't gentle enough, she'll just make it worse.
readingMnemonic: Actually, the person she's being gentle with is her dad (だ). No one would ever want to hurt their dad, especially if he's asked you to walk gently on his back as a way of giving him a massage.

meaningMnemonic: A person puts a lid on their cross after they graduate. It’s a symbolic gesture, putting the lid over the cross, but it’s just what you do when you graduate around these parts.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a wooden cross and picture yourself putting a lid over it. Visualize this motion in your mind and imagine having to do something like this at your graduation.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being held back two more years from graduation. You’d lose all your motivation. Imagine how lousy this would be.
readingMnemonic: Oops, looks like you forgot your lid. Without the lid, you’ll be held back. So two (そつ) more years now until you can graduate. So two more years, eh? Just for forgetting a lid? Nonsense!

meaningMnemonic: A mouth that is old is going to be hard.
additionalM:
Hints
Go ahead and touch that old man's mouth. It's super hard feeling when you touch it.
additionalR:
Hints
"You pressed the hard skin holding me captive! Thank you!" the 子 says, as they break free from their hard mouth prison.
readingMnemonic: You touch the old man's hard mouth and it crumbles away, revealing the face of a 子 (こ) inside.

meaningMnemonic: Causing death at every turn, the moon king sits inside his moon, getting ready to cause death on anything in his sights. Sounds a lot like the Death Star from a certain movie. One of which is "Star Wars: A New Hope."
additionalM:
Hints
Now picture the death moon king as the Emperor, sitting in his Death Star. There is no hope, except for that little opening you can shoot through to destroy the whole thing. That's hope, I guess!
additionalR:
Hints
In the end, the real hope was bowling all along. I hope you've learned a valuable lesson from this space movie.
readingMnemonic: The name A New Hope, as we all know, comes from the ending where the moon king's son sends a bowling (ぼう) ball into that little opening and knocks it out of the sky.

meaningMnemonic: A tree to a genius immediately becomes lumber. They can look at the tree and see more: the ability to turn it into lumber into material and use it for a million different things.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the genius staring at a large tree. Math symbols and equations fly around in their head, until finally a little lightbulb and a pile of lumber appear above their head.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the tree becomes lumber and that lumber is used to craft a ginormous xylophone. Each key is its own plank of lumber!
readingMnemonic: This genius doesn't want to use the lumber to build a house or a chair, no no, they're going to use these materials to build a xylophone (ざい)! The most difficult instrument to create!!

meaningMnemonic: You can't keep big hair private, so you end up having to participate in everything. Can you imagine people asking for volunteers and you trying to look inconspicuous with your big hair sticking up and out and all over? Of course they're going to notice you and make you participate.
additionalM:
Hints
When you're thinking about your next hair style, if you don't like participating in things, you should think about something you can actually keep more private.
additionalR:
Hints
Would you want to participate in Christmas if it meant looking like Santa and visiting every single house on earth?
readingMnemonic: You know who has big hair and loves to participate in everything? Santa-san (さん)! Well, his hair is more big on the bottom (it's a beard) than whatever you have on your head, but hair is hair. And he participates in present giving in every house in the world! See? Big hair = participation!

meaningMnemonic: The roof that became the origin of all roofs was perfect. It was tall and wide so it could fit and protect everyone. And the dimensions were perfect too.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this absolutely perfect roof. They really got it right on their first try.
additionalR:
Hints
Genghis Khan was a perfectionist, and by conquering and bringing all of these different people together, he was able to create something perfect by all standards.
readingMnemonic: This perfect roof was commissioned by Genghis Khan (かん). We got all of the carpenters and home makers and construction workers he'd conquered together and tasked them with making the first roof, but only if they made it absolutely perfect.

meaningMnemonic: When climbing a tree in public, it’s best to choose a pine. Pine trees offer the most coverage, so you’ll be able to hide, even out in public.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine climbing up a pine tree. The pine needles are prickly, so your hands get pricked as you climb. Smell the pine tree smell and feel the pine sap on your hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself falling out of this pine tree and onto the mats. The mats are nice and soft so it’s nice. Hear the whoosh of air as you collapse onto the mats.
readingMnemonic: In case you fall, someone has laid mats (まつ) out around the base of the pine tree. That way, you’ll land on the mats should something unfortunate happen.

meaningMnemonic: You tie a thread on your finger before jumping in the pool to remind yourself of the promise you made to your mother. The thread represents the promise you made to mow the lawn after you finished swimming in the pool.
additionalM:
Hints
The promise reminding thread on your finger was tied too tight. You can feel the thread starting to cut off your circulation as your finger starts to turn purple and go numb. It’s really uncomfortable.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself sitting on a riding mower as you’re pulled around the yard by a yak. The yak is having a hard time pulling you so its making lots of yak noises. Hear them in your mind.
readingMnemonic: After you get out of the pool, you keep the promise you made to your mother. So you get on your yak (やく) powered mower and trim the grass. Yes, your mower is pulled by a yak. It’s very efficient.

meaningMnemonic: Yakuza bars barely exist. The remainder of them aren't even in Japan.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the yakuza bars all being shut down. There's only one place where they can remain.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a yakuza bar in Zanzibar. What a strange place to hold out.
readingMnemonic: The remainder of the yakuza bars aren't in Japan. Strangely, they are all in Zanzibar (ざん).

meaningMnemonic: A grain's child will grow with the seasons. In spring the grain is born, it grows in summer, is harvested in fall, and dies in winter.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch the grain children live their entire lives throughout the seasons. Though there are 72 seasons in Japan, so the life of a grain is actually really long there.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture these seasonal keys floating through the sky, unlocking the weather changes, the growth of new grains, and the aging of us all.
readingMnemonic: All of the seasons have their own special key (き). As they change, that season's key appears and unlocks the next step in the grain's life.

meaningMnemonic: You can branch out your fingers. It's your special skill. Your fingers branch out into smaller fingers and you can hold things really well. You can type super-duper fast. And you can win any tickle fight. These are skills you have thanks to your branching fingers.
additionalM:
Hints
If you could have any skill imaginable, what would it be? Would it be to have these magical branching fingers? (Definitely. It would.)
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a tiny guillotine made for the cutting of fingers. Whoever made this must have had special hand skills too! Maybe they tested it on him...
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, these skills are too much for the normal skill-less people to handle and they pull out the guillotine (ぎ). I guess they're going to chop off your skillful fingers because they're kinda scary.

meaningMnemonic: If you kiss a tree, your status will change to, “In a relationship with a tree.”
additionalM:
Hints
You know Facebook relationship statuses. If you kiss a tree, your status will be that you’re in a relationship with said tree. Imagine how silly that would be.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself as a cock, cock-a-doodle-doing about how you really feel about the tree. What would you say to let the tree down easy?
readingMnemonic: Regardless of the status, you need to let the tree know how you feel. Being a cock (かく), y'know, a male chicken, you cock-a-doodle-do your true feelings to the tree. You actually just want to be friends.

meaningMnemonic: The origin of the geoduck is a pretty stubborn one. The geoduck race is so stubborn that it refused to evolve into an animal that made any sense. Hence, the origin of the geoduck is one of stubbornness.
additionalM:
Hints
You know what a geoduck looks like, right? Does that look like a creature that was looking to change and evolve and be awesome? No, geoducks are weird and stubborn. Imagine how stubborn you’d have to be to not want to evolve into a more attractive animal.
additionalR:
Hints
Gandhi’s stubbornness, however, was pretty effective. Everyone knows Gandhi. Remember Gandhi and his famous stubborn attitude whenever you see this kanji.
readingMnemonic: You know who else was stubborn? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi believed in non-violent resistance and he was pretty stubborn about it.

meaningMnemonic: The mouth of a well will surround you if you fall into it. The mouth of a well is the opening of the well, and if you fall into that well, the mouth as well as the rest of the well will surround you.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself surrounded by this well on all sides. You look up and you can barely see the mouth of the well where you fell in and now you are trapped. Imagine how scared you are. Imagine trying to claw your way up the sides of the well but all you do is break your nails on the walls.
additionalR:
Hints
This eagle is basically a superhero. Imagine an eagle dressed in a superman outfit. He’s your savior. Imagine your gratitude towards this eagle superhero.
readingMnemonic: The well walls surround you as you look up to the mouth once again. This time you see an eagle (い) flying overhead. You call out to the eagle to save you and the eagle comes swooping down into the well and flies you out to safety. What a nice eagle!

meaningMnemonic: A white guy jumps into a pool with a target painted on the bottom. He’s aiming for the bullseye.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this pasty white dude jumping into the target bottomed pool. The sun glints off of his unnaturally white skin and stings your eyes.
additionalR:
Hints
He hits the water right on target and the water splashes onto you. Since he was a techie, he was able to perform the perfect dive. And now you’re all wet.
readingMnemonic: This white dude is a huge techie (てき) so he has electronic enhancements that make sure he hits the target. Being a techie has its advantages.

meaningMnemonic: If you live in the now, there’s a good chance your heart controls your thought process. You don’t have time to think with your brain, you need an answer now so you use your heart to make decisions and thought process.
additionalM:
Hints
Think about the last time you thought it was right to make a decision with your heart. What was it? Use these emotions to remember this kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
Think of all the things you'd do with your life if you only had one 年 left. Maybe you should go do some of them anyways, right now?
readingMnemonic: You're living in the now and letting your heart control all your thoughts. Why are you following your heart? You found you only have one 年 (ねん) to live, so you have to live for the now.

meaningMnemonic: There is a treasure on top of a narwhal who wears a towel that will grant your greatest wish.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this narwhal: above its long horn there is a huge, shiny treasure floating. It pulls the towel tight around itself, "Brururu you found me I see!" it whistles at you.
additionalR:
Hints
If you find the key, what will you wish for? Think about your single, greatest wish. Close your eyes and picture it as clearly as you can and you'll find the key.
readingMnemonic: In order to open the treasure and get your wish, you need the key (き). The narwhal knows where it's hidden, so you'll have to convince it to tell you where the key is.

meaningMnemonic: The thread you weave together to tell others about oneself is the account of your life. It's your very own narrative, tying everything you've been through together.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this account of your life, the thread of the narrative linking all of the different important points in your life together.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the people in your life that you'd give this special key to. They'd get to read the account of your life, so make sure they're trustworthy before you hand that key over.
readingMnemonic: You take this account and lock it with a special key (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you.

meaningMnemonic: You run into someone's forehead with your car. The big forehead you hit is Kim Jong Un's. You know that now you're going to have the whole North Korean army coming after you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself running away from the North Korean army. You have to get to the border, the entire army is coming after you for hitting their dear leader!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself running away from them as they shout and shoot at you. Hear the bullets wizzing past your head as you run away as fast as you can.
readingMnemonic: The army is after you. Each army soldier has a gun (ぐん) and they want to use these guns of theirs to shoot you dead! You killed their leader with a car and now they’re gonna get you back with a gun!

meaningMnemonic: Grains look like they're on fire in autumn. They all turn red and orange and brown, the colors of fire. It's also fun to set grains on fire in Autumn, since it's getting colder.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all the grains in autumn. Picture the all of the colors. The colors of fire.
additionalR:
Hints
Ah yes, the sound of the seasons changing to autumn.
Ack!
Ack!
Ack!
readingMnemonic: As the grains burn, and the season changes to autumn, imagine them yelling out in pain: "ACK (あき)!"

meaningMnemonic: You say to your leader, “Believe and trust in me, I’m responsible.” The leader doesn’t think you can handle your duties, so this is why you said this to him. You want him to believe and trust you. You can handle this task.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself saying this to your leader. Say it out loud as you imagine saying it to a leader of some sort.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself pleading with your leader to trust and believe in you. Imagine the hurt of your shins with the shin splints as you kneel. It hurts a lot, but it proves how serious you are.
readingMnemonic: To show you are serious as you say, “Believe and trust in me, I’m responsible,” you kneel down on each shin (しん). You have shin splints, so it hurts a bit, but you do it anyway to show how serious you are.

meaningMnemonic: A mountain stone is probably going to be a really big stone. We're talking about a boulder here.
additionalM:
Hints
This kanji makes a lot of sense. Just follow the logic.
additionalR:
Hints
Hopefully you know what / where Iwajima is. If not, do a quick history lesson to catch yourself up!
readingMnemonic: Although it doesn't share the kanji, this boulder shares the reading of the first part of the famous "Iwajima" (where a big battle in WWII took place). Think of a big boulder. Now think of it plopped into the ocean to make an island. What island is it? It's Iwajima (the historical spelling of Iwo Jima).

meaningMnemonic: Your private leader is Buddha. You don't feel the need to tell everyone. But when you're alone you give your time to Buddha and let him lead your life.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in the privacy of your own home, your own room, and saying to yourself, "Yes Buddha, you're my leader."
Or, if that irks you, don't. Your religion is your own private right, yo.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Buddha wearing a giant pair of rubber boots. Yes, now this is fashion.
readingMnemonic: Your private Buddha is a little different than other people's idea of him. Your Buddha is wearing boots (ぶつ). They're big and rubber, and they look fabulous on him.

meaningMnemonic: Your magic yoga brush lets you build what's in your mind's eye.
additionalM:
Hints
You do the bridge pose, and in your mind you imagine your brush painting an actual bridge. When you open your eyes, there it is! A bridge has been built, leading straight to your front door.
additionalR:
Hints
It seems like Ken the samurai really appreciates your building skills.
readingMnemonic: You build a bridge. Immediately after, someone is climbing up onto it. It's Ken (けん) the samurai. He waves at you and says, "Did you build this? The craftsmanship is amazing."

meaningMnemonic: If you see an animal among the flowers in a rice paddy, chances are it’s a cat. Cats love rice paddy flowers, almost as much as they love catnip.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this cat meowing and purring as it rubs up against all the flowers in the rice paddy field. Aww, it’s so cute!
additionalR:
Hints
Try not to imagine this too hard. It is disturbing.
readingMnemonic: Wait a minute… This cat is pretty odd looking. You take a closer look, seeing it is missing its neck (ねこ). You go to pet it, but it's super sensitive about that area of its head, which is basically a face connected to a body...

meaningMnemonic: If the snow in winter was red instead of white, that’d be a strange change wouldn’t you say? White snow is normal, red would just be strange. Can you imagine what it would be like if the winter snow changed to the color of red?
additionalM:
Hints
This strange change radical is a modified version of the red radical. Use that to remember it. It’s a strange change from the normal red radical.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine if hens were purple, or even other strange colors. It would be an unexpected change. Imagine this army of rainbow colored hens strutting around and clucking up a storm.
readingMnemonic: You know what else is a strange thing to change? The color of a hen (へん). Hens are already red, so we’d change them to another color, like purple. That would be a pretty strange color for a hen, right?

meaningMnemonic: The sun is out, the sky is blue, things have begun to clear up!
additionalM:
Hints
Look into the blue sky and imagine the clouds parting as the weather clears up and you can see the sun. Gorgeous! The beauty is so great you have to squint.
additionalR:
Hints
Say the "ha ha ha" part out loud while you imagine the weather clearing up. It'll help you to remember the reading of this kanji.
readingMnemonic: Now that it's starting to clear up you can't help but laugh. "Ha (は)! Ha ha ha!" you laugh up into the sky. The sun feels great on your face, making you feel lively! And that blue sky ain't too shabby either.

meaningMnemonic: You saw down a bamboo tree to construct and build a building. Bamboo trees are great for construction, so you saw down a bunch of bamboo trees to build this new building.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself sawing down this bamboo tree. Feel the saw in your hands as you slide through the bamboo, wood chips flying everywhere.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to construct the rest of this building covered in baby chicks. They're very cute, but this is dangerous! You have to build very carefully, so you don't accidentally hurt any of them.
readingMnemonic: As you construct and build this building, you hear a strange cheeping noise. Suddenly a chick (ちく) pops out of one of the bamboo pieces you are building with. Then another, and another. You're surrounded by chicks!

meaningMnemonic: When a mama stands with a man, it gives him courage.
additionalM:
Hints
When all alone, though, the man has no courage. It helps when his mama is there to back him up. Imagine a man's mama standing there with him, saying "you can do it, boy" while giving him reassurance.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a courageous man (and his reassuring mama) standing against the youths. They tell him things about modern technology and avocado toast, but thanks to his mama the man can keep his courage.
readingMnemonic: A man needs courage to stand up to all the youths (ゆう) of the world. They are too numerous and difficult to understand. It's scary, but the man has courage thanks to his mom.

meaningMnemonic: If you stand in front of a tsunami, you’re going to cry. That tsunami is going to hit you hard, and rip you right off the ground on which you stand. And then you’ll cry like a little baby.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine getting hit with the full force of a tsunami. It slams into you and crushes every bone in your body. It hurts so much you cry.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this mean Nazi riding toward you atop of this tsunami wave. Hear him screaming, “Heil!” just before the tsunami wave crashes over you. Rotten Nazi.
readingMnemonic: You know what else can make you cry? A Nazi (な). Nazis are mean, mean people, much worse than tsunamis. Nazis are bad news. Imagine a Nazi surfboarding on top of that tsunami that just hit you and made you cry. I imagine there’s nothing worse in this world than that.

meaningMnemonic: A creeper inside of a cape, who are they? They’re the director of a movie. They try to look all mysterious, but you know it’s just so people go see their movies and think they’re cool. Really they’re just a creep deep down.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the creepiest director you know. Wearing a cloak and cackling as he directs your favorite actors.
additionalR:
Hints
The creep director gets really into whatever his current project is. Picture him wearing a sheep costume with the cape over it, petting and whispering to his sheep cast.
readingMnemonic: The director is currently directing a movie about sheep (し). He keeps petting them and talking to them like they're humans.

meaningMnemonic: This cage with treasure in it is actually a map of the district the treasure is in.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a big pirate map, and on it are a bunch of these markers for the districts where you can find the treasures you've been searching for.
additionalR:
Hints
The treasure of the cookie district is cookies, which you want. And to be fair, even if you weren't a pirate, you'd probably want those cookies.
readingMnemonic: There is one district you're interested in, and that's the cookie (く) district.

meaningMnemonic: There are many flowers in the center of England. It may seem rainy and gray at first, but if you walk right to the center you'll see all the flowers that grow there in the center of the country.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself in the center of England, speaking English to all of the beautiful flowers.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine walking around the giant English acorn. Touch its smooth surface with your hand.
readingMnemonic: You keep walking to the very central center of England and see a giant acorn (えい) planted in the middle of the ground. This acorn is the source of all the flowers and life in England.

meaningMnemonic: The height radical and the height kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
If you paid attention in radicals school, you'll be able to learn this kanji meaning easily.
additionalR:
Hints
Jourm really is a big guy. Look up at him, and try to measure him, but ten feet is too high for you to reach.
readingMnemonic: When you think of height think of our huge farmhand friend, Jourm (じょう). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's ten feet tall.

meaningMnemonic: The husband radical and the husband kanji are the same. How useful, unlike some husbands, I'd imagine.
additionalR:
Hints
Husbands love eating food. Who doesn’t though, really?
readingMnemonic: What do all husbands love? Food (ふう)! Can you hear your future husband? He’s saying,” Fooooood! FOOOOOD!” like some kind of food craving zombie.

meaningMnemonic: If you're anti-eat your meal will just sit in front of you, uneaten. Food is meant to be eaten! Stop trying to fast and take a bite.
additionalM:
Hints
Look down at the huge meal in front of you. I guess there are plenty of reasons to be anti-eat right now, but you'll have to eat your food eventually.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Han Solo slowly eating your whole meal! He's making constant eye contact with you, reaching down and shoving the entire meal into his mouth.
readingMnemonic: As you stare at the meal, Han (はん) Solo appears before you and takes a bite! This is what happens if you don't eat your food, someone else will eat it.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to say how big a cross is, you have to measure it. You can't say the size of something without measuring it first.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to use your hands to show the size of this cross, but the other person shakes their head and says, "Use your words!" Ugh, okay, you'll have to measure it then.
additionalR:
Hints
"This cross measures two cakes wide and three cakes long," you say.
readingMnemonic: You need to measure this cross but all you have is a cake (けい). Good enough! I'm sure all cakes are exactly the same size, so they're a reliable unit of measure.

meaningMnemonic: Tsunamis in the past changed the methods and laws of today.
additionalM:
Hints
Tsunamis used to come crashing into towns, just leveling them completely. Today we have new methods of building and protecting ourselves, and laws to keep them in place, so the past doesn't repeat itself.
additionalR:
Hints
Your home has strong walls and ceilings. You aren't allowed to leave the doors unlocked and open. These methods and laws are because of those past tsunamis and the damage they used to cause. Your home is safe thanks to them!
readingMnemonic: These methods and laws affected your own home (ほう) the most.

meaningMnemonic: The sun has an excuse for disappearing at night. The sun gets really tired, same as anyone else – so when night rolls around the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep. It’s a valid excuse.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you’re the sun, working all day. Of course you get tired. This is a good excuse to go to bed at night and get some rest. Feel how sore and hot and sweaty and exhausted you are after a hard day’s work of being the sun.
additionalR:
Hints
You’re a pretty cool dude. Ray-Bans are cool. You even wear them at night you’re so awesome. Yeah.
readingMnemonic: Since you’re the sun, it’s pretty bright, so before you excuse yourself for the night, you’re wearing Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. You keep these Ray-Ban sunglasses on all day to protect your eyes from being burned by yourself.

meaningMnemonic: The sun rises from the ground, and on top of it is a giant shrimp. It doesn't do anything except for every day right at noon, when it tells you the time. "Hey guyz, it's noon, mmk?"
additionalM:
Hints
Really try to imagine this giant shrimp on the sun as a normal thing that happens, without fail, every day. The shrimp also tells the time right at noon, every day (so important you stress remembering that it's noon, not some other time). Maybe you could have him sing a "noon song" in your imagination as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Right after the shrimp's announcement, imagine it struggling to put on heels, while sitting on the sun. This shrimp is almost bigger than the sun, actually, so all its struggles with its heels are easy to see.
readingMnemonic: At noon, the shrimp also puts on its high heels (ひる) to get ready for the evening, where it wants to make sure it looks good for the other shrimp he/she meets later on.

meaningMnemonic: To throw life out the window, use poison.
additionalM:
Hints
To keep life safely inside the window, put that poison down.
additionalR:
Hints
Have you done Sudoku before? Imagine yourself completing these puzzles and concentrating really hard. They’re fun, but also challenging.
readingMnemonic: If anything's worse than poison it's doing Sudoku (どく) puzzles.

meaningMnemonic: With the right key you can unlock the sun to yesterday, or a previous day. The sun is in charge of the day changes, so if you use a key to unlock it, you can control the flow of time and return to yesterday, or a previous day in the past. Behold the power of the sun.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having the power to control time like this. Picture yourself unlocking the sun to go back in time. Feel the heat of the sun and the bright light in your eyes as you unlock the door to the past.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine wearing this sack as you’re sucked through the vortex of time and space. Feel yourself spinning around as you hurtle back into yesterday.
readingMnemonic: Time traveling to a previous time, like yesterday, can be rough on the body. As such, you wear a small sack (さく) to hold your valuables while you’re ripped through the sands of time. The sack keeps your important stuff from getting lost. The sack holds your key to the sun as well.

meaningMnemonic: A knife got stuck in Wolverine's forehead, and he has a towel wrapped around it to stop the bleeding, but he really needs to return home.
additionalM:
Hints
Everything is fun and games until someone gets hurt. And in this case, very hurt. If something like this happens, it's always best to return home.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as Wolverine climbs up onto car elephant and returns home. Well, this party was a failure.
readingMnemonic: Wolverine wants to return home, but he can't drive himself because there's a knife in his forehead and lots of blood, so he asks his friend the car elephant (かえ) to take him. Car elephant is just an elephant mutant that has a car on his back.

meaningMnemonic: To construct a whole ceremony, you can’t just make it up on the spot. That is not a ceremony. A ceremony has a past. A ceremony is done a certain way because that’s the way it’s always been done. In short, to build a ceremony, you have to create a ritual first. Then, the ritual can be constructed into a bigger, more lavish ceremony.
additionalM:
Hints
Ritual and Ceremony kind of mean the same things, sort of. Don't worry too much if you mix them up a little - both will help you to remember the other. There's a reason this kanji is made up of the ceremony radical already!
additionalR:
Hints
It’s good to practice making your own mnemonics up every once in a while. It’ll help you to add on to the mnemonics already here and make better ones more personal to yourself!
readingMnemonic: So, you’re at a ritual. Think of the most ridiculous ceremony you can think of. Give it a shot – I’ll let you come up with the ridiculousness this time (it’s good practice). When you think of your mnemonic, make sure to imagine it with a Sheikh (an Arabic leader). Have the sheikh do something ridiculous to help you to think of this sheikh (しき) and then remember this on’yomi.

meaningMnemonic: Take your yakuza knife and put it in a row with the others.
additionalM:
Hints
You have a yakuza knife. There are a bunch there, all in a row, so you follow suit by putting yours in the row too.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a bunch of yakuza being enthusiastic about putting their knives in a row. They all say together "Ret's do it!"
readingMnemonic: Should we put them in a row? Let's (れつ) put them in a row!

meaningMnemonic: If you visit a bar after a tsunami, you’ll be hanging out in shallow water. After a tsunami, you want to relax with a drink at the bar. Unfortunately, tsunamis cause floods, and the bar floor is immersed in shallow water.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself at this bar, sipping on a drink while you’re wading in this shallow water. Feel the shallow water getting your socks and shoes all wet. It’s uncomfortable and cold.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself in the bar again sipping on this Asahi beer. Taste the beery beer taste of Asahi as you walk around the bar with your wet feet.
readingMnemonic: What beer are you drinking at this bar while standing in shallow water? You’re drinking Asahi (あさ), the beer of the salaryman. Asahi is super dry, so it takes your attention away from the shallow water a bit.

meaningMnemonic: The simple radical and the simple kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Simple is simple!
additionalR:
Hints
Get a tan, it's simple, stupid! (Though it's terrible for you so uh... don't always take our advice, kay?)
readingMnemonic: One of the most simple things in the world is getting a tan (たん). All you have to do is stand outside long enough. It doesn't matter what skin type you have or what the weather is like. Eventually, if you stand out there long enough, you'll get a tan.

meaningMnemonic: This is anti dirt. The dirt is becoming not dirt as it goes on, forming a... slope! Really what is the air above a slope but anti dirt?
additionalM:
Hints
This is some high level thinking, but I know you can do it. Picture a slope. Now picture an anti slope (like a negative image). It's all just dirt and anti dirt at the same time! Woah! Mind Freak!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a slope. Now picture yourself playing soccer on the slope. Now picture your anti self playing soccer on the anti slope.
readingMnemonic: You need to know these kinds of things about slopes if you want to play soccer (さか). Soccer is pretty slope-intensive. You really have to know how to read their dirt and anti dirt to really get good.

meaningMnemonic: When you see the spring sun you know it's finally the  spring season.
additionalM:
Hints
The spring sun only comes out in spring, which is why you know for sure it's spring. Imagine a different looking sun that only comes out in spring but not the other seasons.
additionalR:
Hints
Go ahead and belt out a few "HAR HAR HARs" for spring. It's warming up, everything is coming to life, and you're happy. "HAR HAR HAR!"
readingMnemonic: When the spring season comes around, it makes you want to laugh: "HAR (はる) HAR HAR!" you yell.

meaningMnemonic: The temple radical and the temple kanji are exactly the same! Brilliant.
additionalR:
Hints
That's too bad - feel sorry for the person and learn a little more about the terror attack, if it will help you to remember the reading of this kanji better.
readingMnemonic: Someone died. You ask how this person died, the person who's getting buried by the temple. The priest/monk says it was in a tragic terror (てら) attack.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits a valley, filling it up with water. Lucky for you, you're a giant, so you just lay down in the valley and use it to bathe.
additionalM:
Hints
Sure, there's a lot of water in the valley, but you're big too. It's the perfect place for you to bathe... and good thing too, you're getting smelly.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine cooking egg yolks in the same water you bathe in.
readingMnemonic: You know what would make the bathing experience even better? If you had some egg yolks (よく) to eat. Just crack those yolks into the water you bathe in, and it'll cook to perfection. Yum!

meaningMnemonic: Having a keen eye for woodworking, you can tell that the bamboo from that tree over there will make an excellent box. Boxes made from bamboo trees are very sturdy and fashionable. You have an eye for fashion as well, you see.
additionalM:
Hints
At some point in school, you most likely had some sort of woodshop class to take. Remember back to those times and imagine yourself crafting a bamboo box out of a bamboo tree you felled yourself. Don’t forget to wear eye protection though! Wouldn’t want anything to happen to those valuable eyes of yours.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the hawk landing in the box and grumpily trying to stuff it full of straw and twigs. At least your beautiful box will be put to good use.
readingMnemonic: While working on your wooden box you hear a strange cry from above. You look up and see an angry hawk (はこ) flying overhead. Oh no! That bamboo you cut down must have been where the hawk lived. Imagine finishing up the box, climbing up some bamboo and tying the box securely up there as a replacement home for the hawk.

meaningMnemonic: A psychic leader can pick a thread up off the ground and make a connection with the person that it came from. This leader is very powerful, so even a thread is enough for them to make a psychic connection with the person who was wearing the thread.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you are this leader and you just picked up this piece of thread from the ground. You get a jarring psychic connection with the owner of the thread. Your head spins, your heart races, and your hands tremble. Picture this happening to you as you pick up the thread from the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
Because the connection is so strong, you feel like you too are eating the cake. You taste the fluffy and creamy vanilla strawberry flavors washing over your tongue. Imagine yourself eating this delectable cake. It’s fantastically delicious.
readingMnemonic: As you develop this psychic connection with the owner of the thread, you can tell that he is currently eating a cake (けい). Since the connection is so strong, you feel like you are eating the cake as well. It’s vanilla strawberry.

meaningMnemonic: After a tsunami, use this machine to cure the people and the country from the damage. Healing machines are all over Japan just in case a tsunami does way more damage than they can handle.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if you had your own machine to cure yourself if a tsunami came to where you live. It would be pretty convenient!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting Jesus to cure half the people and feeding the other half lots of cheese and their wounds miraculously healing on their own! You're a hero!
readingMnemonic: Alternative ways to cure yourself after a tsunami are either praying to Jesus (じ) or eating your weight in cheese (ち). I'm not sure if I have enough cheese for all the people that got hit though... Hmm, do you have cheese?

meaningMnemonic: There is a prison on a cliff surrounded by snakes. Now that's a dangerous place. If you try to escape the prison you either fall to your death off the cliff or get bitten/squeezed to death by the snakes. Can you think of anything more dangerous than this? I can't.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a dangerous prison surrounded by cliffs and snakes. You wouldn't want to be here either, would you?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine staring at the key dangling right outside of the dangerous prison you're trapped in. Would you take the chance and go for it?
readingMnemonic: Lucky for you, even though you're stuck in this dangerous place, there is hope. There is a key (き). All dangerous prisons have a key. You just have to find and steal it so you can avoid the cliffs and snakes!

meaningMnemonic: When the sun gets in your eye, I dare you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you.
additionalM:
Hints
Looking at the sun straight on hurts. It’s bad for your eyes and burns your brain. Imagine how painful it is to stare at the sun.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself bowling without the power of sight. It would be awfully difficult to do well. You’d just have to concentrate really hard on the sound of the pins and determine where you need to throw the ball.
readingMnemonic: After you’ve blinded yourself from the dare of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go bowling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge.

meaningMnemonic: A group of private sword guys are in your rice paddy. You must detain them at once! Private sword guys are people who work for private companies and use their swords on people. They're basically paid assassins. And you're going to detain them!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine running into the rice paddy and detaining the private sword holders one by one. They won't get away this time!
additionalR:
Hints
If Ryu hadn't shown up with this loophole you never would have detained all these private sword guys by yourself!
readingMnemonic: You're running out of steam and you're afraid you might not be able to detain all of these guys when Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter appears. He hates swords, and will only use fists because it's the honorable way to fight, so he starts helping you detain them!

meaningMnemonic: If you listened in to the private lives of twenty people, all of them would have different dialects and ways of speech. Whether they actually use these dialects with you is another story. But when they're alone, or with other people who are from the same place, their speech will be different.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you even imagine twenty different dialects in your head? Well I can tell you that there are definitely at least twenty of them in Japan alone.
additionalR:
Hints
It also helps that bento are delicious, and anyone with any dialect will love them.
readingMnemonic: The best way to learn someone's dialect is to buy them a bento (べん) from where they're from. Not only do these bento have writing in their dialect on them, but their speech will immediately shift to match. Then you'll be able to hear how they sound in their head and in private!

meaningMnemonic: What I say is correct 100%! You may use it as evidence in this murder case.
additionalM:
Hints
You convince the officials questioning you that your evidence can be trusted and it's proof that you definitely didn't have anything to do with any law breaking or murdering.
additionalR:
Hints
You better hope the Shougun believes your evidence is accurate, because he's known to kill people willy-nilly when he thinks they're lying.
readingMnemonic: The officials force you to present this evidence in front of the Shougun (しょう), himself. Your knees quake, you feel like you're gonna be sick, but you try to stand up tall and tell him everything. After all, you know your proof is correct, so you shouldn't be so scared.

meaningMnemonic: If a narwhal sticks a child with its horn then you have to admit that it exists. We know some of you have been doubting narwhals and whether they're real. Well now your kid is a kabob, so do you believe they exist now? I suppose you do.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine needing this kind of horrible proof to believe something exists. Maybe you should have more faith in what we teach.
additionalR:
Hints
I suppose you'll never forget that narwhals exist now that your son has one permanently stuck in him.
readingMnemonic: Oh, and the child we had to narwhal stab to prove they exist - that's your son (そん). Maybe you should have listened and kept your son out of the Narwhal Danger Zone (ぞん) after we warned you about it.

meaningMnemonic: The face radical and the face kanji are the same! But this isn't just a face like the one you're looking at your computer/phone with. It's the surface kind of face too!
additionalM:
Hints
The next time you look at your face, also notice how much surface area it has.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the face of all men put together. Measure how much surface area they all take up.
readingMnemonic: This face you're looking at, that has a lot of surface area, belongs to men (めん). Not a single man, but all men put together. It's hundreds of thousands of men's faces in a row.

meaningMnemonic: You see a scooter with a zombie on it, going really far away. Someone tied that zombie to the scooter and now it's far off in the distance, groaning and growling.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the zombie, going far off into the distance. It's getting smaller and harder to see.
additionalR:
Hints
I mean, to be fair, the zombie wasn't really alive to begin with. But going far enough to end it all? That's some serious distance!
readingMnemonic: The zombie goes so far, that its life ends (えん). Zombies need to eat to live (it's really all they need), but they go so far on their scooter trip, that they just give up and end it all.

meaningMnemonic: You examine the mouth of a zombie and find a small garden in there. There are even benches... it looks like a park.
additionalM:
Hints
Zombies are dead, so I guess their mouths have all the things garden plants crave. Their mouths are like compost piles, if you think about it.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh. The zombie probably bit down on your head and now it's the end for you. At least you were looking at a nice garden at the end of it all...
readingMnemonic: You look closer at the garden and suddenly everything ends (えん).

meaningMnemonic: The radical for gate and the kanji for gates are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals or you won't be allowed to pass.
additionalR:
Hints
They start pounding on the gate, and it begins to budge. Focus in on their moaning noises, because that's the reading of this kanji, but also feel the fear as well. When you start moaning too, it seems to calm them. Go ahead and pretend you're in front of this gate, and moan out loud for me a bit. Uwhhhhhh. Muhehwhhhhhhh.
readingMnemonic: You're standing in front of some gates. You can't get through them, but on the other side you hear all kinds of loud moans (もん). Are those zombie noises? Is this gate to keep the zombies out, or in?

meaningMnemonic: A canopy attaching your entire country is the government. They loom over you all and try to keep you all organized and together under their control.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a map of the world with actual canopies attached to each government, representing the ruling governments of each place.
additionalR:
Hints
Think of all the people who've been labeled as fools by the government because they try to detach themselves from under their reach. It's a pretty long list...
readingMnemonic: Try to get out from under this government canopy and you'll be labeled a fool (ふ). Unless... you can fool them!

meaningMnemonic: Put a lid on something spicy and you'll cook up pure happiness.
additionalM:
Hints
Spicy foods literally do trigger happy chemicals in your brain. It wouldn't be too far off to say that putting a lid on a pot filled with something spicy could produce happiness.
additionalR:
Hints
こういち looks sad. But when you serve him happiness, he starts to perk up a bit. A couple more bites of happiness, and there's a smile on his face. Although when you found こういち he was depressed, down on his luck, and hiding from the government, cooking him some spicy foods seems to have brought him some happiness.
readingMnemonic: Out of spicy foods you made pure happiness. You give it to your sad friend こういち, who waits at the table.

meaningMnemonic: If you're anti-building, you're probably afraid of heights and slopes. The only downside to a building is that they're high and if you fall off of them you could die. So if someone says they're anti-building, they're really just anti-heights.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing on the edge of a very high building. If you feel sick or upset, you may be one of these anti-height people!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine standing at the top of a tall building with Han Solo. He's very afraid of heights. They make him nervous. Like something bad will happen if he were to ever stand above a big pit, high up.
readingMnemonic: Another person you know who's afraid of heights is Han (はん) Solo. Now wait, you may be thinking, he flies a space ship! You're right, because he doesn't like to walk all the way up high buildings, it freaks him out. He flies up instead so he doesn't have to think about falling.

meaningMnemonic: A wolverine's heart is in prison, so you need to hurry to set it free. If you don't hurry, its heart won't survive. And the wolverine's death will be on you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a dying wolverine, its heart trapped in a prison. Hurry, save it! You aren't going fast enough! Hurry, hurry!
additionalR:
Hints
Cucumbers help you hurry to where you need to go. Something about the smell, crunch, and taste helps you hurry it up.
readingMnemonic: You're trying to hurry as fast as you can to save the wolverine. But you're losing strength, so you grab a cucumber (きゅう) from your bag and munch on it to get some of your hurrying power back.

meaningMnemonic: Bamboo heaven is a place for laughing. Bamboo is a very jolly plant, and they love to laugh. Even after death in bamboo heaven, the bamboo continue to laugh joyfully. Bamboo heaven is truly a place of laughter.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself as a bamboo plant that laughs in heaven. What are you laughing about? Chuckle to yourself as you remember this kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
Now picture these bamboo again up in bamboo heaven, and remember this strange accent to remember that the bamboo plants up in bamboo heaven are laughing with nervous laughter at this bamboo war that’s a goin’ on up there.
readingMnemonic: There’s actually a war a goin’ on up in that there bamboo heaven, y’know? Ye might not have heard of it with all that there laughin’ a goin’ on, but there definitely be a war a (わら) goin’ on up in bamboo heaven, y’hear? The bamboo are scared so that’s why they be laughin’ so much. They nervous.

meaningMnemonic: The lip ring wearing leader of the Flowers Gang does not carry his own luggage anywhere. He is so powerful, respected, and feared that people always carry his luggage for him wherever he goes. You might not think a leader of a gang called the Flowers would be intimidating, but he is.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this lip ring wearing gang leader. He’s clad in studded leather and has a big flower embroidered onto the back of his jacket. It’s a big thorny rose. Imagine him in your head, hear the sound of his leather outfit as he strides along unencumbered by luggage.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how much it hurts to get pricked by a needle, especially on your finger. Picture this happening to you now. Not comfortable, is it?
readingMnemonic: Remember that giant thorny rose on the lip ring wearing leader’s back? The thorns coming out of it are real, and they’re as sharp as needles (に). You wouldn’t want to prick your finger on them. They’re super pointy and he uses them to defend his luggage.

meaningMnemonic: It's correct in winter to focus on politics and the government. Elections are happening, in the new year politicians are being sworn in. Winter is government time!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all this politics and government talk as you shiver outside in the winter cold. You’re freezing and you’re bored, but you know this is the right (correct) thing to do.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture two different politicians, both wielding sabers, fighting to make the government the way they want it to be! Who are you rooting for?
readingMnemonic: Everyone involved in politics and government wields a special saber (せい). If two political parties are arguing, they'll whip out their sabers and start slashing away!

meaningMnemonic: The products radical and the product kanji are exactly the same! Productive!
additionalR:
Hints
Then another Hindu person walks in your store and buys some. Then another... What are all these Hindu people doing buying your products, you wonder? When you ask them, they tell you "it's a cultural thing."
readingMnemonic: As you try to sell these products, you finally get a buyer. It's a Hindu (ひん) person. She walks in and buys your products on the spot!

meaningMnemonic: Your roof needs measurements done every year to make sure it will protect you properly.
additionalM:
Hints
If you think about it, your roof protects you from a lot of things! Rain, snow, bird poop. But if your roof's measurements are off it won't be able to protect you properly.
additionalR:
Hints
Odds are, the roof collapsed or a tree fell on you and you died from lack of protection. So now your family and friends are going to sue on your behalf.
readingMnemonic: If the measurements are off, and your roof doesn't protect you, then you get to sue (す)! If you're still alive, that is.

meaningMnemonic: When your tongue becomes too spicy for you to bear, it’s time to quit the jalapeño eating contest. You’ve been eating them for three hours now and the spiciness from the peppers is really burning your tongue. Throw in the towel, it’s time to quit the contest.
additionalM:
Hints
You may have to quit eating but you never have to quit saying words. Especially if you're, well, trying to learn a whole new language full of them.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Jesus scarfing down jalapeño peppers. He never quits. And then he says some words about how the jalapeños gave up their lives for this contest, so we better appreciate them. Thanks Jesus!
readingMnemonic: Oh, you're probably wondering who won that spicy food contest after you quit and became obsessed with words instead. It was Jesus (じ). Who did you expect? He was great with words AND never quitting when things got spicy.

meaningMnemonic: If the pope spends all day staring at fins on the ground, he’s going to lose touch with reality. He should be focusing on his popish duties, but instead he’s looking at the fish fins he dropped, and now can’t eat because they’re dirty. Silly pope. You can’t let this one thing get you down. You have other things to do.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture trying to get the pope to stop staring at the fins laying on the dirty ground. His eyes are all big. Yup, he’s completely lost touch with reality, you think.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the pope angrily kicking your shin super hard. You fall over and pull it close. Feel how badly it aches. Who knew you’d need shin guards to deal with a pope that’s lost touch with reality just from dropping his dinner.
readingMnemonic: You’re doing your best to bring the pope back to reality when he snaps and kicks you in the shin (しん). Oww! What the heck, pope! But he’s already back staring at the fins and your shin is throbbing where he kicked.

meaningMnemonic: This gate of horns will take you to heaven. These horns are related and connected to heaven in some way.
additionalM:
Hints
Perhaps they are related to heaven because the devil has horns? Perhaps they are connected to heaven because these are the horns of heaven's enemies? The real reason they're connected will be revealed in the reading mnemonic.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Genghis Khan taking horns off his enemies, and making a gate to heaven. The horn gate is connected to both heaven and Genghis Khan in that way.
readingMnemonic: They are related and connected to heaven because these are the horns that Genghis Khan (かん) made from his enemies. God said he could come into heaven if he made a gate of horns, so that's what he did.

meaningMnemonic: Going into a building made by a squid is risky. First of all, squids only have tentacles, no bones, and they make all of their buildings out of risky materials like kelp and sharp coral.
additionalM:
Hints
One squid got stuck in his own building, but no one could save him because going in would be too risky. Poor little squid.
additionalR:
Hints
The squid cries, "I can build one that isn't so risky next time!" Ken shakes his head, "I'm not letting you do anymore risky things, you're coming with me from now on." Ken scoops up the squid into a bucket, hoists him over his shoulder, and walks off into the sunset.
Who knows what adventures await our new duo. All we know is that they'll definitely be getting into some risky business.
readingMnemonic: "It's too risky, leave me!" the squid cries. "I'll save you, underwater citizen! Nothing is too risky for Ken (けん) the samurai!" The building is collapsing on the squid, the risk is so great, but Ken the samurai dives in and saves him!

meaningMnemonic: If you play music with your fins, one rule is that you must be a fish. You can’t play music using fish fins that don’t belong to you. That’s the rule. And it’s also rude.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a fish playing music using his fins. What kind of a song is it? Imagine it in your head as you see a sign with the fish fin rule on it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a group of ten (as per the rule) fish playing music with their fins. Now the song can be louder and more intricate. Imagine it playing in your head.
readingMnemonic: There’s also a rule in place to limit the amount of fish fin musicians. No more than ten (てん) are allowed to gather and play their music together. That’s the rule. No more than ten.

meaningMnemonic: Sticking a cross into a rice paddy to get its measurements is your specialty. Most people get really confused when they have to measure their rice paddies, but that's where you come in. You plant a cross right in the middle, look down it from one end to the other, and voila! You know the measurements immediately. That's why it's your specialty!
additionalM:
Hints
Visualize yourself doing this. The numbers just come to you. It's just what you're good at. Your specialty is something no one else in the world is as good at as you!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself at a centaur funeral. Tons of centaurs standing around and stamping their hooves as you make your measurement and stick a cross into the ground.
readingMnemonic: Hearing of your amazing specialty and cross measurement abilities, a centaur (せん) from a far off land recruits you for a job. The centaur’s father has just passed away and the centaur wants you to measure the rice paddies that have been left to him.

meaningMnemonic: A forehead table is completely superfluous.
additionalM:
Hints
Seriously, you don't need a forehead table. It's totally unnecessary to have a table made of foreheads and is a superfluous purchase. First of all, getting all those foreheads is a waste of people. Second, forehead tables aren't very strong. Superfluous, superfluous, superfluous.
additionalR:
Hints
Now that you think about it, it's really odd. You went to his house and saw this forehead table. Then Jourm said, "Ah this? It's a superfluous purchase. Don't mind it." You've never heard him say any word above a third grade level, let alone a fancy word such as superfluous. Also, the table made of foreheads is a bit... strange. You'll have to keep your eye on Jourm.
readingMnemonic: The only person you know with a superfluous forehead table is Jourm (じょう), the ten foot tall, simple farmhand.

meaningMnemonic: There's an ear just sitting on a stool. Nobody's watching, so, you take it.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the rush of stealing something (even though it's a weird something, admittedly). Start walking away quickly. You don't want to get caught!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the ear you took in your hands as you fly down the chute, the wind whipping past your own ears as you slide to freedom!
readingMnemonic: To make sure you get away after taking something that doesn't belong to you, you jump into a laundry chute (しゅ)! You saw other criminals take things and jump down chutes, so you decide to do it too.

meaningMnemonic: As the sun rises over the hills, the ferocious wolverine stalks a turkey on a weekday morning. The wolverine hunts turkeys for a living, but on the weekends, he likes to play racquetball at the local gym. That’s why the turkey is getting hunted on a weekday.
additionalM:
Hints
You’ve probably seen those nature shows like on National Geographic. Think back to one of those shows where the hunter stalks its prey and leaps out in slow motion to do the murder. Now imagine this scene with the wolverine leaping out at the turkey. The wolverine howls a bloodcurdling shriek as the turkey lurches in agony, feathers flying everywhere as the wolverine sinks its teeth into flesh.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine eating this turkey yogurt. It tastes pretty much exactly how you would expect. Chunks of turkey meat mixed with thick and creamy yogurt. It tastes like mushy Thanksgiving. Imagine eating this every day of the week.
readingMnemonic: This wolverine has a strange palate, however. It likes to turn its turkey into turkey yogurt (よう). After the hunt every weekday, the wolverine spends the evening turning the turkey meat into a strange, thick and chunky, turkey yogurt.

meaningMnemonic: Why would you try to take a brush to the sun? It's almost too obvious, because you want to write something down.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine yourself sitting on the sun, writing back to your friends and family with a brush. For someone who can visit the sun, it's really weird that you are writing with a brush like this, but you're doing it just the same.
additionalR:
Hints
Think of your favorite live shows and imagine them on the sun. Also imagine yourself writing back to your friends and family about said shows.
readingMnemonic: What did you write about? You were writing about this amazing circus show (しょ)you just watched on the sun. You didn't expect there to be any shows here, but turns out you were wrong!

meaningMnemonic: The sun is correct, absolutely. The mighty sun is never wrong. It is absolutely correct, always.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the sun in the sky. Its rays blind you as it corrects all of the errors you’ve made.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the sun being so absolutely consumed with rage that it catches a zeppelin on fire and crashes it. Feel the heat from the grounded zeppelin as it smolders.
readingMnemonic: Then, a zeppelin (ぜ) flies in front of the sun, blocking it out. Absolutely, the sun cannot ignore this transgression. Therefore, the sun corrects the zeppelin’s evil ways by frying it with sunshine and bringing it to the ground.

meaningMnemonic: You use a thread for good luck by binding two fingers together. You tie them nice and tight.
additionalM:
Hints
Tying two fingers together with a good luck thread is very common where you're from.
additionalR:
Hints
This ketsup is exactly what you were looking for, but now it won't stop. You need to get out of this bind by untying the thread on your finger. But it won't budge. It's covered in ketsup. Help! You're going to drown!
readingMnemonic: After you bind your fingers, the good luck starts pouring in. Literally. Suddenly ketsup (けつ) starts pouring down from the heavens.
