Imagine seeing a narwhal sticking a stick, and maybe even its horn too, into the dirt on land. It needs to know if life exists outside of the ocean for sure.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the plinky plink of the xylophone and think about what exists in this world. It's a sad song, you realize.
readingMnemonic: The narwhal can't find anything but it can't stop thinking about what could exist outside of its world. It pulls out a xylophone (ざい) and starts tapping the keys with its horn. It plays a sad song about the meaning of life and whether existence is worth it.

meaningMnemonic: The fly radical and the fly kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!
additionalR:
Hints
You’re flying through the air super fast. Feel the air rushing past you as heat builds up all over your body from rocketing through the air so fast.
readingMnemonic: When you fly, you generate a lot of heat (ひ) because you’re moving so fast through the atmosphere. Normally this heat would be a nuisance, but you’re a superhero so it doesn’t bother you. This is actually the reason you’re able to fly – you’re a superhero and super resistant to heat.

meaningMnemonic: You stand on the Cliff of Life and give birth to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it!
additionalM:
Hints
The baby is falling off the cliff! Imagine the sheer terror you feel as the baby plummets to the ground below.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh Santa-san. You're always here for me when I need you most. Even when I'm giving birth to your child.
readingMnemonic: You give birth, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's Santa-san (さん)! He caught your baby!

meaningMnemonic: Put a net around a criminal to show their guilt. Criminals look like anyone else on the street, so you decide to tie them in nets to make sure people know who they're dealing with.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine throwing a net around someone you think, no, you know is guilty of doing something bad to you. It feels pretty nice.
additionalR:
Hints
Woah! The xylophone is huge, how did they... well whatever, you definitely have proof that they're guilty now and the cops should be here any minute to take your criminal catch.
readingMnemonic: The guilt shows on the criminal's face. They smile, shrug, and pull a stolen xylophone (ざい) out of their back pocket.

meaningMnemonic: The hole radical and the hole kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself laughing at Ana while you point at her, continuing to jeer as Ana struggles to escape the hole. You’d help Ana out of the hole, but you’re too busy laughing at her.
readingMnemonic: Ana (あな) fell into a hole. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy!

meaningMnemonic: A spirit loses its skin as a part of the damages it incurs after death.
additionalM:
Hints
Some spirits get mad when they lose their skin, and this makes them incur their wrath on the living humans that still have skin.
additionalR:
Hints
It feels like your skin is cooking! You're turning red. The spirit is trying to incur the same type of skin damage it had done to it by super-heating your skin! Oww owww!
readingMnemonic: When you incur the wrath of an angry spirit, you'll feel your skin heat (ひ) up.

meaningMnemonic: The leader with the old mouth is the one who has said many things. That makes them different from everyone, an individual.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine that leader's old mouth saying things that make the old man stand apart from the others. They are individual from everyone else.
additionalR:
Hints
"You must be your own individual. Don't be a sheeple," he says to the 子s.
readingMnemonic: As an individual, one must teach all the 子s (こ) their way. Their individual way.

meaningMnemonic: A drunkard is the kind of person who would poop two times under a tree before using a machine toilet. There’s a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this drunkard, squatting down under the tree to poop. You can smell the poop and a faint stench of alcohol in the air. How could he not have realized that there was a portable machine toilet right there?
additionalR:
Hints
Listen to the drunkard grumbling about the lack of a key as he poops under the tree. He doesn’t sound happy, and every time he stresses to push out the poop, his voice fluctuates. Imagine hearing this in your mind and being a wee bit disgusted.
readingMnemonic: Oh, I see – the door to the outhouse with the machine toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn’t have the key (き). If he had a machine like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he’s reduced to pooping under the tree instead.

meaningMnemonic: A woman with direction will have things obstruct her path. It's a sad fact that it's still a man's world out there!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this woman with direction, knocking down obstruction after obstruction on her path to success.
additionalR:
Hints
Now imagine that she actually is a bowling ball. Watch her roll down the bowling lane and smash all those stupid pins!
readingMnemonic: This woman is truly magnificent. Some compare her to a bowling (ぼう) ball, because of how she knocks down the obstructions in her path like bowling pins.

meaningMnemonic: Someone stabbed the leader mole with a knife to overthrow it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a mole sneaking up behind the leader mole and stabbing him with a knife. This type of overthrowing of leadership feels familiar to you. Maybe this has happened before in the past?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this like an exaggerated reenactment on the History channel. Leader after leader of とうきょう gets overthrown and replaced with the next guy. It never stops. (Until the end of the Edo period, I guess.)
readingMnemonic: Where do leaders get overthrown the most? In とうきょう. Just think back in Japanese history, back when everyone was at war with one another. People were taking over and getting overthrown and then that guy gets overthrown and then THAT guy gets overthrown. Basically, it used to be hard to stay a leader in とうきょう.

meaningMnemonic: Tying a thread to a tombstone each year will help you manage the passage of time. That way you’ll know how many years it has been, since you’ll have one thread for each year to count.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself coming back to the same tombstone each passing year and tying a new thread to it. You're trying to manage these feelings by keeping track of how much time passes.
additionalR:
Hints
Maybe this is your future tombstone, and eating cake each year is a preemptive celebration of your death day! Ooh, what a spooky theory.
readingMnemonic: Dealing with the passage of time can be tough, so after you tie the thread to the tombstone, each year you eat a piece of cake (けい). You already eat cake to mark the passage of time on your birthday, so why not here as well?

meaningMnemonic: Sitting on the lid of a toilet, an explosion of poop erupts out, getting feces on your cross necklace and a large percent of your clothing. You were just trying to chill out, sitting on the lid of the toilet, and an explosion of poop just flew out the toilet bowl. Now you have poop all over you, like ninety-nine percent of your body is covered in poop. Even your cross necklace.
additionalM:
Hints
This feels disgusting. Imagine yourself being covered in poop. Feel the warm smelly sludge covering your body as the abysmal aroma wafts up into your nostrils. You’re nearly one hundred percent covered in poop.
additionalR:
Hints
Now that the percent of your body covered in poop has reached zero, you can comfortably eat. Imagine yourself eating these Ritz crackers as you slowly start to feel better about life. Taste their buttery crispness as they crumble in your mouth.
readingMnemonic: You’re emotionally scarred, so you need to eat your comfort food in order to calm yourself down. Your comfort food is Ritz (りつ) crackers, so you clean one hundred percent of the poop off you so your body is now zero percent covered by poop, and you start to devour a box of Ritz crackers.

meaningMnemonic: The dirt under a cliff is going to be under a lot of pressure.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being down there with all that dirt. Imagine feeling the pressure closing in around you. It's so hard to breathe... h... help!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine you're the dirt being pressed from every direction, the pressure so strong, and it squeezes an ACHOO right out of you.
readingMnemonic: The dirt being crushed under this pressure can't help but react by sneezing out, "Achoo (あつ)!" This sneeze-inducing pressure probably has something to do with where earthquakes come from.

meaningMnemonic: If there is a building in the direction you want to go it will prevent you from going any further. Like, come on kid, you think you can just walk right through a building? Don't make me laugh!
additionalM:
Hints
There's a building right there. Try to go that direction. Oh, did the building prevent you? Told you so.
additionalR:
Hints
Your bowling antics are now preventing a bunch of people from going the directions they want to go. Nice job.
readingMnemonic: The building is preventing you from going the right direction, so you pull a bowling (ぼう) ball out of your bag, aim, and bowl the building over. The building, and all the ones around it, go tumbling down. But now the rubble is preventing you from going further.

meaningMnemonic: Wash yourself with a big bar of soap if you're stinking everything up.
additionalM:
Hints
Seriously. If you or someone else is stinking to high heaven, embrace a big bar of self care.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to use a big bar of soap on yourself to get the stinky 草 off. But it's not working... the 草 stink is SO STRONG!
readingMnemonic: You're stinking up the room because you spent your day rolling in 草 (くさ). And based on this particular stench, I'd say an animal left something in that 草 too...

meaningMnemonic: Regardless of whether or not you wear a hat while you jackhammer, you’re going to have a surplus of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.
additionalM:
Hints
The hat you’re wearing is ridiculous, giving you a surplus of bad style. Imagine a bunch of people scowling at you, not only because of your crazy hat, but because of the annoying sound of the jackhammer. Hear the obnoxious noise around you as the jackhammer rattles your bones.
additionalR:
Hints
Your hat is doing little to defend you from the onslaught of yo-yos being tossed at you. Feel the yo-yos hitting your body and listen to them roll away after striking you.
readingMnemonic: One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart yo-yo (よ) stand. Having a surplus of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage.

meaningMnemonic: You see a flag stuck in the ground with a little bit of fur coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a tail. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail.
additionalM:
Hints
What kind of animal could it be? You start to feel the soft fur with your hand and then the stench of death hits your nostrils. Ew.
additionalR:
Hints
See the bees swarming out from around the tail and toward your face. Run! Run before there’s nothing left of you but your own tail!
readingMnemonic: You try to pull the flag out of the ground and hear a rumbling buzzing sound. At the end of the flagpole you see a huge beehive (び)! These bees made their home under the tail! Maybe that’s why the flag was sticking in it… to warn people. Oops.

meaningMnemonic: You say, throwing your hat on the ground in front of the bookshelf, "I have a theory!" All this reading and thinking has finally given you a wonderful idea, a theory you think might solve all of your problems!
additionalM:
Hints
This theory you've thought of is great, it's going to change everything!
additionalR:
Hints
"Ron? Ron, what's your theory? What's your theory, Ron?" Hermione asks over and over. But you freeze. You don't remember who you are. "Hermione, I have a theory that I was just a person learning Japanese, and not a magical boy at all." "Shut up Ron, that's a stupid theory," she replies.
readingMnemonic: "What is your theory, Ron (ろん)?" asks Hermione. You're Ron Weasley, and you just came up with a theory that you think will help you stop Voldemort.

meaningMnemonic: Hanging off the edge of a cliff is a sun worshipping child with a thick unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries at the sun for cursing him to this cruel fate. Even the thickness of his unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to pull himself back up.
additionalM:
Hints
I mean, this unibrow is really, really thick. So thick it doesn’t even look real. But it is. It’s really real and really thick.
additionalR:
Hints
I guess if you want to go see that thick, beautiful unibrow you'll have to go see it at Sue's now. What's that? Oh, don't worry about the child. It uh. It's probably at Sue's too! Maybe... (or dead).
readingMnemonic: The child's thick unibrow can't wait any longer and gives up. It hops off the child's face and says, "Hey dude, I'll be at Sue's (あつ). She'll appreciate my thick, luxuriousness more than a weakling like you.

meaningMnemonic: On the ground, holding a brush, is the woman you call your wife.
additionalM:
Hints
You're standing above your wife, trying to figure out what she's making with her brush on the ground. If you have a real wife in real life, picture her doing this right now.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so your wife may be in love with the cyborg monstrosity you created a while ago. This could become a problem.
readingMnemonic: Your wife is drawing your cyborg (さい) on the ground. Oh no... now your wife is making kissy faces at the cyborg drawing.

meaningMnemonic: The life of a shellfish is filled with blame. They take the blame for everything from food poisoning and allergies, to cutting people's feet on beaches.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine an innocent little shellfish, living its quiet little life, while everyone's heaping blame on it. It hides in its little shell and tries to deflect all that blame. What a life!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to look sexy as you slurp up those saucy little shellfish.
readingMnemonic: When those poor shellfish aren't having blame piled on them, they're being eaten, because shellfish are thought to make for a very sexy (せき) meal.

meaningMnemonic: A winter tree is only a winter tree due to a clause in its tree contract.
additionalM:
Hints
The clause states that it cannot be a tree in the summer, because that is the summer tree's territory. Same goes for autumn and spring trees. Go ahead and look at the winter tree's contract, if you want (they're nailed to every tree). There's the clause that says it can only be a tree in the winter.
additionalR:
Hints
Jourm noticed that the trees were getting too crowded, so he wrote up these clauses and added them to the trees' contracts. Now, the forests are less crowded, thanks to the little clause. Makes sense that a farmhand like Jourm would do this too. The fewer trees, the more farmland. It's good for folks like Jourm.
readingMnemonic: This clause was written into all trees' contracts by Jourm (じょう), the large farmhand.

meaningMnemonic: You see a tsunami that's simultaneous (with another tsunami, I assume) and you know the world is about to come to an end.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a tsunami simultaneously happening as the world comes to an end. Oh no, isn't there any way to stop this!?
additionalR:
Hints
So the world won't come to an end this one time, thanks to the cyborg you made. Though it doesn't look very good. The cyborg is beaten up and full of water. This might be the end for it...
readingMnemonic: Just as the world is about to come to an end, your cyborg (さい) appears and blocks it with its cyborg body!

meaningMnemonic: Women who get together to talk about grains are a committee. They're the Committee of Women for Grains (tm tm tm). What does this committee discuss, you wonder.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what this committee of women could be coming together to discuss. Aren't grains just grains? Why do they need a whole committee?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a committee of women standing together in a field of grain, watching eagles swooping around. They take notes and mutter to one another about their options.
readingMnemonic: Well, grains need a committee because the eagles (い) have been eating them all. The women know this, so they're meeting and trying to come up with a way to stop these pesky eagles from eating all the grains and leaving none for the humans.

meaningMnemonic: You only have a few eyes so you need to conserve what's left.
additionalM:
Hints
You only have like, three eyes left. If you conserve them .
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun stares down at you, eyes blazing, and you hand over all but one of your eyes. Now you really have to conserve, or you'll be blind. Thanks Shougun. I bet he has plenty of eyes, he didn't need yours.
readingMnemonic: You're trying to conserve your eyes, when the Shougun (しょう) marches by. He stops, sees you, and demands you give him your remaining eyes! But sir, I'm conserving what little I have left!

meaningMnemonic: Cows, using nothing more than towels and knifes, have taken control of the world. Their system of control is brutal—payback for how us humans have treated them I guess.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this new cow-controlled world—there are cows on every street corner, armed with towels and knives, intimidating all us humans into following their system.
additionalR:
Hints
The cows' towels and knives won't stand a chance against your saber!
readingMnemonic: It's time to take control back from the cows! Pull out your saber (せい) and fight back!

meaningMnemonic: If you use your fingers to point when you compare things you're really just throwing around criticism. You should never need to point fingers when you're just comparing things. If you're pointing and picking and being mean, that's criticism.
additionalM:
Hints
Some criticism is okay, as long as it's constructive and it helps the person get better. But when you start pointing fingers, it's time to step back and try to not be such a jerk.
additionalR:
Hints
Before you throw criticism around, imagine that embarrassed heat. You don't want to feel that way, so why would you do it to someone else?
readingMnemonic: If you're having trouble not giving out criticism, just think about how you would react if someone criticized you. You'd feel an embarrassed heat (ひ) rise throughout your body. That heat will cover your whole face.

meaningMnemonic: A lion harvesting rice uses an axe to cut off the tops of the stalks. The lion is roaming the rice fields using his axe to harvest the rice. He does so by cutting off the part of the rice stalks he needs.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this lion on his hind legs, walking through a rice field. He’s holding an axe in one hand and acting like a human. See him cut off the plants and hear the whoosh of the axe as he cuts.
additionalR:
Hints
When dawn comes in Africa (it's a lion, so that's where he is) it gets too hot to be in the sun, so the lion gets cut off from his job of cutting things off.
readingMnemonic: The lion will cut off rice stalks until dawn (だん). But at the first light of dawn, it will run and hide in the shade of the trees, cut off from the rice.

meaningMnemonic: Both a leader and a king have a duty to protect their people. A good leader always protects his followers, and a good king always protects his subjects. This is their duty.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself being protected by your king and leader. They don’t really like you, but it is their duty to protect you. See them fighting off evil doers and taking bullets for your sake.
additionalR:
Hints
You’re a nincompoop. Even though you’re so nincompoopy, your king and leader still have a duty to protect you. Feel happy and content, despite your nincompoopery.
readingMnemonic: You’re the village nincompoop (にん), but the king and the leader still have a duty to protect you. Even a nincompoop is important to the kings and leaders of the world.

meaningMnemonic: The life thread is an element essential to all living things. This thread of life joins all things together, providing an essential relationship between all life. This element is all that holds this world together.
additionalM:
Hints
Visualize this element of life, interconnecting all living things. Without it, everything would fall apart and into chaos.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine grabbing hold of the element that holds all life together and trying to wash it with soap. It's slippery so you keep dropping it and soap keeps going in your eyes.
readingMnemonic: You need to keep this element clean, so you make sure to wash it with soap (そ) every single day. This turns out to be pretty hard because the element is an invisible thread, but you do your best.

meaningMnemonic: Seeing a mohawk in the winter means the enemy is nearby. You are from the dreadlock tribe and the mohawk tribe is your enemy. You’re deep in the heart of battle and winter has fallen. Now is the time to take out the enemy.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself holed up in a winter encampment, waiting to strike at the mohawk wearing enemies. Feel the cold around you as you scan the horizon for mohawks.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself all teched out like the techie you are. Hear the beeps and boops of all the technology you have at your disposal as you search for more mohawk enemies.
readingMnemonic: You’re kind of a techie (てき), so you have an advantage over your enemy. You’re armed with night vision goggles and other cool tech gear as well. Being a techie certainly has its advantages.

meaningMnemonic: Horns grow on the king that will be next because they're full of envy and jealousy for the present king.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the person next up for king. They have to sit in a chair behind the current king, and as they glare in front of them with envy, horns start to sprout out of their head.
additionalR:
Hints
Centaurs can't be the next king, so people really need to be careful about how much they let jealousy consume them. If you don't watch out, you'll turn into something ugly and twisted.
readingMnemonic: If they can't control their envy and jealousy, they'll start growing hooves and extra legs, until one day, they turn entirely into a centaur (せん)! A jealous centaur, who will never be king.

meaningMnemonic: If you say a new weapon idea out loud, then it will be established immediately.
additionalM:
Hints
Try it out: I want a stabbing weapon with extra weapons that can pop out on the sides. *POOF* You've established a new weapon. And it's been added to the official weapon wiki of the world.
additionalR:
Hints
Establish weapons in sets or the people who use them won't be able to match each other.
readingMnemonic: Weapons have to be established in sets (せつ). So you have to make another one that goes with it. Make them cohesive please.

meaningMnemonic: You should say "peace" before you evaluate a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say "peace" before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand.
additionalM:
Hints
What situation would you like to evaluate? Be sure to say "peace" before doing so. Imagine yourself doing this out loud and think of what you would say.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself trying to explain a situation you’re about to evaluate and your audience keeps shouting “Heyo!” every other sentence. Imagine how frustrating that would be. Get angry at your rude audience and how much they shout “Heyo.”
readingMnemonic: When you say "peace," you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “Heyo!” (ひょう) You look at the people around you and try to evaluate who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!” once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things.

meaningMnemonic: You see a tree with a squid on it, so you get closer to examine it.
additionalM:
Hints
As you examine the tree and the squid in it, you think, "Huh, nope still weird." You should examine it further to find out what's going on.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how many trees Ken examined before he found you both. Picture him putting his face really close to each one, then shedding a single tear when he realized this squid wasn't in it.
readingMnemonic: You're sticking your face in really, really close to examine this little squid in the tree when Ken (けん) the samurai appears behind you. "There you are, squid! Thank you citizen, I've been looking all over for my little chum."

meaningMnemonic: You have a scene going on inside your head. It is of a pair of horns on the ground atop a mountain. No. It is not just one pair of horns. It is many. So many that they create a giant hill atop the mountain, which is already pretty high.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this hill of horns on top of this mountain. This hill of horns makes it possible for you to get just high enough to touch the top of the sky.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel indifferent about this hill of horns on top of the mountain. It's all in your head anyways.
readingMnemonic: How was standing atop this hill of horns on top of a mountain to touch the sky? Eh. It was okay (おか), but that's about it.

meaningMnemonic: The dirt mask is a mask which, when put on, will greatly increase the amount of dirt.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting it on, and suddenly the dirt around you increases by quite a bit.
additionalR:
Hints
Zombie hands keep coming out of the ground, but as long as you wear the mask and increase the dirt on top of them, they won't be able to escape their earthly prison.
readingMnemonic: Use the dirt mask to increase the dirt around you. The zombies (ぞう) are trying to escape, so you just keep increasing the dirt on top of them so they can't get out.

meaningMnemonic: If a tree is growing out of a top hat you need to inspect it to find out why and how this happened. You should probably investigate the area too. I mean, how could a tree grow out of a top hat anyway? Seems suspicious.
additionalM:
Hints
Inspect the tree. Inspect the top hat. Did you find anything?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine stopping to inspect the tree after each minute of sawing. You'll find out why it's growing out of a top hat! Eventually!
readingMnemonic: In the middle of your inspection you realize you need to saw (さ) the tree open to come to a good conclusion. This seems a bit unnecessary, but no! No! For the sake of this investigation you must saw the tree in half!

meaningMnemonic: You're about to enter a roof that has your number on it so you can face the judge. You've been sitting here for what feels like hours, waiting for your number to come up. Finally the time has come—the judge will see you now.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the judge sitting under the roof. Your number is sitting on his big desk, next to the gavel.
additionalR:
Hints
You try to ask the judge what his ruling is, but he just hits you on the shins again!
readingMnemonic: The judge is not happy with you. He tells you to come closer and when you do, he takes his gavel and hits you in the shins (しん). Ouch!

meaningMnemonic: "I'll cut that baby in half with a knife if you don't figure out custody," says the judge. Ah, the oldest judge trick in the book.
additionalM:
Hints
Since you two can't make a decision on who gets custody of the baby, the judge now has to step in and judge for you. Will you figure it out for yourself, or let the baby get cut in half? What an effective judge.
additionalR:
Hints
Han Solo the judge isn't a bad person... but he isn't so good either. He'll cut that baby in half if you don't figure things out. That's the kind of judge Han Solo is.
readingMnemonic: This judge is Han (はん) Solo, so you know he's not going to back down.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the cow tribe is too important to deal with small matters and trivial affairs.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this hoity-toity cow leader who thinks he’s too good for small matters and affairs. See him acting all fancy like he’s better than everyone else. The cow even moos with a fake British accent. How pretentious.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Ken the samurai scooping poop for the leader of the cows, because that's a matter of poop and state.
readingMnemonic: All of his affairs are taken care of by Ken (けん) the samurai, who he hired as his underling.

meaningMnemonic: Buildings hold festivals on special occasions.
additionalM:
Hints
A festival can't be happening all the time. Then it wouldn't be special, it would just be a party building, so they can only happen on special occasions.
additionalR:
Hints
Your cyborg has been really great lately. Your wife loves it. It saved the world. It's nice of you to take this occasion to show the cyborg how much it means to you all with a festival.
readingMnemonic: The occasion this time is to celebrate your wonderful cyborg (さい). It's about time you did something nice for it.

meaningMnemonic: The hat comes to a stop, thinking of a plan. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a hat walking about on your head, pacing back and forth deep in thought. See the hat stroke its chin in contemplation as it tries to think up a plan to get off your noggin and back inside.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the hat begins to grin. This plan is so simple it’s sure to work. Now watch as the hat obtains the key and enters the locked door. What sort of mischief will the hat get into once inside?
readingMnemonic: The plan that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the key (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple!

meaningMnemonic: If there’s grass on the ground and fins in your hand, you need to raise that hand up to the sky. You’re in the middle of a fisherman’s ritual, which can only be performed on grassy ground. You take fish fins from the previous year, and raise them up to the sky in order to ensure a good fishing harvest.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the grass in your toes and the fins in your hand as you raise them up to the sky. See the sun glistening off the fins as you raise them up in the air.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself going through the same process as before, only this time imagine yourself in Little Kyoto. Little Kyoto is really little, so make sure you're in the right spot.
readingMnemonic: This ritual only works in one part of the world however. It absolutely must be performed in Little Kyoto (きょ). The way Little Kyoto lines up with the sun and the sky and all that astrological junk makes it the best place for you to raise fish fins up in the air.

meaningMnemonic: What people say to you will be carved by a blade into your heart, and the next time you see them, you'll immediately recognize them.
additionalM:
Hints
Sometimes your brain won't recognize someone, but your heart will. That's because what they say draws that blade across your heart and leaves a mark, for better or for worse, forever.
additionalR:
Hints
There's just something about Nintendo—you'd recognize them and their games anywhere.
readingMnemonic: You recognize places, names, and even games this way. But the thing that has the most real estate on your heart, the thing you recognize the most, is Nintendo (にん).

meaningMnemonic: The next shellfish will be yours, but this shellfish will be mine. These are the resources we have to share and distribute.
additionalM:
Hints
Our resources are based around a system of trading shellfish. It's not that weird, plenty of ancient societies used shellfish as their main resource!
additionalR:
Hints
Of course you're going to use your resources to get a sheep. You're living in a time when shellfish are used to trade for goods and services!
readingMnemonic: You save up all of your resources so you can buy a sheep (し). You bring a big sack of your shellfish resources to the market and finally get to pick out that sheep you've had your eyes on for months.

meaningMnemonic: The kanji and the radical are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
additionalM:
Hints
If you know the radical, you will know the kanji as well!
additionalR:
Hints
"THIS IS NOT RIGHTEOUSNESS!" you yell, just before the guillotine comes down on your neck.
readingMnemonic: Such righteousness! Well, at least according to the king who thinks he's being righteous. His version of righteousness is to send anyone who disagrees with him to the guillotine (ぎ).

meaningMnemonic: Under the tree lies a turkey with a broken arrow in it. It doesn't have rights like humans, so people can just shoot turkeys with arrows and no one is punished.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if humans didn't have any rights, like this turkey. People could just gun each other down in the street and no one would be punished for it... oh wait. :/
additionalR:
Hints
He jumps down and picks the turkey up, the broken arrow sticking out of its neck. "Turkeys do not have rights, my friend. Just let this one go."
readingMnemonic: "You have rights, so I won't shoot you like this turkey," says the voice of Ken (けん) the samurai, from above you in the tree.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami is coming for the cliff made of tofu, but there is a special sect that protects tofu cliff.
additionalM:
Hints
This sect of the tofu-lovers club takes their duties very seriously and they must protect this tofu cliff at all costs.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh, do you want to be a member of the tofu sect? HA! Don't make me laugh. If you ask to be a member of a sect, you'll never get in.
Never ask for a sect.
readingMnemonic: All of the members of the sect are standing on the cliff, their hands raised, and right as the tsunami is about to collide with them, they shout, "Ha (は)!" and it's repelled! The tsunami sinks and rolls back out to sea, the tofu cliff is safe!

meaningMnemonic: You use a special spear in winter to give yourself the power to do all of your tasks.
additionalM:
Hints
It's hard to get a task done in winter. That's why you have this spear to power and motivate you.
additionalR:
Hints
The moo haunts you as you finish your task. Luckily this spear is helping you keep going even though this task is really difficult.
readingMnemonic: Your task is to spear this cow. "Moo (む)!" it yells at you and runs away. You need to make dinner though... that's your task, so you better catch up to that cow and put an end to its mooing.

meaningMnemonic: A guard is at your door and wants some of your grains. This is the tax you pay for living in this town. Back in the day, grains were used like currency, so it makes sense that there was a grain tax in the olden days.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you imagine a guard coming to your door and demanding you pay your grain tax?
additionalR:
Hints
You don't want to be sliced with the zeiber, so you listen to vat he zei zei zei's and pay the tax.
readingMnemonic: You have to pay this tax, because if you don't the guard will cut you down with his special German saber, a zeiber (ぜい). "Don't you hear vat I zei? Pay ze tax or I vill zlei you!" he shouts.

meaningMnemonic: Angle your sword correctly at a cow to untie it without hurting it. This is actually a pretty tough angle to get your sword, so in order to solve this cow puzzle you have to be really smart and careful.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the cow looking up at you with her big, brown eyes. She doesn't want to be tied here anymore, so you have to solve this and untie her.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture it: you're standing in a kayak with this cow, trying to untie the rope around their neck by getting your sword to cut it at the right angle. You can't hurt the cow or knock over the kayak. Can you solve it in time?!
readingMnemonic: You're trying to untie this cow from the kayak (かい) you're both currently in. Some jerk tied the cow to this kayak and sent it toward a waterfall. If you don't solve this riddle fast, you'll both go with the kayak over the falls!

meaningMnemonic: Taking out your thread, you sew together the public's hearts to make them whole again.
additionalM:
Hints
The world has been in turmoil and the public has been suffering, but it's time to stop splitting our hearts apart and fighting. It's time to be whole again.
additionalR:
Hints
Suddenly people who were fighting for years are crying and holding one another. Their souls recognize each other, they're healed, and the whole nation is finally seeing eye to eye.
readingMnemonic: Once their hearts are whole, the public's soul (そう) becomes one!

meaningMnemonic: You use your fingers in the game of football to aid and assist the other players. And when you smash your fingers in football, you need to get some aid yourself.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself playing football. You catch the ball with your fingers and then assist your team by running and smashing your body into the enemy team. But in the process you smash your fingers... so you need to go to the aid tent.
additionalR:
Hints
You can't assist your team anymore because you got hurt. This isn't fair! It's the end. The end of your life and your career. Boo hoo hoo!
readingMnemonic: When you need aid for your football wrecked fingers you can't help but feel like it's the end (えん) for you. Your fingers hurt so much, you don't even want the nice nurses to aid you.

meaningMnemonic: You have a great ability because your heart gives you the appearance of a superhuman. Your heart is really strong and powerful, fuelling your body to the best of its ability. All this together gives you the appearance of someone in top condition.
additionalM:
Hints
See yourself in this ideal appearance. Everyone loves to look at you because you look so awesome. Your heart has given you many great abilities. Feel strong and powerful in this body of yours.
additionalR:
Hints
Since you don’t know how to tie a tie or tie your shoes, you wear slip ons and clip ons. Hear the noise of Velcro being undone as you kick off your shoes and unclip your tie after a hard day’s work at the office.
readingMnemonic: While you may have the appearance of someone who is super strong, powerful, and awesome, you do have one shortcoming. You don’t know how to tie (たい) a tie. Actually, you don’t even know how to tie your shoes, let alone your tie. How embarrassing.

meaningMnemonic: They say yoga is the correct way to go through birth. Birth isn't easy, but people keep telling you that yoga is the right way to prepare and actually do it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture multiple people you know saying you should do yoga if you plan to give birth. It isn't a question of whether you want to, it's the correct way to do it. So you should.
additionalR:
Hints
Hopefully having a tan doesn't make birth harder, since you've worked so hard to do this the correct way with so much yoga.
readingMnemonic: To prepare for giving birth you end up doing so much yoga outside that you get a really deep tan (たん).

meaningMnemonic: There's an icicle on a dog. That is the dog's condition.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a couple police officers looking at the dog, talking specifically about the condition they found the dog in.
additionalR:
Hints
But, did Jourm forget? We all know he's a bit clumsy and slow, but he's been letting the dog inside for years now. Would he really do this by accident? That's what the police seem to think, despite the condition they found the dog in.
readingMnemonic: The frozen condition of this dog was caused by Jourm (じょう), the local farmhand. He forgot to let the dog back inside, and then it froze.

meaningMnemonic: You use the power of your mouth to spit shellfish at people as a form of congratulations! In fact, you yell "CONGRATULATIONS!" as the shellfish come pouring out of your powerful mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Shellfish were once used as currency, so this totally makes sense. Just think of the shellfish as money coming out of your mouth as you say your congratulations.
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you're congratulating someone, assume the gargoyle stance and dump all of their congratulatory shellfish on them from your mouth.
readingMnemonic: When you say congratulations like this, you look just like a gargoyle (が). You're crouching down, your mouth wide open, just like a stone gargoyle.

meaningMnemonic: You kiss each of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine kissing each of your best friends on the mouth. Does this make you uncomfortable? Excited? Both? Feel that feeling.
additionalR:
Hints
Kissing the cock beak is kind of a strange experience. Feel the feathers in your hands as you steady the cock to kiss it. Cock-a-doodle-doo!
readingMnemonic: Actually, each of your best pals are of the cock (かく) variety. By that, I mean they are both roosters. Imagine kissing both of these cocks on their beaks.

meaningMnemonic: Dollars and shellfish are used to pay expenses and costs. Shellfish used to be used as currency, so they're like the coins that go with dollars.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine opening your bank account and looking at all of your monthly expenses. Now drag the little dollar and shellfish icons over to cover all of those costs.
additionalR:
Hints
When you see how expensive your heat is, you feel a heat going through your body too.
readingMnemonic: What is the biggest expense and cost? It's the heat (ひ) bill.

meaningMnemonic: “Bring in the next woman so that I may examine her figure!” We’re holding auditions for a commercial and we need to find a woman with a nice figure. The last woman was no good, so bring in the next one.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself as a figure judge on this panel. You need to find a woman with the perfect figure to cast in your commercial. You'd cast yourself, but you just aren't confident (Ridiculous! You're special, and beautiful, and no matter who you are [yes you reading this right now] you should be proud of who you are!).
additionalR:
Hints
We should all try harder to have a figure like this stunning sheep woman!
readingMnemonic: The next woman comes in and you examine her figure. The figure you've been searching for! It just happens to belong to a sheep (し) woman. But she's soft, fluffy, and round. The perfect figure!

meaningMnemonic: The womb is a circle of power where a force of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself in the womb. You’re being born into the world. Feel the force and energy of your mother around you. Hear the sound of water as you float about in the womb. Force yourself to breathe the fluid and imagine yourself doing so.
additionalR:
Hints
As the baby is forced out, you slice with your saber and cut the umbilical cord before the baby is caught in a basket!
readingMnemonic: Now pretend you are the pregnant woman. You need to force that baby out of you with such force that the baby comes flying out, so you grab hold of your special saber (せい)! You close your eyes, breathe and feel the force of the saber entering your body. Then the baby is forced right out!

meaningMnemonic: You have something to say, you stand on a towel, and shout, "I GIVE UP!"
additionalM:
Hints
Standing on a towel is the universal signal for giving up, but you still need to say you're abandoning whatever it is with your mouth too (just in case).
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the tater tots at your feet. You feel ashamed for giving up but you were so full, you had to give up! Now they're all down there mocking you.
readingMnemonic: After you announce that you are ready to give up, you throw all of your tater (てい) tots onto the ground. You have abandoned your goal of eating all of them.

meaningMnemonic: You can use a jackhammer to indicate and show someone where the prize is buried. You buried the prize to keep it safe, but the jackhammer is great at unearthing it. Jackhammers do a great job and show where the treasure lies. They indicate quite clearly where one needs to go.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine using this jackhammer to show someone where the prize is buried. Feel the vibrations through your hands and the rest of your body.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Jesus getting all over the top and super preachy about his religious beliefs. He’s doing everything he can to indicate to the crowd that he’s the best, and show them how cool he is. Listen to Jesus preach to the crowd, desperate for their attention.
readingMnemonic: Actually, you're unearthing Jesus (じ). He’s the treasure. For your soul. He’s here to show you that Jesus is still a hip and cool guy and he wants to indicate to you that having faith in Jesus and God and stuff is super rad. Jesus is all like, “Who has two thumbs and wants to show you the way of the Lord? This guy.”

meaningMnemonic: From the roof, an icicle falls and hits wolverine in the forehead, and he has to go over to the stool to lie down. And eventually he goes to sleep.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this entire scene. The icicle falls in slow motion from the roof. It hits wolverine right in the middle of his forehead. He goes down. He has to lie down. He has to sleep.
additionalR:
Hints
Wolverine might have a concussion that's making him neigh in his sleep. I guess it's good that he's laying down, but I'm pretty sure you're not supposed to sleep... Maybe you should wake him up so the neighing will stop—I mean, so he'll be okay!
readingMnemonic: While wolverine sleeps, he makes a horrible neighing (ね) sound. It's like there's a giant horse in his mouth screaming to get out! NEIGH NEIGH!

meaningMnemonic: A Viking who knows how to use a bathtub will have to manage all the baths for the other Vikings. Vikings aren't so great with bathing... if you can get one Viking to figure it out he has to manage the rest of them.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a Viking trying to manage his Viking friends so they'll use the bathtub properly. He has to manage which people go in when, how hot or cold the water is, and provide all the soap. It's a very important job.
additionalR:
Hints
Some of the Vikings managed to fill their bathtubs with acorns and are trying to rub themselves clean with them instead of water...
readingMnemonic: The poor Viking trying to manage all the others keeps having to confiscate acorns (えい). "You can't take baths in acorns and wood, it has to be water!" he shouts.

meaningMnemonic: Can you look at the dirt and know which direction you need to go? Then you might be a monk. Monks have amazing skills like that. And I'm sure you've seen monks wandering around in lots of media. They don't need maps or smartphones. They just look at the dirt and let the earth guide them to where they need to be.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a monk walking through a large field in the middle of nowhere. He knows where to go, he's not afraid. The dirt will lead him in the right direction.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a monk bowling in the middle of the road. Imagine your shock at how well he handles the ball. Also, imagine how heavy it must be for a monk to carry a bowling ball everywhere!
readingMnemonic: You want to know the monk's trick so you hide behind him for a while as he walks. Finally the monk stops, looks around, takes out a bowling (ぼう) ball and starts bowling in the dirt. The bowling ball rolls off, the monk follows it, and then heads off in that direction.

meaningMnemonic: If you try to say things with a knife, the police will put you in a net as your penalty for breaking the knife laws. You can't just go up to other people and say things with a knife out.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine getting so mad that you use a knife instead of words to say what you're trying to say. A net falls over you and pulls you down. The knife goes flying. This is your penalty for acting like a crazy person.
additionalR:
Hints
If you don't want to be punished with bats, maybe next time don't use a knife instead of your words.
readingMnemonic: Your penalty for breaking the law isn't over. Now that you're stuck in a net, you can't fight back when they hit you with bats (ばつ).

meaningMnemonic: A cheap tree has a plan. A plan to stay cheap.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a tree coming up with some elaborate plans to make sure they can spend as little money as possible.
additionalR:
Hints
You're not sure about this anchovy plan. Are you cheap enough to choose a life of eating only anchovies?
readingMnemonic: The cheap tree's plan involves only buying anchovies (あん) and surviving on them. Good exposure to the sun and fresh water is too expensive. The tree plans to save money by eating anchovies.

meaningMnemonic: With a bamboo tree resting atop your head, you devise a plan. The plan is actually for getting the bamboo tree off of your head. You’re trapped under it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being trapped under this bamboo tree that is resting on your head. You’re stuck. Feel the weight of the bamboo tree pressing on your head as you try and devise a plan to get out from under it.
additionalR:
Hints
Bamboo is usually kind of light, but this bamboo has a sack of rocks tied to each end making it heavy. Imagine yourself trying to remove this bamboo tree by pushing it up and away from you. It’s like doing a bench-press, bamboo style.
readingMnemonic: But why is this bamboo tree so heavy? You look to each end of the bamboo and realize that there is a sack (さく) tied on each end. Each sack seems to be filled with heavy rocks. Looks like someone made a plan to trap you here. Now you have to devise a plan to escape!

meaningMnemonic: Pointing your fingers to the sun is the correct way to present yourself or offer to submit your ideas. You're really just raising your hand. And when you want to present yourself, your ideas, or offer anything, the correct way is to raise your fingers to the sun. You definitely learned this in school.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself in class. You want to present next! You want to submit your ideas for class approval. So raise those fingers to the sun the correct way and wait for your teacher to call on you.
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you have to submit work in class just raise your hand and give everyone tater tots. Instant "A" material.
readingMnemonic: You want to present your show and tell of tater tots (てい) to the class. You raise your hand, the teacher calls on you, and you submit the tater tots for her and the class's approval. "Oh my!" the teacher exclaims, "I hope you brought enough tater tots to present to the whole class!" You raise your hand once more to the sky, and in it you submit a whole tray of tater tots!

meaningMnemonic: This net needs to be fixed if you want to put food on the table.
additionalM:
Hints
You can't put something in your net if it's broken. Fix it!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine putting a bunch of cheese in your now-fixed net. It kinda stinks!
readingMnemonic: Once it's fixed, you put a bunch of cheese (ち) in the net. You want to catch something that eats cheese, so that you can then put that animal on your dinner table.

meaningMnemonic: Under the dirt in the ground is a drunkard with something in his mouth from a region in North America. He died from whatever it is that’s in his mouth. That’s how this drunkard ended up under the ground in the first place. His whole face region is disfigured from whatever he ate. I wonder what region of North America the strange object came from?
additionalM:
Hints
Try and imagine yourself unearthing this dead drunkard and trying to figure out what’s in his mouth. Smell the decay of flesh as you poke around in his mouth, trying to figure out what this thing is. Think of an object and what region of North America it comes from.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine touching this super icky substance from the drunkard’s mouth. It’s really icky. Feel yourself throwing up as you feel the icky goo in the region between your fingers.
readingMnemonic: In an attempt to identify what region of North America the thing in the drunkard’s mouth came from, you touch it and try to remove it with your bare hands. Upon touching whatever it is, you find it to be all icky (いき) and gooey. Like, super icky. So icky that you barf in the region immediately adjacent to you.

meaningMnemonic: If someone gets under the canopy over your heart you should respond to them.
additionalM:
Hints
You usually ignore everyone, but this one person... they really got under there and touched your heart. You finally feel like they're the right person to respond to.
additionalR:
Hints
The 王 touched your heart, you responded, and now you're together. It's like a fairy tale!
readingMnemonic: You respond and it turns out it was to the 王 (おう).

meaningMnemonic: It may just be a roof over a bathtub, but this here is actually a Shinto shrine.
additionalM:
Hints
It is indeed just a roof over a bathtub, but I guess spirits inhabit everything according to Shintoism, so there's no reason this bathtub can't be a Shinto shrine too.
additionalR:
Hints
It makes sense, the person who says "It's-a-me! (Mario)" is someone who works on bathtubs (and plumbing).
readingMnemonic: What god does this Shinto shrine hold? You see that "It's a-me-ya! (Mario!)"

meaningMnemonic: A mix of spirit and reason helped you invent the sleeve. Your spirit told you your arms were uncomfortable, stuck to your sides under that shirt. Reason told you that maybe, just maybe, if you made holes for your arms something good would come out of it. And that's how sleeves were born!
additionalM:
Hints
Your spirit and your arms are free! Imagine how unreasonable no sleeves were. How on earth did you survive without them?!
additionalR:
Hints
You also take the extra fabric that helped make your sleeves and turned them into another pair of really light shoes, since they're shoe shaped from the whole process anyway. Waste not!
readingMnemonic: To make the sleeve holes you took your shoe (しゅう) and kicked a hole through your shirt. Then you did it again on the other side, because you have two of those weird arm things.

meaningMnemonic: Your mouth is like an escalator you use to suck and inhale things into your body.
additionalM:
Hints
If you're ever having trouble remembering how to suck or inhale, just picture an actual escalator that leads into your mouth. That'll definitely help.
additionalR:
Hints
You can inhale a cucumber too, I suppose, but don't tell anyone I told you to.
readingMnemonic: Use this mouth ability to suck cucumbers (きゅう) into your mouth. Cucumbers are shaped like cylinders so you can suck them into your mouth like this. Just as nature intended.

meaningMnemonic: While riding on your scooter, you grow a mustache on top of the mustache you already have in order to surpass the people around you. You're in a scooter race and your mustache is the only thing keeping you in the lead, but someone else has a mustache too! So you grow another mustache to surpass them once again!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself running on a scooter with a bunch of other people and closing your eyes tight, willing another mustache to sprout out of your face to surpass them all.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch helplessly as the car surpasses every single one of your scooters. Both of your mustaches droop in shame.
readingMnemonic: Suddenly, something else manages to surpass you all. It's a car (か)! A car with two mustaches is also riding on a scooter and going way faster than you.

meaningMnemonic: Taking orders from a geoduck will place you into enemy territory. Geoducks make terrible commanders, so if you take orders from one, expect to end up in unknown territory, potentially even enemy territory. Be prepared.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this geoduck shouting orders at you to march into enemy territory. See its gross body as a mouth forms and starts shouting out orders.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel yourself in the row boat as you imagine rowing away to safe territory. Hear the geoduck in the background shouting at you from shore, ordering you to return to land.
readingMnemonic: Not wanting to end up dead in enemy territory, you decide to escape this geoduck leader by getting on a row (りょう) boat and rowing your way outta there. The geoduck commander orders you to halt your escape, but you still get in your row boat and row away.

meaningMnemonic: The light of the moon is shining on a guard who's been on duty all night. The moon light makes him so warm and comfortable that he forgets where he is and starts to undress. He thinks he's home! Everyone is going to see him take off his clothes!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a sleepy guard, bathed in moonlight, starting to undress. No! Keep your uniform on guard! Don't undress outside in the middle of the night!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine throwing darts at a guard who's undressing himself. Imagine trying to aim for his pants so they'll be nailed to his body.
readingMnemonic: You can't seem to get the guard to stop undressing so you throw some darts (だつ) at him. You figure that even if the guard doesn't snap out of this weird sleepy trance, at least you can use the darts to stick his clothes to his body. Then maybe he won't be able to undress anymore.

meaningMnemonic: You take all of your thread and allocate them into one place to unite them. You wrap all the thread together into a giant thread ball. Now it's a big, united mess!
additionalM:
Hints
Allocate all of your thread like you would your cash: by uniting it! Not at a bank, but in a big, intertwined lump.
additionalR:
Hints
Try to do this yourself at home. Unite all of your thread and poof! There's とうきょう!
readingMnemonic: You're busy trying to unite all of your thread, twisting and tying and wrapping, and suddenly you look at the ball in your hands and see とうきょう. You've united this thread into the shape of とうきょう. There are even little pins for all the famous neighborhoods and tourist spots. This is strange, because you don't remember putting them there.

meaningMnemonic: The helicopter the leader is in has the most value! He would only choose to fly the very best one, after all. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter he flies goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you understand the value of this helicopter? The leader flew it to war and back! So of course it's worth a lot!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine driving a valuable car with the leader's helicopter on top. Yeah!
readingMnemonic: To further increase the helicopter's value, the leader bought himself a car (か) and then tied them together. Now it has the value of a helicopter AND a car! Wow!

meaningMnemonic: A leader can fix the value of certain goods and services. Leaders basically get to decide how much everything is worth in value, like rice or lamps or how much you get paid for the work you do.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having a wonderful leader who values your work and time and so the value you get from working is high. Now imagine a terrible leader, who thinks you should be working at all times and doesn't find any value in what you do. Life will be a lot harder...
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine if you could fix the value of cheese to something. How much would you make it cost? If you were a dairy farmer you'd probably be pretty pissed about the leader making it this low.
readingMnemonic: This leader has fixed the value of cheese (ち), making it ￥1 permanently. One yen! That's, like, less than a penny! Unfortunately, the leader won't fix any of the other really expensive things... so now everyone only eats cheese.

meaningMnemonic: That scarecrow with the knife is the vice president. Yeah, I know how he looks, and I'm pretty sure he does some murdering on the side, but you didn't hear that from me.
additionalM:
Hints
I don't know how we managed to get a knife-wielding scarecrow as a vice president, there's a side of politics I don't get, I guess. I mean, just look at him up there. If something happens to our president we're stuck with that thing.
additionalR:
Hints
What's going on? Normally if a vice president yells f**k you there would be... I dunno... consequences? What's happening?!
readingMnemonic: It's the vice president's turn to speak at the podium and he just clears his throat and yells, "F**k (ふく) you!" to the crowd, holding up his knife. They cheer.

meaningMnemonic: There's an arrow in a turkey that you can see in your view. The turkey seems to be viewing you too, from afar.
additionalM:
Hints
View the turkey as the turkey views you. View the arrow stuck in it too.
additionalR:
Hints
As you view this strange scene, Genghis Khan turns and views you viewing him. He points two fingers to his eyes and then to you, and marches off into the woods. You also view the turkey running off in the other direction.
readingMnemonic: As you view the turkey, Genghis Khan (かん) suddenly comes into your view too. He towers over the injured turkey, leans down, and... pulls the arrow out!?

meaningMnemonic: The only flowers that the moon gladiators will water are wisteria.
additionalM:
Hints
The moon gladiators have a thing for wisterias.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine them reaching down from the moon and plucking some wisteria up from Mt. Fuji then taking them back up to the moon. Now they water them.
readingMnemonic: Since they're on the moon, where did they get the wisteria from? Actually, from one of the points on earth that is nearest to the moon, Mt. Fuji (ふじ).

meaningMnemonic: A mouth that wants peace can call for it. If you don’t have a mouth, you can’t call for peace. So use your mouth and call for peace when you can. Peace is great.
additionalM:
Hints
Call for peace. Say it aloud. I’m using my mouth to call for peace!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself whirling this yo-yo about while you call for peace. Imagine yourself doing a variety of tricks with it as you slowly convince the people to agree to peace.
readingMnemonic: But before you call for peace, you must first placate the masses. To do so, you astound them with your yo-yo (よ) skills. Once they are so entranced by how talented you are with a yo-yo, you easily convince them to make peace.

meaningMnemonic: On top of a big mountain, wearing a lip ring, you see a cape jutting out into the ocean. You’re wearing a lip ring because you’re a cool and edgy individual who likes to climb big mountains. From the top of the big mountain, you see a cape.
additionalM:
Hints
You’re tired from just climbing up the big mountain but the view is worth it. Feel the wind blustering around you as you take in the beautiful scenery, including the cape.
additionalR:
Hints
See yourself picking up the saw and the key and examining them, as you wonder what on earth they're doing at the top of that big mountain.
readingMnemonic: Atop the big mountain overlooking the cape, you see a saw and a key (さき) lying on the ground. What are they doing there?

meaningMnemonic: Moving in the direction of a gun, an alligator can carry out a murder once it reaches it. This alligator wants to kill someone. The alligator wants to carry out their execution.
additionalM:
Hints
See the alligator swim really slowly in the direction of a gun. See the alligator as it prepares to carry out the murder. It’s scary.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the alligator slinks under the water, holding the gun above the water. When it gets close enough, it carries out the murder on the sheep. Shooting it right in the chest. Now it can eat the sheep without worrying about needing to chomp on it.
readingMnemonic: In order to carry out this murder, the alligator has to sneak up on its prey, so it can shoot it. You look across the water and see a sheep (し) grazing by the shore. The alligator is going to carry out a murder on that sheep!

meaningMnemonic: Dirt can become a castle at any time. You just have to have the right conditions. The right time, the right people, and any patch of dirt can grow into a huge castle.
additionalM:
Hints
Every great building, especially castles, started off as just a plot of dirt, you know? It's kind of inspiring what we can become.
additionalR:
Hints
Once a castle is there, there's really no turning back. So just remember that when dirt becomes a castle, that's all she wrote.
readingMnemonic: Once you turn dirt into a castle, that's all she wrote (しろ). That's it. It's done. The story is over.

meaningMnemonic: They say that flowers held by a turkey on a stool are good to defend yourself with. Even better than a guard dog they say. People are so confused by the turkey sitting on a stool holding flowers that they just lose their will to fight. This turkey is great to defend yourself and your home.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this turkey holding its flowers while sitting on its stool. Hear it gobbling as it defends everything around it with its mere presence.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Godzilla approaching the flower turkey. Hear Godzilla roar as the turkey gobbles in fear before being crushed beneath the massive and scaly foot of Godzilla.
readingMnemonic: The only thing this flower-bearing turkey can't defend against is Godzilla (ご). Godzilla is pretty much undefeatable, especially for a turkey. The turkey is totally unable to defend anything from the mighty Godzilla.

meaningMnemonic: The demon radical and the demon kanji are exactly the same! Wicked!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself locking up a demon with a special demon containing key. Hear the key click into the lock as the demon screams to be set free.
readingMnemonic: How do you keep a demon locked up? Use a key (き). Use a lock and key and keep that demon locked up safely behind bars so he can’t get out and do bad demon stuff.

meaningMnemonic: Under the roof of life a mouth with a knife divides cells to create life.
additionalM:
Hints
The entire house glows with blobs of life, and the mouth holds the knife in its mouth and cuts the life blobs apart to help them grow.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Wario's mouth dividing himself now, and creating more, smaller Warios. They all yell WA! and divide up even more until the whole room is full of わりs and わs!
readingMnemonic: As it divides life, the mouth begins to look really familiar. It has big teeth and a crooked mustache... it's Wario (わり)!

meaningMnemonic: Reaching your ear is the sound of a drunkard who can’t find employment. You hear him before you see him because he’s behind some trash cans. Being a drunkard, he’s like, super wasted and just kind of rambling to himself, making strange sounds. No wonder he can’t find employment.
additionalM:
Hints
Hear the strange sounds this drunkard is making. Let his ramblings enter your ears and imagine what he could be trying to say.
additionalR:
Hints
Actually you find out that he does have employment. He’s a garbage man. Feel the shock of making this shocking discovery. How can this drunkard possibly hold down his job like this?
readingMnemonic: Since this guy is such a pathetic drunkard, it comes as no shock (しょく) that he can’t find employment. If he did find employment, I would be filled with both shock and awe.

meaningMnemonic: If you can eat grains while running up stairs, you'll excel at everything.
additionalM:
Hints
This special workout routine is so hard that, if you can do it, you'll be able to excel at every other thing you try.
additionalR:
Hints
You have to eat the grains AND run up the stairs, or you aren't actually excelling. Good shoes will help you get there faster and protect your toes.
readingMnemonic: In order to excel at this, though, you need a good pair of shoes (しゅう).

meaningMnemonic: A leader wishing to stop criminals will write a moving haiku. The leader pleads with the criminals to stop their crimes, to look within, and to realize there's more to life (like poetry!).
additionalM:
Hints
Unfortunately, the leader of the criminals also writes haiku, and they want all the criminals to keep doing crimes. Look inside and see how much you want what others have, write a haiku, and then steal!
additionalR:
Hints
Just remember: a haiku is always a haiku.
readingMnemonic: A haiku is still a haiku (はい). Whether it's written by a law abiding leader or a criminal leader.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the restaurant says, "Halt!" to everyone who wants to come in. The leader looks them up and down. Stares into their eyes. And then, maybe, they may go into the restaurant to eat.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being told to halt in front of your favorite restaurant, then being turned away. Noooo! Better start sucking up to the restaurant leader.
additionalR:
Hints
HALT! NO TATERS FOR YOU!
readingMnemonic: People only halt because they want this restaurant's world famous tater (てい) tots. Which is probably why there is a leader out front making sure only people who can really appreciate the tater tots can get in to eat them.

meaningMnemonic: You need to go up on the roof and slide down seven times to make this your house. A house isn't a home until you've slid down it exactly seven times, you know.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sliding down your house from the roof all the way down to the ground. I hope you aren't afraid of heights, because you have to do this six more times.
additionalR:
Hints
As you slide, you close your eyes and really hope you don't end up with a tack in your butt and no home to sleep in tonight.
readingMnemonic: If you try to slide down your new house and you land on a tack (たく), that means the house has rejected you. It isn't your home now. You need to leave and find a new home.

meaningMnemonic: You place a cross on this drunkard's clothes to show him you judge him. In fact, you yell, "I JUDGE YOU FOR BEING DRUNK AND WEARING THESE CLOTHES, TAKE THIS!"
additionalM:
Hints
He yells back, "YOU CAN'T JUDGE ME, I CAN DO WHAT I WANT. GET THAT JUDGEY CROSS OFF ME!"
additionalR:
Hints
The cyborg joins in, "A judge would convict you if the fashion police brought you in. I have a bunch of meat and robot parts and even I'm better looking than you."
readingMnemonic: As you judge each other, your cyborg (さい) comes stomping over and slams the drunkard against the wall. With your trusty cyborg coming to your rescue, you can continue to judge this guy all you want.

meaningMnemonic: Loitering around with a brush? Sorry, but you're breaking the law. If you have a brush, that's okay. If you're loitering, that's okay. If you combine the two? Well... watch your back.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a police officer coming for you. He's yelling at you because you have a brush and you're loitering. He grabs you, throws you to the ground, telling you what you're doing wrong.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the hotel staff watching as you get thrown to the ground. You yell "won't the Ritz do anything to help me??" They won't.
readingMnemonic: Where were you loitering with your brush, breaking the law? Right outside the Ritz (りつ) Hotel. You'd think that it would be okay since you were staying there, but the law is the law.

meaningMnemonic: Take a measurement of the road. Hmm. It seems a bit too long. As you measure it, you continue down this road, wondering where it will lead you.
additionalM:
Hints
Roads are really long, so I imagine it would take a long time to measure it (if you want to go from end to end). Imagine yourself pulling a tape measure along with you, all the while thinking, "where will this lead me?"
additionalR:
Hints
What a perfect way to end this road measuring. You're hungry. Nom nom nom. Imagine eating your fill, and taste the donuts in your mouth. You just walked a long ways!
readingMnemonic: Where does the road that you're measuring lead you? An awesome doughnut (どう) shop!

meaningMnemonic: The leather radical and the leather kanji are exactly the same! Cool!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine skinning a cock for its leather. See yourself cutting through the rooster’s skin as you pluck the feathers out so it can be tanned into leather.
readingMnemonic: One way to get leather is to skin a male chicken, a cock (かく). You won’t get much leather from a cock, but you can definitely skin one in a pinch, should you need a little extra leather.

meaningMnemonic: In winter, shellfish head in the direction of the dirt and become a luxury. Luxuries are things that are hard to get, which is why rich people like them so much. It shows they have the money and means to get things other people can't. So when these shellfish try to bury themselves deep, deep in the dirt in winter, they become the biggest luxury of them all.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if you could get your hand on this type of luxury. Ah, that would be the life!
additionalR:
Hints
There's no luxury in the world as luxurious as this zeiber. You forget all about the shellfish and skip home with the zeiber instead.
readingMnemonic: You have your eyes on one of these luxury shellfish, and you're digging down into the cold dirt, when your fingers wrap around something hard and... long? You struggle to pull it out, but once you do, you realize you're holding a rare German saber: the zeiber (ぜい)!

meaningMnemonic: Giving cleats to a child carrying an umbrella is the best way to gather milk. You don’t have any containers, so the child has to hold milk in the upside-down umbrella. The cleats are so the child can run back and forth to transport the milk around.
additionalM:
Hints
See this child running in his cleats. Picture him holding the umbrella upside-down, milk sloshing all about as he runs.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine post-apocalyptic New York City. Milk is a hot commodity here so it’s important not to spill any of the milk. Imagine yourself carrying the milk in the umbrella and being careful not to spill any of it.
readingMnemonic: But where is this child exactly? He’s in New (にゅう) York City. What’s he doing in New York City you ask? Well, he's milking a cow. Why is there a cow to be milked in New York City? Good question. It’s the end of the world and New York City is the last remaining civilization. This is how people live now. Milk is important.

meaningMnemonic: Wrap vines around a stool to obtain it. Don't worry about paying for it, sneak into the stool store and tie some vines around the legs. Then when you leave, pull the vines and the stool will come out after. That's how you obtain a stool!
additionalM:
Hints
You can obtain a lot of goods this way without needing any cash. Just don't tell anyone I told you.
additionalR:
Hints
You have to pull very slowly, or the shoes will fall off the stool. But you really, really want to obtain these particular shoes (they're really sweet), so you keep scooting them toward you.
readingMnemonic: Today you want to obtain a new pair of shoes (しゅう). You tie your vines around the stool they're on, and slowly inch them toward the door.

meaningMnemonic: There is a tsunami coming, so you stand on your roof holding a leaf, wearing fins, and standing before a rice paddy full of people. These are your neighbors and they're here to watch you perform.
additionalM:
Hints
This performance will distract all of you from the impending tsunami. You wave the leaf and dance with the fins. It's a wonderful performance.
additionalR:
Hints
The performance and the tsunami end together. How poetic.
readingMnemonic: As the performance ends (えん), so do you all.

meaningMnemonic: The king can see the present time for what it really is. The future isn't important. The past isn't important. The present is where it's at.
additionalM:
Hints
People are constantly asking the king to do things for them and solve their problems. But the king can see exactly what needs to be done at the present time, and what can wait until tomorrow.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture pretty Genji, carefully instructing his followers what to do at the present time and what can wait.
readingMnemonic: At the present time the king is Genji (げん). The time has finally come for him to get serious, and as they say, there's no time like the present.

meaningMnemonic: The leader put flowers on a cliff. That is their task. It is to provide and equip the cliff with flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a leader carrying flowers up to the top of a cliff. They are saying "I must provide more flowers to the cliff" as they climb up.
additionalR:
Hints
"The bees must be equipped with more flowers. I will provide these flowers for the bees!"
readingMnemonic: Why do they provide and equip the cliff with flowers? It's all for the bees (び).

meaningMnemonic: A shellfish with a knife makes all the rules. It isn't supposed to be making rules, but it has a knife, so who's going to argue?
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a shellfish wielding a knife and shouting out new rules to all of the nervous people standing around it.
additionalR:
Hints
Once everyone follows the rule, and the shellfish is on top of a pile of socks, he cackles, "It's easier to stab your toes with my knife now! Let's get to more rules!"
readingMnemonic: The first rule the shellfish enacts is that all humans take off their socks (そく) and give them to him. Hmm... is this some kind of nasty shellfish? Who would want socks?

meaningMnemonic: A man who is husband material can see a standard woman and think she’s the greatest thing ever. This man will make a great husband. Even though the lady is pretty standard, the husband treats her like she’s anything but.
additionalM:
Hints
This husband sets a new standard for what it means to be a husband. He’s pretty great. Imagine yourself shaking this husband’s hand because he’s so awesome.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this woman actually sticking a physical key into the husband’s chest and turning it. Now this is anything but standard, but it’ll help you remember this kanji and its reading.
readingMnemonic: It’s pretty standard for a husband and wife to exchange vows when getting married, and the husband said this girl held the key (き) to his heart. She unlocked the husband’s heart with the key and now he’s a man made whole.

meaningMnemonic: Riding a tsunami you see a turkey carrying a cross, but that’s pretty standard here. This is your dreamland. You always dream about tsunamis and the turkeys carrying crosses that ride them. This might be strange for other people, but for you it’s pretty normal.
additionalM:
Hints
See this tsunami riding turkey in your mind. Hear it gobble loudly as it waves its cross around. Remember, this is standard fare for you. Nothing unusual here.
additionalR:
Hints
It’s usually pretty toasty in the month of June (in the Northern Hemisphere, at least) so imagine going to bed in this heat. Feel the spray of the refreshing tsunami water in your dream as the turkey continues to ride those tsunami waves with his cross.
