readingMnemonic: These wacky dreams are only standard fare in June (じゅん) though. You don’t have them any other time of the year, just in June. You don’t know why June is the only time you have dreams about tsunami riding turkeys, but that’s just the way it is.

meaningMnemonic: You have a bow and you want to make it long. To do that, you'd naturally just stretch it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding this bow in your hands, and then stretching it into a longer bow. Feel the strain on your arms as you try to stretch wood. You can feel it stretching, but it's strenuous.
additionalR:
Hints
Now Mrs. Chou is hitting you with the stretched out bow. You cry and apologize, but she won't listen. "I'm going to stretch you, like you stretched my bow," she says. Then she does it.
readingMnemonic: As you stretch the bow, you hear someone running at you. "That's my bow you're stretching!" yells Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She is not happy that you're stretching her things. You should probably try to un-stretch it, put it down, and run before she beats you.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of a hundred foreheads in the heart of winter is superior at being gentle. These hundred foreheads are sensitive, especially in the heart of winter, so the leader must be very gentle. Not just any kind of gentle though—the superior kind of gentle that will keep a hundred foreheads following.
additionalM:
Hints
As a leader, you are superior. You’re so gentle to these foreheads. See yourself caring for them in the winter. Feel the chill in the air as you wrap the foreheads in blankets and prepare heating pads for them.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the youths trying to show you that they are the superior ones, then they sneeze, their eyes fill with tears, and you have to gently tuck them back into bed. Silly youths.
readingMnemonic: You need to be superior because all of these foreheads belong to youths (ゆう). They don't know how to take care of themselves, though they try to convince you they can. They're too young to know any better.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami of shrimp crashes into a swamp. Now the swamp is filled with shrimp. They used to live in the ocean, but the tsunami has carried them to their new home in the swamp.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself in the swamp when the tsunami hits. Feel the water crash into you along with the shrimp. You’re all wet and shrimpy now.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the side of your house. It’s covered with shrimp that have been impaled on the tacks. Perfect for dinner.
readingMnemonic: Your house was right next to the swamp and on this side of your house you had many a tack (たく) there to hang things on. Now, on every tack there is skewered a shrimp. The force of the tsunami drove them into the tacks on the side of your house.

meaningMnemonic: A drop of water falls from a bear onto the ground and needs to be wiped up with a towel. Only a teacher or an expert could get away with getting close to this wet bear to wipe up after it.
additionalM:
Hints
The expert is also your teacher, and she's showing you how to clean up after this bear.
additionalR:
Hints
Your teacher assures you this wet sheep is far less dangerous to clean up after than a wet bear. They're the expert, so you should listen and wipe up after that sheep.
readingMnemonic: The teacher tells you to start with something smaller, after all, you're not an expert yet. You have to practice on a wet sheep (し). "I became a wet, dangerous animal expert by starting with sheep, you will too!" your teacher says.

meaningMnemonic: In the morning, if you want your hat to dry, you need to hang it on a tree trunk. In the morning, everything is covered in dew. The grass is wet, the leaves are wet, but the tree trunk isn't wet! It was protected by the rest of the tree, so you can hang your hat there to dry.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture everything early in the morning covered in damp dew. Even your hat is uncomfortably wet. Now walk up to a large tree trunk and touch it—it's dry!
additionalR:
Hints
Now that you think about it, Genghis Khan was the one who taught people that tree trunks stay dry in the morning!
readingMnemonic: You lean against the tree trunk, waiting for your hat to dry, and suddenly you realize Genghis Khan (かん) is on the other side of it. You look around and see that all of the tree trunks around you have Mongols drying their hats under them.

meaningMnemonic: Put your hand over your eye to watch over others.
additionalM:
Hints
You know that way cartoon characters and pirates watch out below them, with their hand shading their eye? That! Now imagine doing that right now.
additionalR:
Hints
Welp, nothing much watching over them will do now. Genghis Khan is probably going to take over your town, so I guess you can watch if you want but... I wouldn't.
readingMnemonic: As you watch over your friends and neighbors you see movement in the distance. Oh no, it's Genghis Khan (かん) and his army!

meaningMnemonic: There are people under a canopy on the street forming their own agency. They're banding together right here in the street, making a new government office!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine them putting together papers, talking to politicians, and standing in the street outside the capitol. They demand for this agency to be formed. They are doing all the correct, legal things to do it too.
additionalR:
Hints
"Whenever you're in a 丁, you're in my territory," she yells, taking out a few agency members with her fists. "You won't be starting any kind of agency here, not on my watch." And she lights it all on fire.
readingMnemonic: This new agency is just starting to make progress when you hear a low rumble... then a screech.

meaningMnemonic: This word has three really important meanings. It's probably best if you remember them all. Let's do this!
additionalM:
Hints
If you're a guest you either have to have the right amount of geoducks, geoducks in framed pictures, or geoducks on your forehead. Otherwise you're a jerk.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the feel of hundreds of gawks. Feel ashamed as they gawk at you. How could you!?
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, if you mess up any of these things, (the amount, the framed pictures, or the forehead tattoo) every other guest will gawk (がく) at you.

meaningMnemonic: The moon shines on your roof in the evening and a snake suddenly appears! Wait, that's not a snake, it's your arm, sticking out from under the roof.
additionalM:
Hints
Arms really look like snakes in the moonlight. Picture it. Your arm is long and shiny, just like a snake.
additionalR:
Hints
Your arms are nude, eh? That's why they look like snakes, you know. You should be more careful.
readingMnemonic: Your arm is exposed to the moon and the outside and you feel a chill. Where are your clothes? Ah, you're nude, eh (うで)?! I guess it is pretty common to sleep in the nude, eh?

meaningMnemonic: You stand in the dirt and see the boundary. The boundary between your home and your neighbors. The boundary between your town and the next. All you have to do to see it is stand in the dirt. It also helps that there is a boundary sign standing in the dirt that you can also see.
additionalM:
Hints
Get off your computer and go stand outside in the dirt and see what boundaries you can see.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself outside of Kyoto. Picture the boundary between you and Kyoto. Now hop over it!
readingMnemonic: The boundary you're looking at is the Kyoto (きょう) boundary. Kyoto is a really famous, important place, so if you think about it, everything could be the boundary between where you are and Kyoto if you just make them really big.

meaningMnemonic: Fire in nature will burn down everything in its path. In nature, there are no firefighters or anyone to contain the fire, so the fire will burn and burn until it has no fuel left to consume.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the fire all around you as it burns. You’re out in nature – the middle of a forest fire. Hear the woods burn and crackle as you feel the heat around you.
additionalR:
Hints
Cry your eyes out as you smell the smell of burning plastic from the nendoroids. Worst. Day. Ever.
readingMnemonic: What is the worst thing that could burn in this fire? Your nendoroid (ねん) collection. You've spent a lot of time and money collecting all these cool and rare and unique nendoroids and now they've all burned in the fire.

meaningMnemonic: You use your fingers at dawn to carry many things. You have to carry yourself out of bed. You have to carry your backpack or purse or laptop bag to school or work. Your fingers have to carry a lot of weight around at dawn.
additionalM:
Hints
Think about your morning routine. You carry yourself into the bathroom and carry a toothbrush into your mouth. You carry your coat and bag out the door.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself carrying a coat and a bag, walking through the rice fields to work, with the hot, dawn sun shining down, making your fingers get tanner and tanner.
readingMnemonic: Once you're carrying everything, and the dawn sun is shining bright, you start getting tan (たん). Especially those fingers you're using to carry things.

meaningMnemonic: If a spirit blesses your older brother it's time to celebrate! This isn't something that happens every day to everyone's older brother. Yours is very good and very lucky. So celebrate with him!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what celebrating would be like. Imagine an older brother too, if you don't actually have one.
additionalR:
Hints
Never celebrate too hard. Otherwise you'll always have to think about the time a celebration spirit shook your brother till his head fell off.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the two of you celebrated too much, and you went a little crazy. The spirit grabbed your brother and shook (しゅく) him. Shook him so hard his head popped off.

meaningMnemonic: The American flag is the reason you need to deliver this package. The flag is inside the package, and you need to deliver it to the president. He lost his old flag, so now it’s up to you to deliver this new one to him. What more of a reason do you need?
additionalM:
Hints
You need to deliver this flag to the president. Imagine yourself running as fast as you can while carrying the parcel in order to get it to him. Your lungs are tired and your legs burn, but you must deliver the flag as soon as possible!
additionalR:
Hints
The world depends on you to do this delivery. If you fail, the United States will be ruined. You have to do it! Deliver that flag now! Run! Run!
readingMnemonic: To deliver this flag is something you just have to do (とど). Need to do. Want to do. There is no one else to do it. This is something only you are equipped to do.

meaningMnemonic: You take your scooter to Korea and everything is different!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine scooting down a street in Korea and seeing how different literally every single thing is compared to what you're used to in Japan.
additionalR:
Hints
Tigger is different in Korea too. For one, he's a white tiger now, and he's, like, really aggressive. Wait, was he always like that?
readingMnemonic: What's also different is that there's a weird tiger bouncing on its tail alongside you yelling that its name is Tigger (ちが). You didn't know Tigger was living in Korea these days. That's definitely different.

meaningMnemonic: When the horns of the king slide down into the construction below he loses distinction. Now the king just looks like everyone else, there's nothing that sets him apart!
additionalM:
Hints
The king's distinction is gone. He isn't special, he isn't different. Without his horns he's like the rest of you plebs.
additionalR:
Hints
I guess the construction worker couldn't distinguish between what he was supposed to saw and the king's horns.
readingMnemonic: The king wants his distinction back so he runs down into the construction site just in time to see his horns getting cut into bits by a saw (さ).

meaningMnemonic: The elephant radical and the elephant kanji are the same. But! This kanji has another meaning: phenomenon. If you were the first person to see an elephant, you'd call it that too.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the first Japanese person to see an elephant. He stops dead in his tracks, points and screams out, "What a phenomenon!"
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the shougun standing over a pit of zombie elephants. None of these are getting out on his watch, letting people believe in such crazy phenomenons.
readingMnemonic: Elephants are great and all, except that when they die they turn into elephant zombies (ぞう). But you never see these zombies because the shougun (しょう) has a special project in place that destroys all elephant bodies when they die.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a flag under the blackjack table that you can kick in order to expand the table. Sometimes you only have a few people playing blackjack so you don’t need to kick the flag at all, and sometimes  there are many people playing blackjack so you need to kick the flag many times in order to expand it to a proper size.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself kicking this flag to see the blackjack table expand. Feel your foot kicking the flag. You’ve kicked it so many times that your leg is sore, but you need to expand the table some more so you keep kicking it. Imagine the blackjack table making that sound Mario makes whenever he gets a mushroom and expands in size.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself kicking the flag ten times. Count it off in your head and imagine each instance up to ten. Any more kicks after ten don’t cause the table to do anything, but it does cause your leg to get sore.
readingMnemonic: The blackjack table does have a limit though of how many times it will expand, and that limit is ten (てん). You can only kick the flag to get the table to expand ten times.

meaningMnemonic: Behind the flag lies a mask—yet another layer of secrecy. You’re standing in front of a crowd, giving a rousing speech. Hiding your face is the flag of your country, and behind that flag you’re also wearing a mask, just in case the flag falls down. The extra layer of secrecy is just to be safe.
additionalM:
Hints
These layers are meant to protect you. We all have layers we hide behind sometimes, you know? You can't be totally transparent with everyone.
additionalR:
Hints
Everyone in the crowd is completely silent, staring at your soul, with all of its layers peeled off.
readingMnemonic: Someone jumps up on stage and starts peeling off your layers! You stand there, first goes the flag, then the mask, then ... your soul (そう) is laid bare. No, literally. You don't have a body, your soul was under that mask. And now it's floating there for all to see.

meaningMnemonic: When you see a spirit you have to look at it. Look at it directly, because if you look away then it could disappear.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the spirit. Look at its shape and into its eyes. Just don't look away.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you have to look at this sheep. Maybe the sheep was projecting the spirit... or maybe it's just a sheep. You'll have to look at it a bit longer to know for sure.
readingMnemonic: You look at the spirit for as long as you can, until you hear a sheep (し) sound. You look away for a second, see the sheep look at you, and when you look back the spirit is gone. Damn!

meaningMnemonic: The king is showing his people how to put a net around a weird zombie by walking around it in a loop.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch as the king loops the net around and around and around the zombie, keeping it completely pinned down.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Genghis Khan looping around and around just like the king is looping around and around this zombie.
readingMnemonic: The king also explains that this loop technique was used by Genghis Khan (かん) when he was conquering cities. He'd loop around the entire place with a net and trap them.

meaningMnemonic: In an attempt to control your clothes, you manufacture a mind control device. This mind control device will allow you to control the mind of your clothes and all that they do. You just need to manufacture it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being able to control your clothes with your mind. What would you have them do? Imagine what you would do with your clothes if you could manufacture something to control them and move them around at will with your mind.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're trying to manufacture a machine that will make sabers and clothes you can use to control them. Soon you'll have a manufactured army of saber-controlling clothes!
readingMnemonic: You manufacture these clothes to control your saber (せい). It's hard to manufacture, you have to do a lot of work, but you manage to make your clothes control your saber. Now you don't need to rely on your hands!

meaningMnemonic: On this scooter, there's an angel with a drop of sweat coming off of it, because it forgot to mention something to you! It seems like it's something important too, since they're sweating so much.
additionalM:
Hints
The angel just visited you, but it forgot to mention something important (probably life-threatening, it's an angel after all), and now you see it scooting at top speeds toward you.
additionalR:
Hints
The angel really should have mentioned ninjutsu earlier. Then maybe you would have gone straight to a dojo to learn instead of falling into a ninjutsu trap yourself. The angel definitely failed its mission.
readingMnemonic: "I forgot to mention, you have to study ninjutsu (じゅつ)!" the angel yells. But it's too late, there are ninjas jumping out of the bushes around you and taking you hostage.

meaningMnemonic: On the ground there's a ceremony where everyone keeps stopping. This stopping ceremony is being performed by the military. They'll march one direction, then stop and turn, then march another direction, then stop again.
additionalM:
Hints
The military really seems to have a thing for stopping a lot during their ceremonies.
additionalR:
Hints
This is a ceremony for celebrating the military so I guess they can drink as much booze as they want, but this seems very strange to you.
readingMnemonic: You look closer at the people in the military and realize that every time they stop they take a drink of booze (ぶ)!

meaningMnemonic: There is a lantern on top of a knife in the dirt. You walk up to take the knife and lantern when you realize it's just a model. It all looked real from far away, but now that you're up close you can see none of it is real.
additionalM:
Hints
Why would anyone make a model that looks like a lantern and a knife sticking into the ground?
additionalR:
Hints
Haven't you seen any of those crazy cakes modeled after things like movies, towns, giants hams, and purses? They're all the rage. Next time you make a cake try to make it look like a model lantern and knife with fake cake dirt and everything.
readingMnemonic: You touch the model and see that it's made of cake (けい)! Someone really into lanterns and knives must have been given this model cake as a birthday present! Though they left it out here so they probably didn't like it.

meaningMnemonic: You have an animal for a husband with horns that are narrow. This animal husband of yours is a goat. A goat with narrow horns. Why is this animal your husband? You’re weird, that’s why.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself married to this animal husband with horns that are narrow. It’s a strange marriage. Listen to the goat making its goat noises as it clomps around your home. Now hug your goat husband and feel its soft fluffy coat against your skin.
additionalR:
Hints
But that doesn’t mean you can’t imagine the semantics. The finer points of the relationship. Go ahead, imagine all the weird stuff that comes with the territory for having a goat as a husband. Use all that weird stuff to remember this kanji and its reading. Want an example? Just imagine the goat doing dishes! Goats don’t have hands! Hahahahaha!!
readingMnemonic: I’m not even going to get into the semantics (せま) of how this weird relationship of yours works. Nope, this reading explanation is on the straight and narrow. Need to know basis. Classified. All that junk. There will be no discussion of the semantics between you and your goat lover.

meaningMnemonic: On your bamboo roof is a bear. It is pulling the bamboo off, because it wants to use it to make a long pipe.
additionalM:
Hints
Bamboo is great for pipes, and the only place for the bear to get it is your roof. So, that's why it's there.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch the bear take away your bamboo. Follow it to Genghis Khan's house. There, the bear installs the pipe in Genghis Khan's bathroom.
readingMnemonic: The pipe will be for Genghis Khan (かん), who would like some pipes for his house.

meaningMnemonic: If you leave a cross on a drunkard's car it's a sign that you'll publish everything if they try to drive. It's basically the universal symbol of, "We're watching you, and we'll publish what you do, so don't drive drunk."
additionalM:
Hints
Open your newspaper in the morning and you can see what's been published about all the drunkards who didn't pay attention to the crosses on their cars. They were all arrested and their stories were published for all to see.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your cyborg, with one of those newsie hats on, publishing stories about all of the bad drunk drivers so they never do it again. It's using its metal and meat arms to publish multiple stories at once.
readingMnemonic: You need someone to publish all these stories, so you get your cyborg (さい) to do it. It can keep an eye on all the drunkards cars through the special crosses you put on their cars. And the cyborg is a great editor, which is a plus.

meaningMnemonic: You have to use two axes to open these shellfish. That seems like overkill, but it is necessary. These particular shellfish are of very high quality meaning they won't open so easily.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the highest quality shellfish you've ever seen. They're hard, smooth, and basically impenetrable.
additionalR:
Hints
I guess your shih tzu knows good quality shellfish too. :(
readingMnemonic: You finally get all of the shellfish open and you're admiring their quality, when your shih tzu (しつ) jumps up on the table and gobbles them down. NO! You try to chase after the little dog, but it's too late. They're gone.

meaningMnemonic: When dawn reaches this village it increases in quantity. That's right. Every morning the amount of people or animals living here goes up by at least one.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture dawn, the sun rising, the birds chirping, and the screams of a new born baby rise in the village. Or Maybe it's a new sheep! Or a new hat that someone just finished making.
additionalR:
Hints
When every dawn brings a new amount of people, those new people are going to need that same amount of row boats.
readingMnemonic: Today's dawn has brought with it an increase in the quantity of row boats! Aww, aren't they cute? Look at all of the new row boats lined up together. They all have their own sets of oars too.

meaningMnemonic: If you're anti-shellfish, then you won't mind if I sell them all. You don't want them in your house anyway!
additionalM:
Hints
if you're serious about being anti-shellfish then you should sell all the ones you have, or let me do it at least.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture me (hi) selling all of your shellfish to Han Solo as you stand there with your arms crossed. Han just shakes his head at you and continues to toss them onto his space ship.
readingMnemonic: I'm going to sell all of our shellfish to Han (はん) Solo. He isn't anti-shellfish like you, he knows how to turn a profit too!

meaningMnemonic: A leader is always together with their servant. The servant is their constant companion, always following close behind the leader, offering them hot towels and bottled water.
additionalM:
Hints
Try to picture the servant without the leader... you can't! The servant and the leader are always together.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the servant enjoying tea and cherry blossoms in きょうと with their family as the leader sits patiently off to the side. What a good relationship these two have!
readingMnemonic: Once a year, when the servant wants to go home to きょうと, the leader follows. The servant isn't just there for the leader, they're companions, they support each other at all times. Even if that means heading home to きょうと to see the fam.

meaningMnemonic: The door leading to the moon can be broken down with one’s shoulder. It’s not a very sturdy door to the moon, so it’s quite easy to drop your shoulder and ram it open.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself smashing through this door using your shoulder and seeing the moon on the other side. Hear the splintering of wood as your shoulder crashes through the door and feel the impact with your body.
additionalR:
Hints
Now the weird man is inspecting your shoulder really closely and he keeps muttering "catapult powers" under his breath. It's very unsettling, but he's kind of right. A shoulder works just like the mechanism that winds up a catapult.
readingMnemonic: "Wow, your shoulder is just like my catapult (かた)!" you hear someone shout. As you turn you're just in time to see a man catapulting through his own moon door!

meaningMnemonic: What might cause a tree to slide down a jet would be if its stocks and shares took a dive in the market. This tree was on a jet for an important investor meeting when it got the news that its stocks and shares had just plummeted. Being very upset, the tree got up and got on the emergency slide out of the jet and plummeted into the ground just like his stocks and shares.
additionalM:
Hints
Visualize this tree sliding out of the jet and falling to his doom. As he falls, visualize red lines falling alongside him to represent the stocks and shares. Hear the shrill whistle of them speeding through the air to the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
Listen to each of these things impact the ground and see each individual mushroom cloud appear around them. KABOOM! KABOOM! KABOOM!
readingMnemonic: Once the tree hits the ground with his stocks and his shares, the impact creates a large KABOOM (かぶ)! Stocks hit the ground - KABOOM! Shares! KABOOM! Tree! KABOOOOOOM~!

meaningMnemonic: If, at a certain angle, you approach an insect, you’ll be able to touch it without it noticing. Most of the time, insects will run away from you when you try and touch them, but if you do so from the right angle, the insect will have no idea.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself approaching this insect from a sneaky and stealthy angle. Now touch it. What does it feel like? Smooth? Hard? Fuzzy? Feel the insect in your mind as you touch it.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel this electrical shock to your system as you touch the lightning bug. This discourages you from ever touching another insect again. You don’t enjoy the shock.
readingMnemonic: Uh oh, looks like this particular insect is a lightning bug so when you touch it you get a shock (しょく). Did you know that lightning bugs contain bazillions of volts inside them? Well they do, and if you touch one, you get a shock. A very big shock.

meaningMnemonic: What does a car and the Death Star have in common? They're both used to transport people and things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine stuffing a bunch of Stormtroopers in your car so you can transport them across the country. Well the Death Star can transport even more Stormtroopers, faster, and through space!
additionalR:
Hints
It's easy to transport a yurt even without a car or the Death Star.
readingMnemonic: Right now you and the Death Star are transporting yurts (ゆ). They're the universe's #1 best transportable homes!

meaningMnemonic: You're flying a helicopter and you see a woman in the moon light touching her waist. She has both hands on her waist, like she's Wonder Woman or something. But it's the middle of the night. What is she doing?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine flying your helicopter closer to the woman, it's not so hard because you have lots of moon light to see in, and try to see why she's touching her waist.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how cozy your waist would be if you tied a nice warm blanket around it.
readingMnemonic: As you get closer you realize her waist looks weird and... puffy? You bring the helicopter down and see that the woman's waist looks incredibly cozy (こし)! She has a blanket balled up and tied around her waist, she's holding it there with her hand, probably because it's cold out at night. But even with just her waist covered, she looks so warm and cozy!

meaningMnemonic: If you could just get your soul to open the window to shellfish, you'll grow accustomed to them sooner or later! I know shellfish are a bit of an acquired taste, but if you don't open that window, you'll never like them!
additionalM:
Hints
Close your eyes and picture your soul. Now your soul is opening a little window inside of you that is the perfect size for shellfish of all kinds. Hopefully with exposure and acceptance you'll grow accustomed to them.
additionalR:
Hints
Force yourself to get accustomed to shellfish like Genghis Khan, then maybe you'll rule most of the planet someday.
readingMnemonic: You'll need to become accustomed to eating shellfish if you want to grow up big and strong like Genghis Khan (かん). He didn't have shellfish growing up either you know, he had to grow accustomed to their taste too, but look how successful he was!

meaningMnemonic: The flag is old but that doesn't mean it's not still alive. This is a living flag, and it gets old just like other living things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the old flag with a face and mouth and eyes and nose... it talks and listens and everything else. It's a flag that's alive D:
additionalR:
Hints
Not as cool as a real relic, it's put in this dumb Little Kyoto shrine that's basically just a tourist attraction. Eh, whatever.
readingMnemonic: The flag that is old and alive is actually a Buddhist relic (that's why it's alive, in fact ... and old!). But, it's a really dumb relic, so it's put in Little Kyoto (きょ).

meaningMnemonic: Your scooter's been stolen by a wolverine, who's now getting water all over it. You need to apprehend that wolverine!
additionalM:
Hints
Not only did the wolverine steal your scooter, but it is getting your poor scooter all wet by riding it through puddles. Now you and all the cops are chasing the wolverine down on police scooters and you're going to apprehend it!
additionalR:
Hints
It's a really nice tie you use to apprehend the wolverine, so even though it's struggling and fighting, it can't get away.
readingMnemonic: You catch up with the wolverine and apprehend it by tying it down with the tie (たい) from around your neck!

meaningMnemonic: You have to fly in a helicopter and use a jackhammer to punch your ballot. The helicopter gets you far away from prying eyes, and the jackhammer makes you really try for whoever you're voting for on that thing. It's foolproof!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to fill out your ballot while flying in a helicopter and using only a jackhammer to do it. Do you think you could do it? Do you think you could do it AND vote for the right person?
additionalR:
Hints
You're starting to think this method of filling out ballots is rigged.
readingMnemonic: While using the jackhammer on the ballot, the helicopter pilot keeps yelling “Heyo (ひょう), don't mess up! Heyo! Watch out, don't let me see!” as he flies the helicopter all over the place.

meaningMnemonic: You see a mantis sitting on a flag and you know for a fact that it does not belong there. Insects should be in trees and on the ground. Not on flags. Insects belong in the wild!
additionalM:
Hints
Look at that mantis, pretending it belongs here. What are you gonna do about it?
additionalR:
Hints
Your Bosozoku life has prepared you for this moment. Those who don't belong, shall be punished, you think to yourself.
readingMnemonic: Luckily for you, and unluckily for this mantis who doesn't belong on your flag, you're a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member, and you don't take crap from nobody. You climb the flagpole, punch the mantis and yell, "YOU DON'T BELONG HERE!"

meaningMnemonic: Use your fingers to grab this guy's foot and catch him! Not physically though, you do grab his foot, but you close your eyes, and catch the idea of him in your mind just by touching your fingers to his foot.
additionalM:
Hints
You don't really like the idea of touching your fingers to someone's foot, so you do it ever so slightly, and only catch the gist of what it's like.
additionalR:
Hints
You wipe your eyes and look up, seeing that the person running from you is wearing socks with little pictures of the Torah on them. You were able to catch that in your brain but not the person. You must have touched those Torah socks and not his foot. You've been tricked!
readingMnemonic: As you touch his foot, you catch a glimpse of the Torah (とら) in your mind. Suddenly, you are able to grasp and understand every single thing written in the Torah. You fall to the ground.

meaningMnemonic: At your wedding you use your fingers to catch the wedding rings. And to catch the bouquet. And to catch the rice that everyone is throwing at you, ow, ow, hey stop! Weddings are really more about catching things than they are about whoever is standing across from you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being at a wedding and getting to catch a ton of things in your fingers.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself grumpily hoeing all the things you couldn't catch, and the dirt under it, and putting it into a big dumpster.
readingMnemonic: You're having a good time catching things until it's cleanup time and someone throws a hoe (ほ) at you. First of all, ow again, that was your face. Second, this is your wedding. You aren't supposed to have to hoe it all up. You're supposed to drop everything you caught and leave!

meaningMnemonic: A leader with a stick, a hook, and an arrow is able to change the climate and weather. Not just the type of climate that causes sunny and rainy days though, the political climate too, because they're a political candidate too.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this leader twirling his stick around with his hook so quickly it changes the actual weather. Then he shoots it into the sky with an arrow, changing the actual climate itself.
additionalR:
Hints
Ask こういち why he's changing the climate. He says more people do their WaniKani reviews when it's raining, so he decided to create climate change to make it more dangerous to go outside. "This way, people will stay indoors and do their WaniKani reviews," he tells you.
readingMnemonic: Who is this climate and weather-changing candidate leader with the hook, stick, and arrow? It's none other than こういち.

meaningMnemonic: The criminal that stole your car was your comrade! You thought the two of you were friends, but you were probably wrong.
additionalM:
Hints
Just because someone is your comrade doesn't mean they actually like you. Don't let your guard down and let them near your car.
additionalR:
Hints
Comrade, what the heck
I want to get my car back
I thought we were friends.
readingMnemonic: You feel really weird about this whole situation so you write your comrade a haiku (はい). It's really all you can do, since your car is long gone.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a tsunami coming and your older brother is in no condition to escape. Your older brother has brittle bone syndrome so there’s no way he’ll be able to escape the tsunami in time in his condition.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your poor brother and the condition he is in. His glass bones and paper skin make it impossible for him to move very fast. Imagine the sad face he makes when he realizes his fate.
additionalR:
Hints
This is also, incidentally, where the tsunami's condition is the worst, so you better get to きょうと quick!
readingMnemonic: His condition gets worse and you have to travel all the way to his home in きょうと to get him out.

meaningMnemonic: If you poop on the roots of a building, the sound will echo all the way through the building, and each and every person in there will know what you did.
additionalM:
Hints
Hear the poop echo. You know what a poop usually sounds like, now imagine that sound again, but louder and with an echo. How could anyone not notice?
additionalR:
Hints
Welp. きょうと knows you pooped. That will echo through your memories for the rest of your life. I hope you're happy.
readingMnemonic: The echo doesn't stop there, this building's roots extend throughout the entire city of きょうと. The echo reverberates and soon everyone in きょうと is listening, horrified, to your poop.

meaningMnemonic: If you mix different types of power you'll produce something effective.
additionalM:
Hints
It doesn't matter what power you mix, because all power is strong. No matter what you use this mixed power on, it will be effective. Imagine some situations where you mix power with power.
additionalR:
Hints
こういちs punch attack was super effective against that Pikurchort.
readingMnemonic: The most effective mix of two powers is two こういちs. Take one, mix it with another, and you have something with immeasurable power. You use it to attack that animal-like creature. It's super effective!

meaningMnemonic: Touch your fingers to your friend to extract their friendship. Extract it with a high five. Extract it with a back rub. Extract it with an, "Oh no, there's some lint on your shirt, let me get that for you."
additionalM:
Hints
REMINDER: You are not allowed to touch any of your friends without their permission. If they say no to extracting, then you don't get to touch. End of story.
additionalR:
Hints
REMINDER: If someone asks you to extract their clothes to help them be nude, you don't have to do it unless you also want to! Choices and respect, people!
readingMnemonic: Your friend looks you in the eye and says, I want you to extract my clothes. I want to be nude (ぬ). Now you have to use your fingers on your friend to extract their clothes to help them be nude.

meaningMnemonic: The fish and sheep are very fresh here. This is a great place to get fresh fish and fresh sheep. I kid you not.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine eating this fresh fish and fresh sheep. It’s the freshest you’ve ever tasted. Taste it on your tongue and experience how fresh it is.
additionalR:
Hints
Can you imagine eating a fresh centaur? How weird would that be? Half of it is human-like, so you’d be like, a half cannibal. Weird, huh?
readingMnemonic: This place also serves fresh centaur (せん), but that’s just weird. Centaur is endangered and you don’t believe in eating endangered things. Even if they are incredibly fresh.

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami hits these flowers they'll both become full of water. Tsunamis carry a lot of water, definitely enough to make both of these flowers full.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture both of these little flowers, happily swaying in the breeze. Then the tsunami comes, leaves, and you look back and their little cup-heads are full to the brim with water.
additionalR:
Hints
Soon you have full color pages, full of stories about both of these tsunami-filled flowers and their adventures together. And when you're done, your heart is full as well. Awwww.
readingMnemonic: As you stare at the full flowers, you decide to write a manga (まん) about them. Your head is full of manga ideas!

meaningMnemonic: A beggar lies sprawled on the ground so you give him some money. You feel bad for the beggar on the ground, so that’s why you decided to give him something.
additionalM:
Hints
See the beggar on the ground. He’s writhing in agony and moaning for help. Imagine how sad and pitiful he looks.
additionalR:
Hints
Now watch as the beggar plays with the yo-yo you just gave him. He’s actually pretty good with it. See the beggar doing insane tricks with his new yo-yo as passersby give him change for his impressive yo-yo performance.
readingMnemonic: When you set the money down next to the beggar he shouts, “No! I want a yo-yo (よ)!” so you go to the corner store and buy him a yo-yo with the money instead. You give the yo-yo to the beggar and he looks very happy.

meaningMnemonic: Somebody got dirt on your fingers and dirt on your toes so you're going to hang them upside-down and slap them with your dirty extremities.
additionalM:
Hints
If someone got dirt all up in your finger and toe business wouldn't you want to hang them too?
additionalR:
Hints
Don't get dirt on me, buddy. Or I'll hang you upside-down and hit you with my car. Then you'll be sorry.
readingMnemonic: You have this person hanging upside-down but they don't seem to be suffering enough, so you hit them with your car (か). No mercy.

meaningMnemonic: Behind a building, a cleat-wearing wolverine is holding his heart and trying to hide.
additionalM:
Hints
You know the phrase, "You can run, but you can't hide?" This wolverine can't run anymore so he's trying to hide (even though he knows it probably won't work).
additionalR:
Hints
Lucky wolverine! Inns are good for hiding. The staff isn't supposed to give out his room number, and there are tons of different rooms for him to hide in.
readingMnemonic: The wolverine looks up at the building he's trying to hide behind and sees it's an inn (いん).

meaningMnemonic: A tree grows next to a greenhouse enclosing an imitation of the tree. The imitation greenhouse tree wants to be big and impressive like the tree outside, so it does its very best imitation of a real tree.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this greenhouse tree struggle to grow big and strong like the wild tree outside. Hear its leaves shake and timber creak. How cute.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the little tree moaning at its pitiful imitation of a real tree. The greenhouse tree sounds very sad and you actually start to feel bad for it. Moan along with the tree in sympathy.
readingMnemonic: The greenhouse tree realizes that its imitation will never be as good as the real thing. When it realizes this, the tree moans (も) aloud. The tree is still kinda tiny, so the moan isn’t very loud, but it is still pretty strange to witness. Speaking of witnesses, Bobo (ぼ) the clown sees this greenhouse tree moaning and decides to take it for his next clown show. Surely this miniature moaning tree can be worked into Bobo's next clown act.

meaningMnemonic: Now your mouth can include more words than ever before! With our new and improved “Mouth Now!” program, your mouth will include more words than you ever thought possible!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how your repertoire of new words will impress all your friends and family. Don’t include them on your secret that you used the Mouth Now! program, just feel super smart with all the words you now know.
additionalR:
Hints
Since you bought the program, you also got the Gandhi books included with your order. Imagine yourself reading them and learning all about non-violent resistance. Fascinating.
readingMnemonic: If you buy now, we’ll also include a handful of books by Gandhi (がん) himself. Gandhi didn’t use our program, but we’re sure if he’d had the opportunity to, he would have used it. So buy now, and get the words of Gandhi in your hands as well as your mouth!

meaningMnemonic: Be careful what you say in public, otherwise you might face a lawsuit. People will sue you for just about anything these days, so you really need to watch what you say in public, otherwise you might find yourself with a lawsuit on your hands.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of all the things you could say in public that could get you stuck dealing with a lawsuit.
Oh my gosh! How dare you think those things?! You're lucky you didn't say them out loud in public, or I'd file a lawsuit against you myself!
additionalR:
Hints
You better hope what you said wasn't about the Shougun, or he's really going to use this lawsuit to destroy you.
readingMnemonic: Any and all lawsuits need to be brought before the Shougun (しょう). Oh, you thought you'd get a judge or a jury? Nope, the Shougun decides your fate.

meaningMnemonic: A building's roots will limit the things under and around it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the roots of a building: metal beams going into the ground. Now imagine trying to build something like a subway under there. It's not good! The building limits what can go under it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Genji tunneling under a building where a cute lady lives. He's trying to get in, but the building roots limit how far he can dig. No! Now how will he steal a secret kiss?!
readingMnemonic: The person who hates these limits more than anyone else is Genji (げん). He wants to be able to tunnel under buildings, sneak in, smooch ladies, and sneak back out. But all the building root limits make that impossible!

meaningMnemonic: A moon who stays in bed all day every day will soon become obese. A healthy moon needs movement and exercise to stay fit and not become obese. If a moon stays in bed all day, they’ll be sure to grow obese over time.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this moon in bed, slowly getting bigger and bigger, becoming more obese every day. Hear the sound of the bed creaking and cracking as the moon grows larger and larger.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine super obese moon the super hero. His powers are rolling and sitting on things. See super obese moon in his little cape and marvel at the fact that he’s even capable of movement.
readingMnemonic: But once the moon gets obese enough, he turns into a super hero (ひ)! He is, super obese moon! The most obese hero in all of history.

meaningMnemonic: Music beans make farts plentiful. And lucky for you, music beans themselves are also plentiful, so you can eat plenty of them to power your musical bean toots.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine dancing to your own plentiful bean music as you gorge on beans.
additionalR:
Hints
Be polite! Keep your plentiful farts at home.
readingMnemonic: Your music bean farts are too plentiful to leave your home (ほう). If you tried to leave your home you'd definitely fart all over people outside, so you keep your plentiful farts to yourself.

meaningMnemonic: A husband marries a husband while the sun goes down and the men replace their solitary lives with one of everlasting companionship. Instead of one husband and one wife, we have two husbands here. They shed their lives of bachelorhood and replace it with one of monogamy.
additionalM:
Hints
See these two husbands as the sun sets under them. Listen to them each saying their vows, expressing how they could never replace one another.
additionalR:
Hints
See the husbands driving off into the sunset in their car. Hear the engine rumble as the car speeds off into the distance.
readingMnemonic: After the ceremony, the husband and his husband get in a car (か) and drive off into the sunset. They’ll never be able to replace this memory with anything. Truly it is the happiest day of these husbands’ lives.

meaningMnemonic: The sun rises over the capital building, creating a breathtaking scene. The sun is so bright and warm as it crests over the capital building. It’s quite the scene to behold.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this scene in your mind. Squint as the sun shines in your eyes and feel its warmth as it rises up and over the capital building.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this scene again, but this time the sun is making the capital look like a big, fancy cake. Now take a bite!
readingMnemonic: The only way to make this scene better would be to add cake (けい). Now that you think about it... as you look at the scene in front of you, the capital kind of looks like a big cake.

meaningMnemonic: A gladiator only sees himself (oneself) on those big scrolls they advertise the fights with. Gladiators don't get mirrors and there are no cameras or videos yet. The scroll drawings are all they get of themselves.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being a gladiator. Your big fight is coming and you're the  main event! Look at the scroll for the fight and try to find yourself.
additionalR:
Hints
After a while of showing off the scroll, someone finally pulls you aside and says, "That guy isn't you, it's the real Genghis Khan. He's coming to the event and he's against you. So. Nice knowing you."
Oh.
readingMnemonic: When you look at the scroll you realize... you look just like Genghis Khan (かん)! You excitedly fist pump and start showing everyone how cool you are.

meaningMnemonic: You want to get your fingers on the humble stool, so you dedicate your life to search for it. Wait, the humble stool? You know, like the holy grail or the ark of the covenant, but it's called the humble stool. It's from some bible or something, I promise.
additionalM:
Hints
Now you have to search through a bunch of religious texts for this humble stool with your fingers. Don't go too fast and get paper cuts!
additionalR:
Hints
You dedicated your soul to searching, and now that your soul is free from its body, you can continue the search until you find it!
readingMnemonic: You search and you search and, unfortunately, you spend your entire life searching and you die without finding the humble stool. But don't worry, your soul (そう) comes back and now you get to continue your search but with afterlife powers!

meaningMnemonic: A lifeguard will choose a tree to set up the station where he'll care for the people on the beach and in the water. Trees provide the shade lifeguards need to take care of half-drowned kids and grannies with sand stuck in their bathing suits. That's why they set up their care stations here.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch the lifeguard walk around the beach. He needs to pick a nice big tree for his set up, so he can provide the best care possible.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine こういち setting up a care station. You hope you don't get in trouble in the water so you don't have to see how good he is at caring for people.
Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.
readingMnemonic: You look closer at the set up and realize the lifeguard is こういち! You know he teaches Japanese but... is こういち really qualified to care for people like this?

meaningMnemonic: The sun rises over the capital, shines down on your hair, and casts a long shadow on the ground in front of you.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the heat of the sun on your back as you look down over your capital, your long hair blowing over your shoulder. Your shadow stretches in front of you and it's honestly pretty impressive.
additionalR:
Hints
What do you do? Keep standing here, admiring the view and casting this shadow on the acorn. Or do you move and let the acorn grow, becoming a tree that can cast its own shadow on your capital.
readingMnemonic: In the shade from your shadow you see a small acorn (えい) laying on the ground. You're about to reach down and pick it up when you realize that your shadow is keeping this little acorn from growing up big and strong.

meaningMnemonic: A thread is mixed all around and begins to strangle you.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine thread everywhere, mixing in with everything. It's all around, and no matter where you go you get more and more caught in this thread. Eventually it tightens because you're trying to escape, and you feel yourself having trouble breathing. Imagine the moment when you realize you're getting strangled.
additionalR:
Hints
In your final moments before you are totally strangled, you think you see a little thread come out of his butt. "I should have done my WaniKani reviews" is your last thought.
readingMnemonic: As you are strangled you see who set this trap. (What else could it be, with all this thread everywhere?) It is こういち, who just watches you as you lose consciousness, tapping his fingers together.

meaningMnemonic: You say you have an axe with a drop of blood on it. You hit someone with that axe and now they're going to sue you. That drop of blood on your axe is pretty incriminating, which is why they have enough of a case to sue you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being unable to stop yourself from saying "I have the axe with the drop on it!" and the recently axed person jumps out from behind a bush and shouts, "Aha! I'm gonna sue you!"
additionalR:
Hints
The person you axed cries and tries desperately to find their blood on the axe so they can keep suing you properly. You hold the soap behind your back and cackle.
readingMnemonic: You want to sue them back so you clean the axe with some soap (そ). "Your honor," you say in court, "I don't see any drops of blood, I countersue!"

meaningMnemonic: There is a spirit at your wedding. It's there as a supplement to the guests because not enough people came.
additionalM:
Hints
It's weird that you supplemented your wedding guests with a spirit or two, but even if you hadn't invited them, they may have showed up anyway.
additionalR:
Hints
Maybe you should supplement your wedding with other things next time... instead of spirits and garden hoes.
readingMnemonic: Along with the spirits to supplement your wedding guests, you made everyone carry a hoe (ほ). That way no one had to bring a date, they carry a garden hoe as a supplement and no one feels bad about being dateless. Everyone is!

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami carries your yurt and you on a stool under it away. You are now in transit.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being carried away on your stool by the tsunami, with your entire yurt floating around you too. You're both in transit... to somewhere. You don't know where though.
additionalR:
Hints
You hope the tsunami's water will drop you off somewhere nice. Somewhere it's easy to jump on a different kind of mass transit, to get back home again.
readingMnemonic: The transit of yourself and your yurt home is due to the water (わた). This is water transit.

meaningMnemonic: You stand with another woman and, with your fingers, adjoin yourselves together. You are united, you are one.
additionalM:
Hints
Look around you. Other women are adjoining their fingers and standing with you. There's hundreds, no, thousands of you standing together.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a bunch of women protesting together. They're holding hands in sets, adjoined together.
readingMnemonic: All of the women who are now adjoining together are in sets (せつ). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison.

meaningMnemonic: A leaf has to do the same task again and again. Grow out of a tree, change color, fall to the ground, get absorbed back into the tree, then start all over again.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the tasks a leaf has to do in its lifetime again and again.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a leaf sawing itself off of a tree. Then picture it again. Now picture Bill Nye pointing to it and saying, "This leaf is a cyborg. See how it has little robot parts, allowing it to do this again and again?"
readingMnemonic: Once again the leaf picks up a saw (さ) and cuts itself off of the tree at the end of fall, like some kind of invincible cyborg (さい).

meaningMnemonic: There once was an animal with an insect friend who felt very alone unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this animal and this insect. Let’s say it’s a flea and a dog. Imagine them going everywhere together. To the park, getting ice cream, even the drive in movie theater. They’re inseparable.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this animal with the insect on his head doing a Sudoku. See the insect hopping around on the animals head shouting answers and suggestions into the animal’s ear. How cute.
readingMnemonic: One activity that the animal can never do alone is solve Sudoku (どく) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team.

meaningMnemonic: On the grass near a rice paddy sits a creeper that is some sort of a dog beast, a vicious animal. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this beast creeping, low to the ground, in the grass around the rice paddy. It's got its eyes on you. Uh oh.
additionalR:
Hints
All beasts have something they're trying to protect. In this case, it's some beastly jewels.
readingMnemonic: The beast is guarding its precious jewels (じゅう), which it buried in the grass or the rice paddy somewhere. If you don't want the beast to think you're coming to steal those jewels, you better keep your distance.

meaningMnemonic: You take some flowers and some fruit and you make a cake out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this cake you have made. It’s majestic. Now taste some of it. It is one great tasting cake. Imagine yourself eating the best cake in all of ever.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the roar of the car engine as you get splattered in the face with the cake. Wipe it off of your face just in time to see the car speeding off into the distance. Also, recall that this kanji shares a reading with the similar kanji, 果.
readingMnemonic: You’re standing back, admiring your cake when you hear a car (か) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car!

meaningMnemonic: They say using a measurement device (like a ruler) is a good way to chastise someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being chastised with a measurement device. Think how horrible it would be getting hit on your knuckles, your nose, or the back of your head. It would be awful. Imagine this experience.
additionalR:
Hints
How could you say something in English while you're in とうきょう?! After you went to all the trouble to learn all this kanji and Japanese? Geez, we almost think you deserve to be chastised...
readingMnemonic: You're being chastised because you tried to say something in English in とうきょう. Everyone around you slowly turned around, eyes aflame and rulers in hand, ready to chastise you for uttering those forbidden words.

meaningMnemonic: The old winter is to blame for today's circumstance. It is the reason things are bad now.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a poor, broken town. And, imagine the mayor of a town telling their people that things are bad because of that bad old winter. "It's to blame for our circumstance!" he yells.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your kid character walking through town, using their super powers to destroy buildings and rot food.
readingMnemonic: In reality, this circumstance was actually caused by a single 子 (こ), though. This kid went through town, destroying everything in their path.

meaningMnemonic: Your new car doesn’t mix well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark contrast to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this garage of yours with a sea of white cars. Now there is a new car that really sticks out like a sore thumb. Imagine yourself looking out over your cars and seeing this wacky car practically jumping out at you.
additionalR:
Hints
See yourself driving around in this peacock car. Hear the engine purr as strangers jeer and yell at you. This car sure does get a lot of attention, doesn’t it?
readingMnemonic: What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a peacock (かく). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark contrast to like, every other car out there.

meaningMnemonic: In your warehouse you use your knife to create. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create.
additionalM:
Hints
What do you create in your warehouse? Picture all the different things you could create in your mind.
additionalR:
Hints
When you create something your soul is happy! It's good for you, you know?
readingMnemonic: When you create it's good for your soul (そう). It's so freeing, in fact, that when you get really into your creating, sometimes you'd swear your soul was floating a little bit outside of your body. But every time you notice, it sinks back down. Hmm.

meaningMnemonic: "A scooter!" you announce. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would create.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being at a maker's contest. Each person has to announce loudly what they'll create, then they have to create it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the scooter you created with a zombie on it. It's a perfect place for the zombie to get stuck and scooted off into nowhere.
readingMnemonic: But, a scooter has been created before. What is different about yours? The scooter you will create is specifically designed to keep zombies (ぞう) busy.

meaningMnemonic: You loiter around your master until he departs. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself loitering around your master’s fancy mansion. You’re pretending to dust things off, but you’re actually just waiting for him to depart.
additionalR:
Hints
Your master has departed! You are the 王 now!
readingMnemonic: Finally, it's time for your master to depart and he calls to you and says, "You are the 王 (おう) of the house now. Take care of everything while I'm gone."

meaningMnemonic: The "Cliff of Ten Thousand Power" is where you go if you want to be encouraged.
additionalM:
Hints
If you can get to the top of the cliff, it will use its "ten thousand power" to encourage you.
additionalR:
Hints
A cliff is encouraging you to buy a ray gun for some reason. This is not the encouragement you expected, but it is encouragement nonetheless. You go back down the cliff and immediately buy a ray gun.
readingMnemonic: When you get there, it does encourage you. The cliff says "Hey, I encourage you to buy a ray (れい) gun."

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami that is white, traveling in the direction of winter is a fierce and violent force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this white tsunami, more violent and fierce than any other tsunami you’ve ever seen, coming toward you. It’s very frightening. Feel the cold wetness it brings to your skin.
additionalR:
Hints
"Geecckkkiiiiii!!!" you scream in horror, as he's thrown about by the fierce, winter tsunami. You have to close your eyes. You can't watch Gecki go.
readingMnemonic: The tsunami is too fierce, too violent, and before you realize what's happening, Gecki (げき), your beloved gecko, is lifted up and carried off into the air.

meaningMnemonic: The fortune radical and the fortune kanji are exactly the same! But it also means occupy as well, so don’t forget that. Fortune and occupy both occupy the same radical.
additionalM:
Hints
Just remember that this kanji also means occupy and you’ll be just fine.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting your fortune told by a centaur fortune teller. Do you trust this mythical beast to know your future? Watch him manipulate his crystal ball as his hooves stomp the ground beneath him.
readingMnemonic: To occupy some free time you have, you go and get your fortune told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a centaur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!

meaningMnemonic: There's a building standing in the way of the next chapter in your life, and it's hindering you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this huge, tall building standing directly in the way. You peer around the other side and there is a book floating in the air that says "Chapter 5: Success and Happiness." Dang, you really want to get over there to that part of your life.
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun wants to hinder you and your life. He wants you to have to work harder so you become better, faster, and stronger than anyone else. Hindering you is his way of making sure you don't take the easy way out in life.
readingMnemonic: Someone put this building here specifically to hinder you. They knew you were close to the next chapter of your life, and they wanted to hinder you really good. And there they are, sitting on a throne smirking. It's the Shougun (しょう).

meaningMnemonic: Your ego... it's totally out of control. I mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's me. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.
additionalM:
Hints
Just keep going with this sentence about the ego. You can't stop, because really it's your ego that's out of control. That's I when you're saying it.
additionalR:
Hints
You're just destroying the ego of that other guy. "Why?" you ask? "Because I am the boss here. And you are the baby. Ego things."
readingMnemonic: I am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says "ga (が) ga ga ga!"

meaningMnemonic: A loitering mountain king in the winter is an indication or sign of something to come.
additionalM:
Hints
We don't want to focus too much on what the indication / sign actually is, though, because it will take away from the indication part (which we want to remember). So, focus on the fact that this is some kind of indication that's important, but you don't know what that indication means or is... because we'll use that with the reading.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine an announcer watching the loitering mountain king, "There he is... and it's still winter. We all know what that means. It's a sign that Mrs. Chou will be coming out of hibernation soon." Then, you can imagine her bursting forth from the mountain, running down her street.
readingMnemonic: When you spot a loitering mountain king in the winter, you know it's an indication that soon Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will appear. It's like a Groundhog's Day kind of situation, but instead it means Mrs. Chou is about to come out, perhaps early for the season.

meaningMnemonic: There are fingers reaching towards you asking you to accept to instruct them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself instructing a class full of knowledge hungry little kids. They reach out with their fingers to accept the truth you bring to them.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself instructing little kids how to punch the straw into small juice boxes. Hold it right-side-up! Don't squeeze too hard! Don't punch it through the other side! No! Don't bite the box! Instructing is hard!
readingMnemonic: "Yes! I will instruct you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small juice (じゅ) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small).

meaningMnemonic: You hold gold fins in your mouth while shopping for pencil lead at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having these gold fins in your mouth. Taste the metal as your tongue runs over them.
additionalR:
Hints
Lead poisoning, huh? What a way for everything to end...
readingMnemonic: You pay for your lead but the cashier puts it in your mouth where the gold fins were and... everything ends (えん).

meaningMnemonic: A broken car sits in a building. You need to get rid of it, so you mail it.
additionalM:
Hints
You just put some postage on it and watch the mail carrier take it away like any other piece of mail.
additionalR:
Hints
You figure youths don't have cars anymore, so they could use one. Ugh, youths these days and their ride share apps.
readingMnemonic: Who did you address this broken car mail to? You sent it to the youths (ゆう) of the world.

meaningMnemonic: In a gold cross, you see a needle sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this golden cross in your head. Why do you suppose there’s this needle stuck in it? You try to pull it out but you can’t. Envision yourself straining, trying to get the thing out.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a needle sticking into your shin. It hurts a ton. How would you try to get it out?
readingMnemonic: You're about to give up on the needle when it pops out and flies directly into your shin (しん). Ouch! Now you're desperately trying to pull the needle out of your shin, but it really won't budge this time. Maybe you should have minded your own business.

meaningMnemonic: If you see someone loitering around with horns on their head you'd be correct to obey and accompany them.
additionalM:
Hints
First of all, this could be really fun. Second of all, if this person is a demon or something, you should really just obey them or they could curse you. What's the worst that could happen?!
additionalR:
Hints
You stole those jewels together and now you're an accomplice for accompanying him! You better hide those jewels!!
readingMnemonic: If you obey the horned man you'll end up with a ton of jewels (じゅう)!

meaningMnemonic: On the moon, it’s easy to turn a pig into pork. The low gravity of the moon makes the whole process much easier and cost efficient. Soon, all the pig farming will be done on the moon and there will never be a pork shortage ever again.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine going to a pig farm/restaurant on the moon. You’re in a space suit, eating some space pork. It’s delicious. Imagine the best pork you’ve ever had. This is better than that.
additionalR:
Hints
Butter and pork. A match made in heaven! Imagine yourself scarfing down this buttered pork by the pound. You’re stuffed, but you have to eat more. It’s soooo gooood.
readingMnemonic: At this particular pig restaurant, they have a secret ingredient that goes onto their pork. Lots and lots of butter (ぶた). Okay, so it’s not that big of a secret. But boy is it delicious. Mmm, butter.

meaningMnemonic: You loiter around a black hole, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to restore mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine loitering around near (but not too near!) the black hole waiting for it to finish so you can restore the galaxy.
additionalR:
Hints
Maybe if you yell f**k you enough things will be restored. Ha. No. Everything's gone and it's your fault for being gullible.
readingMnemonic: Finally there's nothing else for the black hole to eat so you hit the restore button.... but nothing happens. "Oh f**k (ふく) you!" you scream as you realize you were lied to.

meaningMnemonic: During a tsunami, your lip ring is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a river. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how painful this would be, having your lip ring ripped from your lip. It would hurt a lot. Touch your lip and imagine missing half of it. Yikes.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself fording the river, all wet and cold from the water. Keeping your eyes on your car, you move slowly across. Look at the car. Look at it!
readingMnemonic: But why were you trying to cross this river anyway? Well your car (か) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though.

meaningMnemonic: You keep all of your shellfish under a roof down the street and it's your savings. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking down the street to deposit more shellfish into your special savings and gaze happily at the huge pile you keep far enough away that you aren't tempted to spend it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to lift up a shellfish with a pair of smooth chopsticks. It slips right out. Ugh! I guess that's good though, because it's a savings for a reason (you shouldn't be spending it)!
readingMnemonic: When you want to withdraw from your savings you force yourself to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings.

meaningMnemonic: You take this comb, break the handle off, and use it to stamp your official seal of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy marking process, but it gets the job done.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine breaking and bending a comb so you can use it to stamp your seal onto things.
additionalR:
Hints
Hopefully the inn accepts this seal... or you aren't going to have a place to sleep tonight. And it kind of just looks like you dipped a comb in ink and pressed it around on some paper.
readingMnemonic: You need this seal to stay at an inn (いん). All inns require official paperwork, so you had to improvise and make a seal on the fly.

meaningMnemonic: You're trying to use your fingers to cause a landslide so you have to shake the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to wave at the ground now.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine shaking your fingers at the dirt. Do you think you can shake the dirt hard enough to cause a landslide (spoilers, no).
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your shins shaking, your hands are waving, and they won't stop. No! You shouldn't have tried to start a landslide. This was a bad idea!
readingMnemonic: You think you finally got the earth to shake but when you look down it's just your shins (しん). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?!

meaningMnemonic: In a hole, you see a big guy who looks like he wants to stab you. You don’t want him to stab you, so you make sure not to fall into the big hole that houses the big guy that wants to stab you big time.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this hole – it’s like, super big. The guy is really big. They’re terrifying enough on their own, but put them together and you’ve got a big problem. You feel very afraid of this hole and getting stabbed. Just don’t fall in, okay?
additionalR:
Hints
This big guy inside the big hole is totes going to stab you. Why did you fall in?? Feel the big guy press you up against the wall of the hole as he begins to stab you repeatedly.
readingMnemonic: You fall in the big hole. What did I just tell you not to do!? He’s totes (とつ) going to stab you for sure. Totes.

meaningMnemonic: There is a head pinned to a tree by a knife. This person has been stabbed! They were stabbed so hard that they were pinned to the tree here.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how much force you would need to stab someone to have the knife and go all the way through them and pin their head to a tree. That's a lot of force.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting closer to the sheep and seeing blood on its wool. You squint your eyes and see some knives strapped to its back. Even closer and you see a little sign around its neck that says, "Hello, I'm the Stabbing Sheep." Uh oh.
readingMnemonic: You want to know who did the stabbing, so you look around to see if the stabber is still in the area. But all you see is a sheep (し). Sheep can't stab people, right? They have hooves and probably can't pick up knives... right?

meaningMnemonic: You see a soul floating around a tombstone acting suspicious. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine inching closer to this suspicious soul floating around a tombstone. What do you think it's doing?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a suspicious, kevlar wearing, kayaking soul. The afterlife may be more interesting than you thought.
readingMnemonic: You sneak around the tombstone to see what this suspicious soul is doing, and you realize it's pretending to kayak (かい). The soul is sitting behind the tombstone, in a small kayak, moving its arms like it's rowing through water.

meaningMnemonic: The tsunami going down your dry face is just sweat.
additionalM:
Hints
Sweat really does feel like a tsunami though. Wow, it's dry and hot out right now!
additionalR:
Hints
The one place you wish sweat wouldn't go, but somehow it always does: the ass.
readingMnemonic: The sweat isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your ass (あせ).

meaningMnemonic: Out of bamboo, you make a brush – a writing brush. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself using this bamboo writing brush. Do you know many kanji? Of course you do! Imagine yourself writing them all with this nice writing brush. It’s actually fun to write things with it!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the sound the brush makes when it hits the paper. It’s a bit of a plop, and then kind of a scratching sound as the brush bristles move around. Really focus on this sound that the brush makes when it hits the paper.
readingMnemonic: Once the writing brush hits (ひつ) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on!

meaningMnemonic: A woman sitting on a stool with a broken heart is very angry. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him.
additionalM:
Hints
This woman is so angry! Pretend you are the woman. Sit on your stool and feel your heart, painful in your chest, as you fume and think about how angry you are.
additionalR:
Hints
You’re so angry! Imagine your ex as being an actual dog and picture yourself hitting it right in the face with your stool. Hear the dog whimpering in pain as you demolish it.
readingMnemonic: The guy who broke your heart and made you so angry was such a dog (ど). He cheated on you multiple times, with your mother and your sister! What a dog!

meaningMnemonic: You want to go to the sun so you set up a slide twenty stories tall so you can ascend into the heavens.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the air whoosh past your face as you shoot off the end of the long slide and ascend into the air. It's starting to get hot and the sun is getting closer!
additionalR:
Hints
As you ascend, look back through tear-filled eyes and see the Shougun staring up at you. He nods slightly. You've pleased him.
readingMnemonic: You need to ascend into the sky and toward the sun because the Shougun (しょう) said so. He's testing out some space travel technology (the twenty story slide) and you're his guinea pig.

meaningMnemonic: If you're riding your scooter through some rice, it's likely you've gone astray. Also you might be lost.
additionalM:
Hints
Usually there aren't paved areas inside areas of rice. You must be really lost if you ended up here with your scooter.
additionalR:
Hints
How you got so lost that you ended up on an old ship from 1620 is beyond my understanding. But you did it.
