readingMnemonic: You got so lost and went so astray you ended up on the Mayflower  (めい), a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray.

meaningMnemonic: Someone is reaching out with their fingers to call for you. They beckon you closer, this way.
additionalM:
Hints
Something about the way they're beckoning you with their fingers is really enticing. You can't help but walk toward them.
additionalR:
Hints
Even if the Shougun didn't have an army that would crush you if you didn't come when he called, you'd go anyway. Those beckoning fingers are just so... weirdly enticing.
readingMnemonic: The person beckoning you is the Shougun (しょう). You can't help but obey the Shougun's beckoning call.

meaningMnemonic: Inside this moon is a black hole... haha just kidding, it's your belly! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good stomach you have!
additionalM:
Hints
Look down at your perfect belly. It's looking back up at you.
additionalR:
Hints
Forget to eat lunch? Belly grumbles f**k you. Tell someone you're fat and need to lose weight? Belly cries f**k you. Be nice to your belly.
readingMnemonic: If you don't treat your belly with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "F**k (ふく) you!" Be nice to your stomach!

meaningMnemonic: Your eyes start to close as you drive your car because you’re getting drowsy. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life!
additionalM:
Hints
Feel yourself getting drowsy as you drive this goofy car. You’re so tired. Struggle to keep your eyes open. Also visualize this car missing its top and its bottom because the car radical is modified.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself swinging on this tire swing. You’ve been swinging for a while and you’re getting really drowsy.
readingMnemonic: The reason you’re so drowsy, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire swing (すい) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out.

meaningMnemonic: You see a canopy under which Wolverineis sipping some water. He looks so at ease, and at peace.
additionalM:
Hints
Wolverine just looks so peaceful under that canopy with his water.
additionalR:
Hints
こういち sees you and invites you to come sip water under the canopy. Why not? Looks peaceful.
readingMnemonic: Suddenly you realize that it's not just Wolverine, but also こういち. hanging out under the canopy.

meaningMnemonic: Setting up a stand on the top of a mountain, you rake all the rocks to the edge of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself at the top of the mountain, holding the rake in your hands. Look over the edge. Feel the sinking feeling in your stomach as you realize how high up you really are.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself at the edge of this mountain getting your tan on. Feel the sun beating down on you and feel the fresh mountain breeze blowing over your body. It’s very relaxing.
readingMnemonic: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a tan (たん). You lay next to the edge of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.

meaningMnemonic: A tree with a mouth eats a beggar and his stool, which were on the ground next to him, which seems to be a bit extreme, don't you think?
additionalM:
Hints
The beggar was just sitting there on a stool! Why so extreme?
additionalR:
Hints
You know Goku from Dragon Ball, right? Imagine him doing all sorts of extreme things. Then imagine his less impressive brother, Kyoku, also doing extremes. And then they get eaten by the tree.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately we still haven’t come up with a good reading for きょく, but just try and remember this reading as Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z and his strange step brother Kyoku (きょく). Goku and Kyoku are the beggars in this story, the ones performing all the extremes. First Goku gets eaten by the tree with the mouth, and then Kyoku gets eaten as well.

meaningMnemonic: Inside the "Good Building" there's a single guy.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel free to walk around the Good Building. There are no things or people, except for that one guy. Who is that guy.
additionalR:
Hints
You try to talk to the guy, poke him, and even yell at him. But, all he does is hand you some fish roe. When you take it, he offers you more fish roe. What's up with this guy?
readingMnemonic: You talk to that guy. The only thing he does is offer you roe (ろう).

meaningMnemonic: The leader of your yoga class uses a special brush to stay healthy. She rubs the brush on her long arms and legs, and she never ever gets sick.
additionalM:
Hints
If you want to be healthy too, just do yoga and rub this healthy brush all over your bod.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Ken, the picture of samurai health, doing yoga and getting that brush all up in those bits.
readingMnemonic: Not everyone wants to be healthy, but Ken (けん) the samurai sure does. He needs to be ready at a moment's notice so he can do tasks for other people. He's at every class, rubbing himself down with the brush.

meaningMnemonic: You say to some grain and some stairs: I want to invite you to my place.
additionalM:
Hints
So you do. You invite a stalk of grain and a set of stairs to your home.
additionalR:
Hints
Surprisingly, the youths were impressed and spent a long time trying to talk to them.
readingMnemonic: You invited them to your home because your roommate was having a party and inviting a lot of youths (ゆう) over. You wanted to look cool, so you invited some grain and some stairs, the two coolest things you could think of.

meaningMnemonic: You substitute some shellfish for collateral so your friend will lend you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.
additionalM:
Hints
"Shellfish used to be money! People used to lend them to each other all the time!" you say to your friend. "Hmm... okay, I guess so," they say skeptically.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself in this new car that you got with the money your friend lent you. Hear the roar of the engine and feel the wind in your hair.
readingMnemonic: You want your friend to lend you some money so you can buy yourself a car (か). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan.

meaningMnemonic: A drunkard who has his mouth on the ground, has a heart that is misguided. First of all, he tries to drink his problems away, but worse, he's so drunk he's trying to drink out of the ground.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this misguided drunkard. His whole deal is messed up.
additionalR:
Hints
Did I do it? Did I figure out the kid lingo? Am I cool? Or am I just another wack, misguided adult?
readingMnemonic: Nowadays we don't say misguided, we say wack (わく). Like, damn that drunkard is so messed up, he's wack.

meaningMnemonic: When your sick mama tries to do a task she's filled with pain!
additionalM:
Hints
Sick people shouldn't have to do things, of course they're in pain. You shouldn't let your mama do anything if she's in pain, do it for her!
additionalR:
Hints
You finish doing your tasks and hers too, and you ask her, "How is the pain now, Mama?" "THE PAIN IS TOO MUCH!" she cries. Oh mama.
readingMnemonic: Your mama's pain is too (つう) much for her to handle, so now you have to do all of her tasks too.

meaningMnemonic: If you're on your scooter and you run over a root, you'll need to retreat. The roots have obviously rejected you, they want you to leave, so you should.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the roots raising up a little bit from the ground and tripping up your scooter. They reject you, so you should just retreat.
additionalR:
Hints
You didn't retreat fast enough, the roots are rejecting your life, and strangling you with your own tie.
readingMnemonic: You're trying to retreat by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your tie (たい). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck.

meaningMnemonic: When you ride a scooter you'll have a surplus of possible routes. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too!
additionalM:
Hints
Okay, so it might not be legal to take the sidewalk route depending on where you live, but physically, you can do whatever you want because scooters are small.
additionalR:
Hints
Psh, whatever. They aren't your toes, and this is the fastest route! You'll name it the toe route and do whatever you want.
readingMnemonic: You decide to take the fastest route, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single toe (と) on every single person trying to walk there.

meaningMnemonic: Your threads have to suit you if you want a good salary. No one is going to give you a salary if your clothes don't suit you. You have to look professional!
additionalM:
Hints
When you see someone wearing a fancy suit that suits them, don't you wonder about how much their salary is?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your salary being paid in cucumbers. Open that sweet paycheck and watch the cucumbers come tumbling out.
readingMnemonic: Your salary is paid in cucumbers (きゅう). Maybe you shouldn't have worn that cucumber tie when you interviewed for this job, even though it suited you well.

meaningMnemonic: In the capital, a broken dog begins to settle in. This dog used to live in the country, but he kept getting caught in bear and fox traps which busted the poor dog up. The dog didn’t want to live like this, so he decided to settle in the capital city where there aren’t pesky animal traps to get caught in.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this dog going to the capital and settling in. The poor dog looks pretty messed up though. The radical for dog in this kanji is a bit modified, so just remember that the dog in this story is all messed up.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch the broken dog settle in to his new shoes in his new home in the capital. The old dog can finally enjoy life!
readingMnemonic: In order to help the dog settle in, the capital cobbler makes him a pair of shoes (しゅう). The shoes help him walk on his hurt legs, but more importantly, they help him relax and feel like a dog again.

meaningMnemonic: Take your leather and change it into shoes.
additionalM:
Hints
You start with a sheet of leather. Now imagine yourself going through the process of changing them to shoes. Smell the leather and feel it, too.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine some of these old coots busting into a modern shoe store and kicking over all the display stands and setting everything on fire because they hate non leather shoes so much. Hear the old coots screaming and babbling nonsense as they destroy the store.
readingMnemonic: Some shoes aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old coots (くつ). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.

meaningMnemonic: Closing each eye is something that the peoples do before they sleep. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.
additionalM:
Hints
You are one of these peoples, so imagine yourself closing your eyes and sleeping. Go ahead and do it right now. Close one eye, and then the other. Now imagine yourself sleeping.
additionalR:
Hints
Those other peoples were really mean to you. Imagine all the mean things they were saying to you. What did they say? Think about all these mean things as you close your eyes and drift off to sleep. Also keep in mind that this kanji has the same reading as 民, which is included in this kanji.
readingMnemonic: The reason you want to sleep is because all the other peoples were mean (みん) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep.

meaningMnemonic: In the sun while holding a comb in a cage and sitting on a stool, you comb your hair in your spare time. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself in your spare time, sitting on this stool in a cage in the sun. Feel the warmth of the sun on your body and feel the metal bars of the cage holding you in. You try to forget about your situation by combing your hair with the comb. The comb radical is a little modified, so be sure to remember that you made this comb yourself and it’s a little wonky.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself in this cage. You’re going to be there for life because you’d stolen too many cars. Feel the tears run down your face as you continue to comb your hair. You’re going to die in this cage.
readingMnemonic: So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your spare time, you used to steal cars (か). You’d stolen many a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair.

meaningMnemonic: Cut this comb up with your weapon and turn it into the steps for some stairs.
additionalM:
Hints
When you think about it, a comb is like a ladder. So if you cut all the rungs off with your weapon and put them on the ground, they turn into stairs!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine standing at the top of the stairs you made yourself, looking down at the entire town below you, as the light of dawn breaks and fills everything before you with light. And now more people can see this beautiful sight if they climb your steps.
readingMnemonic: You slowly work to create these stairs, you have to slice up a lot of combs, and at dawn (だん) they are done!

meaningMnemonic: If you eat a rice paddy the size of the moon, your stomach is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having a whole rice paddy in your stomach. A rice paddy the size of the moon. Your stomach hurts a lot. You feel like you’re going to throw up.
additionalR:
Hints
This eagle saw your stomach distress and decided to help by making you barf. Hear the screech of the eagle as it swoops down and rams you in the stomach.
readingMnemonic: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended stomach. Bam! The eagle (い) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.

meaningMnemonic: When someone is sick in order to diagnose the correct cause and treatment, you need to check their symptoms. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them!
additionalM:
Hints
If you know all of the symptoms for each and every sickness you'd be able to cure them all!
additionalR:
Hints
You get all up close and personal with the Shougun. Hmm, his symptoms are watery eyes, stuffy nose, angry shouting (wait no, that's not a symptom, is it?). Don't mess up!
readingMnemonic: You need to figure out the symptoms the Shougun (しょう) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head.

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami hits while you're farming, you'll have to wear really thick clothes to deal with it. The water is thick with fish and cars and other ripped-up debris too, which makes it even harder.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting on your thick farming suit as the tsunami comes at you. You hold onto your hoe and brace yourself for the wall of water.
additionalR:
Hints
Thanks Nostradamus, now I'm in my nice, thick gear, struggling to hoe my fields through this wall of tsunami water. But I'm not dead and I'm not wet.
readingMnemonic: You knew to put on your thick tsunami-proof farming gear because Nostradamus (のう) warned you it was coming. He sent a message to your brain yesterday so you'd know what to wear today.

meaningMnemonic: You have a special thread in your towel you can use to make it stand up by tightening it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine pulling this thread and watch as your towel tightens and goes rigid, standing up almost completely on its own (except that the thread did it).
additionalR:
Hints
A tightened towel stands up for easy grease cleanup. No wiping on your pants, no dripping on the floor.
readingMnemonic: You tighten your towel before you eat tater (てい) tots every night. That way it stands up nice and straight next to your eating chair, ready for all that delicious tater tot grease that gets on your fingers.

meaningMnemonic: The scooter is white. This color will urge and compel you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to coerce you, even.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at how white the scooter is. It urges you to use it. It compels you. You feel coerced...
additionalR:
Hints
Really all marketing, advertising, and the like is just a hack of your brain.
Hint: If you see 白 in a kanji, there's a good likelihood the reading will be はく.
readingMnemonic: When they urge, compel and coerce you like this, they are hacking (はく) your brain.

meaningMnemonic: Someone just asked you to say which direction they should visit.
additionalM:
Hints
You better think long and hard about where you think they should visit before you say so. They're relying on you.
additionalR:
Hints
Your home is just over that direction, and it's your favorite place to visit, so why wouldn't this stranger want to visit your home too?! So come and visit my home, random person!
readingMnemonic: You end up saying, "You should visit my home (ほう)." How kind of you!

meaningMnemonic: Taking a thread and moving to the sound of the music, a drunkard makes a weave through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this drunkard bipping and bopping to the sound of the music as he weaves this thread through his clothes to repair them.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this drunken Sheikh again, only this time he is moving to the sound of some Arabic music. You know what that sounds like, right?
readingMnemonic: This drunkard is actually a Sheikh (しき) (an Arabic leader), but he’s just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he is using the thread to weave back together is one of his fancy formal robes.

meaningMnemonic: If your soul is lying in the grass in a treasure chest, you're going to worry about it. It's just sitting there, out in the open, waiting for anyone to come and open it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your soul curled up inside this treasure chest that's just sitting out on the grass. Anyone could open it up and look inside, and this worries you quite a bit!
additionalR:
Hints
You worry about what you'll find if you look directly at your soul. But you also worry about what will happen if someone else looks. So you're stuck in a constant state of worrying: nah or yah?!
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, you also worry about opening it yourself. You stand in front of the chest and think, "Should I open it? Nah, yah (なや). Wait. Nah. Yah. Dang, you can't make up your mind.

meaningMnemonic: You see a flag by the exit letting you know to yield. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this flag telling you to yield. Now look through the exit right by the flag. You can see a bunch of people out there walking. Imagine standing by the exit, yielding to the other people until you have an opening. Hear the hustle and bustle of the people as you wait.
additionalR:
Hints
Darn coots! Forget the yield flag, it’s time to exit. Imagine busting out of the exit, punching and pushing your way through the old coots. Hear them scream and shout “Augh! My hip!” as you plow through them.
readingMnemonic: Even though the flag told you to yield, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old coots (くつ)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way!

meaningMnemonic: Construction in the winter leads to aggression. Just think about it. It's cold, it's unpleasant, and you don't want to be there. So, you start to develop an aggression towards other people working with you on this winter project.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself walking through the winter construction site, taking out your aggression on anyone you see. You hate this winter construction!
additionalR:
Hints
"Aggression" is going to depend on you, so you should imagine a scene where you take your aggression out on こういち, whatever that entails.
Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.
readingMnemonic: You're taking your aggression out on everyone. Then, the sexy construction worker from WaniKani Level 1, こういち, walks by without a shirt on. You take out all your aggression on him.

meaningMnemonic: If someone is coming toward you in a car, holding a weapon in their hand, they're going to attack you!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the car, weapon out the window, preparing to attack you full force!
additionalR:
Hints
Gecki is attacking you now. He's hitting you over and over with his tiny car. He's yelling and smacking your ankles with his weapon. And all you can do is wait and let the attack happen, because you know you deserve it.
readingMnemonic: Right before the attack begins, you recognize the hand holding this weapon and driving this car. It's Gecki (げき), your long-lost gecko who you may or may not have let fly off into a really fierce tsunami. Oops. I think he may be here attacking you out of revenge.

meaningMnemonic: After a tsunami, you find an axe on the ground next to some fins on the beach. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach.
additionalM:
Hints
See these things on the beach. It makes sense to see fins, as fins are usually in the ocean, so seeing them on the beach is logical. Pick up the stuff you find as you feel the beach sand between your toes.
additionalR:
Hints
Pick up the hammer in your hand. It’s pretty heavy. The tsunami must have been very strong to pick up such a heavy hammer.
readingMnemonic: Walking down the beach a bit more, you also find a hammer (はま). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer.

meaningMnemonic: This thread is odd, but that's what makes it beautiful. It's a little frayed, it's a little miscolored, but that's what makes it appealing to you.
additionalM:
Hints
If something is a bit odd, it's usually beautiful in its own way, just like this beautiful thread.
additionalR:
Hints
To remember that there's a beautiful thread hidden away, you tie a not-as-beautiful thread to the end of the key.
readingMnemonic: You take this beautiful thread and lock it up with a key (き). You want to keep it all to yourself, you want its beauty to be for your eyes only!

meaningMnemonic: There are some horns on the ground next to fins on a plate that are meant to benefit everyone. If you're a member of this town, one of your benefits is this little set up.
additionalM:
Hints
You pick up the horns off the ground and put them on your head, then eat some fins off the plate. This is just one of many benefits to living here. You'll never go hungry!
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so using the 駅 is probably a better benefit than eating cold fins off a plate on the ground, but you take what you can get. They're all free!
readingMnemonic: Another benefit is free 駅 usage! Whenever you come back home from places on the train, this 駅 is completely free.

meaningMnemonic: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing stick at the sun, you attain the legs of a child. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself getting new legs. Legs that belong to a child. They’re limber and young and full of energy! Feel your legs of a child underneath you!
additionalR:
Hints
Say back to Jesus, “I’m not your child Jesus! And you’re just jealous of my new legs! You wish you had the legs of a child, Jesus! Your legs are like super old!” Actually say this out loud, and remember how Jesus wishes he could be a child again too.
readingMnemonic: As you delight in your new legs, Jesus (じ) descends from the sky. “My child,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.”

meaningMnemonic: The roof protecting your life and the net protecting your heart are both protected by the constitution.
additionalM:
Hints
The constitution makes it so that everything you hold dear is locked away, nice and safe on a piece of paper, and no one can change the rules or hurt you without your say so.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Ken standing in front of your constitution. But keep a close watch, cause wily ol' Nic Cage is in the business of thievin' on constitutions.
readingMnemonic: Your country's constitution is being protected by none other than Ken (けん) the samurai, hero for hire.

meaningMnemonic: You got your ice orders. Of course, your ice orders are to make things cool and cold.
additionalM:
Hints
Making things cool and cold are pretty much the only orders you'll hear from ice. Ice is very simple in that regard.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a cold ray coming out of your ray gun. Anything it touches becomes cold. "Stay cool, bird boy," you say.
Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.
readingMnemonic: How will you make things cool and cold? You'll use a special ray (れい) gun that shoots a cold ray.

meaningMnemonic: A winter table would be an odd thing to deal with. Winter can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst!
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this winter table. How are you ever going to deal with it? Just think of your favorite warm food and then imagine it getting cold. Deal with it, dog.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the relief of getting rid of this table. No more having to deal with it anymore. The circus show can have it.
readingMnemonic: This winter table is something you have to deal with, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus show (しょ)? They like weird stuff like this.

meaningMnemonic: You loiter on the mountain, reading off the numbers of pi on this winter morning. Everything is so perfect, so mathematical here. You view it as delicate. Not in the sense that it will break apart at any moment, more in the sense that there are smaller, more subtle things to be enjoyed on this mountain, which is why you loiter here doing math.
additionalM:
Hints
You'll have to imagine the things you consider to be "delicate." Is that the snow falling on the branches? Is it the breeze? Is it something else? That's for you to decide, but imagine it vividly whatever it is.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself looking at the bee, thinking how each hair on its body is so delicate. Maybe it has a delicate aroma to go with it. A faint smell of honey?
readingMnemonic: Ah! Of course! The delicate bumble bee (び), that is your epitome of delicate. It lands upon your finger, and you look at its every fiber of being.

meaningMnemonic: A leader uses a stick in the winter made of hair to enforce discipline. The leader uses the stick made of hair to discipline his followers. He hits them with it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the leader disciplining his people with the hair stick in the winter. Imagine him yelling “DISCIPLINE!!” with each hit of the stick as you feel the cold winter air around you.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the leader gets pelted with all sorts of types of shoes. Boots, high heels, baby slippers. They're all colliding with him as the people shout, "Discipline solves nothing!"
readingMnemonic: If the leader uses a stick to discipline his followers, eventually they'll fight back. The disciplined masses start to take off their shoes (しゅう) and throw them at the leader!

meaningMnemonic: You wear a great big cross on your chest and you attend a specialty exhibition for gambling. The big cross on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross, and everyone is gambling.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself at this specialty exhibition. Feel the weight of the cross shaped badge on your chest as you continue gambling at the exhibition.
additionalR:
Hints
Hack the gambling machines. Imagine the sounds of the exhibition around you as you work to hack the machines. Look at the computer parts and cables as you work.
readingMnemonic: You’re not very good at gambling, but you are pretty good at cheating. You hack (はく) the specialty exhibition gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system.

meaningMnemonic: The Grain Mouth King pours grain from his mouth for you and his other subjects. You go to him and pull his finger. When you do this, grain pours from his mouth. But we were greedy. We didn't understand the extent to which we were harvesting his mouth wheat.
additionalM:
Hints
Of course, you need to imagine pulling the Grain Mouth King's finger, to some extent. You can't just read what we write for you, without going to the imagination zone. Pull that finger real hard a couple times, and watch an extra large purge of grain pour forth.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hearing the rumors that the Grain Mouth King ran out of grain, so you go check the extent of his failure yourself. But tater tots taste pretty good too. Imagine eating one of his mouth tater tots and go ahead and comment about it to him.
readingMnemonic: The extent to which we were harvesting grain from his mouth was too great. The Grain Mouth King has run out of grain. He worries he will lose power if he has no grain to offer, so he switches to barfing out tater (てい) tots instead.

meaningMnemonic: Sometime in the future, thread of every color will be faced with extinction. Eventually there will be nothing else to make thread out of, and thread of every kind and color will reach extinction.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what the world would be like without thread. No thread of any color. How would you fix tears in clothes or make new ones? It would be a strange world where thread is extinct.
additionalR:
Hints
Pretend you have deadly zits. They’re everywhere, not just your face. You can’t pop them or you’ll die, but they’re all bulging and extremely painful. Now you’re facing extinction. Lousy.
readingMnemonic: The extinction of thread was brought on by a very strange thing. Deadly zits (ぜつ). These zits killed off all the producers of thread, and eventually the thread went extinct. Dang zits.

meaningMnemonic: Ice from the east is frozen. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this super frozen ice from the east. You’ve never seen anything quite like it before. It’s so frozen, it’s like it was frozen once and then frozen again. Twice frozen. Feel the ice and how freezing cold it is. It’s super cold, guys.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being in とうきょう and seeing all this frozen ice. Hear people speaking Japanese all around you as you touch and feel the freezing twice-frozen ice.
readingMnemonic: Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was frozen in とうきょう. とうきょう is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there.

meaningMnemonic: The giant radical and the giant kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
additionalR:
Hints
See Little Kyoto after the giant rampaged through it. It looks even smaller and more pathetic than ever. Look at all the smoldering rubble and smell the smoke with your nose.
readingMnemonic: Just recently, a giant rampaged through Little Kyoto (きょ), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto.

meaningMnemonic: Only give grains to a turkey if it's immature. Adult turkeys should be eating healthier things, like insects and grass. But immature turkeys don't care if they get fat, so they whine and whine and whine until you give them grains.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine an immature turkey complaining at you until you give it grains. Now it's taking selfies with the grains and posting pics to Instagram and hashtagging them #GRAINLIFE.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a bunch of immature kids and turkeys eating cheese together.
readingMnemonic: Another thing immature turkeys (and people) love is cheese (ち). Most of us non-immature people and birds still like cheese, but if you didn't have an immature cheese phase as a kid or teen, you won't be able to like cheese as a mature old person.

meaningMnemonic: Super poop is a super power you have in infancy. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power!
additionalM:
Hints
Infants poop a lot. There's poop everywhere. The powerful aroma overwhelms you. Eww.
Also refers to childhood, when you still have some of your poop powers, but they're already starting to go away.
additionalR:
Hints
See this infant gobbling up all the yogurt he can get his grubby little hands on. Soon, he begins to poop all over the place. Hear the infant screaming, "Goo-goo! Yogurt poop power! I'm a baby! Wahhhh!!"
readingMnemonic: In infancy, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as yogurt (よう). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power.

meaningMnemonic: You stick horns in the ground using them as spikes and you line up the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself lining up these horns in the ground. The spikes are sharp and you poke yourself with one. Ouch. Need to be more careful as you line these up.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the hay in that bull's mouth as it chomps angrily, watching you line up horns in the ground. It probably wishes you were the hay.
readingMnemonic: As you line up these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on hay (へい) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty.

meaningMnemonic: If you know the radical meaning lovely, you know the kanji meaning lovely as well!
additionalM:
Hints
You know what would make learning this radical lovely? Studying your radicals.
additionalR:
Hints
Try to imagine feeling this way about your ray gun. It's so lovely.
readingMnemonic: "Lovely" is the name of my ray (れい) gun. It's more lovely than any other thing.

meaningMnemonic: The odd radical and the odd kanji are the same. They're both... really strange.
additionalM:
Hints
Remember how odd this one is?
additionalR:
Hints
You only give this odd key to people you trust, so they can unlock your odd secrets and see how odd you are deep down.
readingMnemonic: You're odd too, just like this kanji. But you don't want anyone to know, so you lock away your strange habits with a key (き).

meaningMnemonic: Blood and hair and tofu make up the populace. Those are the three categories the entire populace fits into, anyway.
additionalM:
Hints
Blood shows that all the people are related. Hair shows that we're all humans. Tofu is food to all. So, as you can see, those three words describe the entire populace.
additionalR:
Hints
If you see people in your populace without shoes, it's your job as a fellow member of society to help them get some!
readingMnemonic: The entire populace deserves shoes (しゅう). It's a basic thing all humans should have like flowing blood, hair (somewhere), and tofu to eat.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami that's blue is pure. Some tsunami are other colors, like brown or red because they aren't pure, they'll full of trash and poop and other horrible things. But a blue tsunami is completely pure!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this pure blue tsunami. You can see every crystal clear drop of water in it.
additionalR:
Hints
SPLAASHH! The tsunami's pure water splits and it absorbed into your saber. Now it's pure too. And transparent!
readingMnemonic: Seeing this pure blue tsunami inspires you to pull out your glowing blue saber (せい)! As the pure water comes toward you, you take one, long slash!
mainReading: せい, しょう, しん

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami takes life, cuts it like a sword through thread, and leaves everything behind completely pure. Everything is dead and gone, wiped clean off the face of the earth, thanks to the tsunami. It's back to the way it was before humans were here, it's completely pure.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the tsunami purifying the land of life, and in your mind see the sword cutting clean through the thread of life.
additionalR:
Hints
The area is SO pure that the ground absorbs the ketsup and now it's all pure... ketsup color.
readingMnemonic: After the tsunami pulls away, everything left is pure white. You hate this, so you run over and squirt ketsup (けつ) all over the place to make it not so pure.

meaningMnemonic: A gold Wolverine swam in the water while his father made a record of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine.
additionalM:
Hints
See this gold Wolverine holding his gold medal after getting out of the water. His dad doesn’t want to forget anything about this precious moment so he makes a record of it. Imagine him scribbling furiously in his notebook.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a pitiful Wolverine crying on the ground as each rock hits him. All he wanted was some recognition from his father. Poor guy. Imagine poor Wolverine like this as his dad just looks on and writes in his notebook.
readingMnemonic: Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a record of this also. One angry fan threw a rock (ろく) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records.

meaningMnemonic: Your scooter takes you to the barracks, drops you off, and then goes in reverse all the way back home in the opposite direction.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine riding your scooter to the barracks. It literally drops you on the ground when you get there, and then drives in reverse back the opposite way you came.
additionalR:
Hints
You Gak up the wheels so when the scooter tries to switch to reverse it gets stuck. Success! But now it can't go forward either. Darn you Gak, you tricked me again.
readingMnemonic: Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial.

meaningMnemonic: A grain, from one evening to the next evening, experiences a shift. After two evenings, the grain has shifted from one location to another.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the grain in your head with a time-lapse of one evening after another happening in the background. Slowly, the grain shifts.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the eagle flying down on the second evening, scattering the grains it doesn't eat, shifting their location.
readingMnemonic: This shift is caused by the eagle (い) that wants to eat the grains. Every other evening, the eagle swoops down, shifts the grains (eating a few) and then flies off.

meaningMnemonic: Rice that is blue has a strong spirit. Our spirits are blue, so if you ever see rice (or other food, or even people) that's blue, you know that's their spirit radiating out!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this rice, the pulsing blue spirit of each grain is glowing so bright!
additionalR:
Hints
As you release the spirits in the rice, your saber begins to glow blue too. Their spirits are going inside your saber, making it stronger!
readingMnemonic: You want to see the spirit up close, so you take your saber (せい), throw the blue rice in the air, and slice it in half! The rice explodes and blue light fills everything!

meaningMnemonic: This building has a pig with horns on it because it's our squad's place.
additionalM:
Hints
Our symbol is the horn pig and we put it on everything to show the whole world our squad owns this turf. #SQUADGOALS
additionalR:
Hints
Picture our squad. It's Koichi, Viet, the Crabigator and Tofugu. We're all wearing matching horned pig ties and walking toward you in slow motion, our squad building towering behind us with the pig smirking down at you.
readingMnemonic: Our squad also wears special ties (たい) with our horned pig on it. And we don't care if you think that's lame, because we're A FAMILY.

meaningMnemonic: A canopy is over your car because your car is in storage in a large warehouse.
additionalM:
Hints
The canopy just protects your car from the elements as it sits in storage for long periods of time.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a kid sneaking into your canopy to steal your car that's in storage. Maybe it's two 子s, one stacked on the other with a trench coat. One 子 works the pedals while the other 子 works the steering.
readingMnemonic: Your car is in this storage warehouse, just sitting there. A 子 (こ) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it.

meaningMnemonic: A woman is one of the few strange things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few strange things in this world, with woman being one of them.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine saying this to a woman. Try and imagine her face as you tell her how strange she is.
additionalR:
Hints
Who's strange? Me and you. Me, you - we are strange! Strange, strange, strange!
readingMnemonic: But when you think about it, we're all a little strange. Me, you, myou (みょう) everybody!

meaningMnemonic: The gladiator in front of you draws his sword. He points the sword at your chest and right when you think everything is about to end, you realize he's pointing the sword at the ticket in your hand.
additionalM:
Hints
Right! You needed to buy a ticket to see the gladiator! He doesn't want to kill you, he wants to check to make sure you bought a ticket.
additionalR:
Hints
Ken takes a long time to examine your ticket. I don't think he understands that he needs a ticket to fight the gladiator. Maybe you should give him yours.
readingMnemonic: The gladiator happily marks your ticket with his blade, when Ken (けん) the samurai pushes past you. He holds up his own sword, challenging the gladiator, who just shakes his head and points at your ticket again.

meaningMnemonic: As a hat, four people holding a cross use an umbrella. The umbrella is big enough to be a hat for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that’s why they’re holding the cross.
additionalM:
Hints
See these four people all under one umbrella. No one is carrying the umbrella, it’s just resting on all of their heads like a hat. Their hands are busy holding that cross, anyway.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the four people in the umbrella hat again, only this time imagine them skipping along singing “Mi casa es su casa”. It’ll help you remember.
readingMnemonic: You know the Spanish phrase “Mi casa (かさ) es su casa”? Well this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is an umbrella. Mi casa es yours too, because it’s an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me.

meaningMnemonic: That woman dressed as Wolverine with a towel tied around her forehead is your wife. You're cosplaying together!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your kick-butt wife in her Wolverine costume, the towel around her forehead so she doesn't sweat into her eyes, as you prepare to go to a convention together.
additionalR:
Hints
Your wife is shaking her head saying, "You fool, it's my turn to be Wolverine, you're gonna have to change." Then she smooches your cheek, calls you a fool one more time, and leaves without you.
readingMnemonic: Your wife suddenly looks at you and calls you a fool (ふ). Wuh! Then you look down and see that you're also dressed as Wolverine.

meaningMnemonic: You see a rice paddy and you give it a kiss before granting it the abbreviation, RP. The rice paddy isn’t too fond of this abbreviation, so you kiss it again to soothe it.
additionalM:
Hints
As you imagine yourself giving a kiss to a rice paddy, think about whether or not the abbreviation RP would ever catch on. Do you think it would?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the rice paddy on the rack, squealing for mercy. Turn the handle to turn the rack, causing the rice paddy even more discomfort.
readingMnemonic: The rice paddy still refuses to accept this abbreviation despite your kisses. Therefore, you are forced to take the rice paddy and hang it from a torture rack (りゃく) until it agrees to accept the abbreviation.

meaningMnemonic: Grains get blamed for how much they accumulate. If the grains accumulate too much then they make more work for the farmers. If they accumulate too little, then they're starving the people. Ugh, grains just can't win with you people. They're blamed for everything.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a pile of grains accumulating in size while a person watches. No matter how large the pile gets, the person keeps blaming them for something!
additionalR:
Hints
Is that why people become farmers? Because they think... accumulating a lot of grains is sexy? People are weird.
readingMnemonic: Now the grains have accumulated a ton, they're overflowing in their grain sacks, and the farmer freezes and says, "Now those are some sexy (せき) grains."

meaningMnemonic: There’s a tsunami in heaven and you take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Now the tsunami is big enough to destroy all of heaven. The small drop that you appended to the tsunami was just enough to push it over the edge, reaching full destruction capability.
additionalM:
Hints
Take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Feel the drop of water on your finger and visualize yourself flicking it at the tsunami as it races towards heaven.
additionalR:
Hints
Look up at this ten story tall tsunami. It looks big and powerful. Feel the water spray from the tsunami as it towers over you.
readingMnemonic: Just after you append the small drop of water to the tsunami, it grows ten (てん) stories high. Before it was only nine, but since you appended that drop, the tsunami is now a full ten stories tall.

meaningMnemonic: Under this roof someone odd is trying to approach you. You back up, but they continue their approach anyway.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being under the same roof as an odd person who wants to approach you. You don't want anything to do with them, but they won't back off.
additionalR:
Hints
You hold the key tightly in your hand and press your ear to the roof. You can still hear the odd person... thing(?) approaching. Hopefully this key keeps it away.
readingMnemonic: They approach too closely and you can't take it anymore. You run out from under the roof, slam the door closed, and lock it with a key (き).

meaningMnemonic: Under a roof, but still in the sun, a woman is laying out a fabulous banquet. The woman doesn't want anyone to burn from the sun, but banquets are best outside, so she's set up a roof to protect her and her guests.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a large banquet of food on a sunny day, covered by an outdoor roof, and a woman carefully setting it all up.
additionalR:
Hints
Honestly though, have you ever been to a banquet that ended well? Something always goes wrong when you have that many people under one roof.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the banquet roof comes crashing down right before the guests arrive, and it ends (えん) before it can start.

meaningMnemonic: If you're anti-tree, you won't mind if I turn all of them into boards! Hahaha!
additionalM:
Hints
"Boards are much more useful than trees." - The Anti-Tree Association. Now picture this sign on a big machine that's cutting up all the trees into big boards.
additionalR:
Hints
"Hey kid, I got nothin' against the trees. Business is business, and these trees are gonna get me out of debt," Han says, mussing up your hair. You don't know if you like him anymore.
readingMnemonic: These boards are now being sold to Han (はん) Solo, who's wearing Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses, and who's going to smuggle them all over the universe.

meaningMnemonic: You set up a net on a cross to wash your clothes in the river, when a huge wave of dirt smashes into it, breaking the whole thing and sending your clothes tumbling down the river.
additionalM:
Hints
Oh, why did it have to break! If the net had been strong enough, your clothes wouldn't be even more dirty and lost down the river right now.
additionalR:
Hints
"Hey you, kayak lovers!" you scream, "How dare you break my stuff, I'll get you and all the kayaks out there! You'll pay!"
readingMnemonic: You angrily search to see what caused your clothes washing machine to break and you see some kayaks (かい) upriver. The people in the kayaks are jumping around, kicking dirt up, which is what broke your stuff.

meaningMnemonic: Above you, on a small stool is the eye of your coach. He's really high above you though, and all you can make out is the glint of his eye as he perches on that stool. But he's yelling out orders and corrections, which you can hear very well.
additionalM:
Hints
Look up from the field or court and see the eye of your coach shining down and watching you closely. It makes you uncomfortable, honestly.
additionalR:
Hints
Coach Tokugawa hovers before you, in full shougun garb, and nods his head in approval, winks, then disappears.
readingMnemonic: You finally win the big game and the coach is coming down off of his stool, and you see that's he's the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu!!! That explains why you could only ever make out his eyeball!

meaningMnemonic: A good leader will use charcoal to mark her colleagues. Sometimes if leaders aren't around all the time, people will get rebellious and act badly toward people who can get them in trouble. So when you mark them with charcoal you know that someone close with your leader is around and you should probably stop being a butt.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing one of the leader's colleagues walking around, watching you. You'd get back to work and stop goofing around, right?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine goofing off in your row boat and then seeing one of the colleagues waiting on the shore for you. No! She's gonna take your row boat away!
readingMnemonic: You have to be good around her colleagues, because if you aren't your row (りょう) boat permit will be taken away. Row boating is the only fun you ever get to have, besides learning kanji. So act as best you can around the leader's colleagues so you don't lose your row boat rights.

meaningMnemonic: A tree is not a cup of liquid or a counter for cups. Don’t get them mixed up. The last time you tried making a cup out of a tree to count your throat got filled with splinters when you used it. There wasn't even any liquid in it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine cutting a tree into a cup of liquid and focus on the pain in your throat when you try to actually use it. Instead you kick the tree and angrily count cups of liquid in your head, because they simply are NOT the same.
additionalR:
Hints
Think of a haiku about a cup of liquid and a counter for cups. Use that haiku to help remember this kanji.
readingMnemonic: Another way to remember the counter for cups using a cup of liquid would be by creating and memorizing a haiku (はい) about them. Aren’t haikus useful?

meaningMnemonic: A woman who is good is my daughter. My daughter is a good woman, I guarantee it.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at how good this woman is! She’s my daughter! She’s good! You wish your daughter was as good a woman as mine is!
additionalR:
Hints
Think about how your daughter is basically a moose who may do dumb things. How ashamed you feel. How very, very ashamed. Unlike how I feel about my wonderful, perfect, not a moose-like daughter.
readingMnemonic: Your daughter, on the other hand, is not a good woman. Your daughter looks like a moose who may (むすめ) not be able to find its way out of a wet paper bag. Your daughter looks like a moose who may lose its way without a map. Your daughter looks like a moose who may do lots of stupid things.

meaningMnemonic: They say to wear a hat to cover your hair if your doctor diagnoses you with hair loss. It's the best option, folks.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the doctor diagnosing you with hair loss. He pulls out a hat and places it on your poor, thinning hair.
additionalR:
Hints
Hold your shin as you feel the throbbing pain in it. Even though the pain is so extreme, you can’t help but still think about the diagnosis you got from the doctor.
readingMnemonic: You just had the doctor diagnose you with hair loss. How terrible! You stumble out of the room, dumbfounded. Not paying attention, you bang your shin (しん) on the table. Your shin really hurts. What an awful day.

meaningMnemonic: In the morning, you use a gun on your nose to make it dry.
additionalM:
Hints
Don't worry, there aren't bullets in the gun. It's an air gun! So just imagine shooting the air into your nose every morning to make sure it's nice and dry.
additionalR:
Hints
Now the next time you manage to get your nose nice and dry, think back to our founding father Genghis Khan and thank him for where you are today.
readingMnemonic: This technique for a nice dry nose was invented by Genghis Khan (かん)! Well, not him, but someone who worked under him. You see, he had a bit of a damp nose problem.

meaningMnemonic: A district that lacks things will be in Europe.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a map of Europe in your mind. Now picture little words saying which district is lacking what. This one is lacking water. That one is lacking food.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so maybe this is an old view of Europe. But back in the old days the 王s there would take everything from their subjects, so every district would lack something. Good thing things aren't that way now, huh?
readingMnemonic: Europe is lacking so much because their 王 (おう) keeps taking everything.

meaningMnemonic: A saw cuts into your heart and you are filled with fear. Well, you were filled with fear before the saw reached your heart too, but now that the saw is cutting into your heart, you’re feeling more fear than ever.
additionalM:
Hints
Try and imagine this saw slicing into your heart. Are you filled with fear? You should be.
additionalR:
Hints
I fear you’ll never make it to きょうと. Think of きょうと and how you long for it as you slowly die from that saw wound to the heart.
readingMnemonic: Even more so than your fear of dying, you are filled with the fear that you’ll never get to vacation in きょうと. You always wanted to take a trip to きょうと, but if you die from this saw wound to the heart, you’ll never get the chance to go.

meaningMnemonic: An animal eats a child from a plate in a very fierce manner. This is a fierce animal, so it makes sense that it would eat the child in a fierce style.
additionalM:
Hints
See the fierce animal fiercely eating the child from the plate. It’s very gruesome. See blood and body parts flying everywhere as the animal devours the child.
additionalR:
Hints
That child really shouldn’t have forgotten to mow the lawn. Imagine you are the child, being eaten by the fierce animal and wishing that you would have just mowed the lawn like you said you would.
readingMnemonic: The reason this fierce animal is eating the child from the plate is because the child forgot to mow (もう) the animal’s lawn. The fierce animal had hired the child to mow his lawn today, and when the child forgot to do it, the fierce animal hunted the child down and ate him.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami rolls in and destroys all the construction that was being done on the inlet and the bay. Both the inlet and the bay were having a lot of construction done on them to repair the damage from the last tsunami, and then another tsunami rolled in and destroyed all that too. Bummer.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all the construction on the bay and the inlet getting destroyed by the tsunami. Look at all of it fall apart and crash to the ground as the tsunami knocks it down. Imagine yourself right near the action, feeling the water spray from the tsunami.
additionalR:
Hints
EH? A tsunami you say? Those construction areas are screwed, man. Again, imagine the tsunami demolishing the area. Then be all like, “Eh? A tsunami? Aw, man.”
readingMnemonic: Imagine the Japanese people standing on the bay and the inlet as the tsunami approaches. “Eh (え)? What is that, Akiko?” “Eh? Where? Oh gawd, it’s a tsunami!!”

meaningMnemonic: In the morning, Korea will still be Korea.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture Korea first thing in the morning. You can see all the cities, the countryside, everything waking up.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Genghis Khan admiring Korea from afar, but letting it live on.
readingMnemonic: Korea is still here today on this beautiful morning because of Genghis Khan (かん). When he was conquering all that land in Asia and Europe he looked at Korea in the morning light and said, "Nah, they can keep it."

meaningMnemonic: The narwhal and the turkey are meeting in private to uh, show each other some private things. Doing this they realize they're both male!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a male narwhal and a male turkey meeting together in private. Whispering. Giggling. Pointing at each other's male bits.
additionalR:
Hints
It's just nature. Youths like to learn and try new things. And if two male youth animals wanna get together in private that's their business.
readingMnemonic: These male animals are obviously experimenting with things still. Ah, they must be youths (ゆう)!  To be a youth, again!

meaningMnemonic: On every boat there is a table with a lid on it that's used for navigation. When you take the lid off, there is a big map, a sextant, and some little boat miniatures. All the navigation tools.
additionalM:
Hints
You forget to put the lid back on the navigation station and all those tools and boat pieces go flying around the boat and into the water. Oops.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this seafaring こういち angrily chasing you around the ruined navigation station, trying to hit you with a telescope.
readingMnemonic: You watch the navigation equipment roll away and then you feel a slap on the back of your head. Ouch! You turn around and there stands こういち, who you took with you as the navigator of this expedition. And, you just lost all his stuff!

meaningMnemonic: To the servant you say: "gun, ground, plate." It is your job to oversee everything they do.
additionalM:
Hints
You point to the gun. You point to the ground (that's where the gun goes). You point to the plate (you want it). You have to oversee everything the servant does.
additionalR:
Hints
If anyone had to oversee a lot, it was Genghis Khan, who had one of the largest kingdoms in all of history.
readingMnemonic: Why must you oversee everything? Because you are Genghis Khan (かん), and Genghis Khan oversees everything.

meaningMnemonic: Under this roof you jackhammer your religion into people.
additionalM:
Hints
It's a religion building. They have a lot of different names, churches, mosques, temples, cathedrals, but none of those matter. All that matters is that you really drill whichever religion you want into the heads of the people who come under your roof.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the pile of shoes left outside. If you see a bunch of shoes like this you can be sure there's a religious place around here.
readingMnemonic: Your religion requires everyone to take off their shoes (しゅう). Mostly because the shoes will help them resist the jackhammering, so you tell them that to join your religion they have to leave their shoes at the door.

meaningMnemonic: If what you say comes out blue, everyone knows that means you made a request. You request a favor and the words slide out of your mouth in a bright, blue blob. They hover in front of you for a few seconds, before splashing onto the person you made the request to.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this blue, slimy request. You could have done that thing by yourself, but you requested it of someone else, and now it's all over and everyone can see it.
additionalR:
Hints
Now they have the blue request gunk on them, and you can walk away as your already-blue sword absorbs the rest. Oh, and you don't have to fulfill the request (bonus!).
readingMnemonic: The next time someone requests something from you, take out your saber (せい) and slice it in half!
mainReading: せい, しん, しょう

meaningMnemonic: The soul of a narwhal was sucked into its towel, which is scary!
additionalM:
Hints
Watch as the narwhal's face contorts as you see its soul get slurped out by the towel it was using.
additionalR:
Hints
You don't know what's more scary. That the narwhal's soul got sucked out, or that all of its kind is calling it a fool now that it's dead.
readingMnemonic: As you watch this scary scene you can't help but mutter, "Fool," (ふ) under your breath. Then you hear "Fool, fool, fool, it's too scary you fool!" and you realize all of the other narwhals are chanting.

meaningMnemonic: There is a cross in your forehead with a thread attached to it, forcing you to search where it leads. You’re not sure how the cross got stuck in your forehead, but you are interested in seeing where this piece of thread leads. The search is on.
additionalM:
Hints
It hurts to have this cross stuck in your forehead, but try to ignore that as you search for where the thread leads. Imagine gathering the thread in your hands as you move along.
additionalR:
Hints
Why are there more crosses and threads in the sack? Are you supposed to take them from the sack and throw them at other people’s foreheads? Maybe. Imagine yourself reaching into the sack and throwing the crosses at other people.
readingMnemonic: Your search is over. You found the end of the thread. The thread leads you to a sack (さく). A sack filled with more crosses with more threads attached to them. What does it all mean!?!

meaningMnemonic: The servant radical and the servant kanji are exactly the same! Just remember that the kanji also means retainer and you’ll be fine.
additionalM:
Hints
Retainer and servant are basically the same thing, so remembering this one shouldn’t be too hard for you.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your servant banging his shins on everything in your house. Hand him a pair of jeans and tell him to put them on to soften the blows.
readingMnemonic: Your servant, also known as your retainer, bangs his shins (しん) all the time so you make him wear jeans (じん) to work now. He bangs his shins on all the furniture in the house, knocking over all your valuables. But at least when he’s wearing jeans it doesn’t leave bruises like it did when he wasn’t wearing pants.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the mountain turkeys is our sponsor. He's paying us to say and type everything you're reading.
additionalM:
Hints
This message is brought to you by our generous sponsor, the leader of the mountain turkeys. Long may he reign.
additionalR:
Hints
Turn your cyborg over and you'll see a stamp under one of its feet. It says, "Sponsored by" with a little picture of a turkey on top a mountain.
readingMnemonic: This same sponsor is also how you made your cyborg (さい). You didn't think you were able to get all those body parts yourself, did you? No no, the leader of the mountain turkeys sponsored you so you could do your experiments.

meaningMnemonic: The dirt you use to go from place to place is the street. Back in the old days, all roads were made of dirt, not like the newfangled roads of today.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine using a dirt street to go from one place to another.
additionalR:
Hints
You walk away from the two guys yelling and head down a different street. You hope all streets aren't full of loud guys.
readingMnemonic: As you're walking down the street, staring at the dirt, a guy (がい) bumps into you, "Hey guy, watch where you're going!" As he says this he bumps into another guy. "Watch it guy, I'm walkin' in this street!" "Woah guy, this isn't your business, this is my street!"

meaningMnemonic: Say good luck to one person enough and they'll be stuffed full of that luck.
additionalM:
Hints
Better safe than sorry. Don't just say good luck once, make sure they're stuffed!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a person with the actual words "good luck" stuffed into their body.
readingMnemonic: You stuffed them by saying good luck two (つ) whole times!

meaningMnemonic: The servant sits on a stool, holding a piece of thread, looking very tense.
additionalM:
Hints
You walk by this tense servant and pause for a moment. They raise their tense eyes up at you and you can see they're shaking.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how tense you would be if you were about to try to murder the King! Your entire body would tense up, maybe to the point that you wouldn't be able to actually go through with it.
readingMnemonic: You ask the servant why they're so tense, and they say they've been assigned to assassinate the King (きん) of England with this piece of thread.

meaningMnemonic: At the gate, you kiss the cabinet members, one by one. In order to gain access to this government building, you have to kiss all the members of the cabinet at the gate. What a strange ritual.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine kissing all the members of the cabinet. A lot of them are old men. Imagine kissing all of them at the gate. Eww.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself sneaking past the cabinet members, finding your cock, grabbing it, and getting out of there. You’ve recovered your rooster! The day is won.
readingMnemonic: You need to kiss each member of the cabinet to gain access to their building. And you need to get into the building to recover your cock (かく). Your prize winning cock has been captured by a member of the cabinet and you need to infiltrate their headquarters and recover your rooster!

meaningMnemonic: Your leader sees your bare foot and urges you to put a sock on it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your leader's face when he sees your bare foot, and just how emphatic he is as he urges you to put a sock on it. He's really worried your foot's going to get cold!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel this sock on your foot. It feels great. Wiggle your toes around inside the sock as you think about how glad you are that you did as your leader urged. Note that this kanji also has the same reading as 足, so keep that in mind too!
readingMnemonic: As urged, you put a sock (そく) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock.

meaningMnemonic: When a yakuza's knife boils, you know something very violent and intense is about to happen.
additionalM:
Hints
The yakuza member is so upset his knife boils. Right after, they will definitely get violent and intense.
additionalR:
Hints
In the case of our mnemonic, it's a yakuza member getting violent. So, imagine a yakuza member saying "Ret's get violent!" before doing just that.
readingMnemonic: When someone gets violent or intense, they always yell "Let's (れつ) get violent and intense!"

meaningMnemonic: In the ground of the rice paddy is a treasure. You pull it out of the mucky ground. This will renew your life for the better. Again, this treasure will change your life!
additionalM:
Hints
Pull out the treasure. Think about all the things you will be able to renew in your life. Your car. Your boat. Your house. You lost it all but now you'll be able to get it back.
additionalR:
Hints
Yell at こういち to give your treasure back. Then, fall to the muck as you realize you won't be able to renew your life anymore.
readingMnemonic: Again, you are going to renew your life! Everything will be better. Then, the person who caused all this grief grabs your treasure and runs. こういち is running off with the treasure that was supposed to renew your life!

meaningMnemonic: A demon on a jet is pretty alluring. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring.
additionalM:
Hints
See this demon flying around in his jet. Do you feel allured? You should. Hear the roar of the jet engine as the demon cackles.
additionalR:
Hints
The demon won’t be so alluring once you see him scarfing down humans, tearing the meat from their bones. How gross.
readingMnemonic: This alluring demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. Meat (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat.

meaningMnemonic: You fly north to the moon and break your back when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine flying north to the moon. Feel the force of being rocketed through space on your journey. Now feel your spine telescope and your back break. It really smarts.
additionalR:
Hints
Say this haiku out loud. Memorize it and use this haiku to remember this kanji.
readingMnemonic: Your back hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in haiku (はい) form.

meaningMnemonic: A horse gets trapped in a small room with a stool and an insect, and together they create a very boisterous situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the boisterous sounds coming from this small room. Hear the horse neigh and stomp his hooves, hear the insect buzzing loudly, and hear the wooden stool rattle around as the horse and insect try to escape the room.
additionalR:
Hints
The horse gets even more frightened now that it killed the insect and saw an actual soul float by its head and it grows even more boisterous.
readingMnemonic: At the height of their boisterous sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the soul (そう) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling.

meaningMnemonic: When you eat you want to see the shape of your gun from under a towel, so you decorate your house with them.
additionalM:
Hints
Just picture it: an entire home decorated top to bottom with guns covered in towels, so only the outline shows. As your guests try to eat you say, "Guess what gun this is?! Haha, you got it wrong, pull the towel back."
additionalR:
Hints
Maybe you should be more conscious of other people when you decorate. Or at least, don't shock people into fainting or yelling or leaving. Guns do that, you know?
readingMnemonic: If you actually decorate your house like this it will give people quite a shock (しょく). In fact, they might be so shocked they run out of there screaming.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to buy a geoduck you have to go to the bank beforehand to deposit enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy even one! They're expensive, after all.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself depositing your money beforehand. Imagine the delicious geoduck you'll be able to buy now that the money has been deposited into your account!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to make a deposit to your bank after getting hit in the face with a yo-yo. You can hardly see what you're shoving your money into. You hope it isn't the hands of the kid that hit you!
readingMnemonic: You go to the bank to make the deposit and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a yo-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo! Now you can't see! Now you can't make the deposit!

meaningMnemonic: If you are anti one sided paper you should bind them all up into an edition.
additionalM:
Hints
One sided paper is just anti everything. It's bad for the environment. It's bad for easy reading. Put all those one sided papers together into one, big edition instead.
additionalR:
Hints
Please read my super special Han Solo edition of the Star Wars story. I ripped out all the one sided pages that had him in it and put them into a single edition together so it's just the good stuff now.
readingMnemonic: The first edition you create is a fan fiction all about the adventures of Han (はん) Solo. You hated how short and one sided his story in Star Wars seemed to be, and trying to keep track of it all was really hard. But not anymore!

meaningMnemonic: Traveling in the direction of the ocean, you take a gun and shoot a crab, then stick a flag in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at your flag and hear it flapping in the wind. Also hear your ears ringing a bit from when you shot that crab. Look at all the bits of exploded crab strewn around the area. Yowza.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself locking this flag up with your key. Imagine turning the key in the lock and hearing the click when it is secured.
readingMnemonic: To make sure that no one removes your flag, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the key (き). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami knocks a cleat off a child and the shoe begins to float away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami.
additionalM:
Hints
Your cleat is floating away but you’re floating too. The water is really deep now, but you try and float towards your cleat to retrieve it. Imagine floating in this wet water reaching for your lost cleat.
additionalR:
Hints
Say “Uwaaa~” out loud a few times while you imagine an うに stabbing you as you float along with the tsunami water. What a day you’ve had.
readingMnemonic: While you float in the water, an uni (う) jabs into your foot. “Uwaaa~ (うわ)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~”

meaningMnemonic: You run every day and soon you become a human that can go beyond the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast.
additionalM:
Hints
Run fast! Go beyond the limits imposed upon you by nature! Imagine yourself running faster than any human has ever run ever. Feel yourself cutting through the air, wind breaking across you as you break the sound barrier. Boom!
additionalR:
Hints
Etch these runes into your legs. Go ahead and run a finger over your legs and pretend to etch runes into them. These runes you etch will allow you to run fast forever.
readingMnemonic: To solidify your ability to go beyond the abilities of other humans, you etch (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate.

meaningMnemonic: The sun is being called on to boil the earth by illuminating it.
additionalM:
Hints
We don't want the earth to actually boil, but we do want some of that boiling hot sun light to illuminate all of the darkness of the universe and let us see.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun calling out to the sun, asking it to illuminate our planet with its boiling hot rays. You better thank the Shougun the next time you see him for everything he does for you.
readingMnemonic: The person who calls the sun asking it to illuminate the earth is the Shougun (しょう). It's very specifically the Shougun's responsibility to make sure the earth is illuminated every morning.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami rips a flag off your house in the rain, causing a leak where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this leak in your house and see the rain water coming in. Hear it drip drip dripping down the wall.
additionalR:
Hints
Did you know that roe can plug any leak? It’s true. If you don’t mind wasting some, you should break a leak into your own house and then try to plug it back up again with some salmon roe.
readingMnemonic: The leak is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of roe (ろう) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm!

meaningMnemonic: The lineage radical and the lineage kanji are the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
You come from a lineage of cake makers and eaters. No wonder you love cake so much! (And if you hate cake, no wonder your family doesn't like you.)
readingMnemonic: You trace your lineage back and realize that every single person in your family loved cake (けい). Most of them were cake bakers, too!

meaningMnemonic: A servant holding a gun sits on the ground to see if he can find something to look at. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this servant. He’s doing a great job. Oops, look like he sees you. Yup, he’s pointing his gun at you. Imagine staring down the barrel of his gun as you slowly back away.
additionalR:
Hints
Pretend you are Macho Man Randy Savage. Run at this servant guy, take his gun away, and beat him up. Ohhh yeaaahhh!
readingMnemonic: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man Randy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, look at this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him.

meaningMnemonic: You meet a woman from another clan under the rising sun to prepare for marriage. Your clan and her clan are standing together as the two of you watch the sun rise together.
additionalM:
Hints
Marriage is a big deal and it's going to connect your two clans, so you have to do the ceremony in the sun in front of everyone so they can see.
additionalR:
Hints
