Do you want to go through with this marriage? You better hope you see a condor then! It's the official bird of love and unification, ya know. That's why so many people wait until they're older to get married these days, because there aren't as many condors thanks to deforestation.
readingMnemonic: For the marriage to be official, you need to wait for a condor (こん) to appear. If it doesn't show up before the sun goes down again, the marriage was a failure. You have to try again tomorrow with a different woman.

meaningMnemonic: Your soul will cross through your body and into the net of your clothes so that you'll be hit with nostalgia when you wear them again. Nostalgia for all the things that happened every single time you wore those clothes.
additionalM:
Hints
When you put on an old piece of clothing, a shirt maybe, or some pants, feel the nostalgia that was embedded in it and left there by your soul.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel these nostalgic knots inside you. Now tie knots in the clothes that make you feel nostalgic so you don't wear them again.
readingMnemonic: This nostalgia ties knots (なつ) in your stomach and your chest. Even if the memories and feelings weren't particularly bad, there's something about the wistful feeling of nostalgia that knots up your insides.

meaningMnemonic: You put your fingers and an ear on a stool in the sun so you can get your photograph taken. This is a glamour photo, so you have to be in one of these weird, cheesy poses for it to come out jusssst right.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting your fingers and your ear on a stool, now try to relax your head a little bit, and smile for the camera. This is a professional photograph, so you better do what you're told!
additionalR:
Hints
You've never gotten a professional photograph taken before, but if you had known if you sat(s) down you'd ruin the shot you never would have. Remember everyone, if you sat down while your photo was being taken, you ruined it.
readingMnemonic: As you're getting the photograph taken, the photographer suddenly gets angry at you. "You sat (さつ) down!" he screams. "I sat down?" you ask. "Yes! And now the photo is ruined!"

meaningMnemonic: The tree pirate jumps from a tree and attacks you by hitting you with a pillow.
additionalM:
Hints
It hurts a little bit, but the fact that tree pirates use pillows as their weapons is a bit anticlimactic.
additionalR:
Hints
You give him your Mac cooler and he goes on his way. He's quite happy he can cool down his Mac, now. The trees are quite warm and he hears this will help to cool down his tree apples.
readingMnemonic: As he hits you with his pillow he makes a demand: "Give me your Mac cooler (まくら). He wants the device that cools down your Mac computer.

meaningMnemonic: On a scooter running in one direction is a gun-toting child. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just play.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a child riding a scooter with a gun having a good time. "Come play with me!" they shout. "No!" you yell back.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to explain to the youth that this is not play and that they should stop, but them youths can't stop playing.
P.S. From the WaniKani staff to you: Don't let youths play with guns, please.
readingMnemonic: Everything is play for youths (ゆう), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one.

meaningMnemonic: The soul of a person has a hook that can make them pleasant. When you see, hear, or feel something pleasant, can't you feel that hook pressing into the middle of your body?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine that feeling you get when everything is just SO pleasant. There is a pressure from your soul's hook digging in. It's a good feeling though, a pleasant one! It isn't too hard or too soft.
additionalR:
Hints
Go look up pictures of kayaks to get some of that pleasant high. Mm, your soul is hooking you real good.
readingMnemonic: If you want to feel this pleasant feeling just look at a kayak (かい). Kayaks are the most pleasant boats in the world. Feel that pleasant feeling in your chest just from reading about kayaks in this mnemonic right now.

meaningMnemonic: Those that can only eat a part of a shellfish are probably a bit poor.
additionalM:
Hints
Poor people can't even afford a whole shellfish. They have to settle with just a part.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a poor person going through a garbage bin to find only a part of of a shellfish. What a sad sight.
readingMnemonic: And since they are poor, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash bin (びん). It's quite unfortunate.

meaningMnemonic: If you do yoga correctly, you will not only prolong your body but your life!
additionalM:
Hints
Do you want to prolong your life? Then do yoga correctly!
additionalR:
Hints
Correct yoga will prolong your life but no yoga will end it. Do you think that's a fair trade?
readingMnemonic: You can prolong your life with correct yoga techniques, but unfortunately, if you ever stop doing yoga after you've started this prolonging process, it will just end (えん) suddenly.

meaningMnemonic: Take your fingers, put them on this turtle shell, and push push push! Push the turtle right on out of there.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself using your fingers to push a turtle out of its shell. It really doesn't want to leave, so you have to push really hard.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine pushing some turtle shells flat to make a beautiful obi. Wear it out, watch everyone gasp in awe. Oh... oh no! They're trying to push you out of your obi like you did the turtle. They're mad about your turtle crime!
readingMnemonic: You're trying to push this turtle out so you can use the shell for your new obi (お). You keep seeing other people wearing turtle shell patterns on their obi, but you're going to go a step further. You're going to MAKE your obi out of actual turtle shells! You just have to push this darn turtle out first.

meaningMnemonic: If you look for a leaf among the hills you will notice they are scarce. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being on the hills. You want a leaf to find and take back as a souvenir but there are none. Imagine looking feverishly for a leaf even though you don’t really expect to find one.
additionalR:
Hints
Leaves are scarce here because someone is using these hills for their bowling. The bowling balls knock over everything, and leaves can't grow.
readingMnemonic: Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too scarce to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a giant bowling (ぼう) ball. As you pick it up, another one comes thundering down the hill knocking over a tiny tree.

meaningMnemonic: You're in prison and all you have is a spoon. You use that prison spoon to scoop up nice scents and fragrances out of the air when you have outdoor time and bring them back into your cell.
additionalM:
Hints
It smells really bad in prison, but your prison spoon is full of all of the lovely scents you remember from when you were free.
additionalR:
Hints
Try to come up with some neo-scents right now. This is neo-laundry, this is neo-flowers, and this is neo-delicious-steak I'll never get to eat because I'm in prison sniffing a spoon.
readingMnemonic: You can't remember what any of these scents are anymore, you've been in prison for so long, so you call them all neo-scents (にお). They're neo, they're new.

meaningMnemonic: The next plate is the one you will steal. This one would be too obvious, better wait for the next one.
additionalM:
Hints
Wait for this next plate. Here it is—now steal it! Imagine stealing this plate and making off with it.
additionalR:
Hints
Be careful not to drop that plate! Wouldn’t want to steal something just to break it. Imagine running through the streets of とうきょう. See all the sights and hear all the sounds. Just don’t get too distracted, you gotta get to a safe place and stash your stolen plate away.
readingMnemonic: You steal this plate from a とうきょう restaurant, so after you steal it, picture yourself running through the streets of とうきょう as you lose your pursuers.

meaningMnemonic: Picture a shellfish lifeguard. They're not going anywhere. First, they're a shellfish, so they can't really move. And, they're a lifeguard, so they need to be in their lifeguard tower. How does this shellfish lifeguard get stuff? Through subscription services.
additionalM:
Hints
See a bunch of subscription boxes around the lifeguard tower. It gets everything this way.
additionalR:
Hints
See the shellfish lifeguard drooling as its こういち magazine subscription arrives. "I will read this one now, but I can't wait until next month," it says as a boat sinks in the distance.
Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.
readingMnemonic: The shellfish lifeguard's favorite subscription is its subscription to こういち magazine. It has all the latest こういち versions, news, and interviews.

meaningMnemonic: A scooter with a mohawk, now that's the most suitable hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter!
additionalM:
Hints
You keep seeing scooters all over the city with mohawks and you can't get it out of your head that it's the most suitable thing you've ever seen.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine going online to check out some of your techie message boards and learning the most suitable mohawk for your scooter then installing it yourself.
readingMnemonic: You want this suitable hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a techie (てき), so it's easy for you to install one.

meaningMnemonic: There are some feathers resting on a stand and you and the following of the feathers are following the feathers. The feathers have a following, and you are one member of the following. You and your fellow followers follow the feathers wherever they may go.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you and the following following the feathers all around. Following the feathers isn’t always easy, but you do it anyway. Imagine touching one of the feathers and feeling the smooth texture on your skin.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine cleaning up egg yolk with a feather. The rest of the following follows your example and takes the other feathers, helping you clean up the yolk.
readingMnemonic: While you and the following are following the feathers from their departure from the stand, one of the members of the following drops an egg and yolk (よく) spills everywhere. What a mess! Being a quick thinker, you use one of the feathers to soak up the yolk and clean up the mess.

meaningMnemonic: You're stuck in a prison on the sun with nothing but a spoon. Lucky for you a tsunami is coming, so you take your spoon and use the tsunami to quench your thirst. You spoon the hot, hot water into your mouth as fast as you can. This is the only way to get water on the sun.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this thirst of yours. You've been in this sun prison for longer than you can remember. You've been holding onto this spoon, waiting for this moment for so long.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine quenching your thirst in a real car wash. Open your mouth and let the soapy water dump on over and in you. You'll never be thirsty again!
readingMnemonic: This method of quenching your thirst reminds you of being in a car wash (かわ). The water pours over you in waves, and you're stuck inside a metal cage. Totally the same thing as a car wash, right?

meaningMnemonic: You take some bamboo and attach it together into a token of appreciation for your friend. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to attach some bamboo together into a token for someone.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the embarrassment you feel, forgetting they were allergic to bamboo. Oh well, it’s the thought that counts. You’re still a fool, though.
readingMnemonic: You hand over the token but your friend drops it and yells, "You fool (ふ)! I'm allergic to bamboo!"

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami hits, it's raining, and you're outside trying to use a rake, you're going to be very wet and damp.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how wet and damp you'd be with tsunami water up to your knees and rain pouring down on your head. You struggle with your rake anyway.
additionalR:
Hints
You're still wet, but at least you don't have the feeling of damp clothes touching your body now. You'll have to be really careful raking in the nude though.
readingMnemonic: You can't stand how wet and damp you feel in these clothes so you rip them off and rake in the nude (ぬ)!

meaningMnemonic: There's a mountain coming out of the ground that you want to climb, but your forehead needs a towel for all your sweat. You don't have a towel, so you take off your belt and tie it around your forehead.
additionalM:
Hints
The belt is easy to tighten and it catches all the sweat before it can fall into your eyes. It isn't quite as absorbent as a towel though.
additionalR:
Hints
It works! Your belt tied in a tie is the perfect invention!
readingMnemonic: The belt isn't absorbent enough, so you wrap it in your tie (たい) and then tie the whole thing around your forehead again.

meaningMnemonic: The canopy guy is a guy who stands in the corridor trying to sell people canopies.
additionalM:
Hints
You walk through this corridor every day, and the canopy guy always accosts you with canopy sales. You wish there was another corridor you could take, but it's the only way to get where you want to go.
additionalR:
Hints
The roe salesman in the corridor is worse than the canopy salesman. They're both insistent, but the roe salesman smells bad.
readingMnemonic: You take the corridor, but this time the canopy guy is gone. In his place is a new salesman. This one is trying to sell you roe (ろう).

meaningMnemonic: The rocket turkey has several points which will detach during takeoff.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the rocket turkey taking off. Just like a regular rocket, as it goes up, used pieces of the turkey rocket detach and fall back to the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
The reeds catch on fire - probably best not to fire off turkey rockets so close to these fields of reeds. Imagine the launch site completely surrounded by reeds.
readingMnemonic: When the rocket turkey parts detach, they fall to the ground onto a bed of reeds り.

meaningMnemonic: You loiter around a tombstone to measure its diameter. You’re doing this to each tombstone, and if you loiter around long enough, you’ll soon know the diameter of every tombstone.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine loitering around a tombstone. You're leaning on it. You're staring at nothing. Oh, and you're also measuring its diameter.
additionalR:
Hints
These carefully measured tombstone-diameter cakes are your special way of saying thanks to the ghosts for letting you loiter around their graves.
readingMnemonic: You need to know the diameter of each tombstone so you can make cakes (けい) for each one. But the cakes can't be wider than the tombstones, or they'll flop off onto the ground.

meaningMnemonic: You see a bully take an insect and dissolve it in some acid. Bullies are messed up, mean people. They do awful things that normal kids and people wouldn't do... like dissolve a living creature.
additionalM:
Hints
Actually... try to forget this one. Don't think about a bully dissolving things in acid. Think happy thoughts. Like... the bully getting dissolved instead and all the little insects coming back to life and being happy.
additionalR:
Hints
When you first read this and you pictured the bully dissolving the insect, you pictured them as a youth, right? See? It makes complete sense.
readingMnemonic: The only bullies heartless enough to dissolve insects like this are youths (ゆう). Do you really think an adult would melt a harmless critter? No. Only inexperienced youths could be so cruel.

meaningMnemonic: You have some dirt next to a pool that has an extra drop of water in it because you need them to be equal. If there's too much dirt outside the pool and not enough water inside, it's gonna look weird. We can't have that.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing a pool that isn't equal. It's like a tiny kiddy pool with an inch of water. And it's surrounded by mounds of dirt. No no no, this won't do—add more water to make them equal.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so the existence of a king kind of makes things not, well, equal, for all people. But at least aesthetically everything will be!
readingMnemonic: You spend a few hours making sure the water-to-dirt ratio is perfectly equal, not for yourself, but because the King (きん) of England told you to. You may agree that equality is important, but it's the King's responsibility to keep things that way. Which is why he ordered you, small peon, to do the equalizing work for him.

meaningMnemonic: The buildings are at a surplus. Because of that, we will need to exclude some of them from our future plans. Also, we'll need to remove some buildings too.
additionalM:
Hints
Say you're looking at a map of the city, with all the buildings laid out on it. There are too many, so you start marking which ones to exclude from the building plans. You also remove some buildings from the map all together.
additionalR:
Hints
She's pointing out buildings to exclude / remove with great ferocity. "Remove this one. Exclude this one. Oh, and remove this one too."
readingMnemonic: Working with you on this project to exclude buildings from the plan, as well as remove buildings that already exist is little Jo-Anne (じょ).

meaningMnemonic: You want to change your shellfish into freight so you can transport it. That means packing them up into giant freight containers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine changing your shellfish from loose, wet form, to solid freight form. It's actually a lot of hard work.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of this freight stacked on top of your car. As you drive the car, every turn you make feels slow and heavy from the freight weight.
readingMnemonic: To move this freight, you need a car (か). You strap all of the freight containers to the top of your car, stacked nice and high and precarious, so you can move it.

meaningMnemonic: A child shares his lineage with a grandchild. The child passes his lineage down to his child and then that child’s child is the grandchild and between them all a lineage is shared.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this family tree. See the child, and then the grandchild. Trace the lineage with your finger as you observe.
additionalR:
Hints
Just remember that a son is all you really want. You need a son to carry on the family name and the lineage. So make sure that your child and your grandchild are both sons.
readingMnemonic: The son (そん) of a son is a grandchild. In this case, a grandson. Easy.

meaningMnemonic: There's a strange patch of dirt in this greenhouse that's actually a grave. Dig around a little and you'll find the marker buried in there. If you dig deeper you'll probably find less pleasant things.
additionalM:
Hints
I guess it makes sense to have a grave in a greenhouse. The heat will help the body decompose, then that nice, rich dirt will help the flowers grow.
additionalR:
Hints
Hold the grave bow in your hands. It smells like dirt and wood. Maybe no one will notice if you take it... though you may end up haunted by whoever is buried in this grave.
readingMnemonic: You decide to dig even deeper into the grave out of curiosity and you find a bow (ぼ) and some arrows. This must be the grave of a great archer! But you probably shouldn't keep digging around in this grave looking for more stuff.

meaningMnemonic: You poop twice on a sleeping drunkard person and you find yourself wondering how many more times you can poop on them and wonder how much they can take before they realize what’s going on.
additionalM:
Hints
You’ve already pooped twice on this drunkard, how many more times can you do it? How much do you think this person can take? Just imagine yourself doing this.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself as you eke out that last poop. Really concentrate on eking it out so you can get away in time. Flex your butt muscles for added effect.
readingMnemonic: As you continue thinking about how much poop this drunkard can take and how many more poops you can drop on him, he begins to wake up. Quickly, you eke (いく) out one last poop before you scurry away. You eke that poop out just in time to make your escape.

meaningMnemonic: Wolverine is doing a construction job and he’s using his mouth to measure so he knows how many folks he needs to inquire about helping him with the job. Using one’s mouth is a strange way to measure something, but that’s just how Wolverine does things. Once he measures it all out, he’ll know how many construction workers he needs to inquire about working for him.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine Wolverine going around, measuring the construction site with his mouth. Look at him with his mouth wide open, wandering around the site deep in thought. What a weirdo.
additionalR:
Hints
Look down at your ripped up jeans. You’re so fashionable now! Just like good old ‘90s Wolvie.
readingMnemonic: You decide to inquire as to why Wolverine is using his mouth to measure out this construction site. As you get closer you notice his cool ripped jeans (じん). Instead you inquire how he got such a fresh style. He looks you up and down, pulls out his claws, and tears yours up to match his. You’ve completely forgotten what it was you were asking, but who cares! Look how great you look!

meaningMnemonic: Bring thread to the library to knit. Libraries are quiet and generally pretty empty nowadays, so it's the perfect place to relax and do some knitting. Of course, if you find thread lying around in a library you know what to do now.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself sitting on a rocking chair in the library knitting away. It's quiet and peaceful and the light is warming you just right. Ahh, bliss!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the granny or grampy you are (and must be to have hens and want to knit in peace in a library). You're tired of these hens eating your thread while you try to knit sweaters for all your grandbabies so you come to the library.
readingMnemonic: You need to come to the library to knit because if you try to do it at home all your hens (へん) will try to eat the thread. Hens love eating things that look like worms, like hay, string, and thread. So it's important to get far away from them before you start to knit.

meaningMnemonic: A building made from a womb must be placed upon the land.
additionalM:
Hints
Why must it be placed upon the land? If it were put in water, it would dissolve too quickly. So, you put your womb building on the land, instead.
additionalR:
Hints
It's made of biological materials, so of course it will reek.
readingMnemonic: The land around your womb building will, unfortunately, reek (りく) though.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to get your fingers in the pi tree, you're going to have to look for it. This isn't a tree made of pie, or growing fully-baked pies. It's a pi tree, one that exists infinitely. It's the most rare tree in the world. And if you want to stick your fingers in it, you have to search for it, far and wide!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine it like a quest from a book or movie. You have a band of travelers, and you're all out searching for it together!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the sun's rays on your skin as you search and search and search for the tree. Watch as your skin gets darker, crispier, and hmm, smells like cooked meats. Now that's a good tan.
readingMnemonic: You try to look for the pi tree for so long that you can't help but get a very deep tan (たん). You can't search for anything inside, and you definitely can't find the pi tree inside, so you spend a lot of time outside in the bright sun.

meaningMnemonic: You put a lid on a dish you're cooking, made up of the mouths and foreheads of a pig. Unknown to most, these are the juiciest, most delicious parts of a pig. And dang, they are the most luxurious, too.
additionalM:
Hints
Mix those pig mouths and foreheads in your pot. Think of how luxurious your soup looks.
additionalR:
Hints
"Can I have some of your luxurious soup?" Grandpa Koichi asks. "It smells so swell."
readingMnemonic: Luxurious pig mouth forehead soup is a favorite of Grandpa Koichi (ごういち). You see him sniffing around your window, then he knocks and waves.

meaningMnemonic: You are given some gold to oversee a model. You are a famous architect, so you get a lot of gold for overseeing the construction of models like this one.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you oversee this model being built. Observe it and watch as it grows under your watchful eye.
additionalR:
Hints
You watch nervously as this model of Genghis Khan is finished. You're really not sure if this is who you were meant to model it after, but it's too late to change it now. Genghis Khan it is!
readingMnemonic: As the model nears completion, you realize it's taking the shape of Genghis Khan (かん). Was that what this was supposed to look like? You were so busy overseeing the gold in your pocket, you forgot!

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami came in and buried your flag so now you have to use a spoon and dig it out of the mud.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine using a spoon to dig your flag outta all this mud. So much mud! Feel its cold, soiled wetness on your hands as you dig away.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself out in the day, continuing to dig through the now hardened mud. Feel your arm getting tired as day slowly turns to night.
readingMnemonic: The time of day (でい) is high noon, so the sun soon dries the mud and makes it harder to dig through. It just might take you all day to spoon your way through this mud.

meaningMnemonic: Birds use grass and fruit to make their nests.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a cute little nest with a family of birds in it. It looks like it was woven together with bits of grass and strawberries, so it smells delicious too.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the nest, made of grass, fruit, and the suit of the angry salaryman who's shouting below the tree, and missing the top half of his suit.
readingMnemonic: The bottom of the nest also seems to be padded with someone's suit (す). Did... did this bird attack a human for this?!

meaningMnemonic: You line up your body with the sun and everything looks normal.  The sun is lined up behind you, and you’re looking at all the things the sun has lit up. Everything looks normal.
additionalM:
Hints
Gaze out in a line from the sun as you observe the world. Everything is very normal looking and comforting.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this creepy looking fool as he approaches. He’s kind of freaking you out. Feel very uncomfortable as you continue looking at this fool.
readingMnemonic: Soon you see something that doesn’t look so normal. It’s a fool (ふ), a jester. Dressed all in fool’s garb, this fool is dancing up towards you with a ridiculously unsettling grin on his face.

meaningMnemonic: A tree in spring that's nice and dry will make a good pole or rod. Break it out of the ground and it's just flexible enough for tons of applications.
additionalM:
Hints
Use this pole to hang your towels or curtains. Ooh, use it to pole vault!
additionalR:
Hints
You decide to name this super hard, pole bowling tree-pole-pin bowling. Even harder than candlepin. The thinnest, most extreme pole bowling of all time!
readingMnemonic: After much deliberation, you decide to use this pole to go bowling (ぼう). You line up a few more poles for the pins, and roll a rock toward them.

meaningMnemonic: If you grind rice, every part of it, eventually it will become a fine powder. You can then use this rice powder as a part to create some other dish. Some kind of cake, perhaps.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself grinding this rice into a powder. Hear the scrape of the rice on stone as you grind it down to the finest powder.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, we got a little carried away there. Just keep in mind how fun this is. Make sure you say fun with a little bit of a Scottish accent. You know what they say, Scots have more fun!
readingMnemonic: Actually, grinding the rice down to a powder is super fun (ふん). It’s so fun you don’t want to stop! AH HAHAHAHA! RICE POWDER! SO FUN!

meaningMnemonic: There's a root where your fang previously was. Your fang isn't there anymore, you ripped it out.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the root where your fang previously was. Previously, when you were young, you had a lot of nice fangs but they're all rotting as you get older and you pull them out.
additionalR:
Hints
Previously you didn't have a key, but now you do to keep your old fangs safe.
readingMnemonic: To remember the beautiful fangs you previously had, you keep all of the ones you pull out in a box you lock with a key (き).

meaningMnemonic: You request that winter rescue you from the warmth of the other seasons.
additionalM:
Hints
It's so hot. You hate it. You really hope winter will get your request and come early to rescue you.
additionalR:
Hints
This cucumber is supposed to be cool and refreshing enough to rescue you from the heat. I guess it was too much to expect winter to come early just for you. At least cucumbers are yummy.
readingMnemonic: You get a note in the mail from winter! This is it, you're going to be rescued! You open the note and it says, "I have rescued you with this cucumber (きゅう)." A cucumber falls out of the note.

meaningMnemonic: A leader of (odd looking) lions puts a drop of magic liquid on his face to look like a person who might resemble someone else. The leader of lions is going incognito, so he needs to resemble a person who is not himself. He takes this drop of powerful face paint and transforms.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch this leader as the transformation takes place. Now he doesn’t resemble anything like the leader he used to be. He doesn’t look like the same person. Watch him morph in your head.
additionalR:
Hints
Listen to this horse who used to be a leader neigh and stomp around. Hear the neigh in your ears as you try and calm the horse down.
readingMnemonic: The reason he doesn’t resemble the same person anymore is because he actually resembles a horse now. The leader is now a horse! Listen to him neigh (ね) and stamp his feet. Woah, easy there boy!

meaningMnemonic: On your roof is a scarecrow because you're rich. You want to scare away all the poor, non-rich people so you put a scarecrow on your roof.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking up at the roof at this scarecrow. There's a sign around its neck that says, "Rich people welcome." Ah, you're safe. Time to go to bed!
additionalR:
Hints
You poor sad, no longer rich fool.
readingMnemonic: You wake up the next morning and all of your riches have been stolen! You call the police and they call you a fool (ふ)! Pardon me?! "You basically put an advertisement on your roof telling everyone you're rich. Of course you got robbed, you fool."

meaningMnemonic: If you play blackjack on the moon in the winter, your cards will scatter everywhere. The cards scatter because the gravity is so weak on the moon, so the blackjack game is prone to disaster.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine playing blackjack on the moon where even the slightest move causes the cards to scatter about. Watch them float along. It’s very frustrating to play this way.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself next to Santa-san as he tries to prevent the cards from scattering. Look at the expression of concentration on Santa-san’s face as he tries to prevent the scatter.
readingMnemonic: You are playing blackjack with Santa-san (さん). Santa-san is doing his best to use his Christmas magic to prevent the scatter of cards, but it’s not working out so well. Good effort, Santa-san.

meaningMnemonic: Flowers growing out of a rice paddy into the shape of a cross are really showy flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture these showy flowers growing straight up and out of the middle of the rice paddy, into the shape of a giant cross.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how the car feels as you ram into the showy flowers. The petals explode and rain everywhere. You turn on your windshield wipers to push them away.
readingMnemonic: These flowers are too showy. You hate them. You hate these showy flowers so much you run them over with your car (か)!

meaningMnemonic: You use your mouth when you see a Chinese person and you sigh. You sigh so loud that it’s practically a roar coming out of your mouth. Chinese people and Chinese things make you sigh because it reminds you of when you stayed in China and it brings up memories. The sigh is a sigh of nostalgia.
additionalM:
Hints
Let out a long sigh as you recall memories from China and all the Chinese things you saw and did. Oh, sigh.
additionalR:
Hints
Sigh again as you remember how nice it was to tan everywhere. Picture yourself wandering around some Chinese streets with your shirt off as you soak in the rays and get a tan.
readingMnemonic: Your favorite Chinese thing to do is tan (たん). You can wander around without your shirt on and tan all day. No one will sigh or scoff at you, it’s perfectly acceptable. The Chinese just love to get their tan on.

meaningMnemonic: Your leader sticks his toe into a shellfish. You ask him why and he says he wants to spy on it.
additionalM:
Hints
There’s a hidden camera on his toe and the leader wants to have plenty of secret spy footage to review later.
additionalR:
Hints
If it wasn't for your toe spy network, these egregious tater tot crimes would have never reached the light of day.
readingMnemonic: You and the leader review the spy footage and find a single tater (てい) tot hidden within the shellfish. Together you uncover a huge smuggling ring. Clams, oysters, muscles, you name it! Shellfish of all kinds are using their bodies to sneak tater tots to the undersea world.

meaningMnemonic: If you can write an interesting poem about winter while riding on a horse, I’ll be pretty surprised. It’s hard enough to write a poem as it is, let alone an interesting one. And then you’re riding on a horse and the poem has to be about winter? Heck, I’d be surprised if you didn’t fall off the horse and injure yourself.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to write a poem while riding a horse. It’d be really hard to do. I bet you’d be surprised if you managed to do it as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine riding through きょうと on a horse. As if that wasn’t difficult enough for poem writing, now you have all the sights and sounds of きょうと to distract you as well.
readingMnemonic: You might also be surprised to learn that you are to ride this horse all across きょうと. That gives you a time limit. You have until you traverse きょうと to write this poem about winter.

meaningMnemonic: Wolverine ties a towel around his forehead and takes out his fingers instead of his claws so he can sweep the floor clean. When Wolverine fights, his claws are out and he makes a big ol' mess. But once the fighting is done, it's time to get to work and sweep the mess up.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture Wolverine, hair held back with a towel, claws detracted, sweeping up a bar that he just had a big fight in. He's sweeping up broken bottles and broken chairs and broken evil x-men.
additionalR:
Hints
Sweeping is good for the soul. Sweeping is good for the soul. Sweeping is like chicken soup for the soul.
readingMnemonic: Wolverine knows that sweeping is good for the soul (そう). Plus, if you don't help clean up after you defeat bad guys, you're just as bad as them. Sweeping up the mess cleans your soul of any guilt too!

meaningMnemonic: You want some flowers so you take your cleat to the side of a tree hoping they'll fall down, but you get a vegetable instead. What? You kick the tree again and another, different vegetable falls out.
additionalM:
Hints
Now you have two vegetables and no flowers. Do vegetables even grow on trees?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your cyborg nibbling on the vegetables you cleat-kicked out of this tree. You give all of the things you don't like to your cyborg nowadays. Which is probably why there are so many weird things all over it...
readingMnemonic: You feed these vegetables (that you didn't even want) to your cyborg (さい). It only needs a little though, since its stomach is so thin, so you just make it hold the rest.

meaningMnemonic: Under the moon while you sit on a cliff, you inject a syringe of tofu right into your vein. Ahh, tofu. You’re addicted to it. You sneak out to the cliff at night to get your tofu fix, injecting it straight into your vein.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the tofu running through your veins. Feel the tofu goodness spreading all over your body. It’s so intense you can even taste a little tofu in your mouth.
additionalR:
Hints
Say this out loud, it’ll help you remember. Really focus on the “myake” be sure to say it like you’re all bugged out from tofu overdose.
readingMnemonic: Eventually, your friends and family find you at the cliff, tripping on tofu. Each and every vein on your body is engorged, pulsating with the effects of tofu. Your friends try and take you home. “You cyan’t myake (みゃく) me!” You slur, suffering from the effects of the tofu. “None of you cyan myake me go home! You cyan’t myake me! Nyah!”

meaningMnemonic: You're loitering, staring down at the cross that got caught in the net of your heart, because it's trying to teach you to act with virtue.
additionalM:
Hints
People who keep the cross in their hearts are supposed to be full of virtue, always doing the right thing, always helping others. But you aren't sure if you want to be virtuous, it's a lot of responsibility. So you look down at this symbolic cross and loiter instead of making a decision.
additionalR:
Hints
I don't know about you, but I'm pretty sure Tokugawa Ieyasu is telling you to choose a life of virtue.
readingMnemonic: As you try to decide if you want to live a life of virtue the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own.

meaningMnemonic: The warehouse radical and the warehouse kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine if you kept a bunch of souls in a warehouse. This way they can't haunt anyone. And they can't get lost out in the spirit world. The warehouse is best for them.
readingMnemonic: You have a warehouse to store all of your souls (そう). When people or animals you know pass away, you take their souls and store them in your dry warehouse for safekeeping. It's a public service, really.

meaningMnemonic: Mix spiders into alcohol to make acid. Spiders have a little bit in them already, but if you really want to make it potent, smash them in some whiskey to make a deadly acid that will rip through anything.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine crushing up some spiders into alcohol. Watch it turn green. It's going to eat through the beaker! Quick, do something!
additionalR:
Hints
It’s Christmas morning. Instead of gifts, Santa-san just throws a piece of charcoal at your face. Feel the charcoal smash into your face and explode into acid, burning you. Santa-san runs away laughing. Ho ho ho!
readingMnemonic: You're trying to find a container for this acid when Santa-san (さん) bursts through your wall. He frowns down at you. You're on the naughty list now. You killed spiders AND made dangerous acid? Ooooh you're in trouble.

meaningMnemonic: A husband and his husband find a shellfish and agree to share it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the husbands pulling a different side of the shellfish, it pops in two, and they each get a shell. They smile and high five.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Santa-san flying over the husbands in his sleigh, raining shellfish down upon them from the sky. It warms the heart, wouldn’t you agree?
readingMnemonic: Since the husbands were able to agree, Santa-san (さん) believes they’re both good husbands and belong on the good list. Therefore, Santa-san gives them each lots and lots of shellfish for Christmas.

meaningMnemonic: You come across a spirit wearing a top hat and it claims to be your ancestor. Well of course, if you remember correctly, all of your ancestors wore top hats when they were alive. This spirit must be your long lost, great great... uh... somebody.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine coming across your long dead top hatted ancestor in spirit form. What would you do? What would you say?
additionalR:
Hints
Your ancestor didn't come here to see you, it just wanted to learn about soap. Something that they didn't have back when it was alive. That's actually kinda sad... and stinky. Your ancestor needs to use this soap, if anything.
readingMnemonic: You ask your ancestor what it wants and it points to the soap (そ) by the sink. Soap? It nods at you. I guess your ancestor is here to see the wonders of soap.

meaningMnemonic: A gold bar can be turned into a coin. Well, more than one coin, probably. But you know for sure that you can make at least one coin out of this gold bar.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine taking this gold bar and punching a coin out of it. Imagine yourself pulling a lever to press a coin out of the gold bar. Feel the lever going down as you hear the sound of a gold coin being punched out.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine paying this centaur with your gold coin. Hear the centaur thank you in his gruff voice before he gallops away.
readingMnemonic: You need this coin to give to a centaur (せん). The centaur is your bodyguard and he only accepts gold coins as payment.

meaningMnemonic: A scooter sits at the entrance where people enter. You jump on and are flung inside! Because a lot of other people did the same thing, it's really crowded in here.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine going to your favorite store. There's a scooter on and waiting at the entrance. You can't see inside, so when you are scooted inside by the scooter, you just get thrown into a packed room. So many other people on scooters! It's too crowded!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a 子 at the head of a huge conference table. "I know how to make our stores crowded again!" they shout before showing everyone their plan drawn in Crayons.
readingMnemonic: Whoever came up with the scooter entrance idea, that made your favorite store so crowded? Only a 子 (こ) could come up with something like this. They don't really think about the dangers and legal implications of using a scooter to launch people into a crowded space.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to go to Korea you'll need a good defense.
additionalM:
Hints
Things in Korea haven't been on the safest side lately, so make sure you have some ways to defend yourself before you go.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so maybe this defense strategy will take a while, but you aren't rich and acorns are on the ground for free. Don't judge!
readingMnemonic: You need a good defense to go to Korea, so you fill your pockets with acorns (えい). When you get to Korea you plant them all around yourself. In no time you'll have a strong tree defense, keeping you safe.

meaningMnemonic: A tree combines with a table to make a desk. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk.
additionalM:
Hints
Chop this tree into pieces to transform this table into a desk. Hear the sounds of construction in your head as you make this desk with your bare hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so this is a pretty tricky one to make a reading mnemonic out of, if you can think of a better one, please email us. Until then, just imagine someone slurring “It’s cool, eh?” While you think about how cool this desk really is. Run your hands over the finished project as you say it.
readingMnemonic: When you finish the desk you turn to your friend and say, “It’s cool, eh (つくえ)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.”

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits the ground, dumping all the muddy water onto this poor beggar, making him very dirty.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the dirty beggar gasping for air on the dirty ground. He was not expecting to get hit by a tsunami today.
additionalR:
Hints
The beggar's obi was the only nice thing he had left and now it's all dirty. Maybe he can beg for a new one but... probably not.
readingMnemonic: The beggar sits up and sees how dirty his obi (お) is now and starts to cry. "Oh, my obi. My obi is all dirty, oh no!"

meaningMnemonic: You eat part of a director to domesticate him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down.
additionalM:
Hints
Which part of the director did you choose to eat in order to domesticate him? Think about eating that part of the director and imagine its taste in your mouth as you chew. Eww.
additionalR:
Hints
You’re proud that you managed to domesticate the director, but now you feel kind of bad for having injured him. Okay, you really just feel bad because he’s probably going to sue you and he definitely has a lot of money. Oh, and he’s bleeding all over your car.
readingMnemonic: While you did succeed in your attempt to domesticate the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your car (か) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry!

meaningMnemonic: Put a spirit in a black hole and a duplicate comes out. The duplicate looks exactly like the original spirit that went in. How strange.
additionalM:
Hints
Examine the duplicate spirit. Same ghosty body. Same ghosty glow. A perfect copy.
additionalR:
Hints
You feel pretty bad now. The duplicate spirit seems to have decided to haunt you, and it's muttering "F*** you, f*** you," over and over in your ear.
readingMnemonic: Suddenly the duplicate spirit starts yelling, "Why did you throw me into that black hole?! F*** (ふく) you!"

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami runs into nine trees and produces a dye the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this happening in front of you. See the tsunami turn from the color of water to the color of a forest. The dye washes over you and now you’re forest green as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear each centaur shouting about how he hates that dye for changing his color. They look kind of funny, so you laugh at them a bit, but not too loud – they might hear you and get even more angry.
readingMnemonic: The dye continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of centaurs (せん). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy.

meaningMnemonic: Two pools, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an egg. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar.
additionalM:
Hints
Separate the two pools from one another. Now the pools look like the kanji. The kanji is one white pool and one yellow pool. Neat, huh?
additionalR:
Hints
Just think Tamagotchi whenever you see this kanji. Tamagotchi = tamago = egg. Easy!
readingMnemonic: You remember Tamagotchi (たまご), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an egg, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg.

meaningMnemonic: The eternity radical and the eternity kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
It's the miracle of eternal life!
readingMnemonic: How long is an eternity? Just look at this little acorn (えい) and ask. The acorn starts small but it grows into a huge tree and can live for all eternity by dropping more acorns to create more trees. Its acorn line will live on forever!

meaningMnemonic: Taking a piece of thread you blame the exploits of your past on poor judgment. You tie this thread around your finger to remind you of all the exploits you accomplished in your day. Most of them weren’t actually on purpose, so you blame them on poor judgment and accident.
additionalM:
Hints
Think up what exploits you accomplished. What sort of things might you have done, but not quite on purpose? Think about how it feels to be exalted for such exploits that were but mere accidents.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine setting this sexy fashion trend on accident. Imagine what you were wearing when you got dressed in the dark. Probably a pretty strange, mismatched outfit.
readingMnemonic: One of your exploits was when you got dressed in the dark and were wearing funny clothes and everyone thought that it was sexy (せき). The newspapers and fashion agencies couldn’t get enough of your sexy style.

meaningMnemonic: The eye's root is the eyeball.
additionalM:
Hints
Go ahead and feel your eyeballs moving around in your head. Your eyes aren't just the part on the surface, they're the whole balls in there, attached at the root.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at Gandhi’s eyeball with your eyeball. It's pretty remarkable.
readingMnemonic: You know who has some pretty good eyeballs? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi used his eyes to see the oppression around him and decided to do something about it. But it's all thanks to his eyeballs.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami that hits at night leaves even more fluid than normal. It's dark at night, so the sun isn't there to help evaporate all that tsunami liquid.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the dark fluids from the tsunami flowing by your window at night. You look out and the liquid is shining in the moonlight. It looks like an entire sea is out there!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the 駅 filled to the brim with fluids and liquids. Maybe if you swim, you'll be able to catch your train.
readingMnemonic: This fluid stays in the 駅 (えき) longer than anywhere else. All of those tsunami liquids pour deep inside the 駅 late at night and the sun still can't reach them to help evaporate them during the day. It's a real *night*mare.

meaningMnemonic: Take your fingers and dig the tree bits out of this cleat to gather it into evidence. Gather it in a pile or a bag, just make sure it's all in one place so you can take a closer look later.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your fingers really getting in there to gather the tree pieces from out of this cleat. Some of the tree bits are stabbing under your fingernails, but you have to keep gathering them, don't stop now!
additionalR:
Hints
Gather all of these cyborg bits so you can find it and reattach them later.
readingMnemonic: You gather them all together and realize there are cyborg (さい) parts mixed in with the tree bits. Uh oh, it's as you feared. Your cyborg definitely got into trouble somewhere around here and you walked all over it with your cleats.

meaningMnemonic: If you can understand a samurai's heart, you'll discover their true intentions.
additionalM:
Hints
If you're facing down a samurai, it's pretty important for you to be able to understand their intentions. Not all samurai are good, you know.
additionalR:
Hints
The sheep samurai only has violent intentions for other samurai and sheep. Its heart is dark and surprisingly easy to read.
readingMnemonic: You try to read the intentions of the samurai in front of you and they're dark, evil, scary. Oh no! These are the intentions of the sheep (し) samurai!

meaningMnemonic: There’s a comb and what looks like the same comb, and you found them on the ground next to some fins you showed interest in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that are interesting too.
additionalM:
Hints
Pick up these fins and the two combs. Feel their weight in each hand as you examine them with interest. Smell the fish smell and feel the teeth on the combs.
additionalR:
Hints
You've always had an interest in きょうと, so it makes sense that you'd be interested in things from きょうと too.
readingMnemonic: Since the combs interest you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in きょうと. Dang, きょうと sure does make some nice combs.

meaningMnemonic: If you have a big mouth but a good heart, people will recognize your kindness. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you.
additionalM:
Hints
Share your kindness with the world. Use your big mouth to let people know what you’re doing. “I’M TAKING OUT THE TRASH AND NOBODY EVEN ASKED ME!” Y’know, that sort of thing. Go ahead and say that out loud a few times.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine chopping up these onions. Smell the onion smell in the air as your eyes begin to sting from the onions. Your friend had better appreciate this kindness.
readingMnemonic: To further show your kindness, you chop up some onions (おん) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it’s a nice act of kindness that you’re toughing it out for your pal.

meaningMnemonic: If use a slide to enter a building, you'll be sliding for a long time.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a never-ending slide that goes deep down inside a building. You can't see anything in the dark around you, you just plunge down and slide forever. And forever is a long time, my friend.
additionalR:
Hints
Cucumbers are tasty, but not when you've been eating them for a long time.
readingMnemonic: You slide for such a long time that you get hungry. Luckily, once in a while a cucumber (きゅう) comes tumbling down the slide next to you.

meaningMnemonic: A Viking and his older brother join a party. They can raid and pillage better in a group like this, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this big group that contains the Viking and his older brother. Hear them shouting as a group and imagine their Viking battle cry.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this group of Vikings rampaging through とうきょう. See all the Japanese people running away and screaming as the group of Vikings comes busting in, swinging their axes and shouting loudly.
readingMnemonic: This party has decided to raid とうきょう. It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. とうきょう doesn’t stand a chance.

meaningMnemonic: If the canopy comes beforehand, it's a preface for the rest of the canopy.
additionalM:
Hints
Although not necessarily a book preface, you can imagine a book made out of canvas pages. The canvas pages that came beforehand (i.e. in the beginning, before the book started) is the preface.
additionalR:
Hints
Actually imagine reading through the preface of your favorite book. Except, there's a preface that just goes into great detail about Jo-Anne and doesn't seem related at all to the book.
readingMnemonic: You read the preface. It just goes on and on and on about Jo-Anne (じょ), a short lady the author loves very much.

meaningMnemonic: You count nine of them in the tree, each turkey holding something random or miscellaneous. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the turkeys in the tree. There are nine of them and they are all gobbling up a storm. Hear them gobble as you imagine what random, miscellaneous things they are holding.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at Zazu asking the turkeys random questions about miscellaneous trivia. You’ve seen the Lion King, right? Zazu should be pretty easy to visualize here.
readingMnemonic: As if things couldn’t get any more random, Zazu (ざつ) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys miscellaneous trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange.

meaningMnemonic: Under a tree sitting on the grass is a woman who loves sakura, or cherry tree, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself sitting under the tree in the grass with the woman. Smell the cherries and see the sakura blossoms falling down all around you. How whimsical.
additionalR:
Hints
Sakura means cherry tree and sakura is the way to pronounce this kanji. Easy!
readingMnemonic: How do you say cherry tree in Japanese? Sakura (さくら). Sakura is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember.

meaningMnemonic: The roof of a certain mountain shrouds its contents in secrecy.
additionalM:
Hints
I can't even tell you which mountain it is, nor how to get in. That's what secrecy is all about.
additionalR:
Hints
You can imagine trying to break one of the mitts-wearing members of this group, but they can't tell you anything because of their magical mitts.
readingMnemonic: This secrecy is so secret that the people who know about it wear magical mitts (みつ) of secrecy that make it so we can't tell anyone, no matter what.

meaningMnemonic: A grain is certain to keep a secret.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine telling a piece of grain your deepest, darkest secret.
additionalR:
Hints
This works both ways too. If someone tells you a secret, that same heat fills you up. Now whether this heat is from embarrassment or the rush of getting to be part of a secret is up to you to figure out.
readingMnemonic: If someone finds out your secret (not from the grain though, it will certainly keep it) then your entire face will fill with heat (ひ).

meaningMnemonic: If you see a grassy cliff with an elf under it in winter, it's because their parents are so strict. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand under grassy cliffs to think about what they've done.
additionalM:
Hints
Only really, really strict parents would make their kids do that in the middle of winter! It's cold!
additionalR:
Hints
Oh Genji, if only you were as strict about using protection as you were on your elf child.
readingMnemonic: One of the strict parents of this elf kid is... Genji (げん)?! Looks like he had another illegitimate kid... this time with an elf.

meaningMnemonic: When you're at your cottage the only thing you do with your fingers is throw away things. The cottage is for vacation. And vacation means being as lazy as possible. But you certainly don't want to live in filth, so you have to throw away your trash at least.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sitting in your cottage. You throw away a banana peel. You throw away some used sun tan lotion. You throw away all your cares in the world.
additionalR:
Hints
Just throw away all your suits when you want to relax. Don't worry about needing one some day, throw it awaaaay!
readingMnemonic: The number one thing you throw away while in your cottage is your suit (す). Suits just don't fit the cottage life vibe, man.

meaningMnemonic: They say a shrimp who is bad with translation has no reason to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this one shrimp who is bad at translation. He’s trying to find a reason to live, but he’s having trouble. Look at him all alone, being shunned by the other shrimp.
additionalR:
Hints
The translation of the word yak was the reason this shrimp fell into despair and gave up the translation profession. Now everyone hates him. See this poor shrimp being harassed by others while they shout at him, “Yak! Yak! Yak!”
readingMnemonic: The translation this shrimp failed to make was for the word “yak” (やく). The shrimp found no reason to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart.

meaningMnemonic: In the valley you feel a lack of want. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of how much you want to be in this valley. They have everything in there. You lack nothing. You want for nothing. Man, you wanna be in that valley so badly.
additionalR:
Hints
This was the yolk you wanted. Feel it slosh into your mouth from the sky. Taste the yolk on your tongue before swallowing it. Mmm, egg yolk.
readingMnemonic: Once you get to the valley, you want some protein. Egg yolk (よく) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth.

meaningMnemonic: You're in the sun playing football and you get very warm.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel how warm the sun is, as you try to throw and catch the football.
additionalR:
Hints
Dang, you knew you should have played night football so it wouldn't get so warm. Now the dawn sun is making you uncomfortable under all those layers of football protection.
readingMnemonic: It's warm like this because it's dawn (だん). That's when the sun comes up.

meaningMnemonic: In its scooter, a cat pirate scoots up to welcome you!
additionalM:
Hints
"Nya! Welcome to my ship, grab a scooter and scoot on up here, we're about to start the welcome ceremonya!"
additionalR:
Hints
You're really happy this cat pirate welcomes gay people aboard. Whether that's because you're gay or just because you're a baseline decent human being is up to you.
Also if you aren't the kind of person who would welcome gay people onto your cat pirate ship, you should just leave nyaow.
readingMnemonic: The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they welcome all kinds of people. Especially gay (げい) people. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate either thinks you're gay or wants you to be.

meaningMnemonic: If a leader has a gun it's easy to wound people. When you have a gun and a lot of responsibility it's easy to get carried away and mess up, wounding the people you were supposed to be protecting. You can even wound yourself.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture how easy it would be for the leader of your country to wound someone if they had a gun. Scary, right?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun you've slowly grown to know over the last thirty-ish levels. But he's holding a gun wounding everyone around him. He's screaming and shooting and wounding everyone in sight. Even his mom, even his dog, even his farmers.
readingMnemonic: Which leader wounded the Japanese people? The Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is a military leader. The Shougun even has gun in the name. And they wounded hundreds of thousands of samurai and soldiers.

meaningMnemonic: On a cliff, a fire burns to ashes. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go.
additionalM:
Hints
See the light from the fire as the ashes fly off the cliff. The wind carries some of the ashes over to you. Feel the ashes as they strike your face and wipe the black ash with your hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Ashes on my face. Falling from the cliff of fire. Gives my life meaning. Or just come up with your own haiku. Whatever works for you.
readingMnemonic: The ashes inspire you to write a haiku (はい). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy.

meaningMnemonic: If you see icicles hanging off of a samurai's clothes, don't worry, those are just part of his winter attire. Samurai have to travel and fight in all sorts of conditions, so it only makes sense that they have attire for every season.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a samurai in his winter attire. His helmet is white and fuzzy and he has decorative icicles hanging down off of his armor.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the kind of attire you'd wear as a samurai to reflect your soul. Mine would be bright pink and covered in horses and bananas and daisies to show that I have a happy, kind soul and that I don't want to be killed by anyone else.
readingMnemonic: Attire like this is important because it reflects your soul (そう). The samurai is wearing clothing with icicles because that's how his heart feels too: frozen over because he has to fight in this horrible winter weather.

meaningMnemonic: If someone is holding flowers, they're probably an author. Authors really love flowers, because they help them think of flowery language they can use to sound smart in their books.
additionalM:
Hints

Imagine a time when a book you were reading used flowery language and you couldn't understand. Imagine the annoyance with the author for using words that are hard to understand
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the author trying to use chopsticks to move around a little flower. It looks like they're having a hard time, but people will do anything to be a great author, I suppose.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the author is allergic to flowers. They are only allergic to touching them though, so the author is holding the flowers with a pair of chopsticks (ちょ), really close to their face. Using the chopsticks, they can still use the flowers to think of fancy, author-ly words without touching them.

meaningMnemonic: There's a lid on your village, so you kick it over on its backside to see what's on its underside.
additionalM:
Hints
You've been curious about what's on the lid (and your village's) backside for years, and you finally can't take it anymore so you kick the lid as hard as you can!
additionalR:
Hints
Wait, isn't uranium bad for people? This explains why all of the villagers backsides are covered in weird glowing, green lumps.
readingMnemonic: It turns out your village's own backside is covered in uranium (うら). Eureka! You're all gonna be rich!

meaningMnemonic: The gate to the genius is now closed. The genius’ visiting hours are over, so the gate is closed. This genius has been genetically modified to know more than any human could know, and his days are spent answering questions and advising. But now, his work day is over, so his gates are closed.
additionalM:
Hints
See the genius sitting behind the gate as it creaks closed in front of you. Hear the gate slam closed as you keep in mind that this genius has been modified to have increased intelligence because the genius radical in this kanji is modified as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a bunch of people in front of closed gates, sleeping in piles of hay. Super itchy hay.
readingMnemonic: On the other side of the closed gates there is still a line of people that want the genius's advice. They decide to keep waiting until morning and gather together some hay (へい) so that sleeping outside won't be so awful.

meaningMnemonic: This car is all weird because it looks like the side is going to dangle and drip off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment.
additionalM:
Hints
Compare this kanji to the car kanji, 車. See how the sides and top are different? Use that to remember that this car looks like it’s falling apart. See the parts dangle, and hear the drip of car fluids falling out. This car is a wreck.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself swinging off these dangling car parts. Hear the car creak and groan as you swing around on it, causing more fluid to drip out of the car.
readingMnemonic: You see the parts as they dangle off the car and you get an idea. You could probably swing (すい) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they drip off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits the greenhouse, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a desert.
additionalM:
Hints
The greenhouse was your only hope in turning the desert into a green forest. Now it's all washed away by salt water, meaning nothing will grow anyways. Feel disappointed about this.
additionalR:
Hints
Up, back down, back up, back down. Move your head up and down to keep up with the sun’s movements. Will it ever rise like normal?
readingMnemonic: See the sun come up over the desert, then go back (ばく) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so vague in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out!

meaningMnemonic: Put a rice paddy together with other paddies and you'll see how much they differ. When you're driving or taking a train through the countryside it may seem like all of those rice paddies blurring together are all the same, but they can differ quite a bit!
additionalM:
Hints
Try to picture how each rice paddy differs from the next. Can you think of any differences in the ones you've seen?
additionalR:
Hints
Aha! As an eagle you can easily see that all of the rice paddies have differing colors, shapes, and (if you fly low) smells. They differ a lot!
readingMnemonic: To see how rice paddies differ, you need an eagle's (い) eye view. It can be hard to see from the ground, so soar up into the sky like an eagle and look down at the rice paddies together.

meaningMnemonic: Social commentary aside, the white king is the king that wears all white. Traditionally, this is someone better than a king. The emperor!
additionalM:
Hints
See the emperor, garbed all in white. There are other kings, but the emperor's white clothing shows his status above the rest.
additionalR:
Hints
How did こういち become emperor?! His first decree as emperor is that everybody must learn kanji now.
Note: from now on, Emperor こういち will be a recurring character for the reading mnemonic of こう.
readingMnemonic: Who is the emperor? It is こういち. こういち the emperor stands over his subjects.

meaningMnemonic: To make your fingers wide you extend them.
additionalM:
Hints
Extend your fingers right now and see how wide you can make them.
additionalR:
Hints
You poked the cock right in the eye with your extended fingers. Maybe you shouldn't be doing that in public. Innocent cocks could get hurt.
readingMnemonic: As you extend your fingers a cock (かく) comes running by and runs straight into them. Bu-COCK!

meaningMnemonic: A greenhouse is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the sun into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their livelihood will be awesome, now!
additionalM:
Hints
Just feel happy that your plants have such a nice livelihood now that the sun is out. They look so healthy and fresh!
additionalR:
Hints
Look at Bobo do what he needs to do to maintain his own livelihood. Hear the flowers screaming as they are plucked from their homes.
readingMnemonic: From out of nowhere, Bobo (ぼ) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their livelihood. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood.

meaningMnemonic: Those that are in the middle of your heart are the ones you have the most loyalty towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to.
additionalM:
Hints
Who do you feel the most loyalty towards? Imagine them in the middle of your heart. Feel them in your chest. Imagine them, literally inside the middle of your heart.
additionalR:
Hints
Chewbacca is very loyal. Focus on your loyalty to Chewbacca. Picture him right in the middle of your heart and hear his Chewbacca yell. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 中 which is also included in this kanji.
readingMnemonic: You pictured Chewbacca (ちゅう), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s loyalty. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so he deserves your loyalty back.

meaningMnemonic: There is a moon and a city inside your lung. Inside of your lung there is a city and above that city lies a moon. It’s a pretty sight, but also very strange. Moons and cities don’t usually reside inside lungs.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having a moon and a city inside your lung. Feel their presence as you breathe in and breathe out. Also, 月 often refers to internal organs as well, so remember that when you see this kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
The city and moon
Inside my lung, forgotten.
Where is the answer?
Or just think of your own haiku. Be creative!
readingMnemonic: Having a moon and city inside your lung inspires you to write a haiku (はい). Perhaps the city and moon are just metaphorical. Either way, a haiku is the best way to go about things here.

meaningMnemonic: To say what's in a samurai's heart you start a magazine. You go around writing about and interviewing all the samurai so you can share what they say to everyone who wants to read!
additionalM:
Hints
Why hadn't anyone thought of making a samurai magazine before?!
additionalR:
Hints
The sheep samurai is ruining your magazine! Maybe you should start a new magazine called, "All the places the sheep samurai will be, so stay away!" to make up for all the damage you've caused.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, your magazine helps the sheep (し) samurai find other samurai... and kill them. None of the samurai want to share their feelings with your magazine anymore, oh no!

meaningMnemonic: If someone has their fingers in your syrup, it's just another way of saying they manipulated you. Cause only slimy people manipulate other people, so their fingers are slimy and sticky because they're covered in your syrup from mucking up your life.
additionalM:
Hints
"Ah golly gee wiz, he sure got his fingers all up in my syrup again, dagnabbit." You know, this saying we say all the time when someone manipulates us into doing something.
additionalR:
Hints
What happens to your soul, you ask? It gets covered in syrup. That's probably where the syrup fingers phrase came from in the first place.
readingMnemonic: If you want to manipulate someone else it's going to have a permanent effect on your soul (そう). Being manipulative isn't cool. And your soul will suffer forever for it.

meaningMnemonic: This bamboo absorbed the moon's power, and you want that power in your body, so you surgically insert them into your body to replace your muscles and tendons.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your new bamboo muscles glowing under your skin with the moon's power. You flex and feel the power coursing through you!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine standing before the King, explaining in detail how you cut yourself open and replaced your weak human meat with the special muscles you have now. He's staring intently at you, but more so at your shining body than your mouth as you talk.
readingMnemonic: Your special muscles and tendons have become famous and the King (きん) of England has requested that you appear in his court! It looks like he wants you to teach his barber surgeons how you got your new muscles.

meaningMnemonic: The Not Mouth says “no”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine encountering this Not Mouth. Ask it a question. It answers, “No”. Imagine doing this over and over until you believe that the Not Mouth always says “no”.
additionalR:
Hints
Listen as the Not Mouth continues to scream in bloodcurdling agony. Hear the flames flicker as they lick across the Not Mouth’s being. Seems as though the heat was too much for the Not Mouth.
readingMnemonic: You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of heat (ひ). The Not Mouth says, “no”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat.

meaningMnemonic: If you become a plate, I will pile food up upon you. With such a huge pile, everyone will think you're prosperous.
additionalM:
Hints
If you have piles of something, you're prosperous. If you become a plate, that's the best thing that can happen to you.
additionalR:
Hints
You know a family is seriously prosperous when they don't use forks, they use a magical saber to cut their food. Wowee wow wow.
readingMnemonic: You're so prosperous you use your saber (せい) to cut the food pile and shove the bits into your plate mouth. In fact, your entire family is using your special saber to cut and eat off of you. A normal knife wouldn't be able to get through all this food!

meaningMnemonic: Someone climbs onto the roof from the ground when dawn comes to proclaim that a new day has begun! They proclaim this at the top of their lungs!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a shadowy shape on top of the roof, proclaiming to the entire town that the new day is here! It's come! And it's also time to get up.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture that shadow on the roof, proclaiming it's a new day, but this time make sure you picture the outline of this centaur. He has a human top half and a horse bottom half. And he's yelling down at you, "HEY THE SUN IS UP IT'S DAWN GET OUT OF BED!"
readingMnemonic: The thing that climbs up on the roof to proclaim that the new day is here is a centaur (せん). Ohoho, did you think I was going to say it was a rooster? Wrong! Centaurs are taller than humans and roosters, so when they climb onto the roof with their horse legs they can see dawn starting before anyone else.

meaningMnemonic: The leader who is king of every shellfish sets the rent for everyone. If you rent a home in King Shellfish's kingdom, the rent will be set by the great shellfish leader himself.
additionalM:
Hints
King Shellfish loves when people rent from him. Imagine him rolling in all of the rent money (shellfish) he collected from all the people who rent from him. Hear his shell clattering as he frolics on all the dead shells from the shellfish.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel your entire body shaking, but especially your chin, as you tell him you're two shellfish short on rent this month. The last thing you see is his big fist coming right for your chin.
readingMnemonic: If you don't have enough shellfish to pay your rent, King Shellfish will punch you in the chin (ちん).

meaningMnemonic: Writing a poem in winter is the only way to get respect from other poets.
additionalM:
Hints
Even better, write a poem about winter IN winter. Then they'll really respect you.
additionalR:
Hints
The cake has the word RESPECT in fancy, cursive letters. Imagine eating that cake and taste the respect of your poet peers. Mm mm!
readingMnemonic: Once you have their respect you get cake (けい)!

meaningMnemonic: The horns of the creatures who drink alcohol have a measurement so large that they are revered the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at one of these revered horns. Pick it up and feel its weight. It measures very large. Your arms are getting tired from the weight.
additionalR:
Hints
Good thing you already have one of these revered horns. Now imagine yourself grinding it up into a powder to mix into a potion for your son to drink. Hear the horn grinding away as you physically break the horn up into millions of tiny pieces.
readingMnemonic: The reason you are interested in these revered horns so much is that your son (そん) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life.

meaningMnemonic: You lay your sock in a little circle and boil it so it will ripen.
additionalM:
Hints
You don't want to clean the sock, you want all of those nasty foot and shoe juices to ripen into the sock. It's like how the longer you let an apple ripen, the worse it smells and tastes, after a while.
additionalR:
Hints
Ahhh! Juke for your life, or you'll end up smelling like some ripened stuff I can't even mention!!
