readingMnemonic: You take your ripened sock, and throw it at your worst enemy! But they juke (じゅく) out of the way, and throw a ripened pair of socks at you! You manage to juke too, but they're already preparing what looks like some very ripe underpants.

meaningMnemonic: Your mouth has some hidden horns, and if you have the right alcohol measurement in your body, those horns will come out of your mouth in the form of rumors and gossip.
additionalM:
Hints
It's really easy for to let a rumor slip if you've had a certain amount of alcohol. And those rumors have horns, they're dangerous.
additionalR:
Hints
If someone who looks a little drunk comes up to you and starts with うわさ, there is a 100% chance what follows is gossip.
readingMnemonic: When you start to tell a rumor or spread gossip, you're a little drunk, so you slur you words. "Ooo I saw (うわさ)..." is how you start every rumor. It's got some southern drawl to it almost (Uuuwahsahw).

meaningMnemonic: If you grind a stone down to more than just a few pieces, it will become sand. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel these few grains of sand between your fingertips. Imagine the stones that they originally came from. Nature is crazy.
additionalR:
Hints
Just remember that stones become sand and if you remember that this kanji means sand you’ll remember how to pronounce it as well.
readingMnemonic: What’s in your hand? A few grains of sand (さ)! Sand, sand, sand!

meaningMnemonic: Keeping at a bamboo interval is the definition of simplicity.
additionalM:
Hints
Just one bamboo wide, over and over. That is simplicity.
additionalR:
Hints
Simplicity is how he took over so much of the world. If he didn't stick to simplicity, there's no way he'd have been able to do what he did.
readingMnemonic: Simplicity is what Genghis Khan (かん) always demanded. Everything he decided was based on simplicity.

meaningMnemonic: If you take the flowers off some coral and boil them, steam comes out.
additionalM:
Hints
Steam comes out of the coral flowers because they hold a lot of water. They're flowers, but they're coral flowers, so they came from the ocean. Of course there's water in them, and if you boil that water steam will come out.
additionalR:
Hints
It's weird that Jourm is so sensitive to the smell of steaming coral. He's lived as a farmhand nowhere near the sea all his life... at least that's what he told you. And now he's in your house breathing in the steam really deeply with his nose practically in the pot.
readingMnemonic: As you watch the steam coming off the coral flowers, someone appears behind you. It is Jourm (じょう), the big farmhand. "Are you steaming coral?" he asks. "Smelled it a mile away. I love crunching me some coral."

meaningMnemonic: The storehouse radical and the storehouse kanji meanings are the same. If you know the radical, you know the kanji!
additionalM:
Hints
Your brain is like a storehouse, you know? Hopefully that's where you kept your storehouse knowledge.
additionalR:
Hints
Be really proud of your storehouse. You've collected a lot of zombies and put them in there, where they'll keep fresh a long time!
readingMnemonic: You have a storehouse. Inside is where you keep all your zombies (ぞう).

meaningMnemonic: Bring rice under a canopy, crush it with your brush, and sweep the white powder in your mouth... it's sugar now! You make sugar by carefully crushing rice to a powder, until it's small enough to brush into your mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Taste the sugar in your mouth and feel the breeze waft under the canopy. You're surrounded by rice, but what's in your mouth is definitely sugar now.
additionalR:
Hints
As you eat the sugar, you picture とうきょう. The place where you fell in love with these sugar-making techniques.
readingMnemonic: You learned how to make sugar in とうきょう. You found a special とうきょう sugar sensei and they introduced you to all of the secret methods you know now.

meaningMnemonic: The thread you have inside is your whole supply. When you're outside sewing and you run out, you just go inside, look through your supply, and pick a new one.
additionalM:
Hints
Go inside your house or shed, it doesn't matter where, and look happily at your thread supply. You have thread in all sizes, shapes, and especially colors.
additionalR:
Hints
Nostradamus says you should have a large supply of everything you use regularly. Thread, water, canned foods. You can't see the future, but he can, and if he's telling you to stock up on your inside supplies I think you should listen.
readingMnemonic: You have this supply because Nostradamus (のう) had a prediction, saying you would. And that if you didn't keep a good supply of thread inside, you'd run out.

meaningMnemonic: They say someone with various talents is important. Various talents can include speaking various languages so if you are someone who knows various languages you can say things that various peoples will comprehend.
additionalM:
Hints
You are someone who can say things in various languages. Speak some of these various languages now. You are someone who is good at saying things. Nice job.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself at this show. The spotlight is on and all eyes are watching. You feel kind of nervous, but you speak the various languages with ease.
readingMnemonic: You’re so good at speaking various languages that you decide to put on a show (しょ). At the show, you say a lot of things in various languages and everyone is impressed.

meaningMnemonic: The hole leading to the private heart of your house is the window. Or maybe it's just the window to your soul, and not your house. Like the poetry people say.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine someone looking into a hole that shows your private heart. That's a window. A window you probably should have kept closed. Now everyone is looking in.
additionalR:
Hints
Look out your window back at the faces. Try to express how mad you are at them with your face through the glass. Make as many mad faces that you can think of.
readingMnemonic: You realize that a ton of people are looking into your window and seeing all your private things. This makes you mad (まど)! What right do they have to know your private thoughts and desires?!

meaningMnemonic: The beans radical and the beans kanji are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
*toots*
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine eating these beans from とうきょう. They’re the best beans you’ve ever had. Even if you don’t like beans, you love とうきょう beans. Mmm… beans, beans, とうきょう beans.
readingMnemonic: These beans are from とうきょう. Everybody knows とうきょう has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans!

meaningMnemonic: A tree branch is exactly what it sounds like: the branch of a tree.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a tree branch in your hands. Feel it. Smell it. It smells and feels like a tree.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine playing fetch with a tree branch and a sheep. Man's second best friend.
readingMnemonic: Take this branch and give it to a sheep (し). Sheep are like dogs, they like to play fetch with tree branches. And now you're playing fetch with this sheep and this branch.

meaningMnemonic: You stand on the forehead of your car, take your fingers and brandish them in the air! You wave them around for everyone to see.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing on top of your car, brandishing your fingers in the air, all of the cars stuck behind yours honking angrily.
additionalR:
Hints
You brandish the key in the air and then throw it into the woods. No more cars for you! Everyone should follow your example! Brandish your car keys into the air and throw them away!
readingMnemonic: What are you brandishing in your fingers? Your car's key (き)! You want every driver and every car to know that you aren't going to be driving ever again!

meaningMnemonic: A slice with a knife is called a carve.
additionalM:
Hints
You carve meat, you carve wood, all with a slicing motion with a knife.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine washing down all your hard carving work with an ice cold Coke.
readingMnemonic: You work up a sweat trying to carve meat and wood all day, so you grab yourself a nice Coke (こく). You like Coke, and it goes well with meat and sawdust.

meaningMnemonic: The claw radical and the claw kanji are exactly the same! Ravishing!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine you have too many tumors. Feel the claw digging into your flesh and removing the tumors. It really hurts, but it is necessary.
readingMnemonic: You’ve got not one tumor (つま), but too many (つめ) tumors and you need to claw them out with your sharp claw. One tumor is one tumor too many. Cut them out with your claw!

meaningMnemonic: A child will ask if they want two waters because they need a grown-up's consent. Children aren't allowed to have whatever they want, they need to make sure it's okay and get consent first.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the child finishing their first water. They look at a big stack of bottled waters, but they know better than to just take two more, they need consent first. "Excuse me, sir, could I please have two more waters?" the child asks.
additionalR:
Hints
You need to make sure to get express consent from the Shougun before you do most things. Especially if it's something like taking more than you've been given.
readingMnemonic: "Of course my child, you have my consent," comes the voice of the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is very pleased by this child, because he expects everyone to ask for consent around him.

meaningMnemonic: Hang a towel in a greenhouse and it turns into a curtain. Greenhouses are made of windows, it's all glass, there are no walls. So when you put a towel in there it turns into a curtain. It has no choice but to cover a window, after all.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine hanging towels over all the windows in the greenhouse. They're really fuzzy, thick curtains now.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hiding in a greenhouse blocked off with towel curtains, stuffing your face with big macs. No one can shame you in here. You can eat as many as you want. And hey, you can use the curtains as napkins too.
readingMnemonic: You're hanging these towel curtains because you need a quiet place to eat a Big Mac (まく). But you're a little ashamed. Big macs aren't really good for you, but this stupid greenhouse has too many windows and everyone can see you stuff your face. So that's where the towel curtains come in.

meaningMnemonic: In this construction project, they will be using thread to hold everything together. The color of the thread is a deep red, and it gives everything a crimson look.
additionalM:
Hints
Because thread isn't that strong, you have to use A LOT (to hold things like beams in place). So, the deep red / crimson thread actually stands out a lot in this construction project.
additionalR:
Hints
こういち walks up with a big smile on his face. "I love the color crimson!" he exclaims. "It's the same deep red color as my enemies."
Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.
readingMnemonic: You're done, and the whole building is a deep red crimson color (it takes a lot of thread to hold a whole building in place). It's time to show the client, Emperor こういち, the finished product.

meaningMnemonic: An arrow is what this turkey lacks. For a turkey, that is a delight.
additionalM:
Hints
A turkey that lacks an arrow is a delighted turkey.
additionalR:
Hints
He loves his turkey friend, and every time he sees it he squeals with delight.
readingMnemonic: Delight is what Genghis Khan (かん) felt when he saw his turkey friend, sans an arrow.

meaningMnemonic: Inside the building is the winter Cow. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to descend to reach it.
additionalM:
Hints
Focus on descending the stairs. There are many signs that say "To Winter Cow: descend" with an arrow pointing down. "I guess I'll have to descend," you say.
additionalR:
Hints
"Hello, thank you for descending all the way down here to see me," says the Winter Cow with こういち's face. "You thought you could use the Winter Cow to stop me, but as you can see, I got here first."
readingMnemonic: You descend to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's こういち's face.

meaningMnemonic: The woman sitting on that stool is actually a dude. Oh oops! You thought he was a woman because of his long hair and the way he was sitting. Maybe you shouldn't be judging people based on their looks!
additionalM:
Hints
Dude, I can't believe you called that dude a woman. What's wrong with you?!
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the poor dog. He's not a dude and now he doesn't think he's a good boy, all because of this other dude. Was he sitting on the stool this whole time, waiting to make this dog feel bad? I guess you'll never know...
readingMnemonic: You only found out this dude wasn't a woman when a dog ど ran up and the dude stood up. He started rubbing the dogs face saying, "Who's a good boy? Who's a good boy? Not you! Me! I'm the best boy of them all. Because I am a dude, the best of all boys! HAHAHAHA!"

meaningMnemonic: The ear and the mouth of a king are holy. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine.
additionalM:
Hints
See the holy ear and mouth of this king. They glisten and glitter and people write hymnals about their holy prowess. Imagine a song playing as you witness their holy majesty.
additionalR:
Hints
The holy king heard you turned into a prosperous plate and used the saber to cut your food and now he wants to try it too. As he holds your saber, a holy circle forms around it, making it sparkle and shimmer! Your saber is holy now too!!
readingMnemonic: This holy king has heard of you and your special saber (せい) that glows with pure, blue light. Specifically, the holy king wants to use it on his food!

meaningMnemonic: If a turkey is pointing its fingers at you, you can infer that it wants revenge. This turkey knows you killed his brother for dinner last night, and now he’s going to make you pay. You infer that this turkey is going to take their fingers and wrap them around your neck.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a turkey is pointing at you with its fingers. The gears in your brain begin to slowly turn. From looking at the turkey to its fingers and back to the turkey, you can infer that something bad is probably about to happen to you.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself as Sherlock Holmes, you inferred your way to freedom, swinging away on a conveniently-placed vine.
readingMnemonic: You were able to infer the turkey's plan, so now it's your turn. You look around and see the only way out... is to swing (すい) to safety! How did I infer that, dear Watson? Why, isn't it obvious! There are vines here. Turkeys can't fly. So I shall swing my way to freedom!

meaningMnemonic: Your moon storehouse is another storehouse you own. Remember how your regular storehouse holds zombies (from the kanji 蔵?). Your moon storehouse is on the moon, and it is filled with internal organs.
additionalM:
Hints
Your moon storehouse has internal organs because 1) you have to keep them far away from the zombies or they'll go berserk, and 2) you think it's funny to see them bounce around in low gravity. Boing, boing, boing, haha look at that internal organ.
additionalR:
Hints
Basically, you store zombies in your regular storehouse, harvest their organs, then launch them into space where they are put into a storehouse on the moon where the zombies will never be able to find them again.
readingMnemonic: Where did you get all these internal organs from? You actually harvested them from the zombies (ぞう) from your other storehouse.

meaningMnemonic: Raise your fingers to another member and you'll receive a loss in return. You should never hurt a member of your team, group, or society. It's just wrong. And you'll incur a loss as punishment for your bad deeds.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine raising your fingers to slap, hurt, or point angrily at a member of your own team. How dare you! I hope you're ready for some deep, personal loss.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your son. Your future son, maybe even your animal son, if you don't want to have real kids. Now imagine the loss of that son. Nooooo!
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately for you, payment is in the form of the loss of your son (そん). The loss of any family member is horrible, but this was your son. He was your favorite child. You loved him. But that's the loss you must bear for raising your fingers to a team member.

meaningMnemonic: Seeing a stone and some horns on the ground next to a piece of poop and another piece of poop, you try and pick each of them up with a magnet. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself trying to pick each object up off the ground with your magnet. Hear the clink of the stone against metal as the magnet lifts it off the ground. Must be some iron in it or something.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Jesus snickering behind you as the stone falls to the ground once again. Imagine running after Jesus so you can catch him and give him a piece of your mind. He’s always playing tricks on you.
readingMnemonic: You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time!

meaningMnemonic: They say accidentally firing a catapult is an unforgivable mistake. They say you shot the catapult at your own castle. Even though it was an accident, it’s still a mistake you will never be forgiven for.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine shooting the catapult on your own people by mistake. Hear the catapult whoosh as your heart drops into your stomach. Oh, what a terrible mistake you’ve just made.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Godzilla jumping happily on the castle and surrounding town you hit by mistake. This is probably the worst mistake you've ever made.
readingMnemonic: This mistake alerts Godzilla (ご), who thinks it's town destroying time. He barrels over the hills, sees where you mistakenly catapulted your own people, and proceeds to stomp on the rest of it for you.

meaningMnemonic: The original tsunami was the origin of Japan. A big tsunami came and uncovered the islands of Japan. It's the origin of all life, as far as Japanese people are concerned.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the original tsunami used in the origin story of Japan. It was huge. Bigger than anything you've ever seen. And without it you wouldn't have your precious anime and mangos.
additionalR:
Hints
The origin of Genji was the origin of all Japan: a big ol' tsunami.
readingMnemonic: This tsunami was also the origin of Genji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji." Just think, without this origin, Japan wouldn't exist and neither would the first Japanese heartthrob, Genji!

meaningMnemonic: If you see some dry flowers, pull them up and you'll find a potato.
additionalM:
Hints
Potatoes grow when flowers dry out. All the nutrients are going to the potato under the ground, so the flowers up top get sucked dry.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture an emo potato sitting alone in a dark room, staring at a potato. "You and I are the same."
readingMnemonic: Potatoes are totally emo (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers.

meaningMnemonic: Make your barracks out of thread so it will be pure. If you build it out of clay or bricks or wood, it will inevitably have some dirt in it. Build it out of thread to keep it pure of... well, impurities.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a barracks pure white, like pure snow, made of pure thread.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so maybe building a pure barracks that you can only use in June was a bad idea, but it's there now and I don't want you getting it dirty, so just use it when I say so, okay?
readingMnemonic: This pure thread barracks can only be used in June (じゅん), unfortunately. Any other time of year there will be snow and rain and mud and that will get tracked into the pure barracks and ruin them. But June is the cleanest, most pure month, so you can use it then.

meaningMnemonic: You want some flowers to put on the canopy above your helicopter to keep the birds away, so you ask people what they would recommend.
additionalM:
Hints
You've bought flowers before, but you really don't know which ones would work best to stop birds from landing on the canopy and pooping on your helicopter.
additionalR:
Hints
I hope the centaur recommends a cheap flower... but with your luck flowers that keep birds away will cost a fortune.
readingMnemonic: You ask for a recommendation from the centaur (せん) that owns the local flower shop. Now he's walking around your helicopter canopy and staring at the birds, nodding.

meaningMnemonic: Into a well, a drop of rice falls from your rice bowl. You were eating out of your rice bowl on the side of a well, and some rice fell out of your rice bowl and this drop of rice proceeded to fall all the way down.
additionalM:
Hints
You lost a drop of rice from your rice bowl. Feel sorrow for the lost rice as you watch it fall down the well and hear it splat into the water below.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the don shout, “See ya, sucker!” as he pushes you into the well. You’ve just lost a drop of rice, now your rice bowl, and now you’re all wet in a well. Worst day ever.
readingMnemonic: Just then, the don (どん) of your local mafia shows up, steals your rice bowl, and shoves you into the well. You’d gotten on the don’s bad side, so he came to teach you a lesson. The don steals your rice bowl and shoves you into the well.

meaningMnemonic: Attach meat to your canopy and it will rot.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the smell of rotten meat hanging from your canopy. Now no one wants to come near here.
additionalR:
Hints
What, did you think attaching this meat to the canopy would make it turn into jerky or something? Fool...
readingMnemonic: You let meat rot. You're a fool (ふ). That's really all I can say at this point.

meaningMnemonic: There's a tsunami coming, so you put your fins on, open your mouth wide, and try to run alongside it.
additionalM:
Hints
Your mouth is open so you can scream, because this is probably a bad idea.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so maybe trying to run alongside a tsunami with just some fins and a mouth full of screams and terror wasn't the best idea. But at least everything ended while you did... uh... something unique?
readingMnemonic: You're able to run alongside the tsunami for about ten seconds before everything ends (えん).

meaningMnemonic: You need to take a body measurement before you can shoot. Whether it's for a photo shoot, you're gonna shoot them with a gun, or if you're about to shoot them full of radiation for X-rays, you need the right measurements of that body first.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine someone measuring your body before they shoot you. You hope it's the good kind of shoot and that you're not going to die.
additionalR:
Hints
Shamans are just a different kind of doctor. And this shot is going to save you from getting the flu, which could kill you. Make sure you always go to the local shaman and schedule a shooting.
readingMnemonic: This shoot is being done by a shaman (しゃ). Not only is he doing the body measurements for the shoot, but he's also going to be shooting you with a shot so you don't get the flu.

meaningMnemonic: A magic thread fell from the roof onto the leader of a hundred people, causing him to shrink!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture one hundred people under the same roof watching in horror as their leader suddenly shrinks to nothingness before them.
additionalR:
Hints
The leader gets shook so badly, he can't even call out to his people. They're going to trample his tiny, shrinking body!
readingMnemonic: As the leader shrinks, the hundred people start screaming and running around the entire place. As a result, everything is shook (しゅく) up. Especially the poor, shrunken leader, who gets knocked around the most.

meaningMnemonic: The samurai has a jackhammer, a brush, and some water. All these things tell you that this samurai is actually a slave.
additionalM:
Hints
Traditionally, samurai don't carry things like jackhammers, brushes, or water. The samurai is carrying these things for someone else, meaning this samurai is somebody's slave.
additionalR:
Hints
The samurai slave can use the ray gun to shoot his keeper and get away. Imagine watching him holding up his master and getting away. A ray gun is a truly powerful weapon in the hands of a slave.
readingMnemonic: You don't like seeing a slave. As you walk by, you hand him a ray (れい) gun so he can free himself.

meaningMnemonic: There’s some rice in the shape of a nine on a cross and this is stylish. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it’s stylish to carry it around and be seen with it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine hefting this cross with the rice in the shape of a nine on it. You don’t feel stylish, but society tells you that you are. You’re stylish.
additionalR:
Hints
See the rice fly through the air from you swinging the cross. Hear it as it clatters to the ground. This cross just isn’t as stylish anymore now.
readingMnemonic: It’s also stylish to swing (すい) the cross around while you wait for things. You’re waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off!

meaningMnemonic: You are so sick that you've come to look like the humble stool: thin. Eerily thin, in fact.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing behind a stool and being able to disappear behind it completely. That's how thin this sickness has made you.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your soul pulsing through your thin body. You have no body fat to cover it up, so everyone can see it pulsing and lurking in there. This is why you're hiding behind one of the humble stools in your house.
readingMnemonic: When you're this thin, your soul (そう) is visible from outside of your body too.

meaningMnemonic: If you put dirt in your mouth you're going to throw up. That's just a fact.
additionalM:
Hints
That's pretty much what throwing up feels like too, right? Like a bunch of dirt coming out of your mouth. Barf.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the sound you made the last time you threw up. It sounded like you were saying HA from the bottom of your tummy.
readingMnemonic: When you throw up it sounds like you're shouting, "HA (は)!" Then all the dirt-puke comes out in a wave. It's less of a laugh ha and more of an oh no I'm throwing up ha.

meaningMnemonic: In the middle of the ground is a shellfish that is very valuable. Inside of this valuable shellfish is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this valuable shellfish. What could be inside? Pick it up and shake it about, trying to guess what valuable thing is enclosed.
additionalR:
Hints
You find a bunch of keys, so you try to jam them all into the shellfish one by one, hoping one of them is the right key to get the valuable, hidden treasure.
readingMnemonic: You want to get the valuable thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the key (き). Search for the key!

meaningMnemonic: You see a thread that wants to loiter from some horns and you would be correct to assume that it would hang vertical. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this vertical thread as it hangs from the horns. Take hold of it and pull on the vertical thread. Feel it in your hand.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at Channing Tatum playing with this thread. He’s like a cat playing with a piece of yarn. Look at Mr. Tatum bouncing around batting at the thread like some silly feline.
readingMnemonic: For some reason, Channing Tatum (たて) is strangely attracted to vertical pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat.

meaningMnemonic: Boots give you the power to work! That's why so many professions require you to have work boots.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting your boots on and suddenly being filled with the power and energy to work hard and efficiently.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself in work boots. Now picture the King in work boots. Yours are worn and beaten up and his are clean and look brand new. But at least you both have them, which means you both work at least a little!
readingMnemonic: You need boots to give you the power to work for the King (きん) of England. Really, all work is for the King, since everything is for him. But even he wears boots. And they give him the power to uh... king over things.

meaningMnemonic: Take your fingers and dry them. Then dry them again. This is what you do when you are in  worship. Once you go into your place of worship, and again before you leave. You have really sweaty fingers, and you can't worship anyone or anything if you have wet hands. So you dry them!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your sweaty, sweaty fingers. Dry them off before you enter a place of worship! No god wants to deal with your weird, damp hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being in your place of worship. Close your eyes and say a haiku:
So I won't offend
Lord Crabigator-sama
I dry my hands now.
readingMnemonic: Once you're dry and in wherever your worship is, you begin with a haiku (はい). Really all places of worship have their own version of the haiku, and heck, the 5-7-5 rule is just a guideline, so everyone is doing it pretty close to right anyway.

meaningMnemonic: The ability to boil is one of the main abilities of a bear.
additionalM:
Hints
I bet you didn't know this, but a bear can boil whenever it wants. Imagine a bear heating itself up and boiling, its fur and skin bubbling and letting off steam.
additionalR:
Hints
You can also imagine a bear graduating in the top 5-10% of its class. Or, just imagine a bear saying "Cuma here!" to you.
readingMnemonic: A bear boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magma cum (くま) laude.

meaningMnemonic: Your mouth is wearing a mask so people won't realize you're the one being so boisterous. You want to be loud and rowdy, but you don't want anyone to know it's you. If you cover your mouth with this mask, people won't know you're the one being so boisterous.
additionalM:
Hints
Go put a mask on right now, cover everything around your mouth so it's hard to tell who you are. Now go outside and be as boisterous as possible!
additionalR:
Hints
Using your boisterous mouth, taste the disgusting soapy soap. The soap bubbles are already filling your mouth and stinging your tongue. This is the punishment for boisterous hooligans.
readingMnemonic: You're being anonymously boisterous outside when suddenly someone shoves soap (そ) in your mouth! "I don't know who you are, but you're much too boisterous! Wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell.

meaningMnemonic: There is a circumference around someone's hair, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has carved the hair off someone's head!
additionalM:
Hints
Their hair has literally been carved out of their head, and you discovered it. Of course, the nastiness, the smell, and the feel should be applied to your imagination to make the mnemonic stronger.
additionalR:
Hints
You can also imagine Mrs. Chou doing the act of carving someone's hair out, but that may just be too much.
readingMnemonic: When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have carved out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a tree in your hair, I think it’s a cedar. How did that cedar tree get in your hair?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having a cedar tree in your hair. It’s just a little tree, a sapling, but it’s pretty strange and awkward. It does smell nice though. Mmm… cedar.
additionalR:
Hints
Give Sue her Sue guitar. Hear Sue squeal with glee as she receives her Sue guitar.
readingMnemonic: Once the cedar is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A Sue guitar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it.

meaningMnemonic: The mouth of the World Tree, all it does is chat and talk.
additionalM:
Hints
You'd think the World Tree's mouth would talk wisdom, but all it does is chat, chat, chat.
additionalR:
Hints
The locals shorten Shaman Bay to "Sha Bay," because they always go there to 喋る with the World Tree. Imagine all the shamans hanging about in the bay.
readingMnemonic: To chat or talk with the World Tree, just head over to Shaman Bay (しゃべ).

meaningMnemonic: Gold is not the same as copper. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper.
additionalM:
Hints
Take a piece of gold in one hand and a piece of copper in the other. Bang them together furiously as you shout. “GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER! GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER!”
additionalR:
Hints
Mmm… doughnuts. Eat the doughnut and taste its yummy flavor as you look at the piece of copper. It’s shiny.
readingMnemonic: Smashing the copper against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a doughnut (どう). Go get yourself a doughnut.

meaningMnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both cottage.
additionalM:
Hints
As long as you know the radical cottage, you know the kanji cottage.
additionalR:
Hints
I guess shamans are moving out a lot around here. Why don't you go look for a cottage you can buy from a shaman! I bet you'll get a pretty good, totally not cursed, deal!
readingMnemonic: You got this cottage from a shaman (しゃ). In fact, everyone you know got their cottage from a shaman. One day you're just walking in the woods, and the next thing you know, a shaman is giving you the keys to their old cottage.

meaningMnemonic: You have an alcohol nine times stronger than any other drink in a bottle shaped like a cross and you drink it all and become drunk. You’re like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel how drunk you are as you look at the cross shaped bottle that once held the alcohol. See the cross start to blur in front of you from how drunk you are.
additionalR:
Hints
Speaking of 水, you need to drink some. You need to rehydrate and 水 is the best way to do it. Drink a lot of 水. Go. Now.
readingMnemonic: If you drink so much that you become drunk, then your alcohol will begin to taste like water. What is the reading of 水? It's すい, which is the reading for this kanji.

meaningMnemonic: Fire, fire, flame! There’s flames everywhere!
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the fire all around you, the flames licking at your body. It’s really hot!
additionalR:
Hints
Sorry, but standing in a blaze isn't the best idea. Flames are pretty efficient at ending the lives of the things in it. Maybe you should do this kanji lesson over and try not to stand in the flames next time.
readingMnemonic: The flames gets bigger, surround you, and then everything ends (えん).

meaningMnemonic: If you loiter around my skin, he will get angry at you. He is my boyfriend and he is very protective of me. So don’t loiter around my skin for too long or he will beat you up.
additionalM:
Hints
He is a jealous guy. He will beat you down if you loiter around my skin for too long. Imagine he is beating you up right now. He is screaming at you as he does so.
additionalR:
Hints
He accepts the curry you give him. Smell the curry smell as he eats it right in front of you. He is eating very loudly.
readingMnemonic: He says the only way he will stop beating you up is if you give him some curry (かれ). You give him some curry.

meaningMnemonic: You create a thread with someone by calling out to them to introduce yourself.
additionalM:
Hints
You literally call out, and when they turn around, tie a thread to them, so you'll never forget that you introduced yourselves to each other.
additionalR:
Hints
Finally the Shougun sighs and turns toward you. You call out your name and get the thread around him. Uh oh. He doesn't look happy.
readingMnemonic: You want to introduce yourself to the Shougun (しょう) but no matter how much you call out, he won't come close enough for you to tie your introduction thread to him. You call louder and louder, "SHOUGUN LET ME INTRODUCE MYSELF!"

meaningMnemonic: The jammed in radical and the jammed in kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself jammed into a kayak. Your pants are bunching and sticking out the sides and top. You really don't fit in here.
readingMnemonic: Look down! You're jammed into something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a kayak (かい).

meaningMnemonic: The tsunamis during the old moons (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's lakes.
additionalM:
Hints
Where did lakes come from? They are the residue of tsunamis from many moons ago.
additionalR:
Hints
This is just a stupid story to get this 子 to stop asking "why, why, why?" about everything. Earlier, the 子 asked "where do lakes come from?" and you had to come up with a crazy story to quiet them.
readingMnemonic: "That's where lakes come from," you tell the 子 (こ).

meaningMnemonic: Try to say something to a lifeguard and you'll just end up getting a lecture.
additionalM:
Hints
A lifeguard's favorite part of the job is telling people what to do, where to swim, when to get out of the water, and they love saying it in a bunch of words.
additionalR:
Hints
Close your eyes and picture こういち lecturing you. Ugh, it's the worst!
Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.
readingMnemonic: This lecture loving lifeguard is none other than こういち! I mean, look how long winded the stuff on this site is? Can you imagine him trying to give you a talk about proper swimming etiquette?

meaningMnemonic: In spring, your measurements will reveal your lifespan. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight.
additionalM:
Hints
On the first day of spring, all the girls and boys line up to measure their lifespans.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at Salmon, over here. She drank a thousand small juice boxes last year and now her measurement says she's gonna live another hundred years!
readingMnemonic: If your lifespan measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small juice (じゅ) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all!

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami will pick up a bunch of shellfish and dump them on your shore, so you take a knife and measure them.
additionalM:
Hints
You can't eat shellfish that are too small, so you place your knife along them to measure them. If they're big enough, you stick the knife in and eat them raw.
additionalR:
Hints
If you measure one of these shellfish and it's too small, stuff it right into your sock. Then once the sock measures about 12 shellfish long, toss it back to sea!
readingMnemonic: All of the shellfish you measure that are too small go into your sock (そく). Once the sock is full, you swing it around your head and lob it back into the ocean.

meaningMnemonic: The ground and a shuriken have mutual respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here.
additionalM:
Hints
Pick up the shuriken and throw it into the ground. Hear it whizz through the air and then plunk into the ground. This act of aggression causes their mutual respect to waver.
additionalR:
Hints
You give Godzilla a thumbs up, you see what he's trying to do. He looks down at you and nods. Now you have a mutual respect for one another too.
readingMnemonic: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the mutual respect is out of balance. This summons Godzilla (ご) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground.

meaningMnemonic: This tsunami is the reason we have so much oil now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami!
additionalM:
Hints
Watch as this tsunami crashes over the land, pushing earth out of the way. Once the tsunami passes, hear the spewing geysers of oil as they erupt out of the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at how this oil has changed the world. Instead of living in big homes, condos, or skyscrapers, everyone lives in a yurt at night and travels with all the oil by day.
readingMnemonic: Now that oil is so abundant, everyone lives in yurts (ゆ). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil.

meaningMnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for oneself first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means oneself as well.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Kids can only think of oneself. Until a certain age, that's literally all they can care about.
readingMnemonic: Oneself. Who only thinks of oneself? Every 子 (こ) in the world.

meaningMnemonic: Your fingers are private, no one can see them unless they pay! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine people coming from miles around to pay for a look at your private fingers.
additionalR:
Hints
If somebody looks at your fingers without paying, without your consent, file a harassment claim on their butt! That is NOT okay!
readingMnemonic: If someone tries to look without paying, that's harassment (はら)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent!

meaningMnemonic: A gold man has one mustache above his lip and one mustache below his lip and keeps all his extra mustaches safely tucked away in a pot. This man is made of gold and has a lot of money. That’s how he can afford to groom two mustaches at the same time. If anything should happen to one, he has plenty of back up mustaches in his mustache storage pot.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this double mustachioed gold man as he rifles through his pot of mustaches. Imagine how ticklish they must be.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself as this golden man with the mustache (and another mustache). Say “Nah, babe” over and over again like you’re trying to convince your wife that you actually love her more than your pot of luxurious mustaches.
readingMnemonic: The mustachioed man’s wife asks if he loves his pot of mustaches more than he loves her. “Nah babe (なべ),” he says. “Nah, babe. Nah.”

meaningMnemonic: You have an animal and you say it’s a dog to prevent it from going to prison. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine any animal that’s not a dog. Now imagine dressing it up like a dog so it doesn’t have to go to prison. Practice throwing your voice by saying “woof woof” aloud to help convince people that your animal is actually a dog.
additionalR:
Hints
Poor little Goku doesn’t want to go to prison either so Goku does his best to act like a dog even though he isn’t. How adorable.
readingMnemonic: What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named Goku (ごく). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to prison, so you say that he’s a dog.

meaningMnemonic: The sake radical and the sake kanji are exactly the same! Sweet.
additionalM:
Hints
For goodness sake! Please remember this isn't "sake" as in お酒! It's the English "sake," that rhymes with "bake," "cake," and "steak." Oops.. now I'm hungry.
additionalR:
Hints

See this eagle as it comes to deliver your order just for your sake. Scree! Hear its wings flap and your package plop down on your porch as it's delivered.
readingMnemonic: For the sake of convenience, companies will use eagles (い) for delivery jobs in the future. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery.

meaningMnemonic: Your ear listens to your heart and feels shame. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the shame. Feel the shame in both your ear and your heart. Imagine the things you’ve done to make you feel so much shame.
additionalR:
Hints
You’re super embarrassed for bringing so much shame on yourself again. But then you think of another joke. “Hahaha!” Better luck with the next Haj, I guess.
readingMnemonic: You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before.

meaningMnemonic: Next to the scooter, there's a flag warning you that there are sheep around here, so you should go slow.
additionalM:
Hints
It's also a warning to the sheep that if they want to ride scooters they should also slow down, because as we all know, sheep are speed demons.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of the sheep finally going slowly because there is yummy cheese all over the road.
readingMnemonic: You follow the flag, but the sheep refuse to slow down so you have to get creative. You place cheese (ち) every ten feet or so, that way the sheep slow down to bend down on their scooters and take a bite.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami carries a cross into your soup. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a bowl of soup, but now there is a cross and some tsunami water in it.
additionalR:
Hints
You're curious so you take a sip of this jewel soup and... it's delicious! You should make more and sell it!
readingMnemonic: You pull the cross out of your soup and see that the cross' jewels (じゅう) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup!

meaningMnemonic: The commander's alcohol is really just soy sauce. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce.
additionalM:
Hints
The next time you go to a bar, order yourself a commander's alcohol. It's like saying you want a Roy Rogers or a Shirley Temple, except it isn't pretty and it tastes horrible.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun sitting on his throne, guzzling down some salty, brown soy sauce. It's splashing on his robes and the smell is making his assistants gag.
readingMnemonic: Soy sauce also happens to be the Shougun's (しょう) favorite drink. Unfortunately, he can't just tell people he likes drinking glasses of soy sauce, or they'll look at him weird. Instead he orders it as a commander's alcohol too.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami, once stopped by a belt, will begin to stagnate. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch this belt as it stagnated the tsunami. See the belt glow as its enchantment activates, immediately stagnating the tsunami water.
additionalR:
Hints
Look in the mirror at you in your tie. Put the finishing touches on your outfit and imagine going out into the world with your tie on, no longer afraid of any tsunamis. They’re all stagnant now thanks to that magical belt.
readingMnemonic: While you watch the tsunami stagnate, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your tie (たい). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work.

meaningMnemonic: Tie a squid to a knife and you get a sword! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine creating your own sword out of a knife and a squid.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Ken swinging his squid sword at you. *Squish* it squirts ink on your shoulder. But it doesn't really hurt.
readingMnemonic: You learned how to make swords this way from Ken (けん) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword!

meaningMnemonic: If you scrape a sharp stone against your skin, it will tear. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this sharp stone. Feel its weight in your hand. Now drag the sharp stone against your skin. Feel your skin as it begins to tear. The pain is agonizing.
additionalR:
Hints
You make this noise when you tear other things with the sharp stone too, but now it's more of a HA! TAKE THAT! Feel the same pain I feel!
readingMnemonic: The moment your skin tears you can't help but yelp "Ha (は)!" It sounds like a laugh, but it's more like a pained bark.

meaningMnemonic: The turtle radical and the turtle kanji are exactly the same! Nice!
additionalR:
Hints
See this turtle as he gathers energy, shaking the earth around him, gathering chi for his Kamehameha blast. He releases it in a mighty blast of energy. Kamehameha!!
readingMnemonic: You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this turtle doing a Kamehameha (かめ). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a mighty Kamehameha blast. Shwooom!

meaningMnemonic: If you’re on the edge of a cliff with a snake, you’re unlucky. You’re hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can’t pull yourself back up when you notice a snake approaching your fingers. The snake looks like it’s gonna bite you. How unlucky.
additionalM:
Hints
What will you do? You can either let go and fall off the cliff, or get bit by the snake if you keep holding on. Man, you’re unlucky.
additionalR:
Hints
What a nice yak this is. Perhaps your luck has turned around. Perhaps you aren’t as unlucky as you thought. Your butt sure does hurt from that fall though…
readingMnemonic: Even though you’re so unlucky, you decide to take your chances and let go of the cliff. Amazingly, a yak (やく) runs below you and catches you as you fall. Saved by the yak!

meaningMnemonic: To make alcohol the key is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become vinegar.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine making a bunch of vinegar. You use a key to change it from alcohol to vinegar, yum!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself doing the same thing as before but you are now wearing a suit. Dang, you look good.
readingMnemonic: You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a suit (す). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into vinegar.

meaningMnemonic: You say something and the flowers are right in agreement. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement.
additionalM:
Hints
What did you say to the flowers that you are so in agreement about? Think about what you said.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine you are the flowers. There’s a duck. It’s making a poo. On you. Ew, man, that’s disgusting. Bleh.
readingMnemonic: You and the flowers are in agreement on the fact that neither of you like when a duck (だく) walks across the flowers. You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face.

meaningMnemonic: I’ll give you this bright plate if you agree to an alliance with me. I know you like things that are bright, and I know you like plates too. Therefore, this bright plate should be more than enough to convince you to enter into an alliance with me.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this bright plate. Look at it. It’s awesome. It’s blinding. Hold it in your hands. Marvel at it. Wow. This plate is sweet.
additionalR:
Hints
This Mayflower boat is the best boat you ever did see. Hear the ocean around it as it bobs in the water, full sails billowing in the wind. Boats are cool.
readingMnemonic: The person you are trying to get in an alliance with you is the captain of the Mayflower (めい). You want to be in an alliance with the captain of the Mayflower because you really like boats. You want to ride on the Mayflower like, so bad.

meaningMnemonic: The commander radical and the commander kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
You better remember the Shougun is the commander of everything... or else...
readingMnemonic: Who is the commander of Japan? The Shougun (しょう)! And if you ever say anyone else or vote for someone else or even THINK about someone else being the commander, he'll find you and cut off your head.

meaningMnemonic: The nothing dance is still a dance!
additionalM:
Hints
If you want to do the nothing dance, just clear your head so there's nothing in it, and then dance!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the booze coursing through your veins as you dance like no one is watching.
readingMnemonic: To help you do this dance you need some booze (ぶ). Just enough so it's easier to think of nothing, let all your fears go, and dance.

meaningMnemonic: Your leader gets the blame if your company is in debt. They're the one who led you all into that debt, so they should get the blame too.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the leader standing up in front of everyone as they blame him. He's holding a plaque with the amount of debt you're all in. Try to imagine what that number would be.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as your cyborg saves your company, even though it wasn't even his responsibility, from crippling debt. *sob* I can't believe your cyborg is gone!
readingMnemonic: To pay off this debt your leader says you need to sell your cyborg (さい) to help the company. You fight him! You yell! You scream! The cyborg puts a half-human half-robot hand on your shoulder and shakes its head sadly.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of your branch became the leader from doing deeds. You can't rise to the rank of branch leader if you don't perform a certain number of deeds! Most of them good, I hope.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the leader of your branch doing deeds around your office. Pulling out chairs for people sitting down, emptying the trash, balancing spreadsheets. All good deeds.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture him doing this deed. He's crawling around on the floor looking for your key. You aren't really helping, you're just watching him do the deed of key-searching for you.
readingMnemonic: The deed he's currently working on is finding your lost key (き). He doesn't have to help, you're the one who lost your own house-combination-car key. But he's so used to doing deeds, he can't help but help.

meaningMnemonic: A canopy and a helicopter are being compared by a deer. The deer is standing very still (as deer do) and looking very slowly between the empty canopy and the helicopter sitting next to it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the deer comparing the two structures. It probably has no idea what they are, but it's trying very hard to understand what it's seeing anyway.
additionalR:
Hints
Deer get hit by cars all the time, but it was still really shocking . I mean it was right in front of you. The car could have hit you too!
readingMnemonic: You walk forward, about to call out to the deer, when a car (か) suddenly appears out of no where and runs the deer over! Was this all just a trap set up to murder the deer?!

meaningMnemonic: In prison, when you have access to a big number of fingers, mouths, and legs you can exchange them for things that are worth more to you. What are you gonna do with all these body parts in prison? You should exchange them for cigarettes and toilet alcohol.
additionalM:
Hints
You just have so many fingers, mouths, and legs you've pummeled off of the other prisoners. Exchange them for better loot!
additionalR:
Hints
Think back to when you were a kid and they would roll out those TVs on stands into the classrooms. Imagine watching a documentary on Genghis Khan's exchange routes where he bought and sold body parts. Educational!
readingMnemonic: You learned this type of exchange from the mighty Genghis Khan (かん). You read a book or watched a show about him once and you're pretty positive that Genghis Khan would exchange the body parts of his enemies all over the continents of Asia and Europe for nicer stuff.

meaningMnemonic: The fang radical and the fang kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means tusk. It means fang and tusk.
additionalM:
Hints
Since the fang radical is the same as the fang kanji, that should be easy to remember. Tusks aren’t too different from fangs, so that shouldn’t be too hard to remember either.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a gecko with cute little fangs. You can keep thinking they're cute as long as one never bites you. They may be little, but gecko fangs are no joke!
readingMnemonic: Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (げ)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a stick next to the sun, reflecting on its former glory. The stick used to be a great tree, and the stick thinks that if it stays by the sun long enough it might return to its former form as a towering tree.
additionalM:
Hints
Pretend you are the stick. Really focus on your former self as you feel the sun warm you with its rays. Imagine yourself growing, larger and larger.
additionalR:
Hints
I guess this stick was formerly a cucumber tree. Or maybe it just tried so hard it pooped a cucumber. I don't care which one is true, you pick whatever you want to believe.
readingMnemonic: It's working, it's working! The stick is returning to its former state and... w-wuh? It sprouted a cucumber (きゅう).

meaningMnemonic: A boat will have at least one weapon, generally.
additionalM:
Hints
In general, you can assume a boat will have a weapon, but not all of them will.
additionalR:
Hints
So of all the boats out there, generally all of them have weapons, and generally Han Solo will be on one.
readingMnemonic: Generally a boat with a weapon will be owned by Han (はん) Solo.

meaningMnemonic: When a tsunami comes, the brush makes a good safe haven. Thick brush is a haven from tsunamis because the brush will break the tsunami water and keep you safe and dry.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in the haven of a brush while a tsunami strikes. Hear the water crash and rush all around you while you remain safe in your haven.
additionalR:
Hints
Since there is room for two people in the brush, imagine yourself in the haven with one other person. They and you make two. The other person is a real whiner though - imagine them crying the whole time.
readingMnemonic: The only downside about this haven is that there’s only room for two (つ) people in the brush. The brush isn’t big enough for more than two people, so unless you have a lot of brush, you won’t be saving many people from the tsunami.

meaningMnemonic: If someone is sick feed them charcoal to heal them. Okay, so maybe you shouldn't feed it directly to them, but charcoal has amazing water filtration powers. So put charcoal in their water and the water will heal them right up.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being sick. Like sick as a dog sick. And then you take some charcoal, put it into your drinking water, and then you're healed!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself rowing your row boat into the lake with huge chunks of solid charcoal. You carefully break them up and toss them over the side, so you can heal everyone.
readingMnemonic: You aren't the only one that needs to be healed, so you take your row (りょう) boat out onto the lake where your town gets its drinking water and you dump a bunch of charcoal into it! Now everyone will be healed when they drink.

meaningMnemonic: With a thread, a lion sews together all the rice he'll inherit from his parents one day. He's convinced his parents are going to try to keep some of his inheritance from him, so he's linking it all together so it can't go anywhere.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this lion surrounded by the thousands of grains of rice he'll inherit from his parents. He's carefully threading them all together.
additionalR:
Hints
I'd much rather inherit a cake than a ton of hard to keep track of rice, like this poor lion.
readingMnemonic: If you're going to inherit something from your parents, try to convince them to make it cake (けい), not rice. A single cake is much easier to keep track of and probably tastier (though it will be super stale by the time they die).

meaningMnemonic: When you go on a scooter, anything valuable, you need to leave behind.
additionalM:
Hints
Rings, necklaces, wallets, phones? Don't take them on a scooter. Leave behind all that valuable stuff!
additionalR:
Hints
If you keep too many of your valuables on you, the eagles might not leave you behind either! They'll just pick you up off the scooter and carry you and your valuables off to their nests!
readingMnemonic: Anything you don't leave behind will be stolen by eagles (い). Eagles like shiny, valuable things, especially ones that are bouncing around on you while you scoot by on a scooter.

meaningMnemonic: You tie a piece of thread to your turkey in order to maintain proximity to it. The turkey likes to run away, so you tie a thread to it. This way you can hold the other end and maintain your turkey.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding onto a thread that is attached to a turkey. Feel the turkey tug against the thread as you struggle to maintain control.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you and the turkey and the eagle are all bumbling about in pandemonium. You try to maintain order but it’s not possible. What a kerfuffle.
readingMnemonic: The reason the turkey is struggling is because there’s an eagle (い) swooping down to attack the turkey. You try to maintain control, but once you see the eagle as well, you let go of the thread.

meaningMnemonic: There is a big jackhammer in Nara. That jackhammer is the biggest in all the land and is on display in Nara, Japan.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this big jackhammer. Look at it. It’s so big. Also it’s in Nara. Imagine being in Nara and looking at this big jackhammer. You’re all like, dang – that’s a big jackhammer.
additionalR:
Hints
Just keep in mind what the first part of Nara is. The first part of Nara is “na” so you’ll have no trouble remembering this one.
readingMnemonic: What’s the first part of Nara? Na (な). Well that’s easy.

meaningMnemonic: You take a tree and slice it until you reach its nucleus. To get to the nucleus of the tree you have to make many a slice, but it’s possible.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine slicing this tree smaller and smaller until you finally get to the nucleus of it. It’s super tiny so you have to view it in a microscope. What does it look like?
additionalR:
Hints
Look at this tree nucleus that looks like a cock. While you’re watching it, the nucleus goes “Cock-a-doodle-doo!”
readingMnemonic: It looks like a cock (かく). And by cock I mean a male chicken – a rooster. Why does the nucleus of a tree look like a cock? Science is weird.

meaningMnemonic: This canopy, after your departure, will become obsolete. The canopy was here to protect you, but no one will need it once you're gone.
additionalM:
Hints
During your departure you look back at the obsolete canopy just once. It's standing there, still and alone. It's a really sad sight.
additionalR:
Hints
My sweet canopy
I don't need you anymore
You are obsolete
readingMnemonic: When something becomes obsolete, you must write a haiku (はい). Honestly, the best haiku are about something ending, so this is perfect.

meaningMnemonic: The South Dog gives you an offer. None of the other dogs in the North, East, or West offered you anything.
additionalM:
Hints
It is well known that dogs in the South are famous for their kindness and hospitality. It's customary to always offer something when a guest arrives.
additionalR:
Hints
Ken offers to carry you, too. Imagine him offering this. You can choose whether or not to accept in your mind.
readingMnemonic: The South Dog offers you the services of Ken (けん) the samurai as you traverse his lands.

meaningMnemonic: There is a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Luckily there are no ships around, so the tsunami in the middle of the open sea is not damaging to anyone.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this tsunami in the middle of the open sea. When the tsunami isn’t destroying things and is just out there in the open sea it looks really majestic and pretty.
additionalR:
Hints
You really regret saying oki doki this time. You don’t want to surf on a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Imagine doing so. It’s terrifying and wet and you don’t even know how to surf. You’re going to die.
readingMnemonic: Someone dares you to go out to the open sea and surf on the middle of the tsunami. “Oki (おき) doki,” you reply. You can’t refuse a dare. Every time someone dares you to do something, you always respond with “oki doki”.

meaningMnemonic: Stick your fingers in your mohawk and pluck each hair out, one by one.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine plucking the hairs out of your mohawk with your fingers. It's kind of hard to grab onto them at first, but eventually you're plucking them like it's nothing.
additionalR:
Hints
You didn't realize techies were so inclusive... but they just plucked and plucked at your self-esteem, until you decided to pluck your hair out of your own head.
readingMnemonic: You want to pluck all your mohawk hair out because you're a techie (てき), and everyone at your techie job keeps making fun of you for your hair choices. "Techies should be bald!" your boss screamed. So here you are, plucking your hair out to fit in.

meaningMnemonic: Escalators are used to reach things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself on an escalator. What is up above that you’re trying to reach?
additionalR:
Hints
Cucumbers grow on trees sometimes, so you need to take escalators to get up there and reach them.
readingMnemonic: You're riding the escalator trying to reach a delicious cucumber (きゅう).

meaningMnemonic: A leader has clothes that he is quite reliant on. The leader needs his clothes to make him look like a leader. The leader has become more reliant on his clothes than he is on his actual skills as a leader!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this leader in his clothes. Look how reliant he is on them. Imagine what he would be without his clothes – nothing! And also, naked.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the leader as he shouts at his clothes he’s become so reliant on to do something. Hear the countless eagles screeching around as they terrorize the neighborhood. People scream and weep in the streets.
readingMnemonic: The leader has become so reliant on his clothes that his judgment has been clouded. His kingdom has become infested with eagles (い) but the leader does nothing, trusting that his clothes will rout out the eagles if it is something that needs to be done. He’s become so reliant on his clothes that he’s started to become not so good a leader anymore.

meaningMnemonic: Someone threaded a turtle into long skinny pieces, making a rope.
additionalM:
Hints
A rope made of threaded turtles. Go ahead and grab onto it and see how it feels. A little rough, but strong.
additionalR:
Hints
Besides being awful, where did Jourm learn to thread turtles into ropes? Why does he have so many turtles despite living on such an inland farm? These are nice ropes that Jourm is making though, and you kind of want to buy some.
readingMnemonic: The person making these threaded turtle ropes is the local giant farmhand Jourm (じょう). You watch him stretch and peel pieces of turtle off of turtles, then thread them together into a rope.

meaningMnemonic: What kind of fish jumps from dirt to dirt? A salmon!
additionalM:
Hints
When you're at the river watching salmon jumping up stream, they keep jumping onto the dirt, flopping back into the water, then doing it again.
additionalR:
Hints
Salmon. Drink さけ. Salmon. Drink さけ. Salmon. Drink...
"Ughhh.... I'm feeling tipsy... Hey, where's my しゃけ!?"
readingMnemonic: You make a drinking game out of watching the salmon going up stream. Every time one jumps onto the dirt, you drink a shot of 酒 (さけ). You realize you're drunk when you ask for more さけ but it comes out as しゃけ.

meaningMnemonic: You soak each foot in water before going out in the sun to take your first step. Stepping on the ground when it's been baking in the hot sun can burn your feet, so you're careful to make them wet with water before stepping outside even once.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine each step on hot, sun-baked asphalt. The water under your feet sizzles, leaving steaming footprints where you stepped from.
additionalR:
Hints
Each step is taking you closer to とうきょう. Don't forget that, no matter how hard it seems, don't lose your motivation to keep stepping forward toward your goal. ♡
readingMnemonic: Each step you take brings you closer to とうきょう. Unfortunately, the sun keeps getting hotter, meaning you have to take breaks between steps more often, to get your feet wet with even more water. But you're determined to reach とうきょう, no matter how many steps it takes.

meaningMnemonic: A leader who's humble will stretch in front of everyone. They'll show that they have to get up every hour or so and stretch just like the rest of us.
additionalM:
Hints
The leader is humble and human, just like the rest of us, and has to stretch to stay healthy too. He's not some kind of god!
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the leader stretches his body and the nori seaweed. He takes a bite, stretches the other way, then stretches out a piece for you to eat too. How humble of him!
readingMnemonic: The leader is currently working hard to stretch in front of all of you, and as he does, he munches on some nori (の) seaweed snacks. Then he starts stretching the nori too.

meaningMnemonic: That special woman in your life will eventually take your surname and make it her family name too. Traditionally, a woman will change her last name when she gets married and keep that name for the rest of her life. Her husband’s family name becomes her family name too.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having your surname changed for the rest of your life. How do you feel about having a different family name? Is it a big deal to you or does it not matter much?
additionalR:
Hints
Now you share a family name AND a holy blue saber! You can protect your legacy (and surname) hand in hand and saber in saber. (Or something like that.)
readingMnemonic: Picture this special woman in your mind. She's changing her surname to yours and taking hold of your special saber (せい) as well. And it's... it's splitting in two!

meaningMnemonic: The sweet radical and the sweet kanji are exactly the same! Double sweet.
additionalR:
Hints
Put on the armor! Feel its weight on your body. Now taste the sweet flavor on your tongue. It’s sweet, but not too sweet.
readingMnemonic: The sweet, sweet sensation is almost overwhelming. You gotta put on some sweet resistant armor (あま) to protect you from all that sweetness. The armor will prevent you from having a sweet, sweet sweetness overload.

meaningMnemonic: You send your private sword man out with your shellfish so he can trade them. Shellfish were used as currency back in the olden days. And you aren't going to go out trading and dirty your own hands, no no. Trading your shellfish is the job for the private sword you hired!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your private sword holding a big bag of shellfish and going off to market to trade them.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh boy, I hope my private sword trades my shellfish for that new bowling ball I heard about!
readingMnemonic: While he's out making the trade for you, you decide to relax and do some bowling (ぼう). In fact, you can't wait for the trade to be done because you're hoping he's going to come back with a new bowling ball for you.

meaningMnemonic: A bundle of geoducks is something you can always trust.
additionalM:
Hints
A bundle of geoducks will never lie, never let you down, and never disappoint you. You can trust them completely.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a bundle of geoducks and a piece rye bread. Think about how you can trust the geoducks but you can't trust the rye bread.
readingMnemonic: While you can trust a bundle of geoducks, never ever trust rye (らい) bread.

meaningMnemonic: You run and call out to people at the same time because you're super ultra excited right now. You have a super crazy amount of energy you need to get out with your running and calling.
additionalM:
Hints
You're going for an ultra run, calling out with your super loud voice right down the middle of the street.
additionalR:
Hints
Mrs. Chou is super ultra scary. And if you don't kick it into super ultra high gear she's going to catch up to you and make you super ultra dead.
readingMnemonic: You're just becoming ultra tired when you hear a terrifying sound. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) barreling down toward you. "WERE YOU CALLING FOR ME, CHILD?!" she screams.

meaningMnemonic: You want to put this towel over this scarecrow, but you have to measure its width first. If the towel doesn't have a greater width than the scarecrow, some of it will be showing. Which you definitely don't want.
additionalM:
Hints
The scarecrow creeps you out. You don't want to look at it anymore, so you're standing eerily close to it measuring its width, so you can hide it forever.
additionalR:
Hints
Do you know the width of a habanero? It's one scarecrow minus one cloth.
readingMnemonic: You finish measuring the width of the scarecrow and the width of the towel, and you realize you're the width of a habanero (はば) pepper short. This is fine, you grow those. This is a whole field of habaneros! So you pluck one off the nearest plant, tape it to the cloth, and cover that scarecrow right up.

meaningMnemonic: A skewer to the heart has afflicted your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying.
additionalM:
Hints
You did not wish to be afflicted as such. Feel the skewer in your heart and the great pain it gives you. You know you’re dying.
additionalR:
Hints
You look on in horror as the affliction grabs hold and everything starts to fade, but Genghis Khan still floats before you, watching you closely.
readingMnemonic: Since you’re afflicted with the death, you start to hallucinate and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) appears before you. "Ah, I was afflicted of the same disease. It killed me, you know."

meaningMnemonic: You see an animal wearing a top hat and decide to aim at it. The top hat is a perfect, giant target you use to take down this animal.
additionalM:
Hints
It's much easier to aim for an animal wearing a top hat than one without.
additionalR:
Hints
Your aim with the soap is perfect! The soap knocked the deer's hat right off.
readingMnemonic: Ready, steady, aim... fire! You throw a bar of soap (そ) at the animal. Yes, soap. You were sitting in your bathtub, washing and scrubbing, then the animal in the top hat caught your eye.

meaningMnemonic: This building is full of cars because it's an army base. The cars (and tanks and planes) need to be ready to go at any moment just like the soldiers.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a giant army base housing all of the different cars the army needs at any given time.
additionalR:
Hints
Jeans are pretty durable, now that you think about it. And if the soldiers are working on these cars in the base while they're there, it makes sense to wear a nice pair of jeans.
readingMnemonic: All of the people in the army base are wearing jeans (じん). You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms, but it looks like when they're on the base they have to wear jeans.

meaningMnemonic: There's an explosion in the dirt under a rice paddy, exposing the hidden base under there. A base from baseball! I guess this rice paddy was built on top of an old baseball field...
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a serene rice paddy. Now watch the whole thing explode, rice and dirt going everywhere, and a secret, underground baseball base is left there, smoldering.
additionalR:
Hints
Hold this ruined base in your hands. Darn, you love baseball. At least it's a collectible.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, thanks to the explosion, the base is in ruins (るい). It's dark and smokey and kinda half burned. You probably can't get this in a regulation game.

meaningMnemonic: What's more simple than a bow? A bullet. Bullets just have to be shot out of a gun and somebody dies. Bows you have to load with an arrow and pull it back and aim, yuck. Bullets are the new bows, people.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how simple life would be if we replaced all the bows in the world with bullets. (Insert sarcastic crying face here.)
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine shooting bullets into the sun at dawn. Pow pow, take that history! Blam blam, take that dawn!
readingMnemonic: If you want to shoot bullets, you need to do it at dawn (だん). Back in the old days, it wasn't bright enough to shoot arrows at dawn, but you can shoot bullets at dawn because they're simpler to use!

meaningMnemonic: You brought flowers to place on top of the place where a yakuza took a spoon and killed twenty people, and there is now a burial happening. You carefully toss the flowers in with the dirt and everything is buried together.
additionalM:
Hints
This is the biggest burial you've ever seen. The hole is huge. It has to fit twenty people, after all, and the spoon didn't cut them up to make things any easier.
additionalR:
Hints
I guess the twenty souls couldn't go up to... wherever... until they had a proper burial.
readingMnemonic: Once the burial is complete the souls (そう) of all the dead people come floating up and out of the ground. "Thaaannk YooOoOO~" they moan, as they ascend to the sky.

meaningMnemonic: You take your fingers and slam a lid on the table. You make this big noise to confront the person in front of you.
additionalM:
Hints
They weren't listening, which is why you slammed that lid down. You'll have to confront them more directly.
additionalR:
Hints
こういち is laughing at you as you confront him. Which makes you angrier, so you bang the lid on the table some more.
readingMnemonic: You are trying to confront Emperor こういち. You're confronting him about all the kanji he's forcing you, and everyone else, to learn. "Look here こういち! I know you said I'd learn like 2000 kanji in no time, but this is way too efficient! What will the people do when they're done? Do you think they will sit idly by?"

meaningMnemonic: Below this mountain, a moon and another moon crash into each other and the entire thing crumbles to pieces.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch as the moons crumble together, and then the mountain slowly crumbles down into them too.
additionalR:
Hints
