Your home crumbles like a dry cookie until it's nothing more than a bunch of dust, mixed in with the mountain and the moon. Now where will you live?
readingMnemonic: As the mountain crumbles you see your home (ほう), which is at the very top of the mountain, come crumbling down too.

meaningMnemonic: On the scooter is an insect and a bear. The bear immediately stomps the insect, squishing it flat. "My god, the insect is smashed. Someone call dispatch!"
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the conversation with emergency services. They say they will dispatch an ambulance immediately.
additionalR:
Hints
He takes out a very tiny katana and performs surgery right there. The insect dies on the scooter. "It looks like I've dispatched this insect to the afterlife."
readingMnemonic: Out of the dispatched ambulance jumps Ken (けん) the samurai. "Dispatch sent me! I'm here to fix that insect."

meaningMnemonic: You're in prison, but you can use your fingers and a spoon in the light of the sun to display little moving pictures on your cell wall. It's like a shadow puppet display except you can only make a few characters with your limited hand tools.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine displaying your two favorite characters in the shadows on your prison cell walls. This one is mister fingers and this one is missus spoon. They're best friends.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine displaying cake on the wall. Now pretend to eat the shadow cake with your spoon. You can almost taste it. Except you can't, because this is still prison.
readingMnemonic: There is one thing you display more than anything else and it's cake (けい). You smush your fingers to make a cake shape and use the spoon to pretend you're eating it.

meaningMnemonic: If you combine fire with violence, it will explode! A fire, once full of violence, will surely explode. The fire can’t handle all that violence so the fire just rumbles and shakes and then finally explodes. BOOM!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the fire explode. Feel the heat of the fire and the explosion. It’s very violent. BOOM BOOM BA-BOOM!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself as you back away from the explosion. As you back away, see the fire dance and feel the heat of the explosion on your face.
readingMnemonic: As you watch the fire explode, you start to back (ばく) away. I don’t blame you. You need to back away or else you’ll get caught in the violent explosion. Back away a little more just to be safe.

meaningMnemonic: You're holding a flag on a stick above your eyes to imitate eyebrows. You can't grow any of your own, but you really love eyebrows, so this was the best you could do.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at yourself in the mirror. You can see the stick holding up the flag and it's very clear you drew some eyebrows onto the flag with some markers, but you still look pretty good (in your opinion).
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine walking around town, holding your eyebrow flags. You can feel the meat sticking above your eyes. They stink and they're weirdly lukewarm, but you know your real eyebrows will grow under them any day now.
readingMnemonic: Underneath your fake eyebrows are two slabs of meat (み). Meat helps hair grow, according to many Internet specialists who also happen to sell meat. You're waiting for this meat to foster eyebrow hair, and when that sweet day comes you won't need these flags.

meaningMnemonic: You carry a cross across a rice paddy with a heart on it to return a favor for your friend. The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it.
additionalM:
Hints
This is a pretty big favor. Imagine running through a rice paddy carrying a cross with a warm beating heart on it. Thump thump. Thump thump.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how dumb you feel at this miscommunication. Eh? You don’t feel dumb? Well you should!
readingMnemonic: You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the favor you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “Eh (え)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine!

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami pushes all the fish closer to land, making for some easy fishing. The tsunami starts out in the middle of the ocean and pushes all the fish towards the coast where everyone does their fishing. With all the fish pushed closer to land and closer together, it’s very easy for people to go fishing in one spot and catch a lot of fish.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine going fishing for fish in a fishing spot after a tsunami. There are SO many fish here. Your hook barely touches the water and there’s already a fish on it. Man, fishing like this is easy! Smell the smell of fish and sea air around you.
additionalR:
Hints
Go! Go row! Go and row for the fishing! How do you go? You row! The row part should be pretty easy to remember since you gotta row your boat out to sea, but if you’re having trouble with the go part, just remember that it has the same reading as 魚.
readingMnemonic: To get to the best fishing spot you need to go (ぎょ) row (りょう) out to the middle of the ocean. You go by means of rowing. To get to the fish and do the fishing, you need to go and row out to sea.

meaningMnemonic: Grain left in the sun blossom and give off a wonderful fragrance. They smell fresh and delicious. There's nothing better than the fragrance of fresh, sun-kissed grain.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this warm, grain fragrance. What does it smell like to you? Cooked rice? Gentle flowers? A warm summer's day?
additionalR:
Hints
This fragrance was こういち's armpits the whole time. You thought it was warm grains. Or... maybe he smells like... grains?
readingMnemonic: As you sniff this lovely fragrance you get lost in the smell. When you open your eyes again, you see a farming こういち standing in front of you. With... his... arm... up. "Do you like my fragrance? I was genetically modified to have a unique fragrance compared to the other こういちs."

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami dug out a chunk of the land and now it looks like a big red bow. It's a gulf now!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all the famous gulfs you learned about in geography class. Most of them look like someone pressed a bow into them and dug out the land. (And just imagine they're red because the earth is bleeding, making the sand red.)
additionalR:
Hints
Watch one tsunami come in and cut out a chunk of land, leaving behind a big, red gulf.
readingMnemonic: How many tsunamis does it take to make a gulf? Just one (わん). If there were more, then no land would be left behind. It would all be taken into the sea.

meaningMnemonic: Your foot heard an omen and now it's making you hop over things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your foot hearing this omen, "If you step on a crack, you'll break your mother's back." Now your foot hops over all of the tiny cracks in the street and the sidewalk and you look really silly.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're hopping away in fear from Mrs. Chou!
readingMnemonic: As you hop you start to hear an awful scream coming down the street. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) and she's running straight for you yelling, "STEP ON MY STREET'S CRACKS! STOP HOPPING OR YOUR MOTHER WILL NEVER BREAK HER BACK!"

meaningMnemonic: Take your fingers and wrap them around another person. This is called a hug. Just make sure you include all the stuff attached to your fingers, like your hands and arms too, otherwise it's more of a squeeze, and we don't want to do that to people.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture it like you're a baby who is new to hugs. You start with your fingers, spread them out and move forward. Now wrap all that stuff attached to your fingers around another person. You did it! You're hugging now!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting a nice, big hug from your dad. Mm. It's cozy and feels like home.
readingMnemonic: Who do you love to hug the most? Your dad (だ)! He gives the best hugs. They're warm and big and tight and comforting. The kind of hug dads are really good at giving.

meaningMnemonic: Put the sun in prison and everything will always be in season. If the sun is in prison, the seasons can't change. Want to wear a giant weenie costume all year round? Put the sun in prison on Halloween. Now your weenie body is always in season because it's always the same time of month.
additionalM:
Hints
You're welcome. Now you know how to keep everything in season. Lifehack!
additionalR:
Hints
Jokes on them though. Halloween will be in season forever now. Soon it will be Halloween. Soon it will be time for candy. Soon June will end and people will forget about everything else.
readingMnemonic: When things are in season for too long, people are going to wonder what's going on. When's Christmas? When's Golden Week? Soon (しゅん), you say. Soon enough, it's June (じゅん) which is the middle of the year so everything is soon.

meaningMnemonic: When your ear is crossed with sound, it catches it like a net, and sends it to your heart for processing. Because you're using your heart to process this sound, it means you're giving it a proper listen.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the whole process of sound going through your ear and to your heart, then the gears turning to really understand what someone is saying. It's a real listen, not a fake non-heart listen.
additionalR:
Hints
Focus on listening, and focus on their message about Mrs. Chou. Feel afraid about the future because of it.
readingMnemonic: You are listening so well to what someone is saying. What are they telling you that is so important? They are telling you of the omen of Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who will destroy the earth.

meaningMnemonic: You give your servant a gun along with some other products to look to. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your servant as he looks to your gun and products. You can always look to him to take care of your menial tasks. You feel smug.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your servant as he looks to your car’s o-ring. Hear him clinking and clanking around in the garage as he does so.
readingMnemonic: After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to look to your car’s o-ring (りん). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well.

meaningMnemonic: The omen radical and the omen kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
If you know the omen radical, you know the omen kanji as well!
additionalR:
Hints
You can clarify with the person telling you the omen several things: "Do you believe in the omen about Mrs. Chou destroying the world?" "When will this omen about Mrs. Chou come true?" etc. As long as you're associating omen with Mrs. Chou you should be good, so keep harping on that.
Anyway, whenever you hear any kind of omen (omen is a radical in the kanji), there's a good chance it's going to be about Mrs. Chou.
readingMnemonic: You listen to the omen, in it, it tells of an event in the future when Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will destroy the world.

meaningMnemonic: The weight of life on your sword is big when you pledge to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding up your sword and pledging to protect the lives of everyone in this city. It's a big deal!
additionalR:
Hints
Would you pledge to give up cake to show everyone how serious you are about protecting life?
readingMnemonic: Until the city is safe, you pledge to give up cake (けい), your favorite food.

meaningMnemonic: Destroy a lantern with your knife and you'll be punished.
additionalM:
Hints
Even if it was your own lantern, why stab it with a knife? You could have recycled that. I will punish you for lantern stabbing and pollution!
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you want to stab a lantern with a knife, think about how good cake tastes and stop. Remember, DARE (Don't Attack Reusable Electronics)!
readingMnemonic: I will punish you by taking away your cake (けい)! You'll never eat cake again. Not for birthdays, not for holidays. This is your punishment.

meaningMnemonic: A greenhouse is the newest power of the city you decided to recruit. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little bit of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what you had to do to recruit this greenhouse. Imagine schmoozing with the previous greenhouse owners to recruit them to your cause and sell you the greenhouse.
additionalR:
Hints
Recruit Bobo the clown. Look at him. He’s terrifying. Bobo will make for a great deterrent for entry to your greenhouse.
readingMnemonic: After you recruit the greenhouse, you recruit Bobo (ぼ) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse.

meaningMnemonic: The leader presents you with a prize as reparation for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine receiving your reparation prize. Feel the prize in your hand. It’s all wrapped up but it’s heavy and feels expensive. What could it be?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine receiving your reparations from the Shougun himself. You're angry at him for threatening you, wounding people, and cutting off the heads of people who go against him, but you take it anyway.
readingMnemonic: The leader who presented you with this reparation is the Shougun (しょう) of Japan. He's trying to make up for all the threats he made to you and some of the things you saw (which he's now trying to cover up for).

meaningMnemonic: Everyone from your clan puts their fingers in the ground as a way to resist their lords. Your clan is made of a bunch of peasants, but you aren't going to work the land for other people anymore. You're going to resist. This is a protest! Your fingers work for no one but yourselves from now on!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your entire clan putting their fingers in the ground in unison as a form of resistance. It's a moving sight.
additionalR:
Hints
You make your choice to resist. He orders his guards to pull your fingers out of the ground, chop them into the size of tater tots, and then deep fry them. After they're done, the lord pops one in his mouth and says, "Oooh, resistance is delicious."
readingMnemonic: You're all resisting with your fingers in the ground, when the lords appear, angry. "You resist us by hiding your fingers with potatoes in the ground?! You want your fingers to be useless potatoes so badly? We'll chop them up and turn them into tater (てい) tots!"

meaningMnemonic: This door is big and you need to return it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them.
additionalM:
Hints
Heft this big door in your arms. It’s very heavy. Feel your arms tire as you look for who to return the door to.
additionalR:
Hints
You’re obsessed with returning this big door. Once you enter this mode, the only way to get out is to return the thing you have.
readingMnemonic: You are in return mode (もど). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode.

meaningMnemonic: The sun calls out to the earth by shining down on it.
additionalM:
Hints
The sun doesn't have a voice, unfortunately, so it calls out the only way it can, with its shining rays.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun standing in the shining sunlight. He's so bright and beautiful!
readingMnemonic: This shining is aimed directly at the Shougun (しょう). The sun is shining on the Shougun to not only show its support for his leadership, but to let him shine brighter than anyone else in Japan.

meaningMnemonic: The skewer radical and the skewer kanji are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to use this cushy skewer. It's the right shape (long, thin, pointy at one end), but every time you try to put something on it it squishes in on itself like a long marshmallow.
readingMnemonic: Uh oh, this skewer is really... cushy (くし). It's so soft and cushy you can't get any meat or vegetables onto it.

meaningMnemonic: At this gate you're trying to get some beans through, but the measurements were off and you're starting to struggle. No matter how you push or pull these beans, they're just too big to get through the gate.
additionalM:
Hints
"I'm really struggling here, I thought you said you measured these beans?" you ask the bean seller. "I did! I mean, I struggled with the measurements, I'm not very good at math..." Ugh.
additionalR:
Hints
"How am I supposed to sell my beans if you struggle this much just to get them into とうきょう!" the bean seller shouts. It's making you struggle more, and beans start falling on your head, ripping their way out of their sack.
readingMnemonic: You continue to struggle because you need to get these beans to the other side of the gate and into とうきょう. You usually struggle a little when people want to bring things through the gate to とうきょう, but this is ridiculous.

meaningMnemonic: Happiness is a circle that's tenacious. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can.
additionalM:
Hints
Be tenacious about happiness in your life. No matter how many times it slips away, don't give up. Keep going after it, because it will absolutely come back if you're tenacious enough.
additionalR:
Hints
Will someone take the shoe sometimes? Yeah, but the shih tzu doesn't give up. That's how you need to be with happiness. Kids, be tenacious!
readingMnemonic: Happiness is as tenacious as a shih tzu (しつ) with a shoe (しゅう). That little dog does not want to give up on the shoe, no matter what's happening around it.

meaningMnemonic: Your foot is a little red and you can see traces of ink streaked on it. Where did these traces come from?
additionalM:
Hints
You look closer at your foot, examining the traces of red ink, and slowly the night before comes back to you.
additionalR:
Hints
As you feel the sexy, confident feelings return, you see traces of the ink on your carpet, all the way from the door to the bed. Dang it.
readingMnemonic: Turns out the traces of red ink were from a sexy (せき) rave you were at last night. Everyone around you looked so sexy, with their glow-in-the-dark paint, so you decided to put some of the red ink on your feet so everyone could see your sexy dancing.

meaningMnemonic: A triceratops with a moon knife can whittle down anything.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the triceratops with its little moon knife, doing some whittling. Hand it anything and it will whittle it down.
additionalR:
Hints
Check out the sack that holds all the things that the triceratops whittled down. Go ahead and look through it, it's quite filled.
readingMnemonic: Everything it will whittle down shall be put in a sack (さく).

meaningMnemonic: A leader asks half of his men to accompany him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you are one of the leader’s men who volunteered. What made you want to accompany him? Imagine the good qualities of this leader and how he inspired you to accompany him on this mission.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself as you accompany Han Solo. You try to stay calm, but you’re just so excited to be around Han Solo.
readingMnemonic: The leader you decided to accompany is none other than Han (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome.

meaningMnemonic: You get tooth orders. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your age.
additionalM:
Hints
You get baby age tooth orders (to get your first teeth). You get child age tooth orders (to get your adult teeth). Then you get old age tooth orders (when you start losing your teeth). There are tooth orders for every age.
additionalR:
Hints
Decide what age you have to be to get your first ray gun, and then imagine getting it when you hit that age. Perhaps you use this ray gun on your teeth, to keep them clean.
Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.
readingMnemonic: Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on age. There is also an age in which you get your first ray (れい) gun.

meaningMnemonic: By showing the roof of your top hat you send your best regards.
additionalM:
Hints
Giving your best regards is basically just tipping your hat and showing the roof of it.
additionalR:
Hints
YOLO means "you only live once," so in a way that's a good way to give your best regards. At the very least, it's an interesting way.
readingMnemonic: When you give your best regards you always yell YOLO (よろ) to the other person.

meaningMnemonic: The more shellfish you have, the more you can bribe people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine bribing a bunch of yakuza and politicians with all the shellfish you have. Ohohoh, you'll never be caught!
additionalR:
Hints
Yeah really, why? Why bribe people at all. You could have just been rolling in shellfish dough. Why risk everything?
And you counter with.
Why not?
readingMnemonic: Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY (わい)?!

meaningMnemonic: Someone is offering you a shellfish in exchange for a kiss. This is a bribe! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty.
additionalM:
Hints
"Come on, don't you want this shellfish?" they ask, shaking it up and down at you.
additionalR:
Hints
This is why you never accept a bribe. One second you're staring a yummy shellfish in the face, and the next you're standing alone in the road feeling used.
readingMnemonic: You go through with the bribe and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the road (ろ). No!!

meaningMnemonic: The door in that direction is among a cluster of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing all these doors, this cluster of doors. You feel confused at which one to enter but finally pick one. Hear the door creak as you open it.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as clusters of pins fall when the bowling balls hit them. You back up and peek through one of the other doors in the cluster and it also houses a bowling alley. Huh.
readingMnemonic: After you make it through the door, you come across another cluster of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire bowling (ぼう) alley and people bowling, loudly!

meaningMnemonic: A tiger needs to think and consider its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this tiger as it approaches you. Think what things it has to consider. It has to consider how big of a threat you are and so on. You need to consider how you’re going to escape from this tiger.
additionalR:
Hints
Consider this! Tigers look great in robes.
readingMnemonic: It's considering you for so long that it takes out a robe (りょ), a pipe, and an armchair and starts puffing away, staring intently at you. You didn't even know tigers could wear robes, but this one seems to use it to help itself think.

meaningMnemonic: They say if you put things on a slide, seven things to be exact, that’s the best way to consign goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what seven things you consign over to this other person for safekeeping. Visualize them in your head as you slide each one down the slide.
additionalR:
Hints
Let’s imagine what it would be like to hit this tack while sliding on the slide. It would hurt. Good thing you are consigning it over to someone. Probably safer for everyone that way.
readingMnemonic: One of the seven things you consign over to this guy is a tack (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt.

meaningMnemonic: Past stamps usually depict images contrary to current views.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this stamp. There's Columbus being hugged by a bunch of South American natives. Yikes, that's contrary to how things went, that's for sure.
additionalR:
Hints
Be contrary to the evildoers of the past and be like Kyaku instead.
readingMnemonic: Don't be the type of person who acts contrary to how they should and instead be like Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people.

meaningMnemonic: In the rain I take my rake and shake it, making a demand that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it!
additionalM:
Hints
Go out into the rain and shake your rake. Imagine shouting your demand at the sky as the rain pelts you from above.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself demanding more rain from the sky, trying to fill up your tiny juice box with what little juice rain you were able to get.
readingMnemonic: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's juice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and demand that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box.

meaningMnemonic: A mole in winter will do whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it.
additionalM:
Hints
They do most of their own chores during the rest of the year, so winter is when you should ask them to do things for you.
additionalR:
Hints
Moles will do anything for cheese, but honestly, wouldn't we all?
readingMnemonic: To get the mole to do what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of cheese (ち).

meaningMnemonic: You're on a scooter and suddenly someone throws a hot pepper at you and you have to dodge it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine riding your scooter, dodging multiple hot peppers as they're tossed at you. A few of them get stuck in the wheels and keep coming around and around, and you have to dodge them too.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the heat flow through your body. It's getting harder to dodge as the heat grows and you start sweating!
readingMnemonic: As you dodge the hot peppers, you feel a strong heat (ひ) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating.

meaningMnemonic: When you see flowers in a rice paddy you can't help but use your fingers to draw them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine using your fingers to draw these rice paddy flowers. Don't worry about how well you can draw, this is so beautiful, anyone could capture it.
additionalR:
Hints
To be fair, would you want to look at a drawing that makes you constantly smell stinky B.O.? I didn't think so.
readingMnemonic: Even though you tried to draw the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell B.O. (びょう). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O.

meaningMnemonic: You got your copy of "The Dry Knife." It's the newest edition of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry.
additionalM:
Hints
You're really into this magazine, and when you heard there's a new edition of it, you went out and bought it right away.
additionalR:
Hints
The article on Genghis Khan was perhaps the best written article in the Dry Knife series to date. How did this magazine get such a big interview?
readingMnemonic: In this edition of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis Khan (かん) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning.

meaningMnemonic: You use your scooter when the omen comes so that you can escape.
additionalM:
Hints
Unfortunately, the omen is riding a scooter too, so you're going to have to be crafty to escape this omen properly.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine scooting in and out of とうきょう traffic, the omen looming ever further back behind you. You're doing it! You're escaping!
readingMnemonic: You decide to escape this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of とうきょう. By now, you know とうきょう like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way.

meaningMnemonic: Where do you put your fingers when you're on an escalator? On the handle! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being on an escalator and wrapping your fingers around a small handle on your way up or down. It's still a bit precarious, truth be told.
additionalR:
Hints
暑か? Is the handle hot? Think about it. Is it? What does your imagination tell you?
readingMnemonic: You put your hand on the handle and an old person leans in close to you and says, "暑か?" (あつか). He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him.

meaningMnemonic: If there’s a drop on your head and the rice is big, you know you’re in the interior. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in the interior of someone’s tummy. See the big pieces of rice all around you as drops of stomach fluid continue to drop down on your head.
additionalR:
Hints
If you’re unfamiliar with this Oklahoma song, check it out on YouTube. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s belly as you hear this song booming all around you.
readingMnemonic: While you’re in the interior of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “Oklahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!”

meaningMnemonic: A leader with horns takes a lantern and searches for people to join him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this shady leader approaching you in the night. The lantern light shines in your face. Would you join him?
additionalR:
Hints
The last thing you wanted to do was join that guy so you hid in a haystack to avoid him.
readingMnemonic: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to join him. You look around and spot a large haystack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him.

meaningMnemonic: Under the moon beneath a tree there is a hat filled with water. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your knee in it.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the water splash over your knee as you stick it into this hat. It fits really well, the hat is the perfect size for your knee. Now look up at the moonlight filtering through the tree above.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the heat then the zap going through your knee. It isn't a nice heat, it's a hot heat, then BZZZT zap! Your knee was heat zapped pretty bad.
readingMnemonic: Suddenly, in your knee, you feel heat and a zap (ひざ)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hat water!!

meaningMnemonic: You change this geoduck because you want it to lean. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead.
additionalM:
Hints
Why do you want this geoduck to lean? Try to come up with your own reason. And why don't you look up what a geoduck looks like one more time for good measure. You don't want to be able to get this image out of your head.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the geoduck slowly leans toward the cake, trying to get at it for a taste. But don't let it eat any! Keep putting the cake further and further away so the geoduck has to lean more.
readingMnemonic: To get the geoduck to lean you put a piece of cake (けい) on one of its sides.

meaningMnemonic: The thread on this football is loose. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this football. The thread is loose on the football and needs to be tightened. Attempt to tighten the loose thread on the football as you hold it in your hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Listen to your friends shouting “You rule!” and hear their cheers echo in your ears as you toss the football around again.
readingMnemonic: You finally tighten the loose thread and all of your friends cheer, “You rule!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man!

meaningMnemonic: When it's spring in heaven they play music. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up.
additionalM:
Hints
Close your eyes and imagine all of the spring sounds that come down to you from heaven in the springtime. Mmm, you can almost smell the damp soil and rain.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of the souls in heaven playing spring music together!
readingMnemonic: In heaven, the ones that play music are the souls (そう) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band!

meaningMnemonic: A woman sleeps with the king and becomes pregnant. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby!
additionalM:
Hints
The king radical is slightly altered in this kanji, so just remember that the king is a strange alien and not human. Imagine being this woman and having this half-breed alien baby inside you. Feels weird.
additionalR:
Hints
What game are you playing on the Nintendo? Maybe it’s a game where you kill alien invaders? That’s messed up.
readingMnemonic: Being pregnant with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play Nintendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore.

meaningMnemonic: A woman who has a landslide getting ready inside her is pregnant. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture an ultrasound of the pregnant woman, but instead of a little baby heartbeat, you hear a scary roaring sound. That's what being pregnant is like. Waiting for the landslide to come.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being pregnant and getting kicked by the shins of your baby all day, but especially all night. You're so tired. Please let this landslide come already.
readingMnemonic: When you're pregnant the baby is constantly kicking you with their shins (しん). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you.

meaningMnemonic: You put on the shellfish mask once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind presents.
additionalM:
Hints
You're like beach santa, except you're real and you wear a mask made of shellfish.
additionalR:
Hints
Ooh hoo, it's me! the Shellfish Mask Man!
I go to beach houses and leave presents where I can!
The presents are not clothes, or anything good.
I don't even care if you leave me some food.
Try whipping some up, try cooking me peas,
It matters not, I'll leave you zombies!
Tee hee hee hee hee!
readingMnemonic: The "presents" you leave? They are actually just zombies (ぞう). You leave zombies in people's houses.

meaningMnemonic: Shove your fingers into a bowl of shrimp to select the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel your fingers touching each and every shrimp, one by one, until they graze the one you select as the perfect shrimp. Slowly pull it out and lower it into your mouth. Munch munch... ahhh! The perfect shrimp.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh, woe is me! How will I select the perfect shrimp with my fingers if there are tacks in the shrimp bowls! Boohoohoo!
readingMnemonic: You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp selection methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a tack (たく)!

meaningMnemonic: There's a scooter coming toward you with a net trapping a weird zombie on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to send back the zombie.
additionalM:
Hints
You want to send back this zombie the way it came. You definitely don't want it loose in your neighborhood.
additionalR:
Hints
You managed to send back the zombie, good for you! Genghis Khan would be proud.
readingMnemonic: As you prepare to send back the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis Khan (かん). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came!

meaningMnemonic: You have thread and some syrup and you need to spin them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine carefully dripping syrup onto a thread and then spinning it in a circle.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine eating a syrup cookie you made by spinning it yourself. Homemade is always better than store-bought.
readingMnemonic: As you spin the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a cookie (く)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air.

meaningMnemonic: Use your fingers on the cat pirate to suppress him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine suppressing a cat pirate with your own fingers. His fur is so soft, but his nails are so sharp!
additionalR:
Hints
Defend the yolk! Smell the smell of eggs in the air as you suppress the cat pirate. Maybe even share the yolk with him, once he's done trying to kill you for it. And then enjoy breakfast while petting your new cat friend.
readingMnemonic: He forgot, but you know you had to suppress the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg yolk (よく). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force.

meaningMnemonic: In your prefecture, you come from a long lineage of people who share one heart. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and suspends itself in the sky, for you to take.
additionalM:
Hints
You see the suspended heart in the distance, and make your way towards it.
additionalR:
Hints
"I've protected this suspended heart for you, for you are next in the lineage to receive it." He grabs the heart and throws it into your body.
readingMnemonic: You arrive at the suspended heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is Ken (けん) the samurai.

meaningMnemonic: You take a grain and fashion it into a gun that is small, earning you the title of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations!
additionalM:
Hints
This isn't exactly a title you're proud of, in fact, you're really embarrassed. Maybe you can make a name for yourself in something else so you can get a new title.
additionalR:
Hints
The plaque says, "No one is more deserving of this SAD title." - Love, the Shougun.
readingMnemonic: Word of your SAD title makes it all the way to the Shougun (しょう) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it.

meaningMnemonic: You thread someone together with thread. Someone is falling apart so you use thread to put them back together.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine taking some thread and putting someone back together with it. It’s awfully messy. I hope you’re good with blood.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine threading someone back together again, but this time you have an audience. Hear them “ooh” and “aah” as you put on a riveting show.
readingMnemonic: You’re threading this someone back together as part of a show (しょ). The show is a demonstration to show med students how to thread someone’s skin together after they have an accident. You’re the most experienced, so you’re leading the show.

meaningMnemonic: Your boat holds your weapon like a plate. So in a way, it's just a tray for your weapon.
additionalM:
Hints
A big boat shaped like a plate is just a tray. You keep your weapons on it, nice and flat.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself wearing your Ray-Bans as you look at your tray boat. The steel of your weapons reflect a lot of light into your eyes too. That's why you're wearing Ray-Bans.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, this boat tray is so big and flat that it keeps reflecting the light into your eyes, so you have to put on a pair of big Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses.

meaningMnemonic: Raise your fingers to the sky to symbolize that you abstain from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain.
additionalM:
Hints
Abstaining from doing what other people are doing is important sometimes. So make sure you never forget the universal abstaining symbol.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself in Central America. Standing in the water, blocking poachers from the hicatee turtles. "Abstain!" you shout at them.
readingMnemonic: This symbol to abstain comes from the hicatee (ひか) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee is endangered. So people started to rally around it, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming this hicatee!"

meaningMnemonic: On your roof every evening you meet with snakes. All snakes know your address.
additionalM:
Hints
You're snake famous. Snakes go on a pilgrimage to your address every evening. Your address is passed down from snake generation to snake generation.
additionalR:
Hints
"You only give a 手 a night. Newcomers might have a 手 or two, but some snakes who have been coming to your address for years have hundreds of 手s.
They are human hands."
readingMnemonic: The snakes come to your address every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: a 手 (あて).

meaningMnemonic: The allocate radical and the allocate kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all the jewels you were able to buy because you allocated your funds correctly. Imagine swimming in these jewels. Like a rich duck.
readingMnemonic: If you allocate your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious jewels (じゅう) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever.

meaningMnemonic: There's a tsunami coming and you can't stop the explosion of bitterness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and astringent.
additionalM:
Hints
You're reluctant to face this bitter end at the hands of a tsunami.
additionalR:
Hints
Try to stuff some of the jewels into your bitter mouth before the tsunami stops you.
readingMnemonic: With the bitter taste in your mouth, you reluctantly gather up all of your jewels (じゅう) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it.

meaningMnemonic: A mountain branch will branch off from the rest.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this part of the mountain, branching off from the rest, into a mysterious path of its own.
additionalR:
Hints
If you branch off from the beaten path, you need 1) access, and 2) to be really careful so you keep your head.
readingMnemonic: If you want to branch off from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special key (き). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the guillotine (ぎ).

meaningMnemonic: The dirt next to your village is where you bury the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the village where you grew up. Can you see the dirt area where all your ancestors were buried?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine crying as you bury your pet uni. Your tears can't save it now. (Though it is a bit ironic, since it needed salt water.)
readingMnemonic: You don't just bury dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet uni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive.

meaningMnemonic: You take gold in exchange for executing orders to construct a buzzer. You are a small bell maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you construct this buzzer with your bare hands. Feel the cool metal clink around in your hands as you put it together.
additionalR:
Hints
Wait, should this buzzer be buzzing or ringing? Oh well, you got your gold. It’s the client’s problem now.
readingMnemonic: Finally the buzzer is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes ring (りん)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do.

meaningMnemonic: There is something odd sticking out of the dirt. Oh wait, it's just the cape jutting out into the water below. Phew.
additionalM:
Hints
It's just the cape sticking out into the sea. Haha, for a second... you thought... no...
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the cape (the land mass that sticks out into water) but it's shaped just like your old cyborg. Weep a single tear.
readingMnemonic: The cape below looks just like your cyborg (さい). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories.

meaningMnemonic: A tree crab breaks into your games cabinet and steals a chess piece. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine finding this tree crab in your games cabinet trying to make off with your chess piece. This tree crab is big and you weren’t expecting to find it in your games cabinet so you’re kind of terrified. You scream in horror.
additionalR:
Hints
You put the key in your pocket and call animal control. They unlock the cabinet with the key and remove the tree crab from your home. But who’s to say he won’t be back??
readingMnemonic: Before the tree crab can make it out with the chess piece, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a key (き), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what?

meaningMnemonic: When you say "Nurse!" you're ready to defer to them.
additionalM:
Hints
If you say "nurse" you're asking something of a nurse. For this story, pretend like you don't know what to do, so you're going to defer to their skill and let them take over.
additionalR:
Hints
It makes sense to defer to the knowledge of a medical professional. When going through this story, imagine yourself trying to revive Jourm, but nothing you do works. That's why you defer to the nurse. "Save Jourm," you say. "He's just a simple, kinda weird, ten foot tall farmhand with nine toes."
readingMnemonic: You defer to the nurse because you're trying to save the local farmhand, Jourm (じょう), and you can't do it. He's bleeding a lot, and you don't know what to do.

meaningMnemonic: Whenever a turkey comes in the door, you employ them.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine hundreds of turkeys walking in. The word has gotten out amongst the turkey community that if they walk through your door, you'll employ them.
additionalR:
Hints
"I will employ turkeys, but I will never employ children!" you exclaim.
readingMnemonic: Although you employ turkeys, when a 子 (こ) walks through your door, you send them away.

meaningMnemonic: The excuse radical and the excuse kanji are exactly the same! Dandy!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, stop making excuses.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine all the men you’ve talked to in your life. Think of every excuse they’ve told you. Think of the worst excuse you’ve ever heard. Remember that.
readingMnemonic: Who always makes excuse after excuse? Men (めん)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway.

meaningMnemonic: Your buddy the sheep is part of a flock. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine following your sheep buddy back to his flock. Feel the soft fur of all the sheep around you as they baa peacefully.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the recoil or the gun in your hands and the ringing of the shots in your ears as you slaughter the flock without remorse. BANG BANG BANG!
readingMnemonic: Now take out your gun (ぐん) and murder every sheep in the flock. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun.

meaningMnemonic: In a tree on nine branches are some cross frames. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the tree bark under your palms as you climb up the tree to take a frame. You get a splinter from grabbing the frame. It really smarts.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the picture of Waka Flocka as you imagine the sound of his groovy tunes. It almost makes you forget how painful that frame splinter you got is. Almost.
readingMnemonic: The cross shaped frame you took has a picture of the American rapper Waka (わく) Flocka in it. If you don’t know who Waka is, take the time to YouTube a song of his to get the Waka beat flowin’ through your body.

meaningMnemonic: You need to allocate enough gold to buy a gun. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins and slabs and bricks.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself handing over an armful of gold bars to buy a single gun.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture an old fashioned hold up. You're holding a gun and shoveling jewels into a burlap sack. The heist of the century!
readingMnemonic: You need this gun so you can steal some jewels (じゅう)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store!

meaningMnemonic: A leader who lives in a mountain is a hermit. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this odd hermit leading mountain goats around the mountain, marching to the beat of a drum. It’s a strange sight indeed.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this old hermit fighting this centaur in a duel. Who do you think is gonna win? Hear the hermit screaming in agony as the centaur demolishes him.
readingMnemonic: One day the hermit was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a centaur せん. The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel.

meaningMnemonic: There are three slides sticking out of this building that lead to your home country. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing at the top of the building and looking down at the three slides that stretch off toward your home country. It takes a few hours to slide all the way there, but at the end you'll be home.
additionalR:
Hints
Even if you move, even if you haven't been back in years, your home country will always be your home in some way, deep down.
readingMnemonic: Your home country is your home (ほう)!

meaningMnemonic: You loiter around with a gun while your friend tries to correct a stamp to make it more honorable. Someone messed with the stamp machine and your friend is trying to correct the error. You’re loitering around with a gun since you’re his bodyguard. To have an error on the stamp would not be honorable, so that’s why your friend is going to correct it.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the weight of the gun in your hands as your friend works to make the stamp honorable again. Listen to your friend complain about how there are so few people left in the world that are honorable. Also keep in mind that the correct radical is a little different with the vertical line going through the top, so just think of that as the error trying to be corrected.
additionalR:
Hints
You run, leaving your friend and Godzilla to their honorable battle. A single tear runs down your cheek.
readingMnemonic: Just as you’re pondering what it means to be honorable, your friend gets shot by Godzilla (ご). Godzilla must have been the one who ruined the stamp! "Go, go, save yourself, Godzilla got me!" your friend cries.

meaningMnemonic: When someone wants to view the reality of your soul, show it with humility. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility.
additionalM:
Hints
Focus on the feeling of humility here. You're putting it all out there, you know? With nowhere to hide.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine humility literally moving through your shins. Can you still stand or do you need to fall to your shins, in humility?
readingMnemonic: As humility washes over you, you feel a shaking in your shins (しん). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground.

meaningMnemonic: You use your foot to kick Wolverine in the face so a turkey can leap to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine kicking Wolverine in the head with your foot as the turkey makes turkey sounds in the background. He’s taller than you so you must leap as you kick.
additionalR:
Hints
Leap! Leap onto the yak. Feel the yak fur beneath you as you ride away to safety, wind in your hair.
readingMnemonic: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you leap onto a yak (やく) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it.

meaningMnemonic: They say Mona Lisa had more modesty than any other woman at the time.
additionalM:
Hints
Leonardo da Vinci picked her for her modesty. She's so modest she shows no emotion.
additionalR:
Hints
Have you met Ken the samurai in person? He never smiles, and will never show you his emotions. He's too modest for that.
readingMnemonic: The modesty of Mona Lisa inspired Ken (けん) the samurai to become more modest.

meaningMnemonic: A drop of rain falls on a bear leaning up against a cross stuck into a mound. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this whole scene. A drop of water rouses the bear and he becomes enraged after he rolls down the mound. Hear the bear roar with anger as he charges up the mound and violently smashes the cross into the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
Now look at the bear sitting atop the mound with his head in his paws, looking like a fool filled with regret. This bear feels like a fool for attacking the cross like he did.
readingMnemonic: Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the mound on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a fool (ふ) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish.

meaningMnemonic: The one sided radical and the one sided kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a one sided situation that you've had. Now imagine the winning side with a catapult. For example, a baseball game where one team is destroying the other. That's because instead of a pitcher, they have a catapult.
readingMnemonic: Think of anything that is one sided. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a catapult (かた).

meaningMnemonic: Construction for geoducks doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a paragraph to explain what you're doing.
additionalM:
Hints
Actually imagine yourself writing one paragraph of explanation to the city so you can get the permits to construct housing for your geoducks. On the form, it specifies you should only write a paragraph.
additionalR:
Hints
In that paragraph, you praised こういち for being a great emperor, and you said that this construction project would help you to have more time to do your WaniKani reviews. Clearly you were pandering to Emperor こういち when you wrote it. But hey, it worked!
Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.
readingMnemonic: You turn in your paragraph, and it is given to Emperor こういち, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application.

meaningMnemonic: Criminal writing is always patterned. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you see the patterns in the writing this criminal did? It looks like a quilt or some plaid. It's almost beautiful, the way those death threats are arranged!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture an eagle patterned out of cut out letters. What the words say isn't important (though it is asking for a ransom on your grandma), but the underlying image is gorgeous.
readingMnemonic: As you look closer at the patterned writing you realize that it forms the shape of an eagle (い). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all!

meaningMnemonic: A building in winter will allow life to have prosperity. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a dark, bleak winter landscape. No life anywhere. Now turn around and look at the prosperity on display in the building you're in. Everyone is happy and eating food and not freezing to death.
additionalR:
Hints
Ryu's prosperity has made him realize that having things isn't always enough. Now he's looking wistfully outside at the winter weather, missing the rough times.
readingMnemonic: This prosperity isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed.

meaningMnemonic: Your mouth contains a scroll, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the range of the sphere of your mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
On the map, there is a circle drawn around your mouth showing what range your mouth exists in. Thankfully, your tongue and teeth are within that sphere.
additionalR:
Hints
Everything else on the map was accurate, so you take a close look in the mirror, and there he is: a tiny Ken the samurai, protecting the range that is your mouth. He gives you a small nod and goes back to his post.
readingMnemonic: Looking at the range of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is Ken (けん) the samurai.

meaningMnemonic: There’s an arrow in that turkey and you do everything in your power to recommend that we don’t eat the turkey. There’s an arrow in this turkey. The arrow looks a little broken, so there’s probably splinters all up inside that turkey. I know you’re all hungry but I can’t recommend eating this bird.
additionalM:
Hints
You can’t recommend this turkey. It’s probably dangerous. Imagine sending this turkey back in a restaurant, very upset with everything. Also keep in mind that the arrow is half buried in the turkey and looks a little broken since the arrow radical is a bit off.
additionalR:
Hints
Welp, I guess if Genghis Khan recommends eating food with weapons still in them, you're okay with recommending it too. Eat up, everyone.
readingMnemonic: You recommend the Genghis Khan (かん) special instead of this arrow-tainted turkey! When it comes out, your heart sinks. Genghis Khan apparently ate a cow with an arrow broken off in it.

meaningMnemonic: Show your fingers to a giant to show you refuse him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding up your fingers to show a giant you're refusing to let him do something. Yeesh, you're brave!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine standing in front of a giant, refusing to let him crush Little Kyoto. I hope he doesn't stomp on you instead.
readingMnemonic: What do you refuse? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little Kyoto (きょ). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops.

meaningMnemonic: The grain stuck in your cleat had a former life. In that life it was a rice plant. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up and cleaned up and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now it's just a sad grain in the bottom of your shoe.
additionalM:
Hints
When you look at a grain of rice, you should think of it's former life as a rice plant, not where it ended up.
additionalR:
Hints
You decide to bring the grain back to where all of the other rice plants are, and they all chant いな、いね as you return it to its home. You did a good thing today.
readingMnemonic: The grain of rice, as it thinks about its rice plant life too, mutters, "いな、いね." Yes little grain, it was a really nice life. I'm sorry.

meaningMnemonic: A big turkey has to measure a safe before he can rob it. If the safe is too big it won’t fit in his getaway van and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs the place he needs to measure the safe.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this turkey as he tries to rob this safe. See him with the tape measure as he determines whether or not the safe is too big.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the size of this uber big safe. What could be inside? Probably something good.
readingMnemonic: The safe that the turkey is trying to rob ends up being uber (うば) big. Like, really uber big. So uber big that the turkey can’t even measure it with his tape measure. There’s no way he’s gonna be able to rob this place.

meaningMnemonic: You come across a gold hill. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of steel.
additionalM:
Hints
Dig out many other spots. Every time, it's just steel under there.
additionalR:
Hints
"I suppose I can use this steel, even if it is not a hill of gold," he says. "We will make steel weapons, which we will use to subjugate other nations. The whole world will learn kanji using the WaniKani system!"
readingMnemonic: You report your findings about the steel you found to Emperor こういち. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel.

meaningMnemonic: The turtle shell radical and the turtle shell kanji are exactly the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Cowabunga!
additionalR:
Hints
Because this is WaniKani, こういち has probably set the turtle shell on fire, too. "Burn those turtle shells, burn those kanji!" he yells.
readingMnemonic: With a turtle shell on his back, imagine こういち.

meaningMnemonic: There are hot peppers hiding in this dirt, so you build a wall to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself walking around and seeing a wall around some dirt. You look inside and there are some hot peppers hiding just below the surface. Phew! Good thing this wall was here to protect you from them.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture some corn cobs. Now picture some hot peppers. Put a wall between them.
readingMnemonic: On the other side of this wall there are much less threatening cobs (かべ) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in.

meaningMnemonic: When a spirit stops protecting you, you'll have to go on welfare. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else.
additionalM:
Hints
The next time you see someone on welfare, be nice. Their spirit stopped protecting them, so they need a little more help right now.
additionalR:
Hints
If you've ever been on welfare you probably already know about the sheep.
readingMnemonic: While on welfare, you have to do the only job available to you: herding sheep (し). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it.

meaningMnemonic: Every winter you are alert for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself out in the winter wilderness. You hear twigs snapping, growling, leaves rustling. You’re incredibly alert and aware of everything going on around you.
additionalR:
Hints
Listen to the sasquatch rumble on by as you continue to smell the smelly smells of this putrid bin you’re in.
readingMnemonic: Being the alert fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash bin (びん) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe.

meaningMnemonic: You attempt to expel wind out of your mouth but lack the breath to blow out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so.
additionalM:
Hints
Blow some air out of your mouth. It’s easy, right? Imagine what could cause you to fail at this activity.
additionalR:
Hints
Attempt to blow air out of your mouth while covering it with your hand. It’s hard to do, right? Only a fool would try to blow air out of their mouth this way.
readingMnemonic: You silly fool (ふ), the reason you couldn’t blow any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you.

meaningMnemonic: It's time to do the mouth sun sun chant. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears.
additionalM:
Hints
Open your mouth and practice the chant right now! Sun sun, sun sun, sun sun!
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun is glaring intently at you as you chant. Open your mouth as wide as you can, get all those "sun suns" out, and pray that the sun will appear.
readingMnemonic: You're doing this chant because the Shougun (しょう) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him.

meaningMnemonic: If you try to go somewhere but you're too heavy you'll collide with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all.
additionalM:
Hints
Imaging being too heavy to go anywhere without colliding with things.
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun is glaring at you from the ground. "You've been colliding with my entire city and now you collide into ME?!" Smoke blows out his nostrils.
readingMnemonic: You're going around the town, you collide with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the Shougun (しょう)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad.

meaningMnemonic: The drunkard issued twenty commandments to his people.
additionalM:
Hints
He basically just made up a bunch of commandments to order all the other drunkards around and decided having twenty (twice the amount of that other religion he heard about) would be a good number.
additionalR:
Hints
Commandment 1: Thou shalt not touch my kayak
Commandment 2: Thou shalt not look at my kayak
Commandment 3: Thou shalt give me beer to put in my kayak
It goes on like that for a while...
readingMnemonic: The drunkard is yelling out his twenty commandments to the others at the bar, but they're all about kayaks (かい).

meaningMnemonic: The Mona Lisa is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa concurrently," says your art class teacher.
additionalM:
Hints
Pay close attention to the students around you. Don't go too fast or too slow, or you won't finish concurrently.
additionalR:
Hints
It's a nice painting, the frown is just right, and you finished concurrently with everyone else, but you're probably going to fail this class.
readingMnemonic: Your entire class finishes concurrently. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted Ken (けん) the samurai.

meaningMnemonic: The flowers are being worked upon by a tsunami with a specialty for knowing how to dilute things. The tsunami can dilute the flowers by pouring itself onto it. A tsunami can dilute things because it is made of water. You could say that it’s its specialty.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the flowers as they begin to dilute. Their color and fragrance and dimensions become weaker and more spread out. It’s really trippy to witness.
additionalR:
Hints
As you continue to watch the flower dilute due to the water being poured onto it by the tsunami, imagine what techniques this tsunami is using to hack nature. Is the tsunami a super cyborg from the future? Maybe.
readingMnemonic: As you watch the flower dilute, you determine that this is obviously a nature hack (はく). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature.

meaningMnemonic: When you're driving, you may notice the flags in the dirt near the exits. These flags mark the ditch running along the side of the road. You won't want to try to exit the road here or you'll end up stuck in one.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the flags in the dirt. Picture the ditch just over the edge of them. Now look for another way to exit this road, cause that way is just not a good idea.
additionalR:
Hints
It's a pun, get it? Holy. Hole-y. The ditch is a long hole. See? It's funny.
readingMnemonic: If you do end up veering into a ditch you'll find yourself yelling, "Holy (ほり) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch.

meaningMnemonic: Simultaneously, you throw your knife at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a dose of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch as the dose of poison sinks into your body through the knife that's in your chest, as it simultaneously happens to the other guy too.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're begging them for a dose of the xylophone drug. Just a taste, you want to live!
readingMnemonic: "I need a dose of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny xylophone (ざい) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?"

meaningMnemonic: A fang on a turkey is elegant. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this turkey with a fang. It’s elegant, but also frightening. See the fanged turkey staring at you menacingly.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this elegant gargoyle sitting in front of you. Reach out your hand and feels its hard, elegant stone gargoyle body.
readingMnemonic: This elegant fang makes the turkey look more like a gargoyle (が) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle!

meaningMnemonic: Teachers are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of filial piety.
additionalM:
Hints
Respect your elders, for they have much to teach us.
additionalR:
Hints
I am so ignorant and have much to learn. I must show filial piety to my father, こういち, so that he may teach me.
readingMnemonic: With filial piety in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is こういち.

meaningMnemonic: You walk by a geoduck a frequent amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking around near this geoduck. This is the best area to frequent when you want to look at the geoduck. Just keep looking at it as you walk.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at all the Hindu people as you walk around and observe the geoduck. Hear them all speaking Hindi as you continue to walk around.
readingMnemonic: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because Hindu (ひん) people frequent this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people.

meaningMnemonic: A horse goes to his favorite district to gallop around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there.
additionalM:
Hints
Hear the horse clip clopping around the district as it continues to gallop. Clip clop, clop clip clop!
additionalR:
Hints
The tires screech, the horse neighs, BAM! Total destruction everywhere. Bystanders scream in horror. That horse will never gallop again. It’s a sad day for all horsekind.
readingMnemonic: Then the horse gallops into the road and gets hit by a car (か). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of all the spiders is a genius! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing the leader of the spiders weaving it's own little spider computer. Doing spider math, and spider chemistry. It's a genius!
additionalR:
Hints
Soon we'll be slaves to the genius spiders. Soon we'll be the flies.
readingMnemonic: As you watch the spider genius you realize that soon (しゅん) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs.

meaningMnemonic: A woman is rejoicing. She must be glad and happy to rejoice out loud in front of you like this.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a woman rejoicing loudly. She's got a big smile on her face and she wants you and everyone else to see how glad she is.
additionalR:
Hints
You'd be happy too if you'd just found your lost keys. Though maybe you wouldn't shout it for the entire world to hear.
readingMnemonic: "I'm so glad!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the key (き)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys.

meaningMnemonic: There’s grass on the ground and the fins there say you have no honor. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor.
additionalM:
Hints
Listen to what the fins have to say as they flop around on the ground in the grass. Hear them swish about as they flop, brushing up against the blades of grass.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine taking your yo-yo out to do this. Feel the string tighten around your finger as you unleash the yo-yo and silence all the fins.
readingMnemonic: Being one of little honor, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your yo-yo (よ). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have.

meaningMnemonic: You take flowers down a slide to a drunkard that you picked from your luxuriant garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.
readingMnemonic: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.

meaningMnemonic: Under the same flag, all the people get together to present a new weapon to your lord. You all bow and say, "Milord, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord.
additionalM:
Hints
When you address your lord you better say "milord," otherwise you might get beheaded with the weapon you're all giving him.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh no, oh no, oh no! Now the lord is running around with his dented weapon trying to put dents in all of you. You don't want a dent in your head! Run!
readingMnemonic: As you give the lord his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, Milord?" you ask. "THERE'S A DENT (でん)!" he bellows.

meaningMnemonic: When you go to the yakuza to fix your problems they'll just multiply.
additionalM:
Hints
