You thought you had problems before? Yikes, now you've done it. The yakuza are just going to make all of your problems multiply!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel shock envelop your entire body as late payments multiply into more debt, and the number of people mad at you multiply too. You can't even think from the shock of it all.
readingMnemonic: Just like I said, your problems multiply before your eyes and give you quite a shock (しょく). You really shouldn't be shocked though, because I warned you this would happen.

meaningMnemonic: Inside that building someone is doing a rice dance. That someone is your neighbor.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your neighbor doing a rice dance, whatever that may be, in the building next to yours. That's your neighbor, for ya.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the ring your neighbor has as overly extravagant. You have to make it wild enough for you to remember. Maybe it is integral to their rice dance. Perhaps you covet your neighbor's rice dance ring.
readingMnemonic: Your neighbor has an incredible ring (りん) that they use for their rice dance.

meaningMnemonic: Every winter the thread fields become overgrown. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to wade through this overgrown field of thread. It’s really difficult, and also it’s really cold because it’s winter. You shiver. Imagine chopping the thread down with your machete. Chop chop chop!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself as Han Solo, bravely blasting your way through the overgrown thread with your blaster. Pew pew pew!
readingMnemonic: The reason this field of thread got so overgrown is because you’re Han (はん) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete.

meaningMnemonic: You're using your scooter to navigate the flood because you're on patrol. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine patrolling the flood waters on your scooter, which is bubbling and scooting along on the surface of the water. You have to be extremely vigilant in your patrol, you don't want any lives to be lost on your watch.
additionalR:
Hints
You're in a group with a bunch of other scooter people, and you're all assigned to one month of flood patrol duty. But you got June. The floodiest month. Womp womp.
readingMnemonic: You have to patrol all of the floods in June (じゅん). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot.

meaningMnemonic: This tree is the master of a pillar. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master.
additionalM:
Hints
See the pillar next to the tree master. See the pillar bow over and over in veneration of its tree master.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the crack and snap of branches as the tree beats the crap out of the pillar for having murdered Chewbacca. Unforgivable.
readingMnemonic: While bowing, the pillar accidentally smashes Chewbacca (ちゅう). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished.

meaningMnemonic: Use your fingers to shoo a turkey down the stairs and into a portable carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers.
additionalM:
Hints
Turkeys aren't portable on their own. I mean you could pick one up I guess, but it will bite and poop on you. So get it in a portable carrier first.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting a portable turkey cake made of your pet turkey. It's made of turkey friendly cake mix.
readingMnemonic: You needed the turkey to be more portable because you're going to be bringing it to a cake (けい) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference.

meaningMnemonic: Lift the lid off your preserves, kick it, and praise the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be!
additionalM:
Hints
You also praise the lid. And praise the plants and animals that gave you the food.
additionalR:
Hints
If you're going to praise the ingenuity of the invention of the "lid" for its preservation methods, you should definitely do it from home. Or at least from the internet from home. Find your people where you can, you know?
readingMnemonic: You do this praising in your home (ほう), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects.

meaningMnemonic: Raise your fingers to a criminal to reject their request to have your things. If someone is trying to steal something from you, just reject them.
additionalM:
Hints
"Talk to the hand, I mean, fingers!" you say, refusing the criminal.
additionalR:
Hints
You refuse to listen to any other haikus and you push your fingers into the criminal's face and walk away.
readingMnemonic: After you refuse him, he recites this haiku (はい) at you:

meaningMnemonic: A horse is your master and you are merely a resident in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having a horse as your master. Hear him neigh out orders to you and the other residents of the horse master’s house.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Chewbacca in a cage in the horse master’s house. You’ve proved yourself a worthy resident. Hear Chewbacca making his Wookie sounds as he bashes against the bars of his new cage.
readingMnemonic: To prove yourself a worthy resident of the horse master’s house, you must capture Chewbacca (ちゅう). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca.

meaningMnemonic: You employ a geoduck to review all your work.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine hiring a geoduck, then ask them to review your work. Please review my writing, geoduck. Please review my record-keeping, geoduck. Please review my taxes, geoduck. This geoduck you employed can review anything for you.
additionalR:
Hints
The geoduck tells you that while it was reviewing your records, it found information about a child you have. Even you didn't know this, so you're surprised that this review geoduck found something like this.
readingMnemonic: As the geoduck reviews your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a 子 (こ)!

meaningMnemonic: The cow of righteousness is always there for us. He is the cow that must sacrifice himself for us to survive.
additionalM:
Hints
The reason he is sacrificing himself is so we can all eat! Yum! Thanks to your sacrifice, righteous cow, we all have hamburgers. You should think about all the cows you ask to die for you every day. Maybe say thanks next time.
additionalR:
Hints
Of course, the reading is also shared with kanji like 義. The righteousness radicals seems to have that effect on kanji.
readingMnemonic: The sacrifice must be done via guillotine (ぎ). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing.

meaningMnemonic: You see an animal with some flowers and a turkey on a stool trying to seize them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this turkey straining itself on the stool trying to seize the flowers, grunting with effort. You think he’ll ever get them?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this scene again only with a big cock holding the flowers as the turkey attempts to seize them. Hear the cock shouting cock-a-doodle-doo as it defends its flowers.
readingMnemonic: The animal the turkey is trying to seize the flowers from is a cock (かく). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers.

meaningMnemonic: If you have gold you also need a guard with a very sharp sword to protect it.
additionalM:
Hints
You should probably also get some sharp spikes, sharp traps, and sharp spears to keep that gold safe too. Just a bunch of sharp stuff.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine covering the floor around your gold in sharp acorns. This is basically a Home Alone situation, and anyone who tries to steal your stuff is gonna get stuck full of sharp things and probably stabbed by your guard.
readingMnemonic: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a sharp acorn (えい) that's just laying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea!

meaningMnemonic: Taking a cross, you walk through the rice paddy in the direction of winter and spread your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine facing the direction of the approaching winter while facing away from the rice paddy. Feel the weight of the cross in your hands as you spread your arms and implore the winter to hold off on its arrival.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the strain on your Sheikh arms as you continue to spread them. Since you’re a Sheikh, you have to set a good example for your people, so don’t let them (or your arms) down.
readingMnemonic: You’re actually a Sheikh (しき) (an Arab leader) which makes the fact that you’re holding a cross while you spread your arms even more of a big deal. You spread your arms wider than any Sheikh ever has before.

meaningMnemonic: What kind of woman comes down from heaven? A supernatural one. She is so enchanting.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your idea of what an extremely supernatural woman would look like, and have her come down from heaven towards you. You're totally enchanted by her looks.
additionalR:
Hints
Touch the supernatural yogurt woman and feel the yogurt. Taste the yogurt, what flavor is it? It's totally enchanting you further.
readingMnemonic: The supernatural woman comes down in front of you and she's so enchanting that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of yogurt (よう).

meaningMnemonic: The scooter you made out of grains and are about to ride down the stairs is completely transparent. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this transparent scooter. Well, it's actually a bit hard to see, because it's see-through. I guess imagine the outline and the feel, as you perch at the top of your stairs.
additionalR:
Hints
Almost immediately you lose track of the scooter because it's transparent. All you see is とうきょう in front of you. And no scooter. Maybe this is why people don't make transparent vehicles.
readingMnemonic: You slip, the transparent scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of とうきょう. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back!

meaningMnemonic: In the trash is a weird looking fruit. Someone decided to abandon it here.
additionalM:
Hints
Most people abandon fruit when it's misshapen. It's probably fine though...
additionalR:
Hints
You abandon the fruit and stare intently at this key. It must be why the fruit was weird looking and abandoned in the trash... but what does it go to?! You dig through the trash and try the key on everything that's been abandoned in there.
readingMnemonic: You reach into the trash, take out the abandoned fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a key (き) inside, and you just bit into it.

meaningMnemonic: Your ice wife is amazing. She's also terrible, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your amazing and terrible ice wife. She's floating in your backyard cackling and shooting ice all around.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're floating in the backyard cackling with your amazing wife as you use your terrible saber and freeze things with her!
readingMnemonic: She turns her amazing gaze onto your saber (せい) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too!

meaningMnemonic: Dig up a mole and you attain a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level!
additionalM:
Hints
It's actually pretty easy to attain mole status. Just stand in a field. Wait for the ground to move under you and shove your hand in the earth. Blam! An achievement pops up above your head and you're there.
additionalR:
Hints
If you can attain two animal levels in one day you'll be a legend on the leaderboards.
readingMnemonic: Mole isn't enough, you want to attain sheep (し) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over.

meaningMnemonic: Wipe your fingers on this table in winter to see what it was based on. The cold winter weathers cover the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine tracing your fingers over the table, the cold winter frost stinging them, as you reveal the secrets of this table and what it was based on.
additionalR:
Hints
The buildings and temples are all very childlike. Like crayon drawn on a table.
readingMnemonic: This particular table was based on Little Kyoto (きょ). Little buildings and temples, that sort of look like Little Kyoto. Problem is, it was made by a 子 (こ), so it's not very good.

meaningMnemonic: On the insect signpost there is a single sign that says bee.
additionalM:
Hints
This particular insect signpost points you to where the bee is.
additionalR:
Hints
You got to see a single bee hatch! What a beautiful sight. Weird that a signpost points to it.
readingMnemonic: Thanks to the insect signpost you find the bee. You make it just in time to see the bee hatch (はち) from its egg.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of righteousness is the only one who can run this ceremony. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it.
additionalM:
Hints
Have him run your ceremony for you. Think about why he is so righteous, then think about an extremely righteous ceremony.
additionalR:
Hints
*CHOP*
readingMnemonic: Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this ceremony is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a guillotine (ぎ).

meaningMnemonic: You climb up a mountain and a cliff in search of fire, but all you find is charcoal. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing.
additionalM:
Hints
You’re angry that you could only find charcoal so you take the charcoal in your hands and you crush it atop the cliff on the mountain. Feel the charcoal breaking in your hands as the wind carries the charcoal dust off from the top of the cliff on the mountain.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine lying out in the sun next to the crushed charcoal, thinking you’re going to get tan. You’re very surprised when you actually catch on fire. Hot hot hot!
readingMnemonic: After crushing the charcoal, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lay out in the sun for a while to get a tan (たん). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops.

meaningMnemonic: The clothes radical and the clothes kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!
additionalR:
Hints
Look at the eagle and her egg sitting atop your clothes. Every time you get close the eagle starts to screech at you fiercely. Screee! Screee!
readingMnemonic: An eagle (い) sees a pile of your clothes and lays an egg (え) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami carries a husband and his husband up into the sun where they conceal their centaur. The two husbands run a centaur farm, but the local government isn’t too pleased by this so they have to conceal their centaurs in the sun unless they want them to be confiscated by the government.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the tsunami carrying the husbands and the centaur up into the sun. Hear the water gushing as they conceal the centaur up there. That tsunami is gigantic.
additionalR:
Hints
Just make sure to remember there is a centaur up on that tsunami with the husbands. They need to conceal the centaur to keep it safe.
readingMnemonic: What is it the husbands are going to conceal? Oh that’s right, a centaur (せん). They are concealing a centaur in the sun. How forgetful of you.

meaningMnemonic: The leader gets a nice uniform for the sake of not wanting to look like a fake. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this fake leader. See him scramble into a uniform. Does he look like a real leader? Or can you tell that he is a fake?
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the guillotine comes down. You close your eyes for a second, and when you open them you see that the leader's body was a fake! Wait, where did he go?!
readingMnemonic: Well, everyone found out he was a fake anyway, and now you're all going to use a guillotine (ぎ) to cut off his fake head.

meaningMnemonic: A fire in the rice paddy burns down the field. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm!
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this fire burning the rice paddy and the surrounding field. Smell burnt rice in the air as you see the flames dance before your eyes.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine running around this hot cay as you try to put out the fire in your field. The fire is ravaging the entire hot cay, so it takes you a while to put it out. Man those flames are hot.
Also, this kanji can have the reading はた for the kun'yomi as well. If you learn the longer version (はたけ) it will be easier to just shave off a kana to remember the shorter version.
readingMnemonic: Your rice paddy farm and field are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a hot-a cay! (はたけ) Mama mia!

meaningMnemonic: A Viking insect is a firefly. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this little firefly blinking his firefly light as he flies around shouting a Viking warcry and brandishing an axe. Yaaaargh!
additionalR:
Hints
Hear Hotaru’s shrill scream as she runs away from the Viking firefly. If you don’t know what Hotaru Tomoe looks like, Google a picture of her to get a better visualization.
readingMnemonic: The Viking firefly is attacking Hotaru (ほたる) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones.

meaningMnemonic: A gladiator turns his hand into a fist. A fist for punching other gladiators.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the gladiator squeezing his hand into a tight fist, raising it up and yelling.
additionalR:
Hints
Ken and the gladiator clash! Fists fly! You've never seen hand-to-hand combat like this! You can hardly keep up!!
readingMnemonic: The gladiator's fist is now aimed at Ken (けん) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists.

meaningMnemonic: Everyone has a poop guy from their hometown. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the poop guy from your hometown. Picture him really vividly. The awkward, rude things he does. The way he smells. The way he makes you never want to come back.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine all the wonderful things that exist in your hometown of きょうとう. All the things you love to do and see. And now picture poop guy. Ruining it all with his poop hands.
readingMnemonic: Your hometown is in きょうとう which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in きょうとう too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up.

meaningMnemonic: The roof (hive) on a certain insect (a bee) is what protects all of the honey.
additionalM:
Hints
Bees are a certain insect that build a roof around their honey.
additionalR:
Hints
Your thick mitts make it so the bees can't even sting your hands. Unfortunately, you are naked and only wearing mitts, what were you thinking?
readingMnemonic: To get the honey out, you need to put on special mitts (みつ) so your hands don't get stung.

meaningMnemonic: This leader has two things that remind him of his humanity: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats.
additionalM:
Hints
Reflect upon your own humanity. What does it mean to be human? Is it wearing shoes and hats? Probably.
additionalR:
Hints
Are you wearing jeans right now? If so, rub them with your hands and say aloud “Oh, the humanity!” Or just imagine wearing jeans if you aren’t actually wearing them.
readingMnemonic: Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your humanity is wearing jeans (じん). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity.

meaningMnemonic: On this scooter is a child who's trying to show that his lineage is humble. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this child scooting to his fancy, expensive university in a little suit. Compared to the other kids, his wheels are quite humble!
additionalR:
Hints
You even bought your son this humble scooter and you really hope they don't grow up to be a selfish, spoiled kid this way.
readingMnemonic: This humble child is your son (そん). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble.

meaningMnemonic: There is a tiny leader on Wolverine’s forehead sitting on a stool and commanding his troops to invade Wolverine’s brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine’s body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn’t going to invade Wolverine’s brain, he’s just going to sit on the stool and supervise.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the little leader sitting on Wolverine’s forehead as he shouts “Invade! Invade invade! Invade his brain and destroy the Wolverine!”
additionalR:
Hints
See the little soldiers slicing open Wolverine’s shin as Wolverine grunts in pain. Getting your leg cut open is not a comfortable thing, even for someone as manly as Wolverine.
readingMnemonic: Soon they realize that they cannot invade Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his shin (しん). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body.

meaningMnemonic: Open your mouth. A tiger fell in there on some spikes! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big lie!
additionalM:
Hints
Of course there isn't a tiger in your mouth. And those spikes are just normal teeth. No matter how you look at it, you're saying a lie.
additionalR:
Hints
Now at least you're not lying about spikes being in your mouth.
readingMnemonic: Lie about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using uni soap (うそ).

meaningMnemonic: Aside from gold there are a wide variety of other minerals as well.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of the wide range of minerals there are that aren't gold. There are a lot.
additionalR:
Hints
Emperor こういち is getting all the minerals, and the 鋼, so he can take over all neighboring nations and force them into a subjugation of efficient kanji learning.
readingMnemonic: One person is trying to control all the minerals of the world. That person is Emperor こういち.

meaningMnemonic: Your mouth proclaims "I am noisy and I am picky!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by.
additionalM:
Hints
The townsfolk agree with your mouth, you are noisy and you are picky and you need to shut up.
additionalR:
Hints
"Ken, your armor color is so last year. That squid you have is gross. Your sword is so gaudy. You talk like you're from the Edo Period, but it's Reiwa right now."
Your noisy and picky self just goes off on Ken the Samurai. He skulks off, defeated by your noisy and picky words.
readingMnemonic: You are so noisy and picky that the townsfolk hired Ken (けん) the Samurai to shut you up.

meaningMnemonic: Your leader is also a director so you need to pay respects to him before you can start filming. He’s a huge big-shot and you don’t want to offend him by not paying the proper respects, so you make sure to bow every time you go on stage.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine bowing really really low as you walk on set. Don’t look him in the eye! He might get upset. Just do as you’re told!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Ook Aga looking down on you and you bow, slowly walking onto the stage. Oh no, your cell phone is ringing. He’s grunting Ook Aga Ook Aga and looking around angrily. Quick, put it away and pay your respects harder!! Bow, BOW!
readingMnemonic: The name of the director is Ook Aga (うかが). Ook Aga is a caveman which is why everyone has to be really careful and make sure they pay respects to him. Ook Aga doesn’t know how to live in a civilized society so your phones and clothes scare him. You have to bow really low and respect what he says, moving slowly, so that he continues to direct you and won’t run away or hurt anyone.

meaningMnemonic: You decide to loiter next to the trash under the moon in winter so the moon's light will penetrate you. The sky is clearest in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a single beam of moonlight penetrating through the winter sky, right onto the trash.
additionalR:
Hints
The clear, penetrating beam tastes exactly like iron, which is something you really weren't expecting. But now it's filling your entire mouth and you don't want it to stop.
readingMnemonic: You want the light to penetrate you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots clear through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of 鉄 (てつ).

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits a bundle of geoducks, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating rapids! The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the shallows.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the bundle of geoducks getting smashed by the tsunami, breaking apart, and getting tossed around in the rapids.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine reaching into the shallows and saving the geoducks as they scream, “Save me! Save me!” into your ear.
readingMnemonic: After being washed through the rapids and into the shallows, the living geoducks are screaming “Save (せ) me! Save me!” They need to be saved from the water, and you are the only one who can save them. You gotta run over and help them out.

meaningMnemonic: Your mouth is showy so it makes everybody around you rowdy.
additionalM:
Hints
Your mouth is showy because it's covered in grills and bright red lipstick. People get rowdy because you're a celebrity and your showy mouth is your signature look, and everyone's so excited to see your mouth in person.
additionalR:
Hints
As you drive away in your car you flash that signature mouth at them one more time, and you can see them getting even more rowdy.
readingMnemonic: Everyone is getting rowdy so you get in your car (か) to escape.

meaningMnemonic: You're digging in the dirt when you find a tiger and a cactus. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big ruins. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking through these ruins. Picture the broken tiger and cactus statues. Try to imagine the people who used to live here before it turned to ruins.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the ruins of Little Kyoto. Try to imagine what it was like before the whole place fell apart. Maybe they would have lived on if they hadn't been doing things with sharp cacti and bitey tigers.
readingMnemonic: Well, as it turns out, these are the ruins of Little Kyoto (きょ), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago.

meaningMnemonic: The alcohol you take a measurement most carefully of is sake. Sake is very important to the alcohol culture in Japan, so you must make sure to measure it out to the precise amount.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this sake as you measure it out. Hear it pouring out of the bottle as you catch the whiff of sweet alcohol in the air.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Chewbacca drinking sake all the time while Han Solo told him he needed to stop and get help, but Chewbacca just did his yell thing and drank more sake.
readingMnemonic: You know who enjoyed sake a lot? Chewbacca (ちゅう). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did.

meaningMnemonic: You find some fingers from long ago. They must have been set aside by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside.
additionalM:
Hints
What would have to happen for you to set aside your own fingers? Try to imagine it right now.
additionalR:
Hints
Think of all the things you do with your fingers. Now picture how they would look if you had never ever cleaned them with soap. Uhg, disgusting. You should just set them aside here, and find some new ones.
readingMnemonic: I know why they set aside their fingers long ago, it's because there was no soap (そ). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long...

meaningMnemonic: Something you say to someone you become attached to should be said with sincerity. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine saying something with sincerity to someone you want to become important to you. Say something like, “I love you” out loud. Say it with the utmost sincerity.
additionalR:
Hints
Say, "I love you," again and watch your saber beating in time with your heart. If you weren't sincere it would fade and grow dull.
readingMnemonic: When you say something with complete, unabashed sincerity your special saber (せい) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere!

meaningMnemonic: A tiger has legs that belong to a tiger. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the tiger running with his tiger legs. So majestic. So fierce.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine watching the tiger as it notices the Torah and then runs away. The tiger sounds as if it is screaming in terror as it flees from the proximity of the Torah.
readingMnemonic: The tiger is using his legs to run away from the Torah (とら). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away.

meaningMnemonic: The boat that oversees other boats, land, and people is usually a warship. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a huge warship overseeing everything around it. It's big and kinda scary.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Genghis Khan aboard a monstrous warship. He's carefully watching the sea and land that he's conquered.
readingMnemonic: This huge warship is run by Genghis Khan (かん), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him?

meaningMnemonic: You use your fingers to dig through the trash in the light of the moon in winter because you're going through withdrawal. You need your fix and you need it now, so you're willing to freeze your fingers off digging through moonlit trash to get it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine withdrawal this bad, that you're in the trash like this. Close your eyes and feel the cold, smell the stink.
additionalR:
Hints
These withdrawals are turning you into an 鉄 eater. Ahhh!
readingMnemonic: The withdrawal makes you withdraw a 鉄 (てつ) and try to eat it. The taste of the 鉄 fills your entire mouth.

meaningMnemonic: Each tree needs its drum measurement done before you can say it's really made of wood.
additionalM:
Hints
There are a lot of hoodlums out there that try to dress as trees and confuse people. So make sure you measure their drum before you cut one down or tell someone your secrets under it.
additionalR:
Hints
However! A non-wood tree will be really thirsty from pretending to be a wood tree. It will start making sounds and moving and probably say, "Can I have a juice box, please?"
readingMnemonic: If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of wood, just take out a small juice (じゅ) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all.

meaningMnemonic: The wrap radical and the wrap kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Home is where the wrapped heart is.
readingMnemonic: Think about being wrapped up, nice and warm and safe in your home (ほう). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love.

meaningMnemonic: You hit a tree with an axe so you can do some analysis on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine taking this axe in your hands and chopping away at this tree to do your analysis. Hear the chop chop chop as wood chips fly into your face.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself being sexy and doing tree analysis. What sort of sexy analysis moves can you think of? Oh yeah, so sexy.
readingMnemonic: The person who is doing this analysis is very sexy (せき). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy.

meaningMnemonic: Shoot a melon out of a bow and it will fly in a steep arc. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine shooting a really heavy melon out of a bow. Watch it make an arc through the air. Trace the arc with your finger.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being a 子 and watching melons fly in arcs all over. Imagine a little 子 version of yourself giggling and clapping your hands with absolute glee.
readingMnemonic: Shooting melons in an arc is something little 子's (こ) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place.

meaningMnemonic: The mole has a knife ready for your arrival. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears.
additionalM:
Hints
Welp, your arrival didn't go smoothly. You have a knife in your foot. I'm not sure what you did to make that mole hate you, but you'll have to be more careful next time.
additionalR:
Hints
This certainly wasn't the type of arrival you were expecting when you bought your tickets to とうきょう.
readingMnemonic: Your arrival to とうきょう is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a とうきょう hospital to get this mole knife out.

meaningMnemonic: For a car, the reason why it works is because it has an axis that it is built on. If it doesn't have that, it won't work at all.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a car without an axis on it. Not a car that will work too well.
additionalR:
Hints
You're super sarcastic about this, so feel the sarcasm inside of you when you imagine this.
readingMnemonic: You see a car without an axis and it's your friend's car. He's all like "isn't this a cool car?" You reply: "Gee, cool" (じく) very sarcastically.

meaningMnemonic: If you take a thread and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a hill of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a cable.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself twisting this hill of thread up to make thicker cables. They're strong!
additionalR:
Hints
Gotta do it soon. Imagine swinging from this cable and feeling the wind in your hair.
readingMnemonic: You use this cable to swing down from a building but you need to do it soon (つな)! You're being chased by some bad guys and they've almost caught you, so if you're gonna swing to safety with this cable, you need to do it soon.

meaningMnemonic: When your fingers move like that, you know it's an omen of a challenge that will face you soon in the future.
additionalM:
Hints
What kind of challenge is it? If you look closely at your fingers sometimes you can figure out the challenge that is to come based on their movements.
additionalR:
Hints
Whenever you see an omen (radical), there's a good chance that Mrs. Chou will be a part of it. This is not a good sign.
readingMnemonic: In your finger, you see a challenge. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. Chou's (ちょう) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou!

meaningMnemonic: You take a turkey and try to boil it but you char it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there.
additionalM:
Hints
You should know better than to try to boil something without water! Now what are you going to do with this raw, but charred turkey?!
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun reaches down and bites a charred hunk off the turkey. He yells and spits it out. Why did he do that?! You have no idea but it looked nasty.
readingMnemonic: You're staring sadly at the charred turkey when you suddenly sense the Shougun (しょう) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad.

meaningMnemonic: You see a flag near the exit, so you use your fingers to dig there. Most flags mark something, and this exit is pretty obvious, so there must be something under here. At least that's what you think to yourself as you dig.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine digging under the flag by the exit of your building with your bare fingers. The dirt is getting under your fingernails as you dig. It's getting on your knees. It's everywhere.
additionalR:
Hints
You carefully un-dig the old coots and leave them to their old grumpy coot hole... basement... secret clubhouse? Whatever.
readingMnemonic: You dig until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old coots (くつ). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!"

meaningMnemonic: Take this thread and look at this part. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have distracted you!
additionalM:
Hints
You don't know what part of the thread to look at. What a distraction.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself really enjoying looking at parts of the thread. You don't know why it's so fun, but being derpy is exciting, I guess.
readingMnemonic: Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of fun (ふん).

meaningMnemonic: This bamboo can be whittled into an example of anything. See, here's a car. Here's a snake. I can make so many examples just with bamboo.
additionalM:
Hints
It's amazing how fast this guy can whittle!
additionalR:
Hints
Han Solo's bamboo example comes to life and runs off.
readingMnemonic: One last example for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of Han (はん) Solo!

meaningMnemonic: Someone's fingers touch your tongue and fasten it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this.
additionalM:
Hints
Try to fasten your own tongue with your fingers right now. You probably can't do it, right? That's because your fingers are too big and your tongue is too slippery.
additionalR:
Hints
In this case, many cats fastened your tongue. You should probably be nicer to cats from now on so this doesn't happen again.
readingMnemonic: Only one creature could use its fingers to fasten your tongue like this: cats (かつ). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?"

meaningMnemonic: Under the canopy, you use a tree for your floor. It also becomes your bed, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?
additionalM:
Hints
You lay it down, cut it into slats, and voila! A floor! And a bed!
additionalR:
Hints
This new floor + bed invention, along with your other accomplishments, have you being watched really closely by the Shougun now. He seems to be keeping an eye on you so he can swoop down and check out everything you do.
readingMnemonic: News of your amazing floor / bed spreads and reaches the Shougun (しょう), who wants to come see it. He's impressed, and asks you to build floor beds out of trees laying under this canopy in all of his buildings.

meaningMnemonic: You use your fingers in a shop to grip what you want to buy.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine picking up a few different things in a shop. If something fits nicely in your grip: buy it. If it's too small or too big, put it back.
additionalR:
Hints
Acupuncture is great for strengthening your grip strength. If you do intense shopping (like I do) you should definitely consider it!
readingMnemonic: You have a really strong grip thanks to acupuncture (あく)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles.

meaningMnemonic: In the tree district of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need hinges.
additionalM:
Hints
Don't forget to buy a hinge. Your door purchase will hinge on your hinges.
additionalR:
Hints
Really lengthen out that "sue" because it's a long "suu" for the reading and that will help.
readingMnemonic: You buy an awesome hinge and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO SUUUUEEE (すう) YOU!"

meaningMnemonic: If you have fingers it's easy to hoist things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy.
additionalM:
Hints
Hoist the sails! Hoist the anchor! Hoist a baby! All of these situations are easier if you have a ton of working fingers. (The more the better.)
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hoisting loose yogurt onto a ship. Feel it between your fingers and dripping onto your head as you hoist it above you. I hope you aren't lactose intolerant, cause it's getting all over you.
readingMnemonic: Today, though, you have to hoist a bunch of yogurt (よう). It's for your job. And lucky for you, you have fingers so it's easy! But yogurt is still slippery and heavy. Oh, did I mention this yogurt isn't contained in anything? Good luck!

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami crashes into the sun (breaking it in half) and creating a different wing of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a lagoon.
additionalM:
Hints
The lagoon is beautiful! The water is hot (from hitting the sun) but it isn't so bright that you'll get a sunburn.
additionalR:
Hints
Now picture it all in slow motion. The catapult tosses the tsunami into the air, it smashes the sun, breaks off into a wing of nice, hot water, and finally splashes back to the earth into a beautiful, secluded lagoon.
readingMnemonic: This lagoon was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his catapult (かた). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun!

meaningMnemonic: There are flowers and hills in your front lawn. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking through your lawn and smelling all the flowers as you travel over the rolling hills. What a delightful lawn this is.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at your little Shiba running through the lawn all happy and elated. Hear him barking as he zooms up and down each hill.
readingMnemonic: You are the proud owner of a Shiba (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your lawn and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba.

meaningMnemonic: If the moon is dry, it's good for your liver! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."
additionalR:
Hints
Genghis Khan glares down at you, "You inherited my liver, and that means no moonshine for you. Protect your liver and don't drink, like me, Genghis Khan."
readingMnemonic: As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) comes out! Right out of your liver.

meaningMnemonic: Under the cross is a mouth and another mouth wearing special clothes because they're in mourning.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the cross looming overhead, people's mouths open so they can sob loudly, and everyone wearing the same color clothes (just picture whatever color works for your particular culture/religion combo).
additionalR:
Hints
If you aren't mourning enough, when the soul comes out of the person's body, it will get really mad. "What, I'm not worth a few tears? Really?" And then the soul will haunt you. So you better mourn like you mean it.
readingMnemonic: As the mourning continues, the soul (そう) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it.

meaningMnemonic: You have a thread hill, but the hill is a bit weird looking (take a look at the hill radical in this kanji). It's not any normal hill, it's a weird lumpy hill that isn't quite right. That's because it is a thread hill of netting, and parts of the nets have caught things, like fish and cats, so there's weird abnormal lumps in them.
additionalM:
Hints
You'll need to differentiate this from 綱, which uses the same radicals (though 綱 has a real hill radical). Just remember that the weird "hill" has stuff caught in it because it is netting.
additionalR:
Hints
When you do this, it destroys your lawn mower, because who thought it was a good idea to use a lawn mower on netting? Your dumb idea. C'mon!
readingMnemonic: There's so much netting that it's out of control. You decide to take your lawn mower to mow (もう) it all down.

meaningMnemonic: Even though you’ve old legs, you overcome your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine running a marathon with your old legs to prove you can overcome anything. Feel your old legs cramping up as you try to overcome the marathon and finish the race.
additionalR:
Hints
Filled with the jubilation of achievement from overcoming all odds, imagine the flavor of this cold Coke in your mouth. Fizzy and Coke flavored, it runs down your throat and into your tummy. Yum.
readingMnemonic: When you pass the finish line and finally overcome the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold Coke (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke.

meaningMnemonic: The tsunami that is white is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place overnight, without even asking!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the white tsunami knocking on your door, walking into your house, and then just laying down on your bed. You try to tell it to leave, but it's a tsunami, and it says it will be staying overnight thank you very much.
additionalR:
Hints
See the hairball slowly sinking into the tsunami. The cat hacks up another one.
readingMnemonic: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying overnight and decides it doesn't like it, so it hacks (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave.

meaningMnemonic: If you have one stool and another stool, you have a pair of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in front of this pair of stools. Picture yourself sitting on one stool, getting up, then sitting on the other. Repeat this process.
additionalR:
Hints
It's the same with pairs of socks and pairs of people. Sometimes what looks like two things is really a perfect pair, with one soul. Meant to be together forever.
readingMnemonic: This pair of stools shares a soul (そう). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together.

meaningMnemonic: You walk up to a tree and put dynamite on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful pattern into the side of it as well as the ground around it.
additionalM:
Hints
Think about what pattern it might be. Is it a checkered pattern? Something more complicated and beautiful? Whatever it is, think of something that really impresses you.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine painting your garage with the pattern you imagined earlier.
readingMnemonic: The pattern is so beautiful that you want to put it on your garage (がら). So, you do.

meaningMnemonic: Put an axe in your mouth with your fingers to express your philosophy. Your philosophy of putting weapons in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, so you're showing them that it's not with actions!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine expressing your philosophy, your deepest thoughts and beliefs, by putting it in your mouth.
additionalR:
Hints
Your philosophy and your way of life means everything tastes like 鉄 now, and you think everyone should be that way.
readingMnemonic: Your philosophy on weapons in mouths means you're always tasting 鉄 (てつ). They say blood tastes like copper, well weapons taste like iron.

meaningMnemonic: Use simultaneous jackhammers to perform the purification ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.)
additionalM:
Hints
Close your eyes and feel the purification begin. Try not to let the loud jackhammering sound bother you, just focus on the simultaneous vibrations cleansing you inside and out.
additionalR:
Hints
Hopefully this purification (or just the two jackhammers shaking your brain up like pudding) will get the memories of your cyborg to go away. You can't keep picturing it all the time like this.
readingMnemonic: This purification ritual is supposed to help you forget your cyborg (さい). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it out of your head.

meaningMnemonic: You keep your substitute clothes in a sack. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this sack of substitute clothes. Imagine it filled with all the clothes you hardly ever wear. What kind of clothes would be inside this sack?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how nasty it is in there. Also imagine how smelly it is. Feel angry about putting roe in your sack. Why would you even do that? Why would the roe do this to you, as well.
readingMnemonic: You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes sack. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: F**K ROE (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty.

meaningMnemonic: You grab a satellite with your fingers and shake it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in space and shaking a satellite with your fingers.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine shaking yogurt in space. Now imagine eating yogurt as it continues to shake (in space still)!
readingMnemonic: You need to shake it because this satellite is full of yogurt (よう). And you only like yogurt that's been well shook. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone?

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami breaks your bones, not from hitting you, but from making the ground slippery. The water from the tsunami made all the sidewalks and stairs too slippery to walk on, but you tried anyway, slipped, and broke a couple bones.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to get back up on the slippery ground. You've already broken a few bones, but you slip again, breaking a few more.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the cats trying to walk on the slippery ground. Their legs keep spreading, so they try to jump, but that makes the slipping worse, and they go sliding forward and topple over their fluffy buns and onto your broken body. Now the cats are all perching on top of you and your broken bones as they try to avoid the slippery ground. It would be nice if they didn't have their claws out.
readingMnemonic: As you struggle on the slippery ground you hear a loud yowling sound. You turn and see a bunch of stray cats (かつ) slipping and sliding too. They're coming right for you, uh oh!

meaningMnemonic: A servant secures a stool in the dirt so that it is a solid sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture two stools in your mind. One is solid, you want to sit on it. The other looks like the wind will knock it over. Don't sit on that!
additionalR:
Hints
You better hope that catapult is solid too. If it isn't the whole thing will come apart when you try to launch yourself into the air.
readingMnemonic: You need this stool to be extra solid because you're using it to test your new catapult (かた). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you?

meaningMnemonic: To your car you take an axe. The sun has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that temporarily. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel sad that you were the one to destroy your car for good, even though the sun messed it up temporarily.
additionalR:
Hints
You should probably be worried about this situation.
readingMnemonic: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next.

meaningMnemonic: Thread and vines alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to twist them together to make them strong.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine twisting some threads and vines together. Feel them and twist the two tighter together.
additionalR:
Hints
It turns out those vines you were twisting were cucumber vines! Yum!
readingMnemonic: As you twist the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a cucumber (きゅう) twisted into it.

meaningMnemonic: Flowers find their death in a river out in the wild. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself out in the wild wilderness as you hear the flowers screaming until death takes them. The river is raging, there’s nothing you can do to help the flowers. The wild has claimed them.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this scene again, only imagine it like the wild flowers are experiencing their own great flood. Ah, those flowers are drowning to death à la everything that died in the Biblical flood.
readingMnemonic: Ah (あ), the flowers in the wild have been claimed à la (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do.

meaningMnemonic: Imperial clothes allow you to perform an ancient attack that cannot be repelled.
additionalM:
Hints
IMPERIAL ATTACK, GO! Imagine what this imperial attack might look like and imagine yourself in some swanky imperial clothes while you perform it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the shoes as you attack, they glow—full of attack power! These +4 attack shoes are really special.
readingMnemonic: The attack's power is concentrated in the shoes (しゅう) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami can't resist the call of a bog. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~"
additionalM:
Hints
Close your eyes and hear the bog's temping call.
additionalR:
Hints
So that's what happened to him! If you're a youngun, just do a little Google and you'll be pretty pleased, I'm sure.
readingMnemonic: As you listen to the bog's call you realize it looks just like the Numa (ぬま) Numa guy in your mind. You open your eyes and it's just a bog. You close your eyes, and there he is. The Numa Numa guy.

meaningMnemonic: A good moon is a bright moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the good, good bright moon. Shining and shimmering and smiling down at us on Earth.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this scene like it's a Disney cartoon. The good moon is smiling brightly down at the roe which are smiling right back. They might even start singing a song!
readingMnemonic: It's so bright that you can see all the roe (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon!

meaningMnemonic: Below the canopy of trees is a hand. The hand is just there to chafe against the trees.
additionalM:
Hints
There's a hand just chafing against some trees. That's... interesting.
additionalR:
Hints
This is the hand of a child looking for its mama. And, it chafes against trees to try and find the warm, soft touch of its mama. Instead, it only finds rough bark, so it continues its chafing.
readingMnemonic: As the hand chafes on the trees, it says mama (ま), mama.

meaningMnemonic: The loitering mountain king who hangs around during winter to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your heart, and only sees bad things. So, he chastises you about it.
additionalM:
Hints
"What's in your heart is no good," he chastises you.
additionalR:
Hints
In the 潮 kanji you saved Mrs. Chou from dying, so he is chastising you for it.
readingMnemonic: Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is chastising you for saving Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaningMnemonic: We put a flag to remember where we tried to use a jackhammer to measure your friend's heart. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of consolation?
additionalM:
Hints
Obviously it's not good enough consolation. Be furious about this.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you have absolutely nothing. Not even a consolation flag.
readingMnemonic: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an eagle swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it.

meaningMnemonic: A badger, at the root of its heart, is a courteous creature.
additionalM:
Hints
They may seem gruff and rude at first, but they'll still let you in their home in the middle of winter unannounced and offer you tea, a warm fire, and a place to sleep.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a courteous badger taking care of an injured, and now homeless, condor. It's fluffing the condor's pillows, bringing it soup, and patting it on the shoulder saying, "There, there."
readingMnemonic: Badgers are especially courteous to condors (こん). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet.

meaningMnemonic: A bamboo stalk looks the same as a big ol' cylinder.
additionalM:
Hints
Compare the two things in your mind and make them the same.
additionalR:
Hints
とうきょう is a really weird city now that they passed the cylinder law. Imagine it so deeply that it weirds you out.
readingMnemonic: Picture a cylinder shaped とうきょう. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of とうきょう!

meaningMnemonic: Hit by a tsunami the drunkard is propelled down a slide where he hits the ground which is covered in fire. He is immediately destroyed.
additionalM:
Hints
Even if he wasn't saved by the slide (to avoid the tsunami) he would be in trouble. Seems like the world just wanted to destroy this drunkard.
additionalR:
Hints
Strangely, he just came from a Mets (めつ) game, so maybe that's why he had such bad luck.
readingMnemonic: One could say this drunkard met (めつ) his fate.

meaningMnemonic: A foot on a giant is a pretty long distance for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large distances very quickly.
additionalM:
Hints
Compare the distance you can travel with one step compared to a giant. It's a considerable difference in distance.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine walking the distance between where you are and the (possibly made up) Little Kyoto. Think about the distance.
readingMnemonic: Going to Little Kyoto (きょ) is a short distance for a giant but a long distance for you.

meaningMnemonic: People had to ride their bamboo plows long ago to enroll in things. There were no cars yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their way to the government office or school to enroll.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the little hut that passed for school long ago. All of the bamboo plows are parked around it, as the people enroll themselves and their kids up for classes.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a line of people enrolling for new classes, sports, citizenship, etc. The moment they've enrolled they poof into the perfect, sexy person (in your eyes).
readingMnemonic: If you enroll in something new people will find you very sexy (せき). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than trying to improve yourself.

meaningMnemonic: If the rain touches your foot and gives it a little rain kiss, you know that part of your foot is exposed to the elements. You can also see some dew forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are!
additionalM:
Hints
Ugh, you shouldn't have bought these open toed shoes, at least not during rainy season!
additionalR:
Hints
You wonder how long this road will go. With exposed toes, your feet are going to get all wet with dew if you can't get off this blasted road.
readingMnemonic: You run along the road (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides.

meaningMnemonic: A fire door is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a furnace.
additionalM:
Hints
Open the fire door and feel the heat of the furnace. Hot!
additionalR:
Hints
Smell the tar baking from the furnace. Feel the heat from the furnace. Fix the road, while you're at it.
readingMnemonic: You're using the furnace to melt tar to put on the road (ろ).

meaningMnemonic: You've been ordered to spear this tree but you decide to be really gentle instead.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine gently poking the tree with your spear. You glance around nervously, hoping no one notices how easy on it you're being.
additionalR:
Hints
The jewel has a little note on it, "Thank you for being gentle." Did... did the tree just reward you for being gentle?!
readingMnemonic: You're being really gentle to the tree when a jewel (じゅう) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head.

meaningMnemonic: You have to run, put your ear on the stool, then run back. That's the gist of this game.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself asking how this game works, then getting the above response.
additionalR:
Hints
As you watch, you get more of a gist of what's going on, but not all the way. Some people are throwing the stool down the chute, some people are sliding down it on their ears... I mean, you'll get the gist eventually. Probably.
readingMnemonic: You got the gist, but now there's the matter of this big chute (しゅ). No one told you how to use it, and you've got the gist of how chutes work, but what does it have to do with this running, ear-touching, stool game?!

meaningMnemonic: You hold the roof of the festival up with your fingers but it grates on them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is grating on them really, really badly.
additionalM:
Hints
Have you ever been to a Japanese festival? There's always one of those portable shrines that are basically just roofs people hold up. That's what you're trying to hold with your fingers as the whole thing grates on them.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a very large person that decided to sat down right on top of the roof you've been carrying through the festival. The weight makes the grating so much worse, you can feel the skin coming off of your fingers.
readingMnemonic: Just when you thought the grating couldn't get worse, someone sat (さつ) down on the roof! AHG! It hurts!

meaningMnemonic: Two kings are here right now! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the harp, or something.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself playing a harp even though you probably don't know how to. Entertain these kings to the best of your ability, right now. That's why you're doing it and not someone who knows what they're doing. They want it now.
additionalR:
Hints
Just say to yourself: "This 事 I don't understand. I don't understand this 事 at all omg what am I going to do?"
readingMnemonic: You don't even know how to do the 事 (こと, action) of playing the harp, yet you're doing it.

meaningMnemonic: Look at the dirt on the ground at dawn and you'll be able to see all the hedges growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself leaning over a balcony at dawn, looking at all the hedges appear and their shadows stretch over the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine rooting around under some hedges, desperately trying to find your car keys. Hedges are prickly and there's spiders in here! If only you didn't need a car in the first place!
readingMnemonic: You're looking intently at one particular hedge because yesterday you dropped your car keys (かき) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys.

meaningMnemonic: The root of a stamp is to get an instant picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant.
additionalM:
Hints
Lots of things have roots from wanting to have something in an instant. Just think about instant ramen. The root of that was to get ramen real, real fast. Similar to stamps, ya know?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine using instant socks. How do they feel? Soggy, but hey, it was fast!
readingMnemonic: Think about the thing you want to make instant. I'd want instant socks (そく)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant!

meaningMnemonic: A drunkard goes down a slide, hits the ground and bumps into a woman. Who is that woman? It's none other than her majesty.
additionalM:
Hints
The problem is that you don't want to run into her majesty. That's a grave offense. Feel the fear that you're going to get your head lopped off from running into her.
additionalR:
Hints
Then it starts pecking at your eyes. Imagine fighting off an eagle trying to get at you.
readingMnemonic: After you run into her majesty, her guardian eagle (い) swoops on you and pulls you off of her.

meaningMnemonic: A (fresh water) tsunami. Some horns. The ground. A bunch of poop. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very nourishing soil.
additionalM:
Hints
The stuff in horns is great for fertilizer. So is poop. So is water (as long as it's fresh water). So nourishing!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine him making soil made out of those things. Jesus approves of this nourishing soil.
readingMnemonic: This is the kind of nourishing soil that Jesus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably.

meaningMnemonic: A cow in the winter doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the pasture. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat.
additionalM:
Hints
It's cold outside (it's winter after all). Imagine you having to herd all the cows out to pasture even though they don't want to leave the warm barn.
additionalR:
Hints
Actually say that phrase out loud while thinking about bringing your cows to pasture.
readingMnemonic: ぼく is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "ぼく will take these cows out to pasture!"

meaningMnemonic: The sound of spring water always puts you at peace.
additionalM:
Hints
Everything from winter is melting and trickling and thawing. All the dripping sounds fill you with a peace you can barely describe.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine carefully dipping all of your ties in the peaceful spring waters and hearing that sweet sound you love at all times.
readingMnemonic: You want to feel this peace all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your tie (たい) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love.

meaningMnemonic: An axe is sticking in the ground on top of a mountain. It's sticking into the very peak. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?
additionalM:
Hints
Picture that axe, jammed into the mountain's peak. The person who did that must have been really cool to get all the way up there.
additionalR:
Hints
Go ahead, imagine this peak with an axe in it and actually gawk a bit at how far you have to go to get that high.
readingMnemonic: You can't help but gawk (がく) at the peak. Somehow it looks even higher now.

meaningMnemonic: Take your spoon to the sun to be able to take a bite. It's delicious, you hear. That's the point of the spoon.
additionalM:
Hints
Taste that delicious sun. It doesn't even burn!
additionalR:
Hints
You had your eyes closed because the sun is so bright. When you open them you realize the delicious sun you were eating is really just a giant, really bright, cooked sheep. You should probably point this out to NASA or something.
readingMnemonic: This delicious taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like sheep (し)!

meaningMnemonic: You take out a flag, lay a towel below it, and use your knife to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old printing presses used to work.
additionalM:
Hints
The old way of printing involved taking the pattern you want (the flag) pressing it against the place you want to print it (the towel) and then just slicing that sucker on there (with the knife).
additionalR:
Hints
I guess if you wanted to be slow you could do your printing if you sat down on it too...
readingMnemonic: As you're working on printing your own flag onto this towel you look over and see someone else just sat (さつ) down on theirs. "Excuse me, where is your knife?" you ask. "Oh, this way is slower, but it's less work. I'm just pressing them together with my bum."

meaningMnemonic: The king's hat, not to mention the hair stuck to said hat, is incredibly rare. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself holding a king's hat covered in his hair. Who will you sell it to? This is such a rare item!
additionalR:
Hints
Not sure how it got there, but you'll make a pretty penny from this. The king only had one chin, so that's about as rare as they come.
readingMnemonic: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even rarer. Attached to the hair is the king's chin (ちん).

meaningMnemonic: You need to make a measurement of an area so you take two clumps of dirt to seal in each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to seal things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture sealing other things with dirt. Like the bricks in your wall. Or the hole in your floor. Dirt can seal in anything.
additionalR:
Hints
Dig up your sealed food and eat it in the comfort of your own home. Mm, delicious!
readingMnemonic: You can also seal food (ふう) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew.

meaningMnemonic: The simultaneous radical and the simultaneous kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
It's also simultaneously here and there at the same time. It moves really fast. And simultaneously glowing blue and white. Your saber is a lot of things all at once!
readingMnemonic: What simultaneously protects and kills? Your holy blue saber (せい).

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami hits a pirate they are going to sink no matter how good of a pirate captain they are.
additionalM:
Hints
Tsunamis are big. Pirates are small. Simple as that.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this dignified chin-holding-up-high pirate. Nod your head, because you know he got what he deserves.
readingMnemonic: As the tsunami comes to sink the pirate, the pirate holds his chin (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity.

meaningMnemonic: Put your fingers in somebody's business by slapping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine giving someone a good, hard slap in the face. You're all up in their business now.
additionalR:
Hints
Say that out loud, using ぼく. You're the boss, the boss of slap business.
readingMnemonic: ぼく is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you slap this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? ぼく.

meaningMnemonic: When a yakuza takes a knife to clothes, it will of course cause a split or tear.
additionalM:
Hints
It doesn't matter if it's a yakuza member or not. Any knife will cause a split or tear in clothes.
additionalR:
Hints
Think of a thing you want to tear with your yakuza buddy. You're into it, so you agree and say "Ret's do it!"
readingMnemonic: "I want to split and tear that." You agree, so you say Let's (れつ) do it.

meaningMnemonic: A small tsunami comes in the morning with the moon. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the tide.
additionalM:
Hints
The moon does affect the tides a bit, so you can imagine the tsunami as the water getting bigger whenever the moon is out. That's just the tide.
additionalR:
Hints
She wakes up and says, "If only you came at low tide then I would never have been saved!" She jumps up and runs off, yelling something about destroying the world.
readingMnemonic: You go check out the tide. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. Chou (ちょう)!

meaningMnemonic: This construction project made from shellfish will act as a tribute to the Crabigator.
additionalM:
Hints
The Crabigator is a sea creature (maybe?), so making a tribute from shellfish makes some sense.
additionalR:
Hints
In his power, こういち has made a new religion around the Crabigator, to put the fear of kanji learning into his subjects.
Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.
readingMnemonic: This great tribute is being commissioned by Emperor こういち.

meaningMnemonic: Who will say turkey? Who? WHO???
additionalM:
Hints
Say "who" over and over again, demanding someone says "turkey," for some reason.
additionalR:
Hints
You're so mad at that person even though you demanded someone say turkey.
readingMnemonic: Then, someone says turkey. "Who said turkey? You? How dare (だれ) you."

meaningMnemonic: The radical blade and the kanji blade are exactly the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Please, just know your radicals. Please!
additionalR:
Hints
Ha, HA, HaaAA! Those are the blade sounds we all know and love.
readingMnemonic: When you stab your blade into an enemy you shout "Ha (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound.

meaningMnemonic: The radical can is the same as the kanji can. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a tin can, though.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a tin can in your mind as clearly as you can.
additionalR:
Hints
かん is can, it's really easy, come on. Just take this one.
readingMnemonic: The reading for a can is かん, which seems impossibly easy. If that isn't close enough for you, picture this:

meaningMnemonic: You put a stone into a wrap of some kind. This wrap happens to be a cannon, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.
additionalM:
Hints
This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the cannon goes off, the rock hurtles into your home. And just like that, there is a huge, rock-shaped hole in it. You'll have to shoot a few more rocks at your home with this cannon before it's completely gone.
