readingMnemonic: You aim the cannon at your own home (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long.

meaningMnemonic: A bamboo thing you put on your head to stand taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a conical hat.
additionalM:
Hints
You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.
additionalR:
Hints
Think about a bamboo umbrella on your head. They're pretty similar in shape, after all.
readingMnemonic: A conical hat is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's kasa (かさ)!

meaningMnemonic: The dragon radical is the same as this kanji, which is dragon.
additionalM:
Hints
Not to dragon with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!
additionalR:
Hints
Then imagine after his transformation he attacks you using his Street Fighter moves. "Hadouken!"
readingMnemonic: Imagine a dragon. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character Ryuu (りゅう).

meaningMnemonic: Your fingers told you that a flood last evening seemed to be imminent, and that there was nothing you could do to stop it. You felt it draw close, coming in the darkness of the evening.
additionalM:
Hints
Think back to last evening, when your fingers twitched and twisted, warning you as the flood started to draw close.
additionalR:
Hints
You sat down and now you're still there, waiting for the flood. It's still drawing closer... it'll come eventually.
readingMnemonic: As the flood began to draw close you knew there was nothing you could do, so you sat (さつ) down  and waited.

meaningMnemonic: There's a thread tying wolverine to a pig, balancing them over the edge of a cliff together.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture wolverine and a pig hanging precariously over the edge. One move the wrong way and they'll both go toppling over.
additionalR:
Hints
If you fall off the edge it'll be your end too. Always be safe and never get too close to any edges!
readingMnemonic: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the edge. Straight to their end (えん).

meaningMnemonic: If someone puts a blade to your heart, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to endure the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your chest and ribs are open. There's a blade on your heart. Now try not to move, or your heart will be cut!
additionalR:
Hints
Just think about how much you want to become a ninja. You'll do anything, even endure this.
readingMnemonic: This is all a part of your ninja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing. This is how they train you. If you can endure this you can endure anything, plus you can stay really still, which is good for ninjas.

meaningMnemonic: A gold pool is where you're going to go fishing. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great fishing spot this is.
additionalR:
Hints
Count your golden fish. They're so nice! They're also worth their weight in gold, because, well, they are gold.
readingMnemonic: You caught a couple of gold fish. Two (つ) gold fish, actually!

meaningMnemonic: The good luck radical and the good luck kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Your good luck kitchen kits have charms that say things like, "good food," "good company," and "good luck not cutting off your fingers with kitchen knives."
readingMnemonic: For good luck, you keep special kits (きつ) in your kitchen (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms.

meaningMnemonic: The part of rice that stands up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the grains.
additionalM:
Hints
If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.
additionalR:
Hints
He has his hands flat, and stabs his hands into the grains. Yah! Yah! Yah!
readingMnemonic: You have a box of grains. Ryuu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers.

meaningMnemonic: Your long hair is your friend. It's your hair and you're so proud of it.
additionalM:
Hints
Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.
additionalR:
Hints
Pretend to pray to the great hair 神. What is his reply? Does he give you more hair?
readingMnemonic: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great 神 (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair.

meaningMnemonic: An axe is stuck into the ground on a hill.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine climbing up the hill. The sun is coming up behind the axe,  silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.
additionalR:
Hints
You take the axe out of the hill and cut off some cucumber to eat. Mm mm!
readingMnemonic: You reach the top of the hill and realize the entire hill is covered in cucumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use."

meaningMnemonic: The leader of a big rice paddy is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an umbrella. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is I. It is me.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine that this leader is you. Be rough about it, because 俺 is the "rougher" version of "I." You should only use it in casual situations or if you're a badass.
additionalR:
Hints
More accurately, I'm standing here with an umbrella so I don't get wet. My minions are doing the ore digging, but I am watching to make sure they don't slack off.
readingMnemonic: Why am I standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for ore (おれ).

meaningMnemonic: The ladle radical and the ladle kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Your mom comes rushing in and smacks you on the head. "Fool!" she says, "This is toe soup, what did you think you'd ladle up?!" Oops.
readingMnemonic: You use a ladle to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a toe (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground.

meaningMnemonic: The measurement radical and the measurement kanji are exactly the same.
additionalM:
Hints
If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the sun and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the sun. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to measure the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.
readingMnemonic: You want to measure something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the sun (すん).

meaningMnemonic: The tree has an omen growing from it, one single peach that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.
additionalM:
Hints
Of course, this tree omen of a peach refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).
additionalR:
Hints
It grows bigger everytime you say "MORE MORE" twice. If you say it just once, it stays the same.
readingMnemonic: If momotaro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the peach growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "MORE! MORE!" (もも).

meaningMnemonic: The grain you cut off a tree with a knife is a pear. I don't know if you've ever seen Asian pears, but they're pretty big and sturdy. You can't just pick them off of the tree, you need the help of a knife. That's why this is a pear, and not an apple or peach or something else.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing below a tree full of pears. You take your knife and carefully cut them all down, one by one.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a beautiful, ripe pear in your mind. Now gnash your teeth. Mmm. You want to eat a pear right now, don't you?
readingMnemonic: As you cut the pears down, you can't help but gnash (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast.

meaningMnemonic: The woman servant is the lower ranking princess. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine a princess saying "UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me." Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.
additionalR:
Hints
The servants all know they should tell the king, because the princess is a servant to the king, just as they are, plus they don't want to lose their heads.
readingMnemonic: The princess goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. He may (ひめ) not like it."

meaningMnemonic: You use your fingers when you're in private to use an arrow to push open things.
additionalM:
Hints
You're in private in your own room, no one else is around. Now you wrap your fingers around this big arrow, and you push open your door, your curtains, your windows. It's weird, but you really enjoy this.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the arrow in your hands. You're facing a mirror, but you can't see because you're about to push open your eyes. The anticipation is killing you, push them open now!
readingMnemonic: Your favorite thing to push open is your own eye (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see.

meaningMnemonic: A woman loves her catapult for some good ol' fashioned recreation.
additionalM:
Hints
You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.
additionalR:
Hints
Get out of here, Godzilla! I'm gonna shoot you.
readingMnemonic: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for recreation is Godzilla (ご).

meaningMnemonic: I say, which weighs more: a kilogram of scooters or a kilogram of rice? This is a riddle!
additionalM:
Hints
Think carefully and see if you can come up with the answer to my riddle before you read on.
additionalR:
Hints
Did you say the answer to the riddle is that they're both a kilogram? Not so! A scooter is heavier than some rice! And don't you email me saying that's not so! It's my riddle, I can make the answer whatever I want. That's the law of riddles!
readingMnemonic: Did you figure out the answer to this riddle? Say your answer aloud to the screen right now.... not so (なぞ)! You're wrong.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the temple isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a samurai, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.
additionalM:
Hints
You walk up to a temple and you're surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.
additionalR:
Hints
If you know the meaning you know the reading as well! That doesn't happen too often with kanji, so consider yourself lucky!
readingMnemonic: The reading is samurai, which should be easy enough to remember.

meaningMnemonic: From my mouth I have told you seven times not to do that. Now I have to scold you.
additionalM:
Hints
SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself feeding the deer, then getting scolded (or you doing the scolding to someone else feeding the deer, whichever works best).
readingMnemonic: What were you doing wrong that caused me to scold you? You were feeding the 鹿 (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves!

meaningMnemonic: A tree with two moons on either side, holding the tree up in a horizontal angle, is a shelf.
additionalM:
Hints
So, your shelf is made up of a tree and two moons. Imagine this shelf and put things on it. The moons are kind of rolling around, making it hard to build your shelf.
additionalR:
Hints
Think about the ton-a-stuff you're going to put on there. Like, literally, measure out a ton of things and put them on there. It can hold it!
readingMnemonic: Your moon shelf is great. It's also huge, because moons are really big. That means you can store a ton-a-stuff (たな) on it.

meaningMnemonic: You have mouth vines, so you shout! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout.
additionalM:
Hints
You were born with mouth vines (a rare condition where your mouth is always full of vines), so you've been shouting all your life. And yet people still can't hear you. It's very frustrating.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the word きょうと not coming out clearly because of your mouth vines. People can only hear the きょう part, so they don't know where you want to go. SHOUT LOUDER! きょうと！
readingMnemonic: You need to shout so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "きょうと!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition.

meaningMnemonic: In the cage there are some legs. They are the legs attached to a small animal.
additionalM:
Hints
You can only see the legs, though, because a cloth is covering the cage. What kind of small animal is it? Try to look.
additionalR:
Hints
Who is giving this cat all those hickies? Pretty gross, if you ask me.
readingMnemonic: You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This small animal is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in hickies (ひき).

meaningMnemonic: The spicy radical and spicy kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
additionalR:
Hints
It's bleeding profusely and really hurts a lot. Plus your mouth is still burning from that spicy food you ate. It's pure agony.
readingMnemonic: Imagine eating this spicy food, becoming blinded by the spicy heat, and knocking your shin (しん) on something while you bumble around.

meaningMnemonic: A flowers fang is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little sprout.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).
additionalR:
Hints
You look at all the sprouts. They have all turned into 目s, looking straight at you. You're terrified.
readingMnemonic: When the sprout gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking 目 (め), looking right at you.

meaningMnemonic: The mountain wind coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a storm. Well, it is a storm, really.
additionalM:
Hints
If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty storm.
additionalR:
Hints
The rash comes from being wet and not drying off when you get home. Your skin gets irritated by this moisture.
readingMnemonic: A storm is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get a rash (あらし).

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami goes through a little door, and plops down a big drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the teardrop coming down your eye.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a teardrop going through this process to get out of your eye, though in a more miniature teardrop size.
additionalR:
Hints
Think of several inappropriate situations to cry in. Put yourself in them. Think about how all this crying is ruining things, for real!
readingMnemonic: Your teardrops always come at the worst times, ruining (るい) serious and/or happy moments. You can't stop crying. it is ruining your life!

meaningMnemonic: Rain on a rice paddy means only one thing... thunder! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine hearing the thunder as you run. It is getting closer.
additionalR:
Hints
Thank goodness, that was a close one. The guy who picks you up is named Ryan, though he likes it if you call him Ry (らい).
readingMnemonic: You can't run fast enough to escape the thunder so you hitch a ride (らい) from someone driving by.

meaningMnemonic: When dirt and flowers suit one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a tower! A flower tower made of flower power!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking in the woods and coming across a huge tower made of flowers. It goes so high you can hardly see the top.
additionalR:
Hints
How do you think the とうきょう tower came to be, anyway? It was once a big flower tower. They just replaced it with metal later. BOOM! History bomb, you're welcome.
readingMnemonic: The only place flowers grow into towers like this is in とうきょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers.

meaningMnemonic: The slide to get off this jet is a beautiful, brilliant vermillion color.
additionalM:
Hints
Vermillion is like an orange red, which is perfect for visibility purposes.
additionalR:
Hints
The vermillion chute spits you out and you spit out your lunch. And it looks vermillion. Uh oh. Hospital. Please.
readingMnemonic: As you jump onto the vermillion slide, it more of a steep chute (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick.

meaningMnemonic: A feather is on a rice paddy, and they are attached together. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one wing of your amazing aircraft.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a wing that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine using the yolks to stick everything together. It's all over your hands, and things are pretty nasty.
readingMnemonic: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the yolk (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.

meaningMnemonic: A spoon to measure a geoduck is a very approximate measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?
additionalM:
Hints
Do the comparison. A spoonful of geoduck aka a whole geoduck on a spoon. This is a spoonful, right? This is what the recipe wanted, I think...
additionalR:
Hints
That's a little better. Not too much geoduck. Still a lot, but more like an approximate.
readingMnemonic: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an approximate. So, you take the core (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead.

meaningMnemonic: When you leave grains in your mouth for long enough, they'll turn into flowers of bacteria. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how much bacteria would flower in your mouth if you just left grains in there for like, I dunno, a month. That's a lot of nasty bacteria!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the King's mouth up close. Look at all the bacteria squiggling around and through his teeth and gums. Bleh! Barf!
readingMnemonic: There is a lot of this bacteria in the King (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria.

meaningMnemonic: Something made of gold stands in a village. It's a bell!  The village bell.
additionalM:
Hints
Every village has a bell of its own, standing tall and proud and shiny in the middle for everyone to see and hear.
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun bell even sounds like it's warning you that the Shougun has arrived. It makes a loud, low shooooouu shooou sound.
readingMnemonic: The bell rings whenever the Shougun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects.

meaningMnemonic: The boat radical and the boat kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Boats are boats, you know?
additionalR:
Hints
Try to answer ふな a couple times when doing your reviews. It'll help when we get to the vocab part.
readingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji 船, though there's an extra reading there as well, ふな. They're close, so you should be able to remember it based off of ふね.

meaningMnemonic: The woman who makes your house a home is your bride.
additionalM:
Hints
She's in your house because you married her. Thus, she's your bride. Your house is now a home.
additionalR:
Hints
Your bride is very upset at how sexist you're being right now, and makes you do all the cleaning instead. The maid still gets fired.
readingMnemonic: Now that you have a bride in your house, you can get rid of your maid (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning.

meaningMnemonic: Looking up to the cliff, you see the trees, and the sun shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole calendar.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the different shadow patterns. Know what they all mean. This is your very own calendar system.
additionalR:
Hints
Make sure you make the connection between the word 歴史 and this kanji. If you do, it'll be much easier to remember the reading of this kanji.
readingMnemonic: Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a calendar, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related.

meaningMnemonic: The sun is being blocked by a rain cloud, making it cloudy.
additionalM:
Hints
You look up at the sky, trying to find the sun, but it's so cloudy that you can't even find where the sun should be.
additionalR:
Hints
If it's cloudy there are clouds, so if you can read one, you can read the other!
readingMnemonic: Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both くも.

meaningMnemonic: An alligator is considerably dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].
additionalM:
Hints
The radical meaning and the kanji meaning aren't the same, but we'll get through this together. Just put a considerable amount of effort into this and you'll learn considerably more quickly.
additionalR:
Hints
Also, things that are "considerably" anything start somewhere. They become (なり) whatever "considerable" thing they are now from something smaller before.
readingMnemonic: Speaking of considerably terrifying, that place known as Narnia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there.

meaningMnemonic: There's a sock circle in the dirt on your way to cram school. Every day after school you walk straight until you get to the sock circle, you run around it, and then head off in any direction. Somehow it always leads to cram school.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the sock circle in the dirt in your mind. Now look up and see cram school through the trees.
additionalR:
Hints
Normal kids would probably try to juke cram school, since it's hard and it's more school than they think they need. But you're a good kid who want to cram, so you juke the circle instead.
readingMnemonic: The sock circle seems to have a bit of a gravitational pull, so to make sure you get to cram school on time you have to juke (じゅく) around it every day, to make sure you can get past it.

meaningMnemonic: From the mouth of your older brother comes... a curse!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine him cursing you. He's not a fan of you, since you are siblings, but to think he'd go so far as to put a curse on you? You can't believe it. What kind of curse did he put upon you?
additionalR:
Hints
In your mind, walk around the area where you live. Think about the places you can go that aren't roads. If you try to walk on a road, you can't. This is the no road curse, after all.
readingMnemonic: Turns out, he put the no road (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads.

meaningMnemonic: After the tsunami the sun comes out again and shines on these spikes. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still damp.
additionalM:
Hints
The sun did a little bit of work, so they aren't wet, but they aren't dry either. They're damp.
additionalR:
Hints
Luckily the shih tzu is kinda pinned between the spikes, so it isn't dead or anything, but it's definitely stuck. You try to help it out, but you slip because it's so damp and you fall in too! Imagine the sound of your cries mixing in with the shih tzu's as you both struggling to get out but can't because of how damp everything is.
readingMnemonic: As you're looking at the damp spikes, a shih tzu (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo!

meaningMnemonic: The grains you have stored in your house reflect on your earnings. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at the grains in the houses of people who make vastly different earnings. The poor artist has only a few sacks of grain. The rich samurai has an extra house just for holding his grain. That's how you know he has much higher earnings than the artist.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your own earnings. Can you afford a lot of grains and a car?
readingMnemonic: Another way to check someone's earnings is to see if they have a car (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No!

meaningMnemonic: I have sick in my skin. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably exhausted.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself being really, really exhausted. Then look at your skin. It's all sickly looking.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine exercising so much that your body gets all exhausted and heated (ひ) up.
readingMnemonic: When you're exhausted, your muscles are all probably worn out. Being this worn out, you can probably imagine that your body is all heated (ひ) up, from all the exercising.

meaningMnemonic: A sheep with feathers (and presumably wings, too) is able to fly.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the sheep with feathers taking off and flying around. It's an odd sight, but makes sense, kind of.
additionalR:
Hints
Ha HA! Everyone knows sheep love cake. Works every time. Now this flying sheep is yours!
readingMnemonic: Using this sheep that can fly, you're going to get rich! But there's a problem... you have to catch the sheep. So, you get some cake (かけ) and use it to lure the sheep to your trap, where you catch it!

meaningMnemonic: I'm putting all my shellfish on someone, hoping they'll win the race! This is a gamble and you're gambling.
additionalM:
Hints
Remember, shellfish used to be used as money. So if you're betting shellfish on someone, you're just gambling. And you probably won't get any of those shellfish back.
additionalR:
Hints
If you go to any of those fancy (and not so fancy) gamble-places, they always have a car sitting in the middle of the room. Usually rotating, really slowly, to make you want it more, making you gamble more.
readingMnemonic: If you win this gamble you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new car (か)!

meaningMnemonic: Coming down with the rain is two spikes. They go right through two ghosts.
additionalM:
Hints
The ghosts are pinned to the ground by the spikes, unable to move.
additionalR:
Hints
A ray gun, coincidentally, is the only thing that can kill a ghost, and there it lays, just out of reach. You'll have to be the one to pull the trigger of the ray gun. Do you pick up the ray gun out of the row boat to destroy the ghosts?
readingMnemonic: You come across the ghosts, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that ray (れい) gun that's in that row (りょう) boat and end our suffering."

meaningMnemonic: Tsunami vs lifeguard. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the gutter.
additionalM:
Hints
To be fair, it's pretty obvious who would win. Nobody knows what that lifeguard was thinking.
additionalR:
Hints
"This lifeguard didn't believe in the power of kanji learning," こういち says to the press. "He was punished by the great Crabigator, who sent its tsunami as a warning for all."
Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.
readingMnemonic: In the gutter is a lifeguard, so Emperor こういち decides to survey the damage.

meaningMnemonic: I protect my own animals by going to hunt other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.
additionalM:
Hints
My animals can't protect themselves, that's why I hunt other animals instead.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hunting down animals in a car.
readingMnemonic: I also do all my hunts using a car (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways.

meaningMnemonic: If you've been to the moon in the past, you had to get the special stamp on your leg.
additionalM:
Hints
This leg stamp not only proved you went, but lets everyone around you know you've been to the moon before!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Kyaku lifting up their pant leg and showing you all the stamps from all the different places they've been. There are even some planets on there!
readingMnemonic: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their leg and it was Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too.

meaningMnemonic: When the tsunami struck, it hit your tent full of beans. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of lucidity. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it!
additionalM:
Hints
Then you went back to being crazy. That moment of lucidity was only temporary, and you go back to stockpiling beans.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself wearing a sharp suit and being a model of lucidity
readingMnemonic: Your lucidity is clear to everyone because you wear a suit (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits!

meaningMnemonic: A dirt demon is just a lump. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a lump of dirt. Is there a demon hiding under there? No. It's just a saying, ya nerd.
additionalR:
Hints
If you don't know the game and have never heard the music (especially), it's great stuff! If you have, this word will be really easy for you. If you haven't, look it up!
readingMnemonic: Have you ever heard of the game "Katamari Damacy?" That game is about a little guy who rolls a ball around, turning it into a bigger and bigger lump. What do you think the Katamari (かたまり) part means? It means lump, of course.

meaningMnemonic: The animal king? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a lunatic, though.
additionalM:
Hints
While we're speaking of animals, he's absolutely bat sh*t crazy.
additionalR:
Hints
I think he maybe got too friendly with some raccoons and beavers and went crazy. Watch out for him if you live in きょうと, rabies is no joke.
readingMnemonic: You might see that crazy lunatic hanging around the outskirts of きょうと. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels.

meaningMnemonic: A woman who is a nurse should be called miss.
additionalM:
Hints
Compare this to a man who is a nurse. You should probably call him mister. That's why you know a woman who is a nurse is "miss."
additionalR:
Hints
When you think of "miss," remember the time that Jourm asked you to call him "Miss Jourm." You thought he was a big, ten foot tall guy, but now he suddenly wants you to call him Miss Jourm. Okay, that's up to Jourm so you should respect that.
readingMnemonic: "Call me Miss Jourm (じょう)," Jourm says to you.

meaningMnemonic: If you're showing me your "spirit fruit" then you are just naked. You're nude.
additionalM:
Hints
You know what I mean by "spirit fruit" –– yep, it's out there and you're naked.
additionalR:
Hints
Don't look up "Ra Egyptian god naked" in Google. Nothing good will come of it. Instead, just imagine your own Egyptian god Ra being naked in front of you.
readingMnemonic: Known for being naked (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら).

meaningMnemonic: Below this canopy of trees is a stone. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to polish it.
additionalM:
Hints
It's a single, perfectly round stone under this canopy of trees. It didn't start this way, but thanks to all the polishing you did, it has become nice and smooth.
additionalR:
Hints
There's only this one stone under these trees, and polishing the stone is the only job here. Still, you don't get much from it, thus the meager life of polishing your stone.
readingMnemonic: You polish the stone due to your meager (みが) lifestyle.

meaningMnemonic: This building now has a cloud over it, creating shade.
additionalM:
Hints
This shade is really convenient right now, because it's been such a hot day. Ahh, shade is so nice and cool.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture an inn with a cloud right above it right now. Look at the cloud-shaped shade keeping everyone visiting the inn cool and sunburn-free.
readingMnemonic: The building that's getting this nice shade is the inn (いん) you're staying at.

meaningMnemonic: The moon table is a table that's made entirely of skin. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porey, skin.
additionalM:
Hints
Touch it and feel the "moon table." You know it's not made of moon. How ridiculous.
additionalR:
Hints
You'd think skin would be softer, but it's pretty hard. Much harder than you expected.
readingMnemonic: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of skin, you realize that it's harder (はだ) than you expected.

meaningMnemonic: The cloud floating above a demon has its soul in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the spirit it once was.
additionalM:
Hints
Right now, however, the demon is looming over you, and you can't see anything in the cloud above its head. It just looks mad, like it's gonna pummel you or eat you.
additionalR:
Hints
POOF! Now there's a condor spirit floating in front of you, crying. "Thank you, human. You've saved my soul!" it says, and float/flies off and disappears.
readingMnemonic: You shout out and beg its soul for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a condor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!"

meaningMnemonic: The spear radical and the spear kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Spears are spears. It makes sense!
additionalR:
Hints
How do you like it? Don't stab cows with spears, you monster.
readingMnemonic: You take this spear and stab it into a cow. "MOO (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream.

meaningMnemonic: When your eye catches an omen, it's only natural that you will stare at it.
additionalM:
Hints
You don't see omens that often, so of course you're going to stare. We'll imagine what the omen is in the reading mnemonic.
additionalR:
Hints
Whenever you see an omen (radical), remember that the omen will probably have Mrs. Chou in it!
readingMnemonic: As you stare at the omen, you see Mrs. Chou (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world.

meaningMnemonic: You feel like a stone (again!). When you feel like a stone, your body is feeling very stiff.
additionalM:
Hints
Touch your stiff body. It feels like a stone.
additionalR:
Hints
If only you could ask こういち to give you massages again, but he's too busy for you, now (being emperor and all).
readingMnemonic: You remember how you used to cure these stiff body times: your old friend こういち would just massage them out for you.

meaningMnemonic: The toe is early. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the table.
additionalM:
Hints
See all the toes lined up on the table. They are the ones who showed up early.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the toes talking to each other. "Hello Mr. Toe!" "Oh hello other Mr. Toe!"
readingMnemonic: What do all the early toes on the table do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, talking (たく).

meaningMnemonic: If there's a treasure chest, there's always a villain too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.
additionalM:
Hints
And the villain always gets to the treasure chest first, often via nefarious means. That villain is SO important when it comes to treasure chests.
additionalR:
Hints
Arrrg! If only you had been closer to きょうと! Then you might have beaten this dastardly villain.
readingMnemonic: The villain beat you all the way to きょうと to get this particular treasure chest.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami in the shape of a dragon flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a waterfall.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you see why a tsunami dragon (especially the Asian skinny snake-like kind) could be a waterfall? Try to imagine it.
additionalR:
Hints
Now imagine it being a bit tacky. Dragons are alright but... you just don't want to overdo it, you know?
readingMnemonic: Despite how cool a dragon waterfall is, to be honest it's also pretty tacky (たき).

meaningMnemonic: The well radical and the well kanji are the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you remember that this is a well of water not a "well, actually."
additionalR:
Hints
The Shougun also really likes watching people do physical labor, so forcing his citizens to haul water up from the well is a plus too. But hey, they aren't thirsty!
readingMnemonic: There is a single well in each and every town thanks to the Shougun (しょう). One of the first things he decreed when he came to power was that all people have the right to easy and central access to water.

meaningMnemonic: You use black dirt to make black ink. That's what you use to write in black!
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure the dirt you're using to make black ink is really, really black. Like the kind you find around volcanoes or something.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yelling "SUE ME!" at someone's face, which is covered in the black ink you spilled there.
readingMnemonic: Be careful that you don't spill black ink on anyone or anything. If you do, you have to own it. Imagine spilling black ink on someone, and when they confront you yelling, "Yeah I got black ink on you, so sue me (すみ)!"

meaningMnemonic: Your eye gets kicked with a cleat that came careening toward your forehead when it popped off someone doing a dance, and you blink.
additionalM:
Hints
Well, of course you blink, you can't control that. And when a cleat come hurtling toward your eye it blinks automatically.
additionalR:
Hints
Soon the person who's cleat hit you is running over and trying to apologize and stop your crying, but it's too late.
readingMnemonic: You blink and blink and soon (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more.

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami wraps around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of bubbles. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the bubbles bursting out of the wrapped up tsunami as it crashes down. The air that the tsunami sucked in while it was wrapping up come out as bubbles big and small.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch helplessly as your home, now trapped in a bubble, floats away into the sky.
readingMnemonic: One of the biggest bubbles heads straight for your home (ほう), engulfs it, and picks it up into the air!

meaningMnemonic: Some grains get stuck in his cleat, and Wolverine's heart grows calm. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down.
additionalM:
Hints
He's calm now because he stomped right into a farmer's field (thus the rice) and if he didn't calm down he'd probably ruin it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Wolverine sitting calmly in this field, onions causing tears to stream down his cheeks as he reflect on what he's done.
readingMnemonic: Now that Wolverine is calm, tears come to his eyes. Being calm has given him perspective on what his anger has done. Oh, wait no. There are just some onions (おん) in his cleats too, and they're making calm tears trickle down his eyes.

meaningMnemonic: You see a child with an umbrella in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a cavity in the road. It's a big hole!
additionalM:
Hints
You run over to where the child fell. They are just fine! Because they had an umbrella, they were able to float to the bottom.
additionalR:
Hints
"You will stay in that cavity and/or hole until you repent." If it hasn't been clear up until now, Emperor こういち is going mad with power.
readingMnemonic: "Into my cavity you go!" yells a voice. It is こういち.

meaningMnemonic: This tree is very odd, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a chair!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this odd tree chair being the most comfortable chair you've ever sat on. It's shaped perfectly for you, and the moss makes it soft. Wow, what a chair.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the fear and regret. You should have known not to sit in this "chair". Mother nature never forgives, and now you don't have eyeballs.
readingMnemonic: But, this odd tree chair is also home to an eagle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out.

meaningMnemonic: If you pick certain rice or flowers you'll be put in prison. The most famous of these is the chrysanthemum. Chrysanthemums are super important in Japan because they're the symbol of the imperial family. They're even on the cover of Japanese passports. If you get caught picking a chrysanthemum, you're going to prison.
additionalM:
Hints
Chrysanthemums are really important to the Japanese people. Please don't ever pick them (or rice, because that's stealing food, someone planted that)!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine holding a chrysanthemum in your hands while you get kicked over and over and over in prison. Was it worth it?
readingMnemonic: If you go to prison for chrysanthemum picking, everyone in the prison is going to kick (きく) you nonstop. You broke the chrysanthemum picking law, so kicking is your punishment. And believe me, you don't want these kicks.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami causes the capital to become very cool. The capital was already a pretty cool temperature, but with the addition of the water from the tsunami, the capital is now very cool.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in the capital. The tsunami hits and now you are all wet. You are also very cool because the water is not warm. You are cool and wet. How sad.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine rowing in your row boat. The more you row, the less cool it gets. Feel your arms strain as you do so. It’s all worth it!
readingMnemonic: You don’t like how cool it is in the capital now so you decide to get in your row (りょう) boat and row away to some place that is not so cool. Get in your row boat and row away!

meaningMnemonic: The white thread in your towel comes from cotton. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine shoving your face into a nice, clean, white cotton towel. Mmm, so fresh.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of the men lined up, making towels out of pure white cotton. They're all rubbing their faces in the soft cotton whenever they can.
readingMnemonic: This cotton is made by men (めん).

meaningMnemonic: Below the canopy of trees is a demon. This demon is a devil.
additionalM:
Hints
You thought the devil hangs out in hell, but he actually hangs out under this canopy of trees.
additionalR:
Hints
Into the trees is where all mamas go missing. And so the devil searches for his mama under this canopy of trees.
readingMnemonic: Why is the devil under a canopy of trees? Because he's looking for his mama (ま).

meaningMnemonic: You need to bring charcoal under this roof to heat the dormitory. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at a dormitory chore wheel and seeing it's your turn to carry in the charcoal this week. Bleh!
additionalR:
Hints
The dormitory row boat leaks a little too, so by the time you get back you really need to light the charcoal and heat up!
readingMnemonic: The dormitory is on an island, so when you go out to get the charcoal you have to take a row (りょう) boat. You row and row and row until you reach the shed with all the charcoal. Then you row and row and row it back to the dormitory.

meaningMnemonic: There are nine birds and one of them is a dove and another is a pigeon. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at these nine birds strutting down the street like they own the place. The dove and pigeon are out in front because they are the most important. Hear them chirping and fluttering their feathers about.
additionalR:
Hints
Devour it. You love pigeon hearts. Discard the rest, keep the heart.
readingMnemonic: Take a look at the pigeon in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the heart (はと) from its little body.

meaningMnemonic: Make barracks out of gold and they will get dull quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a huge barracks made of dull, almost brown, gold. Maybe you should have picked a better material.
additionalR:
Hints
You stand cowering in front of the don as he inspects how dull the gold barracks are. You don't wanna be off'd for this just because the don was dull enough to make you use gold!
readingMnemonic: As you stare sadly at the dull barracks, the don (どん) shows up out of nowhere, and he's pissed. He turns his angry gaze toward you and says, "How did my barracks get so dull? Are you at fault? This is bad, this is very bad. Someone will pay for this."

meaningMnemonic: You want to turn your gold comb into a weapon, so you throw it into the forge.
additionalM:
Hints
Once the gold comb has melted down in the forge, you can forge it into whatever weapon you want.
additionalR:
Hints
Most people who do forge work have tans. And now you know why.
readingMnemonic: You're trying to work the forge, but it's harder than you thought. You end up forging outside all day and get a wicked tan (たん).

meaningMnemonic: A crab moves a stone because he is playing the game Go. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this crab placing stones on the Go board. Hear them click and clack as the crab places them with expert precision.
additionalR:
Hints
Go is Go. Easy!
readingMnemonic: Go is pronounced Go (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember!

meaningMnemonic: When you get sick you always eat a hot pepper. It's a habit you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if you had a habit of eating hot peppers whenever you thought you might be getting sick. To be fair, it flushes out your sinuses and tastes good, so it's not the worst habit you could have.
additionalR:
Hints
Unfortunately, now you've gotten into the habit of telling everyone what to do when they get sick. "Yeah, yeah, eat a hot pepper, we know. But couscous is better," they say before you can speak. To each their own, I suppose.
readingMnemonic: Everyone you know has a different habit when they get sick. Instead, they eat couscous (くせ). But you think couscous is gross. It's bland and does nothing for your stuffy noses and scratchy throats. I wonder how you can convince them to replace their habit with your own.

meaningMnemonic: The part of the grain people favor the most is the head of the plant. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself walking through a field of rice plants. Now look very closely at the head of the plant in front of you. See the rice bunched up there? That's the good stuff.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine working in a field of rice and using a hoe so you don't injure the head of the plant. You're sweating and it's hot, but you keep at it.
readingMnemonic: When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head.

meaningMnemonic: I have five things in my mouth and I need them all for me. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.
additionalM:
Hints
What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how you would sound asking for “waga” with your mouth full of five things. You can carry out this experiment in real life if you would like, just be careful not to choke, okay?
readingMnemonic: Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!”

meaningMnemonic: You take some gold and cover your yoga brush in it, turning it into a key. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key!
additionalM:
Hints
You lost your old key, you see. But you're a go with the flow type of person, thanks to all the yoga, so you make a new one!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine carefully putting your makeshift key into your car's lock. You close your eyes and pray that the car guillotine isn't going to trigger, knowing it isn't a legit key.
readingMnemonic: This key has to be perfect, because if it isn't the car guillotine (かぎ) will come down and chop off your hand!

meaningMnemonic: I found part of a plate at the lantern festival, and put it on a tray to keep it safe. There is a legendary plate broken into three parts. One part of the plate I found was at the lantern festival. The lantern festival was pretty cool, but I’m really glad I found the part of that plate I was looking for.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding a tray in your hands with this part of the plate on it, as the light from the lanterns glitters off it and dances around, illuminating the background. It’s enchanting.
additionalR:
Hints
Tap this bone china plate with your knuckle. Hear the pleasant tap as you continue to view all the fancy lanterns around you at the festival.
readingMnemonic: The plate part you found at the lantern festival (and put on the tray) is made out of bone (ぼん) china. How fancy. Is bone china made from real bones? Bones found in China? Probably not, huh.

meaningMnemonic: You're standing under a canopy when you see something strange sticking out of the dirt. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant manor starts rising out of the ground with you on top!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself on top of this manor that rose out of the ground. The canopy is still above you and it seems to be attached to the roof.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being chased by an angry shougun all through his giant, luxurious manor. You barely have time to admire the interior design with him gaining on you like this!
readingMnemonic: The beautiful manor begins to shake and the shougun bursts out of the front door. "WHO HAS UNEARTHED MY SECRET MANOR?!" he screams.

meaningMnemonic: An animal that kicks dirt into people's mouths is a monkey. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at a monkey at the zoo. Aww, it's so cute. But then it turns around and kicks some dirt right into your aww-ing mouth. Yuck! Why monkey, why?!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the monkey saluting you as you spit dirt out of your mouth. Taste the bitter dirt and the bitter shame. You were played by a monkey.
readingMnemonic: You spit the dirt out of your mouth and look back at the monkey to see that it's saluting (さる) you. Is... is it mocking you?

meaningMnemonic: There’s a tree in the east that looks like a pillar. The tree is tall and straight and does not have any leaves or branches. The tree is basically a big wooden pillar that just happens to be alive still.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this big tree pillar over in the east. You always know where east is because of it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine looking down on とうきょう from atop this magnificent pillar. The sun is rising behind you, slowly illuminating the city below.
readingMnemonic: That pillar happens to be in the center of とうきょう. If you need to find east (which is where とうきょう is), you just look for the pillar.

meaningMnemonic: "Say 'big,' ground beggar! Have pride!"
additionalM:
Hints
You are trying to tell a beggar on the ground to say they are big, because you want to make the beggar feel a little pride. "Have pride in your job as a beggar!" you tell them.
additionalR:
Hints
I'm not sure why gaining pride made the beggar revert back to being a child, but it seems like you did something good, maybe?
readingMnemonic: After giving some pride to the ground beggar, he looks up at you and tears off his beard and skin. "I am a 子 (こ) again, thanks to you!"

meaningMnemonic: Inside your eye stands a tiny village that makes up your pupil. That's the black part of your eye!
additionalM:
Hints
Oh, did you think your pupil was a hole? No, no, you misunderstand. That's where the village stands. It's full of little people who whisper to your brain what you should see.
additionalR:
Hints
Even if you're a pupil non-believer, at least you can see how it's shaped like a doughnut hole, right?
readingMnemonic: All of the people in your pupil eat doughnuts (どう) all day long. That's why your eye is shaped like a doughnut, with the "hole" (village) as their home.

meaningMnemonic: On the roof is your heart. OR! In a net in the street. Which would you rather?
additionalM:
Hints
Would you rather have your heart up on the roof, close to falling but out of the way of people. Or would you rather have your heart in a net, which people can't steal from, but is in the way of cars.
additionalR:
Hints
"I'd rather you didn't have that!" you shout as you neighbors run through the neighborhood to their own house. You'd rather this wasn't happening! You'd rather your neighbors let you make your own choice!!
readingMnemonic: As you try to decide which you'd rather have, your neighbors (ねい) come out and grab the heart out of your hands.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of your sad life aims a kick at the sack you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it’s not something you want to have kicked.
additionalM:
Hints
See this leader’s kick coming at your sack. Hear the leader yelling as he aims his kick at your sack. Hiyahhh! Also keep in mind that the life radical is missing the little drop/slide thing on the side. It’s missing that because your life is lousy and sad.
additionalR:
Hints
You thought you were all cool saying “heyo” and moving your sack away from the kick, but they had this planned all along. Heyo…
readingMnemonic: You manage to get your sack out of the way as you shout “Heyo (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!” Unfortunately your leader’s friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. “Heyo!” he shouts, mockingly.

meaningMnemonic: Poop Poop Mountain is covered in poop because it is such a secluded place.
additionalM:
Hints
A secluded place has no toilets, so you just poop right on the mountain.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hundreds of youths on this secluded mountain, all pooping on the ground while trying to get a cell phone signal.
readingMnemonic: The secluded Poop Poop Mountain is a favorite of youths (ゆう). They go there to get away from their phones to get in touch with nature again.

meaningMnemonic: With the power of your mouth you command a tree to become a shelf. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine using your mouth to turn a tree into a shelf. Yell at this tree and keep yelling at it until you see it become a shelf.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine transporting the shelves in your car. Over and over. Back and forth in your car. Vroom vroom.
readingMnemonic: Once you turn the tree into a shelf you put the shelf in your car (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money.

meaningMnemonic: Your village wants to take the village dog and boil it, and you can think of no other response than SHUT UP!
additionalM:
Hints
The entire village is shouting and yelling and pointing at the poor dog. They're boiling a giant boiling pot of water, and you can't even hear yourself think anymore. Shut up, shut up, shut up!
additionalR:
Hints
Even the dog is mocking you now. It's barks sound more like "shut up, shut up" than "bow wow, bow wow." What the heck dog, I was trying to save your life!
readingMnemonic: The villagers are mad that you told them to shut up, and they start to mock (もく) you. They put their hands on their hips, lean forward, cross their eyes, and yell "SHUT UP!" back.

meaningMnemonic: You use your car and an axe to slice down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine driving your car, waving your axe out the window and slicing this guy down. Hear his scream ring in your ears as you slice, slice, SLICE.
additionalR:
Hints
Zanzibar is a crazy place, huh? Continue to drive around Zanzibar as you wave your axe out your car window looking for another victim to slice.
readingMnemonic: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when you sliced down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe.

meaningMnemonic: You stand your towel up so everyone can see it. This announces that you are the sovereign ruler of this bathroom.
additionalM:
Hints
Whenever someone walks into your bathroom, you start screaming that you are the sovereign ruler of this toilet, this sink, this toothbrush, and all that touch these tiles.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your standing towel with a huge tater tot sewn into it. Everyone who sees this will know that you're the toilet tater tot sovereign.
readingMnemonic: As the sovereign ruler of this bathroom, you must choose a monogram to represent your rule. For this, you choose the symbol of the food that passes through you the most: The mighty tater (てい) tot!

meaningMnemonic: Someone with a top hat comes and tells you that your grains are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a tariff that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple.
additionalM:
Hints
People in top hats like to put tariffs on lots of things. Especially things you need, like grains you eat to stay alive. You have no choice but to pay.
additionalR:
Hints
Everything you get from other counties has been tariffed except for soap. You'll be hungry, but at least you'll be clean.
readingMnemonic: You're listening to all the things in this tariff and you finally get fed up and ask what isn't being taxed now. The top hat man looks at you and smiles, holding out his hand. In his hand is some soap (そ).

meaningMnemonic: The gold from the east needs tempering before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it’s entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you’d do in a forge.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine tempering this gold from the east. You’re heat treating the gold when you’re tempering it, so feel the heat from the fire on your face and arms.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself in this rental smithy. It’s really nice. There’s like TVs and live music and free WiFi and everything. It’s a very nice rental in which to do tempering. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 練, which has the same right side.
readingMnemonic: The smithy where you’re doing the tempering is pretty fancy, but it’s just a rental (れん). You haven’t sold enough gold to own a smithy as nice as this one yet, so for now, you rent one. It is pretty swanky though, even for a rental.

meaningMnemonic: If you see a building wearing a giant top hat, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to thwart all of the plans the people in other buildings have.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the building, with it's tall top hat, inching closer to other buildings when no one is looking. It's planning to thwart everything!
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the soap cleans all of the paint away, thwarting the entire paint project. The painters are on the ground, crying and squeaky clean.
readingMnemonic: The building next door is being painted, and the top hat building is jealous. It thwarts the painting plans by dumping soap (そ) out of its windows and onto the painters and the building!

meaningMnemonic: You need to stop a drunkard from going down a slide with a jackhammer to ask him how many years old he is. He's doing a lot of dangerous things right now, and they all have age limits.
additionalM:
Hints
Depending how many years old he is, this guy could be violating like three different laws right now.
additionalR:
Hints
Your saber cuts through the cyborgs robo-body and it screams, "OKAY OKAY I'M NOT A MILLION I'M ONLY FIVE YEARS OLD AND A CYBORG PLEASE DON'T REPROGRAM ME!"
readingMnemonic: When you ask him how many years old he is, he turns to you and screams, "I'M A MILLION YEARS OLD AND YOU'LL NEVER STOP ME!" That's obviously not how old this kid is, so you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and slice the slide in half. Then the jackhammer. Then the kid's metal arm—wait! This kid is a cyborg (さい)!

meaningMnemonic: You get rain orders. Your orders are to make sure there is zero spill.
additionalM:
Hints
Despite it raining, your orders are to make sure none (zero!) of the rain spills anywhere. Figure out what you need to do to make sure you follow these rain orders successfully. Zero spill, alright?
additionalR:
Hints
You just take your ray gun and "zap!" the clouds are gone. There will be zero spills today.
Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.
readingMnemonic: The best way to make sure there is zero spill when it rains is to get rid of the rain. You use a special ray (れい) gun and zap the rain right out of the sky. There will be zero spills because there will be zero rain.

meaningMnemonic: That penguin over there seems to have a towel stuffed with cash.
additionalM:
Hints
The towel the cash is in even has a big $ on it like the ones they have at the bank. You follow the penguin into a back alley.
additionalR:
Hints
You wait for the penguin to leave and you run over to the hay stack and stick your hand in. But you don't feel the towel or the cash! Instead you pull out your hand and it's full of hay and needles. Ouch! No fair, gimme that cash!!
readingMnemonic: Your eyes follow the cash, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a hay (へい) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles.

meaningMnemonic: You give bamboo to someone and they make them into chopsticks. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch this person take ordinary bamboo and transform it into chopsticks right before your eyes. Hear the whooshing and whittling sounds as they form the bamboo into chopsticks with expert speed and precision.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to pick up hash browns with your chopsticks. They would be really hard to eat if you didn't have these handy eating tools!
readingMnemonic: Now use those chopsticks to eat some delicious hash (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for.

meaningMnemonic: Rub charcoal under your eyes if you want to see clearly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun.
additionalM:
Hints
You can even rub charcoal in your eyes if you really want to clear them up, but you should probably only do this under the supervision of your eye doctor.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how dangerous it would be not to have clear vision while you row around in a row boat. You might even smack yourself in the face with your own oars.
readingMnemonic: You have to have clear vision because you're about to go out in your row (りょう) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death.

meaningMnemonic: There is a mountain on top of a bunch of dirt with a steep cliff. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the cliff even bigger and steeper and scarier.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a cliff. Now add two big helpings of dirt and a mountain to the top. It's still a cliff, it's just more cliff than before.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine falling down this huge cliff and the last words you have to hear before you splat on the ground is someone yelling "Guy" at you over and over. What a way to go.
readingMnemonic: As you’re peering over this tall cliff, somebody behind you shouts, “Hey, guy (がい)!” This startles you and you tumble down the cliff. Apparently so did he, because you can hear him saying, "Hey guy! OOF! Are you okay? OOF! Guy? Guy!!!” as you both fall.

meaningMnemonic: Without a fire, you will lack the ability to cook anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself as you cook with a fire very confidently. Knowing you cannot fail, feel the heat and hear the crackling embers of the fire. Smell the delicious smell of whatever you are cooking as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine swinging this meal over the fire. Feel the flames licking at your fingertips as you cook this meal by swinging it back and forth over the fire.
readingMnemonic: You cook your meal evenly by swinging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal.

meaningMnemonic: Sitting safely under your canopy you take rice and dirt, mix it up, and create unique cosmetics for your face.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine mixing dirt and rice together to make some cosmetics that best fit your skin tone and type. No one will see you doing it under this canopy too, so the secret formula you come up with will be safe.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine meeting the Shougun with your new cosmetics all over your face. You look amazing! Stunning! The shougun wants to know where you got that foundation, you're glowing!
readingMnemonic: You need these cosmetics because you have a meeting with the Shougun (しょう) coming up. You want to impress him, and you don't want anyone to copy your look.

meaningMnemonic: A pig with horns runs into a building and makes it fall into the dirt. This makes a loud crash sound. I mean, how could it not? The building literally crashed to the ground when the horned pig attacked it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a pig with horns crashing into a building and both of them crashing into the dirt. Uh oh, is the pig dead?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine walking around the crash site yelling "Sooey! Sooey!" over and over. You'll never know if the pig survived the crash if you don't.
readingMnemonic: You're worried about the pig, that was a pretty big crash, after all. So you yell, "SOOEY (つい)!" Here pig pig pig. SOOEEEYYY! You know—the universal call for pigs

meaningMnemonic: A crab will try to hide what it lacks with deceit. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab.
additionalM:
Hints
Covering things up with deceit is pretty much the worst thing you can do, so don't be like this crab.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the crab with its head, er, front half? Whatever, it's in the guillotine and it's screaming, "You've been deceived! I never deceived anyone, you're all sheep!"
readingMnemonic: Deceit can only take you so far, and soon the crab is caught, tried for its crimes and coverups, and sentenced to death via guillotine (ぎ).

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits your mohawk and it begins to drip. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having all this tsunami water in your hair. Hear it drip from your mohawk. Drip… drip… drip…
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the weight of this dryer helmet on your head as you listen to it whirr away. The dripping has finally stopped! Success!
readingMnemonic: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed techie (てき), so you develop a device to stop the drip drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits.

meaningMnemonic: In the dirt there are flags and horns lined up with a lantern attached to them, making a fence. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you see the fence made of horns and flags through the light of the lantern?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself climbing over this fence (that you're definitely not supposed to climb based on all these flags and horns) and falling into the piles of hay. It's a little scratchy, but otherwise pretty comfy!
readingMnemonic: You want to know what this fence is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of hay (へい).

meaningMnemonic: It's raining on your spear that has winter power. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates fog.
additionalM:
Hints
When warm water touches a cold spear, fog billows out and covers everything.
additionalR:
Hints
You walk toward the kirin through the fog. When you get close, the image before you becomes clear: it's two cans of Kirin beer on a slide.
Next time you see fog, keep your eyes peeled for the real kirin in the kiri.
readingMnemonic: Through the fog you see the shape of a mythical kirin (きり). You can only see the outline through the fog, but you know it's there.

meaningMnemonic: After passing through a door, you use a feather to put the finishing touches on a folding fan. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is.
additionalM:
Hints
Use this folding fan to fan your face. Feel the refreshing breeze as you admire the gorgeous feather you just added. What a fashionista you’ve become.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine handing this newly made folding fan to the centaur. See his face light up with delight as he examines your fine craftsmanship and starts fanning himself with it. Another satisfied customer!
readingMnemonic: Your biggest folding fan customer is a centaur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur.

meaningMnemonic: The door a criminal will get into is the front door. Now hold on, you may be thinking, wouldn't they go for the back door? No! 99% of home invasions happen when you leave your own front door unlocked!
additionalM:
Hints
You better check the locks on your front door right now, because odds are you left it open and didn't even notice. It's the perfect door for a criminal to get access to your home.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how you'd heat up your front door. A hot iron? A blow torch? A small fire? It doesn't matter how, as long as the heat makes it all the way through your front door and hurts any criminals trying to get into it.
readingMnemonic: To protect your front door from criminals you plan to fill it with heat (ひ). Oh yeah, we're gonna Kevin McCallister this.

meaningMnemonic: A soul will only inhabit a root if it's holding a grudge. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something.
additionalM:
Hints
Don't die with a grudge, or your soul might end up angry and trapped in some roots.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a tree with the soul of a condor with a grudge in it before you. You feel bad about being so wasteful with paper and chopsticks now, huh?
readingMnemonic: If you see one of these grudge trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a condor (こん). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees.

meaningMnemonic: You take a towel and wrap it around your head to keep the sun out of your eyes. You've invented... the hat!
additionalM:
Hints
A hat is just a piece of cloth or a towel you get to stay on your head. Extra points if it protect your eyes from the sun.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine bowling with hats. Thankfully, they work as bowling balls just as well as they work as hats. You're so innovative!
readingMnemonic: People see you wearing this fancy new hat thing and start asking you to share. You grab all your extra towels, roll them up, and bowl (ぼう) them down the street toward everyone who asks for one.

meaningMnemonic: The soul mask helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see hate.
additionalM:
Hints
You're supposed to see all the emotions, so why do you only see hate inside everyone?
additionalR:
Hints
Zombies are pretty filled with hate, so it makes sense that you'd see a bunch of hate if you used the soul mask on them.
readingMnemonic: It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much hate because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of zombies (ぞう).

meaningMnemonic: The leader of a narwhal construction crew needs all the help he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being the narwhal leader and asking others for help. Ask a shark for help. Ask a whale for help. Ask a shrimp for help. Go on, ask.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine using this saw and realizing how big of a help it is. Hear the saw sawing away as you and your fellow narwhals get to work.
readingMnemonic: Then you discover a saw (さ) who would be a great big help. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away.

meaningMnemonic: You have fingers in the thousands and while looking up at the sun you decide you want to insert them in there.
additionalM:
Hints
Hold your thousand+ fingers up to the sun and imagine inserting them into the sun's super-hot ... s-sun lava. (That's what it is, right? Yeah, let's go with that.)
additionalR:
Hints
Since you have a thousand fingers too many, you decide to insert them all into the sun and watch as their souls pop out. You listen to the little souls scream at you.
readingMnemonic: You insert one finger, it burns up immediately, and its soul (そう) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone.

meaningMnemonic: A leader and Wolverine take a slide to Italy. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine Wolverine and his leader Professor X going down this slide to Italy. Hear them wooping and cheering as they ride down the slide. Whee~
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this eagle carrying Professor X away from Italy and out over the ocean. You can also remember this reading easily because Italy starts with the letter I. Super simple stuff.
readingMnemonic: Before Professor X can get off the slide into Italy, a large eagle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X!

meaningMnemonic: They say the key to telling a lie is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine an actual key going from you to another person. This key is the lie. You gotta believe in the lie for it to reach the other person and unlock their understanding. Visualize this visual lie.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to lie your way out of this. He saw you steal his saw. He caught you red handed. What sort of lie can you spin to get yourself out of this situation?
readingMnemonic: The lie you told was about not stealing your buddy’s saw (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well.

meaningMnemonic: With a woman's mouth, you have a likeness to me.
additionalM:
Hints
