Imagine someone's putting a woman's mouth over your mouth, looking at you, and commenting on your likeness. All it took was this woman's mouth.
additionalR:
Hints
Jo-Anne popped her mouth off and put it on you. Indeed with that mouth on, you have an extreme likeness to her.
readingMnemonic: You have a likeness to Jo-Anne (じょ) when you wear that mouth.

meaningMnemonic: A landslide came out of your mouth and created your lips. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your mouth as an open hole. Now a landslide of something (words? food? something worse?) comes pouring out, and when it's done you have lips. You flap them open and closed to test them out.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine wrapping your new lips around the mouth of this Kuchi beer bottle. It's so good! And you aren't spilling any of it!
readingMnemonic: Now you can use your new lips to enjoy a nice, cold Kuchi beer (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there.

meaningMnemonic: A Viking moves your mouth with his hand to manipulate it. He sticks his hand into your mouth. With the Viking's hand in your mouth, he can make you look like you’re saying anything he wants.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the Viking having his hand in your mouth. Taste his salty flesh on your tongue. Imagine him manipulating your mouth and your jaw and making it look like you are saying all sorts of funny things.
additionalR:
Hints
You don't want to manipulate the Shougun, but you can't seem to get the Viking's hand out of your mouth. You frantically imagine all the manipulative things the Viking could get the Shougun to do for him like this.
readingMnemonic: The Viking is manipulating you so that he can manipulate the Shougun (しょう)! You and the Shougun have grown pretty close over the last year or so, and this Viking is going to take advantage!

meaningMnemonic: A wave crashes into a woman, transforming her into an old woman! The wave washes away all of the woman’s makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a gorgeous woman. Now see her get hit by a wave of water and turn into an old woman. The old woman could still be pretty too, she just looks way old now. Like ancient.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this old woman acting like a sheep, just saying “baa” over and over and over again. Baa! Baa! Baa!
readingMnemonic: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an old woman, the old woman starts to baa (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes “Baa! Baa!” and hops around on all fours like a sheep.

meaningMnemonic: With a lid, you hit yourself in the mouth and then kick it like a pathetic loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine kicking this lid and with each kick you feel a little bit more pathetic. Your mouth hurts a lot too.
additionalR:
Hints
Hold your eye with one hand and your mouth with the other. Feel them pulse in pain as you reflect on how pathetic you are today.
readingMnemonic: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the eye (あい). How pathetic. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you.

meaningMnemonic: An insect specializing in construction builds a rainbow. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this insect with a construction hat on, building a rainbow. He works very fast. The resulting rainbow is beautiful!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this construction insect being all whiny and needy for attention and stuff. It’s pathetic. Hear him whine and whine because of how needy he is.
readingMnemonic: This rainbow building insect is so needy (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!”

meaningMnemonic: A big treasure treasure treasure treasure is refreshing! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine finding this big treasure treasure treasure treasure and being really refreshed and relieved and happy. This treasure treasure treasure treasure is so big, you’ll be set for life!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the most sour taste you could ever imagine. So super-duper sour! Now imagine that sour taste instantly melting away once you discover this big refreshing treasure treasure treasure treasure. Jackpot!
readingMnemonic: You’d had a sour (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo refreshing!

meaningMnemonic: You keep your tongue to your self to give your heart a rest. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time.
additionalM:
Hints
It's important to let yourself rest every now and then, you know.
additionalR:
Hints
You should rest right now. Take a break from Japanese and go eat some cake. (Just remember to come back when your tongue and heart are sufficiently rested!)
readingMnemonic: What better way to rest than to eat some cake (けい)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief.

meaningMnemonic: This shrimp is the exact length of a shaku, or Japanese foot. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this foot long shrimp. It’s pretty big. Imagine it squirming about making a “shaku shaku” sound as it worms about.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Shaq dribbling the shrimp like a basketball, saying “shaku, shaku, shaku” every time he bounces the shrimp.
readingMnemonic: How is shaku, the Japanese foot, pronounced by Shaq (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese.

meaningMnemonic: Take this stone and throw it at nine crosses to smash them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the nine crosses in front of you, lined up in a triangle. Now take your rock, hold it above your head, and SMASH it down on them as hard as you can!!
additionalR:
Hints
You smash things because your own heart has been smashed by your cyborg. :'(
readingMnemonic: As you smash these crosses, you think of your cyborg (さい) and how much you want to smash the people who took it away from you. Your cyborg was so good at smashing things too. You could be smashing together, if you didn't have to sell it.

meaningMnemonic: Your rice fortune is sticky. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this sticky rice fortune of yours. Run your hands through it and feel the sticky rice between your fingers. Hear the sticky sucking sounds and you stir the sticky rice about.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine sculpting these sticky rice nendoroids with your bare hands. Feel the sticky rice between your fingers as you smush the rice into cute little nendoroids.
readingMnemonic: This rice is so sticky that you are able to sculpt nendoroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it.

meaningMnemonic: In the rice paddy there is a forehead with a top hat. It sits atop an area of tatami mats.
additionalM:
Hints
The meaning you're trying to learn is tatami mat, so focus on the beautiful tatami mats that are strangely in the middle of this rice paddy. On top is a forehead with a top hat. It almost looks like the tatami mats are an altar for this gruesome scene.
additionalR:
Hints
You saw Jourm setting up the tatami mats a day earlier, but you thought he was just making an area for workers in the field to rest in. Does the forehead with a top hat have anything to do with Jourm? Did he... do something bad?
readingMnemonic: Who made this creepy tatami mat altar? It was Jourm (じょう) the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village.

meaningMnemonic: The moon is the same as your torso. Because you’re so FAT! AHHAHAHAHAHA. I’m sorry, that was mean. But really, if your torso was as big as the moon, you’d have one large torso, y’know?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if your torso was as large as the moon. You’re a gigantic human. Imagine floating around in space like this. Wooooaaaahhh.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how many doughnuts you would have to eat to get your torso this size. Now imagine eating all of those doughnuts. I hope you like doughnuts, because you’re going to be eating a lot of them.
readingMnemonic: Your torso got so big because of all the doughnuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things.

meaningMnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for towel first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means towel as well.
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Go into your bathroom or your linen closet right now. Look at your towels. Look for the small きん hidden there.
readingMnemonic: You know who loves towels? The King (きん) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put きん on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one.

meaningMnemonic: There are flowers growing around a heart with a wick sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow.
additionalM:
Hints
See this morbid scene. As the wick burns you can smell the smell of burning organs. The flowers are pretty though.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine slicing your shin with a knife, causing blood to drip on the flowers around the heart with a wick in it. Your shin really hurts from the injury, but the flowers are rejoicing as they’re showered in blood.
readingMnemonic: Sometimes the wick burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your shin (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers.

meaningMnemonic: A tree that is stamped with one pattern, then stamped with another pattern, over and over, is the willow tree.
additionalM:
Hints
A willow tree is a tree that looks like it's on repeat over and over again. It also looks nice on a stamp. Note that the first stamp is kind of an ugly looking backwards stamp, and the second stamp is the normal stamp radical.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch Ryu as he French kisses this willow tree. Hear him slurping and moaning in ecstasy. Why are you watching this? This is gross. Wait – is this turning you on!? Ew.
readingMnemonic: Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves willow trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening.

meaningMnemonic: A scooter with horns with a pig riding on it will be able to accomplish anything.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the pig scooting around. It is able to accomplish anything you can imagine (so go nuts with your imagination).
additionalR:
Hints
Perhaps it even takes the swing all the way around in a full 360 degree rotation. This horned scooter riding pig can truly accomplish anything.
readingMnemonic: It was even able to successfully accomplish a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a swing (すい), swinging back and forth, then jumping off.

meaningMnemonic: Flowers are mysteriously appearing in the rice paddy. No matter what you do to them, they continue to amass.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself spraying poison on these mysterious flowers, but they just double in size, and continue to amass.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the wetness of the rice paddy under your feet and the fluffiness of the chicks pressing in on you. Watch the looming, mysterious flowers above you as the chicks smother you.
readingMnemonic: As the flowers amass it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby chicks (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well.

meaningMnemonic: The moon has a lot of power that is power it gets from the power of every armpit of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine an aura of stinky power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Feel the power leaving you as the moon saps your power through your armpits.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine this whole scene again but keep in mind how wacky it all really is. The moon sapping power from you through your armpits? So wacky.
readingMnemonic: This is a pretty wacky (わき) armpit image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life?

meaningMnemonic: Give a district weapons and it will assault other districts.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture two districts using weapons to assault each other from above. Like in a video game, with little arrows showing you where they're launching each assault.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the districts assaulting each other from above again, and then pan out and see the 王 standing above, watching it all happen. He's cackling.
readingMnemonic: This assault is all the 王's (おう) fault. The 王 gave the weapons to each of the districts on purpose so this would happen.

meaningMnemonic: Having a foul mouth and horns will prevent you from getting into Heaven where you would blossom into an angel. If you have horns, you are not meant for Heaven and will not blossom there. To blossom in Heaven, you must not have horns or a foul mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Swear like a sailor as you imagine yourself with some horns. You’re not going to blossom in Heaven. You’re going to blossom in Hell and become a demon.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine taking a saw to your horns and sawing them off. Hear the reverberation of the saw in your skull as you painfully saw off your horns.
readingMnemonic: You don’t want to blossom into a demon so you saw (さ) off your horns with a saw. If you saw off your horns, maybe you can beg for forgiveness and have your foul mouth forgiven.

meaningMnemonic: Cast a book in gold to make a bowl. Books can be bent into the shape of a bowl, so then all you have to do is pour gold over it to keep it in that shape and ta-da! A bowl has been born!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine creating this bowl yourself. Try not to burn your fingers with that hot gold.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so this may not be the best bowl. You usually don't need a hatch or this much gold coating. But that's how they used to do it in the old days, so that's good enough for you!
readingMnemonic: The gold bowl has a hatch (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the bowl!

meaningMnemonic: Your servant uses a stool to break open shellfish. You know how much work shucking shellfish is so this method is really clever.
additionalM:
Hints
You knew hiring this servant was a good idea. "Clever girl," you say, as your servant sits on some shellfish again.
additionalR:
Hints
You thought you were being so clever, taking shellfish from someone else. It turns out, there is a cost for being shellfish.
readingMnemonic: "More clever than you!" your servant yells, tearing off his wig. "It is I, Ken (けん) the samurai. I saw you take this shellfish from my master's lands."

meaningMnemonic: You use a cleat to climb a tree and your hair gets the same coloring as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine digging your cleats into the bark of the tree until you get high enough for your hair to start coloring itself tree colors. It might be a lot of work, but it's worth it.
additionalR:
Hints
You couldn't take the pain of losing your cyborg, so you've become one. Your robo-hair can change its coloring, but soon you'll be even more cyborg-y than before!
readingMnemonic: This cool coloring can only happen because you turned yourself into a cyborg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones.

meaningMnemonic: In this building there's a small sun that's small. They keep this small, small sun inside of a crevice.
additionalM:
Hints
You wouldn't want to keep a sun out in the open, even if it's small (and small). You'd put it inside something, like a crevice. Imagine walking into the building and seeing the small sun right inside, in a crevice.
additionalR:
Hints
If the sun were out in the open, it'd melt all the snow, making it hard to ski here. So they hide the sun away in a crevice so people can ski.
readingMnemonic: They keep the sun in the crevice because this is a place where people ski (すき).

meaningMnemonic: You need to put a clown in the dirt if you want to cultivate good crops there. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine burying a dead clown in the dirt and then planting some seeds on top. It's worth it, you think, if it helps cultivate your crops.
additionalR:
Hints
Saying bye is polite. Never forget to say bye, even in the middle of a cold-blooded clown murder.
readingMnemonic: Before you can start this whole cultivation process however, you have to say bye (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt.

meaningMnemonic: Your foot, as your mama says, was given the task to dance. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your mama asking you to dance. The two of you pick up and kick your feet to dance, spinning 'round and 'round.
additionalR:
Hints
Lean down and take a big whiff of your dancing feet. The odor is... HORRIBLE! AHGH!
readingMnemonic: You both dance so much that you develop an odor (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet.

meaningMnemonic: This gate makes the sound of darkness. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this gate making an ominous sound. The sound of darkness. Look deep into the darkness of the gate as you hear the sound it makes. Ouummmmm…
additionalR:
Hints
Take the darkness in your hands. It’s like really dark cotton candy. Imagine eating it and how yummy it is. Keep hearing the sound it’s making as you eat. Yummy!
readingMnemonic: You decide to taste the darkness and discover that it is so yummy (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy!

meaningMnemonic: You have a surplus of ladles laid out diagonally in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at all these ladles lying diagonally in front of you. Pick them up. Feel the wood grain. Wonder why you have so many.
additionalR:
Hints
Uh oh, is this one of those weird tests where they find out if you're the chosen one or some old scholar reincarnated? Who knew laying ladles at diagonal angles could reveal this kinda stuff?!
readingMnemonic: In front of this diagonal pattern is a shaman (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook.

meaningMnemonic: You see shrimp on ice at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been exhausted. It's all gone!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the lack of shrimp on the ice. All you wanted was some delicious shrimp for dinner, but now it's all gone 😩
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the worker's jeans and how gross they are with all those shrimp stuffed into them. Yuck!
readingMnemonic: How could the store exhaust its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their jeans (じん) . Aha! The culprit!

meaningMnemonic: Rain falls off a tree and lands in your eye where it turns to frost. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the rain hit your eye and then crystalize into frost immediately. The rain in your eye is wet, and then very cold as it becomes frost.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself walking proudly, casting your frost gaze at all who you pass. "Wow look at that frosty, cool shemo. She's sooooo cool!" you hear them whisper. (Haha cool, get it? Because you're frosty and also a little sad, which is totally in when you're a teen.)
readingMnemonic: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo frost idea because you are a shemo (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns.

meaningMnemonic: You need to feed this grain to a flower wearing turkey on a stool so you start the harvest. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this fat turkey with flowers on its head, sitting on a stool. It's gobbling for grains and you need to be the one who harvests them.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine an angry cock chasing you around as you try to harvest grain. He keeps pecking you, ouch!
readingMnemonic: You're just starting to harvest the grains when an angry cock (かく) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him.

meaningMnemonic: This canopy of trees isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of hemp.
additionalM:
Hints
Wow, these hemp plants are so big that they look like trees. But, despite their size they're still just hemp.
additionalR:
Hints
Your mama knew that you were going to like hemp in the future, so she planted these hemp plants for you. What a great mama.
readingMnemonic: Who planted all this hemp? Your mama (ま) did.

meaningMnemonic: An odd horse is still a horse. It may look a little funny, but that doesn't change what it is on the inside.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this odd horse. Hear it whinny and neigh like a normal horse. It's not so odd, after all.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch the horse take the key in its mouth and open the stable doors. It may be odd, but it sure is resourceful.
readingMnemonic: This horse is particularly odd because it knows how to use a key (き). It carries a key around its neck and uses it to get in and out of its stable.

meaningMnemonic: The landslide measurement humiliates you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet.
additionalM:
Hints
Honestly, that's what you get for lying. But it doesn't make it any less humiliating even if you deserve it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine all of the cruel jokes people say to humiliate you. Feel your face burn and your stomach flip.
readingMnemonic: Your friends and coworkers humiliate you more by making jokes (じょく). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!"

meaningMnemonic: Fire you use to light up the street needs to go in a lamp. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture these lamps lining the street, with their little fires burning brightly. Nowadays we don't have real fire in them, we use electricity!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture とうきょう, not lit up by all of the electricity, signs, shops, and things that light up its streets today, but by old-fashioned fire lamps!
readingMnemonic: These street lamps were first used in とうきょう. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in とうきょう than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up!

meaningMnemonic: In the mysterious rice paddy there is some livestock. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed.
additionalM:
Hints
Examine this mysterious livestock from a distance. Imagine them floating around the mysterious rice paddy like they aren’t even walking. Hear them moo and oink as well.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at this chick bobbling about in the air. It looks very ephemeral and other worldly. Still a very cute chick though. You want to pet it.
readingMnemonic: Your favorite member of the mysterious livestock crew is a little chick (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings.

meaningMnemonic: The tsunami hits your form and you begin to melt. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the water from the tsunami crashing into your form. Feel the water on your body as your form begins to melt. I’m melting! I’m mellltiinnnggg!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel the melt begin to reverse as you eat your yogurt. Taste the yogurt on your tongue as your form begins to solidify once again.
readingMnemonic: The only way to reverse the melt process is to eat some yogurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt!

meaningMnemonic: The type of insect that ruins your writing is the mosquito. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sitting at your desk writing when a mosquito starts bzzzzing in your ear. You can't ignore it, it's gonna bite you. So you flail around helplessly.
additionalR:
Hints
You can't. You can't write like this. You need to kill the mosquito and its little car too.
readingMnemonic: That mosquito noise sounds like it's driving a tiny car (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car?

meaningMnemonic: Take your towel and make it long. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your notebook, which you will write all your notes in.
additionalM:
Hints
You are making the towel really long, because it's white and it might be good for writing in. It's going to become your notebook.
additionalR:
Hints
Something bad is going to happen, and you need to warn everybody. It's her, it's her, it's her. Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou!
readingMnemonic: Inside your long towel notebook you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. Chou" (ちょう).

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami surplus will cover all the dirt with paint. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the different colors of paint being swept along by tsunami after tsunami, painting the dirt as it goes.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine dipping each of your toes into the paint-dirt, one by one, to paint each of them a different color. Why are you doing this?
readingMnemonic: You touch the paint in the dirt with your toe (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow.

meaningMnemonic: Your shellfish are worth a fortune because you decided to paste your fortune to the shellfish.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of your riches, your money, your jewels. They're all pasted directly onto all of your shellfish!
additionalR:
Hints
"Ha ha!" Paste paste. "Ha ha ha!!" PASTE PASTE PASTE.
readingMnemonic: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use paste to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "Ha (は)!" Paste.

meaningMnemonic: The sunlight shines on your forehead in your car with a great radiance. The car you are in is a convertible, so the sunlight shines right onto your big bald forehead. The sun has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from the sunlight hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this radiance emanating from your shiny dome. The radiance is blinding!
additionalR:
Hints
Point your shiny forehead, filled with radiance, at your car. Hear the engine start and jump to life as you power it with the reflected sunlight from your forehead.
readingMnemonic: This radiance is the key (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car.

meaningMnemonic: When your soul has an idea it's just a recollection of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now.
additionalM:
Hints
When you have a recollection of some idea or thing in the past, it's just your soul saying, hey remember this? Let's not forget this.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine recollecting a past life in Oklahoma. Life was simple and nice. You should consider taking this as a sign to move there again!
readingMnemonic: Your soul is sending you a recollection right now of... your past life as a farmer in Oklahoma (おく). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again.

meaningMnemonic: If you try to put your soul into everything, you'll regret it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if you went full force into everything you've ever even thought of doing. Imagine how burnt out your soul would be. Imagine all the regret you'd have that you didn't just stick to one thing and do it well.
additionalR:
Hints
Throw everything you regret away. Only kayak from now on.
readingMnemonic: The regret is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but kayaking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club.

meaningMnemonic: You take a rake in for a measurement but it is resistant. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others.
additionalM:
Hints
Try and move this rake over to the measurement table. It is resistant so you have a hard time moving it. Imagine the rake struggling and resisting endlessly.
additionalR:
Hints
See yourself tying the tie around the rake and attaching it to the measurement table. The rake is still jostling around, but the tie keeps it from moving about too terribly much.
readingMnemonic: Because the rake is persistently resistant, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck tie (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly.

meaningMnemonic: On a cliff, the pope is holding a shield. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the shield glowing brightly as hymns play in the background. The demons try to get close to the pope to shove him off the cliff but the holy shield is too bright and popey.
additionalR:
Hints
This pope would have been in a lot of trouble if June's summer sun hadn't risen at just the right moment. His shield would have become useless and he might have been shoved off the cliff if it was a less sunny month.
readingMnemonic: The light of the pope's shield begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's June (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell!

meaningMnemonic: There is an insect on the roof in a spoon. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a snake to your roof.
additionalM:
Hints
Snakes love insects, especially when they're ready to eat on a spoon. But, snakes don't usually go on top of the roof, so that's why you have to tempt one with an insect in a spoon.
additionalR:
Hints
Especially big snakes. They're really, really hebi.
readingMnemonic: Why don't you just bring a snake up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are heavy (へび).

meaningMnemonic: If the king gives you a knife you become part of his squad. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if you were given a knife and allowed into the king's squad. Would you let the power corrupt you?
additionalR:
Hints
I'm not saying Han Solo is a bad squad leader, but his track record isn't the greatest. I mean, best case scenario the king gets stabbed in the arm and they manage to win.
readingMnemonic: This squad is led by Han (はん) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die.

meaningMnemonic: You’re so hungry that you eat a table so you won’t starve. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive.
additionalM:
Hints
You don’t want to starve, do you? Feel your tummy gurgle in pain. You gotta eat this table. Taste the dry wood taste on your tongue as you eat the table and get splinters in your tongue and gums.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine eating every key. Taste the cold metal on your tongue. After you swallow each key, you hear it clink against the other keys already in your tummy. Clink!
readingMnemonic: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might starve so you decide to eat every key (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve.

meaningMnemonic: If you have nothing to eat but your ego, you'll starve. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people.
additionalM:
Hints
You have to check your ego at the door, because you'll definitely starve otherwise.
additionalR:
Hints
Now your starved body has been moved to the top of a castle, where you scare away people and birds with your loud grumbling stomach and scary face.
readingMnemonic: You starve (thanks ego) and turn into a gargoyle (が). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position.

meaningMnemonic: You drive your scooter off this cliff, holding your cross tight to your chest, at a swift speed.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine swiftly shooting off the side of the cliff on your scooter, holding the cross for dear life.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're swiftly shooting through the sky as your jeans flutter down toward the ground behind you. You also feel a swift breeze on all of your downstairs bits now.
readingMnemonic: Because you had such a swift take off, you didn't notice that your jeans (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now.

meaningMnemonic: There's power, power, and power stacked on top of the moon, threatening to bring it down!
additionalM:
Hints
The moon actually looks like it wants to threaten you now too. It seems to have grown a big, smiling, angry mouth and it's way closer to you than you've ever seen it. All that power is radiating out of it and down towards you, threateningly.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the powerful moon, threatening to crush きょうと and all its residents. If only a small green boy could turn back time and save everyone from this powerful moon!
readingMnemonic: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to threaten the safety of きょうと. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer.

meaningMnemonic: Bite a tree's root with your fang to get an approximation on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close.
additionalM:
Hints
Once you have an approximation on the age, you'll be able to come up with an approximation on how much it's worth too.
additionalR:
Hints
The guy is trying to look at your approximation now, while calling YOU "guy" over and over, and you just want him to buy it and leave you alone!
readingMnemonic: As you're recording your approximation down,  somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey guy (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway.

meaningMnemonic: You run your fingers along the words of a  paragraph. You are learning about the law because you plan to arrest somebody.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine reading the paragraph very slowly. You find your answer. It looks like you'll be able to arrest that person...
additionalR:
Hints
Still, according to this paragraph you're running your fingers through, you can do it. You can arrest こういち.
readingMnemonic: Who do you want to arrest? You want to arrest こういち. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now.

meaningMnemonic: If someone wants to boil, you let them boil!
additionalM:
Hints
There's someone in your face yelling about how they want to boil! You yell back, "Okay, if you want to boil, just boil!"
additionalR:
Hints
Once your knee is done boiling, the person kneels down in front of you and presents it on a platter, mocking you, since you can't kneel anymore. You should pay more attention to what's going on from now on or you could find yourself in... HOT WATER. Ohohoho.
readingMnemonic: Welp, the pot is at a rolling boil and your knee (に) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway.

meaningMnemonic: If a helicopter loiters near a black hole then it's going to capsize. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to cover up a black hole so that the helicopter doesn't capsize. It's one or the other, dude. Cover or capsize. You decide.
additionalR:
Hints
Man, f**k you you, black hole. F**k you you. Making that helicopter capsize and then refusing to be covered?
readingMnemonic: You're doing your best to cover the black hole to stop the helicopter from capsizing but it's not working! “F**k you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing!

meaningMnemonic: The horse who can write a paragraph gets to be a chess piece. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a horse trying to write a paragraph about why it deserves to be a chess piece. See the horse struggle with his hooves to write out a paragraph as he neighs in nervous frustration.
additionalR:
Hints
See this horse in its coma. You feel bad that it will never be able to be a chess piece, but this is a bit dramatic.
readingMnemonic: Upon being told that he will never be a chess piece, the horse slips into a coma (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for.

meaningMnemonic: Your soul connects to five different mouths, enhancing your comprehension. You can easily comprehend what each of those souls belonging to those mouths wants and feels deep down.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being able to comprehend everything about not one, but five other people. Deep down you can feel everything they think and feel.
additionalR:
Hints
Your comprehension of Godzilla reveals so much: he's warning the Japanese people about the use of new technology and warfare and experimentation. He just wants everyone to be able to comprehend these new, seemingly incomprehensible things!
readingMnemonic: Your comprehension is the strongest with the fifth mouth, belonging to Godzilla (ご). You finally get why he wants to destroy buildings and cities.

meaningMnemonic: Your soul is going wild because you're confused. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild!
additionalM:
Hints
Think back to the last time you were confused. Remember how your soul felt? You were so confused it went wild and made you feel dumb and bad, like a wild person.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being confused about Japanese, for example. In your confusion everything seems scary and wild and your soul is utterly bewildered, but then here comes こういち. He sits with you and pats your back and tries to help you stop being so confused.
readingMnemonic: Whenever you're confused, こういち appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by こういち is the best medicine for confusion.

meaningMnemonic: Watch what you say to what appears to be a sweet tree, because that tree will 100% conspire against you.
additionalM:
Hints
Trees may look all sweet and innocent, like they aren't listening to every word you say, but it's a front! They're conspiring against you!! They'll blackmail you and take everything!!!
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as the conspiratorial tree and all it's gossiping friends are bowled over by your bowling ball. Phew. You're safe from the trees.
For now.
readingMnemonic: Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to conspire against you and take you down. Take your bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl it and all its friends down!

meaningMnemonic: On the roof there's some type of turkey bird, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a crane.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the beautiful black and white crane dancing gracefully on the roof. Now that you know what it is, you feel a little bad about calling it a turkey bird.
additionalR:
Hints
The crane keeps saying you're too rude whenever other people come close so they know what kind of person you are. Yikes, you really shouldn't have gotten on this crane's bad side.
readingMnemonic: The crane leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "Too rude (つる)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird.

meaningMnemonic: You use your fingers and a stone to begin cultivation of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in a field, using your fingers and a stone to cultivate the whole thing, by hand.
additionalR:
Hints
Now cultivation is going to involve getting all the tacks out of here, preferably with the stone and not your fingers, so they don't get stuck anymore.
readingMnemonic: Cultivation is suddenly halted because a tack (たく) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks!

meaningMnemonic: You take a lid, and aiming it at the sun you kick it into the air and eventually it begins to decline and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun.
additionalM:
Hints
As you watch the lid decline, keep in mind that the sun radical its middle line extending outside the box on both sides. This is because the sun is going supernova. Pew!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine swinging on these vines as you hear the sun explode and go supernova behind you. Swing faster! Swing faster!
readingMnemonic: As the lid begins to decline in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to swing (すい) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble.

meaningMnemonic: A commander who's big will use his size to encourage his troops.
additionalM:
Hints
"Look at me! You can be a big commander someday too!" he shouts, encouraging everyone.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the encouraged Shougun: his eyes are shining with tears, his heart is pounding, he's been encouraged to be better!
readingMnemonic: He encourages the Shougun (しょう) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami and a couple fires run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a faint remnant of what was once there.
additionalM:
Hints
You go to see if you can find any remainder of the fire + tsunami battle. You can, but it's so faint.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at your skin. It has such a faint tint.
readingMnemonic: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a faint remainder of what was, your tan (たん) is extremely faint as well.

meaningMnemonic: There’s a stone, a tree, another tree, and a coat rack. That stone and two trees will make the perfect foundation for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine making a foundation with the stone and the two trees so you’ll have a place for your coat rack. Feel the wood grain and cold stone against your skin as you move them around to form the foundation.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting on your hands and knees, rubbing a bar of soap all over the foundation you built. The soap gets into all the nooks and crannies in the wood and stone. Now if a coat falls off the coat rack onto the floor, you just add water and poof! Clean!
readingMnemonic: After you finish the foundation, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with soap (そ).

meaningMnemonic: Compare a building to some dirt and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her Highness. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture Her Highness, high up in her building. Now compare her home and life to yours, you dirt person.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture His and Her Highness coming out of their huge building and walking by you in your hay pile. "My goodness, Highness, have you ever seen such a dirty, fluffy creature?" "My no, dear, let's move quickly to remove it from our sight!"
readingMnemonic: I bet His Highness has never had to sleep in hay (へい) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness.

meaningMnemonic: In the event of a tsunami, Wolverine, your forehead, and a stool will all be immersed in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool.
additionalM:
Hints
Feel the water all around you as you become immersed in this tsunami. See Wolverine trying to swim his way to the top as you watch the stool floating about in the water.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the stool crack against your shin and feel the pain erupt through your leg. You try to scream but you’re under water so you just get a big mouthful of tsunami.
readingMnemonic: Still immersed, the stool floats over and hits you in the shin (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts.

meaningMnemonic: The few members of society without power suffer from severe inferiority complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you are one of the few without power. Feel the inferiority crushing down on you. It feels terrible and there is nothing you can do about it.
additionalR:
Hints
Let’s go, let’s go! Time’s a wastin’! I’m tired of this inferiority and want to gain some power!
readingMnemonic: Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of inferiority, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “Let’s (れつ) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!”

meaningMnemonic: This crab trap has the power of intuition. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at this crab trap and see it visibly glowing with intuition. Its powers of intuition are so strong that you can actually see it shimmering with intuition as it expertly traps all those crabs.
additionalR:
Hints
Genghis Khan probably has the strongest intuition of anyone in history. This crab trap is getting close though.
readingMnemonic: This crab trap's intuition powers were extracted from Genghis Khan (かん) himself. And as we all know by know, Genghis Khan was the absolute master of intuition, he always knew what his enemies and his allies were about to do.

meaningMnemonic: A building that has a bully will isolate itself. Building have feelings like people, you know.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a single building, isolated from the rest of the city and those mean, bully buildings that live there.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the sun rising behind an isolated building. A cock lets out a cry from the roof. It's a sad and lonely scene.
readingMnemonic: The isolated building only has one companion, and it's the cock (かく) that lives inside of it.

meaningMnemonic: In the foot capital, it's tough to be a dog because you're always getting kicked.
additionalM:
Hints
In the foot capital, you can only use your feet. So petting dogs looks a lot like kicking them.
additionalR:
Hints
People in the foot capital are very kick-happy, so you can imagine how much 毛 is in the streets.
readingMnemonic: When you kick a dog, there's an explosion of 毛 (け).

meaningMnemonic: You take a stool, another stool, and yet another stool and stack them on top of a tree to make a mulberry bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting three stools on top of a tree and watching it transform into a mulberry. The science of nature!
additionalR:
Hints
Have something you need to cure? Eat a mulberry. Taste the mulberry taste on your tongue as you become cured. Ahh, nice.
readingMnemonic: You then eat a mulberry because a mulberry will cure (くわ) any and all ailments. A mulberry is the cure-all of nature.

meaningMnemonic: You give a flag and a spoon to a nun as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine handing the nun your country’s flag. And also a spoon that is very valuable to you. Imagine getting down on one knee as you do so.
additionalR:
Hints
Feel your knee digging into the cold floor as you present your offerings to the nun. You feel slightly sad as she takes your precious belongings from you.
readingMnemonic: You’re getting down on one knee (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the nun. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved!

meaningMnemonic: The king takes his slide into his private jet and is given a pearl as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine giving this gorgeous white pearl to the king after he slides down his slide and boards the jet. See his king face light up as he sees the pretty pearl.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh. I guess the king didn't need your pearl, since he has a pearl chute to get them off his jet before takeoff. You feel silly. And you kind of want to jump into the pearl chute yourself.
readingMnemonic: The king takes the pearl and tosses it into a chute (しゅ) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls.

meaningMnemonic: Your fingers give you a good reason to pluck things. You pluck flowers out of the ground. You pluck a cat out of a tree. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine using your fingers to pluck grapes and apples and other things, maybe non-fruit things.
additionalR:
Hints
What reason could you have for wanting to pluck the fur off Chewbacca? Because you have fingers! So why not?!
readingMnemonic: Now that you have a reason to pluck things (you have fingers, after all) you decide you want to pluck all the fur off of Chewbacca (ちゅう). He is very furry, and you want to know what he looks like under there.

meaningMnemonic: On the dirt there is a lid trying to cover the number of times the dawn has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a podium. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!)
additionalM:
Hints
This kanji also just... really looks like a podium right? With a guy wearing a graduation cap, pointing toward you, in the crowd.
additionalR:
Hints
I guess that makes sense. This podium is by the dawn for the dawn.
readingMnemonic: You listen to what the podium has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the dawn (だん), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn!

meaningMnemonic: The only type of can you'll be building in prison is one made of pottery. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the first piece of pottery you ever made. Feel it in your hands. At least you've learned something new while you've been stuck in prison.
additionalR:
Hints
Selling your prison pottery in とうきょう might even help you get out faster. Yippee!
readingMnemonic: You get so good at pottery that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in とうきょう. とうきょう is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least.

meaningMnemonic: A woman sees herself (oneself) as a princess or a queen. As women should!
additionalM:
Hints
Just remember, when you're around other women (and woman-aligned peoples), it's important to treat each other like princess and queens, not just oneself.
additionalR:
Hints
All princess and queens can feel the heat coming off of the others.
readingMnemonic: All of us princesses and queens share a special heat (ひ). When we see another princess or queen that heat passes through us and we nod to one another.

meaningMnemonic: Take your greatest treasure, hold a knife nice and close to it, and prune away all the weak and dead bits.
additionalM:
Hints
All treasures need to be taken care of, no matter what they are. Prune away anything that isn't necessary.
additionalR:
Hints
You want your car to be small and sleek, not a giant truck, so you have to carefully prune it when it grows too much.
readingMnemonic: Currently, you want to prune your greatest treasure: your car (か). Your car is made of wood, and it keeps trying to grow new buds and branches, so you have to prune them off.

meaningMnemonic: You stop a spoon from moving by tying it with thread that's purple. The spoon wouldn't stop moving around, so you had to use your favorite purple thread to make it stop. It's the strongest thread you have.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine tying this spoon down with thread that's a color other than purple. Ah, the thread snaps. Darn, you better use your extra strong purple thread (the best color for strength!).
additionalR:
Hints
Oh, did you think purple things were made with dye? No no, purple is a special color. You have to find unique purple sheep to make purple thread and clothes.
readingMnemonic: You have to use all of your purple thread, and now you need more. You go into the back yard and call over your purple sheep (し).

meaningMnemonic: The mouth of that turkey is solely his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what makes this turkey’s mouth so unique. This beak is solely his. It belongs to no other. This turkey is the only turkey with a mouth like his.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hanging a U-ey on the highway. Hear your tires screech as you turn around and get off where you’re supposed to.
readingMnemonic: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a U-ey (ゆい). You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his.

meaningMnemonic: A hill knife is the most sturdy knife you can find.
additionalM:
Hints
The reason hill knives are so sturdy is because they are shaped like hills. Very wide, very thick, not so long. So, they don't break and are more sturdy.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine ごういち rolling the knife back and forth over various things to cut them. "I love my sturdy hill knife," he says.
readingMnemonic: This sturdy (but strangely shaped) knife is used by ごういち.

meaningMnemonic: If someone loiters it's correct to subjugate them.
additionalM:
Hints
You can't just let people do whatever they want. If it isn't correct to loiter here, then it IS correct to subjugate them, and force them to do what you want. You control them now. And they're gonna get it!
additionalR:
Hints
As you swing your saber around, subjugating the loiterers, and making them do as you say, you remind yourself that this is correct. And if it's correct, you have to use your saber to enforce it.
readingMnemonic: You subjugate these loiterers with your holy blue saber (せい)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing.

meaningMnemonic: With your fingers under an axe, you say a vow. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the axe hovering above your fingers. Now say the vow. But don't lie. The axe knows when you're lying.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine what it would be like to slice off your own fingers with the saber you've carried for so long. You better not break that vow.
readingMnemonic: When you finish your vow, you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of this valley is very vulgar. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine meeting the leader of Vulgar Valley. Imagine all the vulgar things he says to prove he is worthy of being the leader of Vulgar Valley. He is so very, very vulgar.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the motorcycles rev and purr as they carouse the Vulgar Valley. Hear the leader screaming vulgar things as he and his Bosozoku bike gang ride all around.
readingMnemonic: This vulgar leader leads his Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami at the gate of the king makes sure all of his plants get watered. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami.
additionalM:
Hints
Hear the tsunami crash into the gate as you see the water slosh around and make sure that all of the king’s plants get good and watered.
additionalR:
Hints
Again, watch and hear the tsunami crashing into the gate and getting the plants watered. This time, remember that the month is June and it is very hot and sticky outside. You’re sweating and very hot.
readingMnemonic: These plants are getting watered in June (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did.

meaningMnemonic: The leader, Master Splinter (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone accidentally poured ooze on him.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine someone accidentally spilling ooze on a rat, then watch the rat turn into a sentient rat martial artist.
additionalR:
Hints
However you look at it, try to make this accident be a good accident.
readingMnemonic: But really, if you do something accidentally, it's probably a good (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake!

meaningMnemonic: The construction beggar is one who begs for construction projects. He doesn't do it for money or fame, he begs for construction because he is so adept at what he does.
additionalM:
Hints
The construction beggar looks like any other beggar, which makes it even stranger that he's so adept at what he does. He really puts everything into his construction work.
additionalR:
Hints
The construction beggar is giving a presentation on why he would be the best choice for making a grand new palace for Emperor こういち. Point number one: he is the most adept at construction.
Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.
readingMnemonic: "The most adept at construction in all the land is me," says the construction beggar to emperor こういち.

meaningMnemonic: A fish in its mouth and in the other mouth is half a beggar (the head is cut off). The other half is on the ground. The animal that has fishes and beggars in its mouth, is an alligator.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine the blood  and fishes and beggars everywhere. The alligator is having a good meal tonight.
additionalR:
Hints
So long as you've ever used WaniKani, you probably know the reading of the word alligator.
readingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the わに in "Wanikani." Ever heard of it?

meaningMnemonic: Put your fingers on the bed, grasp the sheets and bundle them up. Now you can do the laundry!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine pressing your fingers into the bed, grasping tightly and ripping the sheets free. Then you bundle them up into your arms so you can stuff them into the washing machine.
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you grasp your bedsheets yell "Ha!" as you yank them off. Now chuckle a bit, ha ha ha, as you bundle them up into a ball. You can't beat me, bedsheets.
readingMnemonic: In between grasping and bundle-ing, you shout HA (は)! That's when the sheets come off the bed.

meaningMnemonic: A horse that is fat is a burdensome animal.
additionalM:
Hints
A fat horse. So burdensome. Not to mention the burden on the horse on top of the fatness.
additionalR:
Hints
Go visit your dad the burdensome horse because you have to visit your dad. It's weird because you're a human and he's a horse.
readingMnemonic: But you have to be nice to the burdensome horse because this horse is your dad (だ).

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami is the same as a cave. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave!
additionalM:
Hints
Also, imagine a tsunami hitting a cave, becoming the same as the cave (since a cave will shape it).
additionalR:
Hints
Also note that the 同 part of this kanji gives away the reading as well. 同 and 洞 have the same readings!
readingMnemonic: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a doughnut (どう).

meaningMnemonic: The leader all in white is the chief. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all the leaders standing around, then the chief person standing there all in white.
additionalR:
Hints
You'll learn more about which reading to use when the vocabulary roll around. In the meantime, try to remember both of them the best you can!
readingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too.

meaningMnemonic: Under a canopy, someone thinking with a brush in their mouth has a sudden thought, and uses the brush to write the word "China". Thus, China was born.
additionalM:
Hints
All of a sudden China existed! Pretty crazy, right?
additionalR:
Hints
Oh my gosh, can you imagine how mad China will be when you tell them they were invented in とうきょう? Maybe you shouldn't tell anyone this story. Just keep it between you and me, kay?
readingMnemonic: Believe it or not, this sudden invention of China happened in とうきょう. Well, it wasn't とうきょう yet. And it was a traveling Chinese person who did it. But you know legends, they're just all over the place.

meaningMnemonic: You want to write a chapter about hair in your new book so you have to make sure it's really clear. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you file a patent on a chapter? It's not very clear, but what is clear is how great your writing is.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun angrily holding what is clearly your patent and shouting in your face.
readingMnemonic: Your clear writing got the attention of the Shougun (しょう) and now he's at your door once again, but this time he's angrier than usual. Apparently he was going to steal your clear explanations but since you've patented it, he can't.

meaningMnemonic: Watch what you say to the next mouth over, because they hired you to consult them.
additionalM:
Hints
The person with the next mouth in the room is waiting for you to open yours to consult them. He'll do whatever you say.
additionalR:
Hints
He was asking for love advice, so I guess you consulted that he give a sheep to the person he likes? Uh oh. Remind me never to consult with you when I'm feeling unsure about things.
readingMnemonic: You panic, and consult the man into buying a sheep (し).

meaningMnemonic: The Yoga King presides over all courts: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture him sitting above you in the judge's chair in court. He's about to make his judgement.
additionalR:
Hints
"I hereby sentence you to..." *ploop* "Ooh, this is really good. I hereby sentence..." *ploop* "Wow, are these tater tots? Court dismissed."
readingMnemonic: The court of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing tater (てい) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth.

meaningMnemonic: This is an animal with an angled sword claw that's filled with cow meat but looks like an insect. What kind of animal is that? It's a crab.
additionalM:
Hints
If you think about the different parts you can see why this is a crab. A delicious, delicious crab.
additionalR:
Hints
If you've used WaniKani before, you probably know this reading, hopefully. All praise the great allicrab!
readingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the かに in WaniKani.

meaningMnemonic: The sun hits this and breaks into three suns. What can split the sun in three directions? A crystal!
additionalM:
Hints
Crystals take light and refract it around into many directions. That's why there are three suns in this kanji.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the Shougun laying in his bed of crystals. He still has his really serious, angry face though. Even as he rubs the crystals to his face, he's glowering.
readingMnemonic: Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these crystals? That would be the Shougun (しょう).

meaningMnemonic: A woman is making a dirt cage in the sun. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt dam. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the woman working tirelessly in the hot sun, moving and shaping the dirt around this river into a dam to make a pond.
additionalR:
Hints
If you wanna be sexy maybe you should build a dam too.
readingMnemonic: Something about the woman working hard to build this dam makes her super sexy (せき) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows.

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami hits your helicopter while you are jackhammering, it will drift out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your helicopter as it drifts out to sea with the tsunami.
additionalR:
Hints
"Heyoooo stop drifting awaaaay!!"
readingMnemonic: As it drifts away you shout, "Heyooo! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits a roof and then corrects itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an eddy.
additionalM:
Hints
An eddy requires water to change direction and then twirl around, and when the tsunami hits the roof, that's exactly what it does.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine them singing this, emphasizing the "you do" part of the song as they watch the eddy being formed.
readingMnemonic: There is a person trying to create an eddy with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how you do (よど) it."

meaningMnemonic: The correct way to block the sun with dirt is with an embankment. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine an embankment made of dirt, in the correct place, blocking the sun from your eyes.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture an embankment made of dirt and tater tots. Not like, tater tots just thrown in the embankment, you probably see those all the time. But dirt AND tater tots in the embankment itself.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, building a correct embankment doesn't just take dirt, but tater (てい) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high.

meaningMnemonic: You walk out on a cliff, where you find in the ground a mouth poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the empress of these lands!"
additionalM:
Hints
She was buried in the cliff down to her mouth so nobody would find her! You pull her out of the ground and soon what was just a mouth becomes a whole empress!
additionalR:
Hints
It's only natural the empress would want to see her emperor. And right now, the emperor of these lands is Emperor こういち.
readingMnemonic: When you finish unburying the empress, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor こういち."

meaningMnemonic: Turn a sickness into a weapon and it becomes an epidemic. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if countries decided to make sick weapons that would spread epidemics like this all over part of the world. Let's hope they don't...
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a single 駅 on a map, bright red. Now watch the red spread to all of the other 駅 on the map, dyeing them red and spreading the epidemic all over your country.
readingMnemonic: These epidemics spread by 駅 (えき). Each train takes the sickness and shoots off in a different direction, spreading it further.

meaningMnemonic: You have a numbered feather. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to flip and flip over and over.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself doing flips with this feather on your head. Flip flip flip.
additionalR:
Hints
Or, maybe you get so good that you write a 本 (ほん) about doing a flip. Wow, you're good!
readingMnemonic: You're pretty good at your flip technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and hone (ほん) your skills and get better.

meaningMnemonic: A tree can be a tree, but it can also be a psychopath. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to gloom.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all the mood swings of this tree. Psychopath tree! Also very gloomy sometimes.
additionalR:
Hints
Sing along with the moody tree. Gloom to dubstep. Such a big change.
readingMnemonic: Then the tree switches from gloom to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. Uts (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬.

meaningMnemonic: There is a tsunami coming up over a cliff made of dirt. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the horizon.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the tsunami breaking over the cliff on the horizon. It would be beautiful if it wasn't so frightening.
additionalR:
Hints
You wonder who that guy was. You wonder why he was there. You wonder if he's still alive out there, past the horizon.
readingMnemonic: You squint into the horizon and see something else. There's some guy (がい) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone.

meaningMnemonic: A gold name on this piece of wood is the inscription that shows the artist's signature.
additionalM:
Hints
This inscription refers to a signature or something similar. This is an artisan's signature in the form of an inscription.
additionalR:
Hints
If you need to review 名 go ahead and do that. It will help you to remember this kanji.
readingMnemonic: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names めい.

meaningMnemonic: The leader cat pirate is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate to look up to.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this majestic cat pirate leader of leaders. Feel in your heart that you look up to this cat pirate, truly.
additionalR:
Hints
Of course, the gyoza is filled with fish, because we're talking about cat pirates, here.
readingMnemonic: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you look up to) its favorite food: gyoza (ぎょう).

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami crashes into the sun, which is then caught in a net tied to a stool! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, this is from that pirate manga you're always reading!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine reading this issue of your favorite stretchy pirate boy manga, Lumpy uses his arms as a net, his legs tied to a stool, and traps the sun in a net right as the tsunami hits. Gee what kind of crazy trouble is he getting into this time?!
additionalR:
Hints
You already know all about manga and now you can read them too. Look how far you've come. Wow, what a journey. And you're almost at the end. Gosh, I'm just so proud of you, kiddo.
readingMnemonic: Manga starts with man (まん)!

meaningMnemonic: A bamboo tsunami's specialty is to crush everything in front of it, smash down, and turn into multiple record books.
additionalM:
Hints
The bamboo flattens as it hits the ground then turns into papers. The papers combine to become record books that show what happened here, this day.
additionalR:
Hints
Bamboo can also become bo staffs too, if they don't turn into record books.
readingMnemonic: A record book is a book (ぼ), when it comes down to it.

meaningMnemonic: The restaurant radical and the restaurant kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine going to a restaurant and seeing a menu of all different types and styles of tater tots and nothing else. Even the drinks are tater tot based. Mmm mm.
readingMnemonic: This restaurant only serves tater (てい) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No.

meaningMnemonic: What you say on the street needs to be revised. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again.
additionalM:
Hints
Think about all the stupid things you said on the streets today. Do you want those exact phrases, mistakes, and mouth sounds following you around forever? Revise it before you write it down!
additionalR:
Hints
"Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you banana."
Well that's bad. Better revise this so it rhymes.
"Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you want."
Nope, still bad. Revise!
"Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you clam."
Yes. It's gold.
