readingMnemonic: You want to revise the song you wrote about tater (てい) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising.

meaningMnemonic: A samurai who can fight with icicles on him is more robust than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body?
additionalM:
Hints
Picture samurai standing in a line. One, two, three... woah. You look up. This guy has icicles growing off him and he's the size of a bus. Now that's a robust samurai.
additionalR:
Hints
Physical robustness is just a reflection of the strength of your soul!
readingMnemonic: You may think it's just his robust body, but it's actually the samurai's robust soul (そう) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles.

meaningMnemonic: There are nine cars all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a rut.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the cars spinning out in the rut. Spin spin spin. The rut gets bigger. Nine is too many cars.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine turning the thrusters key, then feeling the car lift off the ground. You'll finally get out of this rut!
readingMnemonic: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second key (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button.

meaningMnemonic: A big turkey in the rice paddy is getting all stirred up. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?
additionalM:
Hints
He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
additionalR:
Hints
Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.
readingMnemonic: While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん).

meaningMnemonic: At the top of the mountain is a signpost to tell you you've reached the summit. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs.
additionalM:
Hints
If that signpost wasn't there how would you know you reached the summit? Like, if you were on top of Everest and there was a bad storm... you'd just topple off the other side. Those summit signposts are important!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your beautiful summit home. You know, George Washington had one of these too. So. That's cool, I guess.
readingMnemonic: At the summit, you decide to build your new home (ほう). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer.

meaningMnemonic: There's a cross in the dirt and the dirt is surrounded by flowers and shells from shellfish. This is a tomb. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lay under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously.
additionalM:
Hints
Can you picture this big dirt tomb, with flowers and shellfish decorating it and a cross right on top?
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you see a tomb think about how much fun that person had while they were alive. This tomb is motivating you to try and have as much fun as you can while you can!
readingMnemonic: This may be a tomb, but it feels really fun (ふん). It is decorated, after all. This tomb isn't a sad place, it's a fun place to remember the people you loved.

meaningMnemonic: With your fingers you put some weapons in a boat for transport. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine loading a bunch of weapons into a boat and sailing off to transport them somewhere else.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself as a cool smuggler, transporting stolen... I mean... totally legitimate weapons from one place to another. Just like Han Solo!
readingMnemonic: Hey! You're transporting weapons just like Han (はん) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport.

meaningMnemonic: A fang on a building shows that it's wicked. Something wicked probably lives in the building too.
additionalM:
Hints
Not like, wicked cool, but like wicked evil. I see you, New Englanders.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being chased around the outside of this wicked fanged building as the wicked fanged jaguar tries to eat you. Ahhh!
readingMnemonic: You peek inside the wicked building and a wicked jaguar (じゃ) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you!

meaningMnemonic: We must stop the moon. That, at least, we can come to an agreement on.
additionalM:
Hints
There are a group of people pointing at pictures of the moon coming closer to earth. They are the world's leaders, and although they don't get along normally, this new attack from the moon has united them in agreement: we must stop the moon.
additionalR:
Hints
The world has united against the moon, and they have made Emperor こういち their temporary leader.
readingMnemonic: "We have agreement," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have agreement on who we will follow, Emperor こういち.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to have a tsunami at your wedding, you need to make sure you have it at the bay. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the tsunami coming towards your beautiful wedding as you stand by the bay. It's not safe, but it's memorable!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine throwing buckets of uranium into the bay. It only burns your hands a little. And now they glow green, just like the bay does!
readingMnemonic: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the bay in the first place? By throwing a bunch of uranium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.

meaningMnemonic: Your fingers have husband horns. They are there right between each of your fingers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine little husband horns (the horns your husband has) between all your fingers. Emphasis on _between_.
additionalR:
Hints
Husband, between. Between, husband.
readingMnemonic: What is between your fingers? Your husband (はさ) horns.

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami hits a dollar the water will instantly start to boil!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing in front of an incoming tsunami. Suddenly in the distance you see someone throwing dollar bills into it and it starts to boil. Ahh!
additionalR:
Hints
Feel your poor little foots burn in the boiling water. You really want to know who that jerk was that threw dollars into the tsunami to make it boil!
readingMnemonic: The boiling water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your foots (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots.

meaningMnemonic: A lantern with horns that can hold ten thousand drops of water is sitting on the ground. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's a bottle. It's got horns, and a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle with water inside of it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this horned bottle sitting on the ground. You don't know who left it here or why, but it's here and the weirdest looking bottle you've ever seen.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine picking up this weird bottle with your bare hands and putting it in a trash bin. You did your good deed for today! Yay!
readingMnemonic: Even though you're not the one who left this bottle here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash bin (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know.

meaningMnemonic: The call radical and the call kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean eat, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?!
additionalM:
Hints
Call your mom or dad and ask them to go out to eat with you right now.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting a call from the Shougun himself. He's come to your house before, but he's never asked you to eat with him. This is huge!
readingMnemonic: You are called to come eat by the Shougun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone.

meaningMnemonic: You try to put your toe inside a shellfish, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of chastity.
additionalM:
Hints
"No, I won't open up until I meet the toe I will marry," it says to you.
additionalR:
Hints
You give the shellfish a tater tot, and it breaks its vow of chastity, opening up for your toe. You look the other way, but you can hear the sounds of passion below.
readingMnemonic: "Chastity is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a tater (てい) tot, I'll change my mind."

meaningMnemonic: There is a special type of meditation where you put a lid on your mouth and touch your forehead down to your legs. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely clear. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this pose, imagine everything becoming clear. Clear your mind. Clear your head.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the row boat on the clear pond in your mind. Watch the clear water flow over the row boat's oars.
readingMnemonic: Your mind is as clear as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a row (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.

meaningMnemonic: The spirits of the two trees you destroyed with your jackhammer live on in the collar you made out of them.
additionalM:
Hints
You took the shredding tree bits and carefully molded them into a nice collar to go with all of your shirts. But now it's haunted.
additionalR:
Hints
Whenever you put on your collar you hear a constant stream of, "Eric, pssst, hey Eric, hey!" and you just have to pretend it isn't happening.
readingMnemonic: The collar keeps whispering, "Eric (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird.

meaningMnemonic: So my building has a big splinter, right in the corner. So what?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a huge splinter coming out of the corner of the building. It's in a really dangerous spot, but the owner doesn't seem so worried about it.
additionalR:
Hints
Actually, please don't sue me. I'll fix the splinter coming out of the corner of my building.
readingMnemonic: That corner is dangerous, but what are you going to do, sue me (すみ)?

meaningMnemonic: The buddy building is in the next county. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at a map of your county and the surrounding ones. All of the buildings in the counties next to yours are buddy buildings!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine taking out a gun and shooting in a random direction. When you find where the bullet landed, you know that's the county line. Though if it gets stuck in a building or a person it doesn't count. You'll have to try again.
readingMnemonic: Your county is everything you can reach when shooting a gun (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county.

meaningMnemonic: Put syrup too close to fire and it will dry up. Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine putting some syrup over a fire and watching it dry up. Watch as the sides slowly bubble and harden and lose what makes syrup so good in the first place.
additionalR:
Hints
Go back to imagining a fire drying up some syrup and watch as a tiny little syrup soul cries and is released into the air. Oh no!
readingMnemonic: If you dry up syrup like this, you're removing its soul (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it.

meaningMnemonic: Kill a shrimp with a sickle and you'll need a really good explanation for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?
additionalM:
Hints
Try to come with an explanation for picking up a sickle and cutting the head off a shrimp with it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Shaq popping into your head as you struggle to come up with an explanation for me. Picture Shaq's face. This is payback for Shaq Fu, you think, as you finalize the rest of the explanation in your mind.
readingMnemonic: In your explanation you blame everything on Shaq (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.

meaningMnemonic: If you eat both the moon and the sun with a spoon you'll get fat. Maybe if you only ate one you could get away with it, but you wanted both and now you're pretty fat.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself digging your spoon into the moon, then into the sun, and gulping them both down. Watch your stomach swell with the sun and moon fats. No going back now, gotta finish.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh nooo you've turned into a fat sheep! You're actually pretty adorable and round and fluffy, but you liked being a human!
readingMnemonic: Once you're nice and fat, you look in the mirror to admire your new girth. But that's not you... it's a sheep (し)!

meaningMnemonic: The leader of Korea is destined for greatness.
additionalM:
Hints
I mean, they're the leader of Korea already, right? So they have to have a decent chunk of greatness in them already to get that far.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the greatness of the scene before you: the leader of Korea, a great eagle overhead, it's so great!!
readingMnemonic: The greatness radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great eagle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry.

meaningMnemonic: Your car is dry because you kept it under the eaves of your house.
additionalM:
Hints
One eave, one house. Two eaves, two houses.
additionalR:
Hints
Ken hops down and explains that he's been hired to count all the houses in his lord's domain just because his name is the same as the counter for houses. It isn't really fair, he complains to you, as you try to sneak by and lock him out of your house.
readingMnemonic: On top of the eaves of your house Ken (けん) the samurai is counting houses too.

meaningMnemonic: You put flowers on your scooter and your car. The flowers you put on them are lotus flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine placing lotuses on top of your scooter and car. They are the right kind of flowers for these vehicles.
additionalR:
Hints
You always put a lotus on top of your rental cars and scooters. Come up with a personal reason why you do this.
readingMnemonic: You're putting a lotus on both your scooter and car because they are rentals (れん).

meaningMnemonic: A person with horns has you on the ground and lets loose two poops over your heart. "Mercy! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself saying "mercy" over an over as this horned guy has you on the ground and keeps pooping over your heart.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself saying mercy and seeing Jesus appearing just in time to save the day. The word "mercy" must be his bat signal. Jesus signal? Sure.
readingMnemonic: As you shout "Mercy!" one more time, suddenly Jesus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.

meaningMnemonic: The dirt on the forehead of a pig makes a small mound. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine that you're the pig. How big can you make your forehead dirt mound?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a pig with a mound of dirt the size of two cars leisurely stomping around on a farm.
readingMnemonic: The pig's forehead dirt mound keeps getting bigger until it's the size of two cars (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over.

meaningMnemonic: The mysterious radical and the mysterious kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Who's the mysterious man who's always reciting poetry? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man who gets all the ladies? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man crying over there because someone turned him down? G... Genji...
readingMnemonic: There is no one more mysterious than Genji (げん). He's tall, dark, handsome, and most of all... 〜mysterious〜!

meaningMnemonic: When the moon faces the right direction, everyone on earth becomes obese. The pull of the moon moves all the water on earth as well as inside us, so when it faces the right way, we all get super fat.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the moon turning to face a different direction. Feel your body start to become really obese. You get huge and round just like the moon.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself, as obese and round as a bowling ball, rolling faster and faster down hills. Other people are rolling around you too. You're all screaming. You want the moon to face the other direction so it will stop. You don't like being a human bowling ball!
readingMnemonic: You look around and everyone is obese like you. You try to reach out to them, but you roll over like a big bowling (ぼう) ball. The person next to you does too. Soon you're all rolling around like helpless, obese bowling balls.

meaningMnemonic: You have a plow and a (water) well. These are the two things you need in order to plow.
additionalM:
Hints
You'd think you'd only need a plow, but you also need water if you're going to plow a field, otherwise what's the point?
additionalR:
Hints
Thousands and thousands of こういちs, set free unto the world to do all our plowing work.
readingMnemonic: plowing all the fields are こういちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use.

meaningMnemonic: Everyone knows that when a woman plays football she becomes a princess. Thats how princesses are made.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the awesome princess, kicking butt and taking names, out on the football field.
additionalR:
Hints
Make sure you know both princess words and you'll know their readings too.
readingMnemonic: Remember the word 姫? It means princess too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too.

meaningMnemonic: Your clan is breaking ground and building your new residence. You're all working together to make you a new home!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your clan, working together, to build a new residence for you on their land.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine living in a tater tot residence. Whenever you're hungry, you just lean over to the wall and munch.
readingMnemonic: Your new residence is complete! You step closer and the smell of tater (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan!

meaningMnemonic: You wake up in prison and there is a big mouth full of legs coming really, really close to your own mouth so you scream! Scream because this is terrifying. Scream because it's all you can think to do.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a prison where horrible mouth leg creatures are trying to get in your mouth. You don't want to scream because they might get in there, but you can't help it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Genghis Khan doing something to make you scream. What is it? What could Genghis Khan do that's worse than what's already happening to you?
readingMnemonic: You scream and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis Khan (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream.

meaningMnemonic: Flowers that grow in a rice paddy only live to be seedlings. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the seedlings growing among the rice plants. Once they bloom they'll be picked, so let's hope they stay small as long as they can.
additionalR:
Hints
Listen to the little seedlings say myou over and over. Too bad the farmers can tell they aren't rice plants.
readingMnemonic: The seedlings try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as myou (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.

meaningMnemonic: A turkey sitting on a stool is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal ship counter is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself counting ships by pointing your finger from one turkey propped up on a stool to the next. You'll be the best ship counter in the world at this rate!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself, a sexy ship counter. Sexily counting ships. You go guy/girl/non binary person! So sexy!
readingMnemonic: Once you become the best ship counter in the world everyone will think you are super sexy (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.

meaningMnemonic: If you look in a tiger's stomach you'll find a bunch of skin. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself opening a tigers mouth and looking all the way down into its stomach and seeing a bunch of skin. Why would you imagine that? Eww.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a fool trying to pull skin out of a tiger's stomach. You can imagine them getting their skin added to the pile too if you want.
readingMnemonic: The only person who would try to take skin from a tiger's stomach is a fool (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.

meaningMnemonic: A car that's lacking is really soft. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a soft car lacking what it needs to drive down the road. It's so soft it just flops down and won't move.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture trying to drive this soft naan car. It probably just sinks into the ground and then gets eaten by wild animals (and me).
readingMnemonic: This car is probably so soft because it's made entirely of naan (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).

meaningMnemonic: If you mix a bunch of buildings together, you have yourself a suburb.
additionalM:
Hints
Isn't that all a suburb is? Just a mix of a variety of buildings in one area?
additionalR:
Hints
"That suburb life will encourage more people to study kanji," Emperor こういち continues.
readingMnemonic: "Suburbs are what we need!" says Emperor こういち.

meaningMnemonic: Take the street all the way to that geoduck, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the summit. You humbly present the road to the geoduck and bow before it.
additionalM:
Hints
There is a giant geoduck at the summit of the mountain, and the street will lead you right there. Imagine the grueling climb up the mountain to the summit. Feel it in your legs, and keep looking at that tall, tall geoduck. Now imagine kneeling those same aching legs humbly to the street below the geoduck.
additionalR:
Hints
Anytime you use the street, you're in Mrs. Chou's territory. After detecting you were using her street to reach the geoduck, she started coming after you. Remember, wherever there's a street (radical), Mrs. Chou is not far behind.
readingMnemonic: You are at the top, the summit of everything! You humbly survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she looks angry.

meaningMnemonic: You need to throw your two wolverines and your turkey into the oncoming tsunami if you want to wash them at the same time. It's the only way you can get them clean at once without the wolverines fighting over the turkey and somebody getting hurt. The tsunami is big enough to wash them all before anything bad happens.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the tsunami coming toward you. Two wolverines in one hand and a turkey in the other. You're gonna wash them so good they'll never get dirty again.
additionalR:
Hints
If you want to wash your animals make sure to have your special tack ready. The tsunami will recede pretty fast so get it out!
readingMnemonic: Once they're nice and washed you need to subdue them by poking each of them with a tack (たく). The tack has special sleeping medicine on it, so once they're nice and clean you can put them back in their cages without them trying to eat each other.

meaningMnemonic: If you put two mustaches on either side of a tsunami it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes as whirlpool. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the tsunami spinning in a circle, trying not to hit the mustaches until it spins itself into a giant whirlpool.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture my car getting sucked into the whirlpool. Picture me crying as my car disappears into it forever.
readingMnemonic: The whirlpool is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my car (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!

meaningMnemonic: If you have an ear for the public's heart, you must be very wise. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well.
additionalM:
Hints
Close your eyes and open your ears. Feel all of the wise things fill you.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your wise soul, living inside your body. Somehow it just seems to know what the public really wants. It's like your soul is connected to their souls, granting you this wisdom.
readingMnemonic: All of these wise things are stored in your soul (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live.

meaningMnemonic: When a tree grows old, it will wither.
additionalM:
Hints
Old trees' roots and leaves grow inefficient, and they can't get enough nutrients. It's only natural for them to wither up a little bit.
additionalR:
Hints
It gave the 子 its shade, its sap, and eventually its body to build a house. What an awful child, and what a generic giving tree.
readingMnemonic: This withered tree's best friend is a human 子 (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree.

meaningMnemonic: When a spirit lives in a sheep it becomes the most auspicious creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this auspicious spirit sheep. Blessing the children with its fluffy hooves.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun telling the world that they must fly spirit sheep flags on this day forever, because of how auspicious it is.
readingMnemonic: The spirit sheep is so auspicious that the Shougun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared.

meaningMnemonic: I hope all you're doing in the bathtub is taking a bath. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself taking a bath in your bathtub. Relaxing!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being stuck on the road all day for a week. Imagine how good a bath will feel when you finally get home. Nice and hot and relaxing. Mmmm...
readingMnemonic: When do you miss taking a bath the most? When you're on the road (ろ). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath.

meaningMnemonic: The leader of the library thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very biased person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine showing the leader your favorite book. "That's not a book in MY library," he says, and throws it in the trash. That's so biased! He didn't even give it a shot!
additionalR:
Hints
"This is such biased crap," you say, as you finish reading the title of a book called "Hens are better than all other birds." Screw this leader guy and his books.
readingMnemonic: You decide to give in to his biased recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about hens (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird.

meaningMnemonic: If you look at flowers the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the next thing you notice are the briars. You never see thorns first, only after you've looked at the flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what you see next after looking at the pretty flowers. The briars are what you see next. Spiky and sharp. It would have been nice if you had seen them first.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine seeing the briars and yelling out "Ba RI ars!" as you prick your finger on one.
readingMnemonic: When you see the briars you can't help but yell, Eee! Ba riars! (いばら)! You pause funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch!

meaningMnemonic: This building was a former prison until the cave in. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the cave in in your mind. Can you see all the little prisoners and guards being squished as the building tumbles down around them? Oh no!
additionalR:
Hints
Genghis Khan is all about being smart and using better tactics. In this case, why fight a bunch of guards and prisoners when you can just cause a cave in and win immediately? The ol' Khan cave in, a classic war maneuver.
readingMnemonic: You keep picturing the cave in and you see Genghis Khan (かん) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next!

meaningMnemonic: The famous gold triceratops shellfish is good for only one thing, and that's being made into chains. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture these little gold triceratops shellfish linked together by their horns in a chain around your neck. Feel them hanging there. Sparkly and cold.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the saw in your hands, sawing back and forth on the gold chain around your neck. Maybe this isn't the best fashion accessory if you have to use a saw to get it off.
readingMnemonic: However, the only way to break the chain is to saw (さ) it open. Once the triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw.

meaningMnemonic: You give a bunch of shellfish to a clown as compensation. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the shellfish in your hands. Imagine handing them over to the clown as compensation for the unspeakable acts you had him do for you.
additionalR:
Hints
All you have to do is give him the right amount of compensation and you'll hear his sweet "bye, bye." Then you never have to see him again.
readingMnemonic: Once the clown has been properly compensated, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "Bye (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye."

meaningMnemonic: Your soul is like the ground or the dawn. It is constant, never changing.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of some other things your soul is like, but always make sure you come back to one word: constant.
additionalR:
Hints
A constant rule from Emperor こういち means constant kanji learning and constant WaniKani reviews. They will always be constant!
readingMnemonic: Also constant is the Emperor こういち, who will surely rule for a thousand more years!

meaningMnemonic: You're sewing something with thread but you and your creation get frostbite while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty design. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding your creation in your frostbitten hands as the snowflake design starts to appear. The design gets more and more complicated the longer you watch, twisting this way and that, like it's dancing in front of your eyes.
additionalR:
Hints
Try to picture this ring design in your head. It's something no human hands could have made, frostbitten or otherwise.
readingMnemonic: As you watch the snowflake design form you realize they're moving in a ring (りん) pattern. Rings inside bigger rings, linked with smaller rings.

meaningMnemonic: If you figure out how to use a tsunami as a weapon, everyone is going to die. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture everyone in the world being swept away in a tsunami to die. This is what happens when you try to use nature as a weapon.
additionalR:
Hints
You don't want to die, do you? Get to the boats!
readingMnemonic: The only way to maybe not die is to find boats (ぼつ). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning.

meaningMnemonic: Your fingers grasp this lid and when you raise it you see a poop turkey (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you embrace the turkey.
additionalM:
Hints
Someone was obviously going to cook this poop turkey in a pot, and if you hadn't looked under this lid it surely would have died. Now as you embrace it you can hear the turkey weeping softly.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine embracing the turkey as it covers you in yogurt poo. You hope it's yogurt at least. You aren't gonna taste it to find out. Maybe. Okay you might taste it a little.
readingMnemonic: As you embrace the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping yogurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it!

meaningMnemonic: When you ride your scooter on the ground listening to music under the sun, you're bound to encounter a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to meet you.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of the people you encounter as you ride your scooter, spreading your music around town.
additionalR:
Hints
"We love your music, look at our souls!" Uh oh, this is turning into some kind of horror movie. You better scoot a bit faster or you might meet an unfortunate fate.
readingMnemonic: Everyone you encounter wants to bare their soul (そう) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them.

meaningMnemonic: From your mouth comes a cross, some flowers, and shellfish. It all erupts from your mouth!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine these three things coming out of your mouth not one at a time, but all together like an eruption. Perhaps you're laying on your back, and they burst out of your mouth.
additionalR:
Hints
It's really inconvenient that things erupt from your mouth whenever you're having fun. Makes it hard to have fun.
readingMnemonic: When do inanimate objects erupt from your mouth? Mostly when you're having fun (ふん).

meaningMnemonic: If the yakuza slide you into a jet, things are especially bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad.
additionalM:
Hints
First of all, the yakuza have you, that's bad already. But they're sliding you into their jet? That means you aren't upright, you might even be knocked out or dead. That's especially worrying, don't you think?
additionalR:
Hints
As you slide down the chute, it's especially dark. And especially scary. And especially bad! How did this happen to you?!
readingMnemonic: You're especially worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of chute (しゅ). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where!

meaningMnemonic: A leader puts their hat on the ground next to a bookshelf. This is a test in ethics.
additionalM:
Hints
People hang around the bookshelf, and the leader wants to see if anyone will steal the hat or not. That's why its a test of ethics.
additionalR:
Hints
Now we'll really see how everyone's ethics are. Will they turn in the ring to lost in found? will they ignore it? Will they steal it?
readingMnemonic: To test your ethics even more, the leader puts down a ring (りん) as well.

meaningMnemonic: The building to the east is an exhibit.
additionalM:
Hints
It's a pretty large building and you can see inside to all of the different exhibits within the main exhibit.
additionalR:
Hints
Go up to the first exhibit and look very closely at some turtle chins, then some crab chins, then some alligator chins. This is weirdly familiar.
readingMnemonic: Right now the exhibit has a bunch of chins (ちん) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit.

meaningMnemonic: If you tie a cross to a turkey you can trick everyone into thinking it's a falcon. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine tying a cross to this turkey and see it transform into an elegant falcon. Majestic.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your falcon Hayabusa and the real... ok fake.. Hayabusa running around together and kicking butt.
readingMnemonic: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there.

meaningMnemonic: What do stairs do? They take you from where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get from place to place.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself climbing stairs, picture going from room to room. From place to place. From wherever you were to wherever you want to be.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself taking those first few steps from home, knife heavy in your pocket. You can go as far from home as you want now. The knife will keep you safe.
readingMnemonic: If you're going from place to place, you should really make sure you have a knife (ない) on you for protection. If you want to make it far enough from home you should seriously consider it. Knives keep everyone safe when they're going far from home.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to have your wedding in a car you're going to need a lot of help. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all of your close friends coming to help you squeeze everything for the wedding into your car.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine calling all your friends and scheduling when you will get their help. Make sure you have your day planner ready!
readingMnemonic: You can't just ask for help on the day of the wedding, either. You have to schedule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so make sure you plan early!

meaningMnemonic: There is an animal in the grass and your horrible task is to go hunting for it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the shape of the animal in the grass, off in the distance. You can't see what kind of animal it is yet, but you know you're hunting it.
additionalR:
Hints
You wouldn't be able to go hunting in any other kind of boat—the motor would be too loud. Picture yourself in a row boat with all of your hunting gear. You need to be extra careful not to make any loud splashing sounds with the oars!
readingMnemonic: You're currently hunting in a row (りょう) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away.

meaningMnemonic: If you have spiders in your mouth, then you're going to instigate fights between people. Mostly because the spider in your mouth makes you grumpy, but also because the spider keeps telling you to be an instigator with its little mouth inside your own mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having a spider in your mouth. Imagine being angry about it and instigating fights between people because of it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the fight you and the spider instigated. The guy pointing at the saw, then pointing at his sawed off leg. Listen as the spider tells you to shake your head.
readingMnemonic: The spider in your mouth tells you to instigate a fight by sawing (さ) the other person's leg off. It even whispers where you can find a nice big saw.

meaningMnemonic: If you give a machine a heart it will get lazy. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a machine with a heart, laying on the couch, eating oil snacks, and snoozing. What a lazy machine!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the lazy machine sitting on the couch again. There are untied ties all over the floor.
readingMnemonic: The machine is so lazy it won't even wear its tie (たい) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so.

meaningMnemonic: In its soul, a narwhal that's supposed to do construction under the moon, will be too lazy to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the lazy narwhal laying on a block of ice in the moonlight. There are tools and other blocks of ice around, but he just can't seem to get up and do any construction work.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your lazy dad. Your big, lazy narwhal dad.
readingMnemonic: You can't tell the lazy narwhal he's being lazy because he's your dad (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right.

meaningMnemonic: Take a leather helicopter to the moon to prove your excellent leadership. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space!
additionalM:
Hints
Not many people have the leadership it takes to lead such a mission. Imagine what it takes to do it!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine laughing along with the crew, in awe at your own leadership skills. Ha ha ha! We didn't die!
readingMnemonic: Under your superior leadership you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely!

meaningMnemonic: Shaving the hair off a geoduck before you try to eat it is absolutely necessary. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the page in your cookbook where it says "Shaving the hair off your geoduck = Necessary!!" It's absolutely necessary that you follow that instruction!
additionalR:
Hints
What's necessary? To shave the hair off your geoduck and to wear a suit. That's not too hard. You should do it.
readingMnemonic: It is also necessary that you wear a suit (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly.

meaningMnemonic: If you take a cow's life you're turning it into an offering. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself offering the cow's life up to the god(s). It's a good thing we don't actually have to do this anymore, you think.
additionalR:
Hints
Thanks to the mercy of your saber, the offering is quick and painless. A normal saber, however, would have cut that cow to bits. Like, really just wrecked it. Good thing we didn't make you think about that, huh?
readingMnemonic: You prepare the offering with your holy blue saber (せい). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it.

meaningMnemonic: If a grain has a fault, it needs to be put back in order. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their regularity. Keeping order is a tough job!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being one of these people who maintain order by going out in the fields and inspecting every single grain, keeping the good ones and plucking off the ones with faults.
additionalR:
Hints
If there are faulty grains in there, they cheated and order was not maintained. Now you have to go through all the grains and throw out the weird ones yourself.
readingMnemonic: You can always tell if a company keeps order or if it cheats (ちつ) just by looking at the grains.

meaningMnemonic: There was once a melon child, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an orphan.
additionalM:
Hints
The "melon boy orphan," is what they called him. Imagine a melon (your favorite kind) with a face and arms and legs sticking out. He walks up to you and says "hello kind person, could you help an orphan?"
additionalR:
Hints
That's the sad thing about the melon orphan boy... he's just a child. "Hello gov, I'm just a child," he says to you.
readingMnemonic: The orphan melon boy is but a 子 (こ).

meaningMnemonic: If you point flowers in the same direction you'll be able to smell their wonderful perfume. The best way to get perfume out of flowers is to make them face the same way. Then the smell will go the same direction, making you smell great.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine aiming a bunch of flowers in the same direction towards you. The perfume coats your body. You smell great now!
additionalR:
Hints
Now when you're in your home the overwhelming smell of perfume assaults your nostrils. It's actually... really strong. Oh... oh no it's too strong, you can't breathe. And you live alone. Help! Someone!
readingMnemonic: You decide to perfume your entire home (ほう) by planting flowers all the way around it, all facing in toward it.

meaningMnemonic: Under the window, you place a shellfish, then slam the window shut to pierce its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
additionalR:
Hints
Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.
readingMnemonic: Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.

meaningMnemonic: The rice that's prepared at dawn by the village are provisions for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture everyone in the village getting all of their rice together as provisions for the army. Even the kids and old people are helping out.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the soldiers gobbling down their provisions of rice and roe in their row boats as they row away.
readingMnemonic: Once all of the provisions are ready, the soldiers show up in their row (りょう) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need roe (ろう) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too.

meaningMnemonic: If you stand in the wind it will be really quick to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up again just to be knocked over again, just as quick.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how quick the wind knocks you over when you stand up. So quick, you don't even remember being up. Try again and try to count how many seconds it takes for it to knock you down. Less than one. Now that's quick.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture how quick you sat down. Even faster than the quick wind. Nice job!
readingMnemonic: The wind was so quick to knock you down that you sat (さつ) down instead. The wind may be quick, but it can't knock you down if you've already sat yourself.

meaningMnemonic: If your soul is acting like the sun trapped in a net sitting on a stool, then people will ridicule you for your laziness. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving.
additionalM:
Hints
Your soul just doesn't want to move or do anything though... and that may look like laziness, but you can't help it. You wish your friends and family wouldn't ridicule you. You're going through enough, internally.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself reading manga and watch as the people who ridicule you and call you lazy fade away into the background. You're going to be okay.
readingMnemonic: When people ridicule you, when you can't stop the laziness, you read manga (まん). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person.

meaningMnemonic: Play your drum under the moon and your hair will swell! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell.
additionalM:
Hints
Have you been suffering from flat, boring hair? Well do I have the swelling treatment you've been looking for!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine watching your hair swell to the size of a large bowling ball. Imagine never being able to go bowling again because the comparison is too easy for people to make.
readingMnemonic: Using this method, your hair swells so much it looks like a giant bowling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits.

meaningMnemonic: Your scooter gave you a splinter, so you had to go in for treatment.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how bad a scooter splinter would be! You would need special treatment for that.
additionalR:
Hints
Not just "good," but "goooooood." Emphasize the long vowel for the long vowel in ぐう. You feel this way because when you went in for treatment, they gave you the good, good drugs. You know the ones.
readingMnemonic: After you get treatment, you feel really good (ぐう).

meaningMnemonic: If you try to say something to the Death Star, it would only admonish you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being admonished by the Death Star. It's hovering above you, giant and round, just yelling at you about everything you've ever messed up. It's really awful being yelled at. But the Death Star doing it is particularly scary and embarrassing.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine sitting in your yurt, the home you love, but you can still hear the admonishments from the Death Star in your ears. You feel... bad.
readingMnemonic: Right now you're being admonished about living in a yurt (ゆ). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!"

meaningMnemonic: How many buildings have scooters? All of them!
additionalM:
Hints
All buildings have at least one scooter. It could be out front, on the roof, in the basement. But all of them have scooters and someone who likes to ride them instead of using a car or a bike.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the sound of the scooter's tiny engine: zuwee zuwee zu zu zuwee. All of them do this, which is why you hate them.
readingMnemonic: All of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: zuwee (ずい).

meaningMnemonic: The old moon (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge barbarian floating in the sky.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine a huge barbarian (whatever that means to you) floating in the sky, looking down. Some ancient people look up and wave at the old moon barbarian.
additionalR:
Hints
"You see, my child, the old moon was not like the current moon. It was a giant barbarian in the sky, who would eat children that asked too many questions."
readingMnemonic: At least, this is the kind of story you told your 子 (こ) when they asked you where the moon came from.

meaningMnemonic: In your fingers are flowers which really suit you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you board your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're embarking on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself boarding the ship and letting the flowers slip from your fingers, into the crowd of people waving goodbye.
additionalR:
Hints
Where else would you go at this point? I mean, come on. You've made it 53 levels since you embarked on your kanji journey with us. We know you by now. You want to be in とうきょう.
readingMnemonic: You board a ship to とうきょう, bound for your new life, of course!

meaningMnemonic: You weave gold and white patterns into this towel, turning it into brocade. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine weaving this beautiful brocade fabric out of one of your old towels. Try to actually picture the gold and white patterns you want on there. If you're a crafter, actually do it!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine using your niche key to open this hidden brocade storage room. The key is gold and white and looks like brocade too!
readingMnemonic: You want to keep your brocade fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a niche key (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing.

meaningMnemonic: If you're in Japan (which is the end goal here, let's be honest) then the fish in your village are carp. You may know them as koi, too.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your village in Japan. There's a big, still pond full of bright and beautiful giant carp. You hear the village kids giggle as they feed them and their big round mouths pop out of the water.
additionalR:
Hints
Carp are koi and koi are carp. Blub blub.
readingMnemonic: A carp is called a koi (こい) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know?

meaningMnemonic: Take the moon and wrap it in a bag and it will look just like a cell. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the moon with a big bag circling it. Now look down at your biology homework on cells. They're identical!
additionalR:
Hints
AHHH CLEAN ALL OF THESE CELLS OUT OF YOUR HOME!
readingMnemonic: As you learn about cells you realize they're all over your home (ほう). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere.

meaningMnemonic: Tsunami of conflict will cleanse and purify the lands of people, homes, and culture.
additionalM:
Hints
Anything less than a tsunami of conflict would leave something behind. But this much conflict will cleanse the area of everything.
additionalR:
Hints
You thought Jourm was an ordinary, clumsy, ten foot tall farmhand. But he brought down a tsunami upon your village. And, he brought armed conflict too. This thing he calls "The cleanse" was actually something he had been planning for years. His use of a totally ordinary Viking mouth towel... his table made of foreheads... That tatami mat altar with the forehead wearing a top hat... Was he really a Viking pretending to be a simple farmhand just so he could bring his men inland to cleanse and purify your village? It's too late now. Jourm stands over your body. You are about to receive "The cleanse" too.
readingMnemonic: The cleanse of your lands was caused by Jourm (じょう). Why did the slow farmhand bring an army to the village, and why is he yelling about, "The cleanse," while destroying everything? Jourm?! Weren't we friends?

meaningMnemonic: There's a drop of bear on this towel. A true commander can notice little things like this.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a commander carefully looking over everything. They not only notice a drop of something on a towel, but they're able to identify that the drop is a small piece of liquid bear.
additionalR:
Hints
"Weeee!" says the commander.
readingMnemonic: You watch the commander in all his glory... going back and forth on a swing (すい).

meaningMnemonic: If you say something the same way they say it in the capital, everyone in the whole country will be able to comprehend what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the confused faces of the people in the countryside as you try to talk to them. Decide to say it the way it's said in the capital and see their faces light up as they comprehend what you're trying to say.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself rowing away in your new row boat as the townspeople wave goodbye. They were much nicer once they comprehended what you were asking for. Maybe you'll row your way back here someday.
readingMnemonic: Now that the townspeople finally comprehend what you were trying to say, they sell you the row (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home.

meaningMnemonic: Flowers are growing out of the ground and over your pet pig's forehead and it's causing the poor thing to live in total darkness. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being a pig with flowers hanging down off your forehead and into your eyes so that darkness was all you knew. It's very sad, actually.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine mowing the darkness away. Be careful! If you mow the pig's eyes, the darkness will last forever!
readingMnemonic: To end the darkness you mow (もう) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again.

meaningMnemonic: The sun is rising and there is a net covering someone, who's being forced to watch as dawn appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture someone tied down in a net as dawn breaks.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at Akebono looking at you as you look at dawn breaking.
readingMnemonic: The someone who saw dawn for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ Akebono Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength.

meaningMnemonic: If you get a big hair stuck in your private soul it will be a disaster! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!!
additionalM:
Hints
This disaster is ruining your life. You can't eat, sleep, all you can do is panic trying to get the hair out.
additionalR:
Hints
Santa-san has forsaken you. Your life is a wreck. This is a total disaster just because of one big hair.
readingMnemonic: This disaster is so huge that even Santa-san (さん) left his vacation in Zanzibar (ざん) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san?

meaningMnemonic: When what you're writing is as tall as the grains growing outside, you know you're done with your first draft. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine holding your draft up outside in a field of grains. You're a couple leaves short. Time to get back to the drawing board.
additionalR:
Hints
Now こういち is out there measuring your draft against the tall grain plants. You better hope it's long enough, because if it isn't, Emperor こういち's probably going to execute you.
readingMnemonic: Who asked you to write such a tall draft in the first place? Emperor こういち, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is.

meaningMnemonic: If you can find the door in winter shaped like a mouth it will enlighten you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine searching for this special door in the cold wind and snow of winter. The search for enlightenment always has something to do with suffering and searching on your own like this.
additionalR:
Hints
All you need to do to attain enlightenment is to eat this cake... out of this mouth. Eh. Maybe enlightenment isn't worth it.
readingMnemonic: The door enlightened you by opening up and revealing the cake (けい) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth."

meaningMnemonic: Press your fingers in someone's skin to expose what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable.
additionalM:
Hints
Close your eyes. Picture someone's arm. Now touch their skin with your fingers and peel it back to expose the muscles and bones underneath.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine the heat steaming out, like it's coming out of a teapot, not out of somebody's arm skin.
readingMnemonic: You expose a small hole under their skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat.

meaningMnemonic: A drunkard crosses thread across special spikes to separate the fibers. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a drunkard crossing threads onto spikes and pulling the tiny fibers free. You don't think you could do that. Maybe if you got drunk too...
additionalR:
Hints
Watch the centaur cross the fibers and separate them with his spikes. How strange.
readingMnemonic: You stare at the fibers easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a centaur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it...

meaningMnemonic: If you loiter around a surplus of anything, you need to be gentle and touch everything gently.
additionalM:
Hints
Unfortunately it's not specific as to what kind of surplus you're loitering around, so you'll need to imagine a surplus of something memorable to you. Then, just imagine loitering around there, being really gentle with everything.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Jo-Anne coming back to her surplus, then asking you if you were gentle with the goods. You were, you treated everything very gently.
readingMnemonic: You have to be gentle and handle these things gently because they belong to Jo-Anne (じょ). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine).

meaningMnemonic: Flowers that are thought to be little tents sent from heaven are hollyhocks. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a tiny yokai using a hollyhock as a tent. Aww cute!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself in a field of hollyhocks and the あおい of them match the あおい of the heavens! It's like you're standing on a giant flower filled mirror of the sky.
readingMnemonic: Hollyhocks are mostly あおい (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from.

meaningMnemonic: While the moon is out, a gladiator is riding a horse, yelling about inflation. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the gladiator riding his horse in the light of the moon yelling, "Do you have any idea how important it is to increase the average pay rate to account for inflation? All of us gladiators are going to be unable to pay the bills soon because inflation isn't being taken into account! You'll suffer too! Listen to me!"
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine if you were in this gladiator's place. In five years, you wouldn't be able to afford to eat thanks to the bosses in とうきょう refusing to adjust for inflation. Back in my day, onigiri only cost FIFteen yen!
readingMnemonic: Inflation rises the most in とうきょう, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die).

meaningMnemonic: You use your fingers to take down the old flag and install a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new one in its place.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine reaching out and grabbing onto the old flag with your fingers. Feel the dirty grime and little holes it's gotten. Now install something new!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a newly installed suit flying in the air on a pole.
readingMnemonic: You've decided to install a suit (す) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often.

meaningMnemonic: You cut the flowers off the grain with your knife. The flowers that fall off are jasmine flowers.
additionalM:
Hints
It's weird that jasmine flowers are growing out of your grain, but that's why you're cutting them off.
additionalR:
Hints
You have a farm that grows grain and reeds. Jasmine flowers are growing out of both of those things, ruining your crops! Perhaps you should become a jasmine tea farmer instead...
readingMnemonic: The jasmine is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the reeds (り)!

meaningMnemonic: The thread that goes through Korea is the latitude line splitting up North and South Korea.
additionalM:
Hints
Why thread? Back in the old days globes were sewn together with cloth and thread, so there was a literal thread dividing the Koreas!
Or you can just picture an actual, super long piece of thread going around the entire globe. That works too.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being an eagle yourself, flying around the entire globe, following the latitude line that splits Korea down the middle.
readingMnemonic: The only way you can see this latitude line is to ride an eagle (い) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view.

meaningMnemonic: The melon radical and the melon kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you remember this radical means melon and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hitting the gas pedal in your car as you head for a big melon. Watch it burst into a million pieces as your car makes contact, hurling melon bits all over your windshield. It's a melon firework!
readingMnemonic: What's the best use for a melon? Not eating it, but running over it in your car (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see.

meaningMnemonic: Tigers and wolverines have one big thing in common and it's that the government likes to oppress them. It doesn't matter if you're the animal or a mutant X-Men hybrid. The government will go out of its way to oppress you if you are one.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being a tiger or a wolverine or a tiger-wolverine and being oppressed by the government just because you're different. Imagine being stuck in a cage. Not being allowed to vote. It's awful!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being a tiger/wolverine girl and being so oppressed that you can only sit in a cage, playing with goopy Gak all day. This blows...
readingMnemonic: Tiger and wolverine people are so oppressed that the only thing they're allowed to amuse themselves with is Gak (ぎゃく). You know, that weird goo they made us play with when we were kids? Well that's not so fun when it's all you have.

meaningMnemonic: A cross carrying drunkard wants you to go to a rice paddy together so you can receive something from them.
additionalM:
Hints
You really don't want to receive whatever it is this drunkard wants to give you, and it's even sketchier that they want you to go to a rice paddy together to do it.
additionalR:
Hints
The tie looks harmless enough, but you still receive it skeptically. The drunkard is just holding up his cross and smiling at you. Hmm.
readingMnemonic: Against your better judgement, you decided to go and receive the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light tie (たい) being placed in them.

meaningMnemonic: A boat owned by a Yoga King needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a rowboat, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the Yoga King rowing a rowboat. Maybe he's using his legs. Maybe he's using his butt? You don't know. Yoga people are super flexible, he could be using anything to move this rowboat.
additionalR:
Hints
Go rent a rowboat and try eating tater tots in it. For fun, throw a bunch of them in the water and watch them float. Maybe you'll catch a fish!
readingMnemonic: As he rows the rowboat with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're tater tots (てい). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water.

meaningMnemonic: This is a boat, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks rust colored. In ancient Chinese literature, this rusty red color represented sincerity, and you'll often see this kanji take that meaning in jukugo words.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this broken, rust colored boat. It's a reddish-brown color and it's definitely missing some important pieces.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch your skin slowly change as you tan to match the rust colored boat. Feel your skin in the sun. This may not be good for your health, but it's great for fashion!
readingMnemonic: The rust colored boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and tan (たん). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match.

meaningMnemonic: The threads a criminal wears will always be scarlet. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a person wearing all scarlet all the time. Don't they give you a criminal-y vibe?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a criminal, covered in this scarlet thread, heat radiating off of him.
readingMnemonic: This scarlet color holds a lot of heat (ひ). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too.

meaningMnemonic: Put a turkey on ice and it will only get semi frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine covering a turkey in ice and every time you check it, it's only semi frozen. It doesn't matter what you do, it just refuses to freeze all the way through.
additionalR:
Hints
The lesson is to never try to freeze something in June. If you do it will only semi freeze.
readingMnemonic: Finally you realize it will only semi freeze because it's June (じゅん)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it!

meaningMnemonic: You want to have a quaint cottage wedding, so you have to go to the cottage wedding shop to get everything you need. This shop is the only place you can buy everything you need. It's not like you can make a cottage from scratch!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself walking into the cottage wedding shop. Look at all the different cottages you get to choose from. And there's wedding cake too?! This shop has everything!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine walking around the shop and then falling in love with a hoe with pretty tassels and flowers attached to it. Yes, it's only for decoration, but you're going to buy and use it during your cottage wedding.
readingMnemonic: You're browsing everything in the shop when a garden hoe (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding.

meaningMnemonic: A dirt nurse is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes soil.
additionalM:
Hints
Soil generally has more nutrients in it. It makes sense for dirt that's been nursed to become soil.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine Jourm working with soil (not dirt!). Improving it by mixing in various ingredients. The soil this year is particularly lush, for some reason...
readingMnemonic: Soil is a thing Jourm (じょう) the huge farmhand works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops.

meaningMnemonic: When a horse sees a spider it will start running at a speed no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the eyes of a horse seeing a spider and then running at top speed to get the heck away from it.
additionalR:
Hints
Soon the world will be filled with horses running at full speed all thanks to the spider increase of the 2000s! Soon we will be in the future of top speeds!
readingMnemonic: Once people realize that they can increase the speed of their horses, soon (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner.

meaningMnemonic: There's so much grain in your mouth you need to use a knife to remove it. Only when there is a surplus can you put that much grain in your mouth.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing so much grain that you can stuff your mouth so full you can't swallow or spit it out. You have to use a knife to remove it. After you get all the grain out, comment on the surplus of grain.
additionalR:
Hints
Remember how Jourm made the soil better? Perhaps this is some of that work paying off. Thanks to that and everything else, there is a great surplus.
readingMnemonic: The surplus is thanks to the hard work of folks like Jourm (じょう) the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year.

meaningMnemonic: The roof flowers see everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of tolerance.
additionalM:
Hints
These roof flowers only see because they do not judge. They accept everything. We humans can learn a thing or two about tolerance from these roof flowers.
additionalR:
Hints
You wouldn't expect it, but he actually allowed many types of cultures, religions, and peoples to exist under his reign. The Mongols had an exceptional amount of tolerance for the time.
readingMnemonic: Tolerance is one thing that Genghis Khan (かん) had a surprising amount of.

meaningMnemonic: Who goes into their yurt to boil things? All the people you've ever known. You don't boil things outside, are you crazy?
additionalM:
Hints
Wait, you're telling me all people don't do the same things? Excuse me?
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, now that I've shown you what to do, you're just like all of us.
readingMnemonic: Here, all the people I know do this, so just let me show (しょ) you how. First you go into your yurt, hey! Pay attention and watch what I'm showing you.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to wear a top hat you also have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture all the things you also need. A suit, a tie, a monocle, some shiny shoes. There's also ... something... else. What is it?
additionalR:
Hints
Think about all the things you also need when you wear a top hat. The car is probably the most important addition. Otherwise no one can see the top hat in the first place!
readingMnemonic: You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you also need a nice car (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off.

meaningMnemonic: When the sun comes up the spikes of geoducks appear.
additionalM:
Hints
The spikes don't just come out of the geoduck, they literally appear out of thin air. They didn't even exist before the sun touched them.
additionalR:
Hints
"Thank you sweet geoduck, you have taught me the way of appearing with your spikes."
readingMnemonic: You watch these spikes appear and suddenly Ken (けん)the samurai also appears next to you. "I DID IT!" he shouts, "I've learned how to appear out of thin air!"

meaningMnemonic: What does a tree make that you'd want to put in your mouth? An apricot! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the mouth sized apricots hanging down off the tree. Imagine using your own mouth to bite them down. Just don't swallow the pit!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to eat the bite sized apricot and spitting it out after the taste of anchovies from the zoo fill you up.
readingMnemonic: After you put the apricot in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the anchovies (あん) from the zoo (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore.
