meaningMnemonic: Dry an already dry tree to create a bookmark. The more you dry the tree, the flatter it becomes, making it the perfect way to mark your spot in a book without needing to fold a page or write on it.
additionalM:
Hints
To be fair, books are just dry trees in a way, but bookmarks are actually dry, dry trees that have flattened out and turned into chunks.
additionalR:
Hints
What does she owe you? Open the page to your bookmark and see she owes reeds!
readingMnemonic: What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree bookmarks on a page in your notebook that says "She owes me reeds (しおり)." Oh yeah, you had to make this bookmark in the first place because your friend took your reed bookmarks and didn't give them back.

meaningMnemonic: You see a bunch of trees lined up outside of the gate to the east and realize they look like perfect columns. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture these column trees outside the gate to the east. You end up drawing them in the columns of your graph paper because they fit so well.
additionalR:
Hints
Now draw Randy Savage in the columns on your graph paper. He just seems to fit there now.
readingMnemonic: Out of the tree columns bursts professional wrestler Randy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!"

meaningMnemonic: Your forehead is the origin for the measurement for your crown! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine someone putting a tape measure around your forehead and taking careful measurements for your crown. They better not mess up, or you'll have them put to death!
additionalR:
Hints
Why don't you go look up what Genghis Khan's crown/cap looked like. Then try to imagine how it would look atop your head.
readingMnemonic: You want your crown to be just like Genghis Khan's (かん), which was more of a cap. He's your hero though, because he ruled over the most people, so you want yours to match his measurements.

meaningMnemonic: If you announce that alcohol is illegal you're just being cruel. Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally unjust. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if your country's leader announced that there would be no more alcohol. People would be in the streets in seconds calling them cruel and unjust!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine drinking coke while complaining how unjust it is that you can't add rum to it.
readingMnemonic: After this cruel announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. Coke (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof.

meaningMnemonic: The surplus stool, please describe it.
additionalM:
Hints
You have a surplus (extra) stool, and someone wants it. But, they need to know more about it, so you describe it in great detail. Imagine yourself doing just that. Every screw and nubbin is described.
additionalR:
Hints
Jo-Anne is really excited about this stool. It's the perfect height for her (remember, she's on the shorter side to distinguish じょ from じょう). She pays attention to you describing the stool while sitting on it and spinning around. Have her ask for you to describe it more.
readingMnemonic: You describe the features of the stool to Jo-Anne (じょ).

meaningMnemonic: Jump on a scooter to excuse yourself from answering a question and you've successfully deviated from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to elude them pretty well.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine excusing yourself by scooting away on a scooter. If they want to get your answer, they'll have to chase you.
additionalR:
Hints
Welp, it's too late to turn back now. You've already deviated pretty far, and you're not even sure where you are now. You were too busy trying to elude that person that you didn't look where your scooter was taking you.
readingMnemonic: You deviate from the plan a little too well, and as you're scooting, what you've done eats (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them...

meaningMnemonic: You use thread and writing to sew our family crest. You've been sewing your family crest since you were a kid, you could do it today with your eyes closed.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the thread slowing forming the writing that makes up your family crest. You're making a scarf with your crest on it. It's like a wizarding school house symbol.
additionalR:
Hints
What kind of monster is on your family crest? Picture it in your mind right now. Now tweet to us @wanikaniapp because I really want to know what you came up with!!
readingMnemonic: Your family crest is of a monster! And the writing says "Our Family Monster."

meaningMnemonic: You see a building with a lip ring and it's just so cute you have to flatter it. "That lip ring looks wonderful on you, Buildingさん," you say.
additionalM:
Hints
Flattering buildings is just as nice as flattering people, as long as they're okay with it.
additionalR:
Hints
The "ah" the building made was actually quite loud, and since you've never heard a building speak before, it scared you pretty bad. But at least you know the building was flattered by your compliment (I think.)
readingMnemonic: The building is flattered and you hear it shout, "Ah (あ)!" and blush. The entire building turns red.

meaningMnemonic: If you give Splinter your heart you'll feel pretty foolish afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu!
additionalM:
Hints
You were foolish to give your heart away to Splinter. He didn't want it. Also he's a rat, what's wrong with you?
additionalR:
Hints
What will you do with your foolish goo heart now?
readingMnemonic: Splinter tells you to your face how foolish you are and you feel your heart turn to goo (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo.

meaningMnemonic: A triceratops with a mustache will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "Furthermore..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high esteem that no one ever interrupts him.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this mustachioed triceratops. He probably has a monocle and a fedora too. Every time you think you can talk or leave he says, "Furthermore" again. Come on guy, how much do you have to say?
additionalR:
Hints
"Furthermore!" the mustachioed triceratops points at the Shougun, "He is the best Shougun we'll ever have. And he'll let me talk forever OH OH OH!"
readingMnemonic: Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying furthermore? Because he's the Shougun's (しょう) pet. If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about.

meaningMnemonic: A mouth with a sword is threatening to cut off your fingers because they've kidnapped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine you've been kidnapped. And the person who kidnapped you is going to cut off some of your fingers and mail them to your parents if they don't pay the ransom soon enough. You don't want your fingers to be cut off with a sword! Help!
additionalR:
Hints
If your parents don't send in the kayak to your kidnapper soon, you're gonna lose some fingers. Come on guys, just get the kayak already!!!
readingMnemonic: You've been kidnapped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a kayak (かい). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one.

meaningMnemonic: The leader who usually hits you with a stick in winter finds it in his heart to give you some leisure time.
additionalM:
Hints
You fall to your knees, "Oh thank you for not hitting me with your stick and letting me relax!" You haven't had a moment of leisure in ages!
additionalR:
Hints
As the leader leisurely watches, the youths smack you with their sticks. What a cruel world! "Enjoy your leisure time," the leader yells over, "the youths hit much softer than I do. Have fun!"
readingMnemonic: You're just about to start your leisure time when a group of youths (ゆう) appears with their own sticks. You look back for the leader, and he's wearing a bathrobe, sunglasses, and is drinking some hot cocoa. Wait... this is leisure time for... HIM?! OH NO!

meaningMnemonic: You're in a really important position, heavy with power, but you can't carry all of that around with you, so you boil it all down to just a few merits.
additionalM:
Hints
Most people in places heavy with power, like the scouts, boil down all of their responsibilities and accomplishments this way into merit badges.
additionalR:
Hints
This is why you never see a military officer or a girl scout leaving their merit badges out in the open. They pin them right onto their clothes. Otherwise the raccoons would come.
readingMnemonic: The only problem with consolidating your merits like this is that raccoons (くん) are always trying to steal them. Raccoons really like shiny, small things. Like, say, the physical representation of all your personal and professional merits.

meaningMnemonic: A coat rack will turn into a bundle of sticks if you neglect it. When you neglect a coat rack, the weight from the coats will pull all of the arms off, leaving it as a sparse stick.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this sparse, neglected coat rack. All of its arms and the coats that were on it have fallen off and are in a big pile on the ground.
additionalR:
Hints
If you neglect something for too long, not even a good soap scrub will bring it back. That goes for humans too. Take care of yourselves. Use soap.
readingMnemonic: You go up to the neglected coat rack and try to make things right by cleaning it with soap (そ). But no matter how much you scrub, it won't get clean, the arms won't go back on.

meaningMnemonic: Whatever you say through a satellite turns into Noh chanting. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least.
additionalM:
Hints
Say whatever you want and send it up to the satellite. Now imagine listening to it when it comes back and hearing beautiful, deep Noh chanting back!
additionalR:
Hints
Watch closely the next time you go to a Noh play. See the man Noh chanting? Watch close enough and you'll see him eat a scoop of yogurt every once in a while.
readingMnemonic: While you're fake Noh chanting you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of yogurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work.

meaningMnemonic: After your wedding you have a baby and it uses its mouth to nurse from your post-marriage boobs. Yes, babies nurse from breasts. Get over it, kids.
additionalM:
Hints
You waited until your wedding to have your baby and all it seems to do with its mouth is want to nurse. It doesn't cry, which is nice, but it doesn't laugh or talk either.
additionalR:
Hints
This hoe has really helped you get through nursing. You think you'll keep this up even after your baby is weened off! Hoeing the garden is your new favorite hobby!
readingMnemonic: The baby wants to nurse all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is hoe (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time!

meaningMnemonic: A drunkard gets his hands on a plow and starts planting right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a drunk guy laughing and plowing a field and planting seeds. He wouldn't do this if he was sober, but drunk people can't help themselves.
additionalR:
Hints
Oh my sweet cyborg child! Is this what they've done with you? You're just a drunkard who's only good for planting? Nooooooo!!
readingMnemonic: He keeps planting and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR CYBORG (さい)!

meaningMnemonic: You put your foot on the bar at the gymnasium at your very first practice. That's a big accomplishment since you're here learning how to walk on that long bar like all the cool gymnasts. But you can't just start right away, you need lots of practice so that's why you're here in this class. But so far you got your foot on the bar already, good for you!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your foot touching the bar. This is it. This is exactly what you're at this gym to practice.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your centaur foot on the bar as you practice to become a gymnast. It's going to take years and years of this kind of practice, but you're sure you'll make it all the way up there some day! Never give up!
readingMnemonic: This type of practice is especially hard for you because you're a centaur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar!

meaningMnemonic: The Mouth King, who is just one big mouth, has one skill, and that is to present. That big mouth is always presenting something.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the Mouth King giving a presentation about the importance of mouths. His subjects all flatter him by saying, "Please, please, present to us about mouths again! We truuuuuuly love it!"
additionalR:
Hints
You pour a bucket of tater tots into his mouth body and he continues his presentation about mouths. "You see, mouths are just orifices..."
readingMnemonic: "I will present to you a presentation about mouths, but I require energy. Please fill my giant mouth body with delicious tater (てい) tots.

meaningMnemonic: Your leader managed to find the right direction home using marks in the dirt in the middle of winter. This makes you so proud! You're proud because this resourceful leader is YOUR resourceful leader.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how proud you and your whole country feel as your leader comes trudging in through the snow. He made it home. You're (sniff) so (sob) proud!
additionalR:
Hints
Let's be honest here, ごういち isn't getting any younger. You really should be proud of him for surviving this long at all.
readingMnemonic: This leader you're so proud of is old man ごういち. He's been getting a bit slow over the years, and you really didn't think he'd make it back. But, by gum, he did it.

meaningMnemonic: A sickness that hits you like an arrow will do its gross work rapidly. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this rapid sickness spreading through your body like a cartoon arrow ricocheting through your body. Yuck!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting sick this rapidly. All of a sudden, there's a shih tzu barking in your head, it hurts! And... oh no, where's the toilet?!
readingMnemonic: This rapid sickness makes your head pound like there's a shih tzu (しつ) yapping and barking nonstop. And it's making you sh*t a lot.

meaningMnemonic: Flowers that grow in the west are colored by the sun setting so they turn bright red. That's why red flowers that grow in the west are used to make red dye. They're the closest to the actual color of the red sun, so they're prized by painters and other artists for their perfect color for dye.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself sitting in the west as the red sun sets, smashing those pretty red flowers into a paste to make red dye. Your fingers get dyed red too and you crush the petals into a paste.
additionalR:
Hints
Hear the little girl say あかね while pointing to the red dye. She's right. And the way she says it is so darn cute.
readingMnemonic: As you're smashing the flowers into red dye, a little girl comes up to you and points at the paste. She says, "赤ね (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the red dye on your fingers and nod. She's right, it is red.

meaningMnemonic: You took someone's alcohol and drop drop drop'd it all into the river. Now you have to repay them. Alcohol costs a lot of money, you know.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself dropping the alcohol, drop by drop, into the river. Uh oh, the person just caught up to you, so you better repay them.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine waiting as this person tries on like twenty different pairs of shoes. They're getting them for free! Why do they have to be picky?! Just let me repay you already!
readingMnemonic: In order to repay them for the alcohol you wasted, you offer to give them your shoes (しゅう). They don't want your shoes though, so you have to bring them to a store and watch them try on a bunch of different pairs so you can repay them that way.
mainReading: しゅう, しゅ, とう

meaningMnemonic: You see a mouth coming out of the top of a tree so you go into shock. Your brain just can't comprehend what's in front of you.
additionalM:
Hints
A tree... with... a... mouth? No, it can't be... I... a-. Your face warps into a permanent state of shock.
additionalR:
Hints
I'd be shocked if you ever left your home again, honestly. But hey, there's always anime.
readingMnemonic: The shock you've suffered results in you needing to stay home (ほう) from now on. You don't get to travel, explore, or even get groceries. You're homebound from now on, buddy.

meaningMnemonic: You cast the Mona Lisa in gold and attach it to a stick to turn it into a sickle! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine wielding your gold Mona Lisa sickle. It's sooo heavy, but it's really shiny and it cuts grass and wheat pretty well!
additionalR:
Hints
Hear all the guests say, "Mona Lisa... comma the sickle? WHAT'S HAPPENED HERE?!" As panic ensues. You like your addition and you're very proud.
readingMnemonic: Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a sickle, you have to change the little description under its name in the Louvre. You draw a giant comma (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can.

meaningMnemonic: A wolverine that sticks its legs in rice will become very solemn, very fast. This is weird to you because wolverines always seem so happy. Well his dad died from his legs getting stuck in rice, so just leave the poor solemn creature alone.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if your dad died from getting his legs stuck in some rice, now feel solemn too.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine seeing how violently you shook him. You shook him so hard his solemn mood disappeared!
readingMnemonic: Remember how solemn wolverine looked when his dad died? You hated seeing him like this so you ran up and shook (しゅく) him. You shook the solemn sadness right out of him! You should do that again now!

meaningMnemonic: When you leave flowers on a tombstone they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but stems. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being in a graveyard looking at all the tombstones and seeing nothing but stems on all of them. All the pretty flowery parts have died and blown away.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at all the cookie covered tombstones. Now your bag is full of stems, but you can use them to make more cookies to bring back next time. Don't worry, nobody eats them. Stem cookies are probably poisonous.
readingMnemonic: You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover stems all over them. You brought cookies (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer.

meaningMnemonic: You're sick because you put an arrow in your mouth and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really stupid. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick.
additionalM:
Hints
How stupid do you have to be to put arrows into your mouth until it makes you sick? Pretty darn stupid, it seems.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine if everyone knew that cheese cures the stupid out of people. Then maybe we would have more cheese and less stupid in the world!
readingMnemonic: The only way to cure this serious case of stupid is to make you eat cheese (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together.

meaningMnemonic: Clearing his flowers of icicles, the samurai returns home to his villa.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the samurai's villa. It's in the countryside and covered in flowers and icicles. Even though it's spring, it's still cold, so all the new flowers are very cold.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the samurai sitting in a chair in his beautiful villa and breathing his last breath. His soul slowly floats up and out of his still body and dances around the villa, free.
readingMnemonic: Once the samurai enters the villa, he lets his soul (そう) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go.
mainReading: そう, しょう, ちゃん

meaningMnemonic: If you travel to the fish capital, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty whale! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the underwater fish capital. Statues of whales line the fishy streets, and all of the fish bow down to the whale ruler's giant body.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the gay whale ruler holding whale hands... fins? with his whale husband. They're so cute.
readingMnemonic: The whale who resides over the capital just happens to be gay (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay.

meaningMnemonic: You should stop to buy stamps at noon because that's the only time they're being sold at wholesale price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself stopping at the empty bank at noon, grabbing a handful of wholesale stamps. So many stamps. So few extra charges.
additionalR:
Hints
"Oh Roshi" you say carefully as you hand your stamps over at noon. The guy raises an eyebrow at you, but gives you them wholesale! It worked!
readingMnemonic: Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at wholesale price too. The password is "Oh Roshi" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too!

meaningMnemonic: You start growing thread in your rice paddy to accumulate more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you.
additionalM:
Hints
Just imagine how much thread you'll accumulate if you can just grow it along with your rice in the rice paddy! So much thread!
additionalR:
Hints
Your attempts to accumulate more of something by cheating have brought ruin to everything else you were doing. Nice job, dummy.
readingMnemonic: Sadly, this is a terrible way to accumulate anything thread related and you ended up ruining (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it.

meaningMnemonic: When you meet the leader dog you have to bow to show your respect. Dogs are pretty great, so the leader of all dogs must be the greatest! You should bow really deeply to this one.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself bowing to the leader dog. Leader dog is so cool!
additionalR:
Hints
Bow even deeper as the dog leader keeps barking what sounds like f**k you. You're pretty sure that's what he's saying at least... but maybe... maybe it's not.
readingMnemonic: You bow as low as you can, but you lose your balance and fall over. "F**k you (ふく)!" the leader dog barks. Oh no. You messed up and now the leader dog is super mad. Saying f**k you is a little harsh for falling over though, you think.

meaningMnemonic: When a man meets a tiger he makes the tiger his captive. Men are pretty crappy like that. They see tigers and they want to put them in cages, so the poor tiger becomes a captive of the man.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the sad tiger captive and the man laughing as he pokes at it. Tigers shouldn't be captives but when men find them they always seem to do this anyway.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the poor captive tiger being stuffed into a bathrobe and paraded around a cage for the man.
readingMnemonic: The captive tiger is even sadder because the man put him in a robe (りょ) and is making him act like a human. Tigers look good in robes, but they don't really enjoy being forced into people clothing.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to loiter on a cliff with the pope you better be ready to move in perfect circulation with him. The pope is wearing really heavy robes and it's hot up here on this cliff, so you both need to walk in circles to keep cool.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine this strange circulation of you and the pope up here on a cliff. It's not even like you two are up here for a reason, you're just loitering. But he doesn't want to be hot so he makes you circulate with him.
additionalR:
Hints
"This circulation is all June's fault," you mutter, walking in a circle with the pope to stay cool.
readingMnemonic: This circulation wouldn't have to even be happening if it wasn't June (じゅん). The cliffs are so hot in June, and in any other month the two of you would have just sat down and had a chat. But in June you have to do this weird circulation dance.

meaningMnemonic: If you find some rice in a top hat it's going to be really coarse and rough. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to eat the rice you found in a top hat. It's so coarse it feels like it's scratching your teeth. There's probably some dirt in here too. This wasn't the best idea.
additionalR:
Hints
If you were trying to make this coarse rice taste like soap, you did it. But if you were trying to make it less coarse, well... sorry, but that's not how anything works.
readingMnemonic: You take the coarse rice and try to wash it with soap (そ).

meaningMnemonic: If you try to turn something into ice while having doubts, it will just congeal instead. It will freeze, but it will get kinda yucky too. Your doubts will affect the ice-making process, so try not to be so worried and unsure next time you want normal ice.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking over water in an ice cube tray. You aren't sure if they'll turn out alright, and you doubt whether ice is even a thing. As you think this, the water congeals and freezes into gross shapes.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture frozen, congealed gyoza. Do you want to eat that? I didn't think so.
readingMnemonic: You always end up congealing your gyoza (ぎょう) this way. You want to freeze your leftover gyoza so you can enjoy it later, but you doubt it will turn out all right and it always congeals in a gross, half-frozen gyoza block. Yuck!

meaningMnemonic: The king has a hat that's made from a tree but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big cork. It's a big, wooden plug that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture how silly the king looks with this cork on his head. He kind of looks like a fat, plugged up bottle of wine when he yells now.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the centaurs drinking and giggling, putting the cork from their wine on their head to imitate the stupid king.
readingMnemonic: It turned out this cork hat was given to him by a centaur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing.

meaningMnemonic: The king of the flowers in the center (of England, if you remember) has a special crystal. The king crystal.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the king holding this crystal aloft, giggling as the sun shines through it and sparkles.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine going to England, to the giant acorn in the center of the flowers, and searching for the king's crystal. If you find it, you can probably sell it for a fortune! Or just make a really sweet necklace.
readingMnemonic: The king thinks everyone wants his crystal so he hides it in the giant acorn (えい) in the center of the flowers in England. There's a tiny hole in the bottom of the acorn, and that's where this crystal stays hidden.

meaningMnemonic: The dawn radical and the dawn kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting a tan at dawn. Ahh. Relaxing and warm.
readingMnemonic: Dawn is dawn (だん)! It's also a great time to get a tan (たん). The sun is bright at dawn, but not so much that it will send skin cancer rays into you.

meaningMnemonic: When spring is dry you need to dedicate your time and effort somewhere else. You can't plant flowers or vegetables, it's too dry. You can't play outside, your skin will flake. So you need to dedicate yourself to something inside.
additionalM:
Hints
You know how you get. When you can't go outside, you dedicate yourself full force into something else. I mean, you made it to level 55, right? That's some serious dedication. And it probably started because of one particularly dry spring.
additionalR:
Hints
Dedicate yourself to doing things in your home! Haha, who are we kidding, you already did that.
We love you, nerd. ♡
readingMnemonic: You decide to dedicate yourself to your home (ほう). You don't want to be outside in the dry spring air, so you focus on home activities. You can clean the kitchen, build a shelf, or dedicate your time to your home internet system.

meaningMnemonic: You got off your scooter to load some charcoal onto it, when it suddenly took off into the distance! That's some powerful charcoal.
additionalM:
Hints
Your scooter is charcoal powered, but it looks like you put too much in there and it drove off into the distance without you.
additionalR:
Hints
In the distance you can still make out the shape of your scooter, now on a row boat, fading away and completely out of reach.
readingMnemonic: You chase the scooter into the distance when you see it heading for a lake. Oh good, it should be stopped by the water. But wait! In the distance you see your scooter drive onto a row (りょう) boat and... row itself through the water?! No!!

meaningMnemonic: Put a sock in a building and it turns into an enclosure.
additionalM:
Hints
Why? Because that sock is now enclosed in that building!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture this inception enclosure mess in your mind and you'll never forget this kanji, I promise.
readingMnemonic: Now that you have an enclosure, let's go deeper. Put a cock (かく) in the sock and it becomes an enclosure inside an enclosure.

meaningMnemonic: Put your fingers in a jet if you want to erase them from existence. You aren't just chopping or burning them off. There's like, no trace of them at all. Your parents can't even remember if you were born with fingers or not. Jets are that powerful.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine your fingers slowly getting closer and closer to the jet's engine. It feels like it's going to suck your whole body in. And you better watch out, because if it does you'll be erased from the planet. And probably from time itself.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're so thankful to the mats. If they weren't there you might have erased your whole body! Thank you mats! I'll never walk on you without thanking you for your service again!
readingMnemonic: You're almost done erasing your fingers when the jet starts sucking all of you in. You would try to grab the closest thing to you, but your fingers don't exist anymore, so you hold onto the mats (まつ) at your feet with your toes. The mats are super strong (they're made for jets, after all) and you manage to save yourself!

meaningMnemonic: A leader gets double the dirt to build on if he's the most excellent and most skilled of all the leaders. You don't think dirt is so great? Well what if I took the dirt you own away from you? Your house is on that dirt. It's mine now. Get outta here.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being so excellent at leading, that you get double the dirt that everyone else gets.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your own car. Is it as excellent as you?
readingMnemonic: This excellent leader is going to use all this dirt to store her excellent cars (か)! Excellent people have to have cars in equal or greater than excellent-ness than themselves.

meaningMnemonic: Your soul long ago was very frugal, which is why you get to have too much in this life!
additionalM:
Hints
Thank you soul, for being frugal so that I can have so much now.
additionalR:
Hints
If you want your spouse or S.O. to think you're more sexy, just be more frugal. They'll definitely appreciate it and see you in a different light.
readingMnemonic: You know what being frugal is? Sexy (せき). You save money, you use less resources, that's the sexiest thing I can think of.

meaningMnemonic: A hundred foreheads lower themselves to their hearts in winter in grief. There were once many of their kind, the forehead peoples, but now there are only a hundred left after this harsh winter took the rest of them. Their grief is immense.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if winter was so brutal that there were only one hundred human foreheads left. You lost all of your friends and family. Feel that grief.
additionalR:
Hints
Grief for youths is so painful. No one should have to bury their forehead child.
readingMnemonic: Their grief intensifies because all of the foreheads they lost belonged to youths (ゆう). Dead youths everywhere. Now there's no one left to repopulate the world.

meaningMnemonic: The soul in your toe leaves early. You grieve and mourn for your now-dead toe.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at your toe. It has no soul. It's dark and shriveled, like a mummy's toe. Grieve and watch your tears drip onto it.
additionalR:
Hints
Walk through the streets of とうきょう grieving, with your dead toe flopping onto the pavement.
readingMnemonic: You decide to grieve in とうきょう. Your toe always wanted to walk in とうきょう, and now you can at least fulfill its dying wish.

meaningMnemonic: The sick Death Star needs its heart cured. If it doesn't get healing soon, it will die.
additionalM:
Hints
Maybe the Death Star wouldn't be sick if it wasn't so mean to you, yelling at you for living in a yurt, when it was a yurt on the inside the whole time. Wait! I know the cure!
additionalR:
Hints
Hmm, but does this type of yurt healing technology exist?! You'll have to find out to cure it!!
readingMnemonic: You realized that the only way to cure the Death Star is to turn it back into a yurt (ゆ). Then it won't be able to do any more harm, and its outside will reflect its pleasant self on the inside!

meaningMnemonic: You see a tree growing on a cliff and it has ten thousand horse chestnuts growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture this tree, weighed down by it's own horse chestnuts, leaning over the edge of the cliff.
additionalR:
Hints
Horse chestnuts taste like nasty toe cheese. Imagine what having one in your mouth would be like.
readingMnemonic: You decide to take a bite of a horse chestnut because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like toe cheese (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww!

meaningMnemonic: The imperial radical and the imperial kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
additionalM:
Hints
Make sure you remember this radical means imperial and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Ryu kicking the butts of imperial  scum like Bison and Darth Vader.
readingMnemonic: Who is the coolest imperial you know? Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know!
mainReading: りゅう, りょう, ろう

meaningMnemonic: Go from a bow to a small gun and you're increasing in fire power! Even though the gun is small, it's still a step up from a bow.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine increasing your power with a new weapon. What would it be?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine walking down a line of weapons, each one increasing in power from the one before it. Bow, small gun, bigger gun, tank, Yankee's bat. Yup, that sounds right.
readingMnemonic: You keep trading in weapons to get increasingly stronger gear, when you realize that at the top of the list is... a Yankee's (や) baseball bat? Huh. I would have gone for a tank or a bazooka. But I guess if this will increase your power level, you have to go for it.

meaningMnemonic: Your bones have a scooter that moves through the bone marrow inside them.
additionalM:
Hints
If you think about it, bone marrow is really just a road for tiny blood scooters.
additionalR:
Hints
That's how doctors can tell if there's something wrong with your bone marrow. If they can't hear the zuuwee of the scooters, you're gonna die soon. I mean, maybe, I'm not a doctor.
readingMnemonic: If you put your ear really close a bone with marrow still in it, you'll hear the scooters going zuwee (ずい) as they move the blood around inside there.

meaningMnemonic: The leader is standing funny, facing a direction nearby. He can't go far because there's obviously something wrong with his feet. He's stuck nearby, very close to your side.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the leader very close to your side. He's looking off into the distance, a distance he'll never get to because all he can do is stand there with his messed up feet.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the leader bowling nearby. You keep him close by, you never know when he'll fall over and need your help.
readingMnemonic: You decide to bring the leader to a nearby bowling (ぼう) alley. It's really close and you can stay right by his side as he throws bowling balls and gets his anger out.

meaningMnemonic: The soul of the Death Star is actually quite pleasant. And if you think about it, it's the people who control the Death Star that are evil and kill.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the Death Star in your mind. As you picture it, its pleasant, smiling soul floats up and out of it. "Oh hello, dear," it says happily, "Didn't see you there!"
additionalR:
Hints
Yurts are very pleasant structures. They're round and soft and moveable, just like the Death Star's soul.
readingMnemonic: The pleasant soul within the Death Star actually looks like a yurt (ゆ), not a big angry, metal ball.

meaningMnemonic: You need to run on your toes if you want to proceed down this road. If you can't run on your toes, well then you're out of luck, and you won't be able to move on at all. I didn't make this rule, I just enforce it. Now run!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to proceed down the road by running on your toes. No other part of your foot can touch the ground!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being called a fool when you can't proceed along the road because running on your toes ends up being super hard to do.
readingMnemonic: If you find that you can't proceed, you're a fool (ふ). Everyone can run on their toes. Don't you know that? No? Then you're an even bigger fool, now get outta here!

meaningMnemonic: The sun is the reason why crops grow and people can get out of bed in the morning. But on planets with two suns, they can get even more done and it makes them way more prosperous than us. They work all day, then as the first sun sets, the second one rises and they get a new burst of energy. The whole planet lives in a state of prosperity because of the two suns.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the prosperous planet that has two suns. They get so much work done that no one is ever hungry or tired or without.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun looking over the prosperous world, the two suns at his back.
readingMnemonic: The person on this planet with two suns who benefits from the prosperity the most is the Shougun (しょう). Yes, this planet still has a shougun as their leader, but everything is going so well that they didn't see a need to change. The shogun will be in charge of this prosperous world forever. No one ever thinks of revolt when everyone has everything they could ever need.

meaningMnemonic: The only feeling a dead soul will have is remorse. Remorse for the people it left behind. Regrets for the things it did and didn't do.
additionalM:
Hints
If you died right now and left your soul behind, do you think you'd have regrets?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Genghis Khan looking down at the state of his people, the Mongols, in the modern world. See the remorse in his soul's face. They should be leaders of the modern world. Not reduced to a people struggling in the background.
readingMnemonic: The soul with the most regrets is Genghis Khan (かん). Everyone knows to stay away from him in the spirit world because he's so sad. Not because of his own actions, but because of the state of his people now.

meaningMnemonic: You decide to carve a tree into a giant replica of your big toe because you think it will be really simple. Once you're done though, it looks like a really crude attempt at a fat, lumpy blob. Maybe carving isn't as simple as you thought.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine carving a really simple, crude toe from a tree. It's your first attempt, so I guess you should have known it wouldn't be great.
additionalR:
Hints
Who carved this simple toe? ぼく!
readingMnemonic: You're admiring your simple looking toe tree when a lumberjack runs up and asks who created it. ぼく, you say. As in "I" said it, in a manly dude, way. He doesn't seem to believe you, so you say it a few more times. ぼく ぼく ぼく!

meaningMnemonic: If you put two two pound weights on a person on the moon they'll increase in stature when they come back down. Everything is lighter on the moon so the person won't even feel the weights. Then when they come back to earth they'll have grown a whole two inches taller!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how much height you'd gain if you spent time lifting weights on the moon!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how sexy the height of a ten foot tall person would be after just coming back from weight training on the moon.
readingMnemonic: Getting a taller stature will also make you seem super sexy (せき) on the moon and back home on earth. If you stay on the moon long enough, you'll be the tallest person in the galaxy and who wouldn't find that sexy?! Huh?

meaningMnemonic: You want to slice what you say in half so that people focus on the above text first. The above is what you want them to see! So slice what you say!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine actually slicing the words you say in the air. The above section is what you want people to pay attention to, so you slice a big gap between the above and the below words.
additionalR:
Hints
That guy doesn't care if the above is all he's supposed to hear. That guy sucks.
readingMnemonic: As you focus on the above words you realize a guy (がい) is trying to push the rest of the things you're saying back up with the rest of them. No! The above text is all that matters! Go away guy!

meaningMnemonic: How do you make a mnemonic for the word this? You don’t. But, we can try. You climb many hills. On top of one of the hills is a little drop of water. You pick it up and say “THIS… THIS IS WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR!”
additionalM:
Hints
As you look at the drop of water, you note that you found the right thing. Written on it is the word “this."
additionalR:
Hints
The core of the universe is in this drop of water. Or is it in this mnemonic? Ooohhhhh you'll never knoooowwww!
readingMnemonic: This particular drop of water hold the core (これ) of the universe. If you didn't find this very droplet, we all would have died and this universe would be gone.

meaningMnemonic: The reality of gold is that it has the power to tranquilize anyone who gets their hands on it. Gold may seem cool to have in movies and songs, but in reality, it has the power to mess you up!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being tranquilized by the sweet caress of gold coins. You can't even move. You're in a daze or something.
additionalR:
Hints
If you let gold tranquilize you, you'll drool all over your own chin. Maybe the chins of other people too, who knows?
readingMnemonic: You've been tranquilized and now drool is running down your chin (ちん). It's actually really gross. But you don't care, look at all this gold! No one will care about your chin when you're rich!

meaningMnemonic: When you go to the pool or lake to swim, you'll see a flag stuck somewhere in the water. That flag is there so you know it's okay to pee in that area of the pool. Everyone knows urine dilutes in water, and if everyone just pees in one place, it won't be gross. So go pee over by that flag when you have to go. Don't bother getting out of the water.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine swimming over to the flag that's sticking out of the water and peeing there. Yeah, everyone knows what you're doing over there, but it's better than getting out and walking to the bathroom right? Just pee in the water. Just do it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your embarrassment when you find out that you aren't supposed to urinate in the water, not even by the pee flag, because a life guard yelled NYOOOOOO and pointed right at you while you did it.
readingMnemonic: Right as you start to pee, you hear the life guard start to yell, "NYOOOOOO! (にょう)" and he's pointing at you! You were just peeing by the pee flag! Why is he mad?

meaningMnemonic: Between the roof and the ground there are few shellfish. This is because we invited some VIP guests into our home and they ate all our shellfish.
additionalM:
Hints
The VIPs came into our home (the place between our roof and the ground) where they consumed all our shellfish. Only the best for guests, I guess.
additionalR:
Hints
We are treating these VIP guests extra special because they represent the whole Hindu religion. They get shellfish because of course we weren't going to serve them beef!
readingMnemonic: These VIP guests are part of a Hindu (ひん) envoy.

meaningMnemonic: You're holding a sword in front two buildings. What will you do?
additionalM:
Hints
What? Do you think I'm gonna help you make this decision? No way, you need to dig deep and think about what you want to do.
additionalR:
Hints
What?! You got nachos either way. You should be happy, don't ask me any other questions.
readingMnemonic: A. What is, stab the building on the left? You stab the building on the left with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious nachos (な)!

meaningMnemonic: There is a cage with an axe in it above your house to show that you are an artisan. All of the artisans have to have this special sign somewhere near where they live to show they make things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking down your street and seeing caged axes above all of the artisans homes and shops. You want a new chair? You want some pants mended? Go to one of those signs and you'll find the right artisan.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the Shougun marching angrily down the street. His shoe suddenly snaps in half. With just one glance he'll be able to find the shoe artisan and make them fix his shoe for free.
readingMnemonic: Artisans have to be marked this way because the Shougun (しょう) says so. The Shougun doesn't want to have to put any effort into finding people to make things for him, so he created this new system.

meaningMnemonic: You're tapping your fingers against a white wall when you realize the sound you're making is actually a sick beat. You keep going and start singing along. Boo boo boop. Boo do do do doop! Finger beats!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself in a completely white room. All you have is the white walls, your fingers, and your beats. When you stop all you're left with is white noise. Yuck! Keep those beats coming!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine hacking the wall apart as you try to keep this beat going. The music is all you have, man! You can't lose the beat now!
readingMnemonic: This beat is sick, but as you tap you realize you're hacking (はく) up the wall! Slowly but surely, your fingers are hacking out little bits of the wall. And the beats don't sound as good until you move to a new, clean white area.

meaningMnemonic: Your specialty is dropping people with thread by binding them! You can drop anyone as long as you have enough thread to restrain them. It doesn't matter how much they fight, you'll get them to drop!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if your specialty was dropping people by binding them with thread. You'd be such a weird person.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how you would bind someone so that when they drop they land on their back instead of somewhere more painful. How would you do that?
readingMnemonic: If you're going to be a weirdo who likes to bind people, at least make sure that they land on their backs (ばく) when they DO drop. Landing on your head or your boobs really hurts. So please at least try to make them land on their backs!

meaningMnemonic: You eat and then wrap yourself into a ball because you're bored. You're also sated, because you ate just the right amount, but now you have nothing to do and it's soooo booooring.
additionalM:
Hints
Haven't you ever been so bored that you just wrapped yourself up into a boredom ball?
additionalR:
Hints
Ehhhhhhgggg guys I'm stuck at home and I'm soooo bored. Heeelpp!
readingMnemonic: So now you're bored and stuck at home (ほう). You aren't hungry. There's nothing on TV. And you don't want to have to leave your home to do something, even though that would probably solve your boredom problem.

meaningMnemonic: If you could stop spooning water onto that tree we could use it for brushwood. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already!
additionalM:
Hints
We need to use that brushwood to make a fire! So stop spooning water on it!
additionalR:
Hints
Shiba inu's come from setting brushwood on fire! That must have been how they got their name!
readingMnemonic: You finally set the brushwood on fire and suddenly a Shiba (しば) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa?

meaningMnemonic: The insect that is amongst all the world's trees is the butterfly. They are always hanging around trees, those butterflies.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine any tree in the world with different kinds of butterflies fluttering around. Then go to another tree in the world that looks completely different. Once again, butterflies! They really are fluttering around every tree in the world.
additionalR:
Hints
She grabs another butterfly and starts pulling off wings again, though this time you can see her evil face looking at you while she does it. "I hate butterflies," she says. "They are always dying in my tea."
readingMnemonic: As you look at a butterfly, fluttering around a tree, a hand reaches out from the tree and grabs it, then starts plucking the wings off. An evil laugh comes from inside the tree, and you know it's Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaningMnemonic: The mysterious sound that comes from a bowstring when you pluck it is called a chord. It's still a bowstring though. You need strings to make chords, after all.
additionalM:
Hints
Every time you touch a bowstring, listen to the chords it plays.
additionalR:
Hints
GASP! Genji is finally singing chords of love to you! Your dreams have come true and the most handsome, romantic man ever is finally yours!
readingMnemonic: The chord you're hearing right now is being played by Genji (げん). He's sitting under your window plucking bowstrings and singing.

meaningMnemonic: You're trying to open the lid of a manhole that's covered in ice by jackhammering it a bunch of times but it's not working because it's just too cold. It's so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if it was sooo cold that no matter how many times you tried to jackhammer the ice of the lid for this manhole, it wouldn't crack open.
additionalR:
Hints
If it wasn't so darn cold you wouldn't have to hear this horrible high pitched ringing sound because there wouldn't even be any ice to jackhammer through!
readingMnemonic: Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing cold ice it makes a high pitched ringing (りん) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it.

meaningMnemonic: Under this canopy you have a brush and a task to complete with it. This is totally common.
additionalM:
Hints
This type of thing is common for almost every class or job you'll ever have. They sit you down under the canopy, put a brush in your hand, and say, "Here complete this task. I'll be over there."
additionalR:
Hints
As you eat the yogurt you think about how common yogurt is too. It's just a normal food, common in everyone's fridge.
readingMnemonic: This is so common and familiar to you that you finish your task early and eat some yogurt (よう) while you wait for the guy to come back.

meaningMnemonic: When you drive a car, everyone under your roof is putting their life in your hands, even if they don't say it with their mouth—it's still under your control.
additionalM:
Hints
It's really important to remember how many things are under your control when you operate a vehicle. It isn't just the people in your car either, it's everyone and everything in your way too.
additionalR:
Hints
If you don't want to think about hitting adorable cats with your car, you better maintain control. You're responsible!
readingMnemonic: You have to maintain control of your car or you'll hit a bunch of cats (かつ). The roads are full of cats at all times. And if you lose control of your car for just a second, you'll hit at least two or three cats.

meaningMnemonic: If you can guard your soul from bad things you'll always feel delight and joy. It's hard to guard your soul from everything though, so take all the joy you can, while you can.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine guarding yourself from all the bad things in the world. No more politics, religion, internet trolls debating the two, it's all guarded from your precious soul. Ahhh, it's so joyous to be unburdened.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture joy etched on your own face. No one can get you down.
readingMnemonic: The delight you feel is so great that it becomes permanently etched (えつ) in your soul and even your face.

meaningMnemonic: Put a hole in someone's body with a bow and they'll become destitute. You put a hole in them. They can't work. They can't take care of their house or their kids. They've lost it all.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a destitute person wandering in the streets with a hole in their body.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a destitute person, sitting on the street, holding a cucumber. Putting the cucumber in their hole. Crying.
readingMnemonic: You see this destitute person and decide to give them a cucumber (きゅう). They don't even remember that they're supposed to eat those, so they shove it in the hole you made with your bow.

meaningMnemonic: If when you speak it sounds like the power of a drum is coming out of your mouth, then people will hold you in high esteem. Anyone who has a loud, booming, powerful voice will be held in high esteem in this day and age. Look at all those awesome musicians who have booming voices!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine hearing someone speak and it's so powerful and loud that it sounds like they have a drum booming out of their mouth. You'll love them! You'll hold them in the highest esteem!
additionalR:
Hints
If you hold someone in high esteem you give me your- give them your car. Gimme!
readingMnemonic: You hold them in such high esteem that you give them your car (か). I ... I said you give them your car! Give them your car. Hey, hey!

meaningMnemonic: Twenty penguins together are always evil. Penguins are seen in groups a lot, sure, but did you know that any time there are exactly twenty penguins in a group they're plotting evil things? Evil things like global warming. And how to eat all the fish in the world so humans can't have any.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking around in the arctic when you stumble upon an evil group of penguins. They'd be cute if they weren't holding papers with "Kill All Humans" on them and tiny guns in their penguin hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Only someone or, in this case, something truly evil would kill someone and hide their remains under some hay. That's really disrespectful and, well, evil.
readingMnemonic: The evil penguins can't let you tell the other human's what you've seen, so they murder you and hide your body in a haystack (へい). Your family will never know what happened to you. The penguins will get away with their evil plans.

meaningMnemonic: There is a scooter that is a satellite, but it is far off and far away.
additionalM:
Hints
Look up into the sky. That little moving light is the scooter satellite. It's just scooting along, far away from here.
additionalR:
Hints
The scooter satellite's only purpose is to make a "har har har" sound that is audible from far away. It's quite obnoxious.
readingMnemonic: The scooter satellite is far off, but you can still hear it's horn go "har (はる) har har."

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami together with another tsunami is going to cause a massive flood.
additionalM:
Hints
More than one tsunami will definitely result in a flood. Imagine the floody aftermath of more than one tsunami, arriving together.
additionalR:
Hints
"This flood was caused by you! It is because you did not believe in the holy Crabigator! It is because you didn't do your kanji reviews. It's because you used ignore scripts and reordering scripts and you sinned, sinned, sinned!" こういち says to the scared, cold, now homeless people.
readingMnemonic: After the terrible flood, Emperor こういち comes to survey the destruction and offer hope to his people. But, instead he just tells the people that this flood happened because they didn't believe in the Crabigator's words, and because they weren't doing their kanji reviews.

meaningMnemonic: Your threads are humble and that makes you a perfect gentleman. You don't have to have fancy clothes to be a gentleman, just humble ones that don't stand out and show off too much. That shows how polite you are.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself as the perfect gentleman. You may not have a fancy top hat and tie, but you're humble about what you wear and you're kind to everyone.
additionalR:
Hints
But you're a gentleman, so you don't kick their shins back, you smile and hold in the pain. No matter how bad your shins hurt, you never fight back!
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, as a gentleman who dresses humbly, you're always getting kicked in the shins (しん) by rude kids (and occasionally rude adults).

meaningMnemonic: You've learned that you can catapult things to give them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love.
additionalM:
Hints
If you want to give someone something, use a catapult!
additionalR:
Hints
You give Godzilla old used cars, chunks of old buildings, and sometimes hamburgers. Godzilla is so happy you're giving him food, he doesn't destroy anymore!
readingMnemonic: Give food to your new friend Godzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry.

meaningMnemonic: A samurai hits the foreheads of grains with his weapon so the grains will pop off and into his mouth. He doesn't want to kill the plants, so he's just skimming the grain's foreheads so they'll fall off and he can eat them.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the samurai taking out his weapon and spinning in a lightning fast circle. The forehead grains pop off and come raining into his open mouth.
additionalR:
Hints
These grains aren't even cooked, they're just hard and raw, so the Coke really helps wash them down.
readingMnemonic: Phew, all of this grain is making the samurai thirsty, so he reaches in his bag and pulls out an ice cold, refreshing Coke (こく).

meaningMnemonic: Put your fingers in your ears when there's an explosion in addition to all the other things you were told to do. You have to crouch under a desk, you have to stay away from windows, you have to close your eyes. But in addition to that, you need to protect your ears!
additionalM:
Hints
Pretend you're in a class in the mid-20th century, watching a video on bomb explosion safety. In addition to putting your fingers in your ears, you have to do a bunch of other stuff. You can't just stop after the first step!
additionalR:
Hints
In addition to ears, you have a lot of sets on your body to worry about. Sets of eyes, nostrils, legs, you get the picture.
readingMnemonic: In addition to all the steps you have to take to protect yourself, you can't forget that ears come in sets (せつ). You can't just stick one finger in one ear and have that be the end. You have a set of ears to worry about!

meaningMnemonic: On the roof above, is a small stool. Anyone who sits in that stool will be lonely.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sitting on this small stool, waaaaay up there above the roof. You can't see anyone and you can't talk to anyone. You feel this awful emptiness inside. That's what it's like to be lonely.
additionalR:
Hints
You're so busy talking to Jack, you don't hear the voices from below, "Aren't you lonely up there, miss? Do you want us to get a jack to get you down? Hello? I don't think she can hear us..."
readingMnemonic: You're so lonely, you make up an imaginary friend: Jack (じゃく). Jack doesn't get rid of the lonely feeling because he isn't real, but he is a distraction at least.

meaningMnemonic: Your roof is spicy because you're the manager. You're always testing new recipes in your house to share with everyone who works under you, but that makes all the spice stick to your roof (since it doesn't have good ventilation like a restaurant or a lab would).
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself as the manager of a restaurant or a science lab. You have to test all of your managerial methods at home before you can bring them to work. And if you were to lick that roof of yours... it would be spicy from all of your experiments.
additionalR:
Hints
Unfortunately, you couldn't figure out how to make non-spicy cyborgs, but that's okay because you're going to be the best cyborg manager ever! No one will ever take them away from you again.
readingMnemonic: You've finally done it. You're now the manager of a bunch of spicy new cyborgs (さい). You've been toiling away for over a year, but you've finally replaced the cyborg you lost, and now you can manage them properly without anyone getting in the way.

meaningMnemonic: The only building you'll get frostbite in is a mausoleum. Mausoleums and tombs weren't made for living people, so they aren't insulated from the cold. No one cares if a dead body gets frostbite.
additionalM:
Hints
Unfortunately, you're realizing this because you thought a mausoleum would be a good hiding place from the winter cold. Spoilers, it's not.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine taking your frostbitten fingers and trying to get away from the mausoleum in this row boat. It looks like it was made of bones and it is not very seaworthy. But you row with all your might, because you don't want to end up a permanent fixture in this tomb!
readingMnemonic: You need to escape this mausoleum now but the only way out is on a row (りょう) boat over a creepy frozen pond. You've heard of these mausoleum row boats before, and you're pretty sure they're cursed.

meaningMnemonic: You go to buy a table but it looks it has water damage from drops of water hitting it. This makes it a pretty mediocre table. The water drops haven't really damaged it that much, it still stands and you can use it, but it's kinda ugly, so it's just mediocre.
additionalM:
Hints
You didn't expect to see water drop damage on this table so now your mood is mediocre too.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine having a bone to pick with someone because they're trying to sell you something mediocre and they just won't listen. Now you have a bone to pick with the person who recommended this guy to you!
readingMnemonic: You weren't expecting to see such a mediocre table so you go up to the guy who's selling it and say, "Hey, I have a bone (ぼん) to pick with you!" But he doesn't think there is a bone to pick at all, he doesn't think the table is mediocre like you do.

meaningMnemonic: Who loves their flag, using jackhammers, and precise measurements? Your military officer! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be?
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a military officer doing all those things.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the military officer saluting as an eagle flies overhead. Majestic.
readingMnemonic: That military officer's favorite bird is an eagle (い)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for!

meaningMnemonic: This was pure gold long ago, but now it's not. It's mixed with something else.
additionalM:
Hints
You could swear this thing was gold a long time ago. Now it's a mix of different things.
additionalR:
Hints
Since it was in that sack for so long, it just ended up getting mixed with the other stuff in that sack. It was gold a long time ago, but now it's mixed with everything else.
readingMnemonic: It's mixed (and not pure anymore) because it was put in that sack (さく) filled with various other things.

meaningMnemonic: Stand staring up at the blue sky and you'll feel more peaceful than you ever have. Blue is a color that promotes peaceful thoughts and feelings. That's why all the social media sites are blue. To stop you from being a jerk.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how peaceful staring at the blue ocean, the blue sky, or the blue tumblr makes you.
additionalR:
Hints
Yes! Peaceful blue radicals standing in a row. What's that? YES you do want more radicals added to the site. Well okay then, if it will keep you at peace, sure!
readingMnemonic: Now if someone asks you if the color blue makes you peaceful you should say "YES! (やす)" And you'll have us to thank for that! All those peaceful blue radicals. They're the easiest thing on the site, and if someone asks you if radicals make you feel peaceful say YES again!

meaningMnemonic: When small drops of water work together they gain respect for one another. If you end up working with someone long enough, and they end up being really great, you'll respect them too!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being a small drop of water and seeing other drops of water come to help you by working together. You'd really respect them, right?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine respecting someone so much that you'll cheer ooh yankees over and over even though they're kind of a crappy team.
readingMnemonic: If you respect someone enough you'll even take up their hobbies. The person you respect most loves the Yankees. You don't really feel the same, but you respect that about them so you chant, "Ooh Yankees, Ooh Yankees うやうや with them during each game.

meaningMnemonic: You take some thread, put your scooter up to a signpost, and sew them together. You don't have a lock, so sewing your scooter up to the signpost to keep it safe is all you can think of.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine slowly sewing your scooter to the signpost, passing the thread back and forth through the signpost's metal holes and your scooter's handles.
additionalR:
Hints
Hopefully, if your scooter is still here later you'll be able to start sewing outside of your home more often from now on!
readingMnemonic: You usually only sew at home (ほう), so this is a big exception for you. You're usually worried that if you sew in public people will judge your stitches, so this is a big step for you!

meaningMnemonic: A boat that's white isn't just a boat, it's a ship.
additionalM:
Hints
Boats don't need to be a bright white color. But, ships do! They're dangerous and big, so they paint them nice and white.
additionalR:
Hints
You can also imagine hacking the ship's computer. "Look at me, look at me. You are the hacker now."
readingMnemonic: A white-painted ship is a kind of hack (はく). It makes the ship more visible without costing much.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to fit your fingers into a key hole, you have to squeeze them in. Fingers aren't exactly supposed to fit in key holes... they're for keys, after all. But you want to squeeze your finger on in there anyway to unlock the door.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what it would be like to squeeze your fingers into a keyhole. Maybe try squeezing one finger really tight first. Did that hurt? Well it's going to be a lot worse in that key hole.
additionalR:
Hints
You have the ability to squeeze your fingers into locks to open them, so of course you're stealing. And you squeeze those stolen goodies into your sack so you can take them with you.
readingMnemonic: Once you've squeezed your finger in the key hole to unlock this door you squeeze all the money and jewels and treasures you can fit into your sack (さく). Your stealing sack.

meaningMnemonic: An animal with horns is drinking our alcohol? Still?
additionalM:
Hints
You keep checking outside to see if they have stopped, but they are still drinking. They haven't stopped yet.
additionalR:
Hints
You keep checking, but that youth is still drinking. Of course, you don't know they are a youth, so it's quite impressive an animal can drink this much.
readingMnemonic: The animal with horns that is still drinking your alcohol is no animal at all. It is actually one of the local youths (ゆう) dressed up like a horned animal so they can drink as long as they want and you'll be too scared to shoo them away.

meaningMnemonic: Take a mole out of its hole and it will suffocate. They need to be in tight quarters, unlike us humans. So when you take one out of its nice, safe hole, it thinks it can't breathe and suffocates.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a poor little mole suffocating in your hand after you took it out of its hole. Put it back right away! Don't kill that little mole!
additionalR:
Hints
Unfortunately, you can't use cheats on life, and the mole suddenly stiffens and suffocates to death anyway. You should feel bad about what you've done.
readingMnemonic: As the mole suffocates it cheats (ちつ) and shoves its head into your closed hand. You realize what it's doing and squeeze your hand tighter so it's more like a hole. You can feel the mole breathing again now.

meaningMnemonic: A stone drops from the sky into a rice paddy and then a cross drops on top of it. They've combined to form a tombstone! Wait, does that mean a body fell from the sky first and you just didn't see it?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing a stone and a cross drop from the sky onto each other to form a tombstone right in front of your eyes!
additionalR:
Hints
Can you feel the heat radiating off this space tombstone? Maybe there's a space skeleton sizzling under there too...
readingMnemonic: Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the tombstone it's radiating with intense heat (ひ)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere!

meaningMnemonic: You shoot an arrow at the mouth of the sun so that it will grant you a gift of wisdom. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine shooting an arrow at the mouth of the sun and then waiting for the wisdom of the world to hit you. Did it work? Will you know when it works? Probably...
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself thanking the sun for teaching you that all wisdom comes from cheese. Now take a big bite!
readingMnemonic: You're standing around waiting for the wisdom to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of cheese (ち)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And the key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese!

meaningMnemonic: "For the  samurai, it is a jackhammer that they will lack." That is the latest article of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great sincerity by the government.
additionalM:
Hints
By writing up new articles and laws they keep taking things away from samurai. First the katana, now jackhammers?
additionalR:
Hints
Genghis Khan knew that samurai were a threat to his kingdom, so he took away their secondary weapon, the jackhammer.
readingMnemonic: The one who wrote these articles with such sincerity was Genghis Khan (かん).

meaningMnemonic: The death of your eyes means that you've gone blind.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what it would be like to have one of your eyes die. You'll be blind in that eye forever!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a blind person mowing over everyone in their car as they drive on the sidewalk. Eeek. At least they don't have to see this mess.
readingMnemonic: When you're blind you probably shouldn't drive anymore because if you do you'll mow (もう) everyone over. Actually, don't mow your lawn either. Blind people probably shouldn't be driving anything.

meaningMnemonic: An alcohol nurse is someone who nurses alcohol. In other words, they brew it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a nurse brewing alcohol with the same attention they would nurse a human patient. But this brew is much more important than any person's health.
additionalR:
Hints
As you know, Jourm infiltrated your village and pretended to be a large, simple farmhand, only to bring destruction down upon you. After he was done, he sat down and drank a brew with his Viking buddies.
readingMnemonic: A brew of alcohol is what Jourm (じょう) loves most after a long day.

meaningMnemonic: The concave radical and the concave kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Watch your mouth around the 王. Have you ever seen a concave person? Yeah that's because they didn't live through it. 王s aren't very nice, you know.
readingMnemonic: If you call someone concave the 王 (おう) will find out and he'll have his guards turn you concave.

meaningMnemonic: You give a bow and a stick to your friend's family. This is because your friend died, and he loved bows and sticks. You give this to his family, to give our condolences.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine looking at the bow and stick as you slide them over to your deceased friend's family. This won't do enough, but it is a little condolence at least.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine her saying, "My condolences," as Mrs. Chou does him in.
readingMnemonic: More than a condolence, you want to avenge your friend's death. He was killed by Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she broke his stick and bow, which is why you got the family a new set.

meaningMnemonic: The convex radical and the convex kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
additionalM:
Hints
Study your radicals and you'll read good.
additionalR:
Hints
Tote bags are totes not convex though. Don't mix them up.
readingMnemonic: Is this convex? It's totes (とつ) convex!

meaningMnemonic: An altered bird is a crow! They look like birds but they're bigger and darker and smarter!
additionalM:
Hints
See that bird? Wait, that's not just a bird, it's a crow!
additionalR:
Hints
How many crows have you caressed today?
readingMnemonic: If you can't tell just from looking at it that it's a crow and not a bird, walk up to it and caress (からす) it with your hand! If it caresses you back, it's a crow! If it freaks out and flies away or pecks your face, it's a normal bird. Crows are really smart and like affection. That's what makes them so cool!

meaningMnemonic: An elf who ventures outside in winter has a lot of daring. Elf ears are very, very delicate, and the winter cold can really mess them up. So if you see an elf adventuring in winter, know that that particular elf is a really daring dude.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how much daring it would take to go outside in winter knowing you could be freezing your precious elf ears off.
additionalR:
Hints
Do you think you have the same amount of daring as an elf going out in winter and Genghis Khan? Tell the truth.
readingMnemonic: The amount of daring you'd need is about equal to the amount Genghis Khan (かん) had. And he was really daring!

meaningMnemonic: Even if you have a building, it will eventually turn back into dirt. Everything will degenerate eventually. A brick falls off here, a door comes loose there. Nothing can last forever.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a time lapse video of a building degenerating.
additionalR:
Hints
This may not be a happy thing to think about, but it will help you remember this kanji better. Imagine your dad fighting a degenerative disease. Imagine helping him fight through this. Everything will be okay eventually. I promise.
readingMnemonic: As you watch the building degenerate, you can't help but think of your dad (だ). You had to watch him waste away the same way of a degenerative disease. Why do people have to die, dad?

meaningMnemonic: You take a drum and a branch and... well, what else would you do? You would drum or beat them together.
additionalM:
Hints
A branch is just like a drumstick, so of course you're going to drum them together.
additionalR:
Hints
Kids can't get enough of it. Anything that makes a loud drumming noise or anything they can beat together is fun for them.
readingMnemonic: Who loves to drum things together and make a huge racket? 子s (こ), of course.

meaningMnemonic: You go to a big rice paddy and establish a prison right in the middle of it to restore the equilibrium of the area.
additionalM:
Hints
There was a lot of crime right here in this rice paddy, so you just built a big prison right there to lower the crime rate so this region can experience equilibrium once again.
additionalR:
Hints
The cloned こういちs were causing all the crime in these parts (or so Emperor こういち said), so by throwing them in a prison built right there just for them, this area could once again achieve equilibrium.
readingMnemonic: To restore equilibrium in these parts, you throw all the 耕ing こういち clones into the prison.

meaningMnemonic: If the leader of your gang is a drunkard he'll try to have you fell trees thinking they're rival gang members. You all know they aren't but you can't argue with your leader, especially if he's drunk. Go ahead and attack the trees anyway.
additionalM:
Hints
