Imagine felling trees with a bunch of other guys, yelling things like, "This is what you get for stepping on my turf!" It's a little silly.
additionalR:
Hints
Bats attacking bats. Who will win on this season of Survivor?
readingMnemonic: As you attack the innocent trees with your chains and sticks, a bunch of bats (ばつ) come flying out and attack YOU! You have your own kind of bats so now you're all trying to fell the bats with YOUR bats!

meaningMnemonic: Alcohol is a good teacher on the process of fermentation.
additionalM:
Hints
Because alcohol is so good and addicting, people will work extra hard to ferment it properly. This makes it a good teacher to learn about fermentation. People are motivated to figure it out!
additionalR:
Hints
You are fermenting thousands of bottles of alcohol for Emperor こういち's big party.
readingMnemonic: Using fermentation, you are indeed making some alcohol. It will be drunk at a party put on by Emperor こういち.

meaningMnemonic: Put a guard at your gate to get a good inspection of your neighborhood going. The guard will stand there all day inspecting everything and then report it all back to you. You won't have to do any of the inspection yourself!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the guard doing his inspection in front of the gate all day long. He should have a nice report for you once he's done.
additionalR:
Hints
If you hire a guard to stand at your gate and conduct an inspection of your neighborhood, make sure you tell him not to use an etch a sketch!
readingMnemonic: His inspection is complete, but it looks like he's used an etch (えつ) a sketch to record all the results. That's not really helpful. If you shake it all the inspection results will disappear!

meaningMnemonic: You're riding your scooter toward your yurt as fast as you can because someone is trying to get in there to boil your water and you want to intercept them.
additionalM:
Hints
If you manage to intercept them before they can go in there to boil things, you'll be able to pick up all the clothes and comic books you left on the floor. You really don't want anyone to see those.
additionalR:
Hints
Phew, you intercepted the shaman in time (though she doesn't look very happy about being scooted into) and now you can clean up your yurt before they go in.
readingMnemonic: You manage to intercept the shaman (しゃ) who was just about to open the door to your yurt, and instead you crash right into him.

meaningMnemonic: The moon is easy tonight, so you decide to cut it open. But, the moon wasn't the moon, it was your big, pale, round tummy. You just cut it open, and now you can see your intestines.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the moon, then imagine it cross-fading into your big, round tummy. Then, cut it open because you think the moon is easy to cut. And finally, see your intestines as clearly as you can.
additionalR:
Hints
This scene was in all the omen radicals you've been seeing about her. If only you could have stopped her, then none of this would have happened, right? Perhaps it was all destiny, you think, as your intestines fall from your stomach and Mrs. Chou cackles over your weakening body.
readingMnemonic: All over the world, people are cutting their bellies open, because they think its an easy moon (versus a normal moon, or hard moon, presumably). This is because they have fallen victim to a spell by Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaningMnemonic: The king will send his men with swords into your private rice paddy if you come across lapis lazuli. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch the king's swords digging in your private rice paddy and digging up huge chunks of lapis lazuli. This isn't fair, that lapis should belong to you.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine reading through a giant text called "The Law" and looking for this loophole the king's men claim to have about taking your lapis lazuli. You can't find it... but maybe if you search just a bit longer...
readingMnemonic: You run up and ask how this lapis lazuli thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "Loophole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?

meaningMnemonic: Your nose isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the latter. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A B and C and you'll never forget!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine saying A B C as you look down someones face at their eyes, nose and mouth. Their nose is B!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine running out of cereal so you have to eat your latter option of breakfast oats. They aren't awful but they aren't your A breakfast choice, that's for sure.
readingMnemonic: If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (おつ). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice.

meaningMnemonic: A tree that does well in the wind is a maple tree. Maple trees don't have fruit so the wind can't knock anything off of it. That's why they thrive well in windy places!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a bunch of maple trees being blown by the wind. They don't seem upset, they actually seem really happy.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your kite in the maple tree.
readingMnemonic: When the wind goes through the maple tree you know it's kite day (かえで)!

meaningMnemonic: If you trap the moon in a greenhouse it will grow a creepy membrane around itself. The moon isn't used to the heat it would be exposed to in a greenhouse so that membrane is there to protect it. It's really gross looking though.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing the moon with a membrane sitting stuffed in a greenhouse. It looks like something out of the Alien movies and you're starting to think putting it in there wasn't a good idea.
additionalR:
Hints
Can you imagine if the moon had a membrane and it smelled like a big mac? How does that even happen? You should probably go ask that food chain what they use for their ingredients.
readingMnemonic: You decide to open the greenhouse to check this moon membrane out but when you open the door the smell of big macs (まく) hits you in the face. Eww. Why does this membrane smell like a big mac... or does that mean big macs smell like a festering moon?

meaningMnemonic: If you want to turn your thread into a sweet color you just HAVE to go with navy or dark blue. That's the sweetest color in existence, everyone knows that. After all, blue raspberry flavor is dark blue and it's super sweet.
additionalM:
Hints
Turn your thread a sweet navy color and people will be reminded of yummy blue raspberry. MmMmm.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine a condor stealing your sweet navy thread right after you dyed it, flying off. Lame!
readingMnemonic: Now that your threads are navy colored you need to be careful that condors (こん) don't try to steal it for their nests. Condors love dark blue things and thread is perfect for a condor nest.

meaningMnemonic: Flowers grown in a warehouse will be very pale. They never see the sun, so they don't grow to have bright colors.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking into a warehouse and seeing hundreds of pale flowers growing in it. It's subtle, but beautiful.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a bunch of pale, soulless flowers. You pick one up and it falls apart in your hands.
readingMnemonic: When you grow pale flowers like this, they don't grow a soul (そう). Soul adds color to plants and flowers. That's probably why ghosts and dead bodies are pale too.

meaningMnemonic: Tsunamis get blamed because they pickle everything in their path. That means that everything smells of pickles after a tsunami.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a tsunami crashing over the land, being blamed by everyone. In its path is are piles and piles of pickles, as far as the eye can see!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the two pickles and imagine what kind of pickles they are.
readingMnemonic: Looking at all those pickles, you bend down and pick up two (つ) of them. One in each hand. You look at the pickles in your hand and wonder whether to try one.

meaningMnemonic: A drunkard has dirt in his mouth as he tries to talk to you. You walk over and he spits a question mark into your hand. It's covered in dirt and spit. Um... does this mean he's confused? He probably doesn't even know where he is. But how did he make this question mark and why was it in his mouth?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having a drunkard spit a dirty question mark into your hand. You want to say, "Yes, I'm ??? too."
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself throwing the question mark at the drunkard who only cares about the Yankees. What a waste of time.
readingMnemonic: The drunkard takes the question mark back and presses it to his head. He's wearing a Yankee's (や) cap. Oh come on. "Do you just want to know the Yankee's score in the game?" The drunkard nods.

meaningMnemonic: To the mountains you took your horned husband for you two to get married. (Society wouldn't accept a horned husband!) To hide even more from the prying eyes of society, you take your horned husband into a ravine.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine walking up the mountain in your wedding clothes so you can get married without anyone trying to stop you. Then, because you're still worried, you go into a ravine where you are read your marriage vows.
additionalR:
Hints
This ravine runs right through the middle of きょうと, though most people don't notice it. That makes it the best place for a secret wedding to a horned freak-husband.
readingMnemonic: The ravine is still in きょうと though, because if you went outside the city your marriage wouldn't be legal. So you found a secluded, local ravine.

meaningMnemonic: When a shellfish becomes a drunkard and sees a cross, they'll become a robber. Because they'll steal the cross!
additionalM:
Hints
Some people make really bad choices when they're drunk, and in this case, when a shellfish gets drunk and sees something it wants it'll just rob people for it.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a robber shellfish in a Bosozoku bike gang. Look at him the wrong way and he and his gang will steal all your stuff next time!
readingMnemonic: Once the shellfish has a taste for being a robber, he'll join a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang so he can keep stealing more and more crosses. He'll drink more, steal more, and get to ride cool motorcycles.

meaningMnemonic: Move your coat rack in one direction by shooting it with a gun. Then you can keep shooting it to get a good rotation going. If you think there is a better way to make your coat rack make revolutions, you're probably wrong.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine getting your coat rack to make rotations in a circle just by shooting it with a gun!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture that centaurs angry face. Convince yourself it was the rotation it didn't like.
readingMnemonic: As you watch your coat rack's rotations a centaur (せん) barges in and takes the gun from you, stops the rotating coat rack and leaves. How rude! I guess centaurs don't like when things rotate.

meaningMnemonic: The leader says spring is looking dry, so you'll need your salary in advance.
additionalM:
Hints
The leader shows you the number, it's all of your salary for spring. "This way, if things dry up worse, you'll be okay for a while," he says. This is awfully nice, but very suspicious at the same time.
additionalR:
Hints
You're sitting at home, and there is a knock at the door. A man in a suit, hat, and dark sunglasses hands you a briefcase full of money. "Here's your spring salary. Enjoy the dry weather."
"T-thanks?"
Welp, have fun at home with your stacks of early salary cash.
readingMnemonic: Your salary is sent straight to your home (ほう) instead of the bank. Okay, something is definitely fishy here.

meaningMnemonic: If you put your spoon in the sun while you're in prison, a mouth will appear to scold you. You can never see who the mouth belongs to, but considering you're in prison it's probably a guard. Either way, that person doesn't like what you're doing and they keep scolding you when you put your spoon out into the sun.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to reflect some precious sunlight into your prison room with a spoon. Now imagine a mouth appearing in the way of the sunlight and it scolds you.
additionalR:
Hints
WHAT KIND OF WORLD IS THIS THAT YOU'RE IN A PRISON WHERE CATS SCOLD YOU?!
readingMnemonic: One day you finally get fed up. You need to know who the mouth of the person who's scolding you is. You stick your spoon out into the sun and the mouth appears, scolding you right on time. You reach out and grab them. But in your hand is a pile of cats (かつ).

meaningMnemonic: You have a net of thread for catching a turkey. But, it must be spread out and you must arrange it first.
additionalM:
Hints
The reason you'd use a net made of thread is because it's hard to see. But, it's only that way when you spread out the net. It's important to spread out and arrange your net otherwise the turkey will see it.
additionalR:
Hints
"Let me out of this net!" says Ra. "You arranged and spread it out just right so I couldn't see it!"
readingMnemonic: You spread out your net and arrange it just so. You expect it to catch a turkey, but instead you catch the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら).

meaningMnemonic: You have to put flowers in a bright place if you want them to sprout. If they're left in the shade they'll just rot.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your flowers sprouting out of the ground in the bright spring sun.
additionalR:
Hints
Take a walk around your home right now. Can you find the best place to sprout flowers? Remember, it has to be nice and bright! Not dark and damp. Don't put them in your closet.
readingMnemonic: You want to grow these sprouts in your home (ほう), not outside. So you need to find the windows in your house that are the brightest.

meaningMnemonic: A tree melts into the ground after listening to loud music in the hot sun, so you have to find a nice big tank to scoop the melted tree into. The music made the tree vibrate at juuust the right frequency that it, combined with the hot sun, made the tree turn into a puddle. You can't just leave it being all blobby on the ground, so you find a tank for it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine scooping a melted tree into a tank. It's a very strange sensation.
additionalR:
Hints
"Um, okay?" you reply to the soul, and walk away from the tank. "W-wait! Tanks can't move? Come back, let me haunt you with my tree soul!"
It's a good thing there weren't wheels on that tank!
readingMnemonic: You're staring at the big tank when an eerie sound comes out, "Oooh I am the soul (そう) of the tree! You've trapped me in this tank and now I'm going to haunt it!" You don't want to be haunted by a tank with a soul stuck in it.

meaningMnemonic: The amount of dirt you need to get some peace is a two mat area. Two tatami mats, that is. This is a pretty common measurement in Japan, so you should get really familiar with the amount of space that two tatami mats take up together.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture how big a two mat area is. Lay down and feel the peace this much space brings to you.
additionalR:
Hints
Try to picture a two mat area with two bodies laying in it. Whether they're alive or dead is up to you.
readingMnemonic: A two mat area also happens to be big enough to hold two bodies (つぼ). That's enough space to bring peace to two living, or dead, bodies!

meaningMnemonic: Riding a scooter to the library is a universal experience. People young and old have all, at some point, taken a scooter to the library, picked up a book, used the internet, sat in the comfy chairs, then left via that same scooter.
additionalM:
Hints
Scooters and libraries are universally loved by all!
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you scoot to the library look around. There are little hen scooters and hens there with their chicks. They're reading them books about grains and how to hatch eggs. It's a universally adorable thing to see.
readingMnemonic: Riding a scooter to the library is so universal, even hens (へん) do it.

meaningMnemonic: The machine in your body that is powered by the moon is your womb, also called your uterus! Haven't you ever wondered why periods happen with the revolutions of the moon? That's because it powers your uterus and tells it what to do!
additionalM:
Hints
The next time you're cursing your uterus for making you bleed, curse the moon instead! It's the moon's fault you're in pain.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture an invisible tie tieing your uterus to the moon. Damn you moon, stop pulling, it hurts!
readingMnemonic: It kind of sucks, but there is no way to sever this uterus - moon tie (たい). But if you find a way please tell me, I can't take this anymore.

meaningMnemonic: The building clown is the only clown allowed to accompany you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together.
additionalM:
Hints
I know it's been a long time, but try not to mix this one up with 	部, if you can. Remember, the clown building is in another part of town and the clowns aren't supposed to leave. But the building clown is okay to accompany you through the rest of the city.
additionalR:
Hints
Wave bye to the clown, he'll accompany you on your building job tomorrow, but right now he has to go home and be with the rest of his clown people. He can't accompany you after dark.
readingMnemonic: He can only accompany you for so long though and soon it's time to say bye (ばい) again.

meaningMnemonic: Put your fingers on your husband to aid him. There's something about a spouse's touch that just makes you feel better. Have you ever had someone rub your back while you were hurt or sick or sad? It's nice, right?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine rubbing your husband's back with your fingers to aid him. You want him to feel better. You want him to get that comforting feeling that this kind of touching gives.
additionalR:
Hints
That's true love, my friend.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, your husband wouldn't need your aid if he wasn't such a fool (ふ). He walks into doors, he falls down the stairs, he touches the plate when the waiter says it's hot. And every single time your fool husband hurts himself, you aid him.

meaningMnemonic: When your scooter has a fault, you need to get an alternate. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too.
additionalM:
Hints
You have a scooter that you drive every single day, but if you notice a fault, you need to send it in to get it fixed. That's when you break out your alternate scooter.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine riding on your alternate 鉄 scooter. Feel the hard iron under your bum and the loud sounds it makes as you scoot down the street. I hope your normal scooter is fixed soon.
readingMnemonic: The alternate scooter is made entirely of 鉄 (てつ). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter.

meaningMnemonic: Your husband was wearing his cleats when he accidentally stepped on a bird. Luckily this particular bird is a chicken, and chickens are really durable!
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the sad, stepped on chicken. It's angrily clucking and chasing your husband around your yard for what he did.
additionalR:
Hints
This cake was for your husband, but now he gets nothing. The chicken gets to eat all of the cake in front of him instead.
readingMnemonic: The only way to stop the chicken from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the cake (けい) you were making.

meaningMnemonic: The king raked all the mountains down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your congratulations with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine saying "Congratulations!" to a king who just ordered his servants to rake down all the pretty mountains in his kingdom.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine how hollow your congratulation sounds when you really miss those mountains. This king doesn't deserve your nice words.
readingMnemonic: The moment you say "Congratulations!" you've already started to miss (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!

meaningMnemonic: Gamblers usually only see the sun at dawn. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being a gambler and seeing the bright dawn sun when you come out of the casino or pachinko parlor. It burns your eyes! Evil dawn, get back inside quick!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine getting up at dawn and seeing the あかつき in the sky near the sun. It's so beautiful!
readingMnemonic: If you're up at dawn you'll also see the あか (red) つき (moon). The あかつき only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too!

meaningMnemonic: A clown takes a knife and divides himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?!
additionalM:
Hints
Instead of dying, the clown divides into slightly thinner clowns.
additionalR:
Hints
The many clowns crash to the floor as the bowling ball plows through their... his(?) divided bodies. You can't bear to look anymore.
readingMnemonic: The clown finally stops trying to divide himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over!

meaningMnemonic: If you touch ice for too long you'll get frostbite and that's a really hard thing to endure. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having to endure the pain of frostbite because you were a jerk who put his hand on ice for a few hours.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine if you were one of these cool Shinobi ninjas that could endure the extreme cold and pain of frostbite!
readingMnemonic: The best people in the world at being able to endure the pain are the shinobi (しの) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice.

meaningMnemonic: You have to reach a certain number of flowers and tsunamis hits to become a legitimate fiefdom. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being the person who has to check whether each fiefdom has enough flowers and tsunamis per year to keep their status.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Han Solo flying around Japan checking to make sure all the fiefdoms are up to code.
readingMnemonic: The most famous fiefdom checker is Han (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!

meaningMnemonic: If you say the lineup of your family members that have lived on this earth under the sun, you're really explaining your genealogy.
additionalM:
Hints
Say the line up of what happened under the sun. It's the genealogy of your family or the score of your game!
additionalR:
Hints
Your family genealogy and your game's score aren't even close to being the same thing. Memorize these or everyone will think you're a fool.
readingMnemonic: if you can't tell the difference between your genealogy and a game's score you're a fool (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.

meaningMnemonic: The king wants you to make a rocket that looks glassy. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a king who won't accept a rocket that isn't made of glassy material. He's not very smart...
additionalR:
Hints
Picture the king admiring himself in the glassy surface and then his face contorts. He smashes his fist through the rocket and rips out the reeds. "REEDS AREN'T GLASSY!" he cries, and starts hitting you with them.
readingMnemonic: You take the glassy rocket and try to stuff some thin reeds (り) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second.

meaningMnemonic: You can only manage to avoid a tsunami by standing above it on a small stool if you are very graceful. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being graceful enough to balance on a small stool above a raging tsunami! Sooo cool!
additionalR:
Hints
It doesn't matter how badly the stool shook, you stayed graceful and didn't fall!
readingMnemonic: No matter how graceful you are, the still tsunami shook (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.

meaningMnemonic: The leader does a dance on top of the tree to show his greatness to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his excellence!
additionalM:
Hints
"Look upon your leader's greatness!" he shouts, doing a jig around on the branches.
additionalR:
Hints
"Oh leader, your greatness is so... great!" you shout up at him. He's holding the ketsup bottle over your head and staring into your eyes as he dances in the tree. He isn't sure if he wants to dump it on you yet. He isn't sure if you really recognize his excellence.
readingMnemonic: If you don't recognize the leader's greatness he will throw ketsup (けつ) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing.

meaningMnemonic: A samurai puts his forehead on the table next to his weapon. He is just a husk of his former self. This shell of a samurai has nothing left.
additionalM:
Hints
He's just sitting there, he can't even pick up his weapon or raise his head anymore.
additionalR:
Hints
"Co co co co cooooock!" the cock screams, shocking the samurai back into his lifeless shell. You did it!
readingMnemonic: The only way to bring a husk of a samurai back to life is to have a cock (かく) crow right in his ear.
mainReading: かく, こく, ばい

meaningMnemonic: This is a gold roof, correct? It's important to lock it up, then.
additionalM:
Hints
It's only natural that you'd want to lock a gold roof so nobody can steal it.
additionalR:
Hints
He's the big farmhand who turned out to be an undercover Viking in your town, only to pillage and destroy everything. Under the gold roof is where he locked up all your village's valuables, after wiping you all out.
readingMnemonic: The person who locked the gold roof was Jourm (じょう).

meaningMnemonic: A sweet woman sits under a tree and works as a mediator. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the sweet tree woman being a mediator for you and your arch rival. What she says fixes everything between you two!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine her refusing to let you pay her for her mediator services and just saying "bye" over and over until you leave. Weird.
readingMnemonic: You go to pay the woman for being your mediator for you two but she just says, "Bye ばい)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then.

meaningMnemonic: If a tsunami gets into a net that's imprisoning a bunch of insects, the insects are going to get all muddy. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a net prison full of insects being dragged by a tsunami getting muddier and muddier. Poor buggles!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture a bunch of muddy ducks munching on some muddy trapped insects, in a some muddy leftover tsunami water.
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately for the insects, these muddy conditions have created the perfect habitat for ducks (だく). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat!

meaningMnemonic: The only tree a turkey will live in is an oak tree. They really only do this because oak trees have really yummy acorns and turkeys loooove acorns.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing a turkey sitting in an oak tree munching on acorns. You didn't even know turkeys could fly, but it got up there somehow.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine standing in a grove of oak trees and yelling SOOEY! SOOOOOEY! Now watch as hundreds of turkeys come flying at your face! They think you have more acorns for them. RUN!
readingMnemonic: If you see a bunch of oaks but no turkeys just yell, "SOOEY (つい)!" and they'll all come jumping out! Just because you can't see a turkey in there doesn't mean there isn't one!

meaningMnemonic: If you spill something red on yourself in winter you should pardon yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine spilling red wine or red paint down your shirt. Quickly pardon yourself and get changed now!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine not pardoning yourself fast enough and having the winter shaman spirit away whatever you got red on. That's embarrassing.
readingMnemonic: If you don't pardon yourself fast enough the winter shaman (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked!

meaningMnemonic: Throw a drunkard in a cage with a tiger and some spikes and the tiger will have the time of its life playing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities!
additionalM:
Hints
If you were the tiger how would you play with the drunkard?
additionalR:
Hints
What would you rather watch? A guillotine at work or a tiger playing like this?
readingMnemonic: If you aren't the tiger, watching it play is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a guillotine (ぎ). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore.

meaningMnemonic: If someone gives you a sock you should receive it and thank them. You can't just say no or put the sock on the ground and walk away. You should always receive a sock properly, with both hands, when it's handed to you.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine Dobby reaching out to receive his first sock. Don't you want to be happy like that too?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine standing in きょうと and receiving sock after sock. People just keep giving and you keep receiving!
readingMnemonic: The best place to receive a sock is in きょうと. They're famous for their sock stores and schoolgirls who have too many socks. If you walk down the street someone is bound to try to hand you a sock in きょうと, and you should receive it happily.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to take a flag out of the mouth of a mantis you have to make a formal request first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to request a flag from a scary mantis that has it sitting in it's mouth. Will it give it to you? Will it bite you? You'll have to wait and see.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your shock at finding out the mantis not only understood your request, but agreed! This is great but also makes you wonder what other creatures can understand you...
readingMnemonic: After you request the mantis give you its flag it shocks (しょく) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked!

meaningMnemonic: You see a triceratops standing in front of a full moon and you can't help but see a really strong resemblance. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon!
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the triceratops. Now look at the moon. See the resemblance? Uncanny, don't you think?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine being the Shougun and seeing the resemblance between a triceratops and the moon for the first time. You'd put that on all your stuff too, if you were him.
readingMnemonic: The first person to see this resemblance was the Shougun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.

meaningMnemonic: You see a soul on a cross covered in flowers with shellfish at its feet and you suddenly resent them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you...
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the soul on the cross, flowers all around it and shellfish at its feet. Feel your resentment grow.
additionalR:
Hints
You wanna have fun hanging out on a cross with flowers and all the shellfish you can eat. Your resentment grows and grows as you watch the soul having everything you suddenly want.
readingMnemonic: You realize you resent them because it looks like they're having fun (ふん). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't!

meaningMnemonic: As the tsunami hits your scooter and your car, it alters the wave, creating ripples.
additionalM:
Hints
They're hard to see because a tsunami is pretty big, but your scooter and car do create ripples in the water as it goes past.
additionalR:
Hints
As you watch the ripples come off your car / scooter, be sure to imagine the relief you'd feel if you knew they were rentals and not something owned by you.
readingMnemonic: Ripples come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were rentals (れん), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami.

meaningMnemonic: A tree is stuck in a prison under the ground and it's starting to rot and decay.
additionalM:
Hints
Trees can't live without sunlight, and it's too damp underground in a prison. The water gets all moldy and the tree will rot and die.
additionalR:
Hints
This poor cucumber tree, left in this ground prison to rot. There's nothing worse than eating a rotten cucumber.
readingMnemonic: You get close to the rotting tree and see some rotten cucumbers (きゅう) hanging from its branches. No!

meaningMnemonic: You're walking down the street when you see twenty big crosses lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to run as fast as you can to get past them.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to run down a street with twenty big crosses lining it. It's so scary that you keep running faster and faster as you go.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine distracting yourself from the scary crosses by honing your running skills while you do it.
readingMnemonic: You figure since you're already on the run that you might as well hone (ほん) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.

meaningMnemonic: You hoist your towel above your table, drop into the water and sail away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine sailing out into the open sea, drops of water hitting your face, as the towel sail catches the air and carries you away.
additionalR:
Hints
You sail nervously past Han Solo who also seems to be sailing, though in worse shape than you. But he keeps throwing you finger guns so you figure it's best to just sail on and pretend this never happened.
readingMnemonic: As you sail off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" Han (はん) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water.

meaningMnemonic: The flowers that grow on your roof that look like a sleeping bear is sedge. Sedge grow all over the world!
additionalM:
Hints
You've probably seen them before, you just didn't know what they were called! Looks like a green sleeping bear bum, right?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine biting into a sedge flower and tasting the yummy sugary taste. Mmmm.
readingMnemonic: The next time you see a sedge bite into it. It tastes like sugar (すが)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear.

meaningMnemonic: Pour all of your alcohol in the pool to serve all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine serving all of your guests their alcohol by dumping it all in the pool! Now jump in and drink all you want!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Shaq serving your guests by tossing them into your alcohol filled pool. Thanks, Shaq... I guess.
readingMnemonic: As you serve your guests (and yourself) you look over and see Shaq (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.

meaningMnemonic: Deep in your soul, you feel like you want to pull your fangs out by the root, but instead you let out a loud sigh. You're one of the only people you know that has fangs, and it weighs heavily on your soul.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all of the other people staring and pointing, the kids making fun of you, no one seeing you as equal. And just... sigh. Deep down, you want to get rid of your fangs, but you can't do it.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you're staring in the mirror at yourself. You sigh loudly and take out the pliers. You'll be a guy like everyone else. S-soon. As soon as you can muster up enough strength to stop sighing and rip these fangs out.
readingMnemonic: You sigh again and say, "I wish I was just a normal guy (がい)." I swear the rest of me is a guy like the rest of you. *sigh*

meaningMnemonic: Put thread in the mouth of a worm while the moon is out and it will poop out some silk. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture feeding some thread into the mouth of a worm as the light from the full moon shines in on you. See the silk come out of the worm's butt and into your hands.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Ken with a silk helmet, silk fundoshi, and a silk sheath for his sword.
readingMnemonic: The biggest fan of silk is Ken (けん) the samurai. Everything he wears is silk, even his armor.

meaningMnemonic: You see seven swords just sitting in a hole and so you decide to steal them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right?
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing seven swords just laying abandoned in a hole. Feel the urge to steal them all. Do it, do it!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine your delight as you look up the different sword sets online and realize you happened to steal the best one!
readingMnemonic: You steal the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword sets (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal!

meaningMnemonic: There are stones that smell like trash in the river. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of sulfur. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks.
additionalM:
Hints
If you haven't smelled sulfur before, it smells a bit like rotten eggs. Something that definitely belongs in the trash.
additionalR:
Hints
Ryu looks down at you, holding the sulfurous rock in one hand. Then he uppercuts you with it! Shoryuken!
readingMnemonic: You throw the sulfur rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there.

meaningMnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both Asia.
additionalM:
Hints
As long as you know the radical Asia, you know the kanji Asia.
additionalR:
Hints
A is for Asia!
readingMnemonic: What's the first sound in Asia? It's A (あ). Nice and easy!

meaningMnemonic: The barracks radical and the barracks kanji are the same!
additionalM:
Hints
Know your radicals, yo!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to lift some barracks. They weigh a ton! How are you supposed to do this? Why would you even try to lift something that obviously weighs a couple tons?!
readingMnemonic: Barracks are pretty big, so they weigh a ton (とん). And they probably take tons of materials to build.

meaningMnemonic: You see a mountain in the shape of a turtle shell sticking out into the ocean. It's a cape! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
additionalR:
Hints
The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.
readingMnemonic: You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).

meaningMnemonic: Take three measurements of gold and slide them into a mold to make a cast! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself carefully measuring out the three portions of gold and sliding them into your mold to make a cast of whatever you want. I wonder what it could be?
additionalR:
Hints
Picture your majestic Chewbacca casts. Carefully set them outside your front door to guard you. This was a great idea!
readingMnemonic: You open the cast to reveal your gold statue of Chewbacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.

meaningMnemonic: You have to use your fingers to make an exit because you're so clumsy. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the nob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave.
additionalM:
Hints
Of course, you're too clumsy to do that right either, you accidentally threw the door backwards and hurt some people...
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine trying to use your clumsy fingers all over the sets of doors. You keep falling over and hurting yourself. Why is it so hard to leave?!
readingMnemonic: After you make your clumsy mistake you realize that these doors come in sets (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors!

meaningMnemonic: If you want to say how eternity sounds you have to compose a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. Recite those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it.
additionalM:
Hints
Try to compose a poem about eternity right now. Just jot it down somewhere.
additionalR:
Hints
Let me recite the acorn poem to you now:
Acorns start small
Grow up big and tall
Spread their baby acorns for all
Live on for all eternity
readingMnemonic: You decide to compose a poem about an acorn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you.

meaningMnemonic: If a pilot manages to land under a canopy with a helicopter that's pierced with a sideways barb in the heart of winter you should congratulate them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!
additionalM:
Hints
Can you imagine how hard landing a helicopter in just one of these horrible conditions? Congratulate them!
additionalR:
Hints
Cake is always the appropriate celebratory food.
readingMnemonic: Congratulate the pilot with cake (けい)!

meaningMnemonic: You can only give a kiss of alcohol to dairy. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine trying to give more than a kiss of alcohol to dairy and watch it bubble and curdle and get all gross and chunky.
additionalR:
Hints
Look at all your dairy products: milk, yogurt, cheese, all of it sitting nicely on your dairy rack.
readingMnemonic: Dairy isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a rack (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!

meaningMnemonic: If someone makes a bamboo horse, you know it's deliberate. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo.
additionalM:
Hints
Someone sat down and deliberately planned the entire horse out, collected the materials, and made it by hand.
additionalR:
Hints
Tokugawa Ieyasu then poofs out of existence and so does the bamboo horse.
readingMnemonic: As you admire all the deliberate details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions."

meaningMnemonic: Every leader will come to despise their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine yourself as a leader who's come to despise every single one of their followers. Look down at them in disgust as they ask you to grant them all a pony.
additionalR:
Hints
This is not a healthy way to handle things! If you despise someone you should talk to them, don't turn to booze. Don't be like every leader that's come before you.
readingMnemonic: The more you despise them, the more booze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people.

meaningMnemonic: If there is dirt in a crab trap, it's a lot for the crabs to endure.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine a little crab getting stuck in a crab trap with dirt and other crabs. Endure the horror as long as you can, little friend.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself putting a collar around the crab's neck, then adding a leash and taking your crab for a walk around your neighborhood.
readingMnemonic: You decide to make the little crab that endured being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a collar (こら) round its little neck.

meaningMnemonic: A spirit wearing two mustaches must be evil. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil.
additionalM:
Hints
Look at the evil spirit with two mustaches on its spirit face. Imagine its face in detail, especially those mustaches.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine running around, flailing your arms, trying to get the spirit to stop ruining your car. But your hands go right through him and his two mustaches. You can't stop his evil doings.
readingMnemonic: You're watching the evil mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your car (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil!

meaningMnemonic: If you can stop a turkey by putting a spoon in its face you'll know it's a female turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the female turkey stopping when it sees you holding out a spoon. Why are you doing that human? it thinks. Are you sick?
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine watching a female turkey make a mess of her own cage because she thinks you need help. How sweet.
readingMnemonic: The female turkey then runs around making a mess (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.

meaningMnemonic: If you see someone eyeing your womb you're probably going to be weirded out by how friendly they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine having someone you aren't friendly with trying to have a look at your womb. No thank you.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine only letting this guy start to introduce himself with ぼく before walking the heck outta there. Just because he was acting friendly doesn't mean he was actually your friend.
readingMnemonic: This friendly guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "ぼく-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out.

meaningMnemonic: If you stay up for so long that you get to watch the moon go down and the dawn come, then people will say you have serious guts. Staying up that late is really hard, and not everyone can do it. If you don't have the guts to stay up, you'll just fall asleep and never see the moon and the sun switch places in the sky.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the guts you'd have to have to stay up for so long that you see the moon and the sun switch places! A lot of guts!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine having the guts to stay outside to watch the moon and the sun and then getting a really deep tan from it.
readingMnemonic: You were outside for so long, proving you had guts, that you also got a sweet tan (たん) out of it! It's a really deep tan though, and you probably need more guts if you ever want to do all that again.

meaningMnemonic: You try to use your fingers to cast doubt on people by using them to imitate each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your angry friend standing up next to your fingers, shouting, "I'm the real me! That's just an imitation!" The rest of your friends look nervously at each other. They doubt this person is real now.
additionalR:
Hints
Okay, so that's a lie, Your fingers are definitely imitating them, but you don't want to end up in the guillotine so you keep your mouth shut.
readingMnemonic: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to imitate is the imitation now and they have them in a guillotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation.

meaningMnemonic: A tsunami hits a tree and your hat protects you from the water, but the hat itself is now covered in lacquer. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture your hat and all of the other things the tsunami + tree water touched. It's all been hardened with a thick coating of the lacquer.
additionalR:
Hints
Watch as your shih tzu tries to bite your now lacquered chair. It gets its teeth around the leg, but it's hard as a rock. The shih tzu starts sneezing and spitting, letting go. Looks like it tastes bad too. Perfect!
readingMnemonic: You decide to scoop up the rest of the lacquer water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your shih tzu (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore!

meaningMnemonic: You see a gate with a tree growing through it and it reminds you that you need more leisure time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine spending your leisure time curled up under a tree that's growing through a gate. It's so cozy and secluded!
additionalR:
Hints
But wait. Isn't Genghis Khan dead now? He winks at you, "Leisure time is for the dead." He smiles, and fades away, disappearing into the tree.
readingMnemonic: As you leisurely nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis Khan (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you.

meaningMnemonic: Your soul stands in the village you long for. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you yearn for it.
additionalM:
Hints
Have you ever been away from your village? Maybe you're far away right now, studying Japanese alone. Can't you feel your body longing for your soul back home?
additionalR:
Hints
You long for a cougar to leave you alone! You yearn for a cougar to bother someone else!
readingMnemonic: No matter how much you long for it, you can't go back because a cougar (あこが) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in.

meaningMnemonic: You drop to the ground in a rice paddy, and then drop down in front of the cross you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as lowly as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine dropping down in a rice paddy, then again in front of your cross. Be as lowly as you can make yourself.
additionalR:
Hints
You tried to make yourself lowly in front of God but this heat is probably a sign that you didn't do it well enough.
readingMnemonic: The only problem about being lowly is the heat (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?

meaningMnemonic: You meet a woman whose mouth is big and you instantly know this is the person you want to marry.
additionalM:
Hints
When you think about the person you want to marry, picture their mouth wide in a big, beautiful smile, a wide-open laugh. That's the lady for you, alright!
additionalR:
Hints
When you get to the inn all you do is make her laugh and smile so you can bask in her bright, big, mouth smiles.
readingMnemonic: You marry this woman right away and you both go straight to an inn (いん) together!

meaningMnemonic: If you only let oneself (yourself) into your heart, you'll end up mourning all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself all alone. You never let anyone into your heart but yourself, and now you're mourning the life and friends you could have had.
additionalR:
Hints
You try to push the key back into your body. Back into your eye, you even try to swallow it, but it comes back out. Finally you look down at your mourning heart and try the key there. It clicks. And opens.
readingMnemonic: While you're in mourning, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A key (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning?

meaningMnemonic: When underground music makes it out into the light of the sun (the public), it finally becomes official. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.
additionalM:
Hints
Think of all that music you listened to underground but not in the light of the sun. None of that was official music. None of it!
additionalR:
Hints
The official music penetrates into your soul, instead of just your ears, and it's affecting everyone else's souls too! Oh no... wait that's too many people. This was your song! No, it's too popular now, stop your souls from liking it! Ahhh!
readingMnemonic: Once the music is official, you'll feel it in your soul (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too.

meaningMnemonic: If you're on a mountain looking from above to below that means you're on the peak of the mountain.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine standing right at the peak of a mountain looking at down from above and everything down below. You're really, really high up!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture yourself sitting on a mountain peak in Tokyo and watching a little Tokyo gecko run up and down on them. It's adorable and totally worth the climb.
readingMnemonic: It's only on this type of mountain peak that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable Tokyo gecko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!

meaningMnemonic: We want you to say things with your mouth right now because it's recital time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!
additionalM:
Hints
The recital is happening now. So open your mouth and start already!
additionalR:
Hints
Drink gin before all your recitals! It'll help!
readingMnemonic: Here, if you are too afraid to start the recital now drink this gin (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!

meaningMnemonic: The stone that looks like a turkey boiling underwater is just a reef.
additionalM:
Hints
It may seem like there are a bunch of turkeys under there, but it's just the shape the reef takes. Though I guess if you're looking from above the water it really does look like a bunch of turkeys freaking out.
additionalR:
Hints
You don't know if the Shougun likes the reef because he likes the beauty of the ocean, or if he's fantasizing about turkeys boiling. He's a... complex man.
readingMnemonic: The reef is the Shougun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours.

meaningMnemonic: People think tsunamis are only made of water but they have a few pieces of sand in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how those few grains of sand feel to get swept up into a tsunami. They didn't ask for this. They just wanted to stay at the bottom of the sea.
additionalR:
Hints
I saw the sand, stop doubting me!
readingMnemonic: How do I know there's sand in there? Because I saw (さ) them!

meaningMnemonic: In a flowers net a drunkard slides down like a drop. There they stay, an icon of scorn and neglect.
additionalM:
Hints
It's embarrassing to fall down a flowers net while drunk. Despite that, there you are. Everyone who goes by scorns you or neglects you.
additionalR:
Hints
You try to get up, but no matter how much you "bets you" someone that you can get up, you slide back down the flowers net. "I bets you I can do it next time," you say.
readingMnemonic: Every time you receive scorn and neglect from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I bets you (べつ) I can get up if I want. I bets you I can."

meaningMnemonic: If the tsunami that's heading for your village is fat you should try to select a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine being at the tsunami store and selecting the least fat one there.
additionalR:
Hints
While you select the tsunami that's right for you. Keep an eye out for those fat taco-eating ones. And then stay away from them!
readingMnemonic: If you're having trouble selecting which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating tacos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.

meaningMnemonic: Move thread in the right direction and you'll end up spinning it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine spinning thread into whatever your imagination wants.
additionalR:
Hints
Picture all of these thread-made bowling items. You're a really big bowling fan, huh?
readingMnemonic: While you're spinning you realize that you've always wanted to make your own bowling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes.

meaningMnemonic: Going from a scooter to a helicopter that's big even for yourself (oneself), is huge transition.
additionalM:
Hints
It's an upward transition, so that's nice, but it's still going to take you a long time to get used to using a big helicopter instead of a scooter.
additionalR:
Hints
A centaur is just a human halfway between transitioning into a horse, so it isn't even that hard to do!
readingMnemonic: You decide one transition isn't enough, so you transition to a centaur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better.

meaningMnemonic: There were lots of things that were above you when you were small that you would need a stool to reach, so you just asked your aunt or uncle to get them for you.
additionalM:
Hints
Your parents didn't want you having those things, which is why they put them up high, but your aunt and uncle would always spoil you and get them for you.
additionalR:
Hints
You aren't supposed to wear your obi unless it's a special occasion, but your aunt and uncle don't know that. Now you can run around with it on your head and your parents can't stop you by putting it up high!
readingMnemonic: You ask your aunt and uncle to help you reach your special obi (お) from high up in the closet.

meaningMnemonic: Making a mnemonic for a crab trap is VERY hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!
additionalM:
Hints
How hard is it to come up with a good mnemonic for a crab trap? Very hard!
additionalR:
Hints
How many sentences can you make with very and jeans? More than me I hope.
readingMnemonic: You know what else is very something? Jeans (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.

meaningMnemonic: The tsunami that is good. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you wander the lands in search of it.
additionalM:
Hints
You wander everywhere, with no particular direction in mind.
additionalR:
Hints
Wherever the good tsunami goes, it leaves delicious fish roe behind. That's what makes it a good tsunami.
readingMnemonic: As you wander, you come across a clue. It is fish roe (ろう).

meaningMnemonic: You make a tree spicy by turning it into a wood block print. The spice comes from all the porn you put on there. What? It wasn't me. Porn wood blocks have been around for ages!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the journey a tree took to become a spicy wood block. MmMmm.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine using a zoo saw to cut the blocks out of a tree that you're going to spice up with awesome smut.
readingMnemonic: You make these wood blocks using a zoo saw (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these wood blocks are gonna get once they're covered in dirty pictures.

meaningMnemonic: Under the mountain's roof are people using jackhammers to worship the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them.
additionalM:
Hints
Man your own jackhammer! (And worship the gods.)
additionalR:
Hints
You try to argue that you can't sue someone for the way they choose to worship, but they say they're all deaf now, all the animals have gone, and no one sleeps anymore because of the shaking. Yikes, they might have a case!
readingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others worship in the mountain and they're going to sue (すう) you for the noise.

meaningMnemonic: Set fire to a geoduck if you want to annoy it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how annoyed you would be if someone set YOU on fire for no reason. The geoduck has every reason to find you annoying, dude.
additionalR:
Hints
Think how annoying it must be to be a geoduck when Han Solo comes around.
readingMnemonic: You know who loves annoying geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? Han (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun.

meaningMnemonic: Red insects only bite barbarians. If a red insect bites you then you have barbarian blood! Waaay back a barbarian was your aunt or uncle or great great grand pappy! But the insects kinda hurt, so it's a bit of a downside I guess.
additionalM:
Hints
If you see a red insect follow it and see who it bites. Then you'll know that person is at least part barbarian.
additionalR:
Hints
Thanks to those Ray Bans you still don't know what a real life barbarian looks like. After going to all the trouble of following a red bug too. What a waste.
readingMnemonic: You follow the red insect and see it bite someone who must be a barbarian! You look up at their face but all you can see are giant Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. You really want to look at his face to see what a barbarian looks like but those darn things are in the way!

meaningMnemonic: Under this canopy is the Mona Lisa, being sold for cheap, what a great bargain! You never know what kind of bargains you'll find when you look under a canopy at the wares of a traveling salesperson.
additionalM:
Hints
Look really closely at this Mona Lisa. Hmm, I don't remember her having a mustache, but I guess it is a little dark under this canopy.
additionalR:
Hints
The salesperson pulls the painting away and mutters, "Ah, yes, well this is such a good bargain already! And besides... it's already a rental, you see. From the, uh, the Louvre. So you really should just take this bargain and buy it!"
readingMnemonic: You want to make sure this bargain is as good as it seems, so you ask if you can get this Mona Lisa as a rental (れん). Just for now, so you can make sure it's real before you buy it at that low, low price.

meaningMnemonic: If you want to slice the power out of someone just censure them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself as you slice the power out of that senator you hate by censuring them in front of the world!
additionalR:
Hints
Look at that guy now. What a loser.
readingMnemonic: Once you censure them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another guy (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA!

meaningMnemonic: If you think a tree looks sweet you have to be certain before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching.
additionalM:
Hints
Which tree do you think is sweet? That one? Or that one? Are you absolutely certain? I hope you are!
additionalR:
Hints
So now let me ask you again, are you certain, or would you like to try the bowling ball test?
readingMnemonic: If you really want to be certain, and not just guess, take out your bowling (ぼう) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you.

meaningMnemonic: An arrow is shot from heaven and hits right between your mouth and your mustache to correct your crooked smile. It also straightens your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you.
additionalM:
Hints
An arrow from heaven will correct all your problems!
additionalR:
Hints
If you want someone to correct your teeth or mustache, just wander around きょうと, staring up at the sky. Then when you see an arrow, run for it and try to catch it with your face!
readingMnemonic: These heavenly correcting arrows actually come from きょうと. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky.

meaningMnemonic: Inside this giant mouth is a person, trapped, because they're a criminal. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the criminal, trapped inside the mouth. They don't even look sorry!
additionalR:
Hints
Wearing nothing but shoes is also really uncomfortable too, so it's actually part of the criminal's punishment. They don't seem to know that though.
readingMnemonic: The criminal is only wearing shoes (しゅう). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise.

meaningMnemonic: You ate some grains that made you so sick it feels like a knife is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called diarrhea. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine back to the last time you ate something bad and it gave you diarrhea. It felt like someone was sticking you with a knife, didn't it?
additionalR:
Hints
You learned this reed technique from a group of ninjas who use them to breathe underwater, and you never thought you'd use them like this.
readingMnemonic: The diarrhea is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow reeds (り) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you.

meaningMnemonic: If you ride a scooter with your fingers around an axe you're going to die. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture someone else riding a scooter with an axe in their fingertips. That's so dangerous! One bump, one bad turn, and that axe slips and they'll die.
additionalR:
Hints
Your holy blue saber died for you. It saved you from certain death and now it died. After all you've been through together. All 60 levels. This is the end.
readingMnemonic: You slip. The axe collides with your face. You die. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue saber (せい) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead.

meaningMnemonic: The animal that hangs out in melon patches is the elusive fox! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine seeing a red fox scampering through a melon patch trying to take melons with it.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine buying kits that neigh and putting them around your melon patch to warn you when foxes are around.
readingMnemonic: If you want to stop foxes from stealing your melons you can get one of those kits that neigh (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back!

meaningMnemonic: You're stuck in your car during a tsunami and all you have to break out is an axe. You whack and whack but you're only gradually making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine gradually denting your car door open with an axe while you're trapped in a tsunami. This isn't fast enough!
additionalR:
Hints
YO YANKEES! Gradually yelling that saved your life!
readingMnemonic: As you're gradually making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "YO YANKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open.

meaningMnemonic: You see twenty slides lined up like a grid. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper?
additionalM:
Hints
Picture twenty slides laid out in a grid systems.
additionalR:
Hints
You can make a grid out of anything if you set your mind to it. And you can do math anywhere as long as you have some grid paper!
readingMnemonic: As you stare at the slide grid you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass maths (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later!

meaningMnemonic: Have you heard the tale of the woman who fell in love with a coat rack during a full moon and made him her groom? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the grooms side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what it would be like to fall in love with a coat rack and make it YOUR groom.
additionalR:
Hints
Could you love a moose coat enough to marry it?
readingMnemonic: The best part of the story is that the only coat on the coat rack groom was a moose coat (むこ). So the groom was a really skinny stick with a giant moose hair coat hanging down it.

meaningMnemonic: This cage is full of flowers on the right side to hide the fact that you're in here too.
additionalM:
Hints
You don't really want to be in this cage, but there were some things you didn't want to do today, so you hid. Luckily these flowers block the right side of the cage and hide you completely.
additionalR:
Hints
"N-no?" you respond. "Wrong! I hid all the time. There's nothing wrong with hiding, you're doing a great job." he says, and disappears.
readingMnemonic: As you hide the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?"

meaningMnemonic: You say something to a boot when you want to be humble. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more discreet.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself trying to be humble. You're down on the ground talking to a pair of boots. You don't dare raise your eyes past that.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine saying something to the King. Get low down on the ground to be as humble as you can. Whisper into the King's boots. Lick them if you have to.
readingMnemonic: You're being humble like this because those boots belong to the King (きん) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse!

meaningMnemonic: Flowers that you oversee are always indigo. You aren't sure why though...
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine if every flower you were supposed to oversee was indigo. Indigo everywhere!
additionalR:
Hints
Can you imagine having indigo-only seeing eyes? I can. Because of this awesome mnemonic.
readingMnemonic: Wait, maybe these flowers are only indigo because there is something wrong with your eyes (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see!

meaningMnemonic: Carve a tree into a bar and lay it sticking out into the water to make a jetty or a pier. Now you can walk out on the jetty and go further into the water without needing a boat or getting wet.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine laying your tree turned bar into the water to make your own jetty. Innovative!
additionalR:
Hints
Picture Santa-san coming in from the water on his speedboat and docking on your jetty to deliver presents to you.
readingMnemonic: You made this jetty so it would be easier for Santa-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, so he needs a jetty to give you presents, not a chimney anymore.

meaningMnemonic: Put a yakuza member in a prison on the sun and he'll become a martyr to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine all the yakuza coming out into the streets and holding up signs saying this guy was a martyr. A hero to all who do bad stuff in bad groups but don't wanna get caught.
additionalR:
Hints
Really, it's not the fault of the people who put him there that he's become a martyr. It's the month of June. PUNISH JUNE! PUT JUNE IN THE SUN PRISON! (Is what I assume those yakuza are shouting.)
readingMnemonic: The only reason he ended up a martyr in the first place is because they put him up there in June (じゅん). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer!

meaningMnemonic: In the dirt, you find a lid under the table. You lift it to reveal a deep pit. Why is there a hole under your table?
additionalM:
Hints
You pull away the lid and crawl inside. There is a ladder that takes you deep into the pit.
additionalR:
Hints
After you've nursed こういち back to health, he explains that he was put here by a clone こういち–the very same こういち who became emperor. He tells you he can think of around 61-70 different pain levels of revenge, but also that "it probably wouldn't be worth it, so let's just hang out for a while instead. Ooh, are those cookies?"
readingMnemonic: When you reach the bottom of the pit, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see こういち, starved and chained in a pit under your table.

meaningMnemonic: You're in a net but you have the ability to quit playing along and leave at any time.
additionalM:
Hints
Your captors think they have you trapped, but you know you can leave whenever you feel like it.
additionalR:
Hints
As the heat spreads you decide to leave. You hop out of the net and watch the shock spread in your captors eyes.
readingMnemonic: You don't know if you want to quit this charade until you feel an uncomfortable heat (ひ). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire.

meaningMnemonic: If the death of a woman occurs it's because she was being reckless. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture yourself watching the news about a woman's death. The word RECKLESS?! pops up on your screen and keeps flashing. Huh, she must have been, you think to yourself.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine what reckless thing that woman had to have done to die while mowing the lawn. Eww.
readingMnemonic: As you watch the news about this reckless woman you find out that she died from mowing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it.
