meaningMnemonic: The flowers that wash up on shore in tsunamis that we make into syrup is seaweed. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed.
additionalM:
Hints
Seaweed is the flower of the sea!
additionalR:
Hints
Feed your soul with seaweed and it will thank you. Promise! <3
readingMnemonic: Seaweed is true soul (そう) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul.

meaningMnemonic: Tsunami's have a certain tendency to secrete things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving.
additionalM:
Hints
Certain tsunami secretions are dangerous. Can you think of any?
additionalR:
Hints
The next time someone asks you what does a tsunami secrete? You'll say heat!
readingMnemonic: Most tsunami's secrete heat (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea.

meaningMnemonic: Use your mouth to sing and a shellfish to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a shamisen song just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine using your mouth to sing and a shell to play the shamisen to perform your shamisen song!
additionalR:
Hints
A shamisen song is a song, yay!
readingMnemonic: A shamisen song is just an 歌 (うた) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way!

meaningMnemonic: Half of a rice paddy is always on the shore. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right?
additionalM:
Hints
Picture a rice paddy. Half of it is trailing off into the shore. Hear the seagulls. Feel the ocean breeze!
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine laying on the shore with Han Solo. Enjoying a cool drink. Smelling the fragrance of the rice paddy behind you. Yeah, this is the life!
readingMnemonic: You decide to walk along this shore when you see Han (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lay on the shore with Han!!

meaningMnemonic: The leader squid tells all of its squid people to be thrifty.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the leader squid giving a speech about how you shouldn't buy new things, and how you should live with a roommate to save money. Every squid yen counts!
additionalR:
Hints
Ken's squid is always shaking his head at Ken the samurai's obsession with wearing all silk. He should visit Thrifty Threads, the second hand shop, and get some cotton clothes that would do the job just fine.
Hint: Whenever there's a squid, remember that Ken (けん) the samurai is nearby.
readingMnemonic: Who is a thrifty squid? Ken (けん) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent.

meaningMnemonic: You put your fingers in the coffin to tickle the beggar inside. What you're doing is a new form of torture.
additionalM:
Hints
First, you put them in a coffin to make them think they're going to die. Then you tickle them with your fingers. There is no greater psychological + physical torture than this.
additionalR:
Hints
He keeps screaming: "STOP THIS TICKLE TORTURE. I CAN'T TAKE IT JUST BURY ME."
readingMnemonic: The beggar you will coffin tickle torture is ごういち, a.k.a. Grandpa Koichi. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled.

meaningMnemonic: Give alcohol to a demon and you'll see how ugly it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face.
additionalM:
Hints
Picture the drunk demon as its pretty face drips off revealing the ugly crap piled underneath.
additionalR:
Hints
The demon drinking alcohol out of its nasty shoes is the ugliest scene you've ever seen.
readingMnemonic: The ugly demon is drunk and taking off his shoes (しゅう) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes.

meaningMnemonic: The tsunami swept away one of the cleats your husband just bought and creates an entire valley with it.
additionalM:
Hints
Watch as the tsunami rakes your husband's cleat across the mountain, carving a valley and an easier path for itself. Nature is brutal.
additionalR:
Hints
Imagine yourself eating cake with your husband in this newly formed valley. You both agree that this should be called Cake Valley!
readingMnemonic: When the water clears, you and your husband go to the valley to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of cake (けい)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut."

meaningMnemonic: When you see a tsunami coming courage wells up inside you and you gain the power to save everyone you meet before they get washed away! Feel that courage boil and spread throughout all your limbs. You feel like you have super strength. This tsunami isn't going to hurt anyone while you're alive to stop it!
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine what it feels like to have courage well up inside you. Courage in the face of certain death!
additionalR:
Hints
Who wells up with courage? You do!
readingMnemonic: Who does that courage well up inside? You (ゆう)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero!

meaningMnemonic: Under your own roof, a geoduck jumps out of the ground with a sword and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a widow.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine the geoduck laughing and screaming, "Now you're a widow! Now you're a widow!" flailing the sword around. It's awful.
additionalR:
Hints
It's just you and your car now, living the widow life, driving on into the sunset and forgetting your past.
readingMnemonic: You may be a widow, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your car (か), and run your entire house and the geoduck over.

meaningMnemonic: You're walking in a greenhouse when you see a small drop of water fall and it makes you yearn for the person you adore. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing.
additionalM:
Hints
Imagine how it feels to yearn for someone else when you see the small water drop. Imagine how your heart feels.
additionalR:
Hints
Now you yearn for being somewhere Bobo is not.
readingMnemonic: As you yearn for that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... Bobo (ぼ) the clown?! Uhg. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water.
